Pros: Working From Home and not a hassle to take vacation time.
Cons: Non existent managers, shady business practices, no growth, micromanaging, lying to customers. IBM OFTEN had non USA employees working on client accounts that per their contracts stated they only wanted USA based employees to work on. IBM also took the CHEAP route and at least for my team, stopped hiring USA workers. When I was there, I was the LAST USA worker to be hired, for years after my manager only hired NON USA workers when the need was for USA workers based on the client contracts. In the YEARS I worked there in the office, I NEVER saw or met my manager, only heard his voice on the phone. He never visited our office and was out of touch with the realities of what we dealt with. In addition, the workload became so much and the micromanaging so bad that within a year, at least 5 people left our team. Also, the company employs derailing tactics. One of my team members applied to another job within the company, it was going well and he landed the job. Our manager talked to that position's manager and ended up getting my team member removed from moving into that position. Our manager then lied to this team member telling him he would give him a promotion and a raise...yes he got the promotion in title only which included the workload, but NOT the raise in pay. I honestly don't know how IBM (at least the security side) still functions, maybe because of their name and history? It definitely can't be from the terrible time I and many others experienced.

Pros: I worked at IBM for 3 a year now and I have to say it's been a great experience. The management team is very supportive and always willing to listen to new ideas. The company culture is very collaborative and everyone is always willing to help each other out. One of the things I really appreciate about working at IBMis the flexibility they offer. As long as I get my work done, I can choose my own schedule, which has greatly benefited me. The only downside is that the pay could be a little higher, but overall I'm very happy with my job and the company.
Cons: The only downside is that the pay could be a little higher, but overall I'm very happy with my job and the company.

Pros: If you have a Master’s Degree, know that this will equate to $10K above the normal base pay scale for that position. They also offer financial assistance toward earning your Master’s , and used to give a $10K raise upon completion. Not sure the policy now, but be sure to ask. Also know your stats if you are a woman/minority with a Master’s degree. Use that info to negotiate an extra $5K on your base salary. Don’t forget to also negotiate your starting bonus and your PTO. Good luck!!
Cons: Old ideology. Good ol’ boys club. Used to be very little racial diversity (other than Asian and Indian) and hardly any women. Hope that has changed.

Pros: The company is forward-thinking, understanding they need to advance as technology advances. The company has solid benefits and incentivizes healthy living. There are many leaders who want to see the next generation succeed and are happy to help them grow in the company.

The company is so large that there are not enough consultant roles for the amount of consultants. As a result it can be very competitive to find a new project when a current project is ending.

Pros: Now I come from an agency environment, so it wouldn't be too difficult to beat my prior working experience. That being said, I am consistently impressed with IBM for the following reasons: 1. Autonomy: IBM managers do not hover over you and micromanage your performance. We instead depend on a lot of internal tools to get and give feedback on performance. Communication with our clients and managers is largely left up to us (with guidance), and the feedback from our managers is what is tantamount in our reviews. 2. Work load balance: gone are the days where I have too many reqs to handle. And because I'm assigned to a particular skill set within a business unit, I am able to hone in on my talent pool and also dig in deep to a skill set to get to know. I'm also able to move around, so the skill sets I am exposed to gets broader and deeper the longer I'm here. 3. Education access: IBMers tend to stick around because of the ability to learn entirely new skills through the robust and large internal education program. If your dream is to do something other than your job down the road, there's plenty of opportunity to learn brand-new skills--even learning to code! It's really up to you as an individual to choose your path within IBM.
Cons: 1. The lack of bonuses year over year is a killer when trying to recruit candidates from outside IBM. Even with our best year yet for our shareholders, we will not be seeing competitive bonus incentives. 2. Return to office push: can we please just give up on this? I understand that it is a huge change due to real estate that is owned, but employee retention and satisfaction is much higher when we allow folks to work from home. The pressure to return to office is also much higher on the softer ("easier to replace") skill sets, so this pressure is leveraged against your lower banded positions, where higher banded and more niche skills get much more leeway. 3. Compensation ratings for some cities are just wrong. Austin should not be at a "national" market level, given our rising cost of living pushing many employees out of the city center. Although leadership may be paid to live in the city center, your professional banded positions are not paying enough to be able to live close to the office, or to purchase property within the city.

Pros: People: My team is mind-bogglingly nice and accepting. Your teammates will accept you, encourage you, and teach you to help you get to where you need to be. (Note this varies from team-to-team, but in general the design studio is filled with very nice people) Work-life balance: You will not be assigned more than 40 hours of work a week. It won't even come close, usually. Last year we had a roadmap that was supposed to be "substantial work" and my team finished the entire year in four months. Remote work: I've been able to work from anywhere in the world. Paris, Korea, Canada, and all over the US. Countries are coming out with "Digital nomad" visas, where you can extend your stay for a few years, and if you've ever wanted to live abroad while on an American salary, IBM might be the best company to let you to do so. Agency: you'll be trusted with pretty important stuff, and it's not uncommon for one designer to be in charge of an entire product. There are a lot of them at IBM. If you are a really good designer, you'll get a few chances to shine. Stability: I can't imagine anyone at IBM getting laid off, even after our last round of layoffs when the new CEO stepped in and wanted to make a big splash (had nothing to do with the company's performance), and even in this economy where every other tech company is doing layoffs.
Cons: Low compensation: below market, with shoddy-to-no benefits. However, given the amount of work you have to do I honestly think the pay is fair. Company brand / image: most companies understand that IBM requires a low amount of work and will put a discount on your years of experience. I've seen a few good designers move to other companies and get down-leveled. They're good designers though, so they get promoted back up pretty fast. Low chance of product success: Again, there are a lot of products at IBM. The strategy is kind of to have a small hand in every area of the market, and that means that a lot of the experiments will fail. Many products require heavy investment, but IBM doesn't like taking risks. Of course, that means they're a very steady company, and in this economy maybe that's also a good thing. Low volume of work: For designers, this means it'll be tough to find good feature work / things in general to write case studies on. When it comes to in-house design work a lot of things will already start to blend together, but when you don't have a lot of things to do to begin with... it's tough. If you end up at IBM early-career my advice is don't cruise, take initiative.

Pros: The best reason to work for IBM is the people.  Generally, within my organization, the technical team is first rate and highly skilled.  If you're lucky to work for a manager who is technically competent and a manager who can convey your accomplishments to the rest of the organization you'll do fine.  Pay is average as are general benefits.  Pretty much all I want to say, so I'll run out the clock here.  q w e r t y u i o p a s d f g h j k l z x c v b n m q
Cons:
Management lies, and as a first line manager, I know ... Indeed my management chain requires me to lie to my team:  people I trust and respect.  Lies and  misrepresentation are the IBM family values, particularly for personnel issues and also for business metrics.  That is the biggest downside - you never know when you're getting the straight story.  For example, the PBC system is a ranking system.  A first line manager is told what their "skew" has to be - the company advertises that a first line manager can use their own judgment for differentiation between team members, subject to some oversight to ensure equity.  In actual fact managers are told what to do and are required to lie to their team members so that the executives can make their metrics.  

There are many other examples - and I see them every day - it always comes down to managing the metrics, rather than the results.

Pros: Sadly, I watched the company change. It was a great place to work when I was hired in 2004. It was employee focused, there was a focus on the "IBM family" and my colleagues were truly like members of my family. Early in my career, when there were true leaders, there were plenty career growth opportunities. Leadership even approached you with new and challenging opportunities. In addition, there were true advocates and sponsors, supporting you and your development. With programs being cut (Corporate Service Corps, US Open, NY Rangers, Yankees ticket promotions, BlueThanks recognition gifts), benefits were reduced to almost nothing (401K match dropped from 6% to 5%) and you had to count your blessings if you survived the last rounds of RAs (which they still do regardless of what the CEO says in the press).
Cons: Hostile reorganization missions are used to end people's careers. For example, if you weren't part of the Marketing & Communications click, you were never accepted as part of the team. I was part of the MCC for two years and never felt welcome. I had an interim manager who was my peer on a Friday and became my "acting manager" on a Monday. Her main goal was to find ways I wasn't meeting job role standards, even making up value adds that were never discussed or part of agreed-upon SOWs. I was gaslit for over four months and was placed on a Performance Improvement Plan, where I was NEVER going to meet management's expectations due to the demands for course correction nearly every day. An example of "valuable feedback" from my manager was that she reviewed the same sentence for over 30 minutes and asked nonsense questions, as she gaslit me in every conversation. If you wanted my "seat, " why weren't you transparent and let me find a different role? Instead, my leadership attacked and tortured me. I LOVED the Friday at 5 pm responses - in which three managers conspired to ensure I never met their milestones, generating hours of work over the weekend, in attempt to save my career. YES - I actually did the work while on the PIP. Looking back, I should have done nothing.

Pros:
-The designers, PM's, Managers and Front-End Devs are very smart and very welcoming
-Beautiful studio
-Great healthcare (I have the best plan with only $350 deductible)
-Great work/life balance (varies from team to team)
Cons:
-High turn over

-The pay. I found out with 10+ years of experience I get paid 20K more than a college grad. I got a bonus last year ($1500) and none this year. Pay raise of 5% which wasn't bad as a general statistic but terrible when you look at my base pay. IBM is investing in college grads by trying to pay them more... news flash they leave anyway and then so do your Senior/Lead designers because you pay them an embarrassing amount. You blew your wad on the new shiny toy out of college that bailed 1 year later. Congrats.

-The back end devs are determined to kill the world of good design. We cannot make a wonderful experience and have it be implemented in a reasonable amount of time. By "reasonable" I mean small CSS changes take 2 months and CRITICAL features to help us even half way compete with competitors like AWS take a year. It's filled with old dinosaurs developers who think that they can design and we are just worthless people that wear skinny pants.

-Offering Management (OM) is mostly useless. I have met one or two that were amazing at their job, the rest cannot understand what their job actually is. They are not art directors and they are supposed to deliver to us the main goal of what the design is supposed to be based on actual market research. Most of them have zero clue what actual market research is or what is valid.

Pros: I was paid fairly, and in the olden days (say before 1997) allowed a lot of leeway toward education and professional enrichment.  Salary, bonuses, and even awards were more than fairly given in my case.  The experience I had at IBM really launched my professional career, most of my experience before was in unrelated fields.
Cons:
Over time, management becomes more "metrics driven" - which is to say, short sighted.  Oh how many things we did twice because they weren't realistic about the scope of the work, or how it fit strategically.  Perhaps that's because much of the "boots on the ground" management has no idea what their underlings do.  Also, those awards and bonuses seem pretty arbitrary when you look at the big picture, seems if your own management isn't strong, your dept will never get their share - no matter how hard they work. 

In the end, they'll either sell your division, move your job to India or China, or just plain lay you off.  Everybody I know still in "the company" is watching their backs, just waiting for the axe to fall.

Pros:
1) Scope of company means you can do many things - lots of opportunity to learn new skills, if you're willing to relocate and learn. 
2) Interesting work and a variety of people and cultures
3) Good benefits
4) Cutting-edge technology
Cons:
1) Direction at the top of the company is poor. Not much confidence in the top execs. 
2) Too much focus on cost-side of the equation, a result of poor revenues for many quarters.
3) Shoemakers children with technology for employees - i.e., 4-year cycle for laptop replacement, not a lot of internal Mac support, poor local support for IT issues.
4) Push for 'co-location' after years of allowing work-at-home means many people are commuting long distances to a few sites to keep their jobs.

Pros: - Deeply Inclusive and Ethical culture! I am allowed to wear my goth getup to the office, we had a coworker start gender transition and someone from HR held a meeting with us to go over how to support our coworker during their transition and avoid any awkward conversations. LOVE IT! - My bosses definitely ask for their bottom lines, but we are encouraged to keep a healthy mental state. My due dates have been pushed without argument if I was having a hard time with my depression. - Lots of vacation days, designated holidays, and sick leave. No overtime to PTO options for my position. Life and health insurance is run of the mill, retirement is nice and we have an option to discuss our retirement investments with a financial management team quarterly for FREE. Daycare assistance, adoption assistance, and wonderful education assistance. - There are documents available to show you just what you need to do for raises, bonuses, and promotions. There is a small amount left to discretion, but you will always have proof to argue your worth. You have the opportunity to switch jobs internally and move from location to location (over years, of course. Not months.) This company is full of opportunity and awesome folks.
Cons: - Time zones. You will work on flex time, working a certain amount of hours a week, with whoever you are assigned to work with. Some mornings you will have meetings with offshore teams at 3am, and sometimes you will coordinate deployments at midnight on a Friday. There is usually ample warning, and these terms are kinda negotiable. I have gotten used to quick naps when needed. - Onboarding feels a little silly and lonely. You will be given a LOT of information and then left ALONE for 2 months while you slowly undergo endless onboarding training in addition to your position. I asked for a lot of help, and only got a little. I now mentor folks to try and help alleviate that, but it's rough across most cases.

Pros: The company is very career-centric. This a pro because they will work very hard to make sure you fit into their ecosystem. They will move you around within the company until you find a spot that suits you. They also provide quite good health and retirement plans. There is immanent room for growth and promotion. It is possible to spend an entire life climbing the IBM corporate ladder (and some people obviously do). Additionally, IBM has one of the best learning/training programs I have ever come across. Top industry professionals develop what essentially amount to college-level courses. These courses (available on an enormous range of topics) are available to all employees (though some do require management approval). A self-motivated individual would undoubtedly find IBM to be one of the best places to learn and grow.
Cons: The company is very career-centric. This a con because everybody is old. Because IBM is so good at retaining it's employees, departments seem to become very top-heavy (lots of senior employees but relatively few junior employees). This "oldness" is especially apparent within the software group where management seems to be clinging to old-school development practices. Do NOT expect a modern culture like at Google. As a dev we have zero perks. There is no free coffee. The walls are barren. There is no food in the building. The entire experience feels sterile and dated.

Pros: IBM is a great company as a whole. That's the main reason I've stayed for over a year after being hired as an intern. I have gotten some great projects and exposure right out of college. There's also an insane amount of free internal learning and it is highly encouraged and mandatory in some cases to learn new things on the job. Work-life balance is great. I can work from home many days. The benefits are excellent. I have amazing doctors and the actual insurance companies offer many extra resources to IBM employees. 401k matching is also very ideal, I've saved quite a bit in a very short amount of time. There are also other nice perks like being a preferred employer at apartment complexes where I lived. Overall, you're covered if you're at IBM and in truth, they prepare you for a career in- or outside of the company. All of their certifications are transferable skills.
Cons: I still don't have an official title since my projects are all over the place. Unfortunately as an intern hire, I didn't have the flexibility to negotiate my salary or have a say in what position I wanted to be in. As a result, I am extremely underpaid. Pros:
IBM has that aura of being a great place to work.  The near collapse of the company during the 1980's tarnished that image, and experience folks understand the realities of both the luster and the rust.  

In a company of 300,000 I would be foolish to try and depict the overall company "image", however with more than seven years of experience in the software sales segment of the business I saw some general (negitive) trends.

In order to reduce operating costs a large percentage of the employees work from home.  Many teams are comprised of staff  scattered around the globe, which makes building work relationship more difficult.  Conversely this structure provides a lot of schedule flexibility.
Cons:
In looking at any position within IBM one must evaluate whether the position has requirements to exist where ever you are located.  Ongoing cost cutting efforts may well eliminate your position or ship the position offshore (in the long term).  
There are annual efforts to reduce the bottom n% (5-15%) of low performers acrosss the company.  If you are in a team of superstars, the team will loose their assigned percentage - regardless of the impact.
In order to achieve continued growth, the company buys a lot of smaller companies.  If you are working in an area of the business that has been enhanced throough a purchase, you risk being cast aside once the new venture comes on-line.

Pros:
- In the past there has been a liberal work from home policy. I'm not sure how much longer that will last. 
- The company 401k matching contribution is good and is fully vested from the start.
Cons:
- Multiple (one or more) layoffs per year every year I was at the company (almost 10 years). 
- Terrible or none existent bonuses. 
- Management mostly concerned with how to preserve and progress their careers and has little interest in progressing staff careers. 
- Software engineering organization driven by rigid sales motivated deadlines with little consideration for sound software development practices.  This creates substandard software services that are unmaintainable. But Sales doesn't care and engineering management team is too afraid to push back. 
- Bluemix IS an awful mess and any product or service that has to integrate with it WILL be made worse by having to integrate and adhere to the terrible bureaucracy that exists within it.

Pros: The Work/Life Balance is usually pretty good.  Our prescription plan is excellent.  When you find the right area to work in, you can have a really good time at work every day and be proud of what you have accomplished.  I hear a lot of people from different divisions say that they have GREAT people to work with.  People respect you as an IBMer and know that you aren't going to mislead them.  There are generations of trust behind you.  Generally speaking, first line managers are pretty good and are kind of in the same boat as regular employees.
Cons: Our performance rating system is a ridiculous leftover from when IBM needed to cut the fat.  The fat is all gone, believe me!  In general, this is a hard time for engineers at any company.  At IBM, bonuses and raises are often pretty bad, even when the company does well.... even when you get promoted.   When people leave the company, it's rare to back fill their position.  In our area, we sometimes don't even back fill with an offshore job.

Pros: Solid benefits, good internal training (provided your your manager can afford it), varied career paths, employee discounts on business-partner goods and services, very good work-life flexibility, knowledgeable coworkers.
Cons:
This is not the same company it was five years ago. Poor compensation, questionable job security (especially long-term), and an ever-diminishing sense of community contribute to a massive morale epidemic. Gone are the days of pot-lucks and office pools. Now are the days of over-the-phone performance evaluation with a manager you know only by name, and "virtual teaming" with people you will never in your life meet face to face.

While the IBM name looks great on a resume, non-managerial skills are crippling. Ten years of IBM middleware technical experience gives you terrific qualifications. To work for IBM.

Financial raise and bonus pools have dried up in recent years despite recent profit gains.

US-based hires are few and very far between. College recruiting is a memory.

Global resources, while just as pleasant and able as domestic resources, can be stifling at a professional level. The length of conference calls depends entirely on the moderator's ability to wade through accents. Emails and SameTime messages arrive in a variety of languages.

Far more middle management, mandatory training, and conference calls than is efficient.

Pros:
- Strong focus on innovation and working to truly improve the planet
- Kind and intelligent coworkers who really care
- Consulting by Degrees (CbD) has great training and opportunities to connect with other consultants who are also right out of school
- Great benefits and salary
Cons:
- Public Sector contracts are currently in testing and quality assurance even if you're in Business Analytics and Strategy.  I was put in a position where I was supposed to have at least a BS in Computer Science or Engineering.
- Huge mismatch between employee's skills and project placement.  The emphasis is putting lower bands who are cheap labor onto projects that need bodies asap.
- Horrible experience working at the USPS and was required to be on the project for a minimum of a year and most likely two years.  Worked 6 days a week including Sunday mornings on client site at 4am.
- Inability to move from project to project.  I had almost 10 IBMers leave the company during my 9 months on my project because movement to another project was so impossible, and I did the same.
- So many young consultants are having issues with their projects that it is falling on deaf ears.  The managers and upper management are overwhelmed and don't listen and are surprised that young consultants are leaving.

Pros:
There are boundless opportunities and it is one of few companies where the sky might be the limit. 
There is a real commitment to work life balance and the company provides opportunities for volunteering.
Cons:
This is one place where one person holds their career in your hands. If the manager does not like you, your career is pretty much over. 
There is a constant fear of being RA'd (IBM's term for laid off). 
The relative contribution metric pretty much assures that you will in fact not share your accomplishments with the team. Instead of making the slice of cheese larger, an increasing amount of people compete for a smaller slice of cheese while the executive ranks get the big bonuses.

Pros:
- The work-life balance is good
- Gain experience working with big customers with complex systems
- Good people work there
Cons:
- They had layoffs almost every year during my many years with them. People that were toxic would be left around as a buffer for the next layoff and great people would leave after a layoff so they're not next. 
- So many layers of management and bureaucracy. Upper management were often out of touch and developers often felt underappreciated or powerless. 
- Almost never got bonuses and when we did, it was so small I was embarrassed to mention it to friends that worked at other places. There were hardly any incentive to do exceptional or give my all when it'll often go unappreciated. 
- No longer an innovative company for many reasons - one reason being that the innovation often comes because someone wants a promotion not because they're solving a great need in the industry. There is so much process and bureaucracy, there is hardly any inspiration for innovation. There is also little incentive to try something new because you know there will be no reward for it (no bonuses) and it'll be met with so much resistance and process, it's just not worth fighting. There is no space to try anything new in the midst of all the process, bureaucracy, resistance, daily grind (paperwork, training, support, etc) and the business definitely didn't facilitate innovation or make it easy/attractive.

Sadly, most all decisions are made by Finance which has too much control over client relationships because they do not understand how to support Sales and Technical teams to support clients. Management/Finance will drive out expensive/experienced people, to replace them with affordable/inexperienced people, including zero IT experience, no Computer Science degree, no white collar experience, in a technology company. Why? Because IBM overpaid $38B for Redhat and thus, cuts are everywhere, no one is safe. Deep cuts in product support, product development, relationships, technical expertise, and thus, a lack of resources to do the right thing for clients. As a Sales person, if you care about relationships, you could spend months with. your client on a product escalations, because there is just a lack of people and skills everywhere. You join the product support escalations not because its your job, but because your employer isn't treating your client well, and someone needs to heal the relationship, but there is no help available. Very sad, I don't recommend it.

Pros: IBM is a place that truly values career development and learning. There's great work/life balance. All managers & coworkers are supportive of exploring career options in the company and helping you reach your goals. You'll learn a lot and it's a great place to start a career. As an entry level employee, I had access to senior level executives and am forever appreciative of what I learned from those experiences. The people who work here are smart, friendly and patient in teaching you new things to watch you grow. I'm grateful for all the people I worked with and had as mentors at IBM and will be rooting from afar. IBM is also a company that truly values D&I and deploying tech for good (although there's always room for improvement!).
Cons:
Compensation could be improved, compared to others in the industry. Notoriously overly complex internal structure and very bureaucratic. IBM is also undergoing extensive internal transformation (as it should) to get back to sustainable growth. I have faith in leaders like Arvind and Rob Thomas, but there has been so much change, it's hard to execute on strategy when things are changing every 6 months. 

Most notably, the newest CMO doesn't know what she's doing. No clarity on how to execute on new strategy. Absolute mess. Everyone is leaving left and right due to low morale and no direction from senior leadership. She's got to go.

Pros: There are a number of reasons why IBM can be a great fit for you. Most importantly, the company encourages a healthy work/life balance. Time off is abundant, and the hours are not rigorous. In addition the company treats many employees as "mobile" workers -- working from home or working out of an office as needed. Also, since the company is so large, there are a number of perks and benefits. So, if you are interested in a relaxed work-environment and lots of flexibility, this is a great option. Also, the IBM name on a resume is a great asset.
Cons: IBM does have some challenges, and is not an optimal choice for all. Since the "mobile employee" concept is enforced for many groups, it becomes challenging to develop a sense of teamwork or camaraderie. There notion of the office "water cooler" is non-existent. One might argue that such "off the record" interaction does not necessarily contribute to productivity -- the issue is that inter-personal, informal interaction is limited. The other challenge is one that many large companies will face -- different groups are often incentivized in different manners. It is not uncommon to have internal groups encouraged (and rewarded) to operate along divergent paths. Lastly, you will come across an arrogance at IBM -- that "Big Blue" is infallible.

Pros:
For a majority of time I was there, I worked for one product line.  Some areas of the company have good local managers / leadership, which helps to provide a good working atmosphere where an employee can feel fulfilled with their contributions.

Salary seems to be a little better than average.
Cons:
IBM is currently undergoing a complete transformation of it's business and business it deems 'not in its core' are being dismantled, with little regard to the intelligent resources that it affects.

Outwardly, IBM states that it invests in its employees and will allow them to move from between divisions / products, but in reality it provides little support to those attempting to get education to keep up-to-date technically or professionally (tuition support is touted but seldom is provided). 

Severance of those "let go" is now down to 4 weeks maximum.  Employees who are newly hired are given a 2 year grace period which keeps them from being included in job actions, but after that they can be targeted.

401k matching is only done on a yearly basis, so if you leave the company during the year there is no compensation.

Raises are minimal and depend on the area of the organization you work - personally I had received no raises for 5 years, although my performance reviews were between exceptional and acceptable all 5 years.

IBM is in the process of attempting to collocate resources into key offices with little to no ability to work remotely.  This has also affected work-life balance within the company.

Pros:
Training is good and there is a lot of resources for continued education.
The work load is balanced, and management should be receptive to a desire to do more for DC Operations.
Being a fulltime IBM employee you will receive the standard employee benefits (PTO, 401k, health/dental/vision).
Cons:
Career growth is limited by how much of a priority you are to your manager. Communication is difficult and often obscured when trying to develop internally within IBM. Perhaps due to Data Center Operations being physically separate (and sometimes temporally) from other teams, and IBM Cloud being a separate "child company" acquired and in a continuous state of integration into IBM.
Based on the last couple years, full-time hires are decreasing in favor of contract workers without benefits. IBM should offer full-time employment on completion of training, but this could also change.
New hires are usually stuck on evening or night shift once training has progressed enough (1-2 months), moving off this will again depend on how well you communicate with management, or it may get you moved to a different DC site.
You are responsible for the office environment and equipment maintenance. If you and your coworkers don't stay on top of it, expect tools to degrade. You will have to be your own IT, while also dealing with IBM remote help desk (my experiences with them have been poor, regardless of the time of day I called in).

Pros: Great people and team work
Cons: New employees are brought in at higher pay structure than existing employees that are currently working the same job. No opportunities for existing employees to be moved to the higher pay categories. Great place to start a career. Definitely not a long term employment option if you are looking for competitive and fair pay.

I was loyal to company and remained in same position because they didn't have anyone else to support application and thought I was helping out.  All it really did was hurt me in the end.  When I was not allowed to move to another position or get training to complete certification I should have started looking for a job outside the company.  Laid off after 10+ years.  They were offshoring many jobs to BRIC countries..   Initially very upset with company but would go back to them with different mindset and this time use them for my own personal development and advancement.

Pros: I feel the company is pretty good with the work life balance.  Because the company is very advance some are even allowed to work remotely.  As an engineer supporting the manufacturing line you could essentially do a good portion of your job from home.  The company also provides good benefits at least compared to the other companies I have looked at which is really only two other companies.  They also have other little perks like different corporate discounts and rewards for great achievements (eventhough I hear they are not as good as they used to be).  I did enjoy most of the people are work with.  There are a good number of helpful people with in the company
Cons: It seems there is a lot of backwards thinking in IBM and not just within some divisions.  It seems to be company wide.  It seems like changes always loop back around someone.  The high level managers think they have an understanding of what happens at the lowest level but don't.  There always seems to be a different panic attack each day so it can get stressful at times.  Pick your day and you have some serious issue going on.  The meetings are endless and often pointless.  The meetings always make it seems like it's deja vu.  There is more time spent talking about the problem than actually going to correct it.

Pros: IBM is in the cutting edge of rolling out technology solutions to meet business challenges.  Whatever IBM comes out with like eBusiness, Information on Demand, Websphere, etc. is copied by the competition, but IBM is always ahead of the game.  The level of technical competence is high in the right pockets, which ensures that they could always execute with the right people on the team as members or SMEs.
Cons: There is an incredible amount of overhead between the people who do the work and the level of associate partners, partners, regional managers, practice leads, practice managers, industry leads, industry VPs, competency VP, etc in the Services area.  I would generate about $385,000-$555,000 every year in consulting revenue for the company, but my bonuses and raises were a joke for the kind of contribution I made to the company.  The overhead in Services must be addressed.

Pros: The people I work with are really smart. Great for the resume, as IBM is a pretty well respected company. My coworkers have left for great tech companies and top 5 business schools. Good benefits (but getting worse).
Cons: Hard to get recognition for good work. You're only as good as your PBC rating (IBM's end of year rating system), which can get pretty political and bureaucratic. Management is out of touch with employees and how they feel about the company. People at my level are VERY negative about IBM. Lots of turnover. In Public Sector you can get stuck on a project forever (I've been on the same one for my entire time at IBM and would have to burn a lot of bridges to get off of it, if I even could). 401K matching once a year is bad for employees. Do not feel connected to company as a whole. Management is out of touch with how employees feel about the company. Hard to motivate for IBM's success when the company doesn't give bonuses or raises for people who are supposedly performing well. After almost two years here, and performing very well according to all of my evaluations, I am actually making LESS money than when I started when you consider inflation and the fact that company healthcare costs have gone up.

Pros:
IBM is so big that the Pros/Cons depend somewhat on what group you are working in.

Where I work all my coworkers were good, hardworking people willing to help out. There is a good work life balance, lots of vacation days, sick leave, and flexible hours. Medical, Dental, and Health insurance.
Cons:
Management has very poor communication with its employees. My direct manager goes months without checking in on my to see how things are going. Emails from upper management are full of near meaningless business jargon such as "Creating a playbook to sharpen your digital edge".

The business model in my group requires employees to find projects on their own. IBM does provide a tool for finding projects but often times that tool call doesn't list all the projects or lists incorrect information about the project. Often times, projects are found through less formal methods such as word of mouth.

Pay is atrocious. Far below the industry average.

Email spam. Various people from around the company send you emails about projects and events that are not relevant to you at all. It got so bad I had to create a junk mail folder.

Pros:
- Diverse opportunities.
- Many locations to work in.
- Lots of in-house technology available to pick from.
- Some skilled individuals to work with.
- The company will take care of its employees. In cases of natural disasters they are on top of things and ready to help. There is near 0 chance of discrimination of any kind, this is not something that IBM messes around with.
- Many experts available to consult in just about any area of technology, and business.
-
Cons:
- Poor technical leadership, too many promotions to higher level technical positions that are based on politics, friendships, side-deals, and based on upper management perceived "success". Many high level technical folks manage up and are disconnected with the folks under them providing no real technical leadership for the ones doing the real work.
- Too much focus on dates, time-to-market. This trumps quality of the products, solutions, and services. BAD. The company is very large, so this tends to be driven by the culture established by the executives responsible for the various areas.
- Many in management think a head count is a head count, they don't understand skill levels.

Pros:
* Opportunities to expand knowledge and skills in leading edge technologies
* Promotes imaginative and innovative thinking
* Flexible work schedule
* Variety of family hr programs
Cons:
* IBM's top priority is MONEY - at the cost of their employees - IBM has turned cheap on it's employees
* Classroom Education has essentially demolished - most all classes are on-line self-study and are very limited in selection and MANY of those require management approval. If you are a programmer and want to take a class at a community college to enhance your skills that directly apply to your current position - the cost is yours! Even tuition as low as $125!
* Employee health benefits have greatly reduced - large deductibles and co-pays with limited in-network selection; Randy McDonald warned RTP, NC employees that if Obama was elected, IBMers would pay the price...AND WE HAVE!
* Business travel has greatly reduced - educational conferences, even for top performers, are unheard of.
* Coffee/tea anyone? That will cost you the SAME price as Starbucks...$1.60 and more...NO KIDDING! NOTHING IS FREE anymore! Cafeteria food quality has gone down and their prices are more than outside the IBM facilities!
* So as to save money in utilities, office supplies and workspace, IBM encourages work from home, thus, reducing team spirit and production.
* Salary and Raises? They are getting more and more skimpy and give team members identical excuses, regardless of performance.
* IBM should stand for INDIAN BUSINESS MACHINES. Outsourcing to India is huge and hurting so many IBM US employees. Job stability is threatened with outsourcing.

Pros:
- Watson has an excellent design team and I appreciate the recent focus on design.
- My teammates are motivated, have a good work-life balance, and are fun to be around.
- They tried very hard to make the intern program fun and to bring us together socially. There were intern presentations, Main Event night, boat on Lake Austin.
- Pay was very good.
Cons:
- Required to use internal dev tools like BlueMix that lower our productivity because they always crash.
- As an intern I came to the office every day but most workers at IBM "work from home" very often. I've heard that it's even worse outside of Watson.
- Pay arrived late, especially the promised Lump Sum Travel Reimbursement, which arrived 2 months after I had arrived.
- Senior management seems disconnected from reality on the ground. For example, there was a two-day intern finale event. They decided that the interns would spend paid work hours bagging rice for charity (which I think could be a great idea). They set a goal for 10,000 rice packets and we didn't pack that many during the scheduled events. The organizers were supposed to help with the whole process, but they didn't seem to care once the Instagram pictures were taken. So the rep from the charity was basically abandoned to pack the last 1,000 and pack it onto a truck.
- Lots of "not my problem" attitude about cleaning up common areas, sharing training data, etc. Most people are just concerned with their individual team.

Pros: IBM is still a great name to have on your resume. They do some pretty cool projects, and you learn to work hard at IBM. For some people, things turn out really well at IBM if they get the right first project.
Cons: Projects are chronically understaffed. It's hard to get a good assignment. It seems the best work is hand-picked for certain people. YMMV, but the company is not interested in developing you. They will keep you in the same assignment for a long time, and make it very hard to transfer. In my case, I did a stint as a Support person. I then applied to a Development proper position (which I had done previously). I started out doing Development, but in less than 2 months, Support duties were added to my job, and then my job became that almost 100%. After years at that job working hard, I transferred to a new job, and I noticed that once again, I wasn't allowed to go to a Development proper position, they wanted me to do same job again!!!  Even though there was plenty of Development work to do on my new team, they would rather keep the project understaffed and behind schedule, than to hire one more ready and willing developer to help out, and go out of their way to keep me in a position I no longer wanted to perform.

Pros: Large, stable company, solid benefits packages, numerous locations and in some positions, there is opportunity to learn marketable skills.
Cons: Pay was terrible, management and project management was dismal with a complete lack of communication. Almost no direction was given when onboarding and employees were left to figure it all out on their own. No pay increases and the overall business plan seemed to be most interested in moving all American and UK jobs to India to cut costs.

Pros: Good place to get your start and learn about technology.   You will get to understand the dynamics of different business models(i.e. SaaS/PaaS/Hardware/On-Prem Software) and learn about new technologies (i.e. blockchain, AI, Quantum).   Option to work from home which lets you avoid the commute.
Cons: Compensation is below market; my base pay was comparable to average pay according to Glassdoor but the bonus was basically non-existent.  I literally got ~$700 after tax for the bonus!   Many underfunded products/projects and long lead times to get things done lead to subpar products that aren't competitive.  No ability to retain good talent; see good people who can leave defect to other tech companies (i.e. Google, Microsoft, Salesforce, Startups, etc.) all the time.  Lack of opportunity to grow in the company.  Since IBM is shrinking, there are almost no attractive opportunities to switch roles and get promoted.   IBM is getting it's butt kicked by Google, Amazon, and Microsoft in IaaS/SaaS/PaaS and AI and it is unlikely IBM will be able to reverse this market trend anytime soon.  Senior Management is too secure in their positions.  IBM has underperformed vs. peers for a decade yet most of the Senior Management team have retained their positions.

Pros: Looks good on your resume when you find an employer that wants to keep you long term.     Positions in IBM customer facing roles build skills that will greatly benefit you in your next job, and you may learn how to recognize employers that you do not want to consider in the future.  IBM still has excellent products and these are worthwhile assets in your kit for future employment, especially if you are technical, and for pre-sales technical roles they still provide time to get and keep those technical skills.   You still get to work with some of the finest people in the IT industry, though they do not tend tend to stay long any more once they understand the way IBM views them and their compensation.
Cons: Lower pay than other companies, benefits in a death spiral and management lack of respect for the employee.   Compensation growth is non-existent, in fact likely to be negative regardless of your performance.  If you are not in a customer facing role your job is most probably going to a low cost country, though it may not happen quickly (IBM is accomplishing this slowly so it does not attract too much media attention).   A mobile workforce, as IBM has, often means working alone without support, and without adequate tools.   IBM expense and infrastructure policies mean spending hours a week accounting for travel and activity, which if you have service level agreements must be done on your own time.

Pros:
The IBM brand is a valuable addition to your resume and the access to large Fortune 500 clients with visible projects is unparalleled.  

The access to leading edge technology in some ways is nice.  

There is usually a greater autonomy and less dependence on partners as a young consultant.

The people are a good mix of smart technology and business people who are driven but generally approachable compared to Deloitte (Jerks) and Accenture (Engineering Nerds).
Cons:
IBM is not disorganized but there is no way it can be considered organized.  

The performance review and promotion system is one of the most bureaucratic, time consuming, non-value added and just annoying around.  Unclear expectations for moving to the next levels; levels spaced very very far apart.  A round down system that lowers your performance to your worst review which penalizes you for doing just ok on a first project which you are then penalized for one to two years depending on when you come in during the cycle.

Many managers are not helpful in developing you, encouraging you, or even answering e-mails.  There is high turnover for consultants here; they chalk this up to the nature of the industry.  That may be true but many leave because there is simply no easy way to get promoted other than to leave and come back.  Other offers during employment etc. aren't really considered in this system.

Two words: Lotus Notes.

Pros: Working remotely, health benefits, coworkers, and first line manager.
Cons:
401(k) matching once a year, the lack of being able to reach anyone human in HR or any other department, lack of communication from the top. 
The biggest drawback, the constant layoff's, or as IBM calls them, Resource Actions.  While Companies layoff employee's, it is usually to rid themselves of deadwood.  At IBM, the cut to make the balance sheet look better.  Currently they are laying off as the Company transforms itself, but after 4 years of declining revenues, quarterly layoffs, the problem is not the workers, it is the upper management.  Being in sales if I have a few bad quarters, I get terminated, upper management has them and they get a bonus?  
Don't apply here if you want an employer you can grow with, here you will go down with the ship that is sinking faster than the Titanic. 
The CEO keeps changing direction and shedding assets to keep the shareholders earning.
The ship is sinking a slow but deliberate death, unless the top managers are changed it will continue to decline.

Pros: Cutting edge technology (CMOS H/W), very talented engineers, great and grand projects.  There are some really smart people here; in the development teams, and in research.  It's great to have a research team to help tackle really difficult problems.  Also, generous vacation (though you can't always take it and you can't accumulate it), flexible work-at-home deals depending on your area.  Decent initial salary.
Cons: Compensation is poor. Once you're in, raises are non-existent or really small.  Same for bonuses.  And that's for exemplary performers.  Promotions are very rare, particularly for the technical team.  Management is odd: 1st/2nd line managers spend most of their time trying to be "Project Managers", not too much focus actual management.  There's a project management hierarchy that overlaps with these first lines, and adds little value ( though that might be the best career path).  Zero training. Zero travel. Development projects are overbooked. IBM is really pushing off-shoring to India.  You have to do your job, plus train a team of Indian developers; Middle management is pretty bad, they aim to please Sr management, customers, without consideration to their team.  Sr Management reaps millions, off-shores, and lays technical people off ; their is not a good connection between the team and Sr Management.  7-10 levels of managers in between, too much.

Pros:

Cons:

Pros: good 401k thanks to Ibm, that is all
Cons: merge is a company built on acquiring other companies, stripping them down, putting products they buy into maintenance mode and not developing them further, and bleeding the customer bases dry.  They have no concept of customer satisfaction, priority number one is pushing the sale even if it's something we can't implement or does not make sense for a customer.  Because all they know how to do is acquire and destroy, they have no idea how to develope something on their own that actually works (iconnect network for example).  Now Ibm thinks merge is going to be able to help release new products utilizing the Watson engine this year, not holding my breath on that one.  All departments are silos and getting them to work together is impossible, there is a culture of if it does not fall into my job description leave me alone.  Their sales leadership can be best compared to that of a used car salesman.  They litteraly would rather have their sales people sit at a prospects site for the last two weeks of the quarter and endlessly beg for the deal even if they have been told no decision will be made by then.  Nepotism runs rampant, the high level positions held by a number of upper managers who have zero qualifications to be in that position is amazing.  Upper management would rather have allies and yes men around them rather than hire someone who could implement meaningful change and question the current conditions.
