Pros: IBM owns and develops excellent technology that can really make the world a better place. The engineers are top notch, and they are highly valued within their silo. The company breadth and reach allows it to come up with innovative and creative solutions that has the potential to touch almost every aspect of life, from smarter cities to big data.
Cons: Almost every decision made is a "breadbox" mentality - can I save a buck right now by ___. The company is struggling to deal with the shift from hardware and software licensing to pure cloud models. This has a cascading impact on the broader company because it pressures the field to generate more revenue in lightly depressed markets to compensate for rapidly declining markets. In other words: unrealistic expectations. On top of that, IBM leadership second-guesses itself annually, moving back and forth between similar org structures. In addition, the company is so big that many of its offerings overlap with each other, confusing the sales force and the customer as to which solution is the right fit, ultimately coming down to who the rep is and what solution do they get paid on (versus what is right for the customer). Lastly, it is not a meritocracy. You advance your career inside IBM because of who you know, not what you can do.

Pros: A very large company with many career potentials. Worldwide presence makes it a great company to work for if you have an interest to work overseas. IBM was ahead of its time in so many ways including embracing social, open source, and cloud as the core of its business. Company has very smart people working in it. Work/life balance is good.
Cons:
As much as the company was ahead of its time in many areas: cloud, social, mobile, and open source, it didn't do enough to make a lasting impact in the industry. There are smart, strategic IBMers who had long identified those up-trends. But senior management hung on to status-quo, focusing on mainframes, middle-ware, and once high margin hardware business. 

There is little to no career development. Most people are "tenured" are staying to retire. Executives are compensated based on earnings per share. This inherently steer them to cost cut in places where it matters most: high quality hires, education, and technology investment. Short-term gains and complacency lead to long-term decline of the company. Most executives are just waiting for retirement, leaving a shadow of a company that IBM once was.

Pros: Summit is life changing! Throughout the 6-9 months of training, people are taken from being recent graduates with little experience to young sales professionals ready to sell for Big Blue. In the program, you learn how to not only be an effective sales person, but you also learn about how to engage with C-level execs. The salary is outstanding and the company is focused on investing in you through education. Managers are fantastic and truly care about enabling you to succeed. There is some travel involved. Lastly, the best part about Summit is that you are put with 30-40 people your age that you stay with throughout the program. This is not only great for networking, but it's absolutely crucial to building the culture and your experience at IBM. Some of the people in my group have become my best friends.
Cons: There are some cons about working here- IBM is an extremely large company and it's easy to get lost in the mix. It was also difficult initially to find enough work to do because they start everyone off slow. However, with that being said, it's on YOU to make sure you have your needs met. Whether that is by asking for more work, getting involved on different project teams, or telling your manager you're overwhelmed. A lot of my peers complain about things in the program that they have complete control over to change.

Pros: Great compensation & benefits.  Lower level team members are great & hard working.  Good & a wide variety of experience gained quickly. Working from home has been a perk, but they are getting rid of that option for most positions.
Cons:
Written by a millennial: Currently, IBM is going through a massive change where everyone has to relocate to one of 6 cities.  This tactic is to get rid of the middle/higher level positions who are older & cost more for employment & targeting millennials to hire in.  This tactic disregards the expertise that the mid-higher level employees have in their field.  Team members who have been at IBM for 20+ years are unappreciated & forced into retirement or to look for a new job. 

In addition to IBM not appreciating their loyal & experienced employees, IBM has a horrible onboarding process.  Starting as a university hire, I was just dropped in without understanding my role, the dynamics of the team, & was assigned as the lead for large events within the first couple months.  If IBM plans to replace all of the experienced IBM employees with new young hires, they need to have a very thorough training process in plan based on roles that has a single person assigned to the success of the new hire.

Lastly, all direction comes from the top down.  Reorganization happens at least once a year if not more.  The majority of the time people are trying to understand their role & new team members instead of being able to get quality work done.

Pros:
If you want to be successful and change the world you work for a company like IBM.  IBM is on the cutting edge of technology and the opportunities are endless to those willing to work for it and earn it.  Make no mistake about it… its highly competitive, edgy, stressful and at times it can feel like pure madness.  This is what it takes to be a world leader in technology.  IBM can help you tap into the greatest version of you and come out on the other side a contributor to the brilliance that is IBM.
If you are interested in more than just benefits and you want to make a difference in today’s world… IBM is the place for you.  (FYI… benefits are great).  If you are just looking for a paycheck, “swipe LEFT”.  All things being equal IBM has their share of issues just like every other company.  No matter what company you work for, when faced with a challenge, you can complain about it or build a business case to fix it.  At IBM you can be part of the solution that fixes the problem.  
IBM is a wealth of vision and inspiration and always looking forward to the future.  I would challenge anyone reading this to be the change you want to see in the world… become an IBMer.

One piece of advice… It’s called BIG BLUE for a reason… do not get lost in the ocean…NETWORK.
Cons: I prefer to call them challenges... all companies have them.  Nothing major you can't overcome.

Pros: New technology if you can find a way to get involved with it.
Cons:
No motivators other than “be lucky to have a job”. 
No yearly pay increase. Once you’re hired in, getting a raise is next to impossible even for stellar work. You get great reviews but keep the same salary, year after year, so you’re in essence working for less money due to inflation and when cost of living goes up each year. I’ve been working for ibm for 10 years, hired in at 100k, gotten great reviews for doing more, growing my skill set, advancing IBMs client base and technical position, and in the 10 years, I’ve gotten a couple 1200$ profit sharing bonus and a 1% pay increase and one 2% pay increase.......in 10 years. So I’m in essence making about 17% less less than when I started. (My money doesn’t go as far as it did 10 years ago, doesn’t pay the same amount of bills). And manage always says “maybe next year” year after year, until burnout sets in, our careers have been damaged from the emotional and mental torture that working for a company like this does to you.

Pros: Education, 401K match, work flexibility
Cons: Hugh emphasis to meet/exceed utilization target (~96%+). Manager not aware of biz contributions & value add unless employee makes extra effort to convey directly ...otherwise, unaware exceeding customer's expectations and accolades.

Pros: Iconic company with a. great culture and values.
Cons: Large organization with complexities in terms of navigation and driving outcomes.

Pros: interesting work, flexible work enviroment
Cons: not much room for upward growth in my role

Pros: Good work life balance, good job security
Cons: No bonus, no stock option, no pay raise. Basically only base salary without any meaningful bonuses or raises

Pros: Learn new technologies, lots of paid training and certifications.
Cons: Responsible for finding your own projects, can't afford to be on bench too long. Tendency to have breadth but not depth of knowledge of technologies since you are always working with different clients with different needs and requirements.

Job Title: Senior software development engineer in test (sdet)
Pros: It is a very nice company to work in. People are so friendly
Cons: I don’t have any cons

Pros: Smart coworkers for the most part.
Cons: Lots of organizational thrashing. So-so management. Lots of management churning. IBM squandered its lead in AI with Watson. Now it's way behind its competition -- Microsoft and Google. Unclear if they can catch up.

Pros: If you're a shareholder, you're good.
Cons: If you're an employee or contractor, expect paycuts so shareholders are happy.

Pros: Lots of resources available across the company
Cons: Lots of bureaucracy across orgs

Pros: Life work balance, consistent travel on site work for clients
Cons: Often on the bench due to lack of business

Pros: - Collaboration work environment. - Learning opportunities - Career opportunities
Cons: - Multi projects - Many meetings

Pros: Growth opportunities are usually there for sure
Cons: It is not for everyone

Pros: Competitive pay Flexible working conditions
Cons: "resource actions" (layoffs) have become regular

Pros: coworkers work life balance tech company in the midwest
Cons: how resources are allocated/adjusted can be challenging

Pros: Worked with a good group of people
Cons: don't have any negative comments

Pros: The company is involved in many products and businesses, so there is a lot of opportunity for doing different things throughout your career.  People tend to stay with the same job for two to five years before moving on to do something different, and this is supported fully by management.  There are even opportunities for moving to different areas within the United States, or even to other countries, if you are interested in seeing new places, both on temporary or permanent assignments.  If you wish, you can have a varied career, changing jobs as your interests change, while maintaining the continuity and benefits of having a single employer.
Cons: The company can be somewhat management-heavy at times.  Sometimes it appears that there are levels of middle management that exist simply to keep people busy.  This seems to be especially the case in some of the older organizations that have been producing the same or similar products for many years.  This tends to create a lot of politics, especially when dealing with people in different management chains who seem to be getting a completely different vision for the direction of the project.  Good first-line managers shield their employees from this, while bad ones can make it nearly impossible to be productive.

Pros: Perks as a sales rep, laptop, expensive dinners with customers, rental cars, flights, hotels, box seats to sporting events with customers, phone and internet bill all expensable with corporate card.  Working from home is great too, you could work from Jamaica, and no one would know.  The IBM brand name is great too, you will never be denied a meeting because you represent IBM.  The conferences are top notch and are done at the best hotels, celebrity keynote speakers, and if you have customers, you get to spoil them and yourself all week long with expensive dinners even bottle service at the best clubs in Vegas (if your manager approves).
Cons:
Huge quotas, internal politics, red tape, conference calls, constant fear of layoffs, backstabbing when things go wrong, the amount of internal administrative crap you have to do that takes away from your productivity, cadence calls, etc.

If you have a crappy manager, your life will suck at IBM as a sales rep...period.

Getting taken off of accounts in the middle of the year, or at the beginning of the year is frustrating as a sales rep b/c this is supposed to be a relationship business.  When you're best friends with a CIO, and you have millions of dollars coming your way for years spread out over 4 quarters, it's hard to see that account go to someone else due to restructuring.

Pros:
We were allowed to work remotely but it ended right after the layoffs.
Pay was above average.  
Some really good people worked there.
Cons:
Layoffs.  First month I was there, they laid off 10% of my department, layoffs continued all year long.   

Constant focus changes from C levels. CEO and her managers are to blame for this company failing month after month.  22 months of decline, its obvious its the upper management that needs to be "laid off".

Management were told to do mandatory PIP ( Performance Improvement Plans ) on N number of people.  I saw the email. It is highly unethical.

They accidentally posted their plan on slack saying they outsourcing our jobs overseas, then they said "oh we not.." yet few months later.. they did. They Lie directly to the employees.

The new C level came to the office once, talked for a full hour on "How her son is doing, and how he is the best son ever."  Then 5 minutes of sales need to increase by 400%, then tells no one what the plan is.  After the 5 minutes, she went back talking about her son.  I wish I was joking on this.  This is not leadership, it is a friends of friends network.

Pros: Innovative work on new projects
Cons: structure and lack of impact

Pros: Great company to work for, great pay, lots of room for growth, in house training and certifications, great benefits, remote work, ect
Cons: No bonuses like smaller boutique firms and if you like a smaller team or slower pace, IBM may not be the best fit

Pros: Career Path / Great leaders / Interesting Projects / Good Carrer Opportunities / Work-life Balance
Cons: Sometimes, it is not wasy to cope with so many procedures to follow

Pros: Good company to work for
Cons: To much work pressure for

Pros: Great company to work for!
Cons: I couldn't work from home.

Pros: Very knowledgeable and supportive coworkers
Cons: Large corporate values can outweigh everyday jobs

Pros: When I started at IBM, I was a young overwhelmed employee and kept wondering why IBM hired me. Through the early years, I felt I was a contributor to the business and I was able to quickly get promoted, nice raises, outstanding benefits and had a whole lot of fun while working with top notch people. I was always intrigued by the new and cutting edge stuff coming out and IBM was always good at letting you undertake new challenges and look and move to new opportunities.
Cons: The one thing that always bothered me at IBM was the confusing and complicated bonus payments. Several years ago, I had a manager call a special meeting to go over the new sales plan. It took her about 10 minutes to understand that  she did not quite actually understand the basics and she just got back from a 1 day meeting on the subject. She naturally called in the person who actually developed the plan to speak with us. After 30 minutes she even had questions as to why certain things were the way they were and she wrote the thing. Needless to say, it was the hardest thing to understand each year, especially when your quota kept getting changed throughout the year.

Pros: Lots of opportunities for growth
Cons: Bench time can be stressful

Pros: Co workers were a pleasure to work with.
Cons: Management was inconsistent and at worst showed favoritism.

Pros: Large company with a great history... no one gets fired for buying IBM mentality.
Cons: Sales org pressure is immense to make sure you hit monthly and quarterly targets.

Pros: Varied experiences based on being at a global company; flexibility in work environment.
Cons: Too many layoffs, and pressures to provide a headcount for an upcoming layoff.

Pros: People I have worked with so far are focused on collaboration and the company does seem to have the best interest of their employees in mind.
Cons: Benefits are VERY average and the beauracracy (typical of most big companies) is annoying.

Pros: Benefits Work from home Flexible hours Salary
Cons: Career progression Time off benefits

Pros: people, training opportunities, remote work
Cons: churn, bonus structure favors upper management,

Pros: This is a great advisory role for IBM to Clients, drives many opportunities within IBM and the clients. It's like technical role with seller incentives.
Cons: Realignment has people confused and people in this role are not confident IBM knows the value.

Pros: IBM is IBM Bonus is yearly
Cons: Micromanagement Numbers Game Hard to find a good manager

Pros: IBM is a good name to put on your resume. Nearly unlimited sick days and good vacation/floating holiday package. Flex scheduling. Ability to work from home part time as long as your accounts are maintained.
Cons: High turnover, little to no employee appreciation, bad pay, people who were with Pepsi for years are now racing to get out the door, have trouble replacing people as fast as they're leaving so that puts more workload on the employees that are left and even though you may have 1 person doing 2 peoples' job, getting overtime is like pulling teeth, mediocre training for new hires (who are all temps, they never hire on with IBM), lack of communication around the office (people who have been with Pepsi and IBM since the beginning are leaving and leadership doesn't even communicate this to the teams, its all hush hush like people disappear into thin air), this list could go on and on

Pros:
- Great coworkers
- Good managers
- Ability to work on multiple technologies
- Relatively decent work/life balance
- Great 401k match

Life at IBM certainly isn't boring. You will spend a lot of time listening to long timers about the good old days of when they rewarded people and had fringe benefits. Just ignore them. It's about enjoying your team and the projects you are working on. People at the company are overall great and there is a lot of keen enthusiasm. Fewer diva programmers than most places and a lot of knowledge to acquire if you pay your dues. There are so many technologies to dip into and if you hit up someone from another business unit and offer to help they are more than happy to offload some tasks for you to learn with. People just enjoy sharing here and it's more difficult to not let yourself spread too much.
Cons:
- Low moral due to resource actions 
- Lingering stacked rating system issues
- Almost no appealing benefits

IBM is a big company and has the same problem of any big company. I'd caution to give only as much time as you feel good about because bonuses are rare, acknowledgement is thin, and overall promotions and advancement are up to a roulette of factors. Basically those extra hours you put in are for your own self satisfaction because IBM can't reward top behavior of anyone but sellers right now.

Pros:
(1) IBM has some great training programs and developmental opportunities.  
(2) Your Team will be experienced, professional and dedicated to customer success
(3) Depth of resources...  You can reach out to >400,000 people in IBM and most will be willing to help you out
(4) Good compensation and benefits
Cons:
(1) Leadership has struggled with "Strategic Initiatives" and what it wants to be in the next transformation.   Every part of the  business needs to look over their shoulder - where might the axe fall next?
(2) Weak Manager Skills - I've been in many organizations and by far managers in IBM are not trained or prepared for the roles.   They need improvement in managing their piece of the business and they need improvement on people management skills.  
(3) While they are good at acquiring software solutions - everyone of them seems to have withered on the vine and never achieved greater success than what was initially procured.   Will Red Hat be different?

Pros: Good place to work. Lot's of tech.
Cons: Like most big companies, lots of layers of management.

Pros: Great for developing skills all around the board.
Cons: Lots of changes all the time

Pros: There are lots of interesting teams and projects going on at any time at IBM. If you don't like your current one, you can just move to another one. You can keep reinventing yourself. It's easier than changing jobs, and you get to keep your seniority.
Cons: I wish mid-level management listened more and better to input from the technical employees. We are here to help!

Pros: Great culture, phenomenal pay and they really take care of you
Cons: So far so good. Great place to work for

Pros: Friendly, Good, competitive, High demand, committement
Cons: Less paying, competitive, Hgh demand, Low paying

Pros: The is high level of inclusiveness, equal opportunity for all, and high career growth in divers fields.
Cons: You must put in your best and ready to network

Pros: Great coworkers, lots of opportunities, open source friendly
Cons: Bloated middle management, unclear direction, outsourcing talent

Pros: Work-life balance Great managers Lots of opportunities to learn
Cons: Pay could be more competitive

Pros: Great company with amazing resources and support including opportunities for advanced training and movement within the organization.
Cons: Processes over engineered (contracting) and complicate business arrangements.

Pros: Technology, Values , Corporate culture , Trainings, Professionals
Cons: Completed processes and procedures which are not for doing business but against it.

Pros: Working here or even looking for a job here is amazing
Cons: There are no bad sides working here

Pros: Wide variety of industries, many high-quality people to work with on projects, reputation opens doors to interesting engagements, competitive wages. Hiring process was fairly well run.
Cons:
For such a well-established technology company, searching their practitioner database for reference work and relevant IP yields documents that are often over five years old in a foreign language.

Very inefficient staffing, ad hoc training and career planning...

I was hired as an experienced professional, given a laptop with basic administrative training and then left to fend for myself with no initial projects in mind when I was hired in so as to help establish my network. It took several months to become staffed on the first project.

Variable compensation is only given to a very small percentage at the very top of a year's given achievers and only when the company is performing well so don't count on more than your base salary.

Pros: Compensation was generally at or above the market, the technology available is generally very good with the employee online resources being the most extensive I have ever worked with. Many highly experienced resources remain in the company and are generally available and accessible if you know where to find them.  The quality of the individuals remains high and there is passion to be found.
Cons: This may be a company drifting into stage 4 decline as they have been making a variety of the moves described by Jim Collins in "How the Mighty Fall": A series of Silver Bullets, Grasping for Leader as Savior, Radical Change and Revolution with Fanfare, Chronic Restructuring and Erosion of Financial Strength.  The organization seems to be myopic to an extreme - everyone is laser focused on their own tiny portion of the business without regard to collaboration and cooperation on the big picture.  The organization also appears "penny-wise" and "pound-foolish", making lavish investments in a variety of Major initiatives and acquisitions but choking off basic investment in product support, rock-solid product development, effective and available training investment, REAL employee development, and stable infrastructure.  If you are looking for a stable direction and reliable resources to support that direction, you may be terribly disappointed.

Pros: If your job allows, the ability to be able to work from home is a definite plus because I am able to avoid Austin's commutes.  The benefit package is pretty  good if you are single.
Cons: The thinking behind and implementation of the ineffective and destructive performance review process is supposed to be changing this year.  The challenge for the management team will be how to effectively change the thinking behind the old approach to performance review, with it's focus on "distributions" or quotas. This thinking is very ingrained in our corporate culture. Sadly, the previous system was build on outright untruths formally perpetuated by the management team, such as, "There is no quota system.", which is legendary within IBM. You cannot build a team when staff are effectively played off against each other to improve their "relative contribution".  This would be at the heart of why staff avoid taking on projects with inherent risk because they are afraid of being punished if they don't achieve an aggressive goal by loosing their meager pay increase, being ranked lower, and possibly becoming the target of a layoff.

Pros: Global reach, a lot of bright people, brand recognition (though it is skewed towards computing even today). Base pay was good.
Cons:
Be careful, experienced professionals! I was dropped in at a relatively high level and had not projects from the get-go in the 4th quarter, and they were not closing a lot of work at that time. I didn't get on a billable project for almost six months. In month 17, I was given a lay-off notice based on my prior year performance because of that 1st quarter with no billable utilization... Also, be wary of Partner and Associate Partner underlying interests - watch you back.

I thought I'd have a great opportunity to help out on large projects and run small projects - with all the breadth of industry and the thousands of "open seats", but without that early opportunity to really get known, you are dead. I had some significant successes in industry before moving to this role, but the capabilities were not easily conveyed given this lack of early opportunity to work on things in front of key decision-makers.

Pros: Networking, knowledge, good out of school experience, work life balance.
Cons: Slow, old school company, impacted by economy in consulting

Pros: Great place to work and great benefits
Cons: Long hours and very stressful

Pros: Great managers. Flexibility. They move you often too.
Cons: They move your job often

Pros: Flexibility to carve your own path Vast amounts of learning available Challenging projects
Cons: High utilization requirements Hard to get staffed on projects for higher bands

Pros: Work Life Balance Growth Opportunities. Good Pay Collaborative working environment.
Cons: Lack of appreciation in few projects.

Pros: flexible WFH; not micromanaged; good pay
Cons: no direction; poor management; unclear growth opportunity

Pros: More stability than most companies in the IT industry.  IBM offers flexible working hours, a true commitment to working remotely, and the tools to empower remote employees  The company offers solid benefits, and because it touches all areas in IT,  employees do have a chance to experience different areas.
Cons: The communications function is highly bureaucratic, highly political, and overall does not necessarily reward the most competent employees, but instead ones that fit a specific HR box.  All companies have to deal with this issue, but it's especially bad at IBM and in the Comms function.  It is not a function where young comms professionals should seek to work, although if you have at least five years of experience and want a big brand name, I would recommend IBM only as a short-term (three years) assignment before moving on to another company to leverage your skills and knowledge.   It is not a place to plan a career.

Pros: Mostly good people and bright co-workers. IBM is good about letting people work from home (which is nice, because it's much easier to tolerate working with an obnoxious management team when you're in a remote location).
Cons:
Executive management team likes to micro-manage the business, which causes LOTS of extra and unnecessary workload.  You spend a very large percentage of your time preparing for and giving status updates to senior management (often with technical details beyond their ability to understand).   There are some very good technical people at IBM , but the management system is so oppressive and smothering that few creative ideas ever see the light of day.   

IBM works very, very hard at creating the ILLUSION of being a good employer, but it's actions show otherwise.  Lots of companies have had to do lay-offs, but at least most of them have had the guts to publicly acknowledge the actions they are taking. IBM on the other hand prefers to surreptitiously do its lay-offs and off-shoring of jobs while keeping its employees in the dark.

Pros:
I worked at IBM for more than 30 years where I made WONDERFUL lifelong friends. IBM was more than an employer, it created a family environment. IBM BBQ's, IBM Family Day, IBM Family Dinner..yep these used to exist, and they were GREAT for morale, and kept folks dedicated and proud. There used to be an IBM Country Club at Pt. Washington, Long Island, NY. 
I started selling Office Products, became a first line then a second line sales manager, and traveled extensively to exciting places around the world which I may have not enjoyed if it were on my own dime.
Great healthcare and other benefits though many that existed for the first 10 years slowly evaporated after 1990.
Minorities, women, and other diverse groups of individuals are well represented at IBM.
Cons:
You are only as good as your last quarter's performance.
Having been a manager, I know that there are times when decisions are made purely on the basis of a quota, whether PBC rating, promotion, salary increases.
What ever happened to career development ?? There isn't any anymore.
Really BAD choices in promoting people to exec positions..I had to EARN my stripes.

Pros:
work life balance/integration
compensation, excellent benefits
looks great on resume
good experience
no micro managing (!!) I loved this, 

I was a mechanical engineer.  I liked that I could manage my own work, come and go w/o a problem (no one was watching me, or the clock, etc).  If I had an appointment I just blocked off the time on my calendar and went.  Vacation time was easy to get, very lenient approval process.  People with kids were always able to go to important things or even just volunteer in their kids' class.  As long as you are meeting deadlines and not really screwing up they were very flexible.  On the flip side, some times long hours were necessary.
Cons:
stability
stress level- schedules are so aggressive it makes for a very stressful environment
little to no investment in employees' learning
so many people just waiting for retirement

If you're a early career ME there aren't a lot of options for you, it can be very frustrating.  A lot of hardware has already been sold and there's always a threat that more will be sold so stability is not good in this area.  Its hard to get money for certifications and school, not impossible but you have to really go after it.

Pros: Great Managers Hybrid Schedule Great Benefits Great Pay Company Culture Continuing Education Diversity 401k Matching
Cons: I wish I had the opportunity to join this company sooner

Pros: Good learning and career opportunities here.
Cons: Nothing i can think of.

Pros: Coworkers are great to work with
Cons: Senior leadership is destroying the company. No bonus program. Annual layoffs of US based employees. Lack of vision for the company.

Pros: Flexibility, And Work Life Balance
Cons: Yet not known to me.

Pros: * Good work life balance. * Team Work - Everyone is working together to get the job done. * Management is very supportive.

Pros: IBM is a company that thinks and prioritizes many of its employees and customers, has a solid and great career plan, always placing the employee as the owner of his or her own company.

Pros: I work with the smartest people in the world working on tech for good. I am supported by my management team to be creative and innovative. The work is exciting and impactful!
Cons: We have the support of a large organization behind us. It can take a bit to navigate the organization, but there are so many here to help.

Pros: Great company, great people, great technological vision. Very happy to see that they look to be turning the ship around and focusing on their key areas of business (cloud, data, AI, security)
Cons: Still evolving away from legacy business into the cloud but it looks like they are getting there.

Pros: - good pay - good benefits - access to trainings

Pros: Lots of opportunity to learn new technologies and expand technical skill.

Pros: Overall good company to work having competitive package. Nice work culture and lots of training opportunities

Pros: Good pay and helpful coworkers

Pros: Great place to work at
Cons: None at this point of time

Pros: Great professional people and company culture Many teams and roles, you can explore and find the right one for yourself Internal transfer is easy
Cons: Big company. The product portfolio is too broad to know each of them.

Pros: Lots of different projects to work on in numerous fields.  Lots of talented people. Many opportunities to telecommute. Typically get to work on different projects if you stay there for quite a few years.  Decent benefits.
Cons: Generally don't seem to appreciate the employees any more. They kill (or move overseas) entire projects and often don't give employees a chance at other jobs within company, no matter how talented and hard-working they have been proven to be. Strategy is all about earnings per share, not about how to improve products and their service to customers to increase revenut.  The value to customers has decreased significantly over the years. Decent pay increases rare except for the select few.  Rating system seems to be based largely on office politics. Benefits, although decent, have steadily eroded over time.  Little or no education any more.

IBM has become too political and has adopted a woke culture that seeks to raise awareness of specific groups while making others feel guilty when they are innocent. IBM tends to lead from behind and focuses too much on the finances versus the technologies, and listens more to Wall Street than Main Street. IBM fosters an environment that creates internal competition by over communicating the successes and gains of employees who reach career milestones that they want to enforce, like certifications.

Pros: Working at IBM is like getting another master's degree.  There is so much opportunity to learn in this company, and in general, the willingness of senior technical leaders to teach (and of managers to support such education) is remarkable.  Although organizational politics will sometimes create barriers, the potential of this large, talented organization can be incredible when focused & engaged on a goal.  IBM also seems to be one of the leading firms in terms of "walking the talk" on work life balance.  While extensive use of work/life integration tools may be seen by some as stepping off the career fast-track, it is widely used, and the level of flexibility in many divisions/organizations is quite high compared to peer firms.
Cons: Bureaucracy is incredibly high.  People often compare it to the US Military or other such government bodies.  There will be 6 levels of approval for a $250 purchase.   There are layers upon layers of executive management.  At any given time, at least one other IBM division will be designing a product that competes with yours.

Pros: IBM offers employees a solid brand name, ample benefits, and compensates managers well.  There are many smart people, with a positive overall culture.  Employees and managers enjoy helping each other, and IBM can be a great place to develop your skills and become a stronger person.  Don't confuse personal development with career opportunities, though.
Cons:
Raises are rare and bonuses small, so either negotiate a high salary before being hired, or expect to be underpaid for some time.  A bloated, bureaucratic management structure weighs down the whole organization, so innovation comes slowly and way behind most of the marketplace.  All aspects of work at IBM are process-driven, so expect mountains of rules and documentation that frequently confound common sense.

Probably the worst thing about IBM is the employee rating system.  You are assigned your rating in a group meeting with all first and second line managers, and there is literally no objective criteria built in to the process.  To be rated well, you must be very good at managing relationships with your manager and his
peers.  The people who thrive are frequently not the top contributors, but the ones who self-promote and manage perceptions well.  IBM enforces a brutal ratings curve on the first and second line managers, so if you are not the leader of the pack, do not expect raises or promotions.  You may or may not have job security, depending on the year.

Pros:
It's a big company that has lots of diversity, exceptional staff, and a long history of reinventing itself despite bouts with failed leadership.  Historically, benefits were good and stated company "values" are focused on "win-win" philosophies.  Work-life balance was reasonable, and employees felt valued.  In some parts of the company, shreds of this history remain.

If you find the "right" group / division (likely in a low-wage or developing country), there's still hope of a bright future and a potentially rewarding career.
Cons:
With the second consecutive CEO who lacks the ability to communicate coherent vision and direction to his/her employees, (aside from the relentless drive toward $20 EPS in 2015 which should be a byproduct of stellar performance, not a business target) the company has once again lost its way.  Layoffs of high-knowledge employees and inward-looking short-sighted policies rule the day.

Customer service has deteriorated as a result, and IBM's published sales numbers clearly paint the picture of the current trajectory.  Fear and stifling control are the bureaucratic tools-du-jour, with hollow strategies and PR-generating "partnerships" rounding out the equation.  IBM's nimbler and more customer-focused competitors are once again eating its lunch technologically, commercially, and service-wise.

Pros: IBM used to be a great company to work for and is still known as having skilled employees.  IBM has been very good regarding working from home and working flexible hours around personal needs.
Cons: The last 5-6 years pay increases for experienced, high-performing, staff engineers have not kept up with the dollar increases in the cost of health insurance premiums IBM has passed on to employees.  IBM used to be known as a family-friendly company by providing good benefit coverages for families of employees.  In the last decade, IBM has shifted the burden of providing insurance benefits for employees' spouses and dependents to the employees without increasing the pay to compensate for the added costs.  Compensation and benefit plans are geared toward bringing in young, single, employees at competitive starting salaries who generally only last a few years, while ignoring the dependable, experienced, knowledgeable employees who become stuck in the position of perpetually training the new kids who either wash out or are put on the fast-track ahead of the gray-hairs.  The employees who are the backbone of IBM are unappreciated, but often have no choice about leaving because they do not want to uproot their families.

Pros: The PTO is nice, as a regular employee I get 20 days. Also, the health benefits I have are decent and practically free.
Cons:
I don't even know where to start with the cons of working at the COE in Rochester. Yes, IBM looks good to have on your resume but it's not worth the soul sucking torture you have to go through every day. Training is a joke, they rely on the person who had the role before you to train you in... my past two roles I've gotten because someone has been leaving IBM and they didn't really care about training me. This has left me feeling like I've been "thrown to the wolves" with both of my roles... BUT it's ok, because it's not like the work you do actually adds any value to IBM. 

I've feel like I've gained very little work experience in the finance field. 

If you do happen to take an FA job here, I hope you don't plan on growing your career here. There are very few opportunities for advancement. I guess I shouldn't say that, the Rochester COE does seem to love to do vertical promotions... you know, the type where you get more work but no extra pay. 

Overall, I highly advise that you only take a job here as a very last resort if you can't get another job out of college.

Pros: Stable company; industry leader in many areas; ongoing opportunity to get involved in new areas of the business; focus on customer satisfaction and customer value; innovative; leader in open systems; great supporter/promoter of women, minorities, etc;
Cons:
- I worked there for over 20 years and saw one of their core principles, "respect for the individual", set aside and replaced with "what ever is best for IBM".  On a scale of 1-4 (1 = best), I was rated a 2 or 2+ for every year for over 20 years. I made my quota in 2008, was told multiple times during 2008 what a great job I was doing by my manager, then I was laid off in Feb 2009.
- Staffed very thin - be sure to take your laptop with you on vacation and set aside a few hours a day to work.  Actively trying to move most of their US based resources off shore to lower cost countries ("stealth" layoffs of over 4600 people in Feb 2009 never announced to the press).  
- In sales, a generally high base salary (good) but limited leverage as they always adjust the quota, or ratchet back the pay plan to limit potential payouts. 
- Constant change and reorganizations, warranted in some cases, however it's just movement for the sake of movement at times. Management is sometimes disconnected from the relationships that the front line team builds with customers.

Pros:
- The work from home options at the site were very good. We were only required to be in office a few days per week, with the ability to flex that as low as two days per week. 
- The managers were very understanding of how rough it was to work at IBM and didn't try and compound those issues.
Cons:
- The instability was ridiculous. It seemed like every few months you'd hear about the next big wave of layoffs that were about to happen. Morale in the office dipped, and as each layoff passed the office became emptier and emptier until maybe 10% of desks per each floor were filled.
- They hired mostly non-technical people to perform technical jobs. When I had to teach a coworker who has been there for 3 years what "ls" and "cd" do on their AIX servers, I knew this was the wrong place to be.
- Major outsourcing to India. Basically every job was at risk of being outsourced, or in the process of being outsourced by the time I quit. The Indians they hire to replace the American jobs didn't seem to have much formal education in the field or any experience. It was a hassle training them.
- Second level management and higher are purely about the bottom line with zero regard for the human beings lives they are ruining by penny pinching and shipping jobs overseas. First line management also despised them, but they were powerless.

Pros: IBm offers a pretty good work life balance although that is starting to disappear. The benefits are pretty good too, and the 401K plan is possibly one of the best. You do have a certain amount of  flexibility and  the potential to move around the company, alhough this will likely depend on which group you are in and how well the business is doing. It is  not a given by any means which is what IBM advertised to potential employees. There is a great wealth of information and education avaialble to anyone who wants to stay educated and informed. The IBM name on your resume doesnt hurt either.
Cons: There is way too much bureaucracy and redundancy especially at the management level. There are sometimes literally 3 people to do the sae thing and to attend the same meeting. Each will have his or her own agenda too. The quality of the management is very ordinary overall though there are some really sharp people. All in all, the reason IBM is surviving is because of it's technical talent of which there is a substantial amount. This does not mean there is no deadwood as there as meany people who are there just to colect a salary. The promotion process is not always fair and career growth seems to depend too much on which group you are in. Life in IBM is much better as a manager or above a certain band level(* 9 and above)

Pros: I worked at IBM Global Business Services for 2 years.  IBM GBS is a great place to build technical skills and get experience with high profile clients through implementation projects.  There are a lot of older, more experienced consultants who are more than happy to mentor and help younger consultants build deep technical skills in ERP packages.  There was not a lot of pressure to perform and work/life balance was good.  The performance review system seemed to run well and I felt I got the recognition I deserved at the end of the year.  The training was good and I felt satisfied with the learning opportunities.
Cons: IBM GBS operates like a hybrid between a typical large industry company and a traditional consulting firm.  The nature of the work is similar to other consulting firms like Accenture, Deloitte Consulting, Capgemini, and BearingPoint.  Unfortunately, the nature of the internal operating model is more like working for a F100 company.  In other words, the raises are minimal and the company did not seem interested in retaining or differentiating top performers from the rest of the group.  As a result of this, there was massive attrition in the lower and middle ranks, especially for top performers.  Most of the people I started with are gone.  GBS also seemed to enjoy hiring older, more experienced consultants with no drive to progress up the chain.

Pros: IBM supports a very flexible work schedule, focused on getting the job done rather than what hours were worked during the day.  Also, many jobs allow for some, all, or as-needed portion of the week to be worked from home at the employee's discretion.  Vacation time is self-managed and also very flexible.  The work environment (at least in Austin) is extremely casual.  There is a mind-numbing array of resources available to employees from freely available records detailing corporate policies, HR records, IT systems, capital requests, tools for managing corporate charge card, tools for booking your own corporate travel, on-line libraries, surplus stores, education, book ordering, volume printing, recreational activities, parks and facilities, etc., etc.  IBM also rewards innovation with awards for patent contributions.
Cons:
Resource reductions without backfilling (at least in North America) leave too few resources overcommitted and burnt-out dreading the yearly review cycle.

Intranet search bites (i.e. while there are a mind-numbing array of services available, finding them is never easy).

Pros: 6-12 month paid training with benefits.
Cons:
Salary is lower than what you could get in other sales/technical sales roles.

Prepare to do a lot do a lot of busy work. Some of the training is not relevant or helpful to the role you'll be doing and the important stuff is given a very surface level overview. If you want depth, that will be up to you, and your time and money. 

Because there are so many layers of management, you are often given very conflicting advice on what priorities should be and what you should be working on. "It depends" comes up a lot for answers to what should be simple questions. The phrase "I'm By Myself" is very much true and you will have to spend a considerable amount of time to find people who can give you meaningful help and guidance in your professional career.

As for co-workers, some are very nice and smart, but overall, many are  incredibly cliquey, arrogant, lack maturity and do not embrace the goals of having an inclusive and diverse work culture.  If you do not like networking or working on team projects with people like this, you will have a very difficult time in this program.

Pros: IBM offers diverse job opportunities due to its size and scope which enables mulitple jobs while staying with the same company.  Historically it has attracted smart people looking for this type of single-company career, allowing for extensive long-term personal relationships.  If you are selected to be a "high potential individual" then your work assignments will change at a fairly rapid pace and compensation will rise quickly as IBM tries to retain you. (Fall off that list and your career instantly transforms into a job.)  Mangement will push you into jobs you are not ready for to test your abilities to cope.
Cons: IBM is cutting expenses in order to drive executive compensation.  They are focused on employee expense, by cutting staff and nickle and diming in the US and other developed nations, and moving work to developing nations such as India, China and  the rest of the BRIC.  This is a rather sad state of affairs, where people are losing their jobs because IBM can find other people in other nations who will do the work for significantly less.  In the short term the savings to the company are real. In the long run, the spirt of the company will be lost.

Pros:
- Flex work schedules
- One could get by all the way until retirement by doing just enough
- One could try anything from research to finance to sales to development without leaving IBM
Cons:
- Very varied policies across the company. You could be a smart guy looking to for a promotion from band 7 to 8 in one area, while in another area, people half as smart as you could be on the way to becoming band 10s.
- WAY too much politics
- WAY too much process; needed o keep a large company in order, but often makes no sense at a micro level
- You could climb up the career ladder by being at the right place, saying the right things, contacting the right people... without the need to actually be great at what you do. If you're the quiet type, forget growth here.

Pros: Depends on the project or the client, but hours are generally flexible. There are a lot of good and smart people to work with.
Cons: Pushing to make our numbers and it only gets worse every year, this year they demand we work certain weekends and are pushing for hours so much that we must average 50 hours per week over the whole year just to make up for vacation and holiday time off. Every year we lose something, they adjust something that takes money away from us and saves IBM money. In 2013, they moved the 401K match payout from payday to a lump sum at year end, and we missed out on all that interest. They moved the date raises are given to next year. They also decided not to pay out the bonuses they've paid every year since they started the program. No raise in 5+ years and I have much less to show for it. There is a major push to outsource most of the work over seas and only have about 15% of employees in the US. With so few US Employees, I get the sense that we are way too top heavy with management and all the overhead that comes with it.

Cons:

Pros: IBM has many great programs for employees to grow in all aspects of their life and career. Management is very supportive in making sure you have an opportunity to take advantage of these programs and will encourage you to push yourself. Although there are moments where deadlines are critical and workload reaches capacity, these cycles typically don't last long as management often listens and finds a way to ensure you are not working yourself thin. Everyone is very helpful and always willing to assist and give advice when needed. It is definitely a team-spirited environment,
Cons: The innovative spirit no longer exists as it once did. The goals and projects are all aligned with perception in the cloud market, where there hasn't been much focus on IBM creating its own new frontier. To this, competitors are able to take advantage of this opportunity by offering better compensation packages and more interesting projects to work on. Although, you are at the mercy of the decisions made by leadership with respect to how the company grows in relation to the market and competitors. The biggest con is going from a cloud leader to not being in the BIG three anymore where pride has taken a hit, especially if you were in it from the start. But every day we work hard to push IBM to the front of the line again and one day we shall be again.

Pros:
- Leadership development, mentoring and personal growth. This was a good place to start my career, so many talented individuals able to work with and learn from. 
- Culture of working remotely even before COVID. Fortunate able to work with a good team and good management for years that fostered this + work-life balance.
- Opportunity to work on patents / intellectual property in any job role. Come up with the idea, IBM will take care of the rest + reward financially.
Cons:
- Constant axe hanging over your head, never know if you'll have a job tomorrow due to layoffs, no matter your individual performance.
- Risk adverse. IBM prefers to buy instead of build their own. I've witnessed first hand a business proposal for a new amazing idea (containizeration in its earliest days - before Kubernetes existed) get rejected. IBM purchased Red Hat to catchup vs. take the risk internally to develop the idea. Many other examples similar to this observed over the years.
- Financial based decision making. Short term thinking at expense of long term investment. Poor bonuses due to impossible to meet company goals, frequent attrition (both voluntary and involuntary), missed strategic opportunities, etc. results from this.

Pros: Working from home a lot, very good coworkers. The pay is pretty good, but that's a legacy thing, and without raises or bonuses, you are getting a 4% cut every year with inflation. Work/life balance is good because mostly nobody is paying attention due to poor organization.
Cons: All past perks, even very inexpensive small ones, like being able to thank fellow employees for helping with something by awarding them a cheap catalog gift, are gone. Employees must pay for own internet, office supplies, etc. 401k match not given until end of year, if you make it, otherwise nil. Extremely low morale. Lack of motivation and leadership starting with the CEO (Rometti) down. Way too many layers of management. Infrastructure is old and crumbling - conference calls using old technology and often a disaster of dropped audio/video, antiquated and frustrating Notes email and calendar tools, internal websites, etc. Horrible and offensive internal performance rating system. Constant threat of being laid off ('resource action') demoralizes and distracts everyone. No raises/bonuses, few opportunities to move into other positions that are supposedly open but really aren't.

Pros: IBM is a great company to work for if you are are a self starter, go getter and self motivated. There are doing some great work around cutting edge technology such as Cloud, Watson, Analytics, Big Data.  It's a great place to work if you need work-life balance. W3 site is getting better, the new cloud platform for saving big files has become much easier.
Cons:
IBM has this concept of Blue pages Manager who are like functional managers. I have had 4-5 Managers in the course of 5 years. Most of them were okay, and have been with the company for a long time but still didn't know the inner workings of IBM, therefore couldn't really help me with career advancement.. My feeling is that they didn't want to make an effort to understand the plumbing inside IBM. My current Manager is pretty good and makes an extra effort to get me all the info re: things I can do to advance my career within IBM,

Medical Insurance sucks. If you want a fully covered plan, it can cost you $1350 per month out of pocket. If you take the high deductible plan, and if you or your family member has to go to hospital or for procedures/Xrays/ MRIs etc. you will get numerous Medical Bills in the mail.

Pros: Here's an example of what I mean by innovating to affect the world.  I just finished an exercise where I looked back at my multi-year career at IBM to see where I made a difference, not just to IBM but to my clients and beyond.   I remembered a project I helped lead for a world-class academic medical center a few years ago where we developed a first-of-a-kind piece of clinical technology in collaboration with the client using all of IBM, including hardware, software, services, industry expertise and IBM research.  That project several years ago formed the foundation of the long-term relationship that enabled us to build a Watson instance around cancer diagnosis and treatment that is enabling about 30% of their patients to live longer lives with better outcomes from treatment.   That is real impact on the lives of people.  That is what I mean by "meaningful".
Cons: IBM is in the middle of a difficult transition from a traditional hardware/software/services IT company to a new model of a cognitive and cloud company that doesn't exist anywhere yet.  In the process, there are transition pains as the company needs to meet short-term financial targets while accomplishing incredible change and metamorphosis as a company.  If you are looking for a place to come to work, do your job, and not have to deal with change for 20 years, this is not the company for you.

Pros: Great work life balance. Smart people. Secure, large company.
Cons: Big company bureaucracy is a major hassle when trying to do anything. lots and lots of politics.

Pros: Flexible, nice people, Fair to promotion
Cons: Not really too many cons

Pros: - Sky is the limit to learn, contribute and to grow at IBM ! - Excellent benefits package
Cons: Difficult to draw the line on contributing as all the opportunities are so challenging

Pros: good benifts and salaries overall
Cons: I do not nothing to mention really.

Cons: Engineering teams do not enjoy as much importance as FAANG

Pros: IBM pays very well and they have an average benefit program.  The vacation benefit is very good.  They have flexible schedules for most positions.
Cons: IBM states that they are remaining in the hardware business.  History would indicate that this is not true.  Initially they sold Storage to Hitachi.  Then they sold the Desk Top/Lap Top business to Lenovo.  They are currently in the process of selling Low End Servers to Lenovo and laying off a good portion of their Mid Size Main Frame Server employees.  Anyone accepting a job at IBM in the US hardware business should plan on a short duration at IBM.

Pros: good 401k match, avg in everything else
Cons: Poor Management which just follows the client

Cons: for the same reason as above, salaries are lower than the rest of the high tech

Cons: Too much reorgs. Every year, they shift something around.

Pros: Boomer culture still stuck in the old ways
Cons: Not a modernized benefits structure

Pros: Working remotely allows lots of flexibility
Cons: Don't really see co-workers in-person

Pros: Advancement available in many areas
Cons: Local management lack of authority

Pros: good company to be with
Cons: Lay off happen at random

Pros: the people who work there were all very nice
Cons: hit or miss client work sometimes the work can be slow

Pros: At IBM you work with some of the smartest people in the world.  It still makes me proud to have been associated with an organization that has the reputation for excellence that IBM has.  Smart people, great name, and in addition, IBM is so large that their are a glut of resources at your fingertips.  So much so, that sometimes you get so used to having so many resources that you become a little spoiled.  There is a department or a person for every possible business, sales, or service function.  The benefits are also world class.  I can remember when I started paying about $34.00 per paycheck to cover my entire family and didn't realize how inexpensive that was.
Cons: IBM is very large, but the downside to that is how long takes to do anything.  The red tape is legendary.  It takes a long time for an oceanliner to turn around.  Promotions can be slow.  Progress of any kind takes time and people like to stick to the way things have always been done.  If you have a new idea, or process, you have to move heaven and earth to get it implemented.  Management can also promote on who you know, not what you know.  But this is typical corporate america.  It goes without saying that the level of political intrigue is dense at IBM. Kissing bottom is taken to an art form and there are more angles on everything you say and do than a billiards game.

Pros: IBM is extremely progressive in work/life balance.  You can work at home pretty much whenever you want/need to.  The number of sick days is unlimited.  There are no timesheets to fill out for most professional workers.  Some employees work part time, and parental leave is up to 3 years (unpaid).  There is paid parental leave:  6 weeks for new moms, and 2 weeks for new dads.  Overall, coworkers are very helpful and willing to go out of their way to help you.
Cons: Long hours tend to be the norm at this company, and some people burn out.  The downside to working at home is that sometimes you are expected to be constantly connected.  There is a lot of schedule-driven quality (i.e. the schedule is king, and quality falls by the wayside).  Worst of all, IBM has very strict transfer rules.  You can only transfer to another department with your manager's approval, and sometimes they don't give it.  I wanted to transfer from digital design to hardware simulation, and even though the new department knew me very well and wanted me, the process took over 1 year.

Pros: The opportunity for worldwide travel. The ability to have multiple jobs without leaving a company. This is both good and bad. You'll work with some of the smartest people in the world. Flexibl work schedules. Medical dental 401k. Loads of discounts for personal use including hotels, car rental and financing, electronics, cell phone service, entertainment and many many more. Continuing education. Financial advice, maternity kits including breast pump, books and guides. Great place for a first job. The perks are too numerous to name. You just have to know about them and hope your manager does too.
Cons: Because IBM has products in so many areas, it has many competitors which means you often get stuck using IBM products instead of the best products to get your job done. No investment in its own infrastructure so it can react quickly. E.g. Archaic financial systems. I don't recommend staying with this company longer than 2 years if you have been acquired, after that you lose your sales force and the team of whichever native IBM solution is comparable to yours will start to make life difficult. Pay is not great. Except very small raises and smaller to no bonuses as a top contributor.

Pros: Great Company, Benefits, Team Members, and a chance to learn from a vast number of technologies and excel in many ways whether be it personally and or professionally. There is an abundance of resources and sometimes way too much to sift through, but non-the-less there is information about everything and anything you want to know, learn to better understand and deliver. Great place to be in and a chance to travel around, abroad, move up or parallel, meet people from around the world, and sometime literally, participate in events, conventions conferences, make a difference, make an impact not only within IBM, but within other companies, and even on a global scale. "Who said that Elephants can't dance" IBM is leading the way for future generations and companies as well.
Cons:
With Big companies, you tend to spin your wheels a little, and management will assist and help, but moving up sometimes is slow, raises are almost a rarity and sometimes frustrating. 
Best thing is to Love what you do and you wouldn't mind the minimum raise. Persevere and you'll move up, move around, or move out! Very High Demand on meeting quotas (if you are in sales or technical sales)

Pros:
- IBM has a very open and accepting culture. Everyone there is really nice and usually easy to work with.
- Good work life balance. Being out of the office for appointments, children's events, mental health, etc. is very well supported and encouraged.
- Some of the projects are cool, and it's rewarding knowing that many people depend on the software you work on.
Cons:
- I couldn't tell you how many people there are that do literally nothing and never get fired. It is infuriating feeling like you could do the same and it wouldn't matter.
- Some very talented people work here, but at the same time, many incredibly un-talented people do too which ruins the company's/team's progress.
- The pay isn't competitive. IBM will always lose it's best talent to companies with better pay, benefits, and less red tape.
- Deadlines are a mess. I'm surprised customers continue to use IBM products at times given the outages and issues that occur so frequently at the end of every quarter.
- Designing for the customer gets lost in the complexity of IBM's systems. There are so many features that seem good on paper, but are really hard to use/missing functionality that a customer actually needs.
- No one will advocate for you in your career progression - you must do so yourself.

Pros: Great team work, people help each other always
Cons: Too big and heirachical organization and culture

Cons: Toxic environment, good for sellers and bad for tech people

Cons: People discuss colleagues in a disgraceful manner. Processes such as promotion are entirely opaque. Many IBMers describe a "culture of fear" as prevalent. People hoard information/ knowledge/ ideas if it serves their interest.

Cons: You are always given the opportunity over and over until you lose it yourself.

Pros: Great company reputation.  Lots of different lines of business to move between over the course of a career.  Pretty good as far as work life balancing, especially in terms of coming up with flexible working arrangements for people with differing needs (e.g, work from home).  The stock purchase plan was pretty generous in terms of the discount versus the market.  There were always a lot of training opportunities available.  There are a lot of smart people especially in highly technical parts of the company, but the business side functions were weaker in comparison.  IBM still does offer the opportunity (though no longer the guarantee) of long term tenured employment.
Cons: Career pathing is very nebulous outside of Global Services.  Expect a slow, slow progression in your career track even if you are a strong performer.  Company is pretty conservative and not very entrepreniurial.  Managers weren't always well trained in career coaching and development skills for employees.  Although they are clear that 'you own your career', sometimes it felt more like an excuse not to have well defined career tracks instead of really empowering employees.  There were not a lot of opportunities to network with other groups in the company which also made it more difficult to take advantage of the size of the company in terms of growth opportunities.  Salaries are OK, but don't expect much in the way of incentive compensation or substantially better pay for high performance.

Pros: Excellent people to work with.  Good benefits, 401K match, managers are generally good about vacation.  There are opportunities for career growth, but one must make it one of your goals to advance.  The problem is people are so busy working, they don't spend time on planning their own career.  Another positive in IBM are the opportunities to work on patents.  Generally speaking, I found colleagues are bright and industrious.  But it's not a place for slackers.
Cons: Just like anyplace, there are some good managers and some bad managers.  Good managers open to improving the way things work, not just the way things look on a chart.  Good managers also try to develop their staff and help them advance their career interests.  Bad managers often look out for themselves, not for the staff.  They will pressure people to make unrealistic goals; do not plan well and then work everyone into the ground when the plan is broken.  Careerwise it seems to take a long time to advance unless you have been at the right place, or connect with the right people.  But that's true everywhere.

Pros:
Flexibility is great.
Work from home.
Benefits are pretty good overall.
No micro-management (this, of course, depends on division/organization and employee's skills/performance).
Annual salary reviews (depending on your performance review, you get an increase, I have always gotten an increase every single year, but in recent years that increase is about 2-3% only).
Annual performance bonus.
Cons:
Base salary paid is a little lower than other top companies in the Austin area.
Off-shoring like crazy... too many folks here in the states are getting displaced by employees and/or contractors overseas.
There's smart people anywhere in the world... but it seems that in many cases IBM just hires "global resources" without conducting a good technical interview.... and what happens next is just horrible... you, as the person facing management here in the US, then have to deal with these folks who lack technical skills and you are asked to make it work...
If you are a good and excellent software engineer, you are rewarded like this: you become the lead of some "global team" and you are left with very little time to own a component since you have to spend a lot of time on communication: many global resources do not speak English and/or lack many technical skills (sometimes the need to do baby-sitting is just too much).

Pros:
- Flexible work from home option (or anywhere there's a WiFi connection)
- Freedom. Often your Managers are in remote locations
- Travel (if you like that) Sometimes in interesting cities. Accommodations are nice
- Benefits are decent but declining
- Recognizable name on resume
Cons:
- Impersonal. You are literally a number. You are assigned a serial# on day 1 and this becomes your identity within the company
- Difficult to form relationships with colleagues. There was a complete lack of camaraderie, which fostered competition within my own team and other divisions
- Antiquated internal systems. (i.e. filling out Excel spreadsheets for job tracking purposes)
- Incompetent Managers who knew nothing of the creative process and like to play office politics, favorites and are extremely bureaucratic. Conform to the IBM way and do not speak the truth
- Expectation of 24/7 availability including weekends to meet unrealistic demands and short deadlines without any incentive
- IBM = I'm By Myself. You are your own HR, Admin, Travel Agent, Security and Office Manager and so on
- Have a question? Good luck navigating W3 (IBM's cumbersome intranet) to find answers to the simplest things
- Some office locations are deplorable. My specific mobile location was something straight out of the 80's. No perks. Not even a break room
- Their idea of training and skill growth was watching online videos, of which you are required to complete 40hrs a year on your own time
- Low morale due to constant lay-offs (or Resource Actions) and a sickening severance package of 1 month no matter how many years you dedicated your life and career with IBM

Overall, working for IBM was the worst job experience of my 15+ career as a Graphic Designer.

Your own experience will vary widely depending on the division, your managers and your working environment preferences.

Pros: Still some great people left at IBM. The ability to work from home - but now is limited only to sellers.
Cons:
-19 quarters of sales decline in a row under Ginni Rommety. 
-First/second even 3rd line managers no longer have any decision making ability. 
-The forecasting process is non stop - with more time spent forecasting and presenting sales forecasts to multiple mgrs/levels than actual selling. 
-Raises are almost non-existent and usually only 1-2%. 
-Benefits have continued to decline with healthcare contributions continuing to decrease and employee costs skyrocketing. 
-There is no longer a pension plan, the 401k match happens once a year, in January. So most silent layoffs happen in 4th qtr. 
-30 day severance is the new policy whether you have 1 year of service or 40. 

Overall company environment has gone from poor to absolutely toxic. Many of those who remain are looking to leave or actively doing so. 
-There is a huge push to cull older employees and replace with millenials with some mgrs openly stating that "that job is slated for a millenial hire".  
-I would NEVER allow my children to join the new IBM.

Pros: Career growth opportunities, benefits, management
Cons: Not many cons. Can be challenging but not bad if you are willing to put in the time.

Pros: The people at IBM are key to our success. The strategies that Arvind and the senior leaders have put together, have positioned IBM for a bright future.
Cons: IBM is a big company. Navigating the internals at IBM can be overwhelming at times.

Pros: Amazing People Great Job Wonderful work life balance

Pros: May still look good on a resume; learn about life in a large bureaucratic organization; extremely liberal work-from-home policy,
Cons: Highly matrixed organization is very difficult to navigate.  Learning curve for a new hire is daunting.  Limited training opportunities aside from on-line courses; limited advancement or growth opportunities unless a top 90th percentile or better performer; extreme bureaucracy; much administrative work has been shifted to "exempt" employees who are a fixed cost; extreme aversion to potentially career-limiting acts makes it extremely difficult to effect change -- decision-makers only make the changes they absolutely must and leave others to The Next Person;

Pros: Some of the smartest minds I have ever come in contact with, working on some technology that has, is and will continue to change the world in ways many of us don't understand.  IBM is quietly behind the scenes of so many of mankinds' biggest breakthroughs and businesses that power our economy.  To have a hand in developing and delivering this thinking and these technologies to market is an incredibly exciting opportunity.
Cons: The organization is at times, too smart for its own good.  They prefer slow and perfect over agile and testing and learning.  It is a culture that tends to avoid risk taking, with a rule and process to follow for EVERYTHING - sometimes, multiple conflicting rules for the same process.  IBM is interesting also in the sense that what makes it such a successful and valuable company (the tech intelligence/pure brilliance of its people), is what hurts it when it comes to bringing its cutting edge "stuff" to market.  IBM has a problem translating smart tech jargon into language that clients can understand in terms that address their needs.  We lead with tech, while others like Accenture, lead with problem solving and understanding the client first.

Pros:
At the time of my employment, IBM was providing a 3-month bootcamp for new hires, where they essentially walk you through how to design for an enterprise company. I felt extremely fortunate to have started my professional career with this program, as it taught you how to collaborate, organize, present, and execute outside of a college context. 

IBM's Design program also cares deeply about company culture, and hire people that I found to be some of the best to work with in my professional career. They understand that the ability to collaborate is far more important than talent alone.

Additionally, I found extensive room to grow during my career at IBM. My boss allowed us to create our own programs, such as "learning sessions" to learn, for example, Github from our front end dev, and attend conferences. Teammates who stayed on after I left were also promoted to leads to reward their growth and contributions. If you find the right team within the company, the opportunities were invaluable.
Cons: Retention. Unfortunately, the structure of this bootcamp led to lofty expectations of work environments outside of the Austin office. I gave such a high rating because I personally was very fortunate to be part of a great product we have a lot of personal control in, and saw through from research to launch. However, it really comes down to the team and the office location. The design program is large, and every experience I've heard has varied greatly, along with how long they stayed on at IBM.

Pros: I am surrounded by good people who know how to deliver high quality software. The salary seems higher than most others in the area, with a fair amount of vacation, if you include floating holidays.
Cons:
Those same people who know how to deliver software are hindered by terrible processes and decision making, some of the worst management I've experienced in more than 20 years of working in this industry. They will definitely lay off huge swaths of people at the drop of a hat. Considering that they don't seem to have much mastery in developing worthwhile products, you would be well-served by keeping some money liquid in the event of a layoff. 

Hilariously, *every* piece of software that we use internally is worst in class, including IBM's own products. Every process is ill-defined and difficult to navigate. Knowledge is not shared except through social networks.

There seems to be opportunities for software engineers to move around internally (discovered after layoffs), but I have yet to find anyone who was happy with their move. Opportunities for managers are nearly non-existent.

The benefits are terrible. I hired someone and was able to give him a sizable increase, which he lost (and then some) when he had to pay for health benefits.

Pros: Flexibility, Hybrid, Open, Cool, Good
Cons: Money, Money, Money, Money, Money

Cons: Resource cuts due to revenue and profitablity loss have been draconian in the past. It seems to be cyclical. Hours worked can be very challenging at times
