Pros:
* Brand name. IBM is #2 globally recognized brands. When you have IBM on your resume, you get very few questions. It opens several doors
* Opportunities. IBM is a huge company that has limitless opportunities. There are several people and life timers at IBM, who are yet to scratch the surface.
* Work life balance. IBM is a globally integrated organization. It encourages WFH (after the 1st year of stay at IBM). You will be surprised at how addicted one gets to using Sametime for chatting as well as for scheduling meetings.
* Culture. IBM is a very open company. It is a no non-sense company where Senior leadership is very committed to doing the right thing. IBMers have a bias for the right action.
Cons:
* Compensation. IBM brand is one of the best in the world. As a result, do not expect to be compensated heavily.
* Huge organization. Consequently, things move at a slower pace than you would normally anticipate. But, don't give up so easily. People are committed to doing the right thing and have a bias for the right action.
* Global integration is both a boon and a bain. Bain because, a lot of times you never get to see who you are working with on the other side of the table. You will recognize them by their voice and know a lot about them, but you would have never met them in your life.

Pros: Great people. Most everyone is willing to help you come up to speed. Ample time to learn and build  your skills, particularly when coming out of college. It easy to move up if your willing to take some risks and work hard, at least in software group it is.
Cons:
As a team lead, processes are more than ever to release a product. You count yourself as a full time developer yet meetings, helping the new hires because IBM pretty much only hires those out of college, you find yourself struggling to find time to write code.  

There are many people who are happy putting in there less than 40 which in some ways stagnates the group as a whole. No one is learning anything new, thus just a few key folks end up knowing much and they don't grow because the group is not educating themselves as a whole. I get it, its not a silicon valley company to have that drive but why shouldn't those who work there want to learn and grow themselves?

Pros: There is a lot of exposure to different industries. Its very easy to have a career at IBM where you can change what you are working on every few years without getting board working on a single project/technology.
Cons:
The company is too big for its own good. The company doesn't care about the employee and due to its size takes forever to approve requests for simple things like a notebook or a box of pencils. There are a number of standards that they put in place to ensure all the application have a similar design paradigm means that creativity, exploration, and progression through a fast paced ever changing world is nearly impossible. Its impossible to move up in the company, raises/bonuses are few and far between, No company outings, health care options cost more than any other company I have worked for or heard about. At the end of the day the only things the upper management cares about is whats in their paycheck, the promises made to the stockholders, and they really don't care about you as a person.

On a business note, our customers were also frustrated with the speed at which IBM moved. They need fixed, enhancements etc to compete in their market. Waiting for yearly releases just isn't possible anymore. customers need a more agile release process where they can get releases and change faster and they can put them in place more quickly and efficiently.

Pros: IBM still draws some of the best and brightest. The work can be quite interesting and challenging. And the company offers flexibility in terms of work times and locations (unless you're required to be at a client site).
Cons: There can be a strong feeling of disconnection. You may work with a team that's widely scattered or based elsewhere, and rarely if ever see them. You spend much of your time on conference calls, often at odd hours if you're dealing with colleagues in other parts of the world. Managers range from good to awful. Unfortunately, I encountered more of the "awful" than the good. And finally, career growth can be difficult to impossible. Even if you're a top performer, raises are small to non-existent. The company sets targets that never seem to be reached, at least as far as producing income for employees. The shareholders, on the other hand, almost always hear a much rosier story.

Pros: Well Educated workforce, Most employees work from their home, autonomy, Starting Salary, Opportunity to change departments.   Negotiate for your salary upfront during the hiring process as that is when you have the best leverage and power to negotiate.   Salary ranges at IBM are huge.
Cons: Low salary increases with several years of no salary increases during my 18 years of employment with an MS degree.  Twice I had to take pay cuts to keep my job by moving to a different department,  Minimal commitment to continuing education through internal or external education.  Little support for external industry certifications which are valued by companies.  High Management churn as I had 14 managers in 18 years and only 2 of those managers are still with the company, Benefits have been cut over the years, Stock purchase plan is poor.  Many groups compete against one another.  Many patents but few new products.  The company changed greatly during the 18 years I worked there.  Most of the company growth is through acquisitions.

Pros: My managers and groups I was a part of were great. They were very understanding, no micro-managing, my schedule was mostly my own, and everyone was very patient in training, explaining, and teaching me. It felt sort of casual but I worked in the research division so this does not reflect the company overall. Also, I felt like I was a part of a team and valued for my work but that I was also allowed to not know something. Almost everything I did and knew was from working there, not from school, because people took the time to teach and explain stuff to me.
Cons:
I did not feel valued by the company at large, so by upper management above my own manager. I was pigeonholed by one high level manager and deemed invaluable to the company because of this view held by said manager. The research division is full of contractors and supplementals and only PhDs can get permanent positions there. The basic message I received from this is that the company doesn't want to invest in anyone who isn't 100% exactly what they wanted coming in. With that said, there could be groups that align with this viewpoint as well and I just happened to end up in groups that didn't.

Another con, for contractors at least, is that they bullied me during salary negotiations. We agreed on a salary and then when it reached for the final approval, they demanded we lower it by 15%.

Pros: Great experience for college or grad school hires; smart, team-oriented colleagues; some really interesting projects at the leading edge of technology; very committed to diversity in the workforce (other than age); excellent benefits although becoming less excellent; committed to highest level of ethical behavior in the market and with customers; good name to have on resume; work at home when not on site helps with balance, but that's changing.
Cons: 20 consecutive quarters of revenue decline has caused panic and highly reactive management behaviors; large "job actions" (layoffs) every quarter that used to be solidly about losing low performers but last four events even top tier performers are being let go; so much turnover in customer facing roles that its hard to know who you work with, several SW sales roles on an account have churned twice a year for three years; committed to paying just below average; difficult to get through interview and hiring process; quarterly focus now monthly focus; laid off employees are now declared off limits for re-hiring or contracting in some roles; bringing in lots of outsiders with a very transactional view of the world, bad in a relationship business; gloom and fear have driven morale down.

Pros: It is a good name, looks good on the resume. If you worked here, you are probably smart and that should help you.
Cons:
There is a book , "A View from Beneath the Dancing Elephant".
I did not read it, but the title is great. There is a saying, "RAs are family matter", such as people actually try to make a living and support families while the elephant is stumping around them.

Very bureaucratic and inhuman, people are only resources. If you spend at least 3 years here, you will notice that half of the people you worked with are gone by that time. Extreme amount of talent is let go by the constant RAs. At the same time the company is hiring new people for the same skill set. I have not seen any effort to match existing talents with opportunities. I actually would like to see proactive management of the work force by constant training, re-training, cross-training according to the changing need of the company.

Benefits are getting more and more expensive, compensation is stagnant with zero inflation adjustment.

This year's most important stuff is "diversity and inclusion" and giving people lessons about the "unconscious bias", but this seems to be an attempt to tap into cheap labor even more. What about professional competency, which itself would include the above already?

Look elsewhere and do not waste your time here.

Pros:
The managers I worked for were excellent.   Had a voice in proposed changes and improvements.
Built a personal brand over a 21 year career.
Cons:
Agist.  Started recieving emails at age 55 asking " Have you considered IBM early retirement Plan" : never responded becaus I had no interest.
Three months before my 60th birthday got an email "Why haven't you chosen the IBM early retirement plan?"
There was a link were you could explain.
I clicked the link and explained that due to a divorce I could not financially afford to retire and I love my job and have no interest in leaving.
IBM layed me off 4 days after my 60th birthday.
When I went to a initial meeting with an outplacement agency that IBM had hired; sitting with 30 people I asked " Who is from IBM, and who has 15 or more years of service.  All but 2 hands went up and those two were from different employers.
I did not ask anyones age but based on physical appearance no one was under 50.
We all had to sign the "Will not sue" document to get one months severance pay"  I had 21 years there.

Pros:
As a current IBM employee, it depresses me sometimes to think back on my past employers and just how many of those workplaces were managed by "man/woman-children" who -- more often than not -- let emotion and personal biases control the daily decisions they make. At those places, *genuinely* good ideas by lower-level staff would be ignored 100% of the time if the idea somehow threatens the manager’s brittle ego or even *slightly* increases their workload. These were Tywin Lannister-wannabes I’m talking about – that view their employees as a group of undisciplined children requiring constant supervision, restricting the tiniest of freedoms and establishing authority by reprimanding non-offenses. For these "control-gestapos", managing isn't the goal. Coasting through a life of upper-middle class perks and authority (in title only) is their only motivation. They inhibit any and all culture and creativity from a work environment and drain the lifeforce out of their staff. Sirius Black would never have escaped if Azkaban had a swarm of micromanagers flying around in black hoods. I will be honest with you here… I consider each and every single one of these Putin-sympathizing, workplace-tyrants out there actively defiling our country’s workplaces to be my eternal arch-rivals. 

I guess what I’m trying to say here is IBM does a good job of saying “do this thing by the end of the month” and leaving you alone.
Cons: You will be constantly losing roles to other IBM-employees who are more qualified because their CV shows they previously worked in a similar role.

Pros: I had a great team and a great manager which made my experience at IBM very positive for the most part despite constant internal churn with reorganizations, leadership changes and compensations issues. However, after my departure I would not recommend working at IBM.
Cons:
I left to take an opportunity outside of IBM in February of 2022. I had overall great experience working at IBM over my 3 years at the Company. Upon putting in my two weeks I was immediately notified with 1 hour that it would be my last day. 

I had ended the previous fiscal year FY 2021 at 176% of my sales quota. After waiting 6 plus months to receive payment of my commissions I was notified that I would not be compensated for any of the deals that closed in Q4 of FY'21

I was eliminated from the payment sales pool from one of my deals. The IBM team justified that because I was no longer working at the company in FY'22 I did not deserve to be compensated as part of the team. The deal was closed in December of 2021. 

On another deal, again, the IBM team justified that because I no longer work at IBM and I did not sign a quota for FY'22 that I am not entitled to compensation under the FY'21 compensation plan which I did sign.

IBM is notorious for setting up Sales Plans and not compensating its Sales Team in a fair manner. In addition, IBM does not pay on time. IBMer's are still waiting to be compensated for December 2021 commissions.

Pros: IBM is an organization that fosters innovation and has a winning philosophy of understanding client needs view consulting relationship's and linking those to innovative software and technology solutions.
Cons: A large organization which may cause some to feel a bit lost in the shuffle.

Pros: Steady work and projects. Good balance
Cons: Slow and steady projects. Good balance

Pros: Work-life integration Compassionate leadership Diversity and Inclusion
Cons: Incentives for non sales employees

Pros: Good people and overall nice offices
Cons: Boring technology at this company and poor read on market

Pros: Nice co to work for. Excellent HR benefits
Cons: Ok ok tech exposure for techies. Not so much learn to new ( in my project) They got split to Kyndryl which is worst

Pros: Great Work culture here at IBM
Cons: There are not enough educational benefits

Pros: Company is good unless you are in a bad account.
Cons: Salary is very low compared to the current market

Pros: Managers were great Team size is decent and was easy to work together
Cons: Too many meetings with not much results. Wasted valuable time. Tasks were vague and unclear which lead to unnecessary meetings for clarity.

Pros: Amazing learning opportunities Great work culture Supportive work-life balance
Cons: Onboarding was tricky and a bit overwhelming Huge company = bit lost on where to find information

Pros: good wlb, decent compensation, good benefits
Cons: can't leave in the first year or you have to pay back bonus, inefficient staffing

Pros: Talented, motivated, supportive team culture.
Cons: At times, the left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing.

Job Title: Senior counsel - legal and business affairs
Pros: Big internal support network to reach out with questios
Cons: At times, IBM can feel too large

Pros: I have been with IBM over thirty years and what was the best company in the world to me is now a very sad place to work. Our department shrank, the smartest employees left for better jobs, and all of us left are over-worked with little time for family life. Weekend work has become routine with very little time for a day or two off to catch a break and enjoy life. I will be leaving soon enough with memories of the best company in the world turned into the greatest story tellers (liars) I have ever seen. They over promise and under deliver because all the best people have left IBM usually by mass firings. I'm sorry, there are no PRO's to working here. I am not bitter or angry, just sad to see what we turned into.
Cons: Lies, all the time to clients without much truth being told. They sell services that have not been tried or tested. If they only practiced what they preach, then IBM would be a much better place to work.

Pros: Referring only to consulting services parts of business: Access to great clients. Name recognition of company provides more client experience opportunities overall. Med and 401K benefits are above average. Better employer value for somewhat unskilled working to gain industry experience, though it can be a commodity environment; lower-level candidates will have more "advancement" opportunity. More financially rewarding for those with strong sales focus and can-do on targets, due to large-public-corp and quarterly profits imperatives for top executive reward.
Cons: Sales goals set at upper management levels often unrealistic, and lower levels penalized with little financial accountability at the top. Client sales numbers are often the incentive, not intelligent or great client delivery as foundation. This is always reflected in your annual reviews, which don't even contain factors that really reflect excellent delivery over the "push more across" factors. Productivity targets are unrealistic for the practitioner, with negative impact for training (which is practically nil opportunity except OJT) or off-time benefits in calcs. Often there is a failure (observed) to recognize resource-in-hand capabilities, with a hire-and-go mentality for commodity skills, without understanding or leveraging the value of can-execute and can-complete-on-time and as-scoped experience. Poor top-to-bottom coordination for doing the right job, with frequent lack of pass-through executive-field understanding of the realities of delivering value to clients, or what is practical and achievable.

Pros:
The talent within IBM is committed and strong.  Opportunity, if you can find it at your site, can lead to some growth. 
There has been some hiring of new college hires, which is a breath of fresh air.  
IBM has a long and storied history that can do more for it's employees, shareholders and Society.
Cons:
Co -Location is bastardization of Agile as only 30% of Agile teams are actually Co-Located!  Strategic and Secondary site strategy and co-location are taking opportunity for job movement and career growth away from employees, so employees will feel dead ended and less motivated.  
Too much of the talent has High years of service with what appears to be little to no interest to hire personnel to retain the skills.  That older talent is fast becoming jaded by poor treatment and resentful of new hires, and demotivated to achieve let alone grow skills.

Pros: Great pay, salary and culture!

Pros: IBM Corporation has transformed into a company focused on Cognitive and Cloud solutions.  The company has embraced open source software such Ubuntu server, CentOS server, xCAT server, and OpenStack in its  solutions.  In addition, the business introduces employees to various technologies such as InfiniBand, SAS, Fibre channel, virtualization, automation environments (Robot, Chef, Puppet, Jenkins server), and Cloud services (Watson).  As an employee, first line managers have provided flexibility in work schedules to handle personal matters.
Cons: Vertical career growth in several business units is slow process.  Employees need to actively seek out opportunities in key growth areas within company to avoid getting locked into low growth projects and eventually laid off.  Although the company provides exposure to many technologies, aggressive schedules and working many projects/hours limits employees time to explore and gain deep understanding of new technologies.  Some managers provide flexibility for employees to address family matters.  However, flexibility and work-life balance aren't the same.  Engineers and technical positions should anticipate long hours and working on weekends.

Pros:
Great place to network and meet like minded individuals.
Good place to gain insight into the business side of software contract work.
Good position to add to your resume.
Cons:
I can break down the cons of my experience at IBM CIC Baton Rouge into 3 categories: 1. Pay 2. Management. 3. Projects 

1. The pay at the Baton Rouge CIC is low comparatively and relatively. I personally worked there for ~3 years, and was still earning under $50k annually as a developer. 

 2. Management is out of touch with the developers. When things don’t go as planned, management fails to take ownership over developers. Overall, management doesn’t care about developers. They only seem to care about developers charging hours to a project so they meet their numbers. These, among other, managerial issues are deeply rooted in the CIC. I have seen similar issues brought up to upper management, and sadly, little or nothing is done to address the issue's root cause. Instead management’s usual solution is to throw the CIC a pizza party or send you cookies to show you that they “care”.

3. I worked on 6 different projects while at the CIC, and only 2 of the 6 were quality. One of the “projects” I was assigned was for RI Dept of Health working as a call center operator scheduling covid tests for kids and teachers. Overall quality of projects is not great.

Pros: tons of resources, good benefits.
Cons: So large that it can be slow to react

Pros: Technology leadership, good skill development, fair compensation

Pros: Even tho I was with the company for nearly 20 years before retiring, it always seemed like any day could be your last.  I can't think of much good to say. They have a 401k program like most, but did away with their pension plan which provided very little.  They have a mental health program, primarily because they need it for their stressed out employees.
Cons: You have a choice, work at least 1980 hours per year (if US based) by giving up your vacation & other time off or take your time off and work overtime to make up the difference.  Every employee is measured on that.  It used to be in the reviews before someone sued them. It's all about sales... sometimes it's revenue and sometimes its GP, but it's always something and it's always about the quarter and Wall Street.  They can never get away from utilization because it would impact their share price too much.

Pros: I have had the pleasure of working with some of the most intelligent people that I have ever worked with – true pioneers of the semiconductor art.  I have driven yields in the fab,  negotiated ground rules with the fab, drawn the circuit, drawn the mask set, measured the circuit in the lab, and seen the parts packaged and shipped to create a high profit for the company.  A wonderful experience that I believe cannot be achieved in todays myopic segregated work approach.
Cons: I have seen these phenomenally intelligent and driven people quit and get laid off by the scores in accordance with the 2015 roadmap.  The onset of “matrix management” and other fad management procedures cripple the innovative foundations of the microelectronics group.  IBM does not want to “produce” competitive microelectronics anymore.  They are focusing on software and services.  However, I believe that this is still a great company for software engineers, and project managers.  I would warn against IBM for electronic/chemical engineers (USA).

Pros: Company name recognition, excellent pay, opportunity for advancement as long as you are not on the resource list
Cons: NO job security, sales quotas not attainable any longer because they are not even close to being realistic, products and services are in decline and not even competitive, R&D is almost non existant, and even when you do an excellent job you could still be resourced for no cause

Pros: Was technically a job. Some of the people I worked with were nice.
Cons:
I left and doubled my salary. I expect to quadruple my salary within the next 5-10 years. I had an interview with an elite development team and never responded after seeing life outside IBM. 

THERE ARE NO RAISES. THERE ARE NO PROMOTIONS. "YOU ARE LUCKY TO HAVE A JOB."

Want a raise? "You're lucky you HAVE a job." They paid me around 30,000 despite having a 4 year degree and providing training for the entire office. They "pay overtime" on top of this, but overtime is not allowed/never approved. If you are forced to work overtime and complain about it, you will be randomly selected as a poor performer and fired. 

Many North American jobs are going to India / Brazil / Argentina.

Anybody they hire, which they don't actually hire people by the way, are severly undertrained for their position. It's quite literally people off the street. One of the people on my team was a basketball player, for example.

Disagree with illegal practices, i.e. threatening to fire people for not working free overtime? "If you don't like it, why don't you quit?" (This is probably why IBMs centers are largely in areas with no job competition).

Somebody sexually harasses you or makes a racist remark so you file a complaint? What a coincidence, you've been selected as one of the North American mass firing targets. Certainly no correlation to the team of lawyers that showed up to plan your firings for weeks!

Coffee is considered a luxury. If you are a "whiney complainer" about things like "Not being paid your legally agreed upon salary" then they will threaten to take this away. Nothing else is free.

Pros: Amazing people to work with at IBM
Cons: Bad locations, no cabs to go to office

Cons: IBM expects their employees to be SME's

Pros: I really can't think of any.  Maybe the IBM name and reputation but even that is questionable these days.
Cons: Mandatory voluntary overtime.  Basically, you have to work 10% overtime to get a good review.  You need an excellent review to be considered for a raise.  Promotions are given only after a lengthy process of 'proving your worthy' through a ton of paper work and multiple levels of management approvals.

Pros: IBM is probably the best company on earth that has successfully incorporated work/life balance into its business culture. IBM helps the world get a little bit more green by supporting its employees flexible workplace options and thus help reduce consumption of fossil fuels for commuting. IBM for the most part exhibits tolerance towards diversity and different backgrounds and truly incorporates diversity into its business model.
Cons: There is very little career prospects or skills growth opportunities once you join at IBM at any given level. New projects and job opportunities are handed to known and safer contacts within the department and there is very little if any cross-departmental hiring (huge silo mentality). It is near impossible to get promoted and very difficult to get reasonable salary increases even if you put in years of your life with hard work and dedication for client success. Constant threat of off-shoring and reorganizing people at the whims and fancies of executives and low-morale of the employees.

Pros:
- Access to vast information resources
- Professional environment
- World-class corporate reputation
- Excellent place to build a foundation en route to a better job
Cons:
- Zero investment in developing people, for instance, no formal commitment to ongoing training but plenty of pressure on consultants to train and obtain certifications while trying to remain billable
- Contradictory environment in which IBM controls consultants' deployments on engagements but consultants bear the risk of not being utilized
- Awkward, ineffective, and frustrating evaluation system which penalizes consultants for not having evaluations but fails to censure project leaders who fail to provide evaluations
- Growing practice to place timeline over quality
- Compartmentalization of roles and delivery practices making cross-training in another discipline practically impossible and virtually ensuring the diminishment of a consultant's value when practice areas mature or IBM decides to withdraw from that particular business
- A somewhat peculiar corporate culture typified by a "guilt trip" work ethic which often leads the leadership to fill their agenda with volumes of special projects of little or no real value. (This may explain why IBM has so many internal systems which seem to do the same thing).

Pros: Work from home was allowed at any time, no questions asked. No hour tracking or anyone making sure I was meeting quotas as long as I was getting my work done.
Cons:
The team moved slowly, and individually. There was no sense of teamwork or camaraderie, only individuals with tasks. This was exacerbated by the fact that upper management was forcing the departments into Agile, which led to employees used to doing waterfall to simply do waterfall with iterations. Agile was used entirely as an hour tracking tool for the bosses to send angry emails every day based on their pointless charts, which were based on numbers that everyone was making up.

As a 20something, being the only one in a sea of long time employees with the next youngest employee being in their 30s is a bit of a shock. The fact that IBM only hires college hires or internal makes for the young ones to want to leave, and the internals to result in an echo chamber where no one advances the team. To have to use a version control system whose last major update was in 1995 is insane and will scare off any new talent to a more modern company (where modern in this case could be someone using CVS...).

Pros: The flexibility is great. You can work whenever and wherever within reason.  You can work on a variety of technologies and switching jobs within IBM is not very difficult.
Cons:
Read the below for details, but in short, stay away, there are just so many other better companies to work for that will offer you better career opportunities, compensation and a humanizing work environment. 

The benefits and compensation are truly average. Every year I have been here they have taken something away from the employees, for example: free coffee, water jugs, pay coffee(yes they took that away), subsidized cafeteria food, team social events, site social events, tennis courts (closed down due to disrepair), employee stock purchasing plan went from 15% deduction to 10%, 401k is not matched but once a year instead of per pay check which for those who don't get it means you can't earn money that you don't have until they pay out at year end....assuming they haven't fired you.  They have had consistent layoffs or selling of technology since 2009 reducing the local site almost 50%.  I understand every company has had to adjust in the current economic climate, but match the above w/ IBMs record Earning Per Share numbers and astronomical revenues and it's a simple formula. Upper management is attempting to meet ludicrous goals at the expense of it's employees.

Pros:
Executed tasks such as updating and closing incidents, completing changes, addressing and completing service requests, and updating database fields and analyzing customer requests.  Generated customer reports, satisfied nonstandard data, gathered requests, provided analyses and recommendations, and completed root-cause analysis reports (RCA).
•	Handled supervisory responsibilities for global and national customer accounts and served on-call responsibility for all accounts.  Provided standby responsibility for accounts on 24/7 basis.  Analyzed device utilization rates to identify unused devices, which increased utilization by 40%.  
•	Provided Blackberry coverage for all customer accounts. Upgraded accounts from Blackberry to Mobile Device Management. Demonstrated focus on severity issues, change management, business controls/security compliance, and SLA methodology.  Assisted with roll-out server upgrades.
•	Troubleshot server issues, reviewed server logs for analysis of problems, and found root cause of server crashes.  Worked with Vendors for resolutions.  Made recommendations to clients for device and release upgrades to prevent future issues, 90% of which clients scheduled. 
•	Supported MobileIron Portal Enterprise Services; Configured iPads, iPhones and Android wireless devices; Deleted and reassigned devices for new users; performed monthly maintenance on Traveler Servers; performed 2nd level support for iOS and Android devices.  Supported day to day tasks and collaboration while leading team and supporting all team members.
•	Performed team side-by-side coaching and cross-training for all team members.  Developed cross-training materials.  Provides capacity planning solutions.
Cons: No Cons selected for this position

Pros: Great benefits Great team Great pay
Cons: A company being so big sometimes you can get lost

Pros: There are a number of highly motivated, smart, ethical peers employed by IBM Global Services.  The outsourcing business, in particular, is a hotbed of creativity.  IBM Global Services has, in many cases, done an excellent job in de-centralizing decision making to allow the creative juices to flow in developing client-facing solutions.  IBM's propensity to allow people to work from just about anywhere is a highly satisfying policy.  In most cases, they truly do not care where or when you do the work, just as long as you get it done.  They expect each employee to get it done well and on time.
Cons: Management can be less than completely forthcoming at times.  The executive review of work completed under very stressful circumstances can be frustrated.  Occasionally, executives do not reveal all of their motivations such that the end product can be architected to meet all expectations during the first run through.  The compensation for high performing non-management sales types has room for improvement.  A downside of the current environment is no clear sight in to career advancement opportunities.  Highly qualified people can be stuck in the wrong position for too long.  The annual "chipping away" of the non-salary benefits programs, which may be true of many companies, is a source of irritation.

Pros:
- Constant learning and ample work on interesting projects
- Ability to work across business units and geographies
- Ability to span different areas in your function or general area of expertise
- In general, some smart and nice people at most levels
- Flexibility in work arrangements
Cons:
- Frustrating to navigate many needlessly complicated processes and tools, as well as multiple levels of managers to get what you need to do your job.  This just eats into productive time to do real work and add the value I was hired for
- Eroding workforce in most mature markets, which shifts more work for same or less pay (with longer hours) to those remaining
- Pay packets are deliberately less competitive in most local market conditions, because "they can be"
- Other declines in benefits (e.g., healthcare, retirement)

Pros:
There are no smarter people than IBMers.
The diversity is real and most appreciated
Coworkers are awesome...IBMers are special people
Concern for the community is great...lots of outreach opportunities
Cons:
IBM is in trouble at the moment.  It needs to learn how to act a lot faster, and has tons of catch-up work to do to get to the level of a Google or Apple in speed of execution and delivering innovation to the marketplace.  This could be an opportunity for people looking for that challenge.

There are a lot of well paid people in IBM that don't really understand how the work is done.  This slows down the delivery of new innovation and make setting clear realistic goals difficult.  Hoping leaders realize Agile applies to them first, but I'm not seeing much sign of this beyond a few videos.

Pros: The culture amongst IBM's engineers is one of collaboration and cooperation. I really liked that primary communication was done through chat, not email, and that engineers were generally immediately helpful in getting others unblocked. Combine that with the fact that the engineering core is highly competent, very driven, and run a broad range of experience levels, and you have a very efficient and effective work environment.
Cons: IBM's executives have been gutting the company to keep an earnings-per-share promise from a decade ago. US workers continue to be laid off in big chunks, replaced with cheaper labor in China and India. Furloughs have also become commonplace, meaning that their otherwise middle-of-the-road compensation is actually below market averages. Their intent to unburden themselves of their hardware holdings is quite clear despite their clumsy attempts at veiling that "secret", which means that the remaining loyal workers are facing an uncertain future.

Pros: To succeed at IBM, you need to be entrepreneurial and take initiative. If you sit around and wait for someone to tell you what to do and how to do it, you might not like the results. If you have a vision, are a good communicator, and don't mind putting in the elbow grease, then you can have a lot of fun building out programs, products and technologies (depending on your skillset) that have the potential to affect a great many people and industries.
Cons:
If you're a pessimist, you'll probably focus on how long it can sometimes take to see progress. It does take patience and vigilance. It's a big ship to turn, so it might be especially difficult for people coming in early in their career or from a small business or startup environment. It's all a matter of perspective. I also think the HR practices are a bit outdated, but that doesn't affect most people's day to day life. 

Another issue that has come up more recently is the sheer volume of new hires from the outside not being vetted sufficiently for a fit with culture and values. It's great to have a lot of fresh thinking, but it's hard to tell who has integrity, who can deliver in this complex environment, and who is just a stuffed shirt.

Pros: Good work/life balance. Exciting marketing announcements and investments. Front line employees have good intentions. Brand recognition on your resume. Ability to work from home.
Cons: Very low employee morale. Customer relationships and influence eroding due to legacy products/services, archaic pricing models, company inflexibility, lack of agility, employee turnover, and customer audits. Very high employee turnover, oftentimes within the ranks of the best and brightest. Company culture does not encourage sticking your neck out, transformative ideas, ways of doing things. Getting things done internally takes a herculean amount of effort due to stifling bureaucracy. Tribal knowledge as a substitute for thorough training. No one has any real decision making ability until you reach the Vice President level. Centralized directives oftentimes ignore local market realities. Constant threat of layoffs creates a culture of desperation and fear.

Pros: Great family and great culture to work with
Cons: Long hours and very little pay

Pros: People are nice. Management can be nice, but varies.
Cons: Continuing to shrink and politics at work as company downsizes

Pros: good pay and will learn a lot
Cons: long hours/work after hours at times.

Pros: very great pay, got rich
Cons: very toxic environment, yuck ew

Pros: You can get certs and free training for certs that about the only pro about rocket center
Cons: I have never worked for a company to exploit its employees like this one does. 80hr weeks, the min is "44" and you get paid for 40 hrs. Zero compensation. Rocket Center Management is so out of touch with reality, they hire from outside of the area and those employees leave and they think its because they are not from here.... they leave because you MIGHT make 45k so they are targeting locals to exploit because they think they won't leave. Management also wastes money on "video game nights" so zero holiday bonus like a respectable company gives.. Rocket center is a revolving door and about a 50% or more turn around rate, employees never stay because the paid is band 4 and they have you listed as band 11 and you work 80hrs and every single holiday, 7 days a week. They do no look into why a project was lost, its your fault and you will be punished. You feel like a slave and you can't stand up for yourself because you fear losing your job, its yes Master and thats it. Salary is modern salvery. I could go on but read the rest of the reviews... nothing has changed in the last 3+ years.

Cons: None so far. I wish IBM would give a bonus.

Pros: Let me first say I have worked for IBM Global Business Services for a relatively long time (8 years).  Pros include a fairly good benefits package and decent salary.  IBM brand recognition also helps your resume a little, but the brand recognition is for software and servers, not consulting.  There is a decent number of fairly intelligent peers you work, although the numbers are declining.  It's a good place to go for a year or so to gain technical skills then leave.
Cons: IBM GBS has morphed into one of the poorest run entities in business.  Communication is silent within the organization.  This is because there is nothing but bad news for employees.  Revenue and earnings are growing astronomically while employee raises and bonuses have been trending the opposite direction just as fast.  This same pattern has gone on since 2002. This year IBM has decided to skip promotions to save money yet raise what is known as the skill level for promotion qualified employees so they can bill them for more.  IBM and its senior management are extremely money hungry and employees are treated like chumps (and you are a chump if you continue to work for such a firm).  Its very sad, but you're not a consultant just a person you provides IBM with a source of income.  Expect nothing in return.  In fact, top rated employees with the highest evaluation rating were recently laid off after being "on the bench" for two weeks.

Pros:
Most of the "PROS" were diminished from 2008 until I left, but they were:

PBCs: In the beginning, your goal was to support the goal of your direct manager. You were treated as a professional and given the ability to define how you would support those goals, and you were measured by the success. This meant something, at least in the departments I was in, for many years.  In recent years,they became a joke. 

WFH: This was a blessing for a long time, it afforded work/life balance.  It became a means for 24x7 days as commitments were outsourced around the globe.
Cons: Bungee Cord Management, obvious use of "3" rankings to push out those with the most experience, due to their higher salaries and age.  This became routine over the years, when we witnessed star performers get shoved out the door and we grappled with covering their responsibilities.  Those of us left to pick up the pieces knew their performance was NOT weak.

Pros: I loved IBM when I first started working here years ago.  But much of what I loved no longer exists - including respect for employees and trustworthy management and a fun working environment - yes, it was fun!  However, the only benefit to working at IBM these days is the flexible work schedule and the ability to work from home.
Cons: The constant layoffs (at least one or 2 RAs per year involving 3K to 5K US employees, each time, for 5 years now), and the various incentive programs to increase attrition make IBM an extremely dismal and demoralizing place to work.  IBM has more recently stooped to increasing the quota percentage of negative appraisals across target organizations.  These "3" appraisals identifying "lowest contributors" are a way of avoiding costly layoffs for which IBM annually takes a $1 billion restructuring charge.  So, by falsely and unfairly identifying hard-working employees as "3" performers, IBM is able to force these people out without severance packages.  These appraisals are not fair, and long-time, hard-working IBMers are being cheated out of their severance as those targeted for the "3" appraisal generally have enough years to collect the maximum 6 months severance through an RA.

Pros: Lots of opportunity if you're willing to put in the hours, follow their policies and practices, and get a little bit lucky selling business and working for and with good people, of whom there are plenty. Decent benefits. Lots of resources, but can be difficult to locate, access, and utilize
Cons: Living with no raise in the last six years because I'm not rated in the top 5% of performers. Performance rated by people who know nothing about you and have very limited input and criteria. Promotions available but require tedious documentation, changing criteria, evaluation by people who again know nothing about you, other than what you put on your personal sales document soliciting a promotion, and have sales expectations, which is not where I or many want to go. No pension any more and 401K contribution diminishing.

Pros: Being honest there are some.  lLet me start by sayign this is not a review based on feeling its based on fact. There are a wide range of exciting topics to work on and wide range of departments to work in.  Depending on where you live and who your direct management is will greatly effect your experience.   Great experiences however, used to be a norm,  most all , 80% had great experiences. No one is perfect.  But in today's culture its the opposite.  20% are happy 80% are looking for new jobs or are just trying to hang on
Cons: IBM describes its self as a large ship.  Well the ship is sinking..... IBM has brought on a new set of executive management.  None of which know IBM and each of them trying to put their own spin on how things should be reorganized.   I am very very disappointed in how IBM is treating its employees.  There is zero loyalty and concern for the best part of the company "its incredible employee base"   My recommendation is to run far far away.   If you like working tons of extra hours, with zero work life balance ( which used to be a great benefit for IBM) and zero appreciation from upper management then this is your company.  You will see many new reviews on how wonderful IBM is.  This is because new people are being hired and have yet to experience the true company.

Pros: Good work life balance Benefits
Cons: Not great culture No guidance

Pros: You have the option of coming in between 7am-9am so it's impossible to be late to work, hopefully. You can skip your lunch and leave an hour early but I heard that may depend on if your manager likes you or not.
Cons: IBM is contracted by Pepsi, so you are required to enter in all of your work that you completed at the end of the day and they act as if the world is coming to an end if you don't. It's pretty much a tracking device to see how productive you are. There is completely no organization. There have been so many re-orgs that everything is such a mess. Account officers seem to work against you but your relationship with them determines how successful you are in the position. Managers act like they're always in a bad mood and not very helpful and they are will LIE to your face like it's nothing. The morale is low and the employees there are disgruntled.  Everyone is now hired as a contract worker. You get no vacation time and no benefits. Don't believe the story that you'll get hired on full-time after a full year.  LIES!!! They'll just renew your contract. You're better off applying directly to Pepsi. Better culture and pay!

Pros: Well known, industry leading software guru.  Great benefits.  Nice colleagues.  Competitive pay.  Hiring new graduates like crazy!
Cons: Unfortunately this major giant has been going through major growing pains, or should I say, major shrinking pains for the past couple years.  If you're lucky enough to not be laid off this quarter, expect your product list, territory and client assignments to change next quarter, and every 6 months thereafter.  Rather than sell/grow and expand, you are constantly having to rebuild a new territory and provide major damage control to unhappy customers, all while attempting to exceed a mind numbing impossible to reach quota - just in time for the next 6 month switch-a-roo!  Way too many incredible industry leader colleagues burned out and left or those who stayed have been laid off for replacement new graduate hires.  Serious lack of upward mobility - I was offered 3 amazing promotions from other managers during my 4 years in Sales - all denied by my hiring manager.  Explanation was consistently "the needs of the business" demand you stay in your role.  This type of bird cage mentality will never work for top notch sales reps.  People do not leave companies, they leave managers....for IBM, it's both.

Pros: Lots of challenging opportunities available, and being a large company, IBM offers a large variety of projects for you to work on. The people are nice and generally hard working.  If you want to find another project to work on, your manager will work with you and not stand in your way.
Cons: The only time I heard anything about work-life balance was at New Hire Orientation.  After that, hours could sometimes be 70 hours a week, and almost every weekend required working, with no recognition from management.  If you do something you think you deserve credit for, it's up to you to speak up -- no place for a shrinking violet who waits for good things to come.  This isn't just because it's a large company, it also happens on smaller projects and teams.

Pros: Looks good on the resume it seems.  POTENTIAL to be involved in some really nice stuff.  Keeps you aware of what is out there.   Likely ability to work from home.  New hires may get to use macs.
Cons:
Unbelievably confusing company - everything has a non-intuitive name of blue___ which makes internal website a complete disaster.  Links to links to links....takes 5-6 steps to perform a basic operation.  Lotus notes is the worst email client i've ever seen.  

Basically, simple things such as finding and filling out information actually becomes a huge task which wastes your time.  

Layoffs are constant.  You are a number and everything you do is largely solely tied to your utilization in consulting.  Working with offshore IBM - which is now most of IBM - is worse than imaginable.  All the offshore IBMers literally need a checklist of things to do or they won't do anything.    

You will be blamed/insulted/stressed for not being 'billable' despite it only being senior director/partner level employees who can get you on one or sign one.  As a consultant/senior consultant/manager consultant you are completely at the mercy of random luck and getting stuck on some project which probably has nothing to remotely do with your skills.

Pros:
Great colleagues, including very supportive lower management.

Global opportunities - Able to transfer to other geographies (with company need/approval).

Was flexible about working from home, until mid-2016, when IBM decided on how it would interpret "Agile" * (see Cons)
Cons:
*  As a result of IBM's idea of Agile, everyone must go to their office (or nearest hub office), every working day, regardless of what they're working on or whether they're in a team - As a result, many great engineers were forced to leave, as they were unable to comply with this directive (in contravention of prior agreements) - Thus, there has been a sizeable increase to IBM's _real_ carbon footprint (But, who is accounting for all this extra pollution?).

Ever-diminishing morale, as ongoing cuts are made to Systems group, leaving those who remain increased workloads and low job security.

Even after jumping through all the hoops, like writing publications and filing (questionable) patents, employees can still end up being RA'd (laid off).

Too much focus on end of quarter results (and how these can be manipulated to justify the board decisions and the new company direction, regardless of the overall falling revenue).

Pros: - Brilliant colleagues - Work-life balance - Benefits - Vacation
Cons: - Lack of social activities for new joiners. The induction process was especially painful with everyone working remotely.
