Able to take long lunches and leave early for the day without anyone noticing. Company sponsored events are fun, including baseball games and trips to Minneapolis. Good stepping stone to finding a better job in the cities.
Cons: Finance is drastically underpaid compared to other companies. Intense boredom is common. Some days I go the entire day without doing any work at all. If you give the impression that you have improved your role and eliminated work, you are rewarded with more responsibility and work added to your role with no additional pay increase. New hires are trained by the person who had the role previously, if the previous worker is already gone, you are in trouble.  They used to order pizza for quarter close but the expense was hurting IBM's earnings, so they cut that out. They sell the dream of being promoted to the New York location, but that rarely materializes.

Pros: Technology. Acquisition and Divestiture strategy. Smart approach to M&A. R&D capability is beyond compare. Flexible and remote working support. Global breadth and depth. Hard working employees. I think Ginni Rometty's strategy is the right one and might eventually lead to top line revenue growth, but if IBM doesn't start treating employees better, it won't matter.
Cons: Extremely arrogant. Senior executives live different (far better) lives than on-the-ground employees and are ridiculously out of touch. The anytime, anywhere, all the time, wherever you are, even if you are on holiday workplace. Lack of reward. A culture of managing up and brownnosing. Don't really want to hear results from engagement surveys. Indignant that employees don't recommend working at IBM. Finance dominated culture. Maniacal focus on cost cutting, non-stop Resource Actions, blaming employees for lack of success in IBM strategy. Hierarchical top down culture.

Pros:
-- The people you work with are some of the smartest and most experienced in the industry.

-- Great mentorship opportunities from senior engineers.

-- People are very dedicated and work hard.

-- Generally, good team atmosphere and you learn a lot.
Cons:
-- Management is completely hit or miss. My experience on one team was quite positive, my experience on another team was horrible.

-- Depending on the managements, the project/product can either succeed or totally fall on its face. The engineers will be blamed in any negative outcome. 

-- Bad management do not take responsibility and blame everyone for missed deadlines. Be very careful switching teams and talk to employees who are currently there and pull honest feedback out of them before making the switch.

Pros:
IBM has a strong career path for technical people. You can get a mentor who really cares about you and help you to plan your career over the next 10 years.
IBM really cares about Making it easy for people with diverse backgrounds to work together without discrimination. I’m not going to say that women have it perfect out here, but management makes an active effort to promote women and this creates an atmosphere which is more conducive to collaboration than any I have seen elsewhere. Discrimination against Asians is nonexistent, or at least not significant enough for me to detect.
People will go out of their way to help you.
There is a wealth of opportunities to progress at any time. You need to ensure that you are aligned with the company goals rather than just what your manager is asking you to do.
Cons: The biggest problem at working at IBM is to take an idea and to have world-class impact. It’s relatively easy to have any impact at the scale off one customer or even one line of business but to create a product that’s going to revolutionize the world is difficult.

Pros: Technology...everything you can imagine is here some where; Huge installments and opportunities
Cons: In the U.S.....Expect to be laid off, no raises, even furloughs without pay...all depends on the stock market. Get experience you need and get out...or...make sure you're going with the current hot topic...i.e. Cloud at the moment

Pros:
Pay is good
Great work life balance...while you let your skills atrophy and become dependent on IBM
Not much is expected
Lots of free time to do lots of different things...just not work
Cons:
Skills will atrophy
Rampant politics
Everyone guards their little fiefdoms
Hybrid cloud definition is off from industry norms....hybrid does not mean all IBM software all the time!
Bonus err Commission is very stingily paid out....not designed in such a way that it is achievable
Forget what your offer letter says your title will be, you will NOT be doing the job as described.....ol' bait and switch-aroo time

Pros:
The best part about X-Force is the team culture. We genuinely want to do valuable work for our clients and you can count on your teammates to get sh** done. There are smart and talented coworkers in every direction and they’re willing to help out whenever they can. The team is also surprisingly good at identifying productivity bottle necks and time consuming processes and figuring out ways to automate them or make them less cumbersome. Very proud to be a part of this team.

Aside from the culture, the pay is competitive and benefits are good. Remote work is completely acceptable and there is no pressure from leadership to come “back” to the office. X-Force leadership is doing great things to build the brand like responding to NIST RFCs and providing grants to schools to build cybersecurity education in public schools.
Cons: We’ve experienced a lot of growth and there is a constant stream of client work to do. Minimal downtime during the workday.  Not a place to work if you’re looking for an easy paycheck.

Pros: IBM has tremendous access to markets and customers.  It has robust lines of business across a wide area of IT and consulting, making it possible to spend an entire career (or two) within its boundaries.  IBM enjoys a solid, world-class brand and is instantly recognizable.  For those that are passionate about technology, and are good communicators, this is a great place to work.
Cons: It is a huge place dominated by bureaucracy, office politics and lack of transparency from management.  There is almost too much technology -- through acquisitions, legacy and research, not to speak of assets developed by IBM services, it has created an unwieldy and vast number of products, technologies and components that make it difficult to move quickly.  What makes it frustrating is that there is innovation happening but IBM makes it difficult to take its own assets to market effectively

Pros: Friday flex days, planned events by the COE, 401K match, having IBM on your resume, working with 350 other 20 year olds
Cons: Being controlled by 3 different contradicting forces, low low pay, not much of a bonus, constantly being inundated with IBM propaganda, knowing that no matter how hard you work, you will get the same ratting. Unless your good at sucking up, you won't find much progression here. Management stresses having experience in all different roles, and then five seconds later will tell you how important it is to stay in the same job role for 2 years, this tends to go along with their standard practice of contradicting themselves and not having the intelligence to realize it.

Pros: Outstanding leadership, huge demand in market, ibm investments in security tools, technology, great people and fantastic client base.  We cannot hire enough good people!  Top mention in last four quarterly earnings reports.  This Is Ginnie's chance to take the first new division in 12 years and demonstrate her ability to create a world class business and management consulting organization that will form the core of a transformational practice in ibm driving internal change, creating consultants vs. technicians and focusing on high value management consultanting and delivery services to key industry accounts.
Cons: Need more people with high consulting capabilities and aptitude.  The focus is on creating world class consultants who listen to clients, conduct a root cause analysis to separate symptoms from root causes.  Strong problem solving consultants that can develop strategy and then rapidly deploy and implement change program that transform and deliver measurable improves in our clients business.  Professionals that are consultants first and capable of playing a wide range of projects roles with a high degree of success.

Pros: Strong mix of assets (companies) to contribute to solutions, but requires negotiating labrynth structure and siloed operating model. Very good willing personnel peppered around he organization but they are hampered by lack of teamwork metrics. Strong brand name carries weight undeservedly with clients.
Cons: Siloed operating model creates havoc at clients, pits divisions against each other, and encourages "me first" lack of teamwork. Collaboration across divisions is forced at best. Consulting personnel are not up to standards of Big 4. Lack of depth in key skill set areas cause true SME experts to be spread too thin. High turnover of talented staff who get fed up with politics. Key managers are those who play politics the best as key skill.

Pros:
Lots of opportunities / challenges / stretch assignments to help you grow in your career.
Access to world-class technology and solutions.
Great network of very talented people around the globe for basically any subject you need, at a distance of a "ping".
Job security (for talented and engaged employees who cares about the company).
Competitive benefits package.
Flexibility at work. Lots of options to work remote or adjust work schedule (dependent on the job role).
Cons: Compensation is a little bit low compared to similar job roles in the industry, specially if you grow rapidly in you career.

Pros: The overtime was nice when it was available.
Cons:
There are yearly ratings for each person in each team. Each team has a bell curve. You can be a hair lower in experience or progress compared to your peers and end up being graded poorly. Which results in no bonus. This is a very unfair system.

Depending on what account you work on, you could be applied to no overtime, oncall rotation, and in the cross fire between teams. Again, there is more arguing of who does what and whose problem it is than actually going ahead and doing the work. Just about every little adjustment requires a change that can take anywhere between 24 hours to a week to be approved before you can do said change.

Moving up in the company can also be very difficult. At the time I came in and later laid off, openings on my account were non-existent. Those with experience mostly held their jobs.

Training was non-existent and you learned as you went.

Last, the company seems to be laying off people at random. Regardless of how much you worked or not. You can have a really good or average PBC and still be laid off.

Pros:
Good work life balance and schedule flexibility.
Able to work from home or any where remotely.
A lot of varied projects going on, cool technologies.
Opportunity to attend and participate in many conferences and learning events.
Cons:
For one on the non-engineering track anymore, it was hard to secure a permanent position ( I was in the 3 year temporary positions). They were hiring engineers like crazy in my area but laying off non-engineers, bringing back some positions as contract only. I wasn't eligible for raises or bonuses in my classification, but if I had secured a regular FT position, I am sure the compensation would have favored the SW engineers.

Constant re-orgs; I was only there 30 months and was part of three re-orgs and had 3 managers.

Mad men mentality and acceptance of sexual misconduct by the senior staff. It seemed all the VPs and almost VPs had girlfriends they traveled with (IBM employees) while still obviously married. These were very visible IBMers, think headliners at conferences. I found this very nasty and backwards, and I think it had a negative impact on young engineers wondering how they advance as they saw these girlfriends get prime assignments and travel to all the best conferences.

Pros: Great flexibility in managing your own time. Decent IT support for desktop and mobility. Very good medical and retirement benefits for long term employees but less so for new hires.
Cons:
Once IBM focused on markets where it could hold a leadership share. Now... it's unclear what markets and products matter to IBM. This year has been topsy turvy in the hardware business and the management style has become harsh. With continuous layoffs and cutbacks morale is quite low. Pay for sales is erratic. There isn't much positive to say about the current environment. Maybe it will change? Clients are confused by the ongoing disruption in relationships with IBM sales and support. The company has experienced 18 consecutive quarters of reduced revenue and profit. How long can this continue?

The current HR plan is to cut cost driving experienced sales and technical staff out through layoffs. There are no clear internal opportunities for promotion or growth as only external hires will be considered for job postings.  

IBM has become an unusual place.

Pros: IBM pays a good base salary.  Medical coverage especially for prescriptions is excellent.
Cons:
No long term structure
Sales plans are changed every half. What you sell changes, who you sell to changes.
They have a calculation that they use to determine if you are succeeding in sales or not. What it doesn't take into account is that there is a 12-18 month sales cycle. When your territory and clients change every 6 months... and it takes two months to get the details to you... you are expected to achieve in 4 mo what it takes 18 to do. The only way you luck out is if previous sales reps have gotten something to the finish line and you capitalize on it. Their calculation for what it looks like to "succeed and have the necessary skills" changes as well. So you never know in six months if you'll have a job or not.

Pros: IBM has always been a leader in just about every possible aspect of diversity, from the obvious ones race, color and gender, to less obvious, but equally important ones like national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity and genetics. I would not work for a company that didn't respect and honor diversity.
Cons: While I have no personal experience with it, age discrimination is one facet of diversity that seems to be mentioned often with respect to IBM, and there are pending law suits making age discrimination assertions, so perhaps it is something to watch. IBM also has a history of broad layoffs. After a long history of full employment, the first few rounds of layoffs at IBM were mostly merit based, but over time merit appeared to have less and less to do with layoffs, as entire organizations were eliminated without regard for individual merit. The new CEO has stated that this approach will not continue, but only time will tell.

Pros: Some clients are amazing and it provides networking
Cons: Employees are just a number to them

Pros: Lots of smart people.  Great technologies.  Plenty of opportunities to do a lot of different things in your career (though you need to be very motivated to do this).
Cons: From the inside, it feels like the company is going out of business.  Cost cutting is being taken to an extreme, from everything as simple as office supplies to something more complex like commissions.  Every team meeting was about finding new opportunities and closing business.  "Everybody sells" is the corporate mantra.  There's a stated goal to get EPS to $20 by 2015, doing so is going to hurt IBM (there are plenty of articles about this, just Google for it).  This is not your father's IBM, the company has changed significantly over the past several years.

Pros:
Opportunities to move around within a global organization (they actively encourage techical staff to consider moving to China, India or Africa).

They encourage patent invention and intellictual IP
Cons:
They have lost their way.  Senior management encourages a message of "client first".  Yet they have slashed staffing to WAY beyond the ability to create, deliver, market and train products of quality to their customers.  Research and engineering employees who truly believe in doing a great job no longer have the ability to do so. 

IBM is aggressively moving towards cloud/big data technologies, but are trying to do so with little investment.  

Do more with less is fine.. and sometimes a reality.  But do more with less for years, and less benefits and no work-life balance is not sustainable.

Pros: Great potential for the future and a lot of great ideas being talked about that could make a very bright future.
Cons: Currently too focused on financials and not growing talent, skills, retention, and reassurance of the overall company direction. The top technical resources are being scooped up by other companies by the hour. The company attempt to pretend they are providing education is extremely too focused on current highlighted technologies, but what the company forgets is that even the latest and greatest direction, like Cloud, requires many other skills underneath to be able to provide and improve on that give area.

Pros: Always other opportunities available within the company as you feel it's time for a change, and they recognize dedication and hard work with retention. IBM has a list of even some hidden benefits that have provided an overall package that's very good. The flexibility to work from home is big a financial and a social benefit.
Cons: Salary growth is difficult when with the company for a long period of time. Some careful treading through politics and privilege is sometimes necessary, and occasionally some of the bloat in bureaucracy hinders your ability to get things done efficiently or in a timely manner for your clients.

Pros:
The people I worked with.  
Teamwork - The people that get things done will go overboard to help each other and make a customer happy.
Cons:
Layoffs. Always wondering if you are next on the block. Who wants to work that way?

Paperwork , useless time destroying paperwork. 

PBC's - What a pile of rubbish

Mandatory meetings that have nothing to do with your area. What a waste of time. 

Think40 - They will not pay for anything worthwhile, but forced to show 40 hours of some kind of training. 

All the little home-grown tools we were forced to use that never worked right. More time wasted spent trying to figure it out. 

Not meeting people you work with. I spent 4 years and not one team meeting where we could spend time. 

The millions of emails that come your way. Forced to read them to see if they might contain something you need to know, but most of them someone in management showing everyone they are working.

Pros:
- Research environment, like academia. You finish the PhD and you continue to do what you like most: doing research but getting payed properly!
- Total flexibility
- Open minded environment
- Trust  (they trust you. 100% confidence in you).
Cons:
- Sometimes, you are on your own. You have to search for interesting projects and 'sell' them to the other peers. But, isn't that research?
- Lots of bright minds but sometime you feel a 'generational' barriers... You might be discussing with >65yo man who still does research with their own (sometime outdated) methods. Nevertheless, I've to admit that fundamental thinking is much better in these people w.r.t new millenials. We are more focused to the 'trial&error' approach looking for solution because technology is fast nowadays, but they THINK, study and analyze the problem first, before investing in implementation: 99% of the time, they are right. You can learn a lot from them... but it is time-consuming.
- IBM does not provide the great benefits (free meals, massages, etc.) that new young companies are providing to their employees.

Pros: Fantastic highly technically skilled people to work with.  Opportunity to move to other jobs to grow skill.  A lot of flexibility to get your job done.
Cons:
IBM once prided itself in being a family company where you frequently saw IBM'ers to the 3rd and 4th generations of families.  Now, just another major multi-international company where you are a resource to be utilized and discarded at corporate discretion. 

Once a company that you hired on to and retired with.  Now, just another IT company on your resume.  Employee morale low due to layoffs, collocation requirements, etc.

Benefits are average for a company this size and the company continues to whittle them down annually or pass more of the cost down to the employee.

Company seeds into your 401K, but now in the US you are only eligible for the seed if you are employed through Dec. 31 of that year.  Company has an annual growth driven profit bonus plan, but the bonuses of past couple of years have been very slim (< 1%) if you received one at all.

Pros: Not much to write home about except that there are some very talented people at IBM. Some groups still allow WFH. I have worked here for 20+ years so there must have been something good but hard to quantify.
Cons: Good for top executives and 2% employees. Others are just going through the motions. No clear direction. Even the much touted Watson is bleeding money. Mobile strategy is non existent other than the Apple partnership. Cloud is struggling - most people don't have a clue on how to compete with AWS or Azure. Management identifies some people as worthy and keeps paying them all the perks. Lately, I have seen a lot of average techies become STSMs.

Pros: There are a few managers that are great mentors and want to help with your career growth. The opportunity to work with multi-disciplinary groups leads to a lot of learning. It's pretty nice that the pay is above average and more importantly you have the opportunity to work with people who are equally passionate about healthcare as you are.
Cons: In general, the company is not very organized, has a hard time synchronizing among the same groups within offices and among other offices. Depending on location - culture is non- existent. Some groups have no work-life balance, while others do. Some products never see the light of day (lack of funding, lack of organization), it all depends on what team you are on. The quality of managers is a 50/50 toss up, and favoritism among the top managers is apparent. The opportunity to step into leadership is available, but the ability  to continuously grow and learn applicable industry skills in this environment is questionable.

Pros: Very good work life balance, and good resources for self-learning and improving.
Cons:
1) Very low compensation package compared to market in my current position and YoE.
2) Every other company gives RSUs as an integral part of compensation. I have been with IBM for 6 years and have no stocks.
3) Limited opportunities for personal career progress and promotions. I have had very good performance rating over the years, but I don't feel I am where I am supposed to be in terms of career progress. Also salary increase rate is very low. In my 6 years at IBM, my salary has only increased by 30% compared to my beginning entry-level salary
4) No resources. I have been a tech-lead for 2 years and only have 1 other member in my team who is both developer and tester. It is an important product for WHI that is highly undervalued and not getting the right resources. This results in challenges delivering high-quality and robust versions.
5) Good talent resources are scarce - perhaps for the reasons above, I find it rare that I encounter quality talent at IBM. Several employees I work with are under-qualified for the particular jobs they are assigned to do.

Pros: Strong health benefits with higher than expected family coverage levels, multiple options inside the plan. Broad investment choices inside the 401k. You'll likely work -with- some very nice people.
Cons: This is a company stuck in the past, rewarding the people who mismanaged the company into modern irrelevance. There is very little modern about IBM, it is a business looking for a purpose in the digital world both from a product line up and marketing organization. No IBM product is first in its class. Marketing is slowly trying to catch up with modern times but is counting on veterans who never worked anywhere else in the last 20 years. Staff is constantly and randomly being reduced with groups of hundreds and sometimes thousands losing jobs at once. Chronic under-performers stay while the wrong people get let go. Bonuses are unheard of. The technology you will work with from Email to biz organization is the very best 1992 had to offer, maybe. Even if you come in with world-beating expertise and experience, there is some dimwitted executive above you with far less skill and far more political power who will never let you rise. There is no career growth for mid-career people.

Pros: IBM helps you invest in yourself. I am provided several opportunities to expand my skillset with training and certifications, as well as provided views into different perspectives outside of my day to day. This serves to give insight to other parts of the company that I may not have known about and builds relationships.
Cons: Processes can become convoluted and cause issues with collaboration, innovation or new process development. With IBM being such a large corp, sometimes current processes are so engrained that they are difficult to deviate from when working with other teams that may not have the same processes or when trying to incorporate new services into IBM that may not have existed until now.

Pros: And endless scope and area to develop a person career. Unlike many competing company where career area available for changes and availability to do so. Many competing company do not have breadth and depth of  areas to work on. For example.. if one wishes to pursue career in an another area, this company is where it will provide ypou options to learn and try different area. It is highly encourage to learn and explore. Where-as the competing companies make it difficult to move from one position to another with same company. IBM is like a min country within. Its upto an employee to make or break..most of the time.
Cons: The biggest one being is the salaries, they tend to be at 80% of the market level.. which for some is a significant gap. If IBM were to narrow this gap, then folks may stick around more.. but then there maynot be more position available.  Other downside is, the company being so large, its like an elephant when it comes to responding to market needs/situation.

Pros: IBM offers good career development guidance and support, allowing employees to move among job roles and make for a very long and challenging career. There is a lot of encouragement among senior leadership to pursue opportunities that allow you to stretch your capabilities and develop new skills. IBM is also incredibly flexible and understanding of employees' needs to balance family and children with careers. Working from home is a great benefit and doesn't take away from opportunities, and isn't a problem considering everyone is connected and able to work remotely given our technology and collaborative tools. Great place to work.
Cons: As with any large company, it is incumbent upon employees to establish themselves within their job roles and take responsibility for their own career development and mobility. For an individual who is shy or not comfortable with taking matters into their own hands, this could be perceived as a downside. While I personally do not find this to be a downside, there is also the matter of organizational structure and permissions, which some could call "red tape." Given the task of managing tens of thousands of people, employees do have to adhere to some practices that can be somewhat cumbersome.

Pros: IBM has a lot to offer to college grads and recent hires.  Working from home is a great.   I have had the pleasure of working with people in different countries and learned so much about other cultures.
Cons: IBM culture has changed over the year.  IBM is so focused on cost cutting that they have impacted their ability to execute quickly.   In my role, we spends too much time dealing with this impact of cost cutting (people gone, funding cut,  too many top priorities competing for the same resources).    IBM now embraces "Work force rebalancing".  It is actually a cost cutting "tool".  Numbers are set  and that trickles down to head count reduction.  If you are looking for job security, this is not the safest place to be.

Pros:
Depending on your manager and your position, you can work from a home office.  
Obviously IBM has name recognition.
Cons:
PBC rating system is seriously flawed.  Even as a 2+ (strong performer) there are no salary increases.  In over 4 years with 2 and 2+ ratings, no salary increase.  
The executive management cares about nothing except lining their pockets before they jump ship with their golden parachutes. 
Despite continued claims by our CEO, there is no true direction for the company, only fluff and vaporware.  
Despite continued losses in revenue and decline in stock price, CEO was awarded a $3.6M bonus while massive layoffs continue. 
No longer any chance of moving to new opportunities within different organizations unless you are a "good ole boy".

Pros: Recently acquired by the IBM family with the potential to have a global impact, a broad array of products, and the tools that can meet the imaging needs of the customer. A genuine desire to bring a great product to market with flexible implementation. The products are truly valued by the customers who use them. The Support of customers is extremely customer-focused.
Cons: Extremely silo-oriented product groups, cross-functional communication or projects can be strenuous, limited understanding or experience with Quality Management from the top to bottom of the organization with Medical Devices. Tenured employees have developed a scoped and limited view of their role or product impact on other teams.

Pros: Pay was good, better than many other companies in AZ for Admin type of job.  IBM got every cent out of you and more.  Work from home.  No time cards or clocking in.  There is a level of trust in working from home as long as you get the job done.  You learn to be a professional in every sense of the word.  It is sink or swim.
Cons: They just pile the work on which got to the point where it was unbearable to manage.  Management could not really do anything about it because they were strapped.  There was no one to help and no hire tickets.  I think eventually all business will be in a different country which is where they are headed for cheaper leases of property and labor.  First line management has no pull.  This used to be a great company to work for...I'd still recommend a couple years for experience then get out.

Pros:
There are some amazing pros to this job. The first is of course the effectiveness of training. Over 6 months, you will visit cities all across the country so that IBM can help to infuse over 100 years of experience into your training. This includes seminars, mock meetings, intensive training, shadowing, testing, mentoring, and much more. This training prepares you well for what you will face in a career at IBM or anywhere else. It provides you with a wide breadth and depth of knowledge over sales, technology, and people skills.
Summits are well respected and looked at as if we hold the future, which we may. We are looked upon with admiration from our leaders, which is an amazing feeling. There is also a very close relationship with your peers. As you train with the same group for 6 months, you become very close. The summit managers are some of the most amazing people that I have had the pleasure of working with.
Cons: The traveling can be a lot, and there is a constant fear of not finding a team, or being relocated.

Pros:
- Embracing cloud technologies like Box and Slack has been a plus. 
- Giving employee's choice of a Apple Mac and MS Office has been positive.
Cons:
- Unbelievably paltry bonus, gets lower and lower each year.
- No raises, different excuses each year.
- The longer you work, the less appreciation shown (at least for the non-VP's), as pointed out buy two bullets above.
- Implementing mandatory co-location, supposedly due to big push for implementing agile in the company. Co-location does not mean, just go into the nearest office, you will be expected to uproot your family and way of life and move to the location they tell you.  Alternatively, look for a new job internally which appears to go nowhere and then resign.

Pros: Great coworkers. Good insurance. Work from home benefit was the best thing IBM had going for it.
Cons: Colocation supposedly to enable agile, shoulder to shoulder work which makes no sense with half the team members in India, so everyone knows it was to lay off older, experienced, more expensive employees. Constant layoffs. Replacement of experienced staff with inexperienced staff. Senseless reorgs. Battling business units. Arrogant headquarters. Fewer employees and more work per person. Lousy help desk support for all applications. American jobs shipped overseas. Constant anxiety and worry about having a job, especially those 50 years or older with a target on their backs. Lousy executives do nothing but hound their staff for more powerpoint decks. The current execs make poor decisions but they keep adding more executives and laying off the people who do the work.  It used to be that those who were hit in the 3x a year layoffs got one week of severance for each year of service. Now everyone gets 30 days. IBM glory days are over and no way to pull out of 21 quarter slump with the current executive team. I used to be proud to be an IBMer. No longer.

Pros: Flexibility (work from home or from my home country), research environment similar to academia (flexibility and long term goals) , excellent work-life balance, ability to find experts on any field (from math, physics, social science, operating systems, programming, supercomputing, weather, aeronautics, ...) in the very same building!  Just knock on their door and start the brainstorming. Each of us have a private (not shared) office were we can do meeting, discuss, etc. and do whatever we want.
Cons: It does not provide the "modern" environment and 'cool' things like free food services, or cooking lessons, etc. as other tech companies... I guess this is mainly because the workforce is older than in other tech companies, so people does not care about these extra 'cool' things... which in the end, the things are 'cool' the first day but then you realize that you just walk to your desk and work most of the days.  I just miss the free food, but with the good salary all these tech companies have, what is the % of savings because free food? <1%?

Pros: Management commitment, structure and intensity.  Obviously, a one of the most mature and professional environments of any company.  While impossible for most companies this size to do, IBM can turn the aircraft carrier.
Cons: Like all companies this size, the mandates to turn the aircraft carrier have the impact of destroying innovation, loyalty, motivation and brands within the company.  It is a "student body right" mentality that, while understandable from an external facing sales perspective, causes possibly unintended consequences.  Individual measurement systems are not capable for being flexible for the many individual brands that exist within the vast entity and thus HQ level policies fail.  For example, the CEO, who was personally responsible for making and integrating the biggest acquisition of the last 20 years, has almost completely destroyed the brand of the company that was acquired and certainly has run off most of the talent by subsuming it rather than letting it flourish....e.g., GM can't buy Ferrari and then make those same cars for $40K and yet require them to perform like a Ferrari.

Pros: Flexible work option (2 days per month). PMP certification reimbursable after approval by management.  It is possible to gain a secret clearance (to move to the DC area).  Descent entry level experience. 401k vested at start and employer match at 6%. Medical and dental benefits. Pretty stable environment.
Cons: They say because the cost of living is lower they offer a low wage. Entry level starts between band 1-4 which is around $12.50 and $18.50 per hour. If you want to transfer to another department, be prepared to be low balled through your IBM career.  It is extremely difficult to transfer, get promoted or obtain a substantial pay increase.  Employee portion of medical benefits are expensive! The local area is not good. IBM is operating at model in which they acquire low cost resources and bill the client high; they want they want to invest as little as possible in their employees in low cost areas.  Someone else said they are trying to hire locally because they can't attract or retain good talent outside of this black hole. It is the truth.

Pros:
Good Salary
Great Benefits/Healthcare (very little Copay)
Great Opportunities to Learn
Access to a lot of Courses like Udemy, Safari Online
Good immediate managers-responsive and helpful
Nice 401K kick on Dec 31st--after Second Year--Unless you're first year starts before Dec 15th--you're out of luck the first year
Really big on diversity and inclusiveness.
Cons:
Too many management meeting with no relevance to what you are doing.
Advancement is slow--usually dependent on creating a new client opportunity--which if you're technical is hard to find
Raises - non-existent--has nothing to do with pleasing the client--that's expected.
Don't try to do too much with the internal "Your Learning"--no one is watching. Do the minimum--Had over 200+ hours in "Your Learning" and 3 internal badges--Not noticed. Now I just get my hours from required learning and Udemy courses.
The Immediate management is helpful but upper management is distant and unapproachable.
Sent an email with a suggestion to an organization head--no response.
At a meeting for discussing time management calculations, I raised a question to one of the leaders, and was made to know very quickly not to bother her and only raise questions through my chain of command.

Pros:
Work from home options.
Good vacation and sick time policies.
Good medical for single employees.
Coworkers are very capable and willing to help.
Cons:
Limited growth opportunity.
Inadequate product funding.
Dwindling local workforce..
Lack of innovation opportunity.
Products are in continuing maintenance mode.
IBM prefers to buy companies with new technology rather develop it themselves.
Heavy on process rather than innovation and improvement.
Large families can pay more than $13,000 in premiums for health insurance.
Constant reduction in employee benefits.
Constant downsizing.
Responsibilities pile up due to attrition with no backfill.
Employees are inefficient due to their broad scope of responsibilities.

Pros:
- With its history of research and patents, it boasts a great culture of innovation.  
- Benefits are competitive in many areas, and people, for the most part, and bright and easy to work with.
Cons:
- Large company with typical process and political problems.  
- Too often, leadership changes course creating instability and a fear of where you will end up.  
- If you are joining IBM new, push for as high of an upfront salary as possible, because increases above 3% rarely exist, even with promotions.  
- IBM is a giant finance company with stakeholder obligations its first and foremost priority - employees don't even make the top 10... they are treated like assets.  
- With a company as large as IBM, the people that hide and do very little (except fill their calendar with meetings to make themselves believe they are productive) abound.  There are very few people who actually "do".

Pros:
People I work with are intelligent and some of the brightest in the industry.
Work from home.
Cons:
The same people I work with are handcuffed and handicapped by an arcane management system that is playing catchup on technology.

Too many levels of approval required to get anything done. What takes less than a day at a smaller company can take over a week at IBM.
 
Executive leadership needs stop cutting people in the lower ranks.  Too many good people laid off, now not enough folks to do the work and schedules have not changed.  More work, less people.

Pros: As with anyplace, it is the team you end up on that determines the real work environment. Every single individual I worked with was supportive and lovely The benefits are good. Health insurance is not so good unless you get promoted enough to afford the more exoensive offerings.
Cons: There is little to no job security, you are pretty much a disposable cog in a giant machine and your redundancy is inevitable. In such a rapidly changing industry, IBM sheds the employees of the companies they merge with every year, as soon as whatever agreement to keep the staff employed for expires. They view people as the most expendable and renewable resource and will throw yu away as soon as your sector starts to hint an losing profit.

Pros: My work is purposeful and interesting including feature design, product redesign and integrations. While brought on to do UXD my role is 50% User Research—fortunately I have the education and experience to design and conduct valid user research. Good work culture: I love working with my team of engineers
Cons: IBM keeps dedicated proven performers on contract because "they don't have the budget" ...Paying significantly below market rates, there is no incentive to stay even when I'm exceeding expectations, love the focus of my work and my team is a great fit. My division is led by engineers including my manager and skip level manager. There is no design at the leadership table and while there is an expressed value placed on UXD I have to doubly work to help management understand design principals, trust design decisions and realize (this is big) what constitutes valid user research / design research.

Pros: The teams consisted of seasoned experienced professionals that understood their business and understood how they could apply their own individual skills to the cooperative successful achievements in realizing their objectives with high levels of customer satisfaction based on quality and business transformation value to the clients.
Cons: The outsourcing of skilled jobs to low labor global regions has impacted and reduced customer satisfaction and demoralized the skilled base of talent, especially with the repetitive cost reductions cycles involving the resource actions of several thousand unconfirmed "senior" employees that have been laid off when the company balance sheets have been extremely strong cash positive.

Pros: It's easy to shine among all the dullards, they have tons of free education available, and the work load is usually pretty light (they over-employ).
Cons: Promotions are "open season", so even if you've been on your team for several years, there's a very strong chance someone from another team is going to steal your promotion (even with lateral moves). They outsource their interviews to other managers constantly, meaning that "surprise surprise", that manager's subordinates get the promotions. They hire almost everyone as a "long term supplemental" meaning that your contract ends after a few years no matter how well or poorly you performed during that time, and getting converted to a regular is an act akin to resurrecting the dead.

Pros:
Incredible amount of resources to access, whether it be mentorship or a masters degree, IBM has got your back. This company is focused on building your skills, so it is a great launching pad for people early in their career and lacking experience.

For people are skilled enough in what they do to work from home, IBM is a dream come true.
Cons:
IBM doesn't perform cost of living adjustments, in comparison to other Bay Area competition the pay dismal, however if you move out of the Bay Area to say... Texas, where the taxes are low and the living is cheap; you will be making more money than the local competitors.

Aside from compensation: The company spirit is nowhere near the "Silicon Valley energy" I've seen in other tech firms.

Pros:
1) My good ideas were paid attention to from the very beginning of my time at IBM. The good ones got implemented and continued to be supported for >10 years so far.
2) I get to work with people from all over the world.
3) I got my Master's education paid for by IBM. I went part-time while working full-time.
4) I got to go on a six-month assignment to India from the U.S. My wife accompanied me.
5) IBM has a great legacy of inclusion, especially for lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans people, as well as for heterosexual women and people with disabilities of all sexual orientations and gender identities.
Cons: There is not as much room for advancement into senior roles, depending on the area of the company where you work, i.e., people in sr. leadership positions stay a long time and so there's less room for advancement, but I doubt that's unique to IBM.

Pros:
Core IBM is a great company. As a whole, IBMers are probably the nicest group of people I have ever worked with.  Everyone in Core IBM has a lot of integrity and excellent work ethic.
Health care benefits are very good.
Baton Rouge IBM is a great place to start, if you're fresh out of college.  Major resume boost, and you really do learn a lot on projects.
Cons:
The Baton Rouge CIC is quite possibly the worst part of IBM.  Most managers are unable or unwillingly to do their jobs.
The pay is shockingly low, and "promotions" are insultingly small. I received a "promotion" and it was only a $3000/yr increase...
I spend a lot of weekends working, and I usually don't get home until 9pm. I calculated my hourly rate: it's $14/hr.  Before taxes.
Baton Rouge CIC is a great place to start but not a place to stay.  Get in, get your experience, get out.

Pros: The people are wonderful, bright and professional.  First Line Managers in my experience are superb.
Cons: Quarterly layoffs since IBM hasn't hit Wall Street earnings for 22 straight quarters.  There is no job security here.  Quotas have been set so high the sales force isn't earning any commissions in comparison to past years; this is a way of cost savings.  IBM is a depressing place to work when you know regardless of your effort they will blow you out eventually.  IBM no longer hires seasoned professionals - they only hire young people under 30, again as a way of cost savings via salary.  In GTS if you close a deal it has to go to a War Room internally to see if they have the internal resources to execute.  Nobody is happy here.  Ginni the CEO is the worst and high level management simply doesn't care - they just protect their piece of the pie while the ongoing layoffs continue.

Pros: The work location is wonder, as well as all the people I work with. The pay is decent, great hrs, my remote co workers from IBM are all very friendly and generally helpful, tons of free educational resources given to all employees. Full time, have my own office.
Cons: On going contract, so NO holiday pay, vacation, affordable benefits. The pay was low in the beginning; had to renegotiate in order to get a decent pay rate. Work like a full time employee but will never be an actual employee of IBM, nor MEGlobal(contract location where I work everyday.)

Pros: The pay's good for senior talent.  The benefits are decent.
Cons: Bloated bureaucracy and overbearing processes.  Much lip-service paid to Open Source, but legal approval processes to be able to use it make it agonizing and slow to actually get permission to use it.  Patronizing and often downright mean management.  Management which often explicitly stifles and punishes any hints of dissent; aka, "honest opinions".  Much arrogance about being "cutting edge", whereas the reality is that IBM is too slow to adopt new technologies.  Co-option of terms like "agile", applying them to whatever IBM currently does rather than actually changing and "walking the walk".  Constant fear of being on the "wrong" project or working for the "wrong" manager, which may lead you vulnerable to the next round of layoffs.  A performance review process which often bears little relationship to reality, with only managers and a few "architects" giving any input into your review, as opposed to your actual peers with whom you work.  Lack of money to buy equipment, resulting in obsolete computers on desktops, and a constant struggle to find adequate hardware to test on.

Pros: Good benefits, good people, much autonomy in professional positions
Cons: IBM has very limited upward pay opportunities in many positions.  You may start with a competitive salary but it is hard to increase it.  IBM then lays off senior workers or forces them into retirement.  The top performers have very little work/life balance.  Work/life balance is a joke.  Relative contribution is used as a semantic tool to give average ratings which in turn save the company money.  The ratings are skewed for only a few high performers to get exceeded or outstanding ratings leading to higher salaries. Don't believe that IBM has true respect for the individual.  They don't!

Pros: Still some good people left, and good technology. I worked for IBM for many years, and they gave me a lot of good opportunities. The technical vitality is/was unmatched - there are some really amazing tools and applications developed by people pretty much in their spare time which could easily spawn off a startup. Yet the employees just do it for free. And management hasn't figured out how to put a dollar value on that.
Cons: too much management, too few people left who actually do stuff. Morale is very low after many rounds of layoffs, and incompetent management. I in the past few years, things declined rapidly. Our group was clearly not valued by management, even though the technical field, our partners and customers absolutely loved us. So we suffered the death of a thousand cuts till I finally couldn't take it and left. I realized you don't have to work with depressed, demoralized people.

Pros: All of the best reasons to work at IBM went out the window in the late 1990's. They started dropping salaries, training and educational benefits even then, before 9/11/2001.
Cons:
In it's heyday, IBM set the standard for how employers should treat their employees. They were the 'gold standard' to which all others looked as an example. Outsourcing, corporate greed, and a host of other factors have eroded IBM as a place to work to the point where every IBMer I know is disillusioned. 

I have seen new hires come in with high ideals only to have their enthusiasm crushed after a few years. It did not used to be that way. Hard working people put in 60 hour weeks with no recognition, and very small raises, if any.

Pros: As a consultant, overall view of company is largely, if not wholly dependent on the client engagement that consultant is staffed on and practice area. I have had a mix of successful, balanced projects as well as challenging. There is a lot of autonomy and career direction is largely up to the employee to take the initiative and get the proper face time, otherwise you can be invisible since you rarely work with your career manager on engagements. Every few months there are check-ins that allow you to decide if you want to continue in the role you are in or change directions. That is valuable. There are also work remote project opportunities so you don't get burnt out on travel
Cons: If you are on a project that is not in your practice area- which happens to avoid the bench, it is easy to become invisible. With 400,000 employees, it is up to you to ask for what you want and ask the tough questions. Also, recently, consultants in commerce and Sterling have been having a hard time getting staffed since companies are slow to sign or process is dragged out. Take note.

Pros:
Benefits are relatively good... though constantly being whittled away more year by year. 

Opportunity to learn/grow is good. For example, last year they started a new program "Think40" that basically allocates 40/hours year to education/employee development. IBM used to have an _excellent_ education program: useful/helpful classes, time to take the classes, etc. Over the years that was pretty much eliminated. But now it seems management has figured out continual employee development has value and is starting to bring back some of that former excellence. 

While you are expected to put in extra time for crunch issues, IBM is good about giving time off for personal things. For example, a very close friend of mine (not family) passed away last year. There was no question about taking off for long distance travel for the funeral. That kind of adaptability on IBM's part makes it easy to put in extra time when IBM has an emergency.
Cons:
Constant threat of layoff. 
Constant need to pick up workload from those laid off.

Pros: This is one of the largest technology companies in the world. If you put your mind to it, you can easily advance anywhere and fit a vast number of positions. The company has many resources and seems to pay well. Many very intelligent people (tech side at least), and you have a wealth of knowledge and potential at your hands. Not to mentioned the message this company's name sends on a resume for then future.
Cons: Some employees, especially sales orientied are very process heavy, seem like drones, mindlessly following the norm. As an Engineer, my work with other technical side people has been great, but the sales side seems solely interest in closing, making money, and moving on to the next. (I know this is what sales is, but some I've noticed will throw their own co-workers under the bus whenever convenient.

Pros:
Good, but not great, salary.
Above average job security.
Many job opportunities.
Generally good, if somewhat thread-worn, working conditions, and work from home opportunities.
Company is starting to understand that moving work to China and India is a disaster.
Flexibility in work hours and time off
Cons:
Company is not committed to employee training; no rotations, online training is just window dressing.
Bad management, especially unnecessary layer upon layer of ignorant middle management, permeates much of the business.
Constant, slow decline in employee benefits.
Only a 401K retirement plan.  Company match is not credited to employee until December.
Management's constant nit picking, over-reporting to each other, and distraction from job assignments.
The PBC annual evaluation is ineffective window dressing; it is simply a compensation management tool.
Silly budget constraints on travel: forced to fly at inconvenient times,  stay in sub-par hotels, and rent undersize cars.
Constraints on conference attendance impede ability to stay current and maintain network.

Pros:
1. Ability to work from home provides flexibility and work/life integration.  This, however, is changing with current drive to push workers back into a traditional office setting.
2. Slightly above average benefits such as vacation, discounts for IBMers.
3. Diverse workforce provides opportunity for employees to interact and learn from team members from different backgrounds, cultures, countries.
4. Strong historical reputation as a good place to work.
Cons:
1. Senior leaders don't seem to have a clear concept of corporate mission or strategy.
2. There are a lot of great ideas about the company and its strategy, but it mostly feels like this operates in theory and not in practice.
3. Extremely bureaucratic, although there is more emphasis of late on 'self-directed teams', this feels more like 'corporate-speak' and feels almost nonexistent in practice.
4. Performance rating system has forced percentages, and is very subjective.  This turns performance appraisal into a popularity contest.  Without high ratings it is impossible to get promotions or raises.
5. Significant loss of knowledge and subject matter expertise due to resource actions (layoffs), forced retirement, and divestitures.

Pros: As an external Executive  hire I was paid (Market Rates) which was 40% more than the veteran IBMers that were there for 20-30 years. I made more than my FLM which was a big surprise to me.
Cons: IBM claims that they want to make significant changes to the way they are doing business and say we need to  "Treasure the Wild Duck" but in fact they "Choke the Wild Duck" and put them at the top of the lay off list. Ideas and Opinions are not welcome and in fact there is a huge culture of lies, distrust, back stabbing, dishonesty, and fear across the whole of IBM. The PBC process has made it easy for the VPs to get rid of any and everyone that does not march to the beat of their drum. As a result, it is not a place for creativity, new ideas, loyal employees, collaboration, or a sense of well being. Many people are suffering from Post Traumatic Stress due to the horrible work environment and I know that some have even have heart attacks due to the stress.

Pros: Working with smart & dedicated people who are not executives; colleagues who feel they are making a positive impact on society.
Cons:
On March 2 2016 IBM gave the pink slip to thousands (IBM won't disclose how many). I was a senior employee with very good annual reviews and spent 13 years of my career contributing to IBM. The company changed its severance pay structure in 2016. When severance pay was 6 months, that was a big deal. But now that severance pay is only 1 month - regardless of years of service ! The greed and arrogance of the IBM execs to change this policy in anticipation of the mass layoffs announced on March 2 2016 is vulgar and sickening.

Greed of executives at expense of those employees who have put in years of service.

IBM preaches that IBM takes care of it's own - that's a lie !

Pros:
THIS IS FOR THE CLEVELAND IBM EXPLORYS LOCATION ONLY: BEWARE!!!!

It doesn't matter because the Cons are so horrible. I wish I could have stayed because I am fascinated with what the next level of cognitive computing will be in healthcare. But this place is toxic.
Cons:
I was hired to help with a newly formed services team. Within 2 days, I realized that the harassing and intimidating work environment by a senior manager was not only IGNORED by senior leadership but by the onsite HR representative, and it is creating an unsustainable working situation where everyone is in fear of this person and their job. 

I do not know why IBM is allowing this, but great people are running for the doors. They had an employee survey which identified this person's behavior and how it's affecting the staff, and the SLT chose to ignore it. After the employees put themselves on the line by speaking up, they no longer trust anyone and feel that their voices were ignored. WORST JOB I have ever had.

Job Title: Senior vice president, transformation and operations
Pros:
•	IBMers: working with incredibly talented people from all around the world.
•	IBM's Values.
•	Work-life balance - flexibility. 
•	Great place to learn and grow – skills, experiences, build relationships.
•	You are a part of something meaningful; being in service of human potential and progress (in tech, business and society).
Cons:
Cons:
•	IBM has been built on foundational principle of continuous reinvention, if you are uncomfortable with change, it is probably not be the right place for you. 
•	In a company as big as IBM, if you don't invest time in building your own skills and capabilities you may fall behind or get stuck.

Pros:
- Parental leave benefit is really good (12 weeks paid)
- Learning opportunities for entry level workers, though some of this will be trial by fire
Cons:
- Terrible work/life balance and little regard for employees mental health or wellbeing 
- You are expected to take on roles that are well outside your abilities and preferred career path
- Dramatic understaffing on projects as a means to improve margins 
- All the good resources are leaving, meaning there are no good mentors and everyone is being forced into roles they’re not capable of (see second bullet point above)
- IBM’s obsession with cross and upselling at all costs has led to building Frankenstein ecosystems that don’t work well or provide true value to clients. It’s disheartening to be worked to the bone to build something you’re not proud of 
- HR more or less does not exist and every internal system and process is as convoluted and confusing as possible. It’s amazing the company can even function given how poorly it is run

Pros:
-IBM has above average benefits. They match dollar-for-dollar in our 401(k) plans; they have a variety of health plan options; they also have an advocate hotline for employees to deal with insurance questions/claims.

-IBM has a vast social network. Whether you have pto questions, project specific questions, or just need another set of eyes to review a solution, there are colleagues willing to help. 

-IBM emphasizes continuing education. There are vast resources (databases, search engines, courses, industry knowledge) available to supplement projects.

-IBM covers the cost of job-specific trainings through vouchers.

-The people are great to work with on projects. They come from vast and diverse backgrounds.
Cons:
-Some leadership fixate on short-term vs long-term wins (positioning inexperienced college grads as SME's, not pushing back on clients for fear it could sever future work)

-I'm so focused on project delivery that I don't know how my function adds value my clients. I don't know how my work adds value to IBM.

-There's lack of information on how to move laterally or upwards in my career. I've stopped asking my boss and others because it doesn't lead to anything insightful.

Pros:
- Challenging projects with unique opportunities for employees to develop their skills 
- Smart, friendly, and knowledgeable colleagues 
- Excellent benefits (Dental/Health/Vision insurance, awesome 401(k) , discounts on many 3rd party products and services and many more) 
- Excellent work/life balance (very flexible work environment; probably, this is the biggest + )
- Massive technical resources for employees to grow their skills (eg. online technical library (Books 24x7), workshops, classes, etc)
- Tons of different projects and it is usually fairly easy to switch between projects, so you won't get bored
Cons:
- Low base pay
- Promotions are extremely slow or non-existence 
- Performance reviews are ridiculous and your work will be compared with the rest of the people in your level (no matter how hard you work on a project, you could still get a low rank and no raise)
- Too much bureaucracy 
- If you are thinking about getting your master/PhD, Tuition Reimbursement is like lottery, you sign up and pray to get it
- Absolutely no innovation; if the current solution works, DO NOT TOUCH IT kind of mindset. Hence, the management is very resistance to new ideas.

Pros: One of the best things about working at IBM is that they encourage telecommuting, which was extremely helpful to me as a working mom.  I had the opportunity for some excellent training, and worked with some really smart people on exciting, state-of-the-art projects.
Cons: At least on the services side, IBM reorganized at least once a year, which meant a constantly changing set of objectives and goals and no real strategy -- at least not one that was ever shared.  I had fourteen managers in twelve years and there were times that I worked for someone for several months without ever having a conversation with that person.  The organization is ridiculously top heavy and mid-level managers have to spend an inordinate amount of time reporting to various executives.  It's a shame because IBM used to be a great company that everyone wanted to work for.

Pros: IBM provides employees with challenging and unique work opportunities.  As a consultant you work with some of the top corporations world-wide.
Cons: If you work as a consultant, prepare to work extremely hard and travel extensively.  I usually flew out to the client site on Sunday and made it back home late Friday evening.  Also, you'll be expected to contribute to other projects and assist in scoping new opportunities.  Most of these activities occur after hours of your primary project.  It's all about billable hours, so if you're not on vacation; you are expected to be on the road at a client site - no exception.  To compound matters, for your hard work you will receive no bonus on top of your base salary so negotiate your base carefully on the front end.

Pros: I've been at IBM for well over a decade, and I've been fortunate in that i've had the opportunity to try a few different roles, both in development and client facing.  As long as you can find the right mentors to help you, and can demonstrate ability to learn, you can typically do well at IBM.  Work/life balance isn't great but could be a lot worse.  By and large, people have tons of respect for each other and behave like adults (which often doesn't happen at other large companies, from what I've heard).
Cons: IBM is run like an accounting firm.  There is a tremendous focus on cutting costs and doing more with less.  My teams have always been understaffed, and I haven't had a decent sized raise in over ten years.  There have been numerous rounds of layoffs in recent years where good people have been cut due to elimination of positions.

Pros:
Relaxed, laid back atmosphere to work
Plenty of walking around and chatting
Opportunity to learn IF you have the right team leader and cultivate a friendship with the top manager
Cons:
Focus entirely on Quantity, not Quality or Complexity of work submitted
Nepotism runs rampant
No incentive to do good work, just churn it out to be rewarded
No opportunity for advancement - nobody wants to help you move up since that would leave them with finding a replacement and Rochester is not a great attraction
Pay is roughly 40% below of market rates - just for those with a BS degree, around 50-60% below market if you have a JD or USPTO registration;
I left and was offered 2x my last salary when I inquired about returning.

Pros: Had an awesome 20+ year career with about 8 different jobs that let me grow in many different directions. I always had a focus on strategic partnerships because as big as IBM is, it can't do everything on its own and its ecosystem is an economy unto itself! I loved working with other IBMers and business partners and was able to have tremendous creative expression that led to business results I am proud of to this day! Great place to grow and develop.
Cons: From 2010 to 2015, Ginny the CEO inherited an aggressive profit target that was unachievable as the company did not realize Revenue growth. It took a bit long for the leadership team to realize it and adjust, but hopefuly they will realize growth again soon. The focus on Acquisitions is necessary but Mergers should be considered as well to move the top line more aggressively.

Pros: Talented people, good 401k though matching by IBM is not great.  Used to be able to continuously reinvent and stretch ones self  by moving projects.  Worked really hard but there was a fun, family atmosphere and performance and integrity wete rewarded at all levels-- that was five or six years ago.
Cons: Management is relying on technology to save the day and treat people like they are inventory that could be a nickel cheaper. They have gutted the business of experienced professionals and have not been filling jobs so work demands can be grueling.   Atmosphere is fear and frustration. Difficult to move any more.  No job security. No one trusts HR or management like they used to do so. Constant cuts on the backs of employees in terms of salary, benefits, training,  and staffing and other support to meet customer commitments.

Pros: I've never been surrounded by so many smart people, who genuinely enjoyed their work, and worked on some rad stuff. IBM is such a massive company, they truly are International. I lived in the US but my teammates were in Canada, China, and Israel. It was awesome to work with so many different people from all kinds of cultures. I got to work from home a lot because of the time zone differences. Also, IBM has some pretty cool research projects. And they really do encourage your personal development-- there are databases of excellent presentations that you can watch to teach yourself new skills.
Cons:
Working from home makes it harder to maintain a healthy work/life balance.
There is a proper procedure that must be followed for every little thing. Everyone gets hung up on bureaucracy to the point where it severely limits your productivity.

Pros:
- work with very smart and professional people
- benefits (401K, medical, life insurance, vac). But, new hire quality of benefits is not as robust
- constant challenging environment
- most teammates/employees are very helpful
- management is usually very well trained and effective
- treated with respect and diverse workforce
- salary raises are now market based and seem more fair
- no bias found in salary levels between male and female - equal pay has been a protocol since the company was founded
- love the opportunity to work remotely
- has some great community programs 
- the company business conduct guidelines and values to work by are stellar
Cons:
- lack of communication from director level and above
- only aware of happenings in our own org
- high pressure environment
- lack of job security - anyone can be laid off (resourced) at any time - constant lay offs as products/technology evolves/changes
- overtime my benefits have been reduced. The 401k match used be paid to you throughout the year, now it is paid in last paycheck of the year and if you separate you don't get that years match.
- work long hours @ end of quarters

Pros:
The people actually producing goods (software/hardware/services) are generally good. Benefits and salary are decent and are comparable to other big technology companies. The company has good controls for legal and accounting purposes (Sarbanes Oxley, GDPR, export compliance, etc.) My experience is that IBM is 
conscientious about equal opportunity for all and their facilities are ADA compliant.
Cons:
Too many levels of management and those who support management.
Depending upon division, role, manager, etc, your work-life balance may 
be all work and no life. The corporate intranet is a mess, the search engine for said intranet is all but useless. Management moved everyone from cubicles to shared open-space just in time for SARS-COV2, all done in the name of "collaboration" when the reality is its about packing more people into a smaller space to save money. I've averaged getting a new manager every 18 months, there is often little/no knowledge transfer between managers and you have to train each new manager about what your role is.

Pros: Some of the brightest people that I've ever worked with work at IBM.  IBM has invented a number of significant, important parts of the Information Technology industry.  This includes relational database technology and hard disk drive technology.  IBM is one of the few companies that actually performs the "Research" portion of "Research and Development".
Cons: Like many large companies, IBM is laden with bureaucracy and often inane procedure.  Also, it is completely beyond understanding why a company that has reported record earnings, record profits and has a positive outlook for 2009 would - one day after it's proclamation to the financial community - commence laying off 5,000 of its employees, most of whom were real contributors to the company's success.  IBM's approach to this latest round of layoffs was very calculating, ensuring that no single location was affected in a significant enough way to require additional notice or pay.

Pros: Having IBM on your resume gets attention.  Working at IBM means you don't have to explain what company you work for.  Vendors call you back, and you can push an escalation if need be.  The biggest advantage of working at IBM is the vastness of the company.  You can go as high as you want to - maybe.  There are endless training opportunities and lots of things to do.
Cons: IBM periodically goes through an exercise called a "Resource Action" or "RA," which of course is a euphemism for a layoff.  That is how I parted ways with the company.  The company is gradually reducing its US workforce while increasing its staffing in India and China.  Effects on morale are what you'd expect.

Pros: In my position there are no tight deadlines to speak of.  Pretty laid back.  Plenty of work to keep my busy, but not a lot of pressure to meet hard deadlines.  I come from just the opposite so it's a huge difference for me.
Cons:
Lotus Notes is terrible... I feel like it is the mid 90's.  It's slow and buggy... I honestly could not stand using it if I was in my previous high pressure (and high email volume) job... Since my role at IBM is pretty laid back  the lost productivity just means I get less done... but that's OK.        

Required use of Linux as a desktop for anyone with privileged access.   I like Linux as a server and like the command line but hate it for desktop OS.  

Things can be slow to happen... like getting access to things or policy changes... etc...

Pros: Wide variety of job opportunities, if you are one of the lucky ones to still be employed by "Big Blue."
Cons: The company seemed to have a policy of shedding as many US jobs as possible, and replacing the lost jobs with overseas or contract workers.  My job was "sold" to a foreign company, but I still was expected to work just as hard or harder, with fewer resources.  Despite being one of the top-rated employees, I received a total of 2.5% raises over a 3 year period. The DBPP was discontinued so executives could see their stock options soar in value, replaced with a far less generous defined contribution pension plan. If you wanted to take an opening in another location, IBM would not compensate you for the move. I was expected to work weekends at least once a month, without "comp time" off. Policies were geared to the "politically correct," and if you held traditional values, you were not part of "the team," and your promotion chances were nil.

Pros:
IBM Name on resume
People, projects, experience with IBM
Travel Benefits
Cons: Salary is a joke, 42K for four years of experience with IBM, I know someone that transferred to another sector within IBM and was given the exact same salary even for transferring!!  You are continued to be haunted by ISC Lansing when your no longer assoicated with it  Pay employees what were worth and stop utilizing the words "Low cost center" if you want to keep good hard working employees.  All they care about is utilization for the center no matter what project they get you on even if it is not in your skill set.

Pros:
Simply put, you will be working with a range of professionals who are smart, passionate and either well-respected for their subject matter expertise or the promise of their future potential
 
It is a culture that demands high performance which ensures everyone is bringing their best effort, especially in light of a highly matrix, virtual workforce.

There is solidarity and a very strong emotional connection to understanding the saying of "once an IBMer, always an IBMer"

It has always been an organization that could reinvent itself
Cons:
In the last 10 years, it is an organization that has lost its way, most noticeably on what it means  to have an engaged and empowered workforce.  

While it is essential for organisations to change, IBM has failed to do this with a higher degree of emotional intelligence and organizational savvyness. 

Its greatest asset is its workforce and yet they've become the most embattled

Pros: Negotiated hotel discounts you can use for personal travel (bring your badge).  If all you want to do is follow a bunch of rules and continue to collect great paychecks without really doing much work, this is your place!
Cons: Obsessing about "checking boxes" on stifling bureaucratic processes and silly administrivia rules cast across all employees in attempts to be more efficient that do anything but.  They keep acquiring the smaller and more agile companies I go work for as their source of innovation..

Pros: It is a beginner's job or a job for those already on a pension or another family income. It could lead to other opportunities outside of IBM. When you go to other IBM sites, it's a different and better world.
Cons:
Too many to mention.  Benefits are very expensive.  Under staffed. GBS internal costing has you always working. Take a day off and you have to make up someone else's time off. No flex time. The job is only as good as the manager.  Expect no raises. HR lied about raise and bonus potential when they knew the job had no raise or promotional abilities.  To move up, expect to move out to other sites or out of IBM. 

Management has a "I got mine" mentality.  You need a insider friend to steer you to a better band level. Prepare to be taken advantage of. 

As everything in life... buyer beware!

Pros:
1.) Great coworkers who are always willing to help.
2.) Benefits are just OK.
3.) Not much else. . .
Cons:
1.) 20+ quarters w/o a profit
2.) Layoffs (or RA's, as they are called internally) are the norm. They happened every year I was there. No rhyme or reason for who is selected. They must reduce head count. Expect this every 1Q. Performance terminations occur in 3Q. Every year like clockwork.
3.) Loads of red tape internally. Good luck getting your work done.
4.) Expect new territories every half. Management likes to mix it up and the customers do not take you seriously as they know they will have new reps. in 6 months.
5.) Products are tough sells. Customers see old outdated products (*cough* Lotus Notes *cough*) from an out-of-touch company. With so many RA's, product management unable to deliver promised features on time. Cuts are too deep. But hey! Ginni got her bonus!
6). Check out the Watching IBM Facebook page for others that have been RA or quit because of co-location.

Pros: From day one, I have had a sense that I would be provided every opportunity to succeed. I would be provided the tools and resources to do so. What is communicated from our  organization's VP down, is an expectation to excel at your work, to work hard, and understand that family is first. This type of communication to a large degree, alleviates the family/ work conflict.  In other words, because I am "allowed" to prioritize my family, I don't mind staying late, working early to excel at my work. Flexibility (within reason) has allowed me to take care of doctors appointments, work from home with sick kids, and still excel and communicate my commitment to the company.
Cons: I've started IBM as they have gone away from trend they started; working from home! We have employees that for the past 15 years, have worked from home. I never had the opportunity to do so, but for some of my co workers it has been a tremendous lifestyle adjustment. But such is life. This is the closes thing to a con that I could come up with !

Pros: It's big and can do what it wants
Cons:
Over and over and over again I've seen my leadership plan a process change, an org change, a tool change at a 10,000 ft level and say "we'll figure out the rest when we get in there."
