And over and over and over again they seem mystified as to why they aren't seeing the target results.  They have vision but lack the ability to think through the details.  Changes are rolled out without a thorough stakeholder analysis, without adequate warning, and without adequate training.

There is also no accountability for decision making.  When changes have been rolled out that didn't work well each manager's response was "Well, this issue is above my pay grade".    When issues that could impact our team came up the leaders had to be prompted to push back and make sure the change was really necessary.

Bonus and raise structure was aweful

Pros: Large name with big name clients and deal sizes.
Cons: The culture is overly focused on sales at the expenses of any problems that the consultants will have to fix later down the line. We were never encouraged to sell the right deal. We were encouraged to sell the deal at all costs. For example, my team had to deliver a 4 week consulting engagement. Before my team even touched the ground, the sales team had already spent a week doing "consulting" then asked us to provide the final deliverable in 3 weeks. In fact, they asked us to provide our recommendations the first week we landed. They did all this to win the deal and try to win larger deals but put my team under the gun. Additionally, I had a partner curse at me to center justify a paragraph versus left justify.

Pros: If you luck out with a good management chain then I can see why folks stay in this role for their entire career, but it's unlikely. You can create your own schedule so work-life balance is super flexible as long as your closing deals. I like how we are market segmented, so I only work with customers in a particular industry. Great for providing similar market use cases between customers. Travel was abundant prior to COVID which made the job worth it.
Cons: Number driven, Executives are not supportive, not great culture. I feel alone a lot when it comes to getting help or support from a management level.

Pros: Work-life balance is uncomparable. My manager is the best when it comes to time off for personal reasons. The location I am at is a very tight-knit location. Everyone is like family. There was some negativity within the walls for about 2 years, but it is now gone.
Cons: For IBM to be the 'granddaddy' of the computer/IT, it sure has a long way to go to get all of its systems and applications to talk to each other. There are so many systems and apps that cannot talk to one another which requires ee's to have to do redundant work to get one job done.

Pros: The pride of working for Big Blue, recognition everywhere. It opens doors for me if I want to move on to something else. Great worklife balance and understanding managers. I am allowed freely take time off when I need to, no questions asked. I also get to work with some really brillant people (and of course, some pretty dim ones too) in the cutting edge of technology. There are also a lot of opportunities to move across jobs and functions, which is great because you get to try out different jobs without losing seniority. There is also a very good training structure where you can easily take courses you are interested in.
Cons: I did not like the huge bureacracy that came with a large company. Lots of red tape and also lots of politics. The waves of layoffs I experienced (even though I was not affected) was demoralising, but I guess it's the general economic situation at that time. And being large and old, there are a lot of deadwoods around, people that dont do much work but draw a high pay. Paywise, it was alright but not great. Bonuses were neglible.

Pros: Breadth of opportunities and the people who work at the company.  IBM is a place you can grow and have a career.  For the most part, you can work any where you want.  There are some jobs that are "premier" position" that you may have to work you way in (i.e business development).  Also, the company offers a plethora of opportunities enhance your skills and knowledge.  The offer tuition reimbursement for advanced education and offer numerous internal educational courses.  The majority of staff, middle management, and executives are really good people with hard working values who care about people.
Cons: Salary increases and bonus plans for non sales people are poor.  They will hire you at a competitive rate but if you are not in a critical area, expect a "national inflation" rate salary increase.  Doesn't do much if you live in area where the cost of living is above the national average.  In the Accounting and Finance positions, expect to work long and hard, especially if you are in entry level positions.  The costs don't out weigh the benefits.

Pros: IBM is a very diverse organization.  There are so many opportunities to get involved with different projects and different people with lots of opportunities for change.  IBM also provides many training opportunities for employees.
Cons: As a large corporation, it is sometimes cumbersome to navigate the rigorous evaluation procedures which include multiple deadlines and formal standards for year end reviews, promotions, and the goal-setting process.  As a result, all of these processes take an excessively long time to complete.  Additionally, as a big corporation, it is possible to feel disconnected from people, even your own manager.  I was lucky enough to find strong leadership and a supportive team on the project I was assigned, but if these things are lacking, it is possible to get lost in the shuffle.

Pros: working for a big, global company, participation on Smarter Planet projects, resource manager helps you find projects, leveraging previous IBM assets and tools make work easier and quicker, some big offices (Chicago, NYC, DC, Boston, Dallas) have a good sense of community and plan social events. Get to keep all your frequent flier miles and hotel points.
Cons: utilization heavily counted for performance evaluation, most projects only allow 40 hours max be billed to the client (regardless of how many hours over 40 were actually worked). promotions only happen once per year. have to write long project assessments (2-5+ pages) about each role on every project to be included in end of year evaluation. No compensation for continuing education (whether it be for an advance degree, or just attending lectures, conferences, etc). Only associate partners and higher and sales people get mobile access to their email. We are given out-of-date or used laptops and then expected to re-image them ourselves if it crashes. Meal allowance is per city and must report actuals (not allowed to expense flat per diem)

Pros: Experience over a 30 year career at IBM was that the company allowed me to grow and move with the business.  Both helping IBM enter new markets but also challenging me with a variety of assignments.  IBM truly has embraced the work life integration in that they are very supportive of building schedules that support both your own personal life but also the varied hours a global workforce requires.  IBM's management structure does support you focusing on your Client's needs - although flexibility within the organization has to be actively worked by your management team.
Cons: As with any large organization, the IBM structure can be intimidating for those that are new to the organization.  IBM's organization history does support two way conversation on corporate policy which can slow things down - but in the end deliver the best decision.

Pros: Great people, good benefits, stable company, culture of trying to do good for the world through innovation.  Industry-leading technology in some areas.  There are many pockets of people trying to do the right thing for IBM despite HQ Finance's direction.
Cons: It's frustrating always to be losing colleagues who quit because they got frustrated with IBM's 2015 Roadmap-driven lack of investment in areas that would provide sustainable competitive advantage - both in technology and compensation.  Employees are treated as interchangeable resources - history and experience don't matter when Finance orders its annual job cuts.  This has demoralized the workforce and inhibited innovative thinking.  People are afraid to transfer internally within IBM because they likely will be the first selected should a Resource Action hit their new organization; as a result, cross-pollination of experience and skills that used to lead to great innovations just isn't happening.

Pros:
Really great benefits: medical insurance is great, college hires get 15 days vacation off the bat, they have a wellness program to follow where they give you a rebate, work-life balance is determined by you (you can choose to work only 40 hr a week or you can choose to work more). 
Wonderful to have a Big 5 company on your resume. 
Higher salary over many other companies when starting as a college hire.
Cons:
They have great benefits when getting hired out of college, but they do a poor job of teaching college hires the ropes. IBM will place a young (cheap) college hire anywhere and expect them to know the business process/area. There's not much room to grow as a college hire and not much choice on project, you're basically just placed into a position if you have little experience. Even they've said it, you're a body that is charging the client and making a profit for them. 
Raises are extremely small, bonuses are rare. They try to cut back to make more profit for themselves and don't reward their 'minions' for the work they do.

Pros: IBM was great when I first started in 2005. It wen down hill 3 years later.  Good health care benefits. The only thing that made me stick around was I had a great manager.
Cons: Constantly outsourcing. Have to hand hold India staff. No accountability for offshore staff and their inability. No work life balance. Upper management constantly trying to work exempt staff 60 hours a week. Pay raises and/or bonuses are years apart if you get one. IBM focused on doing the least amount of work possible for the contract. They don't supply the software/tools to do the job. Only way to get tools is if it was freeware. There was no career path. I was stuck doing the same thing for years and losing my skill set. Getting cut from IBM was the best thing that ever happened with IBM. I attended 2 training classes in the 10 years I was there. And that was in the fist 3 years before it fell apart.

Pros: Work from home, benefits package (insurance), my teammates are great.
Cons:
It's no longer a great place to work. The company no longer values its employees. The only thing that seems to matter is the bottom line and it seems they only way that they know how to make "the numbers" is to lay people off and move the work to lower skilled and much cheaper "off-shore" employees. It really sucks when you get a lay off notice and they force you to train your replacement in another country. 

Moral is at an all time low for everyone I work with so no one wants to do a good job anyone. 

They keep getting rid of good skilled employees and replacing them off with off-shore resources, without reducing the workload. What they fail to realize is that something that took a couple hours to complete now takes days...due to language barriers and time zone differences. How is that more cost effective? 

It also seems like the company has been in 'transformation' for YEARS. It is very difficult to get and keep ones bearings when it's likely that everything will change again before too long. Why even try to keep up?

Pros:
The culture is a mosaic, made up on all its acquisitions.  Some organizations are very cut-throat; others are more cooperative.  In my organization,  all of my colleagues pull together and support each other. Plus, my manager is supportive and one of the best I've ever had. 

There is some room for movement within an organization and between organizations.  I've seen several colleagues make lateral moves.   If you're aggressive, you can move up.
Cons: The company has lost $ for 20 straight quarters, so there are constant layoffs.  Whole divisions disappear overnight.  All this while giving the CEO a HUGE raise. Currently, there is a hiring freeze and internal travel ban.  Also, IBM doesn't invest in R&D.  They buy a company, "blue wash" it, and then allow it to sink or swim without investing in the technology.

Pros: Great 1st and 2nd line management. Benefits are very good. Work from home was good before that is being taken away in more recent times. Salary very good. Teams of peers are the best.
Cons: IBM seems to regard employees as they approach retirement as disposable. When given an RA package for separation  and told they have 90 days to find another job internally the work against the employee. I had 2 opportunities of managers that wanted to transfer me into their dept and both times were denied by executive levels and / or HR. After 30+ years it's sad to say IBM no longer cares for their loyal and highly productive employees as they are nearing retirement

Pros: Worked with some great colleagues with an opportunity to lean from employer | clients alike to build skills and intellectual capital.  Historically focused on being a loyal and integrity-driven company, though that has changed over time.  Still would recommend accepting an offer of employment, but look at it as a way to get experience and move on - no longer a long-term career choice.
Cons: Leadership invests too much into stock buy-backs and not enough into solutions.  Truly a quarter-by-quarter decision company with great commercials but weak long-term strategy.  Big move to bring in Millennials at the expense of seasoned Professionals; finding the latter lack the skills, motivation and loyalty to carry the company forward.  Technology is not well-integrated, and Cloud offerings often lack functionality.

Pros:
A lot of people like to make the blanket statement that just because one's experience at a company was bad, then the company itself is bad. Yes, there have been horror stories about layoffs/RAs and out-of-date tech and annoying in-house software, but just remember that with how many teams and employees IBM has, your (potential) experience won't be like that of others.

For example, I have:
-seniors and managers who care deeply about my professional development
-a modern tech stack, where almost nothing is internal (I'm looking at you, IBM Verse)
-amazing work flexibility so I can balance my personal life and my work.

For my priorities, my position at IBM is exactly what I needed for who I am and where I am in my life right now.
Cons: -Everyone has a lingering worry that they're going to get laid off, which isn't healthy for the morale or our work ethic.

Pros: For those afforded the opportunity to work from home, there is great work/life balance.  The company does have some decent benefits, though healthcare benefits have waned dramatically over the past few years.  The biggest benefit of working in a company like IBM, however, is the ability to move into different roles and try new things. The company is vast, and opportunities abound.
Cons: I've worked at IBM for many years.  The culture has shifted dramatically, and not all for the good.  The executives clearly don't care much about the individual employee and are focused, quarter to quarter, on the stockholders only.  They have yet to realize that treating the employees well will result in better results, better profitability.  The shift to "co-location" within the past couple of years has done a lot of damage to morale, even for those not directly impacted.

Pros:
Good breath of technology
Decent benefits
Cons:
IBM has ZERO loyalty to its employees, particularly in the US.
Work goes offshore -> fire US employee
Cheaper out of college resource available -> fire US employee

Also, as documented in various lawsuits and industry articles, if you are over 40, there is a target in your head. You work hard, and get good reviews throughout your career, so that you reach a decent salary band. Great, right? Wrong. Because now you are too expensive for IBM to make a good profit margin, so you are a top candidate for one of the many Resource Actions. That's when there is an arbitrary order from the top for managers to cut a certain percentage of people above a certain band.

For the record, I'm still employed by IBM, and managed to survive many rounds of cuts. But I have absolutely no illusions that my job is safe.

If you are young and need a relatively low starting salary, IBM is probably hiring across all fronts.  So you can make a quick buck. But if you're interested in starting at a company where you can grow, look elsewhere.

Pros: This company is a giant with tons of different job opportunities available throughout your entire career with them should you want to try something new. The company is very forward thinking and is always willing to work with you to give whatever accomodations are necessary for you to perform your job well. The general attitude in the office is accepting, friendly, and collaborative. If you are the type to always be interested in the next big thing, IBM strongly values innovation, so keeping up with new technologies and being able to recognize how they may benefit your product is great habit to have.
Cons: Being such a large company with so many employees there is a lot of red tape and processes for everything. Office politics play a very big role in how your career grows or doesn't. In most positions you will have an active customer base and may need to work odd or extra hours as customer issues come up, which can be stressful. Higher level managers who make promotion and pay rate decisions may be disconnected enough from the actual team member to only make decisions based on what they hear from others.

Pros: Working at IBM you're always (if you're in the right group) surrounded by smart people who can teach you a lot - about tech, running projects, and turning projects around. The WLB is also good, and direct management definitely seems to care about you as a person.
Cons: There is a culture of mediocrity (slow and steady would be the nicer way to put it), that seems leftover from the old days when 30 years at IBM guaranteed you a full pension. For the most part, managers seem surprised when you ask what it takes to get promoted quickly. It's hard to get straight answers, and frequently the manager who gave you advice winds up leaving by the time they suggested you get promoted.

Pros:
- Non-salary benefits are good (time off, insurance, 401k, etc)
- Good learning experience for the fundamentals of a data center
- Job security (if you know what you are doing, you're pretty safe because they literally can not afford to fire you due to staffing issues even if you mess-up)
- Free snacks
Cons:
- Overworked and constantly understaffed
- High turnover rate
- Management (anyone above the site manager is a write-off, your local site manager can be hit or miss)
- Uncompetitive salary
- Outside of Dallas, your ability to move into other IBM Cloud IaaS teams (like network or compute) is non-existent

Pros: Corporate programs for work flexibility, benefits, good learning place for interns
Cons: Those corporate programs are not available to all, work load/targets are usually unrealistic, salary increases/bonus have not kept up with inflation for the last 10 years and show no signs of doing so going forward, no career progression in several areas after band 8 -- and the continual off shoring of jobs means you have no job security.  Ratings are a quota system, not rating  of performance.  High level of employee burn-out under the current politics

Pros: Great name recognition; IBM is a very well respected brand across the board. As a result, you'll get exposure to client work with top players across various industries.
Cons: For those looking to do pure strategy consulting work, this is the wrong firm (no matter what the recruiters tell you). There's so many organizational changes it's hard to keep up. And the company is so big, you can feel "lost", and moves to other opportunities are rare and complicated. It's also VERY hierarchical and bureaucratic; I know of several who had their hands slapped for having the nerve to ask a question of a high level manager or partner (exact words were "if you knew what their position is, you'd know not to bother them with a question about our little team". That says a lot right there. Also, in a case of irony, the technology supplied for IBMers is subpar, and the movement of information throughout the company is slow and archaic.

Pros:
1. Big company resources
2. Progressive company culture
3. Diversified product set allows for general stability and multiple opportunities
4. Pay has been consistent despite down economy
5. Linux
Cons:
1.  Far too much cost-cutting to make (apparently arbitrary) numbers
2.  Top-down driven decision-making with poor communication.  Hard-to-understand directives coming from the heavens without explanation.
3.  Bonuses have been disconnected from personal achievement, resulting in no real incentive to work hard any longer
4.  Fear or inability to fire low performers results in a company full of people just "doing enough not to get fired"
5.  Inability to reward top performers enough relative to how hard they work
6.  Spend money on things that help employees do their jobs.
7.  Astoundingly bad internal helpdesk support

Pros:
Technical breadth and customer opportunities are hard to beat since IBM still is one of the largest tech companies in the world. 

If you can find them, there is an IBM expert on everything (kind of like the Federal Government)
Cons:
IBM used to a stable career choice, but with Resource Actions an annual event for the last five years, its hard to imagine being able to last long enough to retire or even make a difference here.   The typical IBM employee now is a new hire, lasts 1 to 3 years (just long enough to show one or two stable roles on the resume), then takes the resume to get a job somewhere else.

The first and apparently only response to negative financial quarters is - do an RA, freeze hiring and salaries, eliminate training and customer travel, shift work to lower skilled, lower paid resources, shift work offshore.

Pros: Depending on the job, working remotely from home can be a nice perk, although some divisions are beginning to change back to seated positions. Peers and management are generally professional. Employees are more mature and experienced, which could be a pro or a con, depending on your preferences.
Cons: If you want to build up your resume, not a bad place for a couple of years. If you want to grow with a company, this company is not for you. IBM won't hesitate to offshore, outsource or divest your job in a heartbeat, maybe replace you with an H1B. The company has become rudderless and the CEO has led the company to 13 straight bad quarters, it is living off of it's past reputation and the IBM stock has dropped like a rock. Only about 82K US employees left and dropping about 5-10% every year. Most jobs now are in India, Brazil, Malaysia, Mexico, Eastern Europe etc. Company is top heavy and has too many middle managers. HR is from another planet, you can expect tons of propaganda.

Pros: They hire some good people. If you must work at home, they will love you for that.
Cons: More bad managers than good. Employee development is virtual and done in a vacuum. They cut people rather than retrain them, which means IBM does not value the institutional knowledge required to work effectively in the company. Because the workforce is largely virtual, the collaboration suffers. It is difficult to find new opportunities in different organizations. Being a new employee is difficult. The strategy changes yearly, and is often buzz-word driven. I was there twice. The first time it was the best place to work. The second time... well, I left of my own accord and can't tell you the relief I've felt.

Pros:
The world-renowned sales training that you get during the Summit Program far exceeds other top companies.  There is a mix of executive speakers, classroom sales training, abundant live sales training with experienced IBM sellers, technology training, and professional advice that really prepares you for a career in professional consultative sales.

Beyond just the training, there is a great opportunity to network with peers in the Summit program as well as IBMers outside of the program.  The networking is a huge benefit from a personal friendship and a professional standpoint.  Much of the training takes place in cities around the country, so there is an opportunity to work remotely.

I have only been in the Summit Program for a few months, but I am already very impressed.  I know multiple IBMers that have graduated from the Summit Program and have been very successful.  I am proud to be part of this great program and great company.
Cons: IBM is a large company, which has its advantages/disadvantages.  One disadvantage is that there is plenty of administrative work that has to be done, but that is common with many professional roles.

Pros:
Challenging Work
Agile, Fast-Paced and Innovative
Work with Great Talent
Cons: IBM Executives do not seem to care about retaining talent anymore.  I have seen people being forced to relocate under a drive to get everyone back in an office.  Also, seen some reorgs that set some people up to fail.  Literally just drives some of the very best talent to the competition.  Very short-sighted and very sad.

Pros: Always new technology and ideas to work on.  You can do pretty much whatever you want, learn whatever you want - as long as you make money for the company.  You can have a long career in various roles within the company.  Very flexible work/life - lots of remote workers.
Cons: In the last couple years, IBM has been doing tons of layoffs.  They are chopping here and there, whatever is needed to make the quarterly earnings report look good.  They have lost a lot of great people.  At the same time, they are hiring people like mad too.  There are constant re-orgs.  Don't be surprised if your manager changes every year.  And perhaps the name of your organization too.  You can do fine there.. but you could get randomly hit too.  Just be careful and always be prepared.

Pros: Access to lots of talent, team work culture with everyone willing to contribute, great technology and very strong vision. Global scale and resources. Deep industry expertise.
Cons: Corporate overhead is killing competitiveness. Deals are burdened with it, resulting is low margins and increased risk due to team sizes cut to the bone. The indirect overheads come from old real estate and an excessive number of executives on high salaries falling over themselves to be associated with a deal.

Pros: Free training. A way to get into a tech career path if you have a record and no experience, but get out quick.
Cons: Under paid, you'll kill your car because they don't (didn't) give company vehicles, overtime daily that I never got paid for unless I fought daily to make sure it was approved my management, management doesn't care about you. I was in a car accident and hit by a car, on different days lol both times management didn't care at all and asked if I could work any calls that night to compensate the time spent dealing with those incidents. I completed the most calls of any SSR in our area and my bosses response was, "great job, do you think you can get to one more call?" Not even jokingly. I was given no time off when my wife had our baby. We had racist managers, better hope you're a white male. We also saw discrimination against older folks. I could go on, but the gist is that I don't recommend.

Pros: Great benefits and training - IBM never really looks bad on your resume
Cons: Pay - If you are a motivated and industrious hard worker, you are better off elsewhere. Socialized earnings - top and bottom not much difference. Better have a manager who will fight for your commissions. I continually blew out my quota but was given retroactive quota increases - that resulted in negative commission checks! Yes - I am being serious. Explanation: "Since you do so well and were paid in the bonus in the previous quarter, with the increased quota, you were actually overpaid ... so you owe us money." They never made you pay it and tried to make it sound like you were being done a favor when it was 'wiped clean' at the beginning of the next year. Net net - they fund you not off the dollars you sell but at a percentage of your salary. Go someplace that pays you for what you actually sell at a guaranteed rate.

Pros: Opportunities for travel and global work are unparalleled.  Ability to reach out to others and work a difficult problem both encouraged and easy.  Systems for productivity and access to facilities no matter where you travel was tremendous boost.
Cons: Expectation for many jobs on consulting side was travel each and every week.  IBM is a globe hopping firm and if you want to get off the baggage carousel you limit your ability to remain viable in the firm.

Pros: Work From Home. Excellent technical growth opportunities.
Cons:
IBM will make you work like a Donkey. Work life balance is good only when things are easy for management. When it is crunch time, the managers will demand that you work day and night, weekends as well. You will then be told that you did an average job. Many managers don't have a clue of what their employees are coding. Many managers have no programming experience so they can't evaluate your pains. Management collects huge bonuses based on profit sharing. But most employees won't see any of that $.
If you have no self respect and can tolerate annual humiliation, sure go ahead and work for IBM.

Pros: Consulting work can be challenging, a great opportunity to learn, travel and gain a lot of experience quickly.  IBM can provide an excellent name to a resume with worldwide recognition and offer you insight into the world of IT that would be hard to find at most other IT employers.
Cons:
As a consultant you are expected to put in some long hours on the job, hours that IBM expects, not appreciates.  Additionally, you should plan on adding in travel time on top of the work hours put in for the client and having to deal with IBM's restrictive (occasionally bizarre) travel and expense policies.  

Promotions are often based on your ability to jump through hoops (disguised as "development"), fill out review forms and suck up to reviewers/partners, sadly these often have little to do with client satisfaction and adding value to the projects for which you work.

Pros:
Lots of very smart people
The technical teams are willing to share knowledge and information
Access to a wide variety of market and technology areas
Cons:
The company is ruled by Earnings per Share, the metric that the Executives are compensated by
There are way too many Executive level people. 
Non-executive people are compensated based on the company's revenue.  
Revenue is declining so the Executives constantly cut expenses to keep EPS high so THEY can get compensation
Every year or so a new set of management comes in and completely changes the strategy.  Then the technical people have to clean up the broken glass from the previous regime and try to shift to the new strategy.  
None of these strategies use a keep-it-simple approach.  In true IBM fashion the product plans attempt to do everything for everyone and end up doing nothing well.

Pros: Most people at IBM are smart, collaborative, dedicated and enjoyable to work with. Working remotely allows for flexibility and convenience for both the employee and the company. Many of the products and services are innovative and keep the work varied and interesting. Most of the day-to-day tools and technology are helpful in efficiently doing ones job.
Cons: The organization is too middle heavy with 2-3 levels of management spending too much time  "managing up". Increases in salary doesn't come easy and there is a review/rating process that is cumbersome and not balanced to contribution. Many managers and directors are not familiar with the work their team does, so they are unable to train, mentor and sometimes appreciate the efforts. Much time spent by managers telling up the chain what they want to hear vs what they need to hear (and advocating for the people who work for them).

Pros: Huge company with real potential for the few scientist that are out there. Secure work environment for people who are willing to work some extra. The company is not going anywhere anytime soon. Opportunities to stay local or global as much as you like. Chances are the company has various positions for talented people - not just one.
Cons:
Get used to a number because that's what you will be known by if you are the average Joe and that number may get cut if the need arises. Numbers is all this company is about. Acquire and merge when the numbers work out, then cut and let the remaining numbers work for you.
Don't think agile! A flagship this size doesn't move easy nor fast. You may get frustrated quickly unless you got your retirement in sight - safe place to be!

Pros: The people at IBM are wonderful.
Cons:
I have been working for IBM for over 20 years.  There have been layoffs every year, so there has never been any real job security.  I have been waiting for years for when it would be my time to get "RA'ed" - nice word for laid off.

I enjoyed my team, and I worked from home, so I stayed at IBM, even though it grew increasingly stressful.  My manager actually told me that he didn't like to have female employees work for him, he "didn't like the drama."

Well, after all of these years, all of the remote employees in my area have been told that they must physically be in a lab (San Jose for me).  We have 30 days to make a decision.  If we don't relocate to San Jose, then we will have 60 days notice, and then will have to resign, since this is a condition of employment.

I feel like I've been punched in the gut.  But why am I surprised?  IBM has been taking away benefits from it's employees every year.  I am sick.  There is absolutely no respect for their employees.

Pros: The scope and scale of IBM is unmatched. Doing "big things" represent what IBM does best; including driving ww business ecosystems, creating and reinventing markets, and delivering ground breaking technology. It is a good company that gives back to the community and the world through its products, services and philanthropy. It is a generally stable place of employment with options for advancement and options to try your hand at multiple roles and new endeavors during your career.
Cons: IBM is a sales first culture. Everything comes second behind the immediate sale opportunity; including client relationships, employee needs and retention, and everything else. IBM is constantly reinveting itself and currently going through a down cycle as revenue and profitability have missed market expectations for 16 straight quarters. This constant reinvention creates constant shifts in org structure and business strategy that are usually not well communicated or executed, and thus great inconsistency for the employee. This inconsistency causes turmoil, degrades morale, causes talent attrition and limits business results. Also, career advancement does not always equate to equal compensation advancement as many employees find it difficult to gain equivalent compensation through promotion/advancement.

Pros: Good IT Job, excellent manager, excellent M-F hours, average benefits compared to what's happened to USA in recent years.
Cons: This IBM facility likes to pigeon-hole its staff into a position and a department. Transferring to a different department nearly impossible even if you're a stellar employee. This facility runs like an assembly line of data jobs. You will miss out on learning new technologies. You are taught to stay at your dept. for years and do the same thing over and over. Started at 1200 (1300 never attained) employees in 2009 and in recent years almost all jobs were moved over to India. Only less than 300 now work in IA. Have to pay to park your car. No parking. State income tax.

Pros:
Pleased with middle management: In 2 years, I've had 3 different direct managers who were very attentive and invested in my professional development as a university/new graduate hire.
Friendly and helpful work environment: All of my coworkers were extremely knowledgable and helpful, and getting tasks done never felt adversarial.
Flexible work environment: many employees work from home and are still able to communicate with each other effectively
Cons: Reward scheme is awful to nonexistent: Before the end of my first year, I transitioned from QA to development at my own request to work on a newer product. Despite helping present for a conference and receiving a PBC 1, I wasn't given any sort of raise, promotion or stock options package. My starting salary was far below market value and did not change at all in two years. I know lateral moves seem to be the only way to get a raise these days (I negotiated a 30% raise plus stock options). It felt like a lost cause once I had to initiate negotiation for a pay raise.

Pros: IBM is the most innovative company on the planet.  You are surrounded by brilliant people and resources.  Anything can be accomplished due to what seems like unlimited capabilities and potential. For the best opportunity, you must work in a Strategic Growth Unit, (Watson, Analytics, SW, Cloud, Security)
Cons: Unfortunately, IBM is going through another (and continuous) transformation.  They are moving from a $100 Billion IT Product and Services Company to a much smaller higher value company focusing on Enterprise Innovation.  There is much people damage left in the wake.  They operate with a "king has no clothes" and bully mentality.  Lot's of "yes" men in the management change and very few with the guts to "do what is right" for its people and clients.  From this perspective, IBM is broken.

Pros: I learned a lot, which will help me with future jobs.
Cons:
Where to start.  I honestly can't decide what was worse, the projects or the people. The project I worked on was miserable, and every single person on the team wanted to leave (and many eventually did, even the manager, who told us she really didn't want to be here anymore). 

And then there was the people. What do you get when you mix inexperience with over confidence? You guessed it! An IBMer.  Every single day I had to sit across from a coworker who continually bragged about his accolades and achievements, meanwhile doing absolutely nothing. Unfortunately, this guy was not an anomaly at IBM Design.  During Design Bootcamp, there was so much immaturity among the new hires that some designers flat out REFUSED to work with each other, and therefore had to be separated (kind of like in Kindergarten when one kid steals the other's crayon). One girl even started crying when another girl critiqued her wireframe "too harshly" and went and told on her to a design lead.  I wish I was joking. I would sit back and watch all this happen, completely floored by the fact that people like this had passed the culture fit part of the interview.

Pros:
- International company; lots of opportunities to interface with people from different backgrounds and perspectives
- Part of a company that houses some of the best inventors and patent holders in the past decade; Exposure to some of the smartest minds in industry
- New technology is pervasive at IBM; whether you are interested in Agile, Design Thinking, Artificial Intelligence, Cybersecurity or more - there is an opportunity for you to learn and contribute
- Great compensation and benefits
- Depending on team, opportunity for flexible and remote work
Cons:
- With a company of more than 300,000 people, it's hard to have a consistent company culture or set of values across the organization; every division and team will have its own set of expectations
- For some, growth trajectory can often be slow given the limits on how many people can be promoted a year
- While there are lots of exciting things going on at IBM, a lot of where you end up depends on timing and luck versus merit

Pros: Great coworkers who love to collaborate and share their wealth of knowledge before they retire... and that's about it.
Cons:
Teams run extremely lean due to upper management not understanding how the business truly works. Accountants seem to run the company with consistent downsizing almost yearly. Without thinking, they will layoff too many people and then wonder why financial, support, and production goals can not be met. Too many cooks in the kitchen for sure.

401K match is a joke at 2%, and you only get it at the end of the year thus missing out on compounded interest. Compensation is below average and they know it. You will be told, "when you leave you will have the prestige of having worked at IBM and can negotiate a better salary."

Stay away from GTS division at all costs; you will eventually be forced to up-train your replacement over seas.

Pros: A dynamic and flexible work environment that allows for an intrapreneurial approach to managing internal and external IBM customers. A wealth of talent to draw and learn from. Excellent continuing training and educational benefits.
Cons: IBM is not a work environment for non-self-starters as employees are expected to have high business and personal standards; business expectations and customer satisfaction run high so employees must be diligent and innovative. While many may find this as a "Con", I found it to be highly motivational; who doesn't want to be on a team determined to win? IBM plays to win - so do I! You will need to if you want to exceed expectations and receive real rewards.

Job Title: Customer engineer ii in san jose, ca: (past employee - 2009)
Pros:
Pros
customer engineer work is fun & customers are glad to see you.

a breadth of stores and banks means you do not get bored.
Cons:
Cons
emphasis on numbers, quantity not quality.
management expects things to get fixed, with no regards to time/distance,manpower resources, support, training, parts needed.
they expect you to meet 3 numbers (86%): a/ get to the site within 1/2 hrs. b/get it fixed now/today. c/numbers of stores (min 5 a day)
my territory was 2hrs long & 1 hr wide. I spend average 3 hrs driving a day, and still be expected to meet numbers.
management is nut: one day i was told to work til you drop (respond to ATM service 7/24/365), next day "no OT without approval from manager"
company release shoddy/unreliable machinery (check processing module) to bank of america, without any training to field service engineers. Then months later were forced to send them to training only when we have to revisit the same machine twice a day (because engineers don't know how to fix)

Pros:
IBM continues to lead the industry in many technology areas.  
The ability to work an entire career, changing jobs, skills and even geographies at one company is rare, but possible with IBM.  
Although IBM has acquired a significant number of technology companies, there is still a significant investment in internal R&D.  
The IBM name still has clout around the world.
The total compensation package (benefits, bonuses and pay) are slightly higher than at other multinational high-tech firms.
IBM has demonstrated the ability to evolve and grow in a changing market place.
IBM, as a company, generally does much more good than harm for society
Cons:
IBM has ceded the consumer space to other companies which makes the products and services IBM produces less 'flashy'.
The upside potential for compensation is not as high as it might be at some smaller companies.
Must be self-motivated to really want to excel and achieve good things and take a long-term view to really want to work at IBM.

Pros:
IBM culture and management have traditionally been supportive of employees' advancement and career development, allowing for people to try different disciplines.  There is a system in place to ensure that promotions and financial compensation/incentives are merit based (not based on internal politics).

I think that the financial compensation is competitive with industry standards.  Though benefits seem to have been cut back over the years, I think they are still competitive with the industry.
Cons:
It seems more and more evident that everything at IBM comes down to "the bottom line" (money/revenue).  Earnings per share (and the resulting Executive compensation) seems to have become more important to the corporation than their employees.

The company cuts back costs (staff, equipment, contract services) at the expense of the workers.  Meaning we are expected to "do more with less."  This mentality seemed reasonable at first, but it has perpetuated into a vicious cycle where we expect more and more (and more!) out of our people.  Many/Most people are overworked, and work-life balance seems to be a distant memory.

While the culture has traditionally supported employee career development, in harder economic times managers can be reluctant to let their good employees pursue opportunities, for fear of losing the head count - Finance will see it as a chance to save money (and not allow you to backfill the position)... So if somebody leaves your group, more likely than not, one of the existing team members will just have to absorb the additional work... again adding to the overworked staff.

There are MANY corporate practices/processes that have been put in place over many years. Most (not all) of these processes were meant to make sure that the teams delivered a high quality product that met certain industry standards/regulations.  Though we cut back on staff, and we have to do more with less, we never seem to cut back on process.  This is a double-edges sword... Cutting back on some of these practices/process may cause us to deliver a poorer quality product, or to not meet certain standards/regulations... But not cutting back on process means that more and more of our time is spent navigating process.  Spending time on this, and trying to get your "real work" done adds to the problem of an overworked staff.

While there is a system in place to compensate based on merit, over the years the differentiation between the best employees and the average employees has become laughable (corporate funding for these programs seem lower than expected, especially considering reported company earnings).  The minuscule difference between compensation for the best and the average employees have made many people question the point of working so hard (If you can put in less effort and get compensated the same, why kill yourself working 60 hour weeks???).

Finance seems to be making many decisions which they are not qualified to make.  All they care about revenue versus expense.  They have been given power to dictate our expenses, though they do not understand the impact of cutting certain expenses.  Penny pinching today may cause you revenue for the next few years if we don't have enough resources to put out  a product.

Pros: Opportunity to work in different projects and clients.
Cons: Management has no loyalty for its employees. Employees are considered inventory rather than people. Change and growth enabled unqualified people to rise to executive positions. I was rated a 2+ and the following year my client had a large cut in their budget. Consequently, the client cut every contract in place and rescinded existing opportunities. Although my client directed as much work as possible to us, my sales were significantly down from the prior year when I was rated a 2+. Although I had been part of the organization from pre-PWC days and I was known for excellent to outstanding work, I was summarily fired although IBM tried to sugar coat it by saying there were too many employees at my level. This classification was a joke as they promoted others to band 10 during the same review. One of the employees promoted to band 10 had been fired by a client for doing a poor job yet the employee was promoted.

Pros: Although work-life balance continues to suffer with each passing year, you are still flexible to take care of errands and appointments as needed. There is a plethora of talented people in the workplace. And for the most part, there is mutual respect among co-workers.
Cons:
Work morale is at an all-time low due to layoffs and feeling underappreciated by upper management. Because of this, most of the employees who would otherwise be motivated and passionate to innovate, just put in their time, and hope they survive the next round. Perks are practically nonexistent. Benefits, if you can even call it that, continue to get worse.

Salary is subpar compared to the competition. And salary increases are a meager 1-3%, if you are even lucky to get one. Promotions are quite difficult to come by, and management does little to nothing to help you grow in your career.

The buildings are old and dilapidated, and many of the offices are vacant. This sets off a depressing mood as you stroll down the hallways. But what I find most amusing are the water fountains that are not chilled. What's up with that?

Pros: IBM has the great strength of being a huge company with numerous deeply skilled individuals who will be your peers.  Most are more than willing to collaborate or answer a question when asked.  The benefits are good, though you will not find perks like free lunches (or even free coffees).  The salaries are competitive.  And if you work really hard, you will advance along.
Cons: As with any large organization, the mix of businesses that are successful changes over time.  If you find yourself in a role or division that is no longer contributing value, your position is in jeopardy.  Additionally, the IBM background has a mixed reputation in industry.  It can mean great customer skills and deep innovation, or it can mean slow, legacy, last generation technology.

Pros: Great working conditions. If you have a technical job that can be done remotely all you need is a computer, internet connection and a phone. I was able to do my job completely from home for the last year I was there. Prior to that we were only required to be in the physical office 2-3 days a week.
Cons: Management seemed to always be nervous about any changes from the top and it trickles down to the staff. When I was there, IBM seemed to cut staff every other quarter, especially if they have acquired the IT department of another company or state government. The point is, IBM does not care nor do they value the people  quality people that work there. If your department is downsized, it does not matter how long you have been with the company and they make it difficult to transfer to other departments or accounts.

Pros:
Large organization that you can move around and find different opportunities.
Innovative company with leading edge or first of a kind technology solutions.
Corporate Services Corp Leadership Program.
Cons:
Eliminating vast majority of US resources for cheaper off shore labor.
Can be a top performer with all the accolades possible and still be let go in order to be replaced with cheaper labor off shore, which is the path the company continues to do.
Working remotely is now much more rare as most employees have to be co-located in only one of handful of cities in the US.
Poor HR management structure. You are typically on your own as far as career development and have to strongly advocate for yourself even for things as simple as training.
Very expensive health benefits especially if you have more than 1 child.
Minimal bonus and raises even for top performers.

Pros: Worked with a lot of good professionals that cared about what they were doing. Full time work at home (if that's your thing).
Cons:
Where to start. Everything is #1 - no alignment at the Portfolio or across Senior Portfolio Executive Level to clearly define the top initiatives that align to the organization's strategy and short term goals. A LOT of escalations to "pull a resource from your #1 project to support my #1 project." No work/life balance and loads of weekend/overnight work. 

Pay is substantially LOWER than market average - even after obtaining certifications. I was promoted in title several times without compensation.

Lastly, if job security is important to you this is not the place. Most of the jobs have been shipped off-shore (without consent of the customer I might add). Global Delivery Centers established just a few years ago within the U.S. are ghost towns as the jobs promised to the community are now - overseas.

Pros: Decent bonus structure if they give it to you. If you’re in good with upper management the sky is the limit. If they are gone or move on you have to start again. Be aware of this and know your second and third plus line bosses and your journey is fulfilling.
Cons:
There’s no rhyme or reason to the layoffs. In February of my last year as a technical person I made a 90k bonus responsible for large sales. One month later told my position no longer needed. The funny thing is they would keep continue to hire people for the same role that was going away.

Everything about IBM is now a who you know up top to shield you. You lose your safety shield and you’re exposed. It’s dumb when you see worldwide experts let go, but those who are just buddy buddy with upper management are kept around when others do their role for them.

Pros: The biggest pro of a entry level financial analyst at IBM is simply being able to put the IBM Name on your resume. Other than that I did not find many benefits to working in this finance center.
Cons:
Poor management: The managers in the finance center have little to no training, they are simply Financial Analysts that have been with the company too long and want to get promoted. They have no experience or skill in managing employees. 

Time on the "Bench": You have little to no control over your career in the first 2-3 years at IBM your manager will have full control over any horizontal/vertical movements you desire to make as there is no internal job application platform. Some employees will be put on the bench after being hired, meaning you will have no job to do, in my case I was told to watch Netflix on my first day. 

Poor work culture: Older employees are constantly afraid of getting laid off, entry level employees will work very hard and not see any recognition, some employees will sleep at their desk and nothing will be done.

Pros: Decent pay, Benefits, some flexibility
Cons:
I've worked for two different teams but with many in my time at IBM. The communication makes it feel as though there are no teams. Just people working alone. Larger goals of teams and company are unclear. The inter workings of the software are as complex as they come and to boot there is a real lack of documentation and training. Its all cult knowledge that will take years and years to obtain. 

There is easy early advancement but its just too keep you interested.

Large workloads and if you are not someone looking for a place to retire this probably isn't the spot for you. General sentiments are a real lack of fulfillment and purpose.

Pros: Working hours can be flexible since a lot is done remotely (but you will work A LOT of hours). Access to a lot of quality on-line education (if you have time to do it after you finish working A LOT of hours).
Cons: Not enough focus on giving people time for career development. Aggressive (sometimes unreasonable) schedules/deadlines for projects. Constant reorganizing of teams and resource actions (lay-offs) leaves many teams understaffed and lacking skills for achieving success. Employees are no longer treated with respect from upper management. Team reorganization and technical decisions are make without consulting the people below actually doing the work in many cases. Most jobs are going to the "low cost geos" like India for example. You may benefit from working in IBM for a while, but long term, be prepared to burn out.

Pros:
There are some very talented individuals I had the pleasure of working with.
The customer sales events in Vegas were fun.
Strategic customers account base were fun to work with.
Cons:
I started with about 10 folks on my team. All of them were ROCKSTARS. After about 3 years, many were let go.
In my experience, many promotions were achieved by who you now and not based on performance. 
Very few Indians and many chiefs.
Substantial firings for many talented folks came out of the blue. Lack of transparency and weak communication from management around these initiatives.
Frequent customer turnover for account teams which was not well received by strategic customers.
Was mandated to perform the job duties of two roles AE/TSE after being a TSE for two years which was not sustainable or fair. 
Frequent manager turnover and you are rolling the dice if your next manager is going to be effective and care about you.
I experienced technical support teams being greatly understaffed to the point of being scary.

Pros:
-IBM leaders demonstrate integrity, fairness, appreciation, and enthusiasm
-You are appreciated for your ability to grow the company through learning
-Although IBM is "extreme" technical; your skills in learning, development, and facilitation are equally valued
-Project oriented work - you are a trusted professional - not 9-5; loads of work/life flexibility 
-Endless opportunities to be creative - develop new learning programs and see them through to delivery
-Lots of cool tools, very organized, clear communications
-Fun people to work with, fast paced
Cons:
-Always a possibility of layoffs
-IBM has a reputation of being slow and old
-You do all your own administrative work - no support 
-IBM is a big place, it's easy to get overwhelmed and you won't ever understand how the entire company works
-Managers are under a lot of pressure and have lots of red tape - sometimes their hands are tied in making decisions

Pros: IBM is a recognized name that will help you get your next job. In some parts of the company, IBM may be an industry leader (this assertion is not true for the consulting business).
Cons: IBM is a massive company. You will not be singled out for much praise for great work. If you consistently get above average ratings, you won't get big raises (expect about 1.5%, so less than normal inflation, even raises for promotions are small), you won't have any opportunity to improve your skill set (since you will be in the same role for a few years...it's IBM's way of doing things), and you won't have the opportunity to move within the company (not unique to IBM). Overall, IBM is a place where you are expected to sit back and slowly climb the corporate ladder. Follow instructions and you can make it up at a slow pace. If you have any ambition, go somewhere else.

Pros: IBM is a stable company to work for.  It's not going anywhere, and it's not going to get bought out.  You can even transfer between different product teams, although a lot will depend upon the state of business and how good your manager is.  IBM tries to solve big problems and you'll encounter a lot of smart people trying to solve complex problems.  It's a good company to work for so you can learn from other employees, and usually they're more than willing to help.
Cons: I felt valued as an employee by my manager and my peers.  However, at the corporate level, I felt very unappreciated as an employee, e.g. getting rid of the water cooler to save money.  IBM's current strategy is acquiring companies and thereby customers to grow.  Organic growth is not happening.  Now, the focus is about saving money.

Pros: Retirement and health/dental benefits are great. Growth opportunities are available if you are willing to work for it.
Cons:
Work life balance at IBM: Work until you have no life. Many IBMers are required to work 44 hours per week in order to increase employee utilization, which is basically a fancy way of stealing vacation and holiday time from employees by requiring them to make up their off time throughout the entire year.

Annual reviews (called PBC's) are a joke. The only way to obtain the best rating is if you sacrifice a large portion of your free time (above the 44 hours/week) in order to pursue education and "giveback" opportunities. This is unobtainable if you desire to be a family oriented individual and are committed to volunteer activities that do not benefit IBM. If you do excellent work and go above and beyond expectations between 8-5, that will not be enough.

Pros:
The people at IBM are incredible: talented, brilliant, innovative, and constantly working to do the right thing.  I love working with such motivated and friendly people.

Of course, there are always more things to do, so there is always a chance to branch out at least a little bit to try something new and open up some new skillsets for yourself.

Telecommuting (as an engineer) is very common, especially given the automation and IT infrastructure of the fab.  It's not unusual to work from home if you need to.
Cons: The microelectronics division seems to be often overlooked by the larger company, though it clearly is a key part of the overall picture, especially for the server brand.  That impression leads to a common concern about how much the company cares to invest and pay attention to this relatively small but amazing team of co-workers in the microelectronics arena.

Pros: Prior decade(s) there were great Engineers & Developers with whom to work.  The 8% 401k match & funds within were top notch vs other tech companies.  Innovators were rewarded in the Patent program.  There was talk that better bonuses would happen as the business met it's overall EPS roadmap.
Cons:
Business model no longer seems to support experienced talent.  When your "Total Compensation Package" nears $130-$150k USD management appears to view those with advanced skills in software & Engineering as a place to cost cut (AKA layoff).  IBM lobbies Congress for more H1-B workers because they "cannot find skilled workers" that they know already had worked for them, yet fail to rehire after layoffs.
Also reportedly the Pro's mentioned above don't exist anymore.  Business nearly always found an excuse to not pay bonuses & raises on par with other tech companies.

Pros: Believes in work-life balance, offers great medical benefits, 401k, vacation, personal time.  Sensitive to personal issues. Room for advancement, may opportunities within the company in different areas/divisions, Great people to work with and extremely intelligent. Can work from home depending on job.
Cons: Salary is not great.  Hours can be very long at EndofMonth and EndofYear. Training - might have to depend on own initiative and research since everyone is always busy, but everyone is very knowledgeable. It seems  there are 'Resource Actions' every year, therefore, always wondering if you will be affected. Have seen employees train new folks, only to be let go or have seen many jobs relocated overseas, etc.

Pros: The benefits are ok. It is difficult to evaluate benefits against other similar companies.  If you only need medical/dental coverage for yourself it is inexpensive, but add a spouse and the cost skyrockets
Cons: Salaries are low, each employee gets a serial number and is treated like a piece of equipment.  There is no leadership in middle management.  Just a brand who tries to dictate and convince its clients that the IBM way is the best and only way.  Proprietary hardware has been a downfall since the early 90s.  There are a few good products such as Watson, but innovation elsewhere is lacking.  There is a lot of bureaucratic mess to being an employee, and salaried folks are expected to put in 44 hour weeks in most instances.  Business development does not last long because of inflated prices, or poor contract performance.  Employees are expected to recruit college students for helpdesks and menial duties.  To them it sounds great, but to someone with 30 years in the industry it is easy to see and impossible to correct the problems within the business. Yes it is a matrix organization, but though there are many meetings everyone is totally disconnected.  Someone is asleep at the switch, and unless vast organizational culture change occurs, expect the eventual downfall.

Pros: Salary was fair.  Benefits good.  Many of the accounts are diverse and interesting.  Interesting/bright people for the most part.  Love the diversity and the corporate support for it.
Cons: Far too many poor (biased, disengaged) managers on the 1st line and 2nd line levels.  Salaried positions have expectations that PMs will work/donate a lot of hours.  'Continuous improvement' in name only...it is not implemented within PM pool.  Huge disconnect between Dubuque team/management and corporate management.  Most PMs do not expect or want to be with IBM long term due to the lack of opportunity, pay increases & opportunity available...seemingly all PMs are job searching.  If training opportunities have any costs, PMs cannot register or participate in them...free/no cost training only.  Open door/grievance process is broken.  CEO received a multi-million dollar bonus just days after 1000s of employees received layoff notices...it's all about the stockholder & employees are dispensable.

Pros: They pay well and have pretty good benefits. They often don't ask a lot in return. They have very effective sales teams for selling to traditional IBM customers. When I was sick my managers first concern was always my getting well first.
Cons:
Employees are "resources" and the company has a policy of moving most work offshore. The most important consideration for any new project is "How can we staff it with "resources" from China, India, Brazil, etc. Whether they have existing staff that can do it or not is irrelevant. Having the project succeed is secondary at best.

If a job doesn't require shaking the customer's hand, or US citizenship, expect them to move it offshore as soon as they can.

Company is wildly disorganized at high levels. Their historical 3 businesses are hardware software and services. Hardware and software are basically doomed by cloud computing, and they aren't prominent in cloud computing services.

Internal politics dominate basically everything else. Each round of cuts tends to increase the percentage of "political operatives" in the company - since people who are political manipulators rarely get laid off.

Pros:
* Good work/life balance
* Good at keeping pace with market value for position
* Great benefits package(401K matches, health care is great)
* Good upper management
Cons:
*Typical of all companies with a consulting division, you must keep or exceed a certain number of ours as "billable" to a client to maintain a good standing in the company.  Which can be hard if you are between projects or they are "holding" you for another project.

*You get plenty of vacation, but you better not use it all or your "billable" hours will be affected which could leave you with a bad yearly rating.  Remember above statement, that you must maintain a certain amount of billable hours per year.  Which can be very high, 90 to 98 percent of the year you must be billable.  If you do the math, taking a week or two week vacation coupled with holidays will hurt that rating.

*Can be hard to get new experience or projects if you are at one project too long

Pros:
Decent pay
Group I was in had flexible hours
Good management/supervision, but it is very dependent on who your supervisor is

Honestly as part time this was great, it can be good to get some experience in your area. However, I don't see it as being the fulfilling longstanding career that used to be attached with the IBM name.
Cons:
Big place means a lot of bureaucracy
Suggestions often not implemented
Little upward mobility right now

Everyone is pretty stuck in their ways. The processes put in place can be super frustrating, and there are so many different groups that must work together to push a product out, yet nobody knows more than just what their group does. This makes communication difficult at times, slowing pushing out a product, which leads to everyone higher in the development chain putting unnecessary pressure on those lower in the chain.

Pros:
Diversity - The company is extremely supported of its diverse workforce and has good benefits for all types of employees and their families.

Remote Work - The ability to work remotely and/or from any IBM office worldwide.

Insane amounts of peer resources around the world available to assist you in almost anything you can think of.  

Decent College Tuition program reimbursement.
Cons:
Stuck in the past with Technology - especially for a Tech company.  Lotus Notes?  Really?

Compensation increases, travel budgets, expense policies are all less than to be desired.  This may not be abnormal for a company this size, but having been part of an acquisition, it isn't what I signed up for.

Pros: use to be a stable company
Cons: old school, slow to adopt and keep making wrong bet

Pros: Amazing past legacy, great diversity and some bright people that try their hardest every day. A lot of career oppurtunities if you are self starter and motivated. Provides great working experience with some big name clients.
Cons:
Graduate entry consultant program (CBD) is horribly mismanged. Consulting practice is focused on good at selling and bad at delivering. You are very likely to be assigned a manager you will never ever get to meet, who probably doesn't care about you or one that is being forced to act as a manager now that he is at a higher band level. They have annual layoff cycles and you may end up getting caught in them even with good performance. Company is way to big for it's own good and somehow the CEO still incharge after six years of revenue decline. 

In closing, I honestly don't know if it was the right move to join IBM out of college. Sure the pay was great and so was the experience while it lasted but the badly mismanged entry level training program and overall disorganization definitely threw a wrench in my career plans.

Pros: Pay, world wide reach, innovation
Cons: IBM thinks its reputation carries it forward but it holds them back just as much if not more.  Large, cold & heartless, an employee can get promoted and then released the next quarter. Bean counters make those decisions so one is only as valuable as their performance in the last quarter.

Pros: As a second career professional, I have found that working at IBM has truly fulfilled my desire and goal to find the meaningful capstone of my professional journey. IBM is a company that encourages and fosters the growth and innovation of all in a very inclusive environment. From the support of management, to the highly collaborative and innovative culture, to the expansive array of learning paths, certification tracks, and learning resources, IBM provides the means for all to not only succeed in their current position, but to fully prepare themselves for success at the next level, and in reaching their full potential. I have found the work to be extraordinarily meaningful and fulfilling, such that I'm happy to go to work everyday, and proud to be an IBMer!
Cons: IBM is such a large global company that getting oriented can seem rather daunting and overwhelming. But with support of the management team and peers, and with some individual effort to network and learn, that downside is effectively eliminated.

Pros: is too flexible that have open space for accepting that some people takes advantage of it and simply does not work
Cons:
- leaders and managers only work for upper leaders
- managers are not prepared and majority not even presence
- half of the teams are specialized in their roles, half are not - so only its a mess. It causes many unnecessary discussions and the team environment is usually heavy 
- It is very hard to do the right and correct thing
- people are only nominated by colleagues and friends
- Many managers are charlatan and dot not share the real specialists credits
- Diversity and inclusion is fake fake fake - I've had my work and ideas presented by white male as his many times when me - Latin women and a female Chinese co-worker made it al from scratch. 
- very common to get my manager calling me as his words " so he could take notes on what he would present on the next day" and he would sound specialist
- also many co workers are just not meant for their role

Pros:
Good Benefits.
Good first line managers.
Cons:
Products are rushed out the door before being ready.
As a technician I have to deal with unhappy customers every day because the products are sold before being ready.

Pros:
- Great benefits package
- IBM name is good for the resume
Cons:
- no type of overtime compensation (money, time off, etc.)
- documentation need to "petition" for a promotion is ridiculously tedious and time consuming.  Stellar job performance is not enough.  You must dedicate your life to IBM.
- you're expected to live, breathe, eat and sleep IBM.  There is absolutely NO work/life balance.  70 hour work weeks are the norm
- your success depends solely on politics and whose behind your willing to kiss the most.
- pay is below market, raises trickle down VERY slowly, if at all.  Get as much up front as possible if you decide to join IBM.  Don't let the "IBMer" commercials fool you.
- The ability to work across practice areas or industries (public sector vs. commercial, hcm, fm, scm, ais, etc.) is an outright LIE.  If you don't mind being pigeonholed...IBM's the place to be.

Pros:
Good benefits package (4 weeks of vacation to start, basic health care and dental for employee paid, 5% full match on 401K after 1 year)
Reasonably laid back work environment
IBM looks good on my resume
Cons:
Communication to me from my manager is really lacking.
I came to the company with 4 years of IT experience and was made to take an entry level job with a salary in the low 30s. Several other people with less experience that have come in after me are making more than I am to start.
The management on our team is so disconnected there are 3-4 people that literally do almost nothing all day, every day while several of us run like crazy to get things done.
IBM is not in a "promotion or raise mode" at the moment so I'm doing work that is in a higher band but not being paid for it. This has gone on in this position for many months.

Pros: broad resources to leverage for any assignment , reasonable pay, benefits historically excellent
Cons: benefits slowly going down the drain, constant US resource actions leading to extremely overworked people left (now you have to be billable at least 125-145% of the time just to be considered "average") extremely unfair rewards system (advertise that they "reward performance" but reality is, rewards are extremely limited so most who "perform" are definitely NOT rewarded due to the inadequate forced curve.  Innovation is possible at IBM, but definitely an uphill battle.  Most business units are purely interested in staffing their opps and nothing more--you will have to fight LONG and HARD to get anything new seriously considered--but, it IS possible at least.

Pros: Vacation time and decent benefits.   There are a lot of good resources on the intranet pages if you learn how to find them.
Cons:
No raises-- they place people in a band lower than their current salary and responsibility to make them abouve the midpoint..  and give raises to 20% of the staff at best.

I came to GBS from a deal with a major company.  Their goal was to eliminate staff and send the position to India.   The daily group discussion concerned the regularly occurring RAs (layoffs).  I ended up being the last person in a group of more than 10-- they shifted more and more work with no compensation in pay.   Not only that, it was odd having treating former co-workers as "customers".  I ended up leaving because of the amount and type of work -- I'm a software developer and didn't want to spend my time filling out forms about function points and training developers in India how to do their job-- that didn't work, anyway, because the staff in India switched to new positions and groups on a regular basis.

Pros: Benefits are great.  Colleagues are nice.  Work from home opportunity.
Cons: Expected to work too many hours (60+ regularly).  Too few resources, too many hours, no raises, expected to do your own job plus+, clients are always unhappy due to IBM processes and too few resources to keep projects on track.  Frequent layoffs (2-3 year) even while still hiring.  Management structure terrible - always have two managers with conflicting priorities.

Pros:
At one time it was a good place to work. 
They paid me.
Cons:
It became a terrible place to work and from what I understand not much has changed.

Had a backstabbing manager who screwed me over after detailing a family situation I was going through.
This company is concerned about one thing - the stock price and will do whatever it takes to inflate it.
Management did nothing but pay lip service and say that you had to understand the business.
Resource actions there should be illegal, but they operate just under the radar of the laws so that they don't get caught.
Was part of a resource action and 6 months later was contacted by a contracting company about my position under the manager who targeted me in the RA.  Only good outcome to that was that his bean counting butt was shown the door.

IBM has sold it's PC, Retail and now Server groups...what's left?

Pros: the training for sales is the best in the business.  Strong team and IBM provided adequate time to take the training.  Sales compensation was average at best
Cons:
lack of support - everything is "on your own" to figure out.  You get 5 page emails to set up your phone and no support if it doesn't work.  Hopefully you have a friend that can help you out
Antiquated systems - the forecasting solution is a joke.  It's still Excel based, way too complicated, and you spend a great deal of time trying to figure out why numbers don't match
no teamwork - there is no sense of team. none. 
most of the team is made up of "B" and "C" players just trying to "get by" and find a role where they can "hide" for a year or two

Pros: Pockets of interesting work going on.  Untapped potential to deliver value.
Cons:
Ridiculously large (over 400,000 employees);  Bureaucracy that rivals the US federal government for "red tape" and inefficiency.  Always looking for ways not to pay sales people.  Majority of middle managers are extremely incompetent, lacking integrity, courage, and intelligence.

Pay scale is based on where you live so that means you will definitely be underpaid if you live in a lower cost of living area and your duties are broader than that geography.  I guess it is a "pro" if you life in a higher cost area.  Just an example of very old style management thinking.

Pros: (few) Professional and talented coworkers
Cons: Incompetent and Toxic Management, backstabbing  coworkers, employees are afraid to speak up, tyrannical leaders, obsolete and incompetent old managers (30-40+ year with IBM) that act as IBM henchmen. No career opportunities. If you ask for a transfer in another technology or organization (even in the same location) your performance review will be sabotage  to be "layoff" aka  Resource Action (RA) in the next round. No job security. You feel like a temp employee surviving every day until you are RAed or get a a job offer from another company  TO NEWLY  COLLEGE GRADUATE STAY AWAY FROM IBM.
