Pros: Telecommuting is widely accepted, in fact, most of us don't even have an office that we belong to.   The benefits are good, 401K with company match, stock purchase plan.
Cons: Too many to list.  Executives build fiefdoms, strong cliques.  Individual contributors are promoted to management because it's a missing skill but they aren't good managers (in fact, some are abysmal) and your performance suffers for it.  Be prepared to be RA'd (resource action aka laid off) every February.  Worst review system ever, stack ranking and a certain percent have to be cut regardless of contribution.

Pros: A once great company, with some still very sharp people to work with (but they won't last long). Looks good on a resume, stay a couple year then move along like everyone else.
Cons:
Run away. A rapidly sinking ship. 

Due to constant, rolling cost cutting, management has hollowed out the entire experience and knowledge base (personnel) of the company by constant layoffs (RA's in the company vernacular). Virtually all of the experienced employees have been laid off, all positions have been outsourced to the cheapest, least experienced parts of the globe.

Entire internal company systems (knowledge based, IT, etc.) no longer function as those who created them have been let go. 

The company's execs have only one goal--short term profit and expense cuts that will line their pockets. There is no concern with the consequences that these executive decisions will have next year, much less in five years.

This has all created a company death spiral (lower revenue in Q1, more job & budget cuts in Q2, and so on).
 
Morale at the company is something like that of an ancient Roman slave galley.

Salaries are consistently under-market averages

Pros: With IBM for 25 years.....   I've seen IBM's leadership  transform to understand and advocate for LGBT rights in all countries.  There are countries and states, which do not have laws about rights for our community, and IBM has negotiated and educated some to understand the value our GLBT diversity brings to the market and spending power.  Last time I checked we had 42 Out Executives in IBM world wide, imagine that!
Cons: No matter where you are there are still people afraid and confused about our journey in life.

Pros:
IBM's Summit Program is a world-class sales training program, where you have the opportunity to go through sales school, where you learn the best sales methodology and use them in practice for 6 months before going into the field. Sales school is supplemented by communication workshops (including stand-and-deliver and group presentations), as well as classroom learning on IBM's hardware, software and services offerings. It is a very comprehensive sales and leadership training. The Summit Program prepared me for my current sales role and beyond, into any leadership role I want to pursue in the future.

Not to mention my first year has been a lot of fun, with excellent compensation and work-life balance. It is a culture of giving, networking, support, mentorship, and positivity. I have made some of my best friends working for IBM.
Cons: Heavy travel schedule in sales (this is a pro for me, but may be a con for others)

Pros:
- work/life balanc
- leadership has innovative, unique vision
- corporate discounts
- decently nice office spaces
- good brand to have on resume
- "badges"/internal education
- easy to be comfortable and remain in position
Cons:
- bureaucratic
- corporate vision not being executed on local level - US full of toxic teams + outsourcing whenever possible to cheaper countries
- complicated organization structure and processes are counterproductive to innovation and operational efficiency
- instead of fixing, another team to address the issue will be added, creating more confusion and cooks in the kitchen
- many toxic teams that are difficult to improve due to their tenure at the company - very common for employees to stay 20+ years
- age tends to be either very young or very old, not much in the middle
- limited to no yearly bonus structure
- always be prepared for restructuring/RAs/firing
- poor morale/culture - people stay because it's easier than leaving
- low pay - also, big differences in salary for the same role
- not much room for upward growth

Pros: -Remote work during covid pandemic
Cons:
-low pay
-high turnover rate
-trained data analyst, but title remains data engineer
-can't take concerns to management, they will assume quitting is your only option
-12 hr days depending on your project
-frequent project hopping
-projects not always geared towards your skills or career
-in office management staff separate themselves from employees
-micro management from certain managers
-raises are low and keep you under average pay until you've reached 4 years
-CICs are located in economically distressed areas for tax breaks. This means although you have a greater number of minorities working, a large chunk of minorities within the greater company are making less than the US average for their job role.

Pros: The great thing available here is the depth of opportunities to learn - in person and educationally. There are still people here who can teach you something, because they have experienced it. And they haven't been put out. They still work here! Secondly the pay is higher than you think because IBM wants to recruit and retain the best. And thirdly, they are working to be more inclusive - which is probably the secret sauce of their continued (since 1911) success.
Cons:
Some people (older and some young ones too) want to go back to the past which in their eyes is the good ole days...resist that
Some of the pay for long-timers may not have kept up with the newer salaries.
The health insurance could be better.

Pros: IBM is a company that is very focused on the contribution of the individual to a team goal.  The company has woven in work life integration into its culture and provides an environment where the most intelligent people can comfortably perform and are routinely recognized.  There several career paths for one to pursue and opportunities for growth.  IBM is one of the great companies to work for in North America.
Cons: IBM does have many processes.  There are protocols in place that can be stifling and like with any large companies there can be obstacles both large and small and leaders both new and old who struggle to put the customer first.  Proactive career management is the responsibility of the individual for the most part and the company is currently experiencing some restructuring.

Pros:
Good work-life balance
Great co-workers
Decent salary (not the best, but not the worse either)
Great technical community
Good place to learn about new technologies
Cons:
too many levels of management (executives with no reporting strucutre?!?)
very hard to get any straight answers from upper management
if your on an technical incentive plan, you can kiss any incentive payment goodbye (IBM will make sure you barely make your base salary...)
employee motivation is down the drain.
Lots of very talented employees are fleeing the company because of the above-mentioned reasons.

Pros: Potential for very dynamic job assignments, always learning something new and exciting.  There is a great feeling of just being associated with IBM, but over time, that fades.  Management can often be really good, but its not always the case.  People generally are highly motivated both personally and corporately
Cons: Management - be careful of your leadership.  That can be your biggest hero or your worst enemy.  Due to political nature, if things don't go well on an assignment, management will find someone to blame - it could be you.  Beware of undocumented promises from management.  At IBM, if it isn't in writing, it was never said.  Oh, and by a huge measure, raises suck or are non-existent.  Lots of raises go through lengthy 'dry spells'

Pros: IBM institutes a philosophy for keeping its employees by offering them the opportunity to build career experience with the encouragement to move about the company.  Overall this works well although one needs to also cast a wide net which can take quite a long time.
Cons: My position pertained to selling the smarter commerce suite of applications which are well accepted in the market place.  If you are a seasoned sales person and truly do not like to cold call then you will fail.  IBM is NOT a marketing company and depends almost exclusively on each seller to build the field product buzz on their own.  You have 12 month to do that and make your numbers before your accounts are thrown back into the hat and you start almost from 0.

Pros:
Work life balance could not be better, but if you take advantage of that option you won't move ahead or get pay raises

Colleges are smart, supportive, hard working
Cons:
Expect nothing and you'll be happy.  Don't expect raises, bonuses, a meal with your team members.  

There is one thing to expect, anyway to save a dime they will.  For the last 10 years working from home IBM did not pay for any supplies (printers/toner/paper, pens....), internet (evennthough you may need higher bandwidth to run systems), peer awards (logo apparel) removed, stóp using tie lines and use phones join feature and for larger conference calls we were asked to stop calling in with the 800#.  All petty stuff which is the worst part.

In the NY area Career advancement is like swimming up the Hudson.   You'll be fighting jobs going to CoEs/offshored, sites closing, divestitures, moving into management dried up

Pros: State of the art in every respect. Be prepared to work. Be prepared to make IBM an extension of your family, because you will be expected to give it all you've got (and that can often mean work flowing into your time off - like weekends).
Cons: Sometimes long-term IBM employees can be a tad condescending. I guess that is an occupational hazard when you work for a large corporation, though. Keeping any negative thoughts you may have about individuals to yourself can help you in navigating "office politics." As  said: occupational hazard in a big corporation. IBM is no exception. But if you resolve to do a good job (and are good at "handling" people and their idiosyncrasies) IBM is a company with many paths for advancement.

Pros: It's a place where you can work hard and see the results of your work and be recognized for your efforts.  This year's recognition award was hosted in one of the finest hotels in Punta Cana and IBM made all of there feel extremely special.  I've never had as much support by colleagues willing to help me than at IBM. You are working among the brightest, most innovative people willing to assist you.  IBM is a company that has reinvented itself so many times to not only remain relevant but to maintain it's leadership position over well over 100 years.
Cons: Sometimes the large size of the organization can get in the way of itself.  All the help I've noted in the pros sometimes comes at a price where we have too many hands in things.

Pros: You will have good people to work with and a big brand name for your resume. The work load isn't too heavy.
Cons: Raises and bonuses are non existent and have been for years. If you perform well and you are not in sales or an executive, your bonus may be $800. Also, as of 2019 IBM eliminated out of network health coverage. None of the plans offer it though they still call the plans PPO plans, but read the fine print. You are 100% out of pocket for out of network coverage. But the costs go up every year while the coverage declines. IBM used to allow work from home but in an effort to streamline that option is gone, so you will pay to commute (not reimbursed) and work in an open plan office with picnic tables as desks and not even a coat closet in some locations. Worse case you end up at a WeWork.

Pros:
Benefits and compensation (3 weeks vacation, good healthcare plans, family leave etc)
 Parental leave for men and women is awesome (short term disability plus 12 weeks parental leave for a total of 18 weeks paid for women and 12 weeks paid for men)
Great colleagues
Lots of training opportunities (especially online coursework)
Huge portfolio of technology to learn about
Strong brand recognition  
Awesome place to work for women - there are a lot of female leaders!
Increased focus on improving employee engagement in public sector recently
Cons:
Long hours
High focus on utilization and minimum utilization is 44 billable hours per week (on top of that you have proposals, giveback etc) 
It can be hard to find interesting consulting assignments if you are not technical
It’s a huge company, so it takes a long time to navigate 
Highly independent culture (IBM - “I’m By Myself”), little support from management in onboarding process or in general to find career opportunities/projects
Bonuses are very small

Pros:
IBM is a historic company and trying to turn a new leaf with a younger workforce and recent acquisitions/divestitures. The overwhelming majority of managers use the "as long as you get your work done, we don't care how you spend your time" guiding principle. This flexibility has been a lifesaver during the pandemic, where working from home has been anything but a walk in the park.
The compensation appears to be above market and I feel appreciated for my work. The benefits package is a bit underwhelming but made up for in base salary.
Cons:
A company this large can be hard to navigate. We live and work entirely in TLA's (three letter acronyms) and knowing them all is a point of pride for some. Getting acclimated takes time and requires individual effort to break silos between teams who should be more communicative with each other.
IBM places a lot of responsibility on individual contributors to complete projects and often makes last-minute decisions that change the trajectory of our outcomes. If you're not married to your work, you'll be fine.

Pros:
* Smart, helpful, capable peers
* Finally creating momentum towards a more focused approach on Hybrid Cloud and AI (Machine Learning, mostly)
* Best chance of career growth for those in their early 20's to late 30's
Cons:
* Traditional command and control thinking from most senior execs, leaders, and managers.
* Brands (owners of various product lines) own the budgets and set the focus too much on "what's in it for IBM" instead of "what's in it for the client".
* 'Agile' is still a buzzword and not applied in consistent or meaningful ways the vast majority of the time. Agile is more than a framework (Scrum, in particular).
* Too much downsizing without seeming regard for the performance of the individuals; large, sweeping Resource Allocations (RAs) = seemingly getting rid of swaths of employees without trying to identify the performance of individuals affected so that we don't lose our best talent.

Pros: Strong opportunities for learning. Colleagues with tons of experience in the field which is a tremendous resource. Camaraderie and office culture not bad and hybrid schedule is plus!
Cons:
Recruiter unaware of compensation plan....or plan was changed from what was on the offer letter. Additionally, any "overpayment" was scheduled for collection. Not cool since it was done over a shorter period and amounts to hundreds of dollars...

Why? because 18% of your actual salary is given to a pool where those who excel will cash out from the pool and those who don't will take that reduction in pay for two halves until they are shown the door. Not accepting this plan will prevent you from any movement at IBM.

On the tools side....the sales side could benefit from better tools but I'll leave that alone. Also cross-collaboration is difficult and streams are muddy when prospecting is a metric measured weekly.

Pros: Brand name, experience working for a large corporation, and resume builder.  IBM sales is highly regarded but in order to make more money you'll need to leave IBM.  The sales plans are not generous, and re-organizations and layoffs are envogue.
Cons: raise freezes, low compensation, no career path, extremely matrixed, and constantly changing management.  The IBM matrix requires you to have far too many sales cadences.  You'll spend most of your time reporting to layers management and mending internal IBM issues than selling.  Even so, working together as one IBM is a constant challenge as self interest among the brands, and pillars makes the selling process much more complex.  For such a large corporation, there is far too much finger pointing and not enough internal coordination/cooperation, which wastes far too much time.

Pros: IBM pays its top performers at (almost) industry average.
Cons:
- IBM does not invest in its employees.  For example, lip service is paid to continuing education, but there is no support from lower and middle management for keeping your skills current.

- IBM does not want employees to work for the company for more than 5-7 years.  IBM is focused on having the lowest paid workforce (in all countries) in lieu of product and technical expertise.

- There is a complete failure in leadership at the upper management and executive levels.  Rather than gain market share through R&D and product excellence, profit growth now comes from buying companies and layoffs.  This year (2009) is an excellent example;  since sales were flat,  >10000 employees were outsourced and stock buybacks were used to increase the EPS.

Pros:
As you move up in band, you get some cooler projects, bu that will take 4+ years to start getting the more interesting jobs. 

With that said, working from home is a great option, you can work pretty much anywhere in the world. They give you a fair amount of vacation days. My health insurance is essentially free.
Cons:
Unfortunately the company is shifting into less profitable business that are driving market shift, and when your bonus pool (albeit small) is tied to profit growth, kinda makes it hard to get compensated well

You get 15 Vacation days a year and 5 personal choice holidays on top of the regular holidays to use whenever you want, unfortnately last year of my 20 days, I used 4.

Pros:
Large, well-recognized company.
Vast breadth of experience and opportunity.
Work from Home
Work-Life Balance (not true for everyone).
Cons:
Executive focus on EPS at the expense of product development, employee satisfaction/retention, and customer satisfaction.
Executive compensation based on EPS drives this.
Banding system & "80% of market salary" guidance artificially suppress earnings.
401(k) contribution only once per year.
PBC reviews use outdated "Stack ranking" system requiring underrating of some employees despite performance.
"Resource Action" culture and lack of transparency has most employees running scared.
IBM Core Values are frequently violated from the top down, and have become a joke.

Pros: IBM is, without a doubt a great company and a good employer. The company is huge, it's decision-making slow super slow and the business is run by the spreadsheet masters. Nonetheless, job opportunities are there for the right people who don't mind mind-numbing bureaucracy.
Cons: For people with Silicon Valley DNA - for people who are accustomed to getting things done - its not a good fit. Decsions are made in a vacuum at HQ in New York. They don't get agile, they aspire to be cloud, but severely lack the DNA and relevant infrastructure to make it happen. IBM's CRM system is a custom version of Siebel. What can I say.

Pros: Great people in S&D and excellent MGT...  GBS could use some classes in how to treat employees with respect and not verbal abuse - Just a few bad apples and it rolls down from there.  But other manager are great and will help you all they can!!  Some of the smartest people in the world!
Cons: You work in your job description and that is about it.. NOT too much room to branch out BUT lots of mobility across the silos after your 2 year commitment. Be sure you manage your our career as it is up to you to get ahead...  Negotiate pay on the way in as in sales... that is where your base stays....  ONE you leave  - you will be labeled "IBM" and the employer will assume you cannot sell without the entire BUS..  so other jobs are difficult to get...  but you will get lots of interviews since IBM has good reputation..

Pros: Excellent salary for a first job out of college, great benefits for a young single person, 3 weeks PTO to start. I am lucky in that most of my team is on site and so I have many people with ample experience to help me. Some really interesting stuff is happening -- if you can get on the right team. Depending on the manager, generally able to work from home frequently and flexible hours. Seems to be lots of opportunity to move around in the company.
Cons: Culture is seriously lacking and morale is generally mediocre. The population skews older, with young people struggling to meet each other. Location is outside of Boston, so for those relocating getting started on a social life is hard. Tons of "blue tape" to get anything done. Rating system that determines bonuses seems broken and criteria seems to vary from manager to manager. A definite sense of being resigned, or even cynicism, from a lot of employees, makes you question where things are going and if you should stick around.

Pros: Worked at IBM for over 30 years.  It used to be a wonderful place to work, with talented people and best of breed hardware/software.  It no longer is that company and the best that can be said of it is flexible work from home and somewhat flexible work hours.  Pay/benefits are average.
Cons: Company used to be run by engineers, but now is run by the finance department.  Minimal investment in it's people and R&D over the last 15 years and everything is now spent on stock buy backs.  Most of the experienced and talented people are now gone.  The existing set of customers are really paying the price with the current product set and services now offered.  It used to be that having IBM on your resume was a good thing...  I'm not so sure anymore, as it was harder and harder to get good college talent to come to IBM.

Pros: Diverse jobs, extensive amount of resources by brand, industry.  Excellent thought leadership.  Very strong commitment to advancing broad complex topics in the world.  Very smart, collaborative and talented people.  Working through transformation which is a challenge in the marketplace for all large mature companies.  The right investments are being made but need to be made faster
Cons: Executive top heavy.  Not as focused on treating their employees well any more.    Complex organization and capabilities is both a curse and blessing.

Pros: Flexible work schedule including work from home as needed/desired
Cons:
Management at all levels renege on their promises, from earned retirement pensions and medical benefits to earned comp-time.  For example, at 2nd line management direct request I put in over 400 hours of unpaid overtime over a 3 month period to help get a hot project out and when I went to use the banked time after project completion, per prior management agreement, management denied it and allowed me to have NOTHING.  

Working 60+ hours per week, my raises average 1.1% for the last 4 years.  Insufficient return on investment for this job.

Pros: I thoroughly enjoyed the SSR work!  IBM had such a fantastic reputation.  Having IBM on your resume still looks good.
Cons: I would not want to be an SSR at IBM today. High stress, low reward.  You are expected to actively participate in the sales and leads process, even as a non-customer facing SSR.  The pay raise, IF you can get one, does not keep up with the annual increase in the cost of benefits.  It is all about making the executives wealthier at an enormous cost to you and your family.

Pros: Decent benefits and pay.  Many opportunities to work from home if you prefer that situation.  Good training available to all employees.
Cons: IBM is going through a difficult transition in the IT industry.  Parts of IBM are growing revenue and parts of IBM are losing revenue.  In recent years, this has led to yearly 'resource actions' where large numbers of employees are laid off in the parts of IBM that are losing revenue.  My experience is that IBMers struggle with work-life balance.  If you are in the part of IBM that is growing the team is always understaffed so everyone is working OT just to keep up.  If you are in the part of IBM that is losing revenue, headcount is cut so deep the few remaining headcount are doing the work of multiple people or constantly training off shore resources that seem to turn over quickly.

Pros:
Pros are that:
* IBM is really big and worldwide, with people doing almost ever imaginable job in IT
* IBM is generally on the cutting edge of technology, and must stay that way to survive
* IBM has a ton of educational opportunities to help it's people move into new areas, and
* IBM pays pretty well
Cons:
Cons are that:
* Overtime, including weekends, is often expected and sometimes demanded, and that does not leave much time to live
* Travel to a job site, sometimes takes over 10 hours by plane, and can occur like that every week, which cuts into the time to live some more
* There are so many offshore personnel, and H1 visas, that work for less, that that is somewhat limiting in terms of competition and opportunities, but this is the way of the world now

Pros:
- vast amount of resources available online or reach out to other global teams, if you have the time you can learn anything you want as there are many online courses available
-- IBMers acts in a very professional manner to help out each other
-- there are still many career opportunities available, you need to know where and what to look for as well as how to create these opportunities for yourself 
-- IBM is truthfully out there making the world a better place with Watson, the mission is no different than when I joined 10 years ago helping the world to solve problems.  
-- I had the opportunity to be on a Corporate Service Corps program that has enriched myself both personally and professional.   But most important of all, I was there to help to make the world a better place by providing our expertise to emerging markets which helped profit & non-profit organization as well.
Cons: -- IBM is a big company that can be difficult in navigating through process, but there is always someone that you can ask.

Pros:
- Great colleagues that I will miss... some really smart and helpful people
- Work from home flexibility
- Not micromanaged
- Frontline managers do care, for the most part
- Decent pay and vacation allowance
Cons:
- So many mid and upper level managers who do nothing but push spreadsheets and devise plans to screw the worker bees
- Constant reorgs that adversely affect the lower ranks
-Screw you out of benefits: 401 match only if employed on Dec 15th, so of course they layoff thousands right before that; Severance pay reduced to a single month no matter how many years you've put in
-Screw you out of a job for no reason with constant 'resource actions'
-Ginny will BS the media on how they are adding jobs but reality is the opposite as they layoff folks in their 50's for no reason and maybe replace with kids or foreigners in other countries

Pros: Access to the most incredible minds.  Resources that are built in to the giant machine.  Being a part of something great.  Flexibility in finding lateral move jobs.
Cons: You can get lost in the sauce.  Employee upward growth potential is limited once you get 'up there' at least in marketing.  They've been hiring a lot of external agency experienced resources but they don't know anything about how to be and embrace being an IBMer.  The 'new' blood is taking the life out of the passionate IBMers who would give their left leg for the success of the company.  Instead marketers are being shelved or over looked.   Raises are infinitesimal.

Pros: Collaborative tools are a plus. Everybody knows who I work for and I don't have to explain my who my employer is past three letters, IBM. Vacation days are nice, Sick time policy nice, Healthy lifestyle perks such as steps challenges, logging workouts and monetary rewards for keeping an active lifestyle are nice. HSA plan so far has been a positive.
Cons: Salary increases are the most minimal, seems they can barely keep up with inflation. Bonuses for anyone in IT seem to be non -existent, banding and layering has diminished my direct reports so now I'm no longer a manager thanks to changes that occurred after acquisition. Travel and hiring bans have been in effect ever since our acquisition took place, nobody knows what the future holds for our team.

Pros: Knowing that it is a great company and there are some pockets of greatness and talented people and the chance that you might get into those pockets.  There is a transition that they are trying to make happen at the company level  and you might catch one of those waves if you are lucky.
Cons: For a supposedly technology and engineering company, it is very much a project management / sales focused company.  For every person that does the actual work that goes into the delivered service / product, there are layers and layers of people who are managing, representing, saying things they have no clue about and making decisions. You might be working just to make up for the mediocrity around you and not benefiting yourself.

Pros:
Decent benefits.
My co-workers are great hard working people that do what they are asked and more.
Cons: The current management regime from the Board, CEO, and top 200 executives are too focused on getting rid of pretty much anyone over 50.  They keep saying the following over and over again, " We must focus on Millennials and getting new blood into the organization." ....translation, get rid of anyone older than 50.  They are losing way too many highly skilled employees in the name of new skills.  The very people that they are getting rid of possess those deep technical and highly sought after skills they say that they need to hire from the outside...pure B.S.

Pros:
CbD used to be a slightly better program, but there have been significant management issues that have made it go down the gutter. 
- Great work life balance
- Decent breadth of experience
- Good resources/training
- Much better diversity at the younger level than other huge companies or banks, etc.
Cons:
- They pay market rate, but then you cannot get a raise for 2 years (no exceptions). 
- No year end bonuses (I don't count $200 as a bonus)
- Not a rotational program
- No say over your staffing/career goals
- Somewhat diverse but not enough... tons of younger women but not many female executives because no women want to be high up there...
- Ivy league school grads get paid $75k or more to start. Other schools will get $70 or less. YOU CAN NEGOTIATE PAY AND LOCATION AND TYPE OF CONSULTANT. Do it!!

Pros: Got to work mostly from home for 10 years... til they tossed me aside for cheaper offshore replacements.
Cons:
As a consultant, you are required to work 106% or more of billable hours in a year, and you have to make up any vacation time that reduces that percentage.
They offer lots of training but a lot of it is garbage, and you are required to take a LOT of mandatory training that isn't even in your area of expertise.
Mgt offers help to get your job done but when push comes to shove they cannot really help at all and all they tell you is "well, we just need to get it done!"
Horrible raises!  Might get 1-2% in the "good" years, zero in others even when you get a good review.
When they terminated me they said they didn't have any more jobs for me yet when I look on their career website they have 15 open jobs... offshore...

Pros:
Work from Home
Travel if you 
Not much competition on the teams because IBM continuous layoffs
My team is very open to folks speaking candidate without *much* fear of reprisal. Good support from my leadership.
Cons:
Layoffs 2 to 3 times a a year removing some of their best producres
IBM guts a team with layoffs then "holds accountable" (blames) remaining employees for under performance -- VP's swoop in to save the day and spin real disasters as wins while changing nothing
Officers get huge bonuses, employees get pennies
Travel reimbursements ignore employees personal and real costs for leaving home to earn revenue for the company
though I make well into 6 figures, after unpaid overtime, my wage less than a Starbucks employee
Much less support among on the teams because IBM continuous layoffs

Pros: Adopting innovative methods in making learning experience better. Your Learning, Your Career really helps learn besides other tools specific to skill set. I can select a topic of interest and start my learning journey and track progress. These interactive sessions either help download content or transcripts and once you complete the test assessment process ensures that you understand the content. I really appreciate IBMs effort and not only this there are generic badges that allow entire world make use of the badge program and learn topics like IBM Cloud, Block Chain, AI etc.
Cons: I experienced some issues once I move from one org to another within IBM but technical team was very helpful to resolve issues. In some cases due to some issues one of my course tracking was not updating and team was very helpful and since we automated lot of this to adopt AI driven approach in learning experience that may be the issue.

Pros:
- you bond with coworkers over shared trauma
- if you are looking for a kick in the pants to go to therapy, look no further
Cons: where to begin. all management drink the kool aid that IBM is the best thing since sliced bread, when in fact the products don't work and the service to their customers is horrible. multiple managers had said very sexist and demeaning things to me, including that I am "going no where in life" and "just wake up every day with no plan." and these are the things I am allowed to write on the internet. I worked there for 1.5 years and every day it got worse than the last. There is no career development, VERY high turnover, and no respect from upper management. PLUS if you thinking of taking this job just for the name on your resume - stop right there. IBM has little to no credibility in the market anymore - when I was looking for a new job on several occasions I told the interviewer I worked at IBM and they said "I'm sorry." Conversely, employees who got laid off were regularly congratulated by peers. Run don't walk away from this company and find a place that actually respects you!

Pros: IBM was a great place to work because of all the information sharing and availability of all employees through out the company. I was amazed to find out that almost 40% of IBM's software developers work remotely. This being said IBM makes all employees available to everyone for questioning. Don't know Perl? There is an IBM community dedicated to learning Perl where professionals share their opinions. This also follows for many other technologies.
Cons: Since I was just a co-op the project was a "nice to have" feature on a main product line. While the work was challenging, engaging, and fun, I couldn't help but feel that this might not make it into a release. And if it was to be released it wasn't going to be for a long while and they'll probably just have to re-write it since a lot of the product will have changed since then.

Pros: Opportunity to work with highly professional people from diverse technical and cultural backgrounds. Opportunity to pursue many different job roles. Work with cutting edge technologies. Managers tend to actually grok people management and are generally rational folks.
Cons: Gradually but inexorably moving towards a services-based "consulting sweatshop." Uncertain future for US based software development. Constant cost-cutting (staff reductions, corner cutting) in prod dev areas, leading to lower quality products. Most innovation is now through acquisitions, as cost-cutting (along with the political turf wars that ensue as middle mgmnt squabble over a a piece of an ever-shrinking budget) and process (i.e. corporate instructions, or the private sector version of "unfunded mandates") make organic innovation extremely difficult.

Pros: I have worked both in headquarters and brands (GTS/SWG/IGF/STG). Brands are a sweatshop and very few people make it in there. Mine was a horrific experience. In my experience, the ONLY good thing about a career in finance at IBM is that you can expect your paycheck to be deposited into the checking account like clock work.
Cons: If you are an undergrad and looking to join IBM I guess it's OK; however, be prepared to get underpaid and overworked. It requires a certain type of personality to do finance jobs at this company, which are boring and mundane. Moreover, I have heard them describe some people at IBM as leaders and I am having a really hard time believing that's what a real visionary should be. At best, you learn how to deal with IBM's definition of an executive. Many are dumb but lucky, others are gestapo style because they don't know any better. Very few executives are pleasant to work for.

Pros:
IBM hires great people - positive, hard-working and bright so the people, and teams are great
IBM supports and even promotes tele-commuting or working from home which allows for work/life balance
IBM offers lots of training and education and a chance to move to many areas of the business
IBM hires good management who have good people-management skills
IBM trusts its employees and has good policies in place between management and staff
IBM values are excellent
Cons: The company has changed over the years.  It used to reward its employees with trips, motivational awards, company outings etc. This has all but stopped completely.   Quotas were challenging but attainable, allowing one to earn a really good income. That has all but stopped and the environment as of late has been driving employees to meet unrealistic quotas.  Lots of pressure on employees.  Junior employees are micro-managed with all actions tracked.  Top-performing senior sales people are not adequately paid.  Job satisfaction has dropped among my colleagues.  The famous IBM culture is not the same as before, sadly.

Pros:
Good name recognition
Good benefits and learning opportunities
Great people to work with
Cons:
They are laying off people to help their stock price.  I heard employee count will go from 100,000 to 30,000 over the next two years.  Customers suffer because of lack of employee resources and services on their contract is bad.
I got laid off by a manager.  That manager was incompetent and laid off employees to cover that manager's weakness.  That manager is still there.  Managers can have affairs with their employees.  It will be known by upper management, and those managers still work there.  That is unexcusable.  It seems if you are a manager, you are untouchable.
I still have a lot of friends who work there and don't like it.  They feel that they will enventually be laid off.

Pros: Brand recognition is through the roof, and the talent of people here is as good as you will find anywhere.  IBM has a process called TA-DA-QA that is designed to insure accuracy and quality on large deals, and for certain opportunities the company will do a deal for pure cost alone.  Very aggressive and very focused.
Cons: Executive management is insane.  Quotas are unrealistic, they do NOT give a hoot about work/life balance, and they will work you to death... The same TA-DA-QA process that ensures deal quality often keeps teams of employees on conference calls till 4:00 am quibbling over contract verbiage-  I've gone through it many times.  IBM also manufactures very little anymore so we just resold other companies' products, using outsourced labor at higher prices than the industry norm... Makes it very difficult to compete against more nimble, aggressive smaller vendors who can offer the exact same product and delivery subcontractor at a better price.

Pros: IBM is a recognized name in the IT industry. When people hear it they listen. Everybody still trying to be IBM from old. It just that the old ways have gone out the window. You will have to climb the ladder quickly and bleed big blue. Big blue is your new family now. It is good paying job for management in America, but most other employees are contractors.
Cons: The company outsource to other countries to protect their earnings. I am not bad mouth other countries but when the bottom line means cutting American jobs to save a buck. They should really think how they are hurt America instead of profit. Which they claim they never make all year then at the end seem to pull out for the shareholders.

Pros: IBM is still a great company, developing industry leading technology.  The market has changed requiring IBM to make major changes.   IBM Sr Management is trying to make these changes as quickly as possible for a very large organization.  The former management (CEO) setup the current management with the stock buyback strategy vs delivering leading edge technology.  The stock buyback to achieve EPS, hurt the delivery of the technology that was leading edge.
Cons: IBM is too reactive for current Qtr results, vs building a successful long term strategy.   The company continues to operate in silo's and the lack of cooperation between software, services and hardware.  There are still differences between sales plans and channel strategies between these groups.  IBM wants to leverage the resources of the channel but many times there is competition between IBM and BP sellers.

Pros: Work life balance is good,  though this is now changing as they force all employees to work full time from an IBM office (IBM used to be much more open to working from home) . Salaries are above market average
Cons:
Layoffs, feels unstable, executive make up new policies to make life a little more difficult and push employees out- they don't calling it layoffs but effectively that's what it is - workforce redaction - the side effect of this practice is that the good/strong employees leave and the mediocre ones stay. 

Every other month there is a new big strategic shift, which usually goes nowhere bcz they don't give it enough time to takeoff before they shift again. 
Too much short term thinking, focused on immediate revenue with very little investment in r&d.  

In IBM you are a little screw in a big machine, and they make you feel that way every day.

Pros: Easy on boarding with being able to do everything from signing documents to providing your own photo for your badge.  Great training system with admin mentoring new hire. Decent office. Some benefits are good such as medical. Just starting to implement a one day work from home.
Cons: Below average pay for the high level expectations.   Many restrictions that make it somewhat challenging work environment.   Still using Lotus Notes  but the last I heard they might be implementing Outlook.

Pros:
If you’re recently hired at the director+ level they pay well because no one from outside the company wants to work there.
Director+ gets you and administrative assistant which is exceedingly outdated but it’s nice not to have to do your own expenses
Cons: It’s hard to describe just how sad it is to work at this company.  It’s collapsing under the weight of overly complicated, inflexible business processes. There are two types of people here: people that actually do some work and walk around looking traumatized and people that fire out emails all day, clogging up everyone’s inbox or sit on 30 person conference calls and produce nothing. It’s pure lunacy. The co-location thing they did was one of the stupidest moves anyone has ever seen in business. In fact it was downright abusive and heartbreaking to watch people struggle with that decision.  Directors and above spend most of their day inspecting or being inspected using these Byzantine metrics reports.Everyone is constantly worrying when they get laid off too.  Within two days of working here I had decided to pull the plug and walked away from a huge paycheck. Seriously I don’t know how anyone works at this company it’s miserable.

Pros: I would give 4.5 stars but can only give whole starts. I don't think IBM is perfect but I'm not either. There is great opportunity within IBM.. Many training environments and opportunities to keep us fulfilled with expanding our roles here with diversity, new process and quantum computing. The list is almost limitless.
Cons:
Too much is shared on slack, it seems it an open book but do get many responders to find answers to many open questions. 

There is better hiring now but ran too lean and mean for too many years>
With experienced IBM'ers leaving for brand new ones out of graduate school. There is not any good cross over to that dump some of that experience to transition to the new people. Wish there was a better way but with 2 weeks notice can't get anybody hired before the person leaves. Not going to close that gap anytime soon.

Pros: free e-learning, opportunity in other career paths, flexible work schedule, 401K
Cons: Lack of job security, disconnect in communications as manager and employees are scattered, hard to focus when no clear objectives defined outside of contract obligations. The raise structure, iwhich is a cost savings for IBM, and does reflect the needs of it employees, it is based on market data from all of North America. It leaves it open for them to always point to an area of the country that is doing poorly and use that as excuse to why they are unable to pay you more money.

Pros: Average benefits and the ability to work in a good location that provides small town atmosphere with big city benefits of restruants, entertainment, and recreation.  The climate is moderate with an average high temp of 71 degrees, an average sunshire days of 62%, rain fall of 40 inches and only a annual 9 inch trace of snow.  The traffic is moderate and the commute is short.  Housing is reasonable in comparison to larger cities.
Cons: Long hours, little personal time off, NO overtime pay.  Employees are required to replace hours for vacation and holiday time-off with additional hours worked to receive any bonus or salary increases. Management receive excessive compensation as compared to the employees they manage.  60 to 80 hour work week are not uncommon with no compensation in pay or time off. Company removes employees who even mention the word UNION.

Pros: With the size of IBM, there are a tremendous number of opportunities available to it's employees which affords a large amount of both lateral and vertical growth for those who are willing to work and schmooze for it.  The benefits are excellent with a comprehensive insurance plan and 6% match 401(k).
Cons: Size is a double-edged sword.  In order to be recognized among the rest of the go-getters, it's vital to have a manager or mentor willing to champion you.  There is a slew of paper work every year to self-evaluate yourself and petition for promotions.  It is a constant battle to differentiate yourself from your peers to prevent yourself from becoming another gear with a serial number (every IBMer has a serial number) in the masses.  As with all consulting, be prepared to travel 100% of the time and burn the midnight oil when required to do so.

Pros: Overrall IBM is a workplace where life and work are well balanced. The management is professional and friendly. The technology is new if it's not the most cutting-edge. If you're a person who thinks that life is equally or more important than work. IBM is an ideal place to work.
Cons: Career growth is not obvious to everyone. Unless you're quite aggressive. It takes longer time than other hyper companies for you to advance. Plus it's lagging behind in providing competitive compensation than those new companies. As a software developer, another thing I don't like is that the company's budget control is so tight, I cannot get my laptop, my supposed major workstation upgraded in 5 years. It's already an useless junk. Now I'm using my personal computer for company's work. That's right! I'm subsidizing the company to perform my daily job.

Pros: In twenty years at IBM, I have worked with the best and the brightest.  The people are hard working and their blood runs blue.  My job has included travel all over the US on short and long term projects.  My immediate managers have all been remote and only had a chance to meet a few in person.  You are given the freedom to do your job.  Benefits are not bad but seem to be reduced each year
Cons: Many changes at IBM and not positive ones. The 401K match was reduced to 3% match, no raises and meager annual bonus.   CEO and Board seek only to enrich themselves by laying off long time employees (older) employees and replacing with off-shore resources.  Limited availability for training and transfer. IBM now stands for India Business Machines

Pros: Work/life balance is good in sales if you manage your territory properly.  Co-worker relationships are generally positive - everyone is in the same boat and willing to help.
Cons: IT industry turmoil creating waves internally.  Outside personnel viewed more positively than longtime employees.  Depressed income levels for those who have remained loyal to IBM yet still are very positive contributors to IBM's business.

Pros: Wide range of career opportunities ... including focus and investments in legitimate areas of growth in the marketplace.    Many outstanding differentiating technologies to bring to the table for clients.
Cons: Not a good culture  ... individuals no longer matter ....  constant expectation of layoffs and changes permeates the company.   Years removed from the days of consistently being one of America's most admired companies.     Many leaders in roles where they do not bring significant value.    Significant challenges with vision and ability to execute.   Very inwardly focused - no longer a top sales organization.

Pros: Many opportunities to learn new skills and expand your knowledge. Great benefits, great team mates.
Cons: Bonuses, raises and co-location. They recently implemented the co-location policy within the marketing department, which is expected to expand to all other business units as well. This doesn't just mean that we could find an office closest to us, we were given the ultimatum to either re-locate (in my case halfway across the country, first to San Francisco and then a month later to Boston), or find another job. I think this decision was a little short sighted, and a thinly veiled attempt to reduce workforce costs by forcing those with families and loved ones close by to either resign or essentially start their lives over. All of this with no increase in salary and a bare bones moving package.

Pros:
IBM has some great people working for them and tremendous internal resources on which to rely to help close business.  Sales at IBM are team based.  This is a necessity as most deals are quite large (enterprise) and involve many moving parts.  It's not possible to be a technical expert on everything so it's important that you are able to team with additional resources to deliver the right value message to your opportunities.

IBM also provides reasonable compensation and benefits for the role.
Cons: IBM is a chaotic workplace.  It is constantly changing organizational structure and vision.  This has lead to deteriorating morale as front line employees find themselves with significant uncertainty as their roles shift to meet the needs of the new organization.

Pros:
Due to high attrition IBM doesn’t have a choice but to pay new joiners very well. Negotiate well and you can hit upper end of the range. That’s it good things end here !!

Go to IBM to get a higher base and move as soon as possible after that.
Cons:
Toxic management/partners. Employees are “resources” so no one will ever bother to ask about your career goals etc. No clear processes for bonus, hikes or promotions. Everything is driven by partners whims and fancies. 
HR is non existent. Internal tools are archaic. Sales teams over promises to sell anything and everything. Delivery teams have no clue how to deliver. 
All good people have either left or are on the way out.

Pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, flexibility in hours (depending on manager) and being able to work from home.  The company has an international presence so you'll get to work with people literally all over the world.  Depending on the position, you'll have opportunities for travel.
Cons: There is a lot of talk about work life balance but that's not really the culture.  While there is often some recognition for hard work/insane hours it rarely pays off financially.  Also raises and bonuses have dried up despite the company's good performance.  In most departments, many positions get back filled to places like China and India.  This makes people nervous.  Most of the products are not exactly that interesting to work on... but there are some cool things happening.

Pros: IBM is a good company for techies looking to learn on the job. The services organization provides the breadth and depth few service organizations can provide. IBM provides an arsenal of products that are considered the best in the business and used by most fortune 500 companies which opens up the door for advancement outside the organization. Overall it is a very good stepping stone for your career.
Cons: IBM is very HR oriented when it comes to compensating employees. So if you happen to below the market reference point, you have a chance of getting a raise. Even when the company does well as in the past year, the benefits are not passed on to the employees. The raise this year was 0-2% for the IT Specialist job category which is pathetic by any standards.

Pros: In my experience, IBM does a great job of career management.  My managers have always been heavily invested advancing my career, giving me opportunities to shine in front of executives.  And they've always had very frank and open discussions about my career goals and how to achieve them at the company.  Another advantage is that just about any job you can conceive of exists within IBM and you can find it and position yourself to get it - if that's what you want.  Finally, the company is so invested across all technology areas that you can always move to some new, exciting area if you want, or need, to.
Cons: Benefits are bare-bones and employee contributions are increasing every year.  Constant "resource actions" force remaining employees to do more, with less.  And in a company of 370K+ employees, it's hard to feel like your individual contribution really matters.

Pros: Excellent benefits if you are willing to pay for them and an excellent 401K match. Still a good growth opportunity for someone just starting out. Especially if you are a self motivated person. A job history here is still is plus in the professional history section on your resume.
Cons: Seen a lot of highs and lows over the years. They seem to be in one of the lowest times right now. Promotions and raises have been slim to none for the last ten years. It seems that management will "throw the dog a bone" when moral hits rock bottom and give an across the board raise. No interest  in projecting or planning for the future. Only looking at the bottom line right now. Budgets are nonexistent  and people are "Resource Actioned" or laid off monthly.

Pros: Working at IBM did give me the opportunity to learn a myriad of skills, including professionalism, teamwork, and programming.  I earned a nice salary for the duties I performed.
Cons: Unfortunately, IBM wants you to give every ounce of yourself to your work and the company...and then pays off the United States worker by laying them off right before they reach retirement.  They preach quality, productivity, and efficiency...but will brush those qualities aside for the ability to hire 3rd world country employees at ridiculously low wages...who then must muddle through for years trying to support business and application processes.  IBM Senior Management does not seem to understand that they have destroyed loyalty, ownership, and pride in the company and it's employees by accepting big bonuses on the backs of the United States workers who built the company and  on the United States consumer and tax payer who by their products.

Pros: flelxible, easy, the training is good, day go by quickly, mobile offices, as long as you do your job well you will not be bothered, interview was easy.
Cons: growth opportunity in the ssr position is practically nonexistent, rasises nonexistent, bonus nonexistent, increased vacation nonexistent, the people you work with sometimes can talk alot behind your back and can be quite rude to your face. unfair practices such as overtime and distinguising the hardworkers from the slackers. unchallenging.

Pros: IBM does an excellent job of laying out the corporate roadmap.  I understand our vision, priorities and how my role fits into the bigger picture to meet these objectives.  I have an amazing manager that trusts me and I am able to execute the best way I see fit.  Having the right manager at IBM makes a big difference! Also, must of the US based employees have the option of working from home.  That is a huge perk for me! I have the discipline to work from home.  I probably work longer house because of it but I really like the flexibility it provides.  I also work with some AMAZING people.  Like in every company there are good and bad but overall most people at IBM are top notch.
Cons: IBM is a big company and continuing to grow.  It's sometimes difficult to find the right person to assist on an engagement.  Also, there are inconsistencies across brands.

Pros: I've always been happy with how flexible the job has been.  If you need time for a doctor's appt or something, you just take the time.  No one is looking over my shoulder or tracking anything.  Working from home is an option, and also flexible.  I've also had great teams, and most of my managers have been good.  Overall it has been a positive experience.
Cons:
Salary - very poor, not competitive with other companies, and getting worse as the Burlington fab has been the anchor on Ginni's plans.
Morale - yearly layoff's have taken their toll.  Nearly everyone I talk to is grumpy and pissed at IBM.  It's really made it an unhappy place to work.  I used to enjoy my job, now I'm mostly putting in my time.

Pros: Some flexibility with normal work hours. Could come in up to 2 hours before or after 'normal' work hours and leave later or earlier, as appropriate. Sometimes could work from home as each person gets their own laptop. Can change jobs within the company after 2-3 years, if you want to learn different areas.
Cons: My experience with 99.9% of managers was that if you got the job done, and someone else didn't, they wouldn't spend the time and work with the slacker to get him/her to do his/her job. They would just add it to you to do it. You can complain, but they don't care, because they know you'll get the work done, or you have failed to be a 'team player' - they LOVE that buzz word! But why would it take 3 people to replace you each time you left a job?

Pros: You will meet amazing people from all over the world.  If you love being a road warrior, this is the organization for you.  Airfare is always economy, car rentals are always Hertz, lots of hotel options are negotiated rates.  Loads of IBM-related discounts.  MacBooks are now being issued to consultants, for those who prefer Apple to Lenova.  Many, many, many well-defined business processes and supporting IT systems.
Cons: Must meet billing targets to remain employed.  44 hrs/week is typical, although everyone actually puts in closer to 60 hrs/week of effort.  Seriously - you may be a rockstar in all ways measureable, but if you miss your billing utilization target, expect a negative review.  Must be willing to use Lotus Notes.  Got kids?  You might want to wait until they're in college before joining Big Blue, assuming you actually want to particpate in their childhood...

Pros:
* great vision for the cognitive era of computing and its role in business, government, and society
* ample talent and resources to bring the vision to life
* limitless opportunities for anyone to contribute and be part of this journey into the future

I am an IBM Distinguished Engineer. My background is in machine learning.  I focus on technologies that make sales and marketing smarter for IBM and its clients.  If you aspire to lead the cognitive revolution, please join us.  I am proud to be part of this great company.
Cons: IBM is big, complex, and ever changing.   If you're looking for a regular 9-5 job in a static environment -- think again.  IBM will support you in efforts to change the world -- but you have to lead the way and show you can do it.

Pros: IBM is a good company with great history.  The culture of being an IBMer is great where people are willing to help you when you need it.  The size of the company allows for growth and the ability to move into different fields if that interests you.  It is also a global company that allows you to work with people from around the world and learn how to work together despite our differences.
Cons: The challenge of having an amazing history is that you have to push hard to not rely on it.  Too many times this company relies on the greatness of its past to make an excuse of not taking action in the present.  The market changes and IBM must change with it.

Pros:
- IBM gives mobile employees incredible freedom to work from home or from an IBM office 
- IBM generally pays fairly well, but most IBMers are on a leveraged sales quota plan that can vary widely depending on sales success. 
- If you enjoy travel, IBM offers plenty of opportunity to travel.
- IBM provides employees with many options for devices: Apple products - including MacBooks, iPhones & iPads; Lenovo laptops, and B.Y.O.D. options for phone. 
- IBM places a high value on mentoring; there are opportunities to get involved with formal mentor programs and IBMers tend to be very open to "unofficial" mentoring relationships for those seeking advice/guidance in their career
Cons:
- IBM is a highly sales-driven organization and pressure from the top-down has created an ultra-competitive environment that sometimes feels like "everyone for themselves." 
- Job security isn't super strong: Re-organizations and realignments are commonplace and "resource actions" (aka - down sizing) are not uncommon either.
- IBM talks a lot about "career mobility," but doesn't always "practice what they preach."

Pros: Management was great most of the time. We got 10 vacation and 6 sick days per year + 8 holidays. They matched compensation of my previous employer. They have a a lot of online classes you can take for free. you can work OT on projects if you want.
Cons: Supplemental employees didn't get raises, even after 4 years. No 401K match for Supplementals, so you really need to negotiate your salary up front because the bonuses they offer are only for the first 6 months. Even if you get promoted, you might not get a raise. Health insurance for Supplemental employees was horrible. The worst I have ever seen. Extremely high deductibles and out of pocket maximums(the amount you have to pay before everything is 100% covered).

Pros: I liked my teammates, my manager and my benefits. Had more good experiences than bad, but I had to get out of there in order to advance my career in Workday.
Cons: Utilization always came first before talent development, quality of projects was poor and IBM core was already stretched for senior level Workday consultants because many of them already left. There was also no structure for advancement or learning if you were new. No mentors, or training path. There was no way to get yourself off the bench to pick up more hours doing other Workday projects or post production support. You get placed where your manager decides they need the billable hours most. Sometimes you are forced to get "cross trained" and never get to do Workday again. Other Workday partners don't operate like this. I don't recommend if you're new to Workday.

Pros: Vacation time if you've been there a while.  I used to be able to work from home but IBM is canceling all work at home policies, so there's not much reason to stick around.
Cons: Poor management that provides little direction.  The "matrix" environment creates several bosses you have to report to and each boss is in a different organization with different goals.  It's truly a case of the left and right hands not talking to each other and putting staff in the middle to make both sides happy.  Career development is not a focus and certifications are not encouraged.  I've tried to transfer to other positions and management would never provide me a release date; even though HR policies says there's a 90 day maximum hold period.

Pros: Tremendous opportunities for learning and personal advancement, but you have to take total ownership of your career. There is no management guidance. Managers are simply there to manage "resources" - and that means "you".
Cons: Deep and unyielding bureaucracy. Takes a long time to understand and get to grips with the IBM Way. The company is divided into five major divisions who appear unwilling to communicate and create common goals for the most part. The ability to work across business lines is an art and a skill understood by only a few. Significant politicking is required to keep your job from being outsourced. Layoffs are an annual event. IBM has become a business dictated by the bottom line. There is little to no investment in people development, despite much lip service to the contrary. Human resources are just another commodity to be replaced by the cheapest alternative, most often from non-US sources.

Pros: Brand recognition is good. State of the art technology company. Broad range of technologies and opportunities to use them. High business ethics.
Cons:
Little respect for employees. Written direction that if you take your vacation, you should work extra to make up for it. Documented minimum acceptable work week is 45 hours. Education opportunities are rare, and usually only offered after hours or weekends. Business is managed on an individual utilization model that motivates employees to charge more hours, not to do a better more efficient job for our services customers. Employee year end evaluations are first measured on who has billed the most hours.

Little opportunity for internal innovation. IBM just buys innovation in the form of acquisitions.

Way too much bureaucracy. Every business opportunity has 6-10 people in charge, client executives, delivery executives, business development executives, practice area executives, sector  executives, geography executives, and the list goes on.

Pros: The legacy company culture from the founding Watson family still lingers, resulting in a typically congenial working atmosphere.  The sheer size of the company means you have access to resources unthinkable in smaller companies.  There are so many careers in IBM, you could switch once a year and never even scratch the surface.
Cons: Read Dilbert, and know the absurdity of a large, often contradictory hierarchical organization.  Our new CEO and senior leadership have grossly mismanaged our hardware business into a hole from which it will most likely not recover.  IBM is trying, as much as possible, to offshore jobs to cheaper countries.  We have now become a bellwether for employee benefit takeaways.

Pros: I am currently at IBM STG co-op.  IBM has given me the opportunities to explore the possibilities available to me at IBM.  I work with very knowledge people and the work environment is very dynamic and supportive.  I am comfortable, and I learn a lot about subjects that one cannot learn in school--which is the most valuable type of experience needed.  I am given responsibilities that affect the company going forward, and IBM empowers me to do my best by giving me all the tools I need to succeed.
Cons: The only downside is that if IBM does offer me a position it will not be outside my co-op area.  I wish I would apply for other positions else where in the company internally.  The only downside so far.

Pros: flexible working conditions, ability to work from a home office, opportunity for advancement if you network internally and are persistent.
Cons: IBM'ers must keep an updated resume in your top drawer at all times; there is no job security even for top performers.  You have to constantly promote yourself to management and remind them of your achievements or they will go unnoticed and unrewarded.   If your job requires you to be on Call 24x7, you will have no personal life and will experience burnout, as you are expected to be available at any time, even while on vacation, with no additional compensation.  Expect new college hires to be making more than you do even after 10 or 20 years with the company, at the same job position.

Pros:
+ Benefits are very comprehensive.
+ Salary isn't great, but reasonable for the industry.
+ The employees work together as a team, even across organizations.
Cons:
- Totally random layoffs - it's like thinning the herd - you never know who is going to be next.  
- Getting the top appraisal means you've worked the most billable hours, not that your work was the best.
- I'm seeing a recent trend where offshore employees are hired based on who is cheapest at the current moment.  With the fluctuation of the dollar we're looking at Brazil one week, Phillipines the next, Cairo the week after.  The offshore employees miss out on a lot of the benefits of working on a team.

Pros: Exposure to many areas, people, and various types of work; Travel to various locations around the US; Ability to become a strong team contributor; Stellar co-workers with great know how and/or determination; Huge network to find support and help; Great benefits; Very stable and secure feeling;
Cons: Extremely large company - hard to not just be a number; Lack of personal touch/feel; 100% travel; Difficult to obtain promotions and raises; Bonuses are very minimal; No true feeling of team/family/belonging; Constantly being put in situations where you are the "expert" but know very little;

Pros: Flexible work schedules. Opportunity to change positions every 2-3 years if you speak up. Interesting products. Going through a transformation, which can be interesting to be a part of.
Cons: Very siloed with product lines not working well together on joint development; senior leadership is too in-bred (to lead the cloud initiative, Ginni passed over the CEO of Softlayer, who actually knew about cloud, and put a long-time IBMer in charge who had no experience with cloud); way too process oriented, not nimble like most younger tech companies; don't use some of their own best tools very widely, and conversely use too many of their own worst tools, so the business cannot be managed effectively;

Pros:
Lot of big empty offices.
Getting to work with great people who revolutionised computer science 
Many people end up getting paid for noting.
Cons: Its like hug aircraft carrier almost out of supplies , sailing to somewhere it thinks is land. Captain is making decisions based on the gauges and dials which are broken and only really smart engineers know what needs to be fixed. But they are never being asked so they are taking out the lifeboats and leaving the ship.

Pros: I love that I get to work with some of the smartest people in their respective industry. I work on a great small team that allows me to be creative and do things on my own. There are tons of opportunities to shadow people, take on stretch assignments and learn about other parts of the business without having to leave... it's very easy to make a big career change and most of the time it's encouraged. Compensation in my field is unmatched anywhere else. Also, the flexibility to work from home is a plus.
Cons: It's very difficult to get groups to follow cultural changes. A lot of IBMers have been around for a long time, and to get them to change the way we do things is like moving a glacier. I will say that there are great efforts IBM is trying to change, but it really is impossible to make any sort of change until upper management steps in... and even that takes a long while.

Pros:
Global Reach
Great on Diversity
Career Possibilities
Stated Values
Some first line manager are very good leaders.
Internal education is good.
Cons:
Short Term tactical vs. long time strategic.
Finance runs the business vs. Sr Leadership
Uninspiring, dishonest, and negative Senior Leadership
Human Resources is nothing but a vehicle to assist Finance   
Awful work place environment, no decision making power for first line managers.
Work/Life balance - 60-70 hours per week is the expected norm with no recognition
Cuts, cuts, cuts, - if you are not an executive, you have to buy your own paper clips..
Stated Values are not practiced.
Expectation that cost savings vs. revenue generation will lead to success.

Pros: With in IBM - GBS is a good place to work as you don't really interact much with IBM or Management as you work for a Client.
Cons:
A lot of them on a high level
- Poor Benefits esp. 401k worst I have seen
- Politics in Management 
   I'm a victim of racism , I had been rated 2+(over achiever)  every year and successfully delivered projects on time but still put me on RA. And reason for RA is cost cut but my Peer who has not performed well and hasn't delivered project was not effected at all as she was White. I was asked to pass on my successful projects to her. 

I took the package which they offered as part of RA as I have seen enough. And the Best part they haven't settled my RA amount yet it's been over 2 months and HR keeps saying check is on the way...lol. I guess they ran out of money..lol

Pros:
- My coworkers are pleasant and generally capable.
- Generally rewards excellence
- Lots of free materials and courses to learn from
- Work hours generally fit a standard 9-5, only had a crushing load for a few months of my 3 years here, and it's largely my fault for overestimating my ability
- Good managers invested in my growth and career
- Good base pay
Cons:
- I've kind of been left to my own devices since 1 year and 3 months in. I'm happy to take ownership of the product I work on, but I don't feel like my technical skills are up to snuff without having a senior help me learn what I don't know.
- Promotions weren't hard but they aren't easy either, there's only so many positions to go around.
- A decent amount of turnover in the sense of people leaving IBM for something better.
- The directives from upper leadership leave something to be desired.
- It's a big, bloated machine. It works, just not always quickly.
- Good base pay, but no other compensation

Pros: work life balance is excellent.  I can take time off whenever I need and get good recognition.  It has very entrepreneurial spirit so I can make solutions and am very free to pursue activities I think will help generate the most revenue.  Management in my case is very hands off and allows me to do what I want.
Cons: lack of support from senior management to do my job.  No access to hardware resources.  I'm always scrounging to get resources to do my job.  There is no good direction, but this can be a good thing because I'm free to make my own decisions.

Pros:
A recognizable name and fair to decent benefits are a plus for IBM. There are good, intelligent people to find as mentors at a company of this size.

Nevetheless, It's very easy to fall through the cracks here and coast along with little notice from management.

A good first job for those fresh out of school looking for a big name to boost their resume.
Cons:
Constant threat of layoffs. IBM is moving many of their jobs offshore with little regard to their US based workforce. 

Red tape, complicated internal processes and little focus on the welfare of the employee make IBM a living example of a Dilbert cartoon. Often times, the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing.

Pros:
Excellent compensation. Very predictable environment. Very standardized ways of doing things. Good company to go on cruise control while dealing with life.

If you do not want a challenging job, this is a good place. I find it very easy to get my assignments done, but very difficult to get new opportunities that have not been fully planned out by management. 

On the upside, the company is very predictable. No wildly annoying personalities. They won't last. A fair number of very serious, do it by the numbers people. IBM invented the box, so there is no sense thinking outside of it.
Cons: Very little room for creativity. Every idea has to go through 10-15 meetings and 20+ people for approval. Very difficult to stay passionate about a job/idea when there are so many 'processes' to go through. It probably makes for more stable products, but completely kills innovation.

Pros: Working in IBM development you have access to the latest technical advancements.  It is not difficult to find an area of interest within the product development and the current environment of "do more with less and more quickly" does allow engineers to expand their horizons by taking on responsibilities in areas they have not previously had an opportunity to explore.
Cons: Schedules and product requirements are constantly changing and by the time they figure out what they want, the engineers are forced to scramble in order to make extremely aggressive deadlines.  Layoffs and reorgs have left most teams with less resource than they need to do their jobs.  The rating system is demotivating since people who work very hard are likely to get the same rating as those doing little work.

Pros:
Employees with a passion for IT technology.
Processes and procedures for all aspects of the business keep operations running fairly smoothly.
Cons:
Bully culture in executive ranks (at least in the US).
The company has been driving up the stock price by cutting expenses, especially salaries and benefits - hence the many rounds of cuts and early retirements which have decimated the ranks of experienced professionals in IBM.  The brain drain has accelerated with the voluntary departure of top talent.
Extremely risk adverse management forcing a unhealthy and unsustainable reliance on innovation through acquisitions.  (IBM Research still excels at invention, but their output typically must go outside of IBM to be nurtured to the innovation stage (by engineers and entrepreneurs) before being brought into the IBM product portfolio through company acquisition.

Pros: The benefits are amazing with 4-5 weeks of vacation time, 6 weeks of full paid sick leave and endless discounts from cell phone to car companies.
Cons:
The amount of favoritism at Dubuque IBM is uncalled for. I see this daily as a team lead and management does not care for any employee besides themselves. All managers get a PBC rating of 1 no matter how poorly they do and get to downgrade each employee on the team to get a big bonus. I saw this the past few years and management looks the other way. It is sad to see this center has the worst turnover rate than any others.

The average salary amount is $32,000. We advertise our jobs at $45,000 to $50,000 and rarely offer that rate.

IBM used to be the place to work 10 years ago but with all the cuts in the past few years, I would advise not to work here.

Pros: Ability to work from home, travel perks, network with many people and external clients.
Cons:
