Very poor management - no one knows what you are doing. Typical "CbDers" were lucky to speak with their managers twice a year, of whom were managing 100+ individuals. Your performance is measured entirely on what you say you did at the end of the year. 

To be blunt, the company was dishonest about what the CbD program is. The program marketed itself as "strategy & transformation" roles. In reality, the only projects myself or other CbDer's found themselves on were IT implementation projects, which offered little challenge.

IBM's recent marketing campaigns claim the company is involved in analytics, mobile, cloud and social media work. I saw nor heard of any real projects in these fields. These appear to be areas IBM would like to be involved in, but hasn't yet been able to figure out how to do so. It's easy to see right through their fancy marketing after working for IBM.

Pros: If you are looking for a lifetime career you can very well find it IBM. Benefits are good, pay is fair.  It is the rare individual who will "kill it" from a salary standpoint, unless you time it right in sales, or are a GBS Partner.  If you enjoy process overkill with minimal oversight and direction, freedom to shape your role and the opportunity to be involved in a massive team matrix style of management, IBM is an interesting place.
Cons: Surprising the number of "lifers" that are employed/in hiding at this company, many without any experience outside of IBM.  IBM may pride itself on the number of acquisitions and the numbers of "new" IBMrs in the ranks, but those folks quickly figure out the stifling environment and bloated layers of management within the company and realize if they want to do anything innovative they seek roles elsewhere.

Pros: The best reasons to work at IBM are that you are involved in the mainstream of what is happening in the IT and business services surrounding IT.  The company is innovative, encouraging of diversity, and collaboration among cross functional teams.
Cons: The challenges of working at IBM is getting everyone that you work with to get on the same page.  Sometimes that is the biggest obstacle to accomplish something.   Another challenge is the amount of "red tape" that is sometimes associated with the simplest of processes.  Getting IBM to change how something is done, even to improve efficiency isn't easy to accomplish.

Pros: If you ever do a quick review of IBM's history, you will find an organization that invented or improved a multitude of industries and aspects of modern life.  The original founder, and his son, seemed invested in creating a business that was a positive force in society and which took pride in advancing the lives of employees and their families.
Cons: Today's IBM manages and incents plenty of unintentional and bad behaviors.  Managers are driven to protect and champion their own employees regardless of relative value.  Top line revenue numbers and short term profitability have overtaken innovation, customer loyalty, and employee growth as prime motivators in the company.  Employment at IBM can feel very frustrating from both a personal and technical perspective.

Pros: New initiatives in cloud, analytics, mobility, Watson and social are the hot focus right now. If you have any of those skills you should  be fine. There are lots of educational opportunities that you should take advantage of as often as you can.  There is a mentoring program but it is only as good you make it.
Cons: Continual Resource Actions (RAs) impacting morale of the work force in many areas. If you have 25+ years at IBM you feel like you have a target on your  back.

Pros:
- The elder people you work with have a tremendous amount of knowledge and experience you can learn from
- Work hours are flexible as long as you do what is expected of you
Cons:
- Poughkeepsie, NY is one of the least attractive places to work. The town offers nothing for young people. The consensus among new hires is to work for 2-3 years and then go work somewhere else, away from Poughkeepsie.
- Salary is sub-par, bonus' are poor, and raises are not definite. Sadly, there is no monetary incentive to stay; pay is much better elsewhere.
- Working from home has been banned. You must come into the office now, or you'll get the boot.
- Generally, cost-saving initiatives are at the expense of the employee reflected in their 401K's, benefits, compensation, and flexibility.

Pros: Decent pay, fair amount of flexibility depending on your job role
Cons: I joined this company just a few years ago with high hopes that it would live up to its name and (former) reputation. I couldn't be more disappointed with my experience here as a "millennial" excited to grow a career here. The culture is terrible, the executive management is greedy and out of touch, and the constant layoffs and disregard for the employee (and customer for that matter) result in the lowest morale I have ever seen in a company. Since I started 2 years ago, almost everyone I have met has been laid off without explanation or beat them to it by leaving on their own. Do not believe the propaganda and run the other way to an employer that appreciates you and compensates you accordingly.

Pros: Work from home policy is great. pay is fine, 401k match , flexible hours as long as you are productive
Cons:
Managers don't value employees. Products are out-dated. Employees pay the price of bad decisions made by upper/middle management. They don't value women although they say they do. Very hard to secure your jobs unless you have good connections.
Cannot compete with smaller companies in the market which is demotivating. Travel is exaggerated. Continuous Layoffs make all employees feel insecure and constantly on the look for another job. A lot of people are staying only because of the flexibility. 
Very bas reputation in the market, a lot of clients don't want to work with IBM anymore because of the unstable products and the high turn over 
Will definitely leave as soon as I find another job with an equal pay. Not a company for women.

Pros: Very smart colleagues and professional atmosphere.    Great opportunity to learn from large selection of online courses.    Good salary and benefits.  Some flexibility in occasionally working remotely is available, but fading fast.
Cons: Company keeps chipping away at benefits and flexibility.    Recent changes now require developers to work at the office, and many talented engineers who couldn't move were let go.    Regular resource actions have seriously affected morale, and upper management's attempts at improving morale are not effective, since layoffs continue to occur.     Recent college hires are making more than higher band engineers with more experience and impact to the team's and company's success.    The fact that compensation is still based on a scale means that above average contributors will never be adequately compensated relative to new graduates.

Pros: Used to be work at home but that is now being rescinded.  I'm trying to figure out how they will retain legacy critical and hard to find skills with out a work at home policy.  For new millenials entering the work force IBM is a terrific company to work for to get your legs.  It is also a terrific company to have on your resume.  I would not stay more than 3-5 years however for fear of getting pigeon holed.
Cons: A company that's looking to re-invent itself and you can find yourself on the wrong island and playing a game of survivor with your team mates.  Teamwork is constantly stressed but current environment does not support.

Pros:
I'm a new father and took advantage of the existing Parental Leave program that was available to us in the US. With the old program, it was 6 weeks of paid leave. With the new program, IBM dads and moms are now entitled to 12 weeks of paid leave. This program doesn't utilize your vacation days. So if you have vacation days, those days are still entitled to you. This is the primary reason I'm spending some time on writing this review.

Employee discounts. I honestly didn't know this existed till I started navigated the maze of wiki sites we have (see Con below). It was pretty nice that we had access to discounts from electronics to things like Disney park.
Cons:
* Bonuses and raises are slim to none.
* Team members are also concerned about losing the ability to work from home.
* A lot of systems to navigate and old systems that are still in use that need to be replaced
* 401k matching isn't done till the last paycheck of the year

Pros: It used to be a time when Ibm was a good company. It is going to be two years I have left IBM india and spent 6.5 yrs in IBM india.I could not think of anyone staying in Ibm apart from from some dead wood senior management people who speak about cognitive computing, cloud and recently blockchain but did not even know what they are speaking about.
Cons:
No point of talking about their cons.
Constant failure of project shows where they stand. Only some big one comes in news...😋😋
Technically strong people... please stay away... you have much better product or service company to work for...
Working mother... don't get fool by their wfh...IBM India follow the strategy of paying much less than the market by attracting needy people with those facilities.

Pros: Did have great people but the good ones jump ship eventually
Cons:
- Management don't care about their people. They are just focused on keeping their jobs so anyone gets thrown under the bus to save themselves
- HR are all about protecting their management team, NOT their staff
- So many unnecessary meetings. Meetings for meetings sake
- Customers are NOT valued once IBM has their money. They don't matter and the support is no longer there for them.
- Bullyboy management style with many having narcissistic, self important, deluded and self serving aspirations
- Rule by fear not support as everyone is scared of losing their jobs
- NO morale
- LOTS of dead wood still left in the ranks despite so many redundancies
- Forcing people to work from offices or lose your job. Saves them redundancy payouts as they say "your job still exists, you just don't want to work in the office"

Pros: Learning possibilities are endless, internal networking was phenomenal, and accessibility to anyone at any level was unlike any other organization I had worked for previously.
Cons: A constant , nervous feeling that there was no ground beneath your feet due to the constant disruptions, transformations, and restructuring. The move from a being a largely telecommuting company back to bricks and mortar is one such painful example where lives were disrupted. I wasn't around for it, but I lived through other disruptions.  The move back to offices must have been horrific for many. While at IBM, many were prepping for the eventual day that they that they are told you are being 'resourced' - that's IBMese for you're laid off. How does one stay productive and focused in such an environment?

Pros:
1) The health plan is good.  

2) Depending on the position, there is the ability to work from home.

3) The 401(k) match is good, although they apply the match only at the end of the year.
Cons:
1) IBM invokes layoffs virtually every year.  It is part of their business plan. The highest-rated performers are not immune from being laid off.

2) The performance rating system uses "stack ranking" to force an artificial predetermined distribution of high vs low performers.  The corporation denies that they use this method but it is an open secret within the organization.

3) The company defines a bad quarter as not meeting their predetermined financial goals, even if they are profitable.  The response to a "bad" quarter is to invoke layoffs to lower expenses.  This is very much to the detriment of the remaining employees and their products.

4) Rigid work environment full of red tape, takes forever to get anything done.

5) The company tacitly expects salaried employees to put in significant overtime.

Pros: Good products and strong professionals.  IBM culture drives pride in being an IBMer.  Easy to find help in meeting tasks.
Cons: Matrix management has too many managers which leads to micromanagement of every decision.  IBM is a 100 year old company and many processes are slow and involve too many people.  Admin folks follow age old processes explicitly and not empowered to make exceptions to changing needs.  This bogs the organization down in detail as managers take excessive time trying to approve simple decisons as they work their way through excessive matrixed managment.  In summary, there are too many people matrixed into normal decision processes so not even simple decision can be made in a timely manner.  Even worst, no one seems empowered to step up and stop rediculous over management of what should be simple decisions.

Pros: Salary that is comparable to entry-level contract work. Work from home and client site, instead of an actual building. "Flexible" work schedules. Practically doubled in size during the worst recession in most of our lifetimes...though growth was everywhere except the US.
Cons: IBM's idea of "flexible"work schedule means 130% utilization (or else), evening and weekend work, having to work an extra week for every week of vacation you take (or else), frequent stealth layoffs when IBM is looking to purchase another company in distress, a dramatic shift from quality to quantity (utilization is all that matters to them, now), abandoned core beliefs.

Pros: Work with a lot of smart people, most of whom are willing to share their knowledge and experience. Working at home adds nice flexibility, even if it can be isolating. The brand has great recognition and respect. There are opportunities to try new roles, though in general, roles are very narrow in scope.
Cons: Through layoffs and attrition, the team has become very very lean. We have "resources" available in India, Brazil and elsewhere, but they're often much less experienced than those they're replacing. With 3 major reorganizations in less than a year, there's a lot of confusion and churn over priorities and goals. Since most people work from home, there's a heavy reliance on conference calls, with 5-6 hours/day not unusual. Even with several consecutive years of "top performance," raises have been minimal or non-existent - never more than 2% in a year. Too much bureaucracy: it can take a long time to accomplish what should be simple tasks.

Pros: The people are generally really great to work with. Well credentialed, professional and work well together. Salary and benefits are near par in the industry.
Cons: The current strategy is based on lower the employee expense base and as a result, many many positions are being moved to low cost countries. In spite of on going cost reduction activities, profits continue to disappoint. As a result, the  leadership has adopted a 'use a stick' philosophy of motivation. The performance review process forces a distribution on the management team to ensure a ready pool of individuals pre-identified for resource actions.

Pros: IBM is a legendary company that is going through significant change in their business and future strategy.  In my time there, I did well and was well rewarded for my efforts.  Benefits were very good especially the 401K match.  IBM had been very good for me.
Cons: IBM is a very large and complex business.  In the last several years, there has been so much change that it seemed as though I was constantly starting over.  Every 6 months, new pay plans, quotas, team members, customers etc.  Hard to get and keep momentum. Most recently, there have been a large number of layoffs making it increasingly difficult to deliver to customers.

Pros: For some people may  provide opportunities to pursue interesting and important technology trends.  However, years of a strategy that weakens its delivery capabilities may mean that while IBM could be a good place to try out, it eventually may not be able to support longer term career goals.
Cons: Currently perception may look better than the reality.  Frequent reorganizations, intensive employee churn and unstable strategy and tactics means the dust never settles enough to effectively operationalize the ideas.   This leaves the organization confused, off balance, and struggling with day to day survival down to the individual employee level, instead of successfully delivering solutions.  Sellers drink the coolaid about new capabilities, but a limited ability to actually deliver leaves the rest of the organization in cleanup mode for promises that cannot consistently be kept.   Excitement with great ambitions gives way to disillusioned reality when things move from slides and PoCs to attempts at more complete solutions.   Lesson: stay on the solution sales side, and away from solution delivery.

Pros: Being out at work as lesbian enabled me to experience helping launch an internal startup -- a business development team dedicated to the LGBT+ B2B market. My management also supported my 6-month assignment in India with my wife, accompanying me, even though homosexual activity is illegal in India; it said that it couldn't get me out of jail if I were jailed due to the country's laws, but that Pat & I could be fully out as a couple within IBM's four walls; we were and local management and colleagues all were lovely to and inclusive of us. My U.S. management also sponsored my Master's at Columbia while I worked full-time. All this while being able to mentor and be mentored by amazing LGBT+ colleagues and allies!
Cons: Join an investment bank, rather than IBM, if you want to be wildly wealthy, but you can earn a healthy living here.

Pros: Flexible work environment for most jobs. I work from home 99.9% of the time, but other positions or locations may require you to be in an office. Pretty good benefits. Big emphasis on learning. A lot of good workers with passion. Lots of opportunities.
Cons: Sometimes it's very bureaucratic...death by 1000 papercuts. Other times it can be very innovative.  401k match for the year is only if you're there at the company on Dec 15th.  Raises have been very sparse, if you got one at all, even with good/great performance by the worker.  Not a lot of job options unless you're a tech person (architect, data scientist, etc)

Pros: Brand recognition on a resume. Large budget for projects, felt like a waste at times, but we spent it. I worked from home the last 1/2 of my career which was great. Benefits were good.
Cons: Where do I begin. I came in to IBM underpaid, just to get my foot in the door. The organization I was in was so archaic. Layoffs happened every quarter. Meanwhile the President & Top Management received huge bonuses even though there were failing quarters. I moved in to a more popular organization in IBM, thinking it was safer. Little did I know, they were forcing ppl to relocate to "hub" cities. Targeting those who worked from home. If they didn't move, they'd lose their job. Then that job was replaced by newly graduated college students and paid severely less. they called this "new collar" what it really was a massacre of those who devoted their lives to IBM, worked overtime for little pay.

Pros: It's slow paced and a lot of managers aren't really involved. They just do their own thing.
Cons: Most people here have been here a while and most without engineering degrees since they didn't exist back then. They do things here their own way and these life time employees are the team leads and management.This makes it really hard for new grads in engineering to come in and learn. It's also incredibly difficult to bring in new tools, get acceptance for new tools and to get the team to automate things. It's also difficult to do object oriented on legacy systems and one has to follow the teams coding  style right down to the comments so you end up being a depressed underpaid code monkey.

Pros: Great place to learn with ample resources to do your job with and explore interests. I found that subject matter experts were generally easy to get in touch with and learn from if proactive about reaching out. There's always something exciting happening somewhere in the company, and offering management has great exposure to much of what goes on. Found IBM's corporate values were generally prevalent across the company. Met many people who became sincere friends outside work.
Cons:
Matrixed company felt disjointed and difficult to move around; it seemed like two people could have the same job title and be doing very different things, or be in different parts of the company and have very different experiences. A lot of bureaucracy at times, and the work could be a grind. 

If you love engineering and dev/ops, you'll probably be happier here than if you love B2C work. When IBM gets it right, they really get it right, but you have to know up front that IBM isn't the right place for everyone.

Pros:
I joined IBM in 1988. Been here 34 years.
I came out as gay to my hiring manager and (in 1988!) he was delighted to tell me all about IBM's respect for diversity and protections for various minorities.
Just in the last five years, I got an adult diagnosis of autism (mild, with apparently excellent coping mechanisms). I get a lot of support from my management team and my peers, they are happy to let me work the hours that work best for me, and are always pointing me to resources for neurodiverse people, inviting me to take advantage of other accommodation opportunities.

I just wish I wasn't getting old, because I'd love to keep working for IBM for another 34 years.
Cons: Twice during my long career, I spent some time in job positions that were not a great fit for my signature skills, and that was a bit depressing, but the job that followed each suboptimal experience was the best job to date!

Pros:
* Significant learning opportunities via online trainings, certifications, etc.
* Can make good money (negotiated a great salary)
* People I worked with with mostly nice and collaborative
* Company Culture in Marketing was very supportive of their people
* Large supporters of work/life balance and remote work
Cons:
* Many processes and decision makers involved - roadblocks to getting things done
* Many people still insist on doing things the way they've always done it
* Organization so large, difficult to move fast or create a sense of urgency
* IBM Cloud is not a leader in the industry - difficult to get partner/customer focus when up against AWS, Azure, Google Cloud....
* 401K plan - only match contribution at the end of the year (if you leave before then you do not get any 401K match for that year)

Pros: flexibility, Open culture and work/life balance
Cons: It is hard to find good first line and second line managers. Though i do not have much experience dealing with executives, I dont think too highly of them

Pros: Usually great co-workers and technically, some of the best in the industry IMO. Often interesting projects that allow you to greatly expand your knowledge in many, many fields.
Cons:
Incompetent senior management that has restricted first line managers to the extent they are glorified team leads. Everything, every decision, every raise, every bonus, every schedule is micro-managed by senior managers. The first lines are just talking heads touting the company line when you know very few believe any of it.

That and that fact that every year, senior managers figure out a way to take something from the employees, vacation, raises, promotions, retirement, you name it.

Fire Randy McDonald (HR VP) first, he seems to take particular joy in sticking it to the employees every year.

Pros:
There is a lot of down time when you aren't on a project to do other things.
Some projects offer good travel opportunities.
IBM is now on your resume.
Cons:
There is a lack of communication between managers and it makes it frustrating to get on a project.
Deployment managers are clueless to who you are and what skills you have.
You get thrown into projects where you don't have the skills or you are sold as a professional.
They say 10% travel, but many projects are every week to client location for months.
Salary is a joke to other jobs in the field, even in other IBM departments you get paid nearly 2X.

Pros:
-decent ability to work from home when needed (flip side is you're expected to be "online" at ridiculous hours.  As a co-op I had to work until midnight once a month!)
-good compensation for the MN area
-tons of free education online, but it only applies to areas within IBM
-work only with other finance people at the Center of Excellence, lots of face to face knowledge sharing and ability to move around within finance
Cons:
-TONS of employee turnover, it's rare if someone stays over 4 years
-not a lot of respect for the individual, most teams you support are not local, so there's only ST or phone conversations
-very easy to get into finance in Rochester and get stuck, I'm lucky I got out while I could

Pros:
Lots of autonomy
Bring your own device
Amazing culture and opportunities to learn
Supportive management and fair treatment
Competitive pay and decent benefits
Cons:
Only 3 weeks of vacation to start
Benefits could be better, they are average
A decent amount of big company bureaucracy
You have to use Lotus Notes

Pros: While I can't recommend IBM as a place to end a career, it is a good place to be able to make enough to pay the bills while learning Java and all of its associated technologies.  One thing about IBM is that they won't fire you on your first, or even second outings working with their clients, as long as you are trying.
Cons: The old adage about IBM's "culture" is true, and is a hard thing to put up with, but I tolerate it well enough by telling myself that I am traveling in disguise.  Other than that, and the ~standard corporate tricks they attempt to pull on us, it is an ok place to work.  And East Lansing, if you like Michigan at all, is very nice.

Pros: One big selling point for me in joining IBM was the ability to work from home. This definitely helps with the work life balance. Pay seems to be competitive, benefits are decent, and you have unlimited IBM resources at your disposal for self education and research.
Cons:
It didn't take long to realize the negatives of working from home. Since everyone works from home, you never engage your colleagues/managers, except for when working on a deal. Even though there are "teams", you never feel like that you are a part of a team...just groups of individuals that reports to the same manager.  

Though there are offices, it's 99% empty. You'll see people there once in a while...but it really is depressing when you go into an office and it's completely dead.

Also managers are just that...managers, vs leaders that inspire and motivate. 99% of your interaction with your manager is giving them pipeline updates so that they in turn can update their manager and so on.

Pros: Once a great global tech company, but external rapid changes in tech landscape, the company no longer retain that position.  But I give them credit for just surviving as most of its peers have folded or bought out.  Any tech companies over 50 years old is a rare species.   This I believe has to do with its hiring, training, and management philosophy that was put in place in earlier years.  I have switched industry since then, but some of the best and most capable people I met were from IBM.
Cons: Did not take Personal Computing (low margin and low ASP) seriously enough, or understood the consumer market well enough.   It should have spinoff that division in the 80's or not have outsourced key parts to the like of Microsoft and Intel.

Pros:
- Strong importance on give back to the community
- Inspires you to continue education
- Inspires you to start your own company
- Vacation benefits and sick leave are good if you are a legacy employee or longer than 2 years now
- Good resume builder and brilliant people to mentor (Avoid the bad, negative employees)
Cons:
- Lack of concern for the individuals development even though that is the sales pitch
- Internally competition amongst divisions and regions
- Lack of focus on your background
- Like most consulting firms, the metrics used to rate employees does not incentivize efficiency, just billing hours for short-term revenue kudos to push stock price while compromising the delivery it owes to its clients.
- It is making poor globalization choices just like most outsourcing firms because the government incentivizes it to occur.  This is not IBM's fault but rather the government.

Pros: Great compensation, health benefits, employee discounts on a variety of things. Easy for relocation as there are offices just about everywhere in the world. It's been around forever so it's stable in that aspect of job security. Nice 401k match and various financial options, tuition reimbursements, spousal and family perks, etc.
Cons: 80%+ travel for consultants, which can be very draining if it's not your thing. Very poor work-life balance. The sheer size of the company makes it extremely easy to get lost in the shuffle. Lots of unnecessary bureaucracy and hoop-jumping for things like promotions and performance reviews, although there are signs of an attempt to improve this. Employee site very difficult to navigate.I still don't really know how to answer people who ask me "so what do you actually do?".

Pros: Heritage brand that certainly opens doors. IBM is made up of high integrity, intelligent professionals and boasts an incredible array of offerings which are being made even more powerful with the addition of Watson cognitive intelligence.
Cons: IBM can't get out of its own way from an internal operations standpoint.  Too many disparate systems, which in and of themselves are hugely inefficient and make it difficult to navigate quickly and effectively to progress simple tasks, much less the sale.  IBM forges ahead with what they think are great ideas - both from an internal operations standpoint and product development - but they don't involve and ask the right stakeholders before moving forward, often missing the mark because they made the wrong assumptions.

Pros:
- Most people who work in lower level roles at IBM are amazing.
- Most Lower level management strives to work hard and support team.
- Lots of resources and learning for employees.
- working from home is nice, but going away for a lot of people and teams
Cons:
- Upper management creates chaos for no reason, there’s some major dictator types!
- Highly political environment that keeps getting worse and worse.
- The company is failing and management is either lying or blind to the fact. I would have so much more respect for leaders who admit the problem and work to fix it. Instead they just keep saying we are the best of the best and leaders of the industry. It turns a blind eye to problems and is unrealistic. 

I’ve hated working here honestly. It’s been a nice resume boost and I’ve gotten some great connections but no way I would stay here long term!

The company doesn’t invest in employees at all, despite what they tell you.

As a side note: a lot of the 5 star reviews are “questionable” as employees are encouraged to add them in peak recruiting cycles.

Pros:
* I worked with some fantastic people
* Some of the products and services really were "best in class"
* There was a clear path to promotion while remaining in an engineering role rather than being forced to transition to management
* I was pleasantly surprised several times with raises and bonuses. It's literally the only place I've ever worked where I received a raise without asking for it, and it happened to me twice in 3 years at IBM.
* IBM's marketing and name recognition is awesome
Cons:
* Some of the products were not "best in class"
* Bureaucracy and politics got in the way of quality and cost us good people
* A strategy shouldn't drastically change every year or two
* IBM's complete flip-flop on remote workers was the primary reason I left
* I had 6 managers in 3 years

Pros: IBM offers self starters opportunities to grow with new roles, new leaders, and education. IBM is a large organization which requires you to network internally with peers, mentors and leaders in many different organizations. You create and build your own reputation. For many roles you can work your own hours but expect it to be 50 hour work weeks at a minumum.
Cons: Don't expect anything to come easy. You need to work with the uncertainty of losing your job, long/unpredictable hours.

Pros: New Sr. Leadership at the CEO level
Cons:
1. Career Framework vs . Reality
Painting a picture of current learning & career plans that suggest promotion & salary benefits is creating false expecations. The deal pieplines simply do not favor a high number of Band 8 -10 positions for everyone. Consider when pitching career framework, including statitics for opportunities directly from Professional Marketplace and if possible, actual deal piplines. Theis is IBM 's real-time reality. 
2. Re: Inclusiveness / culture efforts : All the meetings , emails, campaigns, etc ., etc . used to be, at one time, represented by four (4) simple words : "Respect for the Individual" (Thomas Watson). Maybe save a few $$$, revist our founder's viewpoint, and simpilfy the entire culture program and cut some of the fluff.

Pros: IBM does have some pros. The sheer size and history are incredible. A lot of diversity, and a lot of insanely smart people
Cons:
The cons list is too long to be listed cleanly so I'll try to summarize:
IBM still uses layoffs in a way that (to me) is antiquated.
A lot of long term people's only skill is surviving at IBM.
Expenses and audits are extremely painful. People work in fear of getting a resource action or an audit.
Extremely talented people get resourced just because the machine is too big to really notice them.

Pros: At this point, the pay is good and the vacation plan is great (for a long time employee).  The technical challenges are outstanding.
Cons: I have little or no faith that any of the benefits that value to me will continue to be offered.  There is too much emphasis on squeezing blood from the stone by continuing to cut costs - all in the interest of increased net income.  The focus isn't on growing revenue, it's on net income ... so the costs must come down.  All of that burden falls on the employees in the form of fewer resources (mostly staffing, but also increased times to replace obsolete hardware), benefit cuts (mostly in reductions in pensions and increases in health care costs), and depressing facilities (lousy cafeterias, unpainted buildings, unrepaired sidewalks, etc).  The workforce is stressed out, burned out, and worn out.

Pros:
Top notch work life balance in my line of work (IT development).  I'm work at home employee since I joined IBM.
People around me and in other department that I deal with are very professional.  I rarely see inter office politics.  I never saw intimidation, negativity towards other people etc.  1st and 2nd line managers are always straight forward with us.
The company is genuinely interested in diversity.
I have very decent market rate pay package.
Lots of learning opportunity if you are interested.  Since IBM owns numerous software development tools, they are at your disposal, free to use to further your knowledge and career.
Cons: In US locations, I see new project opportunity to on is drying up.  There is lot of administrative work involved in my job as software developer and technical lead.  There is more operational work then new development opportunity due to cut backs and off shoring.

Pros: The best part of working for IBM is some employees have the option to work at home.
Cons: There is absolutely no respect for the individual.  Sr. management could not care less about the employees.  They are on a mission to move work offshore to India and China, and get rid of as many U.S. employees as they can.  They are even forcing the U.S. employees to train their replacements.  Then, employees with 20+ years and excellent reviews are thrown out like yesterday's trash.  These are not low level employees -- we are talking about senior professionals in IT, finance, etc., who are highly educated and high performing employees.

Pros: Great work from home and ability to move around.
Cons: Terrible moral, working employees to death to meet their Roadkill 2015 target.  The truth is they will meet it by selling off all the properties they aquired when times where good how ever in the process their SW/HW and Services group will crumble due to the lack of people, over worked and under paid.   Clients are jumping ship and it can be seen as their revenue remains flat how ever profit is booming.   That means SQUEEEEEZE.     Enjoy IBM while you can, work it, get experience then jump ship ad go some where that will respect and pay you accordingly.

Pros:
Most employees are given the opportunity to work at home.
Work hours are generally flexible which helps with life interruptions.
The company name looks good on your resume.
Cons:
Salary stays flat regardless of performance, promotions, or responsibilities.
Almost impossible to get paid training.
Benefits cost more each year so with no raises you actually take home less money.
The company has one goal only and that is earnings per share target.

Pros:
You will be surrounded by really talented people who have high standards and expect the same.
In the division I worked, people were always willing to take the time to help a coworker work through a problem or to discuss new ideas. Lots of opportunity to take on different roles and career paths if you are proactive in managing your career.
Cons:
Like any big company, you have to learn how to work the system to get things done. You also need to stay on top of technology trends and  position yourself to be part of the forward movement, as with any company..
Difficult to move between divisions if trying to change jobs/career paths.
As corporate VPs work to the 2015 EPS goal, cost savings by cutting back on employee compensation has been obvious.

Pros:
- Work-life balance is honored and enforced; there's a lot of flexibility with sick time, time for personal business, and working flexible hours or working remotely
- Really talented coworkers; the best ones are leaving though.
- The least amount of office drama/politics out of every other place I've worked in
- IBM still has a huge global impact; makes one proud to work for a company that sets up solutions for cities, governments, hospitals, space programs, banks all over the world.
Cons:
- Pay and benefits do not match competition for top talent in the industry
- There's an astounding lack of vision at the upper levels of management; feels like the company has been shooting itself in the foot for years now, and nothing has been done to address the issues
- Lack of clear top-down communication about company's direction
- A lot of unnecessary bureaucracy; hard to change things and get things done
- Very low employee morale

Pros:
- Still a great name on your resume (for now)
- Ability to easily move to new roles based on career aspirations
- Great, smart people to work with
- Good work/life balance depending on the business unit you work in (NOT GBS)
Cons:
There are many - here are a few:
- Moral is low because employees don't feel they are valued
- Promotions / raises very scarce unless you are at the lowest or highest levels
- Continual reorganizations - chasing changes in the market
- Continual territory changes for sales teams
- Revenue has not increased in years - profit is obtained and EPS is increased by cutting costs and buying back stock 
- Costs are cut via selling off parts of the business, constant layoffs (called RAs for Resource Action) and outsourcing jobs to growth market areas
- CEO and SVP team given raises, bonuses, & stock options even though they failed to achieve all stated objectives

Pros: Home office Remote work allowed, decent 401k program, with the right manager advancement is possible
Cons:
1. Required to work from home office, but must pay for all equipment and supplies myself, no reimbursement
2. Lack of Raises - have not had a pay raise in 6 years
3. PBC rating system the pits you against your team mates for the quota allowance of top ratings. (last year avg 68 hrs per wk, brought in $450k of add-on business (I am not a sales person) and received praising letters from all customers, I was rated a 2 because there was only 1 2+ available
4. I have worked for 18 years and every year I see more of our very knowledgeable, top performers, in my opinion, either leave or get a Resource Action (layed off) due to "cost savings" measures

Pros:
- Because of its sheer size the company has a very large number of above average or brilliant people. 
- Extremely broad portfolio of technologies.
- Some truly great products.
- Good compensation and benefits.
Cons:
- Because of its sheer size the company has a very large number of below average people.
- Lacks a cohesive, consistent vision for the future.
- The reaction to adversity is to increase the level of micromanagement.
- Lots of exceptional people have left. More are trying to.

Pros: You can work from home. Get up at 6 am and shut down the laptop after 6 pm. You will have some flexible hours during the day.
Cons: There is no raise. No bonus except for the top 1% contributor. The bonus amount is in the embarrassing scale. The average base salary is consistently below the local market. This is their business model. Believe it or not, they are proud of it. The competent workers left for the fair market value. A lot of employees who are still with the company are either too old to change, or reduce the working hours voluntarily to match the pay, or just too out-dated technically to compete in the market to find another job. This is the reality in US. In Indian, the turn-over rate is very high since they give minimum pay for the new graduates. Within 2-3 years, they left for other companies for 100% increase in the salary. No wonder this titanic ship is sinking. Do not jump on it unless you are fresh out of college."

Pros: Good benefits.  Outstanding professionals in the company.  It used to be an outstanding company that valued their employees.
Cons: Managers are looking out for themselves and not employees.   Product strategy changes? You may be out of a job.  They may give you a low rating (first one in your long career) to force you out.  Same review cycle, I received positive feedback from VP.   Manager bullied employees so they would leave.  Blocked from going to HR to report behavior.  Manager made decision on which projects each employee received.  High billable projects taken away and replaced with low billing/no billable projects, which hurt billable expectations in performance review.   Suggestions to improve outcomes were ignored.  An "emperor without clothes" syndrome.  High turnover in dept. as a result and by design.

Pros: You will have the opportunity to work with some very smart people that want to make a solid contribution. The professional non-management class does the best they can day in and day out (despite a ridiculous amount of administrative red tape)
Cons: Every year IBM takes something away in terms of benefits, work life balance, financial incentives, basic common courtesy, respect for employees, and basic integrity. In addition to traveling (10-20 hrs) and billing 44 hours per week to clients, the latest trend is that you must spend many more hours on IBM's internal social media, more hours on training, mentoring, administrative work, and IBM internal conference calls. An 80 hour work week, week after week,  month after month, year after year is physically and mentally difficult to sustain --- and have any kind of fulfilling family life.

Pros: Amazing people that I call friends. Flexibility to work from home (for the past three years, that ends in 2017 for most biz units).  Great training programs.  You can get in the door with the IBM name.
Cons: Morale is at an all time low.  The constant, every 6 month change to account coverage and strategy makes success very difficult.  The lay offs, also known as "skills re-balancing" or Resource Actions have taken a toll.  Often very good people have been let go because they have been in the wrong organization at the wrong time.

Pros: Last year I was selected to participate in the Corporate Service Corp, modeled after the Peace Corp, to provide a month of pro bono consulting in a developing country in an area I knew very little about. It was the most amazing experience. IBM did a tremendous job in preparing me, and making sure that I and the other IBMers on this assignment were well taken care of, well prepared for this assignment, while ensuring that we immersed in the local culture to the maximum. My manager, co workers, clients were so supportive of my taking one month off work to go make a difference in another part of the world, solving a key real world problem. I learnt skills that I would never have an opportunity to learn otherwise. Opportunities such as these and my current role, keep me at IBM. The learnings these roles provide, the global reach is unparalleled.
Cons: Not a leading driver for compensation, but follows the market

Pros:
Benefits were good.
Work in some areas was interesting.
Cons:
Leadership is only interested in their career, moving quickly before the glass breaks.
I spend much of my management career trying to convince employees that taking away benefits was a good thing for them.
No executive is held accountable, only lower level management and employees - just look at who getting laid off and how many VPs a small organization has.
They have no clue on how to grow revenue.

Pros: Generally speaking IBM offers an interesting, challenging and expansive work environment with good career opportunities. If you deliver your quality work on time and are a good team player, then you'll get rewarded. There's equal opportunity.  There's lots of chances to further your knowledge through a vast offering of education opportunities. IBM rewards people who take charge and shows interest in the business.
Cons: Mediocre salaries and declining benefits.  Poor long term employment stability prospects. Generally old and uninspiring work environments. Mediocre cafeterias. Work weeks of 40 hours is not so. It's easily 50+ hours in any of the full time development jobs. People are frequently, though politely, asked to do whatever's needed to get the job done.

Pros: If you like eating fast food or cheap chain restaurants, then nothing to worry.  The per diem at New York city is about 55 dollars.   You can keep the money if you haven't spend it all.  Nice for those who don't eat too much or don't look for quality food.
Cons: You will ALWAYS fly economy unless you get an upgrade due to your airline status.  IBM do not pay for business even if your flight is 20+ hours.  This is a general rule regardless of your position.   Only the CEO flies on business.  Plain and simple.

Pros: Up to 20 weeks paid maternity leave and 12 weeks paid paternity leave is amazing. Competitive salary, flexible work environment, one of the few industry research labs out there. Supportive of publishing and attending conferences. Lots of room for growth if you take the initiative.
Cons: Paid parental leave does not apply to post-docs, even though they are otherwise treated as full-time employees and this is not well-advertised. I found out when I was pregnant with my second child. A lot of bureaucracy when it comes to purchasing and safety. It is a major hindrance on innovation in research. A lot of tolerance for dead weight.

Pros: As an employee, you have vast resource of learning tools at your disposal. If there is a certification you want to work on, there are learning avenues for you to achieve it. IBM also has some very powerful applications - WATSON, Red Hat, cloud - that competitors cannot beat.
Cons:
I have been with IBM for 5+ years now. In this time I have not received a single raise despite the fact that the contract I worked on meet or exceed our annual numbers. The issue is that raises & bonuses are tied to the WHOLE division you work in. Sine the division as a whole did not make the annual numbers, no raises or bonuses. 
Also, health insurance is very expensive if you want to cover your family. Instead of offering a family play, IBM makes you pay for each person covered. Pushes the cost of selecting the better plans out of reach.

Pros: Job flexibility, ability to work at home, set my own hours.  Management cares about the work being done, not the when and where.  We enjoy a lot of flexibility, which really helps with work life balance.  It is okay to spend time during the day doing something at the kid's school as long as the work is made up in the evenings or weekends.
Cons: Too large, hard to make a difference, hard to change things.  The structure and size is at times overwhelming...it can take days to find the right contact for a simple question, and one hand rarely know what the other is doing, leading to a lot of duplication of effort, and conflict.

Pros: Systems and Technology group has some of the best and the brightest working on leading edge technologies.  It is a pleasure to work with these people and keep up on the bleeding edge of what is going on in the computer industry.  I have certainly learned a lot in my time in STG, and continue to learn on a daily basis.
Cons: producing more powerful computers means that you sell less to replace existing ones.  Unfortunately, the cost of the new machines generally isn't 2x the cost of the replacements - hence lowering revenue.  In order to meet corporate expectations, cutting costs by reducing headcount has an impact on what can be developed and what can be sold.  It becomes a vicious cycle, low sales due to diminished products, which in turn leads to lower head counts.

Pros: Great place to start a career right out of college.  Diverse projects provide an opportunity to observe how business is done in different industries.  You also get to travel and see the country (and possibly the world).  People who work here are great, they're some of the smartest people I've worked with.
Cons:
Travel schedule can be exhausting. You are a profit center, so focus on maintaining billable status is paramount, and management assures you don't forget it!

The biggest negative I see about IBM now is, that the management is moving large amount of work off-shore to lower cost locales, this is great when the objective is to reduce cost, but quality is compromised. In my opinion, IBM will do well for the near future, but once the quality issue catch up.. watch out.

Pros: Opportunity abound for those who want it. Conservative workplace, highly virtual where teams are global almost every meeting, extremely high matrixed organization provides challenges for those who want to navigate the system. The workplace is reflective of any megacap company except IBM sets the standard for those companies in business process, use of technology for employees, and work/life balance. Don't get me wrong, get ready to work 50 hours normal week and up to 70 a few weeks in the year when busy. But the work is terribly rewarding. It's great to be an IBMer.
Cons: Large, really large company. Systems galore. Meetings are on the phone almost all the time except when meeting with clients or being assigned to client sites. When you have 420,000 employees, you need that. But, if you don't like having a serial number and being part of the machinery, you may want to rethink IBM.

Pros: IBM on resume and experience
Cons:
Salary Salary Salary is a joke 20K below national averages for people with no experience
Ability to transfer within IBM even after transitioning to regular status you have to wait another year
No OT anymore to make up for the horrible salary anymore by transitioning us to regular status
Inconsistent attendance policy as to who has to adhere to the three days work from Lansing and who can work from home whenever they wish even though they live in Lansing.
Being put on projects that are not part of our skill set just to make the center hit it's utilization numbers and required to work OT when we are not paid for it to help the center hit utilization targets
very few new benefits for being made a regular employee which the management tried to use to soften the salary situation

Pros: IBM provides employment flexibility, independence and a sharing of knowledge with professional co-workers.  As an Enterprise Architect and Trusted Advisor, I was able to provide strategic influence over customer technologies and business operations.  It was a great opportunity to help many different organizations.
Cons: I had little influence on IBM's direction and management seemed to have been trying to figure out what the next leadership direction might be, at least regarding US employment.  Employee concerns over employment may be summed up in a remark I heard...  There are 2 types of IBM'ers, those that were laid off, and those that fear they will soon be laid off.

Pros: IBM is a very empowering company even down to the Sales rep level.  They allow you a lot of freedom and opportunity for career advancement and training for a big company.  There are an incredible amount of very smart collaborative professionals.
Cons: IBM is a political company that is very complicated internally and is overly thick in management layers.  I have been at the company for several years and many inept employees seem to avoid layoffs and continue to drag the quality of the company down.

Pros: 401K and health care benefits are a plus, secure job with opportunities to move up, the managers are friendly and supportive; they will often assist in working around your schedule.
Cons: More often than not, you will never meet those higher in position than your current manager, making the company seem a bit faceless. Entire divisions can be laid off due to this due to workers just being another cog in the wheel  in the grand scheme of things. If you do not push for higher positions, you will be left behind. Workers are not compensated properly for managing work, constant travel and administrative duties off-hours.

Pros:
* Exciting to be part of 105 old company that is once again transforming to "Be Essential" to our clients and delivering new innovations (e.g. Watson, Blockchain) to the market.  Our challenges remaining at the top of a fast-paced industry ensure there are multiple opportunities to contribute and grow. 
* IBM invests heavily in professional development 
* IBM is a 'top 5' management company (as recognized by the Drucker Institute) and is a place for leaders 
* IBM has some of the best talent I have worked with in my 20+ year career 
* IBM's breadth and global reach provide unique career opportunities across Consulting, Offering Management, internal Operations- whatever passion you want to pursue
* IBM has a commitment to service and giving back to its communities in a meaningful way
* IBM values diversity 
* One of the best 401(k) programs and good benefits package
Cons: * Like any organization of IBM's scope and size, you will run into fiefdoms and/or people that are slower to change

Pros: Large IT company with many resources and business lines.
Cons: IBM is in CONSTANT flux trying to adapt to a world where the need/demand for large Mainframes has dwindled tremendously.  IBM has been forced to cut down product lines, and unfortunately, has let go huge numbers of US workers with great experience and knowledge, for much cheaper but less experienced workers from India, China, Russia, Philippines, South America, etc.  The net result is that I was terrified to sell IT Technical Services since I knew that the quality of services provided was mediocre at best, yet I was charging customers the highest prices just because they were from IBM.

Pros:
Flexible environment for working parents, work from home, etc
Salary levels above average in the industry for similar roles
Entrepreneurial - room to try and execute your ideas
Local level managers and leaders very supportive, positive
Loyal customer base and fun innovative solutions
Very smart people, helpful teams, overall want to see each other succeed
Really care about customers' outcomes
Great opportunities for learning and skill building
Cons:
Huge percent of time each week preparing updates and reports for your management to pass on to their management
Bare bones product management resources to support customers and product enhancements
New CEO brought in his politics, polarizing if you don't agree
Promotion process unfair and ambiguous, driving great resources out
Poor vaccination policy handling (10 week exemption turnaround time, intrusive interviewing , limited 90 day approval, punitive communications)

Pros: IBM is a large company with many opportunities to have and hold many different positions through a long career. Opportunities from manufacturing to sales and everything in between exist. Services, technical, admin, staff, teaching, HR, sales, graphic design, TV and Video production, food service, etc. There are few companies where you can have this kind of exposure to many different positions. Large companies offer more stability, excellent benefits, and a diverse work environment.
Cons: It's a big company. It's easy to get lost. Salary growth can be stagnant. Without establishing a network at the company, you will get lost. Many IBM workers are mobile workers and a sense of community can be lost if you aren't active in establishing it for yourself. This isn't the IBM of 25 years ago where Respect for the Individual was paramount and employee loyalty fueled its success. Lifelong employment at IBM is no longer guaranteed no matter how hard you work.

Pros: IBM provides a diverse set of opportunities across a wide spectrum of information technology, with considerable resources available when properly aligned.  There is the ability to work on significant projects and have a global impact.  The company has a long history and many creative and experienced professionals.
Cons: After being wined and dined touring China and Russia, CEO Palmisano came back to US to talk about how "messy" Western democracies are and immediately began shifting jobs overseas at increasing rates including selling PC company to Lenovo.  There is a large bureaucracy with lots of internal fiefdoms.  Company has gone from respecting employees and striving for excellence to shooting for the middle ground across compensation and benefits.  Work can be all-consuming and the wrong immediate management can make life miserable.

Pros: I can telecommute, that's the only reason I am staying
Cons: Completely lost with objectives, no clarity, a lot of noise

Pros:
great benefits - health care, 401K
good starting salary, hard to get laid off unless there is a recession or the company is doing poorly.
Cons:
senior management does not care about your career.  They only care if you are billable.
Promotions are hard to comeby.  If you don't get the right project and role, you have no chance of moving up.  Raises are only 2-3% per year unless they determine you're being underpaid compared to the market.  When I left IBM, I was getting paid as much as a new college hire even though I had 2+ years under my belt.

Performance ratings based too much upon utilization.  It's not our fault if you can't find a project for us.

Annual Bonuses are lousy, barely 2%

Pros: My resume looks better now, with four years experience at IBM. It helped me get my current job. I was actually introduced to the executive vice president of marketing by my manager with the words... She comes to us from IBM. He seemed impressed.
Cons: There are way too many layers of management at IBM, and they are too far removed geographically from where the vast number of employees are located. I worked in the largest single location where IBM employees are situated... at its heyday, there were upwards of 15,000 employees working there. But many managers aren't located there. My first line of management was several states and at least 1000 miles away. And he managed people in several states. IBM wouldn't even let him travel to meet his people in person.

Pros: The people are great - some of the best people in the industry in terms of work ethic, can-do attitude, helpfulness and competency.  The work environment is pretty good -- cubes, decent equipment, comfortable, on-site cafeteria with decent food.  Vacation: I've worked with IBM for 25 years and get 5 weeks paid vacation, plus sick leave.
Cons: The corporate focus is to make money for the shareholders and executives.  Employees are simply expendable resources, and are squeezed to do way too much with way too little.  If you're not a top performer, your life can be miserable until you quit or are forced out.

Pros:
Can work on every technology and move about
Still has very sharp Distinguished engineers
Cons:
-death by a thousand cuts. Pension got replaced by higher 401k which is now just matched once a year in lump sum
-every group pads sizings 2x. Management pads another 2x. Nothing ships even if you hit all your dates because test team needs 6-9 months to test
-bonus and raise has 0 correlation with what actual profits or what CEO says to shareholders about record profits in annual letter. In last 12 years have never seen a bonus higher than 6-8% even with 1 rating (top3-4% of performers)
-Orwellian double speak about everything. 
-even the restrooms are falling apart now. 
-supposed to be open door policy. But line managers hate it if you write to senior execs without going through them
- even a laptop refresh can take 5 years

Pros: Big company with lots of resources, people, locations, and opportunities.   Image has been that it is the best of breed.
Cons: Very senior management more interested in driving stock price up for their own personal gain than growing a company which the staff and clients will admire.   Many of their worldwide studies are based on bogus data that they create to convince the world they are the best and on top of the trends.  If you compare it to others studies of the same companies, leaders, industries, etc. it does not match or even come close.

Pros: Great talented and friendly people!  Lots of flexibility in organizing one's work, choosing projects, deciding how much  one want to get involved, etc... .  Lots of resource at your disposal!  Within IBM I always felt very protected and respected.  Great benefits.
Cons: Frequent layoffs lead to constant  rumors true or false,  which lead to a state of fear.  Employees tend to forget what they have; instead focus on what they could lose and often become paralyzed.

Pros:
Great benefits (health, dental, special needs support, etc.)
Great co-workers (for the most part - - there have been a few bad apples)
Flexible work schedule (project dependent)
Cons:
A lot of overhead administrivia (both weekly and yearly)
Disappointing bonus structure
Yearly merit increases are a joke
Management/organizational structure fluctuates too frequently

Pros: From a technical point of view, your learning opportunities are unbounded.  Through training and job experience, even an "off" day can provide a chance to learn.  With solutions focus, working on one product area will almost certainly lead to learning about some other area.  People are great!  People are helpful and have a willingness to mentor, or be mentored.
Cons: With mobile offices, you may be separated physically from a team, so be ready to use tools to feel connected.  Still a huge bureaucracy, so getting through or following processes can be frustrating.  The elephant is still learning how to dance.  No longer is being good at your job a guarantee you will be able to keep that job.

Pros: ability to work from home or pretty much anywhere, you can find a subject matter expert on anything, many different kinds of technologies - most of the people are really great to work with and very dedicated - great place to work for a few years for your resume
Cons: there was no such thing as work life balance and morale was low in the area I worked  - the salary plan was poor even for good performers if you were in an area that does not receive commissions - variable pay has been drastically reduced for years - I agree with other reviewers that there is too much middle management

Pros: Great job to gain valuable experience and the agile principles that corporate has implemented show promise for better management in the future. Also, great place for young professionals as there are many recent college graduates at the office. One of the best work-life balances I've seen for an entry level position as there are ample opportunities to work from home/remotely and paid time off is good for entry level.
Cons: High turnover for employees (leaving for better opportunities, not fired) and even small changes can take months to become implemented. Even in Rochester, cost of living is essentially the same as MSP but employees are not compensated as such. Not the only option but the best option to make a salary that is comparable to an FA in the MSP area is to move to New York where cost of living is much higher as well.

Pros: Flexible work hours, work from home.
Cons: Pays below market, Management doesn't listen to people actually doing the job.

Pros: There are no longer any 'Pros' to working at IBM. The company continues to loose customers and market share, the endless cycle of budget cuts, layoffs and increased expectations as eroded the last shreds of decency from the company. People are looking to either get out or protect themselves from the next layoff and seasoned professionals are being let go and replaced with young inexperienced people at 1/2 the salary.
Cons: To many to list. The pressure is unrelenting, no one in marketing does any actual marketing they simply take numbers and information, drop them into powerpoint decks or incredibly myopic 'funnel charts' and 'spin the numbers'. Good, decent, seasoned professionals that have spend years trying to right the ship are being let go and replaced by inexperienced college grads and yet management wants to know why the numbers are off, why the pipeline isn't healthier. Marketing is told to sell and promote solutions that do not actually exist and if they do, don't work. The company is all about 'cloud solutions' but the cloud solutions suffer from poor architecture and constant outages.

Pros: The amount of business acumen across industries, languages and cultures is invigorating. There is no problem that cannot be solved - or so it seems. According to IBM's founder's view that "...every problem mankind is confronted with, can be solved, if people only THINK..." is embodied in how this large organism works every day. You get to contribute to solving problems like cancer, water shortages, production impasses, irrigation systems and many more with the solutions you help build. It is very rewarding to play a small - and sometimes not so small - part in solving bib problems.
Cons: It is a big company and not for the faint-of-heart. You need to show persistence, conviction - and, yes, success - to get others to see the world your way. If you are looking for instant gratification, this one is not for you. Chances are, that the people around you are way smarter than you.

Pros: The pay is good but they will use you to move jobs off-shore or to lower paying vendor.
Cons: Some areas lack management direction.  They really care about bottom line more than valuing the employee unless you have something to really give them in their main business goals.  If you support normal, boring, day-to-day operations you are always targeted for a lay-off or training lower skilled, cheaper labor off shore or a lower paying vendor they work with.

Pros:
Rate of starting base and commission is very good, especially for younger people starting out. IBM invests 6 months of sales training into all new sales employees, which is invaluable. There is definitely a culture of learning. You can do a multitude of different roles in the company and it is fairly easy to change roles. The company changes and restructures a lot which can be good or bad. You can be located in any major city in the world and it is fairly easy to switch location. 
Typical IBM sales roles require at least 50% travel, which can be good if you like to travel.
Cons: The company is extremely large, bureaucratic, and confusing to navigate. It is the epitome of a vertical company, which causes it to be slower than flatter companies. The company is hard to navigate if you’re looking to move up because the progression path from sales roles is not always clear.

Pros:
IBM is helping the world manage change into the digitization tsunami. I love speaking with so many companies that need our solutions and expertise in order to be able to thrive into this new era of global technology and integration of all value chains. 
IBM is an amazing company for me. But you have to be innovative, relentless in your pursuit of growing at your craft. highly collaborative, and flexible.
Cons:
IBM takes a tremendous amount of life to be successful at. And IBM is full of Type A personalities. 
The bureaucratic process is insane, but if you network well and learn to manage the matrix. You will do well. 
If you are not self-motivated, don't come to IBM ; you won't survive.

Pros:
IBM allows you as many paths as you can imagine. You can start technical, transition to management, transition back, take options as they fit your needs and career goals. IBM will give you as many challenges as you can handle - and reward your successes. 
IBM is fiercely diverse. Different viewpoints are at every desk and this multi-party collaboration gives the company a strength and a staying power rarely found. You WILL find every political stripe, every community, every kind of person - but almost always friendly, professional, welcoming.
IBM is stable - in a tumultuous industry with much churn, you can find a home here.
Cons: IBM is definitely a large company. You truly do own your career path, which means that if you end up in a situation where you need a change, you do need to speak up and take action. Once you do that, every manager and leadership team I've worked with has been open - focused on your happiness and productivity.

Pros:
IBM has long ago lost the concept of commitment  being bi-directional. It expects more commitment from workers than it gives in return. That said, I think it is better than most companies. IBM does not shy away from dumping valuable employees but it probably does not pick that course as fast as many companies.

I can only speak for one small part of the software side but I think IBM does try to encourage people to try new things and give them some time to come up to speed.
Cons: A very secretive place regarding job actions.  People simply vanish and when someone does vanish the people who work nearby seldom ask questions.

Pros: Great technology and leading edge stuff in the hardware area.  Working with IBM Research can give you a good feeling about how you fit within the company.
Cons: Promotions/raises few and far between.  Most advances seem to be saved for acquisitions in order not to loose key members of the new company.  Internal promotions are almost non-existent, and even though the company is making record revenues/profits, very little of that is being seen at the grunt level.  Hurts morale to see the company making massive profits and to be told either a) cut backs need to occur, or b) no raises again this year.

Pros:
- Never ending training available as long as you seek it. 
- No matter what, IBM has a great reputation with large companies and some SMB. 
- Great benefit package (medical, vacation, personal days, flexibility)
Cons:
- Company is huge therefore the visibility of your business unit is limited to the ivory tower in NY. 
- If you are talented and make your numbers, your manager will most likely not let you move however if you do not perform the same scenario applies. It's very hard to move. 
- IBM lacks a CRM software and the entire business runs on an excel sheet. 
- The administrative tasks take up too much of your time. 
- Highly layered management. Sometimes makes you wonder what certain roles are for.

Pros: Brand and company are great to have on your resume, everyone knows big blue.
Cons:
Innovation in the company is less and less the focus is shifting more and more to cater to wall street.  The days of ibm being a company of thinkers and great innovators is long gone.
For employees especially American based, every day is lived in fear that today will be your last.
Raises and bonuses even for top performers are below standards if even given at all.  Negotiate up front only newer employees from outside have remotely competitive base salaries, once in be prepared to live with that salary regardless of duties position or band prerequisites.  If cost of living and above average performance combined  is worth 1 or 2% a year then this is the place for you.

Pros: It may look good in your resume.
Cons: Total disregard for quality.  Exclusive focus on reducing costs.  Proposals to clients get rejected because they don't include enough people from India.  Possibilities for career advancement are few as IBM is focused on reducing costs by shipping jobs abroad.  The only thing IBM has increased in the US are levels of management.

Pros:
Smart engineers but the best don;t stay more than 5 years or so.
Salary is fairly compettive over past 10 or so years.
Cons:
US jobs are moving offshore faster and faster.
2013 there is a lot of confusion to implement new CEO mandates.
Management plainly does not care about the people or engineering anymore, just the bottomline.
I predict in 5 years there will be a bunch of executives in US watching a few thousand Asian workers produce 90% of their software...seriously that is the trend.

Pros: Opportunities for advancement.  Benefits are good.  Large educational opportunities.
Cons: I found it hard to avoid cut throat competitive culture within the work force. I think there'd have been a larger amount of work, innovation and imaginative solutions offered by employees had they not been engaged in clamoring to the few top ratings offered.  Teams are much more productive when members aren't competing with one another to achieve the same goal.

Pros: Lots of internal learning.  You can find experts in any relevant field, most of which are happy to talk to you.  Partnership with Apple is huge, brings a lot of publicity.
Cons: Culture.  Too concerned with cost cutting and the bottom line.  Do not treat employees very well, minimal perks.  In consulting, they staff you where they need you, not based on interests.  You can get stuck on a project in one role for years without much growth.  They give their entry level consultants work that could be done by interns.

Pros:
potentially the best wage you can find in VT with decent hours
good benefits coverage
Cons:
No job security
Dead slow conversion rates
Poorly informed management
Lack of Ejection for weak employees
Draining moral
High school attitudes and environments
lots of lazy people on shift making your job harder and the days longer
No chance for personal improvement for anyone not inside an office *think 40 is a joke*
No Employee investment outside of permanent staff
3 year sentence with no job security or commitment
can be let go with no reason
emotionally draining 
made to feel like your fighting a wall to get converted
made to feel like a second class citizen due to your LTS status 
Employers work scheduled makes finding work impossible
Forced to change shift on conversion regardless of outside life
YOUR LIFE MUST MEET THE NEEDS OF THE EMPLOYER!
If you dont change shifts you never get converted this means COMPULSORY NIGHTS

Pros: Definitely gives many opportunities to develop personal, networking and sales skills. You will be able to gain lasting friendships, which will carry over into your personal life and give birth to other numerous opportunities. Also training is great i.e. "Global Sales School" and "Top Gun".
Cons: Working remote with such a huge company does vastly limit the ability to develop strong networks throughout the company.  As a CTP you will find it hard to work with reps depending on the product/offering you sale, this is because reps go where the money is. Be prepared to carry a heavier work load to make up for the shift. In addition management often looses sit of what the sales teams need to be successful and never really push for change.

Pros: Given the size and breadth of the company, there are many opportunities for career growth. Generally well-respected company at least gets you a foot in the door with clients. Constantly re-inventing itself to stay relevant and ahead of the curve. Flexible work options (e.g., work from home) although this is changing and shifting to greater emphasis on physically being in the same office with your team.
Cons: Constantly re-inventing itself means frequent churn, in some area more than others. Quick to cut funding (marketing, projects, etc.) in order to make quarterly targets. Along the same lines, there are many jobs pushed offshore which can cause unease -- and goes against the push to have teams co-located.

Pros:
Company Reputation
Excellent medical benefits
Moving between divisions used to be easy (right now it is hard because IBM is laying people off (Called Resource Action (RA) in IBM parlance)
Cons:
Pay raises and promotions are slower than others
Work from home, which had been one of the mainstays, is being cancelled
Very tightly defined roles -- you are pre-sales only, and penalized for giving after sales support. This hurts both your and the company's reputation
Tech team is under the thumb of sales, so it can't produce on its own. If you have a bad seller (e.g., can't close, won't hunt), you will be penalized and held accountable for their performance
In my last group, management was always hunting for someone to throw under the bus if a deal didn't close. Twice, I was asked to say who was responsible for the loss of sale. At other companies I have worked, it was viewed as a team effort and we trained tech people to improve.

Pros: During one of the most exciting times of the intersection between business and technology in history, IBM is leading the way to reinvent itself and create an environment of partnerships and countless opportunities. IBM gives a platform for employees to build a customer-centric P&L to drive growth for product and service lines and the company while delivering for customers.
Cons: Like any large enterprise, the larger the program responsibilities the bigger are the challenges. Although opportunities are in front of us, the internal silo's get in the way of the obvious. Employees who embraces challenges and seek opportunities through focus and resilience to build internal and external partnerhips, will thrive. Those who are a mere employees hoping to be guided, might not. You can look at it as a pro or con, your choice.

Pros:
· Classic tech company amenities: free coffee, snacks, drinks.
· The majority of coworkers are nice and friendly. The camaraderie was the highlight of my experience.
· Huge bell curve. Top engineers there are brilliant, but the worst ones are unmotivated and coasting. Frankly, the average engineer is nothing to sneeze at.
· If you want to coast, a good place to do it. 
· There are opportunities to work hard and make an impact.
Cons:
· Pay is not competitive for the location. Lowball.
