· Bad apples. While they exist in every workplace, their existence speaks to the company's culture and behavioral hiring bar. HR is unhelpful and won't protect one from harassers. 
· Management lacks structure with task assignments and does not keep promises. Politics get in the way of good work. 
· Lack of formal structure because the place is small. There's no formal way to keep track of tasks.
· Mediocre engineering standards. Not much of a formal code review process and poor code quality.

Pros:
Benefits 4 out 5
Leadership good at high level
Cheap insurance
Welcoming environment
Cons:
Poor lower leadership
Poor availability for tool to manage team
Lack of budget to innovate effectively

Pros: IBM has impressed me with their commitment to diversity.  The company has so many interesting projects in development and combine viewpoints from international employees as well as those within the US.  The resources available on site are quite sufficient for research and personal development and the location of the site is ideal for anyone interested in live music, making for a good work/life balance opportunity.
Cons: Apparently there are some divisions that do work longer hours, but I have not experienced this personally.  I find that those who work longer weeks are a bit too committed to their work.  I have found that the managers are quite flexible when it comes to their employees' schedules.

Pros: IBM is a great place to work, if you are a minority or a woman.  If you're a woman and show the slightest spark of competence, you will fly past your male counterparts, whether or not you deserve it.  Because of this, there are so many horrendous first and second level managers, as well as Senior and STSM level technical leaders.
Cons: The only way to get into the top ranks is to be the toady of a mid-level manager.  If you are really unfortunate, you will work for an EO candidate who will surely take credit for your accomplishments.  If you are really lucky, you'll work for one of the dwindling number of career managers (30+ years with the company) who will be straight with you.

Pros: IBM Research has a lot of smart people, working on a variety of projects. Its easy to find a project thats deep and interesting enough fairly quickly. Folks with non-trivial expertise in almost any technical area are not too hard to find. There is a strong focus on getting your research to make a financial impact - this can of course be a pro or a con depending on your POV. High level of independence to select approaches to selecting problems/projects and also in choosing approaches to solve them.
Cons: Although the project you're working on may be making a large impact (within and outside the organization), apart from a couple of your peers and your immediate manager nobody really cares or seems to notice your contributions. Its very very easy to just get lost here - this is similar to a complaint I had while in academia.

Pros: work at home, make your own hours for the most part, benefits are pretty decent but dwindling, first line management does support their employees, working with some of the most helpful and knowledgeable people in their fields
Cons: expense controls are very very restrictive, support staff cut so much that customer satisfaction is going down, programs for leadership advancement and funding to attend conferences have all disappeared, and the laptops are all aging and undersized, should be replaced every 2 years

Pros: Enjoy working with people who have a passion for the jobs they perform. Most IBMers are very knowledgeable in their areas of expertise and will help you wherever possible.
Cons: As in most companies, I believe we are working far longer hours then ever before. If you are an exempt employee, your hourly rate drops significantly due to the excessive nights and weekends worked. As much as you earn, when you look at an hourly rate, it's not always that impressive.

Pros: Great company to work for those that are interested in career development. There is a Lot to learn. Work flexibility home versus office is available upon request.  Having a Fitness center is the best.
Cons: IBM stands for " I'm by myself" very hard to get things done. Very complicated company to work for, lots of politics. If you know people within the company you will achieve great things while others don't. Managers only hire their friends to collect on referral bonus. Not keen on rewarding hard work, as they are slowly moving the inside group back to PSP (Pool system Payment) where no matter how well you do towards your goal your commission check still depends on how the organization does for the quarter. Management can still use their discretion to position you in the pool.

Pros: Plenty of opportunity to learn best practice in development, project management and service management.  Work with highly intelligent and dedicated teams.
Cons: Don't think that just because you are at one of the biggest IT companies in the world you will be working on cutting edge technology.  In the Services arm of the business, you work on old equipment with limited funding for investment.  You often create home grown solutions instead of using existing technology because they won't fund it.  Lots of political limitations here.  Horrible morale.  They do not concern themselves with the best interests of their employees or customers.

Pros:
- Cool technology differentiation (eg Watson / Cognitive). 
- Truly global with diverse culture. 
- Strong graduate development program. 
- Good career progression opportunities generally. 
- Women leaders are respected and do well.
- 'Soft' compensation benefits are solid and competitive.
Cons:
- Leaders have overlapping responsibilities across multiple functional dimensions. For new offerings and technologies, the number of partners involved in a client or deal becomes distracting (industry, geography, account, technology, sales, consulting, external partner, business unit, etc).
- Can be difficult to navigate for new hires. 
- Compliance is important, but some of the processes and approvals seem just too laborious and even redundant. Proposals often take too long to approve and get out the door.
- Risk averse culture in the ranks.

Pros: Not much to sell so you'll have free time to look for other work.
Cons:
Leadership is horrible.  Does not understand Healthcare and is very short sighted focus on revenue vs. what it takes to grow the business.  
Treats complex software sales like hardware deals.   
Territories and managers constantly in flux with unreasonable quota.
Layoffs every 2 to 3 months so no one feels safe, and if you don't hit your number for the first 6 months, you're a target for the rest of the year.  
Competing products that do the same thing and sales reps that compete / share the same territory with overlap in product set.
Products not selling and not updated since acquisitions.
No clear strategy for the future
Partnership at IBM = Buy something from IBM, not partner
Product strategy derived from what a customer will pay for, not from what the broader market needs.

Pros: People are very friendly; work/life balance is great in public sector (often capped hours on projects per contract)

IBM tries to 'train' any idiot to do any job. It's a good place for interns because those are the only people IBM wants to actually employ. Be an intern and if they give you a regular job, take it but for no more than 1 year.
Cons:
They typically do. They've dumbed down and check-boxed everything so pervasively that people who work the desk at the DMV have more autonomy. All you're ever ordered to do is paperwork and process. The job doesn't matter. 

But because pay is so low and they have a million reasons why you never get an increase, the reality of being a monkey is liberating.  Any job you do hear is do-able in about 90 days. But after that it's just the same 90 days over and over. The real downside is if you make the tiniest mistake in your process you will have 10 people chewing you out and complaining.

Pros: It's a job and a paycheck
Cons:
*This company has no idea what they want to do or be in this  would of technology.  Sr. Management wouldn't know innovation if it bit then in the butt.  They buy different companies and suck the life out of them, run thier customer base off and then layoff all the employee's. 

* The insurance is high we less coverage

* They don't pay a bonus unless you're in sales

* Yearly merit increases or 1 to 2%, even if you are a top performer... what a joke.

* They only paid their percentage of 401k incentives on December 31st. which means if you work for the company all year and get fired or leave before December 31st they won't contribute anything to your 401k for that year.

Pros: Medical benefits are great. The projects that I've worked on have been engaging and interesting for the most part. Usually it's contracting work for companies outside of IBM. I have heard of some people getting stuck on projects that are not quite as glamorous though.
Cons:
Before covid, it was mandatory to work in the office. This was frustrating because I was usually working with client teams in another state or country meaning I traveled all the way to the office to talk on the phone all day to talk to people that were nowhere near me.

The company is rather bureaucratic and there are a lot of hoops and seemingly unnecessary trainings that are required to move up the ranks.

The pay is pretty underwhelming given the average salary of the field. This was my first major job and I would say it's a great first job, but it feels like a stepping stone, not a destination.

Pros: Flexibility and work/life balance are the top things that keep me here.  I have been with the company 20+ years and have built up 4+ weeks vacation, which is also nice.  I took advantages of educational programs (offered in the past) and IBM paid for and helped me earn a degree.  The old IBM was very good to work for, the new IBM will not give you one morsel more than they think they need to.
Cons: The downsides are the insiduous, and it seems that the norm is take aways and doubletalk.  Basically promotions and meaningful raises, at least at the worker bee level, are as rare and far between.  They always have a "believeable" reason why raises, bonuses and premiums are so low, yet executives continue to make sure things are structured in a way that does not effect them.

Pros:
There are a lot of positives about working in IBM.  

IBM is global and growing, investing in high margin businesses with huge potential to grow revenue profitably.  Relentless focus on cost-cutting and off-shoring jobs, while delivering savings, is demotivating for employees and represents the single-minded focus the company has on shareholders and investors, not employees.  That balance needs to change or the company won't meet its revenue and profit targets because employees will start walking or running out the door.
Cons:
Inability to reduce cost structures in EMEA due to European labor laws
Lack of real recognition and compensation for top performers
Relentless focus on cost cutting and too much focus on shareholders and investors, not employees

Pros:
Some good policies of old days are still existing, like relocation benefits but they won't last long
Flexible work timings 
Presence in major cities of world
Cons:
Moving away from Employee caring company to Employee sucking company. 
Believe me IBM US is still a great place to be in. The subsidiary companies like IBM India, rather cost center like IBM India is a glorified body shopping shop for employees they ship from India. After few years you will realize what damage they did to your career.
Compensation - That remains pathetic in India and US ( IBM India only)
Health Benefits - They have increased the insurance contribution from employee to 100% in US and in India where insurance premium is to be paid by employer as per law, they have managed to reduce the coverage to 3 lakh (family) which in today's India is nothing.

Pros: Many of the old IBM ways still exist, such as lots of great 1st line managers who used to get lots of training in how to be a great manager, lots of team spirit and willingness to be helpful, and some optimism still remains.
Cons: This is no longer a fun place to work.  Middle and Senior management think it's all about them  and their careers and not the products.  Also, there are not enough people left to produce good products any longer.  Quality is severely suffering.  Also, everyone works from home, so it's like everyone has checked out, just collecting pay checks.

Pros:
-Good resume and experience builder
-Stability in career, work from home options
Cons:
-Little to no annual raises
-Disingenuity regarding advancement through career based on locations
-"Drinking water from a firehose", poor training and enablement
-Cumbersome and error-prone business intelligence/financial infrastructure
-No discernible company culture (team building events, Happy Hours, company clubs
-Salary in Westchester, NY (Finance HQ) not commensurate with cost of living
-Expectation to often work from home, often late with little/no bonus compensation
-No defined career path

Pros: Amazingly smart people! If you have a chance to work with IBM Research - take it ! Fantastic organization. IBM'ers are wicked smart and very professional.  IBM really gets behind clients if they are hired. Great job experience for Band 7, 8 and 9's ( younger less experienced resources) but plan an exit strategy.
Cons: 1. IBM is very hard to do business with as far as clients are concerned ( from a contracting perspective as they expect everyone to bend to their Ts&Cs, 2). Sales teams are cutthroat and will run you over for deal credit - make sure if you get involved in a "deal" that you have in writing what our "cut" is up front  - sometimes even that won't matter and 3) make your sales target EVERY YEAR or you will be fired immediately. No "performance improvement  plan" - just good bye and so long.

Pros: Fellow account managers and support teams were great.  The Sales Engineers are people you want to know due to their knowledge and understanding of the software- in and out.  The perks were great and departments were run well until...IBM.
Cons: Then IBM takes over.  Layoffs, perks taken away, red tape, everything that comes with a Jabba the Hut like IBM.  People became numbers and the metrics took over actual selling and training.  When new upper management was brought in, those managers brought more incompetent mid level managers that lack any leadership qualities and experience in the software field.  No offers for help or advice for employees to grow.  SPSS account managers that had been there for 8+ years were passed over for senior positions so that newly hired upper and middle management can hire friends from old jobs.

Pros: Numerous career paths from which to choose. Excellent opportunities for career growth or even a career change and still remain with the company. They have very diverse workforce. They also believe in equal pay for equal work, regardless of race, sex, religion or sexual orientation.
Cons:
Bureaucracy! Too many layers of management. This tends to create a bubble up effect, when an issue arises at the staff level, by time  the executives are engage they are told everything is under control. Meanwhile the fire rages out of control.  Because of this, most executives seem out of touch with the teams on the front lines. The executives always tend to get low ratings on the employee surveys. 

Also, work / life balance doesn't really exist. Most people that want to advance in their career are working 65+ hours per week.

Pros: Originally? training, education, paid certification, bonuses, profit sharing, effective team meetings, clear communication through the management chains.
Cons: Now? absolutely none of the above. Everyone is burned out, hiring freezes, no education budgets, no certification budgets, minimal growth profit sharing, no band promotions, cross team collaboration is dismal, etc.

Pros: Many opportunities to gain experience in a variety of roles worldwide.   One of the best training programs in the industry.   Some of the most incredible technical professionals that I've ever worked with.
Cons:
Executive management is entrenched and focused on financial gimmicks to improve/support the bottom line, while bleeding and flogging of the senior management, mid-management and employee ranks who, as a result, have lost the needed morale to grow revenues.  

While top contributors are seeing measly raises and bonuses, many in the employee ranks are worried about getting laid off prior to Dec 15 losing their entire 401k match for the year.  Standout employees are leaving in droves, rapidly shifting the employee mix to those that are just shy of retirement and others that are complacent with little to no drive to innovate.

Pros: I can work from home AND they give me a Lenovo(R) laptop to use for completing my work
Cons: Technology, processes, administrative overhead, large corporate politics, lack of quality reimbursement of actual business expenses.

Pros:
Most of the people I met at IBM were nice for the most part.
I was able to work from home %100 of the time, which was great.
Cons:
IBM is in continuous layoff mode. And, they will never stop. IBM has no loyalty to their employees, nor to any of their clients. I was on a profitable account, and they still laid off a ton of people, leaving the client with no one to fulfill their needs.
IBM expects you to work most weekends or "volunteer" but you can't claim vacation, sick time, nor holiday on the weekend.
Way too much paperwork and old processes that take a lot of time away from actual work. I moved from the previous contract company on the same account. As soon as we went from CSC to IBM, our paperwork increased 10 times.

Pros: IBM helped me grow into a competent engineer. I worked with a great team and had fun on the projects I worked on. My work/life balance was good and I felt like my manager respected me (not my execs).
Cons:
Execs felt like you were just a cog in their grand machine. People are treated as dispensable. Constantly felt like I had no job security as a resource action (lay-off) could come at any time. Executives didn't give a good sense of direction and didn't convey that they knew what they were doing.
(Some of this may have changed since I left, they at least started giving free snacks, drinks, and coffee. The lowest of low perks but they used to not give anything)

Pros: Big company presents lots of opportunities.  Most of the people I worked with were bright and good to work with.  It's such a big company that there are lots of different areas to work in, and I believe moving around is not too hard if you're qualified.
Cons: Being a small cog in a big machine - ocassional bureaucratic headaches.  The pay was adequate, but perhaps felt a bit on the low end vs. competitors.  Benefits felt a little stingy.  It was a bit disapointing when I was there that a big portion of bonuses were tied to the division's performance and the overall firm's performance, so in a time when parts of the business I had nothing to do with were under performing, my compensation was was lower.

Pros: Employee discounts with many of the business partners, including auto companies, financial institutions, insurers, cellular phone providers, large retailers, and many others.  It's especially nice at Christmas time.  There are also discounts on IBM items, but they are rarely used because IBM doesn't exactly focus on consumer items.
Cons: Many, many of their engineering jobs have been offshored.  The older workers mostly feel they're doomed to being laid off after the next quarterly report that disappoints the analysts.  The company is more than happy to replace these workers with younger ones or foreigners who cost less.  The stock price RIGHT NOW is the most important thing, always.

Pros: A company motivated by innovation and research-the crimeajewel in the crown of any high tech company in the information age.As we move to NGN fibre networks all over the US and Europe,and download speeds of 100mbs become the norm for everyone,and all tech devices become ip enabled,(with the ability to communicate with each other-even though manafactured differently by different companies with different designs),the pace of the information age and the demands on people in both their work and home life will increase dramaticly.In this world of instant information and feedback, innovation and speed to market in a compeditive enviroment will be key to corporations and SME's winning out.
Cons: Long hours.Too many meetings.Not enough promotion prospects.

Pros: Flexible work location and schedue if you can find a job where this is permitted.  Some great people to work with in the trenches although they are becoming more and more scarce...
Cons: Unbelievable focus on process over production.  Way too much bureaucracy.  Corporate centric command-and-control management mentality with seemingly arbitrary decisions forced on the unwitting masses...  The US workforce is under a constant threat of layoffs due to offshoring.  Pay raises seem nonexistent, even for high performers. Consequently, the morale of the workforce is at its lowest ever and continuing to drop.

Pros: I worked for IBM to obtain training and opportunity. Even though there have been significant cutbacks in funding for education, IBM is still a good place if you need to further your education, (e.g.BA, Phd). The work at IBM is challenging and looks good on a resume.
Cons: No matter what career path you take, expect to get the feeling that you will be laid off any moment. Layoffs are the norm as work transitions outside the US.  Pay and benefits also change constantly so expect to spend a lot of your time with financial planning and understanding health insurance terms.  Pay is OK for employees hired with upper level degrees.  Don't expect recognition if you earn an upper level degree once hired.

Pros:
competitive salary and benefits
flexible work arrangements
global opportunities
comprehensive work locations if located near a primary office (cafeterias, lounges, kitchens, etc)
solid results even in poor economy
stable company with good reputation
Volunteer opportunities and company support of them
Cons:
high emphasis on outsourcing US jobs and training of your replacements
poor management execution of IBM values and processes
failure to reward technically skilled professionals (more advancement based on politics or popularity)
sneaky layoffs (resource actions) that are designed to avoid regulations and reporting requirements
technical work often focused on proprietary products that are not standards based, thus some knowledge is not highly valuable outside of company
management does not understand technical issues or complexity
too much management churn/movement
very limited accountability for managerial mistakes
too much finger pointing from management towards engineering
high emphasis on rewarding management and sales but low emphasis on rewarding engineering

Pros:
Work with some very smart and wonderful people.  The people "in the trenches" are the best around.  I have really enjoyed the teams I have worked with inside the company.  Very smart and hard working people.
Mentoring is available depending on "who you know"
Some online training can still be had for free.  Paid training is extremely limited and you need to take classes on your own time
Depending on the job, project & manager decent work/life balance and time off can be had
Cons:
Lots of jobs in US being eliminated
Work/Life balance can be an issue.  Especially when working the global clock (needing to be available to meet with teams in all time zones).
Enormous pressure to meet deadlines/cut costs, often not realistic.

Pros: Big company, Ok health benefits, the illusion of job security.
Cons:
Really frugal (cheap) company, no snacks, employees are required to work on old/outdated computer equipment (lots of developers still forced to work on Windows XP), and managers don't seem to appreciate your input or innovations. I actually applied the Joel Test to the area I worked at within IBM, and found that they failed miserably.

If you're a Software Engineer, you'll most likely find yourself working with outdated technologies and programming frameworks mandated by non-technical executives. And if you haven't heard, IBM is laying off people left and right at this time, with the possibility of more layoffs coming towards the end of this year. Definitely not the best company to be at right now.

Pros: I worked for IBM for 26 years, now retired.  Over the years I was well compensated and had many opportunties to advance.  Had several job changes over the years, last being a software engineer for the Information Management of the Software Group.  This was the best job I had.  Worked from home 100%, had very competent co-workers and mostly good managers.
Cons: Over the years, benefits were slowly taken away, to the point where they seemed to be squeezing ever last thing they could take from the employees.  Just one example, workers at home were compensated for internet access when I stated, but the last year I worked, they stopped.  Their reasoning was everyone would have their own internet anyway so why should IBM compensate, they gave us the option to go to a work site, but since that was 90 miles away, that really wasn't an option.

Pros: 1) Challenging work 2)Excellent global experience 3) You can gain a variety of assignments in very different business units without changing companies
Cons: 1) Finance runs the company so it's impossible to get reasonable resources -- people or pencils-- 2) Bureaucracy is rampant, so it takes a long time to get anything done and a sense of urgency is squashed 3) Leaders (even mid level executives) are generally not trusted to do the right thing and every decision is scrutinized. This leads to the disenfranchisement of the leadership team and the feeling that they don't own their decisions. You can surmise what the downstream effect of that is.

Pros:
Very well respected in the industry
Solid financial results allows freedom to do new things
Almost universal work from home policy which allows employees to spend time with family
Cons:
Work from home policy means that most teams are geographically dispersed and in some cases you may never even meet your boss or coworkers in person.
Policy decisions are often made by the institution - i.e. no one stands behind them so they cannot be challenged or discussed.
The power is all in management - the workers are just resources.
Yearly layoff policy trims thousands off the payroll silently on a regular basis Q)  "Where's Joe?"  A) "Didn't you hear?  He left the company in the last Resource Action"

Pros: Some interesting engineer opportunities.   Great tradition.    Comfortable chairs.
Cons:
Uninspiring engineering leads.  Everyone seems defensive and afraid of the next round of layoffs.   Marking time.

Annual review is a gladiator fight where the losers end up as '2' performers waiting for the axe.   Offices are from Dilbert.   Benefits reduced year to year.   Executives want 'wild ducks' but timid middle-level managers don't.

Anecdote: For his annual performance appraisal, one Distinguished Engineer told me his process looks like this. Hears form above what the top 5 initiatives are and writes down he is an expert in these areas.  His executive signs off and he continues as a '1' performer.     Hasn't contributed anything meaningful in years.

Pros: Remote employee. If you have the discipline, working form home is a great idea. Don't kid yourself, it is a also great for the employer. You end up working more hours, They don't have to pay rent, buy desks and chairs, pay electricity, pay for heat or air conditioning.. It is a win win situation
Cons: Their infrastructure is sub par and requires substantial manual intervention/manipulation. They will place you in roles that are very far removed from your skill set in order to support the need for manual intervention.IBM typically has Resource Actions once or twice a year. Their selection process in indiscriminate, not attached to performance and is the only tool in their bag to rebut poor earnings (11 straight quarters as of this posting)

Pros: Top notch technology coupled with very knowledgeable people; politics was rampant in Information Management, particularly "DB2 bigots" (& nothing wrong with loving DB2, but there were many who's attitude was "DB2 or nothing" despite IBM buying out some top notch database technologies). Great benefits such as full medical, dental, and vision, as well as broad fund options for the 401K with an employer match.
Cons: No matter how loyal you are as an IBM employee, watch your back since (at least from my perspective) you may be laid off at any time.

Pros:
Big company, lots of opportunities to learn new things and career choices.
Working from Home positions!!!
Cons:
IBM keeps cutting workforce in the US every year moving the work to APAC... customers do not want to deal with people who are not local to the US so they cling onto the few US resources left overloading them with work... fewer and fewer people make for very long work weeks.
The added aggravation of all the overhead activities to be performed to align with Management initiatives turns this company into the only relationship you will entertain as you won't have time for anything else

Pros: Reinvent yourself constantly.  There is always opportunity to get into a new role / project / technology. There is a wide range of on line education and certifications.  If you are in a sales role and overachieve, you are taken care of.  Many opportunities exist and most internal operations interact with a global team.
Cons: Shareholder profit first, free cash for acquisitions second.  Taking care of their employees is far, far, down the list. Salary increases even to cost of living adjustments is hard to come by. Promotions are near non-existent.  We pay subcontractors and IBMers who leave and return far more then those loyal to the company. Short sighted decisions that are often overly-corrected the next year.  Everyone is and acts in their business silo and not integrated as one.

Pros: The working environment is very friendly. Each intern has his or her own space. I prefer a relatively private space compared to the open-spaced design in many IT companies in the bay area. Each Tuesday afternoon the team will get together in a tea hour to talk about everyone's ideas, progress or anything you like. The interns will have opportunity to present the work during intern as posters. In the end there will be a formal presentation summarizing what you have done in the summer, which is a good start for a paper outline. No traffic jam in the rush hours because we are in the very south.
Cons: The location is the very very south of silicon valley (I think it is the most south). So if you want to stay near to your friends who work in mountain view, it is a little bit far.

Pros:
Constantly reinventing itself in a fast moving industry
You have great latitude for being entrepreneur and lead
Great focus on driving innovative offerings in the market place and help our customers to transform themselves and disrupt in the marketplace
Ability to move up and laterally in broad solution areas
Right business strategy: focus on high value areas, focusing on delivering outcome vs products
Great investment in employee skills and industry knowledge
Ability to work remotely for the most part
Strong values and customer-oriented culture
Cons:
Takes a bit of effort to understand the organization and the broad portfolio
Can take a while to adjust to a remote way of working.  Most internal meetings are over conference calls, which has positives but could take a bit of effort to adjust and get used to
Technology companies work in fast moving environments to specific divisions can change direction relatively quickly.  People who can't easily adjust/adopt change might find it difficult.

Pros: As an experienced hire, IBM has been an awesome working environment. The approach to diversity is so much part of IBM's DNA that they see only my skills and the benefits that I bring to the business model. My favorite "pro" is that there's almost no paper anywhere--IBM is already doing what they are advising others to do. And, it's a world-wide 24 hour organization--each day is something new--so nice to be on the raw edge of technology. Another huge "pro" is the focus on being a learning organization--as an employee you can grow in knowledge as much as you can absorb. Skills are grown in-house and can adapt as quickly as the environment changes.
Cons: The project manager roles throughout IBM could  be transitioned to personal contributor leadership roles to create additional enterprise value.

Pros: It really depends where you are and which people you work with but if you are lucky, you get to have great mentors, participate and lead employee resource groups, corporate service corps opportunity, do business travel and you're cheered on to go up the ladder or expand your horizons within IBM.
Cons: If you are unlucky to have a crap manager, you're only way out really is to move managers or move out of the company. IBM is too big and there's a process for everything so you won't get to do things as you want right away and changes you want in your career can be halted because everyone else is too busy doing their own thing and they just let your manager take care of you. But with the premise I mentioned, it can get really hard and frustrating.

Pros: Flexible on job location (i.e. remote work), and setting your own hours.  Plenty of opportunities to work abroad.  There are training/education/certification opportunities, but all are virtual and self study.  The company is large enough where lateral moves can be easy to find, and offer new career challenges.
Cons: Finance runs the company, and they will frequently (and suddenly) put in place strict spending cuts.  To the point where it is nearly impossible to do any non-customer travel.  For group training, conferences, team meetings, etc.  There are people with whom I have worked for 10+ years, and have never met face to face.  Management puts little effort into career guidance.  There are some exceptions to that rule, but not many.

Pros:
- Was able to gain lots of experience very fast 
- Many opportunities to learn and gain industry experience
- Opportunities for new roles
- the company is always reinventing itself and it can be exciting to be part of that!
Cons:
- Not a lot of yearly raises or bonuses
- To get a new role you need to network internally just like getting a job
- Sometimes work long hours and weekends depending on your project and role

Pros: I personally enjoy who I work with and how understanding my co-workers and managers are.  For example when I give input or suggestions in team meetings I feel that what I say is valued and taken to heart.
Cons: I feel that the apprenticeship program has still has quite a bit of a ways to go. However, I am thankful I was chosen to be part of it. With that said, I think IBM needs to think about having more training "hands-on" and less video watching. Rather, try to have apprentices shadow people more often and see the role they are training to do. Videos can only help so much before the brain turns to mush. Changing things up helps the mind stay active.

Pros:
Lots of freedom to explore and publish research
Very collaborative
Good work/life balance
The technology (in AI) is underrated relative to the competition, most companies have essentially the same stuff these days but IBM just doesn't have the reputation or the data of a Google or Amazon
Cons:
A lot of people working on the same things
Behind the competition in a lot of areas due to IBM's business model (can't learn from other clients' data, nothing is consumer facing)
Compensation and benefits is below average for the labor market. This used to be ok because IBMers like the work/life balance and job security, but job security is no longer any better than the competitors

Pros: Challenging client projects; opportunity to move around inside the company and do very different things; senior leadership with their heads and hearts in the right place; smart, talented, driven people; belief that IBMers can figure out how to solve any problem; legacy of innovation that changes the world.
Cons: Too much bureaucracy; career progression slows down dramatically with each promotion; matrix management structure with too many executives in charge of nothing; confusing business process, constantly changing owners so it's like starting from scratch to get things done internally; too focused on its own profits and not enough priority placed on the clients; tolerates toxic leaders who do not demonstrate IBM values.

Pros:
IBM is a large company with a lot of great people to work with.  The IBM community is diverse, with locations around the world with people of all races, creeds, religions and beliefs.  With all of this diversity, I think IBM has the ability to do anything it wants.  The talent pool seems endless and the opportunities that arise for its employees are there if you are motivated to go after them.  

Often when you come out of college, you think you know what you want to do, but once you start doing that job, you find that it just doesn't suit you.  IBM has many many disciplines that allow you to morph your career should you desire a change.
Cons: It is a large company, and this isn't for everyone.  Still, I believe if you are motivated, the large size shouldn't be a problem.

Pros: Benefits are great, work-life balance can be good if you're an efficient worker with a good manager and you leverage that.
Cons: IP Agreements are extremely restrictive given the size of the company.  Since IBM is into so many different areas of development, much of what you may be interested in working on externally they could reasonably claim ownership of.  Your group may not work on anything remotely close to what you want to work on in your personal time, but IBM can still claim ownership of it because it falls under the wide open umbrella of the entire company's "actual or anticipated" business interests.

Pros: IBM is an extremely stable company.  There is a lot of opportunity for advancement across the various towers which can help to make one's career at IBM a very long one.  I feel strongly that I could remain at IBM for the remaining 25 years of my career and retire from there, if I choose to.  Not many companies offer this level of job security.
Cons: It takes a lot of effort to make any significant impacts in a company with nearly 400,000 employees.  Advancement is based almost entirely on one's influence within one's business unit and IBM in general.  It takes a great deal of effort, experience, and ability to make an impact within a company this size.  Additionally, the salaries at IBM tend to be lower than at similar companies.  The benefits help to offset this somewhat but not completely.

Pros: A huge company.  Diversified options.  Something for everyone.
Cons: Huge Company.  No shortage of talent.  Lets say 1% is considered the cream of the crop.  1% of 370K employees is 3.7K ppl competing for top positions.  Easy to be really good and still not make it at all.

Pros: It always looks good to have IBM on your resume since it is such a respected company.  There are good, intelligent people to learn from.  IBM pushes innovation so most of their employees hold multiple patents.
Cons: No one seems satisfied at IBM Tucson.  Many people have left or are looking for work outside the company.  The main reasons are compensation and career advancement.

Pros: PERCEIVED IBM brand. Great opportunities for different types of consulting assignments, though not so much anymore due to the infighting for bill rates between organizations. Good job security but poor opportunities to grow, so if security's your only criteria in measuring a 'GREAT' company, then it's an OK place. 90% of your IBM colleagues are truly GREAT and you will learn far more from each other than the company.
Cons: Consultants have NO work/life balance; just utilization targets. Period. Anyone who tells you otherwise isn't a full time consultant at IBM. Negotiate your salary VERY carefully before you sign off. Virtually NO raises once you get in, and you'll quickly find that new hires (many MUCH less experienced), make MUCH more than you do because they knew how to research and negotiate better. Also, bonuses are a joke so focus on your BASE pay.

Pros: Very Smart employees, Good for gaining leadership experience, Company still has a lot of prestige (looks good on resume), Competitive Starting Salary & Benefits
Cons: Slow & Tedious Promotion Process (You essentially have to write 16 essays on why you deserve a promotion and this is with the new "less cumbersome" Go Organic process).  Executive pay is tied to EPS Goals and any failure to meet those goals rolls down on employees and effects compensation.  Company changed 401(k) matching so that match is paid in lump sum to 401(k) at the end of the year.  You miss out on investment growth throughout the year and if you leave before 15 December, you don't receive any match for the entire year.

Pros: It's a good place to understand corporate America. It's where you experience how talent is commoditized, measured, and evaluated.
Cons:
It this the kind of environment or treatment that creates employee satisfaction? I think not.
The leadership style is primarily based on command and control, which limits the ability to develop a variety of talent and other leadership styles. Command and control is the most common and easiest leadership style to adopt. My advise for leaders who are looking to join IBM is to spend as little time as possible at IBM to develop and experience it in one of the largest command and control companies in the world, and then get out to develop all your other leadership styles that will actually change the world and touch more lives in a positive way. You won't get a chance to do that at IBM, other leadership skills can not be commoditized, thus not rewarded.

Pros: Ability to work from home, wonderful set of employees and manager with expertise to learn from, global operations.  Amazing breadth of enterprise software products and services.
Cons: In major transition so very challenging place to work, low morale.  Major reorg just took place.  Culture is reactive instead of proactive so lots of firedrills to respond to.  Many managers are too focused on tactical activities and addressing action items, unable to focus on longer-term plans and activities.  Endless meetings, reviews and approvals.  Not a good place to work for young people.

Pros: Working from home, prestigious degree of technical talent, flexible schedule, brand recognition
Cons: Field marketing aka demand programs a.k.a. performance marketing at this company is antiquated. Tools are dramatically out of date and slow. IBM will never be able to keep up with its more nimble competitors for this reason.

Pros: Ability to work from home in certain positions.
Cons: You are no more than an insignificant cog and a commodity at IBM. IBM is totally focused on shareholders' value and invests very little in employees. Compensation is below average, however IBM goes to great lengths to produce "industry salary reports" to show how fairly employees are supposedly compensated. IBM Global Services goes after outsourcing contracts without having resources to fulfill the contract and without consideration of the actual effort that it takes. Sales team appears to be completely disconnected from the realities of providing a service under a contract. Salaried consultants are forced to bill 50-60 hours per week (if not billing at least that much, then performance reviews suffer and your job is on the line.)

Pros:
+ Name/Brand/History of success and ability to adapt to changing markets
+ Many different roles in different business units - interesting and different work in many places (just not in consulting)
+ Starting to wake up and realize cost reduction is not the way to create long-term value/growth, seeing more investment in infrastructure and people
Cons:
-  Pure comedy to see other consulting firms brought in to do work with healthy expense budgets, better hardware (computers, SW) while we are supposedly an industry leading tech company
- Despite being revenue producing there are almost no raises unless you are promoted and minimal bonus pool
- Not much quality consulting work unless you work on internal projects

Pros:
- High, competitive salary. Could not believe I was making X amount out of college.
- Access to the best training whether that be online on in person (free!)
- Great health insurance
- Good reputation . . . Everyone always looks very impressed when they find out that I work for IBM
Cons:
- Ambiguity within the first year of job. Had no idea what I was doing for about 10 months
- Front line manager isn't helpful or open for questions (please note, this was with MY manager. There are about 10 others that I hear are really helpful and great leaders... I just got unlucky)

Pros:
- Large company trying to become successful again
- Salaries are competitive
- Might be a good place for new graduates
Cons:
My opinion based on conversations with a lot of friends at IBM:
- Cannot be counted on for long term stability with multiple layoffs per year.
- Layoffs appeared to be mainly talented lifers and hiring appears to be young inexperienced resources. Only time will tell how this change will work.
- A few weeks before the layoffs, IBM changed the severance policy from 2 weeks pay for every year of service to 4 weeks severance no matter how long you were there. 35 years and you still get 4 weeks of pay. To me, that should be of great concern for those interested in IBM.
- Unless the new IBM changes go very well, the stock is artificially inflated due to recent layoffs of 10's of thousands (most likely from the US) and this might be a concern as well.

Pros:
One of the most recognizable brands in the industry
Broad portfolio of great products, and complimentary products, to offer customers the "one stop shop" experience
Tremendous amount of training and career support
Good pay and benefits
Cons:
Executive management making knee-jerk responses with one-size-fits-all policies across every single business unit.  
Laying off SEs strictly on financial performance with zero regard to whether or not they have any support from the sales team, as well as the constant churn of sales and SE organization changes every 6 months.  
Exec management completely out of touch with what is happening on the ground.

Pros:
Higher pay compared to some.  About on par for other large companies though.
PTO/Health is VERY standard.
Cons:
Long working hours (based on team).  But it seems fairly consistent that most are asked to regularly work 50+ hours.  Salaried employees especially.

The "IBM way" phrase that gets thrown around is their way of saying "work longer, for no extra pay, because you work for IBM" (which clearly means you're superior to the competition and should be proud).

They have no real structure, or company goals, other than money.  

In my orientation class, they ACTUALLY said "What does IBM do?  We don't know, but help us define it."..... They actually do not have any core.

Others: 
 You wont be able to move within the company.  If you do well, your boss will not allow you to move, which they must sign off on.  
Consistent fear of RAs for many.
They are very sneaky in their hiring process, in terms of their expectations of you.

Pros:
Flexible working hours
Proximity to incredible researchers
Plenty of practitioner-level talent
Cons:
It's a hopeless, confused situation for some Business Units. Middle and upper management should be replaced entirely. No strategy, no sense of direction or purpose, and our competition is eating us alive. A lot of management promotions will leave you scratching your head, too. Like, are your products are stagnant? Do you hire ridiculously bad managers? Is your staff morale in the toilet? Have you experienced more attrition than anyone before you? Promoted.

On top of it all, good luck trying to get a promotion, access to new software, or even a steady supply of napkins or cups in the kitchen. IBM can't afford it.

Pros:
- Access to infinite resources to learn, grow, and innovate
- Excellent retention and work life balance for a Big corp/tech company
- Excellent parental leave benefits
- Relatively easy to change teams and move to areas of emerging technologies
Cons: - As it's the case for most big companies, if your group or team projects are less exciting and less revenue generating outside of R&D, you won't have a pleasant ride.

Pros: Flexible projects with potential to learn a lot. Can meet a lot of people and grow a solid network of respectable peers. Great place to learn architecture as you’ll be building a lot of projects from scratch/early stages.
Cons: Unorganized and understaffed for many projects. Unrealistic deadlines and expectations. Promotion track revolves around workplace politics, selling, and yes manning management instead of merit or performance based. Often seen as just a body to throw at a project, despite qualifications. This creates unorganized and inexperienced teams trying to meet unrealistic deadlines quite often.

Pros: There are lots of opportunities for advacement and to do different and challenging things. The benefits package is pretty good. The vacation package is reasonable and IBM is very good about extra time off for getting married and having children. There is also a lot of opportunity to work from home.
Cons: IBM is very beauruacratic,, and it is getting worse. It becomes more difficult every day to get things done.  The education opportunities used to be much better. They are very restrictive now about the cost of attending classes. When I began 8 years ago there was much focus on promoting educaction and having people develop new skills.

Pros: IBM has a very respectful working environment.  Employees have tremendous freedom to complete their work.  There is a campaign environment to much of the work that divides the year into distinct cycles and phases.  The opportunities to interact with Research, Services, Software, Hardware, and Industries provides a lot of areas for professional development.
Cons: Very slow career progression.  Many executives bully employees.  IBM constantly revisits old ideas instead of searching for new ones.  Some of the best leaders have recently retired.  The yearly PBC review process is arbitrary and the goals are often abstract.  IBM has one of the most convoluted compensation programs in the world.  Complaints from sales reps about unpaid commissions and constantly changing bonus metrics are so common.

Pros: IBM still does have a decent benefits package - Insurance, sick leave.  Even though the cost is much higher that we have paid in the past, it is still much lower and coverage is better than what you can get on the outside.
Cons: Hours - management thinks that we should be living, dying breathing IBM.    We are penalized for things that are out of our control.  Lack of respect from management.  Many feel that we do not have the intelligence to do our jobs.

Pros: There are some top notch technical people at IBM and in general, my coworkers are competent and pleasant to work with.
Cons:
IBM Microelectronics' glory days are in the past.  It lost its technological leadership years ago and it has long been a second class semiconductor manufacturer.  As IBM continues to be less and less a hardware company and more and more a services/software company, its days as a semiconductor manufacturer seem numbered.

Working for IBM in general is a cold, dehumanizing experience.  As an employee, you are a piece of office equipment to be surplussed when business needs change or when there is a business downturn.

Pros: IBM has a reasonable wage.  And it still has a family like culture.  IBM values Diversity so thoes who are diverse will be more Secure.
Cons: IBM is a good place to work as long as your manager believes you are in the in-crowd.  Once Management changes and you are no longer in the in-crowd and things get bad in the economy then they will get rid of you.  I was just laid off after many years of great performace.  I was left scratching my head as to why they chose me.  There were plenty of others that did not have the skill or pashion for the job as I did.

Pros: IBM has always been very respectful of work-life balance and time off for life events, etc. Leaders are generally very accessible and willing to engage all employee levels. The work can be very rewarding.
Cons: The spreadsheet mentality means that they may not always completely understand how to value a good employee whose benefit to the company rises above their bottom line or utilization tallies (particularly in the area of User Experience and other creative/design roles). It was NOT always like this here. It seems back in the earlier part of the decade, we were encouraged to "Do the Right Thing" and were rewarded for our efforts and risk in a more organic way.

Pros:
Ability to work from home
Large number of opportunities if willing to relocate
Diverse group of intelligent people
Cons:
Poor Worklife Balancing
First level managers have little to no power to impact anything
Glass Ceiling for non executives
Poor Bonus Structure

Pros: Lots of experience around, lots of internal resources, good insight into the corporate world, great experience for college graduates just breaking into the industry.
Cons: Hired in for one thing but end up doing something completely different, pay is low compared to other companies, management is lackluster.

Pros:
Great benefits package and comparable salaries
Ability to work from home is widely accepted
Can really grow your career and expertise if you so desire
Most colleagues are nice, professional and in the same boat as you.
Cons:
Yearly layoffs drastically impact moral and ability to get work accomplished.
Internally-facing organizations move very slowly and it's frustrating.
Externally-facing organizations often move too quickly and rush to failure.
As much as they cut the dead weight, there are still middle-managers who are apathetic and just filling a seat.

Pros: Good technical environment (semiconductor business) to expand knowledge base.  Empowered to do experiments as needed, to find answers to ongoing problems.
Cons: Penny pinching.  CEO and executives are focused ONLY on "EPS" (Earnings Per Share), and the price of common stock.  After all, this how they grow their personal wealth...through stock options.  Living in constant fear of being sold off or outsourced.  No conferences allowed.  Very little new equipment purchased for our lab.  Seem to be "cooking the books", for years now, to make the division more attractive to potential suitors. Forget about meaningful salary increases.  Many, many years since I saw one of those.

Pros: On the whole, IBMers are a smart and motivated group. The company is well managed with an excellent management track, once you get on it.  With its breadth of hardware (decreasing) and software (increasing) products, it can provide 'one stop' shopping for its clients.  The company has an excellent worldwide reputation which is good enough to get you in the door of many potential clients.
Cons: However, there is a lot of corporate structure, some of which is needed to mitigate risk, but some that seems to have gotten a life of its own and lost track of its original intent.  It has struggled to properly assimilate and monetize its' numerous acquisitions, a process which is slowed by the detailed requirements to release any IBM software product.

Pros: Flexible hours, working from home.
Cons: Management is top-heavy.  Jobs of hard-working U.S. employees are constantly being outsourced, off-shored, downsized.  Cost-cutting is the only goal.  Ageism is rampant.  No job security.  Project Management is a joke:  efficiency and hard work is ignored, old knowledge/experience has been retired, cut up and replaced by multiple foreign workers who don't know or understand how anything works together. Pay has decreased every year, no bonuses, OT no longer paid. No pension, 401(k) company match only at end of calendar year if one is "lucky" enough to still be employed.  Employee morale could not be lower.  Non-management employees considering unionizing.  Employee desktop tools are last century; offshore "Help" desk not helpful as they cannot understand questions or "don't know that product."

Pros: Awesome people to work with, some of the best minds anywhere. Processes and procedures in place for everything. Fantastic potential in a company to ride the cloud generation and pull out the guns it has and the incredible reputation. Watson technology can take it over the top once again if they let the Ginny out of the box.
Cons: No visionary at the helm that would inspire the masses. Good candidate for a show like CBS's Undercover Boss to see the reality of the field. Massive brain drain occurring due to lack of leadership. Too much emphasis on dividends and rate of return, stock buybacks. Selling of key parts of company continues (hardware, chip development) creating a shell with a volatile inside.

Pros: Services, Cloud, mobile, software etc model is proving out with the growth numbers in 2015--- Ginny's strategy is right....BUT
Cons: ..unfortunately, there are too many entrenched baby boomers at the top who are concerned about their own pocketbooks at the expense of this winning strategy-- optics of taking a pay raise after underperforming is not good for company or investors--- I want my CEO to be highly paid.... if she is producing results--- she is not 11 quarters in a row -- most people being laid off have better track records than her

Pros: IBM feels like a lot of small companies, that is good when you want to move around, as you can  have a lot of experiences in different positions, domains, locations and working with a lot of individuals.
Cons: 1) The best talent tends to leave IBM in order to be more appreciated  (read "paid better"). Those remaining, especially second-line management exemplifies the Peter Principle  (promoted beyond their level of competence).  2) The technical support infrastructure, software tools (laptops,Lotus Notes, ST), etc.are old and/or buggy technologies. Internal human support takes too long to address, that you spend hours searching the intranet for self-help, taking away from job productivity time and time again.

Pros: Great resume builder to work for a company as big and well known as IBM.  Great healthcare benefits for full time employees.  As an employee you get a lot of discounts from various companies.
Cons: Because of the size of the company it's extremely hard to get recognized for good work.  Pay raises ate based on a ranking system that is unfair.  I say this because senior management tells your direct manager how many people they can select for each ranking. 1 is the best 4 is the worst, only 10% of staff can be a 1, 10% can be a 2, the 80% left need to be 2's and 3's.  Only people with 1's get a raise.

Pros: You may have some decent people to work with, and you probably won't have to talk with the ones you don't want to. The benefits are ok. They have an online library membership that has a few useful books.
Cons: I could list off the cons and air ibm's dirty laundry and it would be a very big and long review. But to keep it brief, there are a lot of things that will keep you shaking your head and wondering why you're still here. The absolute worst thing is it feels like the management doesn't trust the employees.

Pros: Good exposure to new technologies (usually through acquisitions) and good support teams behind you.  Mostly work from home office which helps, but travel can be high as sales teams and customers are scattered over your territory.  If you are just starting out, probably a good place to get some experience and add to your resume, but move on after 5 years or so.
Cons: Commissions and quotas....IBM constantly makes changes to control your earnings, so very difficult to have a blowout quarterly paycheck.  IBM imposes a ton of internal process work that never seems to end, but this is typical of most large companies vs startups.  Constant need to justify your existence.

Pros: Great company history, work hard get paid well, great people to work with and around.
Cons:
Changed a lot in last 10 years.  If you like to live to work then this is the place for you. 
Can go years without a pay raise. 
Lots of offshoring, jobs are not secure, regardless of what division you are in.

Pros: There used to be many of these but they have slowly disappeared over the years. Some of the few left are the ability to telecommute when needed in most cases. It depends on your manager.
Cons:
This list gets larger every year but the biggest con is that there are constant layoffs. IBM values its stock price over its customers and employees now. Layoffs have nothing to do with your performance and everything to do with your being a senior employee making a higher salary. Last I heard for people getting laid off this year you only get 1 month salary no matter how long you have been with the company. 
Benefits are dwindling slowly but surely.

Pros:
Work from home (though IBM seems to be reducing this option for some positions)

Good, dedicated co-workers at the lower levels
Cons:
Lack of raises

Lots of talk about customer focus but focus is on $$$ even when it results in significant negative impact to customers

Training provided is only online and primarily sales focused

Repeated layoffs in the U.S. - IBM execs think of employees only as a cost that they want to eliminate.  Everyone is always waiting for the call regardless of performance ratings.

Total lack of respect for employees

Pros:
Large organization with many job opportunities... although they're shrinking 
High skilled coworkers 
Having IBM on your resume is valued by others, for now.
Cons:
Sinking morale - ongoing job cuts, co-location, and a CEO who earned 31M whil rank and file bonuses were enough for a nice dinner out... are taking a toll
Despite ongoing job cuts, massive layers of managers and mid level execs
Culture of blame vs a culture of try then adjust
Matrixed organization often results in 3, 4, 5 or more exec level bosses.

Pros:
Diversity of challenges to solve
amazing colleagues - some of the smartest people I’ve ever met are IBMers. I love the people I work with
Geographic reach
Cons: Upper level management out of touch with customer and employee needs and too entrenched in legacy, cumbersome business processes. Incentive systems based on previous org siloes that can make it feel impossible to collaborate across business units for the benefit of customers. Mixed messages on purpose: shareholders vs customers vs employees vs society. Despite a female CEO still limited women at the top and no visible effort to nurture the next gen of female execs.

Pros: IBM' learning platform is best in class. You will find everything you need, no matter what you are looking for from strategy to execution to technologies. The content is tailored to suit to you role and experience. It's like driving on a predefined pathway without worrying about if to go left or right. Leadership provides enough opportunities to take a break from day to day hustles and learn. In fact there is mandatory training each need to finish every year which kinda forces you to thin hard where you will spend those required hours so that helps you to succeed.
Cons: Like any other big organization, IBM is huge and you need coach or mentor to navigate you. Finding right coach or mentor is something that most of the folks find tough but recently IBM started addressing this through more collaborative platform for mentors and mentees - time will tell how that helps address this only con of such a great organization.

Pros: The people I worked with were fantastic. Very nice, will go out of your way to help and teach you. Great work life balance. Relatively high starting salary.
Cons: Maybe depends on where you work since it is a big company, but coming out of school my expectations of a tech company and what I've experience thus far at IBM were very different. I occasionally feel that IBM is behind with the times in some aspects and long term vision is unclear to me. Tech seems archaic. Pay rises aren't great and annual bonuses are almost insultingly low if you're lucky to get one. Doesn't really incentive young people to stay in my opinion, though there are plenty of IBM lifers...

Pros: Sharp, sometimes brilliant, colleagues; opportunities to talk with colleagues in different jobs/divisions within the company and learn from them about latest trends in developing technology and what customers and business partners are doing. At IBM the employees are first-rate -- really creative and smart.
Cons: The workload is overwhelming. I have worked 70-hour weeks for years, and still can't accomplish everything I want to do to feel satisfied with my job. I am at the highest level of non-executive employee, and everyone at my level feels that we have targets on our backs -- IBM is trying to remove highly paid people in Western countries and hire less competent people in developing countries.

Pros: Working at home.  Make 95K sitting home, eating chips, and checking your email every 2 hours.  Another good reason is that IBM looks good on your resume.  Finally, you get really good at dealing with politics and difficult angry people (who are this way because they are stressed from being overworked and forced to achieve unrealistic goals.)
Cons: Hard to advance career (even when you really try hard)  and  LOTS of red tape to go through to get anything done.  I always tell people working at IBM is 90% filling out forms / 10% doing actual technical work.  IBM needs to start caring about employees again and we will care about the company.  Until then, we will be unproductive.

Pros: A lot of different opportunities with one employeer.  In many instances, given the ability to work from home or a remote location.  IBM tries to give a good work-life balance which often works in some peoples favor but can also hurt others.
Cons: Easy to get "lost" in such a large corporation.  Something always seems to be changing which requires learning a new system or process that is not always an improvement.  The ability to work from anywhere is also one of the downfalls.  I have found that employees (regardless of their position or standing) are expected to be available at all times regardless of what is going on in their life.

Pros: IBM provides flexibilities such as telecommuting, flexible hours, as well as a casual working environment.  Employees have unlimited sick days up to a year.  It also provides educational opportunities such as internal classes.
Cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy.  Many managers believe that people who talk the most during meetings are people who know.  Many managers are not technical people themselves.  That creates unnecessary layers of inefficiency.  Employees also have to use up their annual vacation.  If you don't use it, you lose it.  Salaries are relatively lower compared to other peer companies.  ESPP only offers 5% discount when employees purchase IBM stocks.

Pros:
There haven't been any good reasons to work on the ibm finance team for over 10 years now.  The ibm finance leadership team has become increasingly small minded, lacking in any BACKBONE, and is purely self centered.

The only reason to work at ibm is for a paycheck until you can find another better job elsewhere which many former employees have already done and continue to do so.
Cons: ibm is a great place to work if you enjoy working 60+ hours a week, being harranged by do nothing 1st & 2nd line managers, and if you like working for people who you do not respect.

Pros: 1. Because of its reputation and standing, it gets interesting assignments and you get to do interesting work. 2. It has a large, organized reservoir of templates, models, tools and instruments -- and training to back their use -- and you can learn and grow in your profession. 3. It has many competent professionals and encourages 'communities of practice,' which aids professional growth. 4. IBM is huge and involved in many different lines of exploration, which in turn broadens your professional view and, if you choose, helps you develop your knowledge and skill in a new or different direction -- a major career advantage in a time of radical flux.
Cons: 1. Despite its claim, it is a very mechanistic organization, which has an engineering approach to its employees, who are viewed as cogs in a machine and left to feel used and dispensable. 2. Despite an elaborate on-boarding program, its treatment of new employees is casual and thoughtless, and the initial period for newcomers is hard. 3. It is particularly bad for younger employees, who haven't had long working experience and are not principally self-directed; they often rudderless and lost in a giant maze. 4. Most employees are now 'virtual' and get scant team or organizational support, leaving them isolated, unsupported and painfully on their own.

Pros:
Healthcare, 401K, good location, its a job and a good name for your resume. 
Good education to take with you to your next job.
Cons:
Low paid, limited if any raises, no room for growth, too much work, too few people due to constant turn over.  I have seen at least 100 people on my floor leave in the past year then you have to pick up their work even though you have no time.  The if you can't fit it in you get a poor rating. 
Managers are like robots, running around like crazy, always in a frenzy, no time for their people. Two or 3 years without a raise or bonus.

Pros: Company offers wide variety of opportunities for different roles, career paths - IF you can get support of your manager.
Cons: Very few opportunities to build interpersonal and team relationship(s) with colleagues and coworkers as most are work from home. Spend lots of time on conference calls with cast of dozens or more. Very slow movement on projects due to "too many cooks," political wrangling and landscape. Difficult to build trust, as many are individual contributors focus on impressing management and rather than focusing on projects that help move the organization forward.

Pros: Good training & development opportunities for both early and mid-career people. Good for the resume, because IBM is well known and respected. Opportunity to develop or expand a professional network, as lots of folks move into and out of IBM.
Cons: More recent globalization of the company means very limited career path for non-emerging market employees.  Leadership "talks" about career, work-life balance and opportunity, but that's all it is - "talk".  If you want to be recognized you've got to forget the work-life balance and be a complete politician and workaholic.  Horrible culture resulting from weak middle management, continuous "workforce rebalancing" - layoffs and pressue to train and re-train and re-train staff brought on in growth markets where turnover is huge.

Pros: Once was a great company. Great benefits, good base salary - lousy commission structure for quota compared to similar companies.
Cons: Lack of leadership from director level through senior manager. Didn't provide the right resources for on boarding and learning the company environment. All system training was via WebEx (as everyone is remote) so no on-site training with peers and real world examples. Everyone has been there way too long and the culture of old - is still being disseminated. Hiring manager told me quota was x and second half it was 100% increase. That is one way to limit the income potential of a top seller at IBM. Raise the quota that wasn't to be raised by a ridiculous amount.

Pros:
The people - Most IBMers rank as the "best of the best." Very exciting to encounter and work with the most extraordinary people in the business. 
Depending on division and management chain, projects can be challenging, exciting, with a great deal of relevance to current and future technological impact on business and society.
A wealth of available online education.
Cons:
Unfortunately, in recent years an alarming number of what I believe to be the most dedicated workforce in the world are quite literally dropping dead from causes related to overwork and excessive stress.  (My statement is based on personal knowledge - not hearsay.)
In many areas, work/life balance is nonexistent. 
Personnel review system is a numbers game with no relationship to actual performance. Final decisions are often made by managers who have no personal knowledge of the person under review.
Raises are all but nonexistent.
Benefits erode every year.

Pros: Smart colleagues, well-respected company that's a household name, work on challenging and important initiatives, most decisions based on facts and the merits of the argument.
Cons: Bureaucratic and complex. Company does not invest in its employees as much as it used to, pays the minimum to retain employees. You need to be good at setting boundaries because there are major work/life balance issues with expectations that you be connected 24x7. Lack of promotions unless you are politically connected. Feeling of social isolation due to over-reliance on technology and conference calls rather than face to face meetings.

Pros: Some of the managers and employees are truly amazing and make the experience worth it all. Plus working for a fortune 500 company comes with the perk of endless knowledge and daily challenges that really push your limits and help you grow rapidly.
Cons: Most of the employees and managers are at the end of their careers or are spouses of Mayo Clinic employees and don't have a passion for what they do. They are truly there to collect a pay check and will gladly let you know that. This causes a somewhat hostile and dull work environment with feeds into the high attrition of millennials.

Pros: The old adage may still be true: nobody gets fired for choosing Big Blue. Sometimes it feels as though IBM is too big to fail, so it will be around forever. So in that one sense, there's job security. There's a strong sense of mission alignment, especially among senior management. I suppose one can take some comfort in that.
Cons: The downside is the constant feeling of thrash as IBM goes quarter over quarter posting losses on its balance sheet. Watson technology is the new hope - but don't be fooled by the marketing, there's plenty of confusion over what exactly Watson can do, and way too much overloading products with the word 'cognitive'.

Pros: In the past IBM has used a very effective work from home program. However, even that is changing to low cost "Agile" work centers were everyone knows a little bit about a lot but there are no real subject matter experts.
Cons:
Toxic work environment.
"Global Resources" does not include the United States.
Upper management is totally disconnect from the day to day workings of the business
Movement of work to low skilled resources in India, China, Mexico, Costa Rica etc is killing customer satisfaction and quality

Pros: Bright, passionate (but beleagured) workforce. Good, though continually reduced benefits. Flexiblity and W/L balance *if* you work within a good org.
Cons: Continued layoffs, disrespectful and/or oblivious leadership, unrealistic and unattainable goals underpinned with the overt threat of job security, disempowerment of rank-and-file and first-line mgmt, continued hiring freezes (for everyone except executives who seem to be hired by the truckload), reactive coupled with stagnant thinking, "agile" workspaces (where *no* thinking actually happens), competing divisions who are supposedly focused on the same goal, too focused on lowering costs instead of focusing on improving products and services, focus on "minimally viable products" that are never enhanced beyond "minimally viable"

Pros:
Despite being in business for more than 100 years, IBM is a surprisingly innovative and progressive company.  Like any big company there are times when it's hard to move things forward; however, working for a company this size you have the tremendous resources and an opportunity to work at a truly large scale. 

Additionally, I've been with this company for 31 years as an "out of the closet" bisexual woman.   Over the years IBM has been cutting edge regarding it's social and anti discrimination policies.  I'm truly proud of this.  Ethically, this company is superb.
Cons: I personally don't like the "back to the office" policy that has been instituted.  For those of us who where asked to work at how 10 years ago and may have moved to other locations, it's not easy.  However, my leadership has worked with me on this issue, so there is some flexibility.

Pros: Good salary,  great benefits, work from home and opportunities to travel.  Great people to work with and very smart ones at that!
Cons: Have to worry every quarter if you are next to be RA'ed (resource action, another acronym for "laid off"). Poor performance quarter after quarter.  Too many silos and nothing gets done in a timely manner.  Very "old" school company and stuck on "old" processes and procedures.  Too many politics and upper management.  Very little or no advancement for pursuing other career opportunities.  If you want job security, doesn't exist at IBM.

Pros:
I receive a paycheck.  
I have a job that offers mediocre benefits.
Cons:
No room for advancement.  Management at all levels have no idea what it actually takes to achieve the desired results and will not pay attention to those who do.  
Experience means nothing, the "process" is everything.  Square pegs must fit in round holes with no thought given to trying to help the client, being proactive or what it takes to achieve the desired results.  Managers have one agenda and that is making themselves look good at the expense of their employees who have no say in how things might be run better.  The CEO sends out several emails gushing about her great achievements and accomplishments that appear to have little to do with the actual operation of the company and more about making herself look good.  The bottom line is more important than employees.  Benefits are adequate to poor with everything done to benefit the company at the expense of the employee.

Pros: Watson brand opened many doors.
Cons: IBM is unsure if it wants to be a software company or a consultancy firm...so unfortunately it does neither great. The cost to customers far too often outweigh the value once you add in all the software costs and people required to implement and support. Lack of teamwork and job descriptions/accountability makes it nearly impossible to work. Travel and hours is extreme (often more than 5 days/week when you account for travel and often more than 80 hours/week). Rotating door in management and strategic direction. Billing rates are astronomical, when combined with requests to overstaff as a means of training new associates, makes the price unreasonable to win new business.
