Bad required software (e.g. must use IBM own software rather than a far better competing product)
raises NEVER happen without changing jobs - negotiate a good salary when you get hired or be prepared to change teams/managers whenever you are due for a raise
Fragmented teams so theres little to no shared knowledge

Pros: IBM provides great OTJ training, access to relevant systems and builds skills quickly in the field of finance. The workplace is highly flexible and there are frequent departmental activities and outings to build morale. Working at the finance Center of Excellence allows for a great deal of networking, team building, and skill sharing.
Cons: There is a lot of turnover with a very young workforce. Individual roles vary widely in both responsibility and workload, with some having very little work while others require overtime. All finance employees enter under "long-term supplemental" status, which includes slightly less pay and less benefits.

Pros: IBM employs  some of the smartest people on the planet. The rank and file, every day non managers are some of the brightest and smartest people you can ever meet.  Very supportive, and highly efficient.
Cons: Once upon a time, IBM was a great company.  Lou Gerstner saved IBM, but at the cost of its corporate soul.  Now IBM, while still a good place to work, but it's only average... Management is no different then any other tech company.... Id go as far as saying it's probably below average hen it comes to management and leadership.

Pros: There are none. 30 years ago it was a great company to work for. Senior management cared about the most valuable asset within the company, their employees. Today you are just a number no matter how well you perform. Salary and benefits lag behind the industry and management lacks vision.
Cons:
Benefits are average at best, most  lag behind the industry. 
Salary lags industry and annual increases are hit or miss. Increase percentages are a joke. 
No clear direction from upper management. There truly is no vision, just great "buzz" words. 
The worst HR people in the industry. Most HR people are flunky's who flushed out of real jobs.

Pros: IBM is a fine company to work for. There are plenty of avenues open to employees to further educate themselves and IBM will help.  For the 22 years I worked for them, I was able to further my education and open a couple of new chapters in my life. I was able to better myself quite a bit.
Cons: IBM is a large company and sometimes it is difficult to find who you need to go to in order to go farther with things you are trying to do for customers.  But, once you do find the correct avenue, there is usually plenty lf information.

Pros: Benefits package is a plus;  vacation, holidays, and health care options.  Depending on the position there can be flexable work location (Office, Home, Client site).
Cons: Too many layoffs in all areas of the business including Watson and Cloud. Bonuses almost eliminated or of little amount.  Layoffs include top performers.  Training focus is IBM only based training, no value placed on external (Non IBM) certifications.  Promotions, growth opportunities very limited. Salaries below standard for industry.  Work / Life balance no longer valued.  Internal job postings / hiring frozen.

Pros:
As a veteran of the US military, I've always appreciated that IBM recognizes the unique value, skills, and experience each individual brings to the company. Our leadership supports hiring veterans and encourages  veterans working for the company to share their thoughts and help others with military career transitions.

Additionally, I appreciate the company focus on corporate citizenship. As an individual IBM, I've found volunteer opportunities in my community and logged time I committed to nonprofit organizations I've served. I received an IBM community grant for one organization for the time I volunteered. Also, I was accepted into the Corporate Service Corps and spent a month as a corporate volunteer, consulting with an organization in Vietnam.
Cons: IBM is a large, global company. If you're considering employment and have worked for a small company or organization, it may take time to understand the many divisions and organizations within IBM.

Pros: Ability to switch to different roles and completely different jobs while inside the same company.  Access to leading thinkers and do-ers across a very VERY broad range of technical and business topics.  Availability of training programs.  Support for volunteer activities in the local community, as well as key programs like Corporate Services Corp where I spend a month with a team of 10 IBMers addressing IT challenges in central Africa.  Respect that comes from association with the IBM brand and history.  Relentless re-invention toward emerging and strategic areas of technology.
Cons: Not as much flexibility for mid/low level managers as their would be in a small organization.  Be aware that skills atrophy will result in minimal compensation increases and eventually needing to locate alternative roles or even company -- but this is reality of working in a tech business.

Pros: IBM is huge with 10K's of products, 340K employees, and unlimited potential. When you figure out how to work with and use IBM's size, you can delight your clients, make a good living, work with people who become your friends, and on rare occasions get an amazing reward like going to Hawaii with friend for Best of IBM (only 1K go).
Cons: IBM is huge with 10K's of products, 340K employees, and unlimited ways to get lost or feel unwanted, plus some areas just don't succeed. It takes brains, heart, guts and a little bit of luck, but that is true anywhere.

Pros: IBM provides many resources available to you regardless what job you may have. IBM has global locations, wherever you travel to, you can find colleagues there who can lend a helping hand. IBM has good managers who normally are eager to help to make you successful. IBM has increasingly become Open Source software driving development company, its services and technical skills have been up to date in every area. IBM provides relatively flexible working hours so that employees can have their own working habbit to be very productive.
Cons: Since the company is very big, in some cases the communications between leaders and workers may not be as good as it can be.

Pros: Decent pay and benefits.  Good remote work policy.
Cons: LOTs of bureaucracy.  The company is turning into EMC...lots of hacks and disjointed groups.  IBM is struggling has been laying off 3 times a year, for the past 6 years.  Leaders are very focused on their own gain and are not focused on the customer.  For some reason, they are not replacing executive leaders like Microsoft and Google have.  Their products don't work well, and there are layers and layers and layers of management and policies and blah.  Moral is low and people fearing for their jobs.  Lastly, IBM hands out jobs to relatives/friends of former executives.  There are young people in management roles that have no business there.  This company has not yet turned around.  The consolidate divisions and say the new unit is profitable.  Silly finance tricks like that.

Pros: Good resume filler (that’s it)
Cons:
Management so disconnected from the actual work, truly unbelievable. All they care about is hiring enough people. Placing people in rolls they are prepared for? Nope. Paying people what they are worth? Nope. Overall interest in the employees and their lives outside of work? Nope.

When leaving, my manager told me I was making a “big mistake”. What kind of manager does that? All they would push is the hiring number they had to reach. That’s it, you don’t matter to them at all.

The leader of the office once said “I sometimes forget you guys have families” to us employees at the company picnic. Awesome! Way to reassure me that this place is a terrible work environment. 

Terrible training plan, huge disconnect from “core” IBM. Embarrassing to even say I contributed to that office.

Pros: Decent salary, Large and long-established company
Cons:
Experience will largely depend on co-workers and your team's management, but more often than not, they'll promise the customer too much too soon, and then development is left with the difficulty and stress of making it happen.

Since I've worked at IBM, I always had the feeling that they sort of fell behind after the tech boom. IBM used to be a company that was known for innovation, and these days it just seems like IBM is looking at the competition and asking, "How can we do something like that but offer it to the customer for a cheaper price?!"

Pros: At IBM research you get the opportunity to change groups and join projects you like, that can allow you to change and redefine your career as times/interests change. They WANT you to learn, grow and contribute. Career change/evolution within the company itself is always possible.
Cons: For some reason for the past 10 years (2010 - 2020) you feel some parts of the company's technology (along with stock market capitalization) falling behind compared to competitors. It could be the dilemma of a leading incumbent to protect legacy tech. But, things are starting to change, hopefully, after the new CEO (Arvind Krishna)

Pros: Opportunity for professional growth and advancement, whether you're on a management track or technical track in your career.
Cons: Often (though far from always) subject to a "one size fits all" mentality when it comes to job role, education/training, etc. Decisions sometimes made/dictated at the highest levels to be applied to everyone with a particular title, often requiring a lot of additional work/overhead with little perceived benefit. People ("resources") in the same role/band are not always interchangeable.

Pros: Work Like balance is probably one of the best things IBM has going for it provided that you take advantage of what they are offering.  Otherwise you can get sucked in and commit way too much time to work.
Cons: The promotion system to rating have recently been disconnected allowing them to give praise but hold off on promoting and paying more.  It really boils down to a "trick" to keeping you working for them for less money.  On a different topic IBM is a big company and they say you can move around when you first start.  I would say that this is not always the case.  Depending how the business is doing and your area they will often hold you back.

Pros: IBM really provides it all. If you want to work in a certain area of IT, the company does provide support tools to achieve those goals.  Also, if you are an experienced project manager, you will have the opportunity to manage very large, complex installations within a few short years.  The culture of IBM differs from Deloitte and Accenture in that it has a much more rigid hierarchy and is truly a corporate environment.  The blue suit rule still stands.
Cons: IBM is really a mature organization, therefore, newly hired college graduates are expected to act within their roles and not make waves.  Innovation that matters is true, but only if there has been a thorough business case brought to bear.

Pros: Very innovative company with incredible potential. Fairly quick on moving into emerging technologies. Decent education opportunities available to employees even if initial training is terrible.
Cons: The majority of managers are too worried about covering their own butts and only focus on the numbers, so the actual quality of work is terrible. Countless employees with amazing talent are practically forced out of the company due to management not showing recognition for their hard work. New employees are many times left to fend for themselves due to inadequate initial training. Management is so worried about losing back fill spots that they keep incompetent contractors around wasting space instead of working to replace them.

Pros: The pay. Good pay and easy work. I have simple projects with lots of detail. The deadlines are flexible as long as I am making progress. The pay is great but since I am with a contractor, no benefits.
Cons: The lack of job security. One week im secure for years, the next week I am on the chopping block. Very nerve racking. There seems to be always a budget issue. Apparently it is possible to go from contractor status to full time regular status....but we shall see. Also there is no teaching. You need to learn the job yourself or you sink.

Pros:
People - One of the most enjoyable aspects of working at IBM is the people.  Very talented, smart, motivated, and friendly people.
Challenging Environment - With clients all over the Fortune 500, you can rest assured tat you will be engaged solving business problems and devising solutions on every engagement.
Knowledge Sharing Tools - IBM has made a huge effort in implementing internal knowledge sharing tools that are top-notch and allow you to find the information you need and learn from what other have done in the organization.  The latest web 2.0 emphasis is remarkable!
Available information
Benefits
Cons: Compensation is below industry although it is said that we are competitive.

Pros:
The pay is competitive and the number of vacation days is also good.  The flexibility of working from home can be very nice depending on your personal needs.  I enjoyed the ability to work later in the day.  The company culture is relaxed.

I personally like the attitude of Sam P. and I agree with his direction/strategy.
Cons:
It is difficult to move within the company from one position to another.  I felt locked in my current role for the past several years.  It seems like this is only particular to my department.  Working from home can also kill your work life balance since you are always checking your email when you're at home.

I do not like the middle management because they make very important decisions and it looks like they have no idea how things work in the "front lines".

Pros:
-Overworking means that you're able to learn a lot of new things: I'd think 1 year at IBM is equivalent to ~2 years at another company: experience-wise
-Exposure to Customers and designing customer solutions
-Flex time, Can work any time you want.
Cons:
-Complete Lack of Respect for Employees by Management, No loyalty to employees
-Unrealistic exceptions for EPS/Profit that when failed to meet, is then used as excuse to mistreat employees.
-Long work hours for no benefit.
-Unedible cafeteria food.
-Less Pay:  I actually didn't feel like I 'wanted' more money, but the job I took after IBM paid >30% more than IBM.
-Currently very low morale: In the last 3 years or so all the 'water cooler' talk and been negative and depressing.
-Lack of long term friendships:  Because of all the turnover and layoffs and moving around people, 100% of my friends had since come and gone.
-Embarrassing to say work at IBM.  Because of all the Cons, it got to a point where it was embarrassing to say I worked for IBM when speaking with neighbors.

Pros:
1) IBM has name recognition
2) IBM has a long history
Cons:
Too many cons.  
1) Dog eat dog environment.  No team work or comradery.  Everyone is out for themselves only
2) Given accounts that have had little to any software sales in the past 5 years!  Quota of $1750K and the history of the sales in these accounts for the past 5 years was under a million dollars!
3) Mgmt will never, ever support you.  Dog eat dog.  
4) the processes they have in place are so mind numbing, frustrating.  Laptop problems arise on a weekly basis.  Have to send it in to someplace across the country to have it fixed!  Frustrating and not productive
5) First line managers are basically baby sitters.  Have zero power and are hired to be micro managers. They are on top of you every second.
6) No work/life balance.  They expect you to work 12+ hours a day.  They monitor you on SameTime.

THE WORST ENVIRONMENT TO WORK IN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Pros: Work from home, lots of vacation time when you been there 10 yrs, occasional comp time, lots of sick time should you need it.
Cons: High stress, High attrition rate in Finance and never backfilled so work gets piled on to those that are left, no raise 10 out of 15 yrs, horrible pay, 401K change this year to not get paid until Dec 31 and need to be employed on Dec 15 in order to get it. Bonus structure gets worse it seems every year- supposed to be profit sharing and even with company having record profits our bonuses do not go up. No career path anymore. Only concerned with

Pros: I enjoyed a wide variety of work experiences with IBM, giving me the opportunity to learn many new things quickly and be placed in challenging learning situations. Huge company with the power to send you many places and do many things
Cons: "Blue Goo"- Sometimes it is incredibly difficult or frustrating to get your problems fixed or questions answered because of the vast bureaucracy. My first day I was issued a lemon for a work computer, the process to get it replaced was difficult and extremely inconvenient as a traveling consultant, and after I finally got it replaced the 'new' machine had it's own host of issues.

Pros: The best aspect of working for IBM was working with a great team of people.  My co-workers were knowledgeable,  friendly, and took pride in their work.  The hours were flexible and this came in handy when I had to take my parents to doctor appointments.  The pay was great and the medical benefits were good.
Cons: The base pay was very good but we didn't get raises for five years.  The team leads got the raises and big bonuses.  There wasn't much room for advancement.  The team leads were awarded all the high visibility projects so there wasn't much opportunity to grow your leadership skills.

Pros: Global company with huge portfolio of advanced software and hardware products, competitive cloud platform (SoftLayer) and good (but not great) service capabilities.  Vast sales and distribution network across all industries, strong ties to government institutions (in most countries), access to the largest companies across the globe.  Solid (but rapidly deteriorating) technical and consulting know-how.  Attempts to "move decisions closer to the clients" are laudable, but drown in the sea of incompetence.
Cons: Mid-level management structure and their lack of skills (both technical and people-management) are absolutely atrocious.  There are layers upon layers of "pointy-hair managers" - every other Dilbert cartoon seems to be inspired by IBM. 2015 EPS target drives all decision making, cost-cutting replaces innovation, and there is shortage of ideas where the new growth should come from.

Pros: The best reason to work here now is to gain experience, learn what you can, and use that experience, knowledge and reference on a resume, in seeking bigger and better opportunities.  Unless you are one of the few to make it to the top.
Cons: Having to do more with less can only go so far.  Persons are loaded with work until they fail by not being able to do it all in a quality manner.  Then you are evaluated in not getting your job done and not contributing as much as expected.  All for earnings per share and executive compensation.

Pros: They are RARE, but, if you are lucky, you can find one, MAYBE two IBM managers in a 20+ year career that actually care about the people and are professional.
Cons: What was once a stellar example of reciprocal fidelity and mutual respect and professionality in the 70s/80s is now a maze of backstabbing, obfuscation, double-talk, and outright lies. No, I wasn't even cut in the "Project Chrome" resource action, but I may end my tenure shortly and by choice. Piece of advice, don't work here, this isn't knee-jerk, it's honest. Look elsewhere because I haven't inflated my comments, they are accurate, I am not angry, I am disappointed, and that is far far worse. Find a company that will value and nurture you to give them your absolute best, but don't look here.

Pros: Flexibility to work from home or anywhere.  Flexible hours.  Great colleagues located around the world.  Occasional opportunity for international travel.  Solid company reputation helps resume.  Interesting work.  Work-from-home option (if not a road warrior travelling consultant) is great for employees with children.  Road-warrior consulting allowed some young single consultants to have little to no home expenses (crashed on weekends with friends or justified staying over weekend at client location to save airfare).
Cons: Raises were very minimal and opportunities to advance were very limited.  Constant drive to layoff employees and convert to contractors kept morale low.

Pros: IBM is such a huge company that there are many opportunities available. Chances are, if you end up in a position you don't like, you can transfer to a different position although it's much easier if you transfer within a division. Of course there are many opportunities here to work on stuff that really matters in society. The company's restructuring efforts may finally be paying off this year.
Cons: Since the company is so large, sometimes it's difficult to turn the ship around. Change is happening, but slowly. Some of the tools we have to use only make the job more difficult. It's easy to be lured in to a job or physical geography with no growth, as some locations are only downsizing.

Pros:
IBM is a great place to work, to grow, to learn and even to reinvent yourself.
IBM has many resources to help employees achieve their goals.
IBM is a company built on values
IBM employees are very talented
IBM values corporate citizenship in areas of education, environment, health, community, development of less privileged communities and countries
Cons: With 28 years with IBM I have seen changes to IBM and to the industry. When I was looking for a job out of college there were many companies that talked about "Full Employment" - this is a concept from the past where no one ever got laid off. You could get fired based on performance, but not laid off because your job went away or it went to another part of the world.

Pros: IBM Reputation with existing customers, technology
Cons: Management that is cross pollinated into different divisions where they have no technical expertise to run a business unit. Questions around ethics of management

Pros: Still some good people are there. Decent pay and benefits. The company does care about diversity (except for the layoffs of older employees dubiously called "skills transformation.") The company has a few good senior leaders.
Cons:
In software sales for large accounts, you get paid based on a subjective judgement rather than how much you sold. You have to prove that you worked on a deal. Many people who helped on large deals get nothing, and then those people get PIPs for lack of performance.
The company is still driven by EPS rather than by making customers successful and employees feel valued.

Pros: Amazing technology company on the forefront of leading technologies such as AI; Flexible work-life arrangements; Great people and community overall
Cons: Tendency to react in extreme ways to potential or actual downturns in financial results, which creates a vicious cycle of hiring/firing, offshoring/onshoring, etc. focused more on near-term gain rather than long-results; IBM gets in its own way with this behavior and often promotes those who engage in it

Pros: They have state-of-the-art technology in areas such as blockchain, cloud, AI and robotic process automation. They offer great resources to learn about the different technologies and how they apply to certain industries. The hours usually aren’t bad (8-10 hours/day) and the people I’ve worked with are nice and helpful.
Cons: It’s easy to get lost in the crowd. IBM has recently hired a lot of entry-level consultants, so it can be difficult to get on a project, especially within the technology area and/or industry you’re interested in.

Pros: I've had the pleasure of working with the smartest people ever in my professional career.  The experiences are fantastic - super interesting projects for wonderful clients.
Cons: While health benefits are still pretty good, pay increases and bonus pay, in particular, have suffered due to lagging financial performance.  Bonus pay has been close to non-existent many years.   This is unfortunate as most large US employers are performing very strongly and rewarding their employees with at least a 20% bonus.  Ours is closer to 2%.

Pros: IBM encourages employee learning and development. Their Think40 program requires employees to log 40 hours/year in personal or professional development, and supports this requirement with a seemingly endless library of webinars on an array of topics. You can also log your own activities towards this goal (books, conferences, professional webinars, etc).
Cons: Joining IBM means becoming a small piece of a giant organization. As such, when IBM's financial situation becomes unfavorable, they will reduce costs, and an easy way to do so is to reduce headcount. Staff who are laid off receive 90 days’ notice and one-month severance pay, regardless of tenure. Client facing roles are not immune. Remaining staff are told to "lean in" and are left to pick up the pieces and take on additional workload.  Re: benefits, IBM's 401k contributions are made at year end, so if they eliminate staff during the year, they don't have to contribute as much money.

Pros: Everyone in the team is nice and want to see you successful (isn't always the case at tech companies). Most of management have technical background. There looks to be plenty of opportunities to lead and advance, both in and out of job description. Having Arvind as CEO has led to some excellent decisions to give the company direction such as NewCo spin off and Red Hat purchase. I hope to see what else he has up his sleeves to make IBM great again!
Cons: From what I can tell, there is two much bureaucracy in management. Definitely not as bad as I have seen elsewhere but something to work on, lots of chains of commands and approvals. Also too many buzz words and acronyms. I get that its the name of the game sometimes in tech but it's nice to know what is going on behind the fancy words from management.

Pros: The people who work in the design org at IBM are very supportive, whether it's a fellow teammate or a manager. I feel like I can ask anyone a question and get what I need to do well. The design studio is a very collaborative and fun environment.
Cons: Design at IBM is quite young. As a result, not all of the teams at the company really know what to do with designers. We try to advocate for being involved in the entire product development process, but we're sometimes brought in at the last minute or the time our work takes to do is de-prioritized. Across most of the company, there isn't a very strong process in place, and it's hard for design to truly, seamlessly collaborate with our partners in Dev and Project Management. Which can be frustrating.

Pros: IBM invest in their people. IBM provide the training you need to succeed in your job. You can obtain certifications and badges all for free through the company. They instill in you the importance of being a life learner. You can do all different types of jobs and never leave the company. You can be your authentic self at work. I love how they are an inclusive employer and focused on hiring neurodivergent employees.
Cons: Diversity is in their DNA but when you look up the management chain, it's not always easy to see someone who looks like you but they are working to change that across the company.

Pros: You get paid and most of the people are nice.
Cons: Most hires in the last 2 years have been sub-par and lack basic skills. We work with self made applications that don't work as intended. There are too many siloed tribes that don't communicate or integrate well. Senior leadership withholds information necessary to plan ahead. Procurement and Finance take months to even order the things your team needs to build the next project.

Pros: IBM Reputation with existing customers, technology
Cons: Management that is cross pollinated into different divisions where they have no technical expertise to run a business unit. Questions around ethics of management

Pros: Still some good people are there. Decent pay and benefits. The company does care about diversity (except for the layoffs of older employees dubiously called "skills transformation.") The company has a few good senior leaders.
Cons:
In software sales for large accounts, you get paid based on a subjective judgement rather than how much you sold. You have to prove that you worked on a deal. Many people who helped on large deals get nothing, and then those people get PIPs for lack of performance.
The company is still driven by EPS rather than by making customers successful and employees feel valued.

Pros: Amazing technology company on the forefront of leading technologies such as AI; Flexible work-life arrangements; Great people and community overall
Cons: Tendency to react in extreme ways to potential or actual downturns in financial results, which creates a vicious cycle of hiring/firing, offshoring/onshoring, etc. focused more on near-term gain rather than long-results; IBM gets in its own way with this behavior and often promotes those who engage in it

They offer great resources to learn about the different technologies and how they apply to certain industries. The hours usually aren’t bad (8-10 hours/day) and the people I’ve worked with are nice and helpful.
Cons: It’s easy to get lost in the crowd. IBM has recently hired a lot of entry-level consultants, so it can be difficult to get on a project, especially within the technology area and/or industry you’re interested in.

Bonus pay has been close to non-existent many years.   This is unfortunate as most large US employers are performing very strongly and rewarding their employees with at least a 20% bonus.  Ours is closer to 2%.

Re: benefits, IBM's 401k contributions are made at year end, so if they eliminate staff during the year, they don't have to contribute as much money.

There looks to be plenty of opportunities to lead and advance, both in and out of job description. Having Arvind as CEO has led to some excellent decisions to give the company direction such as NewCo spin off and Red Hat purchase. I hope to see what else he has up his sleeves to make IBM great again!

Also too many buzz words and acronyms. I get that its the name of the game sometimes in tech but it's nice to know what is going on behind the fancy words from management.

Cons: Design at IBM is quite young. As a result, not all of the teams at the company really know what to do with designers. We try to advocate for being involved in the entire product development process, but we're sometimes brought in at the last minute or the time our work takes to do is de-prioritized. Across most of the company, there isn't a very strong process in place, and it's hard for design to truly, seamlessly collaborate with our partners in Dev and Project Management. Which can be frustrating.

They instill in you the importance of being a life learner. You can do all different types of jobs and never leave the company. You can be your authentic self at work. I love how they are an inclusive employer and focused on hiring neurodivergent employees.
Cons: Diversity is in their DNA but when you look up the management chain, it's not always easy to see someone who looks like you but they are working to change that across the company.

Pros: You get paid and most of the people are nice.
Cons: Most hires in the last 2 years have been sub-par and lack basic skills. We work with self made applications that don't work as intended. There are too many siloed tribes that don't communicate or integrate well. Senior leadership withholds information necessary to plan ahead. Procurement and Finance take months to even order the things your team needs to build the next project.

Pros: Large company, lots of opportunities. Salary grows slowly even for top performers, but is quite competitive. Great support for education, patent development, and opportunity to leverage great technology.
Cons: Process quagmire's abound, and building software here is neither "Agile" nor agile. Work life balance is completely out the window - 60 hr weeks are norm, 80 are frequent, and 100 is at least a couple of times a year. Latest of (very frequent) senior management changes sees more people with a long IBM history parachuted into an business where they have no domain experience, and make predictably bad decisions as a result.

Pros: Innovative, very smart people, fast paced environment. Opportunity to work on some of the most interesting projects in the world.  Want to take care of their customers.
Cons: Areas competing for the same business in dysfunction ways, even if people want to collborate their performance metrics discourage colllaboration, broken processes that may make it difficult for you to achieve your performance goals, large groups of people moved into positions they don't want without asking them, historically large layoffs even of top performers. I have been at IBM for 30 years and this is not the great company it used to be. Admittedly, they are trying to make it better. This being said, count yourselves lucky if you get a job there for at least a while.

Pros: The amazing minds I have met and the amount of determination I have seen in trying to please this company.
Cons: The lies. You do better than you're taught and still get told you're not doing well enough. I can only wonder if my 'poor performance' stems from lack of quality training on these applications that IBM is buying. What are we really doing in the client's office when developers are 'punished' for providing quality solutions? 45 hours a week is what I'm contracted to provide. No OT pay, but my work ethic pushes about 60 hours a week out of me. Two of three project managers value my work, but the one that can fire me says that I don't contribute. Me == confused.

Pros: The pay and benefits are very good.  The people I worked with were always willing to help and were very good at their jobs.  Annual reviews were fair and reflected the work done.  Hard work and job excellence are rewarded.
Cons: More work is being done by fewer people and work life balance is suffering as a result.There is There is a lot of work and a lot of overtime, to the point where it's difficult if not impossible to get all work completed and completed well.

Pros:
Once you settle down you can flexibly manage your time.
Virtual relationship with your manager
Work independently.
You work for top class clients in major cities across the world
Promotion process is straight forward; you get promoted once you meet and document the predefined requirements.
It does everything you can imagine.
A lot of smart hard working consultants who always delivers what is promised.
Cons:
Top heavy.
Too much overheads for non profitable internal works.
GBS and few other divisions feed other non-sense divisions.
Slow to market and new technology demand due to its size and decision making hierarchy
Inversley undiverse
One lump sum 401K match at the end of the year; if you leave before year end you lose year worth 401K (I am not making this up).
You have no control over your raise. you get what they decide.
Bonus is a joke.
Too many org changes and moving corporate goals

Pros: Few companies in the world have the depth of intellectual property and brand value as IBM.  Many great products and services.  Committed to maintain a research focus to ensure long-term success.  This is a great institution and one that will survive the transformation taking place in enterprise IT.  There are many good jobs to be had in IBM.
Cons: However, it is not always a great place to work.  Unrealistically high quotas for most sales staff means year over year pay cuts.  An HR organization that is more committed to protecting the institution than seeing to the development and training of staff.  An unrelenting cost reduction focus that stifles innovation around new service offering.

Pros: Prestigious company with innovative solutions... great to be able to say you work at IBM.  All really depends on department, manager, colleagues, etc.  A lot of smart and talented employees both full-time and contractors.
Cons: Company is made up of over 50% contractors.  (Could be as high as 80% according to WSJ article.)  Lay offs of both contractors (despite renewed contracts for years) and full-time employees are abrupt and often handled very poorly.  People are viewed as a number.  As a contractor, don't expect a rate increase no matter how long you are there.  Not even a cost-of-living increase.   A lot depends on managers.  The department is only as good as the manager... the morale is only as good as the manager.  Your work can be inspiring, satisfying, and growth oriented depending on the manager.

Pros: There were lots of internal resources within the company but it was mostly a serve yourself setup. There was very little support in helping you become better at what you do.
Cons: The big problem I hit while there was an underwhelming direction from leadership on priorities. Building certain types of software requires attention to detail and there was very little paid to things that made certain products usable. All the decisions makers only cared about having a list of check boxes they could mark with no bearing on utility, quality, or impact it had on the overall sustainability of the project.

Pros:
IBM is making a deep investment in the data security portfolio. Lots of solid acquisitions (QRadar, Big Fix, Resilient Systems) Compensation for sales position is competitive. Deep penetration into the fortune 500 with relationships at the very top make large enterprise sales possible.
It is possible to reinvent your career at IBM. IBM enables and encourages this.
Cons:
Channel sales are a mess. The programs are difficult to understand and even more difficult for business partners to get paid on. Most VAR's in the security space don't work with IBM. This is a huge opportunity missed.

The culture is dated. Too many people who have been at IBM for way too long with dated, unproductive practices. Meetings that result in meetings so they can schedule more meetings.

Healthcare is very expensive for such a large company

Pros: I worked in the systems business in field sales.  The work life balance was good.  The pay was mediocre.  Since revenue was dropping each quarter the axe was always falling.
Cons: Eventually after all the cuts the only one left where the 20+ year IBMers who where married to IBM.  Anybody who had talent and was not afraid to leave left.  Their are still a few good folks left.  I wish them well.  My advice is if you decide to leave be prepared to be terminated the same day.  Do not tell them where you are going.  They have no right to know.

Pros:
- Many good people
- Good work/life balance on the right team
- Free coffee and snacks
- Remote work allowed
Cons:
- Hiring standards quite low. Definitely not the best of the best
- Low pay. Non existent bonuses
- On call with no pay
- Very low morale
- Constant reorgs and layoffs
- Endless bureaucracy
- Very poor product vision and not communicated clearly. Nobody knows why they're working on what they're working on or where we'll be at in three months.

Don't buy into the Watson hype. It's not any better than traditional IBM.

If you want to punch the clock or this is your first job out of school, it's an OK choice. If you want to do something meaningful or have pride in your work, look elsewhere. If the team requires on call, run away fast.

Pros: Good benefits. Professional atmosphere, flexible with family
Cons: Poor working hours, badly disorganized. Very little training. I was hired for a new team, it was implied that there were multiple shifts to choose from however about 2 months into the job we found out that the only shifts were second and third. Took a long time to get access to everything we needed for the job. Once complete, there was only one person to train 4 other people, and that person was assigned to other projects. We were then sent out to struggle on our own.

Pros:
- as IBM is a huge conglomerate, you can have many different career experiences in one place.
- despite all the negative press, the company has a strong balance sheet and strong product margins, i.e. good stability and a cautious view on taking risk
- good benefits, though like most companies they pare back - 401k match (up to $16k annually), deferred comp for high income earners, low-cost medical.
- if you are good at your work, work/life balance is at least possible
Cons:
- need to negotiate starting salary strongly - raises/promotions are very, very rare
- bonuses even on sales plans seem totally subjective and random
- 60% of your colleagues suck, and somehow the resource actions never seem to get those people
- near constant organizational and territory change disrupts client and partner relationships, a competitive disadvantage and leads to a lot of internal "self-promotion"

Pros: Fresh college grads get much needed experience and a foot in the door,  a lot of resources available to you to grow as a professional, very laid-back and relaxed atmosphere, great work/life balance
Cons: Salary and benefits are not even competitive for the area, career growth and prospects are virtually non-existent or entirely too long, low morale among employees, location itself is a little too remote, policies in place without any justification to their existence, project deployment is slow and the work is often unsatisfying

Pros: Wide variety of work. Lots of talented people. Opportunity to learn. Design Thinking. A good place to gain experience before you jump to a thriving company. They’ve been around for 100+-year-old tech company. (Not sure if that’s a pro or a con.)
Cons: Soul-crushing executive leadership. Feels like a sinking ship. No 401K match until December so that they don’t pay the match if you leave or get laid off. Insultingly low bonuses. (Would be better if they gave you nothing at all.) Seeing the CEO grinning while sitting between Donald Trump and Jared Kushner was a source of embarrassment. (Although she wasn’t alone.)

Pros:
- Up to 6% 401K matching
- 3 month paid maternity & paternity leave
- Great internal education opportunities (tons of resources) although this isn't relevant to Salesforce
Cons:
- Make the company money or you're laid off
- Massive company with slow, outdated processes and systems
- Terrible culture
- Offshore devs
- Slow promotions
- Unclear career path
- Poor Salesforce education and no encouragement to seek certifications
- Low salary with poor bonus structure

Pros: There are incredible people - both young and old - here who really care about the success of new hires and clients and the general progress/change of the "old" IBM to the "new". There has always been an ethical leadership aspect to the culture and history of IBM - granted, it's still big corp, but it's clear to me that ethics and security is important to the cloud sales team. There's a wealth of knowledge, resources, and help that the company is willing to invest in the employees. A great starting point for any career to learn about/get exposed to what else is out there while getting advice from both young and old connections in almost any industry.
Cons: Very large company - a lot of moving parts. Slow-moving bureaucracy - official decisions takes a while to solidify and then will change shortly after solidification.

Pros:
The company experience has been extremely positive.

There are great and challenging projects where they can place you to gain incredible experience or to exercise your already extensive knowledge.

I have spoken to many peers who have been around for 10+ years and love the culture and everything around the company.

The company has recently been bought by IBM but will remain to continue under the TAOS flag while gaining access to the IBM perks and vast library of knowledge.

They continue to put time and effort into your education by scheduling lunch and learns that you can attend or later view at your leisure.

There are various ways to make extra money, by either passing exams or working additional hours, or interviewing candidates, on top of their compensation package and bonus.
Cons: I have not experienced any!

Pros:
A large company
Teams are great
Wonderful to work with one and one as well as in a team settings
1st line and 2nd line managements often demonstrate good leadership
Cons:
Lack of incentives for upper mobility, enhance loyalty and ownership. As a result, bulk of the workforce often failed to aligned with company's strategic solutions. 

Historically, company's strategic solutions seem came late into the game or entered in way too early.

Pros:
Endless career options throughout the company, different locations, lots of opportunity to work from home, Work life balance is promoted and you can usually have management support to adjust schedule when necessary. Great education possibilities, IBM payed for my MBA. 
Some benefits are industry leading and the company attempts to keep up with the market.
Cons:
Cheap vacation allowances - 10 years to get 4 weeks is absolutely ridiculous
Your manager can make or break your job satisfaction, they have too much control over what you can and can't do human resources policy wise.  
Managers don't adhere to policies or don't support them and you don't get to take advantage of the great programs IBM has.
Poor first line managers

Pros: Stable position once you are inside.  The networking can be very useful. There is a culture of mentoring and networking that takes a certain amount of effort to get into, but does yield decent information.
Cons: Bureacratic. Poor attention to quality. Overall software product strategy is lacking. Lots of vague, insincere, old-style rah-rah.  Management tends to bring in their friends rather than hire for competency. Project schedules are set without understanding the details of what the commitments entail.  The product designs tend to be overelaborated and inelegant and user-hostile. They have a rigid, waterfall product management template AND they are attempting to ram agile development into it.

Pros: IBM is a large company with a long, established history. Generally speaking, people know who IBM is--across the globe. The global reach is an additional benefit: provides more stability in the crazy global economy and makes it veyr interesting in terms of working with colleagues in different parts of the world and getting their view of things.
Cons: The company is so large that it's very difficult to navigate. More importantly, the size becomes a greater issue as more of the workforce is remote. I've worked with people for years whom I have never met. Additionally, there is very little consideration of the issues associated with working with global counterparts: ie: the fact that the people with whom you're trying to meet/work are 12 or 14 hours apart.

Pros: As a large company, there are many divisions, fields, and locations from which to choose.  This advantage gets lost, though, when opportunities come up in different locations--the company, which used to stand for "I've Been Moved," will not pay for your move--you pay out of your own pocket (except if you are an executive, of course).
Cons: Outsourcing, layoffs, increasing workload for remaining employees, working weekends with no recognition or extra pay, no pay increases 2 of 4 years.  If you want a promotion--good luck.  If you want a job in a different location, you pay for the move yourself.  No travel, no Christmas parties, no retirement package, no stock options--just more and more work for the same amount of pay.

Pros: It is a Global Company, recognised and respected throughout United States of America and globally.  IBM has been in business for a very long time and has several Innovation and research on the pipeline. It is a one of the largest service and technology company. It also exposes to several different sector's, naming a few would be Finance, Automobile, Healthcare, Insurance, Pharma and Biotech.
Cons:
It is very large and growth has been slow for the united states employees, cut back all the time and it is a survival game.

It would help to keep jobs on shore since the customer and business presence is in the United States.

Pros: Benefits, they are still great compared to other Large companies, but slowing losing ground.  Working with a great group of people, it really does feel like a family.  Flexibility to work from home a couple days a week.  I am actually more productive on these days.   Flexibility with work hours, ability to start a little later if needed, or take a long lunch for a doctors / dentist appointment.  Most first line managers are wonderful.  Recognition when a job is well done.  Continual effort in fostering of teamwork.
Cons: The constant fear of 'the job' going over seas.  Upper management is too quick to say yes to every poor idea.

Pros: job security, big company insurance package, ability to move up - but limited.  I met a lot of great people at the job and still keep in touch with them.
Cons: monotonous, "Office Space" movie-esque, typical office politics, you are definitely faceless and the management does not have a clean hold on what goes on.  I don't understand how management can make suggestions and implement action plans when they have never picked up the phone and dealt with the problems we had to.  the managers don't even know the equipment.  I made the mistake of ONCE asking for help on a call and the manager looked at me blankly and tried to come up with some kind of answer.  It was oh so very painful.

Pros: Salary,  company resources, business reputation.
Cons:
IBM does not value its employees.   Treats people like commodities.    Senior management view themselves at the chosen ones, and the rest of us as "resources".     In my view, they have no morals,  no character and no soul.     They are not creators of wealth and jobs, rather they are exploiters.    In the past, I have seen some great leaders at IBM.   No more.

I think the future of IBM as a company is not good.    The present culture is not sustainable.   They are throwing away too many good people.

I remain thankful for the years I have had at IBM and hope to remain employed there for a few more years.    I could not in good conscience recommend it to anyone else.

Pros: Most of the engineers you work worth are over-qualified for the work asked of them.  Everyone is polite and professional.  Junior software developers will be technically challenged.  It looks good on your resume. Great career track for a FEW management-bound people.
Cons: Salaries are being reduced thru raises which don't keep up with inflation.  Everyone worries about being fired -- everyone is ranked, and bottom 2.5% are whacked every 6 months.  Medical and dental benefits are expensive for families.  IBM's interpretation of Agile software development methology has turned the place into a sweatshop.  Every Band 9 ($120K+) faces a "move up or move out" dilemma.

Pros: Good 401k match, good health benefits only for employee
Cons: No work life balance, work nights weekends, a lot of travel, no salary increments unless you get a 2+ or 1 rating or get promoted

Pros: The benefits, such as health benefits and 401K are very good.  Resources within IBM are great as well.  The intranet and all its contents are great resources for employees at IBM.
Cons: I do not enjoy working for such a large company.  There is excessive regulation and rigid conformity to formal rules  working for such a large company where I have never had that working for other companies in the past.  By being a consultant that travels, we have to file taxes in each state we travel to.  The per diem rates we receive through IBM are considerably lower then that of the GSA federal rates and we as the employee lose out in the end.

Pros: Nice environment for supporting outsourced accounts and often able to work at customer sites or remotely. IBM offers competitive salaries and educational opportunities for some positions.
Cons: IBM is one of the leaders in off-shoring jobs and if you're in a role that's offshored, you have about a 90% chance of being cut in a resource action.  They target folks who have been around 10 to 15 years and maxed out on salaries. They start by lowering your performance rating without supporting evidence and once that happens, you're history. They supposedly give you an opportunity to find another position in the company but once your names on the cut list, that won't happen.  The folks who stay are chosen based on personality vs performance within the group.

Pros: Compensation and benefits were nice while they lasted. The people that are typically on your team are great people (can't always say the same for management).
Cons: Baffling decisions made by management, starting at the first-line level. The decision-making gets worse the higher you go. They seem to be content with shooting themselves in the foot and missing constant opportunities to grab onto something great.

Pros: It used to be a fabulous company.  NOT now, not during the past 10 years.  Read Endicott Alliance employee postings if you don't believe me.
Cons: Work 80 +hrs per week, no weekends off.   Vacation time, when able to go, is spent working. Very top heavy management that lacks technical skills.  Constant churn, with year after year after year after year after year after year of layoffs that keep moral low. Good employees forced into poor performance reviews - just so management can meet its numbers.  I know.  I worked both technical and mgt in my 30 year career.  Employees are nothing but "resources".  The way I was forced to treat people as a manager made me sick.  DON"T WORK HERE, young people.  This is a stodgy old company that will only inhibit your career. And the pay is much better elsewhere.

Pros: The pros are pretty limited and so are the reasons to work here. It is a big company with many clients so that does present some opportunity to get experiences with different clients, although still the work may be repetitive or not at the upper tier of consulting work.
Cons: The projects are boring and low level IT projects as opposed to those that are truly strategic. In my time with the company a majority of the projects in my practice area were a failure or added no real value to the client. Career growth is terrible as management does a terrible job managing resources and basically only see resources as bodies to bill utilization, without caring about whether a project aligns with career aspirations or current skills at all.

Pros: If you are willing to work hard, have the skills that are desired by IBM and you are not marked for a resource action, I have always found that there is many opportunities available at this large company.
Cons: In my position, the biggest con is IBM's lack of work and life balance. I am expected to be on call 24x7 each and every day of the year as well as I must be reachable while on vacation.  This is not an easy situation to live with, but is what I have chosen to do in order to remain employed.

Pros: You'll meet a lot of smart people from all walks of life. You'll learn a lot about selling to and making offerings for the largest companies in the world. Senior management can be inspirational and incisive.
Cons: IBM is like a retirement home for once-great software (or at least once-successful software). A retirement home that is well connected to the government and has strong PR, but really no hope of resuscitation. An east-coast retirement home that looks yearningly at successful Silicon Valley and Seattle youngsters playing volleyball in the sun, and wishes it could be young and matter again. But it's just not in the DNA.

Pros:
- Name Recognition
- Ability to work in a large company with a massive scope
- Able to see a broad area of world technical progress
Cons:
- Lack of connection between employees and managers. Managers change more than once per year and more often than not don't work in the same office as their employees. When year-end reviews happen the results are inconsistent. 

- Random layoffs and job stress
- Expectation of continuous long hours
- Poor track record on raises and promotions

Pros: Medical dental 401k Benefits are excellent. Employees have the ability to reinvent themselves by switching teams. Take on international assignments, take on stretch assignments which is temporarily working in a new position. Giving the employee the chance to "try on" the job to see if it's a good fit, without fully committing to it.
Cons: Extremely hard to break into management. I've been identified as having leadership qualities,taken the required leadership courses. Expressed my desire to manage. Taken on more responsibilities. Excellent performance reviews. But with the constant management shuffle above me, no one to champion for me.  Mentorship is basically non existent.

Pros: IBM is still one of the most respected companies to have on your resume. Their commitment to diversity and community is unsurpassed.  It's hard to get into IBM but there's a reason for that - you have to be really good at what you do.  And when you do - you're trusted to do your thing and free to succeed at your own pace.
Cons: Effecting change at a company of this size is like rotating the earth and frequently happens as blunt force, impacting thousands of people through 'resource actions' (mass layoffs).  Seniority, performance and experience used to be taken into account - but no longer.  Anyone who is in the wrong place at the right time is now vulnerable.  Institutional knowledge is lost in epic proportions every time this happens.

Pros: One, a track record of changing when needed.  No organization can survive without fundamentally altering itself.  IBM has survived for over 100 years because of its ability to change when needed  The current changes are the most widespread and deepest that have occurred in my time with IBM.  Two, the money is good and nearly all of your co-workers work hard and are easy to get along with.
Cons: One, changes are sometime made without a clear benefit; change for the sake of change.  Two, the benefits to US-based employees has reduced from year to year. Three, executives occasionally fail to lead (not manage) when leadership is most needed.

Pros: Many companies are looking for the best of the best, IBM is looking to get them and keep them long term.  They pay you what you are worth, then give you the tools to get even better and earn more.
Cons: I have heard many complaints and rumors that IBM lays off a lot of people.  I personally have seen IBM offer people in fading technologies opportunities within the fast growing areas of the organization.  I have seen people resistant to change RA'ed after those technologies were sunset, I have also seen people thrive in new jobs.  While I have never seen another company expend any energy trying to keep people, I do think that we could do a bit better job of it.

Pros: IBM Values, competitive salary, approachable executive level and above
Cons: Too many reductions in headcount to meet financial levels; sometimes IBM's values do not trickle down to the management level

Pros: Tons of things going on, which means opportunities to focus on new interests. Plenty of resources (people, books, videos, courses) if you are someone who enjoys learning a little every day.
Cons: Constant rumors of layoffs, now with a limited severance program - 1 month no matter how many years of service. Raises and bonuses below industry average due to (planned) sharp declines in revenue and stock buybacks to elevate stock price. This is not a place for those who are anxious about losing their job will thrive due to your being up all night worried about getting let go.

Pros: Good work life balance. Chance to work on interesting projects and interact with bright people.
Cons: IBM Research has gone to extremes in recent years to advance the careers of women. While there is no doubt that historically many talented women have been discriminated against, this is no longer the case and programs designed to give priority to women over men in technical leadership roles need to be critically questioned. The levels to which these programs are practiced has made it very difficult for qualified men to advance in the company and many top (male) AI researchers have left as a result. I realize that no place is a perfect meritocracy but IBM has swayed so far way from one that it has compromised its ability to attract top talent.

Pros: Over the many years I worked for IBM, no matter what the job, my colleagues were always top-notch.  Great people to work alongside, dedicated, innovative, highly-skilled and resilient.  The opportunities I had the pleasure of working on were tremendous, and while challenging the work was typically interesting. If you had a management chain with the ear of their executive, a lot of good could happen.
Cons: In recent years, there was an unfortunate constant drumbeat of resource actions and mixed priorities which continued to pile work on those that remained, and without a laser focus and necessary support needed for success. Work was typically reactionary, and overtime was significant.

Pros:
First 6 months of training in Summit program are great. Learn a lot, challenging, flexible work schedule. 
Name recognition. 
Relatively good pay. Don't think it is above average though.
Cons:
Horrible work culture in the Coppell Sales Center. 
Unsanitary work facilities. 
Inflexible management around remote work.
Required to come in office despite zero valid need to do so. 
Siloed view of the rest of IBM. 
Lots of workers look well past age of retirement/lots of shuffling around the office.
Poor attitudes in older workers - i.e. treats kitchen staff terribly. 
Kept at uncomfortably cold temperature. No covered parking for extreme heat or hail storms. 
No food or drinks left out for free at any point.

Pros:
You can make whatever you want with your career. All of my managers have been very supportive in the transitions I want to make and have your growth as a priority. 

A lot of the new grads that have gone into CBD practice complains saying IBM just chose their career path for them and they can't change. I haven't seen this to be the case. You just need to have the balls to have an honest, yet hard conversation with your managers and delivery leader, to let them know what you want out of your time here. 

Overall a dope company.
Cons: The company as a whole seems to be just playing catch up in the terms of technology and outlook. This causes some tension because it's hard to plan your long-term future with the company.

Pros: Can work at home.  Casual dress unless at client and then its do in Rome as the Romans do.  Many possible jobs to change to.  Many different organizations to work in.  More smart people than perhaps any other company.  Great access to research.  Decent benefits.  Try to avoid layoffs.  Great projects to work on.  Always looking to work in the latest technology.
Cons: You can end up with way too much travel.  Travel benefits suck.  Cost savings seem to be more important than revenue growth.  Such a big company makes it hard to find out who knows what.  Many managers are incompetent.

Pros: The only reason to work for IBM is to have it on your resume.  Software group is a respectable place to work, but you have to plan on moving to Reserach Triangle Park in North Carolina if you want to continue working in that group ... That is how I ended up in IBM Global Servicesm see the negative review for what I think of them.
Cons: IBM Global Service forces its employees into mandatory overtime via a practice known as utilization ... if you do excellent work that your peers and colleagues appreciate but are under utilized ... there goes your bonus performance evaluations.  Matrix management does not well, especially if you move into a group where the manager already has his favorites.

Pros: Room for advancement, stable company with global opportunities.  Management has gone through alot of trouble to make sure the HR infrastructure is tailored to helping employees develop their careers.  IBM has alot of talented employees that are easy to reach out to and get help.
Cons: Bureaucracy is almost engrained in IBM's corporate culture.  IBM is slow to react to changes in the industry.  There are so many parts of IBM that sometimes act independently, or even worse, to each other's detriment.  There is much confusion inside of IBM as to where the boundaries are between groups.

Pros: I work from home, and I greatly appreciate the time and money it saves me. I don't commute, I don't eat out, I don't incure huge clothing bills or dry cleaning expenses. I also love the flexibility - I can work from anywhere, so I get to travel a lot. I just work during the days and have my nights and weekends to visit with friends and family or sightsee in a new place.. Also, for those who have been around awhile, we get plenty of vacation (I have 4 weeks now and will get 5 weeks shortly).
Cons: "Browbeating" is still the classic managerial style. There is a lack of leadership and creativity in management, even though the matrixed nature of the organization really calls for it.

Pros: IBM Microelectronics works on some of the most bleeding edge technology projects in the industry.  You'll be working on industry leading projects.  IBM makes the processors in all the latest video game consoles and was a leader in developing multi-core processor designs.  Their foundry and manufacturing business
Cons: In my opinion, IBM doesn't want to be in the processor business.  They're just trying to milk the division until it no longer helps serve Services and Software groups.  I don't believe they compensate the microelectronics group fairly in terms of performance bonuses.  Server group almost always gets the lowest bonuses at IBM even though the other groups revenues are based upon server group hardware.

Pros: Large company with opportunities in many fields.  You can change jobs from time to time.  You can move to other parts of the country or internationally and stil work for the same company.  Benefits are still as good as any other company.  The company is profitable and, overall, seems to be managed for the long haul.
Cons: For a US based mechanical engineer - they appear to be getting out of the hardware business and are moving work to Asia.  So the future is limited.  There is little opportunity to advance engineering skills because they use the lowest cost manufacturers, so the technology is always the same.  New materials and processes are seldome encountered.

Pros: The best reason to work for IBM is it's a company everyone has heard of and will look good on your resume when apply for a new job.
Cons: In the area where I work IBM has pushed affirmative action too far. There are all kinds of support groups for women and minorities, and if you are a woman or a minority you can expect someone in upper management to mentor you and help you get promoted. If you are a white man, good luck. A minority doing the same level of work as a white man can expect to be at least one band higher if not more.

Pros:
Flextime is available, but that is almost a standard in the technical world, so I'm not sure it's much of a pro.
Lot of smart people to work with, but I've found lots of smart people to work with in other places too.
Educational opportunities, but such cost controls that one can never participate in really valuable education.
Cons:
No way for advancement without significant job change and likely a relocation.
Money is sub par compared to other companies
Poor moral due to severe cost controls that hit everything from "thanks" and other  awards to simple team pizza lunches. 
Long hours and good work go unrewarded
IT equipment is sub par compared to other companies. Lack of resources to do the work.
Constant feeling of impending doom as you wait for the outsourcing axe

Pros: You work around very intelligent people.  Some of the technology is leading edge from research.  People are overall easy to work with.
Cons: Can be a very high stress environment with long hours and no weekends off.  Depending on where you work, the flexibility may be gone for working remotely.  Also, there is constant worries among co-workers that this year could be their year to be let go.  It can be a rather uncomfortable place to work.

Pros:
- You can learn a lot about a lot of different technologies
- Challenging projects to manage
- Remote work normal
Cons:
- Can be bureaucratic
- Much too much measurement and repeated measurement
- Too much overtime (60 hour work week the norm, over 70 sometimes)
- Not special with treating employees.  Not much "respect for the individual"  Profit is the bottom line not the people
- Pressure not to be hit by the next layoff that you know will come, like clockwork

Pros: The people I work with are smart, wonderful people. Good work life balance. Very flexible with personal time off if needed.
Cons: Several years ago, IBM changed the 401K match for new employees to 3%. Prior employees receive a 6% match. Annual bonus' and merit salary increases ONLY go to the top performers in the work group (top 10-15% of employees). Annual performance reviews are stack ranked. That means there will ALWAYS be a bottom group regardless of how well you perform in your job. Several years ago, IBM reduced the maximum vacation for employees hired after that date. They will never receive more than 20 days per year. Prior employees can receive 25 days. New employees start with 15 vacation days and max to 20 after 10 years of service.

Pros: IBM has a good education program, allowing you to take online courses.  The projects expose you to differing technologies and experiences.  They are a challenge.
Cons: IBM, at least where I am, does not give yearly increases, to my knowledge.  They expect you to bill your maximum hours, and do your online education on your own time. There is a lot of bureaucracy.  I just earned an MBA in Aug 2013 and applied for internal entry-level consulting positions: everyone I have contacted about those positions has virtually ignored me.  There is a large emphasis on the numbers, but little or no emphasis on rewarding a good job.

Pros:
Federal Consulting only:
1. Large programs with national significance.
Cons:
1. Pay is crap.
2. No annual raises - even inflation raises. COLA adjustments don't occur.
3. 12% bonus potential mentioned before getting the job is a fallacy. You will never even get 5%. If you get rated a 1 (best), good luck in getting 3%.
4. The way IBM GBS is setup in the public sector, it actually incentivizes one to become a 1099 and work with IBM. In fact - it is great as a subK.
5. Strong smart IBMers leave - unless they're paid well or are IBMers from the "Old Blue".
6. Most IBMers I know have almost never received a raise. In years!

Pros: Flexibility in hours, great pay in a low cost to live area, great 401k and health benefits, patent oppotunities, and quick promotions if you prove yourself. There is also very intelligent people to learn from and commicate with. Very professional environment.
Cons: The area is very conservative feeling which can be a con for some. The culture feels very old time and not very exciting in some departments. Progress on work is slow. Old technology is really common in development in older departments  since moving forward is so slow in such large companies.

Pros: I've worked for IBM Cloud for over a year and a half and I have really enjoyed every day. We work mostly infrastructure and hardware to expand services in an IaaS environment.
Cons: There seems to be a fair amount of turn-over for new hires. Most that newly join the company seems to not even know that much about working on home computers. It leads to more advanced techs having to teach about even simple components and proper handling of these components. In the long run, it turns into techs working to advance their career having to spend less time taking the certifications to advance and more time teaching basics over and over.

Pros: They do permit full time remote options for full time employees should your work role permit the opportunity.
Cons: It seem you are at the mercy of the clients regardless of if the work makes sense or is reasonable to do. The account managers yes the clients to death and the workers are left to figure out how to make the unrealistic promises come to pass. Prepare to be dumped on a lot. Managers really only seem to care about what it takes to make the next level up happy - not how you feel, what your career goals are or anything else - you get plugged in where it serves them best.

Pros: Remote work was nice. Although they didn’t pay for office equipment beyond your laptop and docking station. Want a nice chair? Pay for it yourself. Fast internet? Again it comes out of your pocket.
Cons:
They didn’t pay for squat. 
Even though you may have been working 45 to 60 hours a week for the last three years, you only accumulate the “standard amount”. If you leave the company having took a couple of extra days, they will send you a bill for the difference.

If you are in sales, they will come up with every BS excuse they can not to actually pay you your commission.

Pros:
Younger folks-good on resume
Older Folks-Lucky enough to have both pension/401K combo (rare today)
Both Old/Young-IBM still good on resume
Cons:
You are nothing but part of the supply chain-completley commoditized
Future- For high-potential employee this is a large broad company
Future-For average professional-career path is parimarily managed by YOU
Lay offs-anytime/anyplace no transition or education to place you in another part of company-it's who knows you  (not who you know)

Pros:
Nobody can really tell if you're doing anything - management is so screwed up they don't even know where people are most of the time.
For the most part, you're in company with good people. Information sharing is part of the 'old' IBM culture, and a lot of people still believe in it.
Cons:
Declining pay annually. 
'Commodity' job shop - not a career place any more.
New hires are generally lackluster people who were dead-ended at other companies - not the 'top 10%' off premier college campuses that we used to get.

Pros: It's a market leader with lot of opportunities.  With over three hundred thousand employees around the globe and core business that spans hardware, software, and services, there are tons of opportunities to learn and grow in just about any area you field you care to pursue.  Also, IBM is good at listening to it's employees.  It is an organization that encourages autonomy and contribution by it's personnel.  This may be due to the proclivity towards hiring independent minded technical people.  In fact, you do not need be a sales or management star to excel at IBM.  There are many, many individual contributors on a technical plane that are akin to executives with their power and pay.
Cons: It's a behemoth that encourages specialization and has an engineering dominated mindset

Pros: Opportunities to move jobs, change careers, get educated, travel.  Time available to take care of self or family in times of sickness or death - as well as birth.  Some of the smartest people in the world work here, most are accessible.  Great mentoring program.
Cons: Top heavy organizations.  Too many executives.  Too many Fellows and Distinguished Engineers.  No local management.  Spending at the highest levels is out of control.  Limit corporate jet / helicopter passes to Sam and his direct reports with <10k people orgs.  Realize that not everyone fits in the same box.  Too much politics and too much 'friends and family'.

Pros:
The best reasons to work for IBM are one, name recognition, second, the opportunity to work anywhere in
the world and finally very good advancement opportunities. I met a lot of great people.
Cons:
I found IBM slow moving....also there was this "one size that fits all mentality" that really hurt 
productivity. The biggest disappointment for me was I thought IBM was a place for growth, training and
long term employment. It really turned out to be a typical US company these days...ie no direction, no
training and the minute the stock falls there's an employee fire sale...many employees I meet said 
management cared more about stock price than their welfare...i tend to agree. Also....IBM seems to
shed a lot of really good talent at the entry level.

Pros: A stable, solid company, process-oriented, structured company who treats employees well. The benefit package and long PTO days are very attractive. Salary is above average, very reasonable for the type of software development work required. The work environment is very nice too. Nice campus, location, cafeteria, gym and various services on site.
Cons: Dealing with globalization may not be easy. Teams that coordinates with offshore teams often work long, strange hours. You might be expected to attend meetings (online, at home ok) as early as 7am or as late as 10pm. More agile than a company of similar size is still big. Product cycle is slow and very process oriented. Things don't get done as simple and as fast as they should. Maybe folks there are pretty set in their own ways. Not the most innovative crowd. Don't be stuck in a group that is not performing. Bottom line counts a lot.

Pros: Remnants of old school corporate culture where everyone treats you with respect. Potentiall very friendly atmosphere. Travel opportunities for consultants although some of the places you go to will not be that exotic. Rapid promotion is possible if you are lucky and/or have been identified. Sounds cliche but it really is what you make of it.
Cons: Very impersonal. I have never met my manager in person. Arbitrary promotion and resource deployment scheme within the consulting organization. Project deployments based purely on billable hours, no regard is paid to career growth. Pervasive bean counting. Management shakeups are frequent. Old PriceWaterhouseCooper organization is not well integrated. If you're not one of the lucky ones on the fast track you could be in for a very miserable time as no one is really watching out for you.

Pros: Great company to start out fresh out of college.  I started out already being experience and settled down but I wish I would have started at IBM right out of college just for the fact that traveling consultants are very well taken care of.  IBM allows you to travel home or else where every weekend which is great if you do not have to travel home every weekend, giving you the option to travel somewhere different every weekend.
Cons: Big company easy to get lost.  If you are not a self promoter you can easily get past over for promotions or great projects to work on.  Some people don’t like the large company which some times weeds out the good employees that are working and don’t have the time to self promote.  I have seen a lot of great workers lost because they are not pushing them selves to be promoted.

Pros: If you have NO life and are willing to work  70 to 90 hours a week, you will be paid well.
Cons: In order to get ahead and not be laid off, you will need to sacrifice your personal life in order to put the hours in that the job will demand.
