For example, I had 4:30 am conference calls with a contracting group in Romania with deliverables due on Saturdays. Further, there are too many "Queen Bees" involved in Systems and Technology who get accolades  for 1000 page design documents written such that contractors cannot comprehend them.

Pros: The business really is trying to do the right things for the world (in alignment with making shareholders profits). The techies really do share information (at my lower level) and help each other out. The lower management really does care about their employees.
Cons: Very strong push for hardware to do more with less - that means layoffs, no promotions. But more projects. I think they're trying to get rid of the older generation to be able to hire more new (and cheaper) blood. Might be the right move for them....I'm getting tired of the long hours and nonstop sense of urgency. Hardware is commoditized now, run by project managers. Little left to actually invent.

Pros: If you are an RSM you will have your own office. You can manage your own schedule. A lot of smart people around. The culture encourages collaboration.
Cons: They do not pay well. They literally stopped raising salaries 4 years ago. We can't get new good talents, they goto Google, Microsoft and others for the better offer. Good experienced people are also moving on. There seems to be a disconnect between executives and the people who are doing the actual work.

Pros:
Technical teams have a lot of  experience and are extremely competent, some of the best in the industry
Technology, at least historically, has been good
Good work/life balance is possible
If you can telecommute it is a big win/win
Cons:
Most of the top talent will be retiring soon
Benefit plans repeatedly raided, older employees lost big-time from retirement plan bait and switch
Little or no salary increases year after year
Employee profit sharing is a joke since only the executives see anything even in an outstanding year

Pros:
-Great salary/benefits/401(k) plan
-Great work life balance program
-Managers are great about having monthly one-on-ones with their employees to discuss performance, business changes, and allow employees to share their concerns and feedback
-amazing and talented people everywhere in the business and IBM provides numerous resources to grow your knowledge
Cons:
-not a 40 hour a week job...although IBM has a strong commitment to work life balance, if you want a great performance review at the end of the year, you better be willing to make some sacrifices
-career paths are virtually non-existent...employees are left with the responsibility of deciding where they want to go with their career (this may sound great), but rarely does an opportunity arise during a time you'd be approved to leave your current position.

Pros: People are incredibly talented, diverse workforce in every sense and opportunities abound. On the leading edge of technology.
Cons: Expect to continually be nickled and dimed to death regarding benefits. The new 401K change a perfect example. The "roadmap" inevitably means more squeezing of employees via cost cutting as it is apparent the company is not doing sufficient at growing revenue to meet their EPS target. The PBC system is terrible for morale and I say this as a manager who's dealt with it on both sides.

Pros: People are very helpful. They almost have to be given the heavy matrix organization.  Telecommuting is a big plus most of the time.  Large company means there's opportunity for growth and movement.
Cons: Working from home is great, but harder to end the work day.  Not always having the opportunity to meet co-workers to develop a good working bond, and understand individual working styles because you either never get to meet them or you might once or twice.  Matrix management - this is a big matrix and not always easy to understand.

Pros: Mature infrastructure that provides very basic operating resources required to conduct business. There still are some very capable people that can provide true depth in their areas of expertise.
Cons: Extreme focus on Earnings Per Share is starving many areas of the needed funding for everything from development to commissions. Executive compensation based on stock price is skewing the decision process to focus on short term gain.

Pros: IBM is a great place to work most of the time. Most "knowledge workers" work at home and stay busy going from one conference call to the next. You might have to work on a spreadsheet or .ppt from time to time, but marketing roles require very little real work. It can be mind-numbingly boring, but leaves plenty of time to pursue other things. Most of the real work is involves managing your way around the infrastructure of the company.
Cons: It is a totally executive centric organization, and most employees pledge their allegiance to their VP and then go to war with other groups. The capricious, megalomaniac executive, always grasping for power and control, is woven into the fabric of the culture, and exec worship is required for survival.

Pros: There have been plenty of chances for personal growth, as long as you grab hold and run with them.  Many work-from-home opportunities if that is your thing.  Customers genuinely appreciate the expertise you bring to the table.
Cons: The company is very bureaucratic overall, and generally run by the accountants for the accountants.  The "temporary" spending freezes on practically everything have become "permanent" without avenues for exceptions for things you really do need to do your job.  First line management has had most if not all decision making privileges taken away from them.

Pros: The flexibility is the biggest benefit.  I have the ability to work at home can work a flexible schedule if needed
Cons:
> Depending on the organization you're in, your vacation may really be flexible time away rather than true vacation. Some areas require utilization over 105%.   100% is 52 weeks of 40 hours, so vacations and holidays will force you to make up the time taken off, in addition to the meeting the  expected overtime.  
> Pay raises and variable pay  have been minimal or non-existent the last 5 years

Pros: The first line managers I worked for were good people and my coworkers were nice as well.  As a remote employee I did not have to cope with commuting and my schedule was flexible to an extent. I could take time during the day to do personal things sometimes since I needed to do other work at night or early in the morning with colleagues or clients overseas.
Cons: As time went on my organization shifted from a primarily US staffed team to about 35% US and 65% internationally based workers. My international colleagues were mostly very professional but there were still problems supporting US based clients. During US working hours clients expected attention for their needs but the assigned person from my team would be often offline due to timezone differences. Also, there seemed to be a push to replace IBM regular employees with contract workers.

Job Title: Principal datacenter and cloud specialty seller
Pros: Great brand name.  Nothing works better than to have a brand name that everyone knows and a reputation of finishing the work regardless of the price even if they loose money.
Cons: 1st line managers only last about a year so you get a new boss every year.  I had 8 in 7 years.  One boss had me as an employee and we never met each other.  You get the feeling that your not part of a family you are only a number.  They will never pay for training to keep you  qualified for your job.

Pros: Good experience, very challenging environment, a lot of resources, and learning opportunities. A lot of free time.
Cons:
No one cares whether you show up or work from home. IBM does nothing to support interns and treats undergraduates like mid level professionals, who already have a family, car, and do not need extra support. My social skills were stunted after this internship since I barely got to talk to anyone.

Advice: this isn't Google, Apple, or Microsoft. Do not expect to do more than work. This will not be fun but it will be challenging. be prepare to see the worst and kind-of-okay in people. Also I cried about 3 times during my summer there.

Pros:
The shift from a hardware-centric to service-centric and now to a cloud and cognitive service model. A transformation of this kind is not easy for any company with more than 75,000 employees let alone 400,000 that IBM has world-wide. Google reports at 57,000, Apple around than 80,000, Blackberry/RIM at 7000 (at its peak) to put into perspective.  Blackberry led the market was too comfortable and failed to transform to market demands. 

Many, many of the leaders and executives at IBM have Engineering, Computer Science backgrounds - they aren't your typical no-work experience MBAs.  They make decisions very analytically (as Engineers tend to do) with their clients in mind trying to help solve business and world problems. That problem was once mainframes, servers, storage and systems; evolved to implementing and building IT solutions around that hardware; now it's an hybrid cloud implement-yourself-slash-business-service.  Very few companies own the entire ecosystem (mainframe, business solutions and cloud availability) - IBM does. The cognitive guys can request improvements and features to the hardcore engineering server CPU team for maximum optimization- making the most advance system easily available to all businesses.  

No doubt, IBM is years ahead the competition with their Watson Services and it's built on an ecosystem that is in line with the CIOs and CTOs initiative going into the future.  The platform also lends well to startups and smaller companies being able to leverage and take advantage of IBM's top-notch enterprise and industry services at flexible, scalable and affordable rates.  This is new ground for IBM that was typically reserved for big firms and enterprise companies. Way to go, IBM!
Cons: Old sellers not willing to adapt to what the industry is demanding will have a tough transition. Again, 400,000 employees makes it difficult for any company. People can get comfortable and changing becomes difficult.  Again, Blackberry/RIM is evidence of being the smart phone leader who failed to transform and was just barely saved from a bankruptcy by being acquired for pennies on the dollar. Again, Jim Balsillie, former CEO of Balckberry, had no engineering or computer science background, and tried to run the company solely with his Harvard MBA, which he ran into the ground.  IBM has a lot of work to transform a lot of people who are more comfortable doing things the old way.

Pros: You get to put IBM on your resume. They do train you, but what's the point? They treat you like nothing afterwards. So, you start looking. We have lost so many people in the past two years, because they were unhappy, that our department is in shambles.
Cons: Management from the CEO down sucks. They will literally send people who are loyal employees overseas, have them train their replacements, then fire them. One of the most unethical companies I know. They have done away with so many things that once made this company THE place to work. Sad, because they make plenty of money and could treat their employees right. Instead they don't even call them people or employees, they call us resources. That's all you are here. A resource. The CEO obviously doesn't care about us, she lays off thousands, and then doesn't see any problem with collecting a $4.5M bonus. She took that money after 15 straight months of declining revenue.. shameful.

Pros: Flexibility to telecommute, good mentors if you seek them out, career progression possible. I met some fantastic people and the best part about the job are the coworkers I work with... outside of them honestly it's an old boys club with a bunch of old white men running the show.
Cons: The company is trying to do too much and there is no clear vision. Layoffs are happening all the time because the company is not doing well - letting experienced people go in favor of cheaper younger people. You are (in sales) expected to have no outside life.. Culture is money and revenue over everything including client satisfaction. So much bureaucracy that you're going through at least 16 different people to get anything done. And honestly, there are some questionable business practices going on that in not comfortable with.

Pros: There were a lot of opportunities at IBM.  There broad range of products and services create ample opportunity to move in almost any direction desired.  BTW, I originally worked for Informix Software where I was Principal Technical Architect .  Informix was then acquired by IBM.  I left IBM back in 2002 -- the system doesn't allow for older entries; so I note that here.
Cons: I would say that aggressive people probably fit best at IBM.  I never felt that employees worked together and supported each other as I had experienced in other companies -- even though the model at that time was that of a matrix organization.  All-in-all, it seemed to me to be mostly  a very competitive environment.

Pros: IBM has a multitude of areas where employees can get involved in emerging trends or tried and true technology.  IBM offers the ability to move to different areas without having to change company's to change career paths.   IBM experts are very accessible to help someone get involved with their passion whether it be something which goes across industries such as cloud or cognitive and something which is specific to an industry including finance, healthcare, banking, transportation, etc.    IBM also has great community service related opportunities to allow employees to give back.
Cons: Continual pressure to reduce costs drives work to lower cost countries resulting in reduced workforce in some countries like U.S.   However, if you are willing to re-educate and retrain in emerging technologies IBM continues to expand U.S. workforce.

Pros: Pro used to be work-life balance but not any more.  IBM is forcing any and all remote work to relocate to one of 10 core sites regardless if your team is located in that area or not.  Pension, 401K matching and health insurance offerings are good.
Cons: Cons - little if any raises and when they are awarded it's at a rate of 2-3% of your current salary.  Employees are an after thought.  Benefits continue to decline, work satisfaction is on the decline and there is very little, if any, chance of moving from one division to another.

Pros: Amazing people to work with, probably the most diverse workforce in tech (and they mean it when they say they embrace diversity). Doing lots of exciting projects in artificial intelligence and enterprise cloud. Storied history. Moving into newer urban facilities instead of being stuck in the exurbs.
Cons: Shackled with systems and processes that struggle to keep up with the pace of change. Spent too much time destroying innovation and product capabilities with Roadmap to 2015's financial engineering shenanigans. Lost a lot of talent,  institutional knowledge, and a key employment differentiator in the tech industry, when switched away from encouraging remote work.

Pros:
In the past, you were able to move around or work at home but it's now very limited.  Since it's a large company you can move around to different areas but saw less of that over the years.
Great co-workers
Cons:
Benefits decrease yearly.  For example, now the 401k match only done if you are working on Dec 15 of each year.  They laid me off in Aug so I lose match for entire year.
Used to be a good place to work for a long career but now with layoffs happening 2 times a year, your chances of lasting long are slim.  I would recommend working here only 3-5 years then finding a new employer.  Just come in to get experience and move on.

Pros: IBM is a company that stands by its values of dedication to client's success, trust and responsibility, and innovation that matters. It is also a company that truly celebrates diversity across the world. There is so much to learn, so many different opportunities, and many different jobs and roles one can play.
Cons: It is a very large company which you need to know how to navigate. It has been around for more than a 100 years and may not seem as sexy, exciting or current as other younger companies (but it is!)

Pros: A regular paycheck and okay-enough benefits.
Cons: Leadership is incompetent and irrational - everything is quid pro quo and curried favors. Do not make waves, know your place and always tell your leaders "yes" to whatever they want to hear (and yes, our mid-line leader/director actually told us to always placate our leaders if we wanted to keep our jobs). This is not how you run a company, this is how you destroy an institution and skim a profit off of third-party vendor relationships. Also, every effort is made to place every US/UK/EU position in a "low-cost-country", which no matter the intended country always gets changed to India for some reason.

Pros: Even if individual managers do not nescessarily understand the rights of their employees (some do, some don't, like in any large org) systemically the rights of the employees seem protected. A far sight from perfect, but better than any other place Ive worked.
Cons:
IBM is, as it has always been, a place that it takes a long time for the average guy to make good money. Ive seen many young managers handed great responsibility while making far less then their run of the mill employees.
Also, the pension isn't any good, especially the one for new employees.

Pros: Some of the best reasons to work for IBM are: IBM cares very much about work-life balance and allows for very flexible working hours; IBM provides plenty of learning opportunities through projects across different organizations; IBM has the resource to carry out pioneering projects that most of the smaller companies cannot afford to; IBM's scale makes the job relatively stable in the current market place.
Cons: Some major downsides of working at IBM include: it is such a large organization that it is very difficult and may take a long time to advance in the career path; breaking barriers between organizations can be difficult and often result in low efficiency; there are too many old people that are too used to the established way of doing business

Pros: Being part of the state of the art of technology development. Being on the cutting edge. People work hard and produce in this division. It's great to work with such a talented and motivated group.
Cons: Career advancement and recognition are almost non-existent relative to other divisions within IBM. Other IBM divisions are recognized for their accomplishments. RSUs, options and annual awards are the norm. These things are RARE in IBM Micro. This "other division" recognition is hard to swallow when you realize that it is your team's accomplishments that have SIGNIFICANTLY helped the other divisions succeed. An important but not immediately necessary IBM non-benefit is the lack of a retirement health plan for new employees. Plain and simple, there is none. This is a huge downside for IBM.

Pros: If you are focused on moving up the corporate ladder and playing politics you can go far in IBM, regardless of your talent level, but you will have to re-locate.
Cons: You never know when your time is up, regardless of how well you do from a numbers standpoint.   There is never any feeling of comfort, always worry that you will be the next to go.   IBM has drastically changed as a company and it is all about EPS, period.

Pros: Fellow practitioners make IBM a great place to work.  The talent is very good and can accomplish anything given the chance.
Cons: The company is being run by accountants. Every year there is something else that is reduced which is affecting morale and productivity.  Basic software that my customer has that I can't get. I know many people who buy their own copies of software just to do their job we are asked to do. Education is a big complaint as well.  And every employee gets animated when we bring up the subject thanks awards.

Pros: - Good network of information and access to professionals in variety of areas of expertise.
Cons:
- Job growth is very slow, despite continued excellent performance. Learning and skill development are only talked about, and employees are not given enough opportunities to actually carry them out.
- Management does not always take responsibility.
- Process of assessing and rating management is very poor, and does not accurately convey their performance to their reviewers.
- Position classification system is not well designed, and employees' skill levels do not suit their position within the company.
- The interview processes are not well designed to properly assess candidates' skill levels.
- Lack of openness toward employees.

Pros: IBM continues to seek out the best and brightest among computer professionals from around the world.  The culture of technical excellence and advancement is still solidly in place.
Cons: With so many highly talented and skilled professionals, the culture at IBM is often cutthroat to the point that genuine talent is overshadowed by personalities and cliques.  Employees are often viewed as disposable and interchangeable, with more emphasis frequently placed on bringing in fresh college hires than retaining more experienced workers.

Pros:
excellent flexibility in work hours
solid pay
Working on some IBM technology can be great experience for moving to career with IBM's customers
Cons:
tech company completely run by accountants and sales
Virtually no technical backgrounds in senior leadership
No emphasis on creating truly world class technology
With massive job cuts in the US workforce in recent years, it's nearly impossibly to move around in the company, which was previously a big positive

Pros: IBM offers incredible career development opportunities. As a global company I had the benefit of traveling to international locations for work and regularly work with global colleagues. In addition to career development the work life balance is fairly good given how competitive the technology marketplace is.
Cons: Like many large organization there is a fair amount of bureaucracy that gets in the way of doing the actual work that I enjoy. I would say that this is necessary to manage and control such a large enterprise. The scale and resources, however, far outweigh the occasional headache from a tedious process.

Pros: The benefits are really nice and the people who do work locally are all very bright and dedicated.
Cons: I worked for a company that was acquired by IBM.  While IBM has a lot of talented people working for it, it quickly became apparent that as a highly paid engineer at IBM you are considered a liability.  We were actively interviewing engineers in India and Singapore to replace us and we told to expect yearly layoffs.  They delivered on that promise. To say the mood was sour is an understatement.  The worst part is the quality of our products suffered greatly and eventually there will be no one in the U.S. who actually knows how the software works.

Pros: Excellent people to work with.  Challenging job assignments.  You get to work with a lot of modern technology
Cons: Management is brutal towards employees.  Yearly layoffs that are random cuts no matter how good you are ( e.g. really good developer was promoted one month, laid off two months later)   Very cheap company ( e.g. no budget for training / education,  laptop upgrade only every 5 years)  Very short term vision for management focus on expense reduction ( e.g. Hardware is not provided to test software because it is too expensive)   Pay and benefits are below average.

Pros:
1. Very professional.  This applied to in terms of approach to tasks, assignment of correct persons to tasks, planning of timelines in respect of resources and workloads and in monitoring of execution.  All around there was a clear understanding of what was involved and what needed to be done.  The work accordingly proceeded smoothly and all knew what slippages were acceptable and which were not.
2. High standards of work.  The quality of work expected was high and it was achieved.
3. Stress free.  There was a refreshing lack of office politics and no undue pressure as all involved had a clear understanding of the processes and what should be done and what could not.
Cons: None experienced during my time at IBM

Pros: For the most part, IBM employees are exceptional; bright, driven, hard working, conscientious, productive.
Cons: In the years that I have been with IBM, it has gone from a company that seemingly valued its employees to a company that only values its bottom line.  IBM no longer provides money for continued education, no longer provides work-from-home employees with necessities such as printers, monitors, keyboards, etc.  Raises are minimal and do not meet cost of living increases.  Bonuses have shrunk over the years to being nearly non-existent.  Employees work together for years and never meet their fellow department members or managers.  There are several resource actions every year and the employees who remain are expected to pick up the resulting unassigned work load.

Pros: Lots of credibility built up in the marketplace (from when employees used to care and be proud of working for the company) and a large enough business to sustain itself through challenges for a while
Cons: IBM is increasingly being run by the bean-counters, with a maniacal focus on financial metrics, at the expense of employee development and engagement. Hard to come by IBMers who are truly proud of the company and enjoy working there.

Pros:
Big 4 consulting org
6% match on 401k
generous vacation and holiday time off
Warm leads from SWG and other sales teams
Most funded R&D org in the industry; most patents in world each year
Respected Engineering firm
Cons:
Salary is lower than industry average
No pay raises
No bonus in GBS
Not a marketing firm (lacks marketing expertise to bring new innovative products to market - speech failed, mobile failed, collaboration tools don't hold a match to google docs, will see how watson does)
Loads of processes that are costly but ineffective - DS&P, PMR, Delivery Excellence, etc. 
Ran by spreadsheets, lots of resource actions all around company to meet 2015 financial goals; lots of offshoring key roles for same reasons; 
high pressure for over 100% consultant utilization

Pros: Company values are ethical.  Great salary, health and dental benefits and training. Ability to work from home was much appreciated.  Time off was sufficient.
Cons: Lack of support and communication from their HR.  Overwhelming expectations initially with training and requirements. Need for career better opportunities.  Once contract expired, most jobs were only available for internal candidates.

Pros: IBM has some of the best talent out there. Many of the technology and technologists are second to none. IBM encourages patent generation and has many opportunities to grow skill base. Great work-life balance. New employees can take on a lot of real responsibility.
Cons: Large bureaucracy (100 years in the making). Executve leadership team driven by short term financials and reactionary behavior, which consistently undermines the creation of great technology (takes many quarters and financial fortitude to carry through). Variable compensation rarely delivered due to poor strategic decisions from executive leadership team.

Pros:
IBM is flexible and rewards innovation (for those high enough or allowed to introduce it).  Great people work there that want to do good.

Fantastic volunteer programs through "On Demand Community," where one can earn cash rewards for the nonprofit or school they serve with 40 or more hours a year.

Good leadership development programs.
Cons:
There is NO loyalty to you or job security.  You can have friends at IBM, but unless you are a very strong performer, NO ONE will stick their neck out for you.  No one.  

It's also never a good idea to have opinions contrary to the company line.

Pros: Generally smart workforce. Support remote work environment. Opportunities for training and development. Company still has many "tentacles" into clients and prospects in order to pursue potential business.
Cons: Workforce is overwhelmingly apathetic and tired. Most employees are motivated primarily to do whatever is needed to cruise into retirement. No focus on employee satisfaction. No focus on enhancing loyalty. First and second layer management talent is generally weak and primarily focused on job protection and internal politics.

Pros: Large scale projects. Work that keeps you invested in what you are doing. Hands off non-micromanaging approach. Valuable experience. Encourage learning and increasing ones own value.
Cons: Salary could be higher considering the importance of the work being done. Job security can be unstable based on cash flow from client, unless you can move to another area within IBM. Sometimes tough to move up latter for raises.

Pros: The people at the Baton Rouge Center are great people to work with. Friendly and gives you help on your project even if they are on another.
Cons: This is a Consultant position, not a developer position. If you are looking for in-house developer position this is not it. It is also a sink or die situation. There is no way to move vertical or horizontal. You are stuck in your position until you find another job. You work 44 hours or more per week which means you will burn out quickly on some project.

Pros: IBM provides lots of pretty advancement opportunities IF you can take the time to look for them and IF they are not in another one of their many many downsizing projects which seems to always be going on. IBM employment looks nice on the resume ...
Cons: IBM is not what it used to be and they do not care at all about their employees in my opinion. Like so many other big companies, its all about making more money than they did last year regardless of what that means to their employees. Working for IBM used to mean a lot more than it does now.

Pros:
The community of designers is wonderful
Solving difficult problems through design
Being part of the whole process of design
Great place to learn about other design disciplines
The organization as a while has come a long way in a few years with regards to incorporating design and design thinking. (Still has a long way to go, but there is progress)
Cons:
Suffers from the typical faults of a large corporation
As a visual designer, opportunities to be creative are somewhat limited
Overall happiness is VERY dependent on the team and org

Pros:
Flexible work schedule and location 
International travel opportunities
A lot of vacation time
Exciting technology
Most of the folks in the product side are gung-ho and engaged
Cons:
Morale was terrible the last few years, with the constant cutting and underperformance of the company overall, which meant no real bonuses or raises.
Too many layers of "do nothing" management.  Between my FLM and the GM there were about four other people who created no demonstrable value.
No advancement for the technical track
FLMs are just cycled through the company.
Productivity software was anything but... seriously ditch Notes/Verse, Communities, etc, The market has rejected them so should IBM finally.

Pros:
- Breadth of learning: so much rich, relevant, timely education at your finger tips
- Collaborative environment: colleagues are welcoming and helpful
- The sky is the limit on what you can make of your career once you demonstrate your ability to contribute
- For a 100+ year old company, the logo and brand are still globally strong, secure, and trusted despite the competition and challenges
Cons:
- It is obviously a large company, which requires one to be meticulous about focusing on what matters most: clients, collaboration, and making money (my words)
- Overwhelming amount of information, resources, training, materials are available so you have to be extremely diligent to be focused (again) on what matters most to your role (& Client), your manager, and the company.

Pros: IBM is no longer the uptight blue suit wearing company of the past. I expected a far more rigidly managed culture of conformity but what I have experienced is rather open, friendly and relaxed. Ability to apply your subject matter expertise with a great amount of autonomy while working with clients if excellent for experienced professionals.
Cons: Administrative processes take the concept of employee self-service to the extreme. Many internal systems are old, overengineered and occasionally just don't work at all. It can be both difficult and frustrating to find a human to help. With all that said the biggest Con of working for IBM is the email and scheduling platform (Lotus Notes or something called Verse). Outlook, Gmail or really anything else would be more effective and efficient. Its really that bad.

Pros: Everyone I've met and worked with has been very supportive and cooperative, giving me the support to get up to speed quickly in my position as a newcomer to IBM. I'm loving working with a lot of smart, creative, enthusiastic folks.
Cons: As with all large organizations, there's some momentum hindering agility. For example, one of the tools we use is OK, but there's a newer, more effective one in the market that I'm used to using for my previous employer. It's a bit of a step back to use the 'approved' tool. However, it takes time for IT to review and approve it, and I'm sure they have stricter security requirements than my previous employer, but the organizational momentum is still a bit of a drag with regard to toolsets. Oh, and that's just one example, but there are multiple cases I could name.

Pros: There are very bright people and the work is challenging. Good benefits.  Opportunity to completely change career directions (e.g go from technical to sales).  Management is taken very seriously.  You can learn a lot and there are some very good personnel practices.  Responsibility is given to people throughout the organization. The company cares about its customers and is succesful on the whole.  You do get exposed to global cultures and there is commitment to diversity
Cons: Work life balance is weighted too much to work especially since we are a global economy and deal with other geos that are in different time zones.  There is too much beauracracy. There are challenges to move beyond a certain level unless you are located in a lab.  Too many meetings.

Pros: Flex-time and work from home options. There are lots of e-learning opportunities that you can take of advantage of on the learning @ IBM site. Opportunities to consult on a variety of topics.
Cons:
Salary is lower than industry standards.
Formal evaluation of work performed (PBC) does not truly reflect employee's performance. Evaluations are distributed  based on formula. So many individuals must receive a low number no matter if they actually performed at a higher level . There are lots of ways that you must document the work that you've performed/ There is a utilization requirement wherein you end up not really getting any paid time off (vacation / holiday) because you are working extra hours to make up for any "time off" you may be taking.

Pros: Ability to offer end to end capabilities to clients, huge amount of resources to work with, ability to change roles / build broad experience, being part of a mobile workforce.  Opportunity to work closely with a global workforce. Compensation and benefits are very good, the business is strong, business is diversified enough to weather downturns in specific sectors or segments.  In the services business, the ability to work remotely, live just about anywhere is a huge plus.
Cons: Difficulty in effectively leveraging all the capabilities available due to vastness, sometimes conflicting performance metrics.  Occasionally seems too bureaucratic / requiring too many approvals on deals.  The flip side of being a remote / mobile worker is very little sense of Team.

Pros: The total compensation package is good and there are plenty of good people to work for and with.  There's a wide variety of work to do within IBM, so there are sometimes good opportunities to change jobs internally.
Cons: Not the stable job it once was.  Regular layoffs are a matter of course now, and indications are that those jobs will move overseas and not return to the US.  Since IBM seems more interested in buying new technology instead of creating it, you're better off being in a company bought by IBM if you want new technology experience.  IBM cares much more about the stock and how the world perceives it than how employees feel about the company, and that leads to poor products and support.

Pros:
There is some job flexibility - you can work at home in some jobs.   

The benefits are good:
- Several options for health insurance
- Dental/Vision coverage
- Long term disability
- Matching 401K (but no pension)

The pay is good when compared to other companies.
Cons: The hours are very long.  People are expected to work overtime almost all of the time.  There is no such thing as a 40 hour work week.  There are limited opportunities for advancement.   It is difficult to transfer into another position - your manager will not want to let you go.  The wrong people are rewarded and promoted.  Most importantly - they outsource jobs overseas constantly.   There is no job security whatsoever.

Pros: IBM is a stable, wealthy company that has many perks including the benefit package and health insurance avaiable.  IBM employment for the most part is relatively stable.
Cons: IBMers are typically overworked providing services that exeed 40 hours a week including nights and weekends that are just expected.  Balancing personal and work life can be difficult especially since the many positions are work from home.  Additionally, collaboration becomes very difficult in this position since everyone must engage in conference calls.

Pros: Easy on-boarding, lot's of self autonomy, strong compensation packages, great benefits, liberal vacation policy
Cons: Too many required conference calls, slim resources through management for training, unrealistic annual goals, too many re-orgs and down-sizings only to re-hire again. Management is aloof and doesn't engage with reports, hard to get internal information, have to rely on the rumor mill. IBM thinks when you walk in the client's door for the first time the sale is 50% over on name recognition. Discontinuing products without fair warning to sales team.

Pros:
relatively stable job.
big name.
open-source friendly.
good process management for development.
some very cool tools and advanced research (but not always accessible to software engineers).
Cons:
too much bureaucracy.
too many hierarchies and bloated.
too many politics.
bad compensation.
technologies aging, too old for the fast-paced tech world today.
moving slowly when it comes to innovation and new ideas.
work/life balance is bad, sometimes you have to work 60 hrs a week and standby/work on weekends, and manager will bug you after you left the office for the weekends/holidays.
firefighting is a common thing, testing is not through enough.
weak in the internet world.
no great engineering/creative culture and belief, the company is more and more business/money-making focused.

Pros: IBM has a true grasp of business, plans well, and teaches its employees.  It is the perfect place to begin a career and learn all you can.  If you can manage to stay relevant, it can also be a great place to end your career, aka retire.
Cons: IBM has lost some of what used to be what set it apart: Respect for the Individual.  It was too quick to try to mirror some of the behaviors of newer, fresher companies in the 80's and 90's.  Most of those companies are no longer around; IBM managed to outlast them, but at the cost of some great talent.

Pros: IBM has lots of very talented and hard working people. There is a wealth of technical knowledge within the company.
Cons: IBM seems to be focused solely on the bottom line.  The company no longer seems interested in maintaining a competitive advantage through technical innovation or by attracting and retaining top technical talent.  IBM is bleeding away talented people through resource actions (aka layoffs) and people leaving on their own initiative. The remaining people are expected to carry the ever growing workload with fewer resources after losing strong experienced people.  Also, the periodic layoffs strip away any sense of job security.

Pros:
The people are some of the best and brightest in technology.  There are opportunities to work on cutting edge technology and to create new markets.  

Ginni Rometty is driving a significant shift in the IBM business and culture. This is an exciting time to be part of that transformation.
Cons: Expense controls continue to be severe to meet the 2015 EPS goal.  This is causing projects in key investment areas to be understaffed.  The performance evaluation system drives a competitive culture that is counter to the teaming culture that is needed for success with aggressive schedules and reduced staff.

Pros: The management  has been slowly destroying the company.
Cons: used to be very good for personal growth and work-life balance back 20 year ago, but these advantages are almost gone.

Pros:
work from home
flexibility
if you know how to network, changing jobs can be easy
good culture for cooperation amongst IBMers - you rarely find someone who says "I won't help you"
good ethics culture (despite individual behaviors which might not always be)
Cons:
international mobility is not a reality.... it's akin to getting hired in a new country each time
certainly moving from US to abroad is "easier"
coming back is not
career advancement - seems to be random or based on networking
frequent resource actions/layoffs... you always wonder why some people are left and why some are let go... IBM doesn't seem to be able to keep the best and let go of the worse...

Pros: IBM's direction of where they need to be seems right on.  Solid people work for the company and the expectations of all working hard for the best of the company are there
Cons: The company is not the same as it used to be with customers first, employees second and that contributes to the best for IBM.   Think is is IBM business first, customers in there somewhere but the way it was making financials over the last few years was taking a good bit away from employees:  401K, insurance (always used to be top) and career goals.

Pros: Flexible works schedule with majority of US employees working from home.  Excellent first-line & second line management.  Extremely bright workforce, with a true passion for customer success.  Strong focus on leading edge technology.  Very easy to move across the various business lines into new roles.  Pay seems to be above industry averages.  Strong corporate values and customer focus.
Cons: Senior executive management (GM's, SVPs, Cxx) are somewhat disconnected from the lower level workforce and are in a constant shuffle to advance their careers at the expense of the business. Work-life balance is a challenge due to the routine shifting of business priorities, resulting in a large churn on project workloads.  Internal promotions are secondary in order to support acquired workforces.   Forced distribution of annual performance ratings creates motivation issues for a large percentage of the workforce.

Pros: IBM is an exciting place to work as the leader in the IT industry.  IBM is constantly evolving and transforming to meet the challenges of its customers.  You get to work with people all across the world, spanning multiple geographies and cultures.  There are always opportunities opening up as the company enters into new markets.
Cons: If you cannot adapt to constant change in every aspect of your daily work, then do not work at IBM.  It is difficult to get anything done as the processes and technology are constantly changing.  The revolving door of people assigned to perform tasks makes it difficult to build any personal relationships with your peers.

Pros: Benefits are great.  If you're willing to travel and keep up with the demand to have your billing percentage up you'll gain a lot of valuable experience.  There's always room to learn new skills and apply them in a project.
Cons: Long hours depending on the assignment.  Travel can wear you out, so look for opportunities within IBM to remain valuable and be billable.  Depending on your assignment, work-life balance may not equate.

Pros:
1. Web Based education available
2. Work from home availability
3. Opportunity to work in multiple IT fields
4. Large knowledge base
5. Global opportunity
Cons:
1.  If you have been with IBM longer than 10 years and are in the US your days are numbered.
2.  Constant assault on benefits by finance
3.  Very low % raises if any, even for high performers
4.  Finance driven employee evaluation system forces low evaluations in an effort to justify layoffs.

Pros:
Telecommuting
Flexible 
Internal Recorded Training Resources 
Lots of mobile tools
Has finally recognized need for corporate overhaul of vision
Talented resources
Cons:
Non-USA staff preferred 
Benefits package is below expectations 
Severance packages are horrible 
Integration teams have little value to incoming staff/companies 
Unusual subcontracting practices (pro and con)
Very silo'd corporate environment making it hard to take advantage of a large corporation's resources 
Poor execution on new cloud direction 
Behind the ball in cloud business 
Pay range/bonus not good but reflective of business performance

Pros: Career growth in many division is great with huge potential for those starting out and in a mid-level role. Great hype machine and plenty of opportunities to get out on the speaker circuit.
Cons: Fear-based leadership that's widening the gap between themselves senior level team leaders. Silos are pretty strong everywhere and struggling to adopt new thinking and collaborating across groups. Real legacy problems, especially in the midset of IBMers who have been there 10+ years. They really seem unaware of what's going out elsewhere. Overall "leadership" is more focused on their own individual eminence, that's why IBM has a hard time shipping product.

Pros: Interesting work, a lot of flexibility in picking an assignment.  Remarkable people, access to new hardware
Cons: The company did not have success financially for a while, GAP revenue has been declining for 6 years (management does the tricks to forge the numbers, but  when we gave away wafer manufacturing to Global Foundries and gave them 4.5 Billion US dollars to take it off our hands, this was a truly bad testament to our management skills. At a time when our competitors are building second headquarters we are sold out of our office space and are renting now. It sends a message we are planning to close the shop down.

Pros:
Many Locations around the US and the World
Many different types of jobs - not all are I/T
Competitive Salaries and Benefits in job market
Trying to become more agile and collaborative every day
Lots of educational opportunities
Room for advancement and growth if employee shows desire and initiative
Work life programs, exercise incentives, etc
Good checks and balances with management in place
Pushing for use of newer technologies and Cloud
Cons: Getting better but still too many processes at times.

Pros: Great people to work with, some of the most intelligent and engaging co-workers I've encountered. Learned so much from people with different levels of expertise across many regions and ages. Generally pays well and treats you well when you're an employee.
Cons: Too many clicks or old timers who have progressed to executive levels without necessarily developing expertise in areas they now manage. General just a few good managers, most are focused on their own careers over those supporting their efforts. Company doesn't exude any real loyalty, once they don't need you, so long. Not enough focused leadership and accountability at the top, they push it down and others pay the cost.

Pros: Diverse community, extremely bright people to work with, IBM does so much you can have a career learning and doing many different things all in one place. AI, Data Science and Analytics, Cloud, eCommerce, Collaboration, etc in roles of marketing, product management, engineering, HR, etc.
Cons: IBM of late has struggled to finds it differentiation and focus in market and again be an innovative leader. Much of this is because while it still has longer term strategies they are measured quarterly (or even monthly) and regular reorganization and reactive behavior and change keep them from achieving the persistence needed for long term success.

Pros: Follows the internal rulebook in conducting business. For example, one year a portion of my team received a significant portion of additional pay due to an adjustment based on working hours. It appears to me that IBM Payroll self corrected this without employees prompting the company for it. This shows IBM internal business is conducted strictly based on the written policies.
Cons: Company is encumbered by unnecessary processes, not nimble. Top down managerial approach. Company made acquisitions but does not know how to keep the vigor of the acquired entity alive, instead, shows down the energy by IBM's old fashioned culture and our sector was eventually divested from IBM so I say IBM need to think through their acquisition strategy. If you have multiple acquisitions that did not work out, it seems to question the business judgment of the leadership.

Pros: Tech stack is better than you might expect. They use the latest in cloud, artificial intelligence, and other skills.
Cons: Absolutely all things claimed to be done by Silicone Valley will be summarily implemented regardless of whether they apply to the specific situation. You'll spend much more time on compliance than productive work. Pay is at the lower end of what you could get. No raises or bonuses. Health insurance is more costly than average, barely less than hourly contract workers. HR will not share this publicly because it is so bad. They have an agile environment, you might find yourself like an ancient Egyptian slave building a useless pyramid under the whip of some under-educated "scrum master" who can barely turn on a computer.

Pros: IBM has may diverse avenues to travel in any career direction. If one gets tired of their job, they can look within IBM and move to something different within their field of training or something completely different. IBM strives to encourage team work and mentoring, so move to another job can be a good experience.
Cons: There are some areas where IBM has managed to under-staff which can cause undue stress. They try to encourage open communication across all levels of management, but sometimes it seems the communication lands on def ears. One has to take the recognition and not stress on the ignored.

Pros: I rejoined IBM because of great people I worked with before that I’d get to work with again. Unsurprisingly I have met even more incredible people who are working sincerely to help our clients and prospects to improve their security posture. Given the long history of patents which reflect the commitment to problem solving through innovation and iteration I’m proud to be a part of that fundamental drive to improve outcomes for people everywhere.
Cons: There’s still some matrixes of complexity that need to be addressed but as the company progresses through transforming to become nimble but firm in its core values I believe these will be addressed.

Pros: In my experience at IBM, managers were well-trained and were often interested in seeing employees grow and expand their skills.  IBM does hire some wonderful people - I was able to learn many skills from many of my teammates and also developed a variety of mentoring relationships.
Cons: Work-life balance was always promoted but not always well-enforced.  The size of IBM makes it a difficult company to learn and training in entry-level positions is not always available.  Compensation was not always in line with other companies (for those in their early careers) and oftentimes employees would have to threaten quitting to receive a retention bonus.

Pros: Excellent place to develop skills. Good internal training programs. Reasonable work/life balance. Great place for a first or second job to develop skills and training, before obtaining competitive compensation elsewhere.
Cons: Uncompetitive salary. Poor raises and bonuses even for top performers. Lack of career advancement opportunity, promotions extraordinarily difficult to come by, even for top performers. Middle management has significantly lack of vision. Employees are treated (and referred to as:) interchangeable "resources" rather than individuals. Many employees are average at best..80/20 rule applies

Pros: 4 weeks of vacation time.  Very good benefits.  They did pay for my Master's, although I don't think they're doing that anymore.  However, once I did get my Master's I was not allowed to actually use it in my work environtment.  In fact, I was actively discouraged from getting certified in my profession.  Additionally, I did the exact same job as someone else on the team, with whom no one could work, and yet he was two bands higher than I was for doing the same job.  I do love working from home though.  That to me is so worth what I'm doing.
Cons: You never know when you or your job is on the chopping block.

Pros:
There are a lot of good, honest, smart, competent, helpful people in IBM, and most of them will cooperate to get the job done.
The architects, strategists and designers do a good job and the product range (once acquired companies have been properly assimilated) is consistent and top class. 
The benefits are pretty good.  Even when they lay you off they make sure you don't fall flat on your face. 
Top management knows how to run a business, evidenced by the results over the last few years.
Cons: Centralized micro-management.  Anyone below director level has little or no discretion in how to do their jobs.  Targets are unnecessarily complex.  Admin such as travel bookings and expense reimbursement is done by Java programs against which there is no appeal.

Pros: Great technology, can work at home, connected place.  In the CIO's office got good visibility of what was going on around IBM, but the sense of being able to effect  change across the company was sometimes quite strained.  Not always possible.  Overall IBM is easy to move around (in normal times) so can take widely different jobs without changing employer and losing benefits.
Cons: Mentoring and development is on your own.  Management ability overall is matrixed and relatively poor and unskilled.    Generally new people are very on their on.  Great place for real go getters, but not so good for others.  Can be difficult to move in times of tight times.

Pros:
* Solid, well known company
* Performing well over the last few years ... they "beat" the recession
* Lot's of information available to those who want it
Cons:
* US workforce has been shrinking for years, the typical development team has to coordinate with teams in India, China, and Brazil
* Bonus and salary pools have been shrinking for years. Bonuses are typically prefaced with "Be happy you are getting a bonus, I had to lay two people off yesterday"
* Top appraisals being severely limited in the US and Europe. Management is unable to offer deserving people an appropriate appraisal

Pros: It was a good place to work when I first started working in 1998.  They used to pay for tuition reimbursements and provide professional classes to take every  year.  The bonuses used to good and was a good environment to work in.
Cons: With the recent job cuts the morals for US employees have gone down.  The goal is to get US based employees to below 100K and increase the headcount in India which is already above 90K.  Most employees work way too much overtime and most are stressed out.  Most people are worried about loosing their jobs.  There is no work life balance at IBM. Most people work from home. Most managers are not qualified to be managers and lack the education or certification in Management.

Pros:
Coworkers are intelligent, enjoyable to be around.
Good work/life balance - work from home as much as you need, just get the job done.
Structured, professional management style
Cons:
Company future outlook is bleak - constantly finding new ways to pare down our benefits.
Does not pay to obtain certifications/education or to go to conferences.
Upper management cuts jobs and expects deadlines to remain unchanged.

Pros: I really had a great experience working for IBM. The environment has a lot of trust and collaboration. I was assigned on really great projects even though I was right out of college. There is fantastic flexibility. There is no fixed office time and you can make your own as long as you get your job done. Lots of opportunity to work from home as well. The executives are very down to earth and really roll-up their sleeves to work. I may go back to work for the company again after a few years.
Cons: Salary increases are very slow. They make up for it in term of flex benefits, however if you stay here for long, you will lag the market in terms of pay. You may need to then jump a couple of jobs to get back at market pay.

Pros:
World-class benefits include excellent health insurance coverage, and dollar-for-dollar matching up to 6% on your 401k.

There are myriad career growth opportunities, with strong encouragement to increase and broaden your skills. Example, Ginni Rometty's challenge for employees to devote 40 hours to self-directed personal development.

If you live to work, you can really go far in the company.
Cons:
Salary tends to be lower relative to other companies, and raises are small. The best way to get a raise is to go to another company.

While there are many career paths, those opportunities, your direct manager plays a significant role in making those options a possibility. Additionally, much of that personal development must be done on your own time.

The "relative contribution" method used for annual reviews leaves employees in the dark about where they stand.

Pros: None None None and None whatsoever.
Cons: Management will use you and abuse you. give you meager pay and no raises/bonuses(even if there was , it'll be divided worldwide, which is about 50$ after taxes). IBM will Micromanage you to death and constantly increasing your workload and place you on a quota system.Meet you quota of 3 tickets a day, then it automatically increases to 4 then 5 till they cut down your department to barebone. You'll be rated every quarter. Your 401k will only be matched if you survive a whole year. Never have i experience so poor treatment and subjected to yearly sessions to belittle you on how easily replaceable you are and worthless. For those that got outsourced to IBM, well start looking for another job it's a dead end.  I had no choice when my previous company outsourced us to IBM.

Pros:
IBM does have all the "perks" of working for a big company.   It's still the largest technology company in the world, so there are few things that it isn't involved in.  
If you are unsure of exactly what you want to do or you like to explore all aspects of technology, it is fairly easy to move around (usually with some planning ahead 6-12 mo) and may have the opportunity to work and learn with some of the experts or juggernauts in each field tackling some of the largest/complex problems.
Cons: All the cons of a big company - so there can be a lot of politics, red tape, and freeloaders around.

Pros:
- Everyone is friendly, encouraging, there to help each other grow and learn
- ability to work remotely, or work from home (flexible and adaptive)
- professional but not stodgy 
- successfully turning around their design approach and embracing new methodologies
Cons:
- as an intern relatively brand new to my field and with all of my team working remotely, I felt at times lost and as though I was missing out on the powerful learning experience of in-person collaboration among my team and other interns (of course in fairness to IBM, during the interview process they stressed their desire for someone who was autonomous and took initiative). 
- Even looking at regular employees, I feel there is a great disadvantage to having teams so spread out (but also some advantages), this is certainly an area for IBM to reconsider

Pros: IBM has a lot of job possibilities to offer. The company is over 400,000+ employees. IBM deals with state of the art tech you will not find at other companies. The shear volume of customers will give you a huge amount experience that you can not get at smaller companies.
Cons: People are just numbers or assets to be used and discarded as needed. This is true for most major companies, so just be prepared. The focus is on cost/profit so depending what BU you work for you could be expected to do the work of a number of people. It can be hard and grueling at times.

Pros: It is a reputed company, and nice to have this brand name on your resume. Salary is competitive if you have other offer. Benefit package is reasonable.
Cons: The work/life balance at IBM is horrible. They want to suck all of your time and energy. IBM literally wants your 24/7 devotion (except during your 15 days vacation time). The immediate management always assign tons of work and says you have the flexibility to work from home (which they know it is impossible to finish at office). They always fire lots of people and hire fresh graduates. If you argue  little bit with the management you will be on their red list and when the work-force balance time comes (which is nowadays almost every year) you will  definitely get fired. Salary increment is very poor and you always have to chase the time line. IBM always believe once the employee accepts the job offer, they buy the candidate. IBM is a golden cage where you have no freedom.

Pros: Still generally a good (though no longer generous) employer staffed with skilled and intelligent people; operated by management as a good place to develop skills before leaving for a higher paying and/or more supportive employer
Cons: Unrelenting focus on cost reduction far beyond the point of diminishing returns; continual and ongoing takeaways for the past 25 years; highly "lawyerly" approach to communicating with employees about benefits; destructive management paradigm sometimes described as becoming comfortable with being uncomfortable; rank and file is even less impressed with senior management than senior management seems to be with us

Pros:
Powerful name in IT.
Access to an enormous network of talent.
Lots of computer based training available if you utilize it on your own time.
Flexible work environment.
Access to a broad range of tools and templates sharing industry best practices.
Access to experts in just about every IT topic imaginable
Nice benefits (except for salary)
Cons:
No loyalty to long term employees
You are just a tool in a giant toolbox or a number on a spreadsheet.  You have no meaning beyond that.
Low pay compared to industry standards
Laughable bonuses and pay raises.
No desire or interest in investing in long term employees.  Company would rather replace you than train you in something new.

Pros: Years ago it was a great company. The last 10 to 15 years have been horrible. Senior management cares about no one but themselves. HR is incompetent and a puppet. They are pretty much worthless when it comes to being an employee advocate.
Cons: You are constantly looking over your shoulder to be permanently laid off.  Pay for performance is a joke. It doesn't matter if you[re a top performer and have been for years, one day they will eventually get rid of you when they need to cut more cost. Everyone is just a number. There is no focus at all on what should be their most valued resource: their employees!

Pros: Not many.  The business direction is solid, execution leaves much to be desired.  The company is technically growing if one looks purely at employment numbers globally.
Cons: Too many to list.  Wages are far below industry standards.  The culture is one of extreme focus on LEAN and doing more with less, yet not realizing one can't squeeze blood from a rock.  Far too much emphasis on the "important" big ticket items, and the less sexy "back office" and "administrative" tasks which are still critical to the business are left by the wayside.  It's a terrible place to be if you're an American.

Pros:
Of course, IBM is large so things may be different depending on where you reside. 
Plenty of interesting technology to work with. They are very flexible with work schedule and location. Smart people for peers. Although the benefits are declining in value they are still pretty good.
Cons: They still use a standard distribution method to rate employees. The manager typically provides a review, which is different than a rating, then you are rated. Theoretically, the rating is correlated to the review. However, each group is given a distribution of ratings that have to be applied to the employees. Most people get average. But every group needs to have an underperformer. You can have a review of "walks on water" and still get an average rating.

Pros:
- Wonderful and bright people. 
- Reputation is still relatively strong despite decreasing focus on delivering value to clients.
- There are still heroic employees to save the day.
- Great benefits
Cons:
- Senior management that focuses only on cost cutting, to the detriment of client satisfaction and employee satisfaction. 
- Quarterly layoffs.
- Decrease in project controls and QA, leading to sub-par results for clients.
- Reducing US staff and replacing with much less experienced staff in other parts of the world. Fewer and fewer people know what they are doing and how to navigate the IBM structure and processes that continue to change. 
- 17 straight quarters of dropping revenues, and the CEO is not held accountable.

Pros: There was a time when IBM had a lot to offer but they have slowly taken it away.. Many people stayed for the flexibility as you will read review after review but they have now taken that away too so what was left of a pros has gone away.
Cons: They found a loophole to get rid of their USA employees, they always do.. There should be in a couple of months MANY positions available because they've forced many to resign with "relocating their positions".  I continue to see them lay off their USA employees it's just a matter of time.  They have taken away mobility.  Ive seen people dedicate their lives and just before retirement let them go and offer 1 month severance..  I promise google them. Go to Facebook "Watching IBM"..

Pros:
Where else can you truly change the world? IBM works on world changing progress in every corner of the globe, in every industry.
Career movement - you can work at this one company for many years and have many different job roles, titles, professions and experiences
Opportunities to volunteer and contribute to society like Corporate Service Corps, an employee "peace corps"
So many amazing world-class experts are your colleagues - with a few clicks, you can be sending messages to learn from a Nobel Prize laureate, a world-renowned designer, an AI trainer
Cons:
You have to learn the lingo and know how to work in a matrix - it can be hard to operate that way if you come from a small company
Long-time IBMers are often very cynical, so it's hard to break out of the cycle and try new things

Pros: Work-life balance was good.  There was significant flexibility.  I was not micromanaged (partly as a result of good managers; not all enjoyed this).  Some great technical folk.  Can be fun to work on great products.  Some resources were excellent and that could make work fun and productive.
Cons: Culture and morale became very poor with all the layoffs and poor management at many levels (above 1st).  Pay was uncompetitive.  Became a financial product company:  products felt like afterthought, which made product development not fun or successful.  Poor at attracting, developing, and retaining top-quality talent.  Not good at getting rid of low-performers (many layoffs, but they seemed to be only weakly correlated with performance on the job).  Even so, became very "stack-rank" driven, putting co-workers at odds rather than encouraging collaboration for the best product/company-result.

Pros:
Great work-life balance as many IBMers are family-oriented and the work is not demanding like a startup. Opportunities to brainstorm and file patents. 
Teams like the design studio, mobile innovation lab, or security have challenging and fun work/culture, but most of Austin IBM working on the chip/cloud is lowkey energy and monotomous without challenging work. 
The reputation of IBM goes a long way on the resume. 
Paid conference trips if you present or help with the booth.
Cons:
Potential stagnation of career due to legacy technology and prioritization of stability over innovation. Most teams lack the zest and drive you'll find in small engineering teams at startups. 
Austin 9xx and 045 offices are drab and are unpleasant to work in.

Pros: The projects are intriguing and provide good opportunities to work with new technology and expand your technical skills.
Cons:
Many company policies and rules are designed to avoid paying employees. This includes such unethical practices as laying off hundreds of workers 3 days before they would be eligible for the once-per-year 401k match.

Management is also more concerned with the question of "can the product do X?" without any concern for "can the product do X well?", which leads to stifling of innovation and lack of ability to build a product you're actually proud of. The expectation before promotions is also that you fill the role before getting any compensation or title change for it.

Pros:
The people (IBMers) are great colleagues and people to work. There are plenty of mentors and leaders that can help you to navigate the big corporate world.
It offers flexibility with work hours and work-from-home options. 
As WW global company, you can travel and see the world. Also, once you in you can explore a lot of different roles without leaving the company. 
You can have an opportunity to work on a first-of-a-kind and some research project.
Cons:
Birocrarcay. It would be best if you had a lot of approvals to do anything beyond everyday work. 
It is a spreadsheet, Wall Street driven company without good care for employees. The previous resource actions were brutal to some groups. Thus, the trust in management is deficient. In many cases, you are just a number on the spreadsheet. 
Trust in the brand is becoming iffy.

Pros: A perpetual learning environment -- chances to grow never cease. You will be working with the smartest, sharpest people on the planet. Opportunity to work with global teams provides chances to grow both personal international friendships and rewarding professional networks. Total encouragement to solve challenging problems -- for those that like to work hard
Cons: You have to promote yourself to become recognized in this big organization. That takes additional time away from your core job responsibilities. You have to be on an incredibly successful project to advance. So, vigilant analysis of business hotspots -- and re-skilling if necessary to move to a position in an emerging area -- is the best way to get ahead. You must keep up with what keeps this company ticking to build out a rewarding career, and this requires a substantial investment in time.

Pros: Relaxed work environment with flexible scheduling.  Variety of work and opportunities is tremendous.  IBM also provides a means for changing between jobs within the company and allows you to shadow other jobs to see if a different position would be right for you.  Good benefits package.  Great discount program.
Cons: Big corporation bureaucracy.  You see a lot of the "red tape" that is typically associated with companies of this size.  Everyone complains about the lack of raises and promotions which is standard with what I've seen at other large companies; there's only so much money to go around.

Pros: IBM is a recognized name in the IT industry
Cons: IBM preaches work from home and work life balance, but they don't practice what they preach. Management have a much easier time moving to other positions within IBM, than non-management staff. Very political place to work...IBM has been in a constant state of change over the last four plus years and very little of it has benefited the employee, from no longer offering a pension to revoking work from home privileges to all employees within the our division to not granting pay increases for even some of their top performers for two years running now. Overall a huge surprise to someone who grew up in the Big Blue family.

Pros: Professional development is infinite at IBM with the full spectrum of positions from engineering to business.  Deal with state-of-the-art in technology solutions.  One of the few companies which do the entire spectrum in the IT industry from hardware to software, everything can be done in-house if needed.  Best reasonable respect given to employees regarding work-life balance.  Have to possibilities to explore and find the exact position that interest you.  The employee, including first line managers have excellent people skills.  IBM has its hands in very special markets due to its specialties and legendary status.
Cons: One of the largest companies in the world comes with a large amount of possibilities but with a slow response to feedback.  Compensation is right at industry average levels.

Pros: I has mostly good coworkers but I am not impressed with upper management.
Cons: IBM has offshored my positions 3 separate times and now laid off. The benefits are shrinking every year. More people seem more cut throat that in the past because of the way reviews are given so it is harder to get a sense of a good team atmosphere.  It is a joke how they do appraisals since they make us write personal business commitments as our goals and we could accomplish all the goals we set forth.  But these PBCs are not used in the evaluation. 1st line managers haggle with other 1st line managers over who "ranks" higher so you better hope your manager is close to you and they are better at debating with other managers.

Pros: Very good people throughout the company - far better than IBM deserves.
Cons: Sadly, IBM has made alienating its workforce into an art form.  People work under continual threat of  being laid off, and those who remain watch their benefits erode every year.  Every action from upper management reflects their attitude that "human capital" is to be used and then discarded.  You are free to dismiss this post as a rant from a disgruntled ex-employee, but mark my words - join IBM and 1) you'll be sorry, and 2) you'll be back here to leave a post identical to this one.  Run, don't walk, from this sorry excuse for a company.

Pros: IBM has good products and a lot of them.  Since the product portfolio is strong, there are options in moving within a division to sell different solutions.  The pay is competitive, but limited by the absurd quota setting and six month cycle.  Lots of professional and knowledgeable people work at the customer level.
Cons: The Peter principle of management is in full effect.  Those in management are typically put there for the wrong reasons.  Success in selling has no impact on success as a manager.  To much of a revolving door on the sales territories means that valuable customer relationships are being ignored.

Pros: Still provides some opportunities for learning new technologies, albeit on our own time.
Cons: Absolutely no job security.  They fire employees on a regular basis with no regard for the level of contribution.  They may use the terms "Resource Action" or "Workload Balancing", but the net effect is the same to those who are "selected for participation".  I'd never recommend IBM to anyone as a career choice.  Only a job to do until they can find something better.

Pros: Lots of talented people; great networking; competitive salary and benefits package; lots of free education on line; flexible working conditions including work from home
Cons: You are only a number; you get pigeonholed in an area and it is very hard to move on; education in a classroom setting is very restricted; pennypinching seems to abound (removal of reimbursement for internet access; reduced expense allowed for phone calls; removal of the Thanks award program); always waiting for the next resource action induces a lot of stress.

Pros: My experience with IBM was both good and bad.  The good part is that there are a lot of new positions to switch to.  Many people who I worked with did this.
Cons: Here is the bad: I worked for a part of IBM that was being restructured.  During the process, a corporate guy came to our office and told us what was going on.  He gave the impression that there would be changes, but the changes that happened were much more significant that what he implied.  After that, a few people I worked with at IBM moved to other parts of the company.  Now, the place where I worked is significantly smaller.

Pros:
Working remote/home for many positions (just be aware that this is a prelude to EVENTUALLY outsourcing your job to a cheaper 3rd world locale). You have access to some strong co-workers for support and to learn from.  In general, there are also many opportunities to get involved with different technologies (although that comes with a caveat, see my comments in the "cons" section). And across the industry, for resume purposes, IBM still has a good name so take advantage of it while it lasts.

IBM is now a good company for any fresh-out-of-school newbie that wants to gain some standard 21st corporate world experience. Plus the pay is not bad for newbies. For more experienced workers however, IBM is very limited.  Executive management's not-so-secret agenda is to layoff as many "high priced" USA-based employees (and in other developed countries) and outsource everything possible to the 3rd world. Any gaps are theoretically back-filled with the "layoffees" as contractors, assuming they can't find work elsewhere.
Cons:
At this point in IBM's history, it's a lot like life during the decline of the Roman Empire. There were worse places to live during the decline of the empire but the Visigoths were coming. When considering the eradication of IBM's developed-world workforce (and compensation packages) throughout a never-ending quest to transfer the payrolls to cheaper 3rd world countries, there is a lot of risk involved with working at IBM long term.  In the short term, it's a decent place to pay your dues for a few years and then leave for greener pastures with 'IBM' on your resume.

You'll have lots of exposure to different technologies at IBM. Unfortunately, a lot of what's forced on you is either proprietary, obscure, or rapidly vanishing outside the world of IBM (think Lotus Word Pro, Lotus Notes, Domino, etc). Many US-based jobs at IBM are "tenuous", so the workplace feels a lot like dining under the Sword of Damocles.
