Since your co-workers know that the end could come at any moment, and their survival depends upon how well they rank compared to you, the result is reduced information flow/share, cooperation, participation, and general workplace camaraderie among your co-workers.

On the subject of "how you rank", the PBC system (performance reviews) at IBM is a TOTAL FARCE.  It's basically a random system of ranking by the managers. Worse yet, you usually already have a performance number assigned before the evaluations ever begin -- based on who the manager's favorite employees are, how many people in the dept the execs said will need to be laid off in the next year, etc.  

Specific to a bonus/commission/performance-based role at IBM like the TSM position, another rub is that you don't pick your assignments - they're given to you. So, if a manager needs to get rid of someone, it's far easier to assign the "DOA" and "tire-kicking" deals (which are almost certain to go nowhere and therefore result in lower performance) to anyone targeted for layoff than it is to deal with concocting other reasons to get rid of them and thereby meet executive management's employee attrition goals.

Pros: Working for the IBM brand has benefits. Excellent benefits, but pay can vary greatly depending on how high value your work is. Services is more low value, margins are low and so are pay scales. That said, there are also some computing areas that are high paying and high value, if you are lucky enough to have earned those skills.
Cons: IBM is an ocean to work in. There is move to relocate work towards global delivery centers and tier 3 cities and away from the work from home model to reduce costs. This means layoffs for those high paying jobs unless you are willing to relocate to these centers. If you are a rock star and perform high value technical work or client facing work that involves intimate knowledge of client domain there is a good chance you will not get RA-ed.

Pros: I was a software development summer intern at the Mass lab in Littleton, MA. The location is really nice during the summer, and the premises feel pretty new. This probably varies for each intern, but the team I was in was really nice and willing to help me with my problems, and we all got along pretty well. Pay depends on the number of credits towards your degree that you've finished, but the rate is relatively good.
Cons: Even as an intern, you can feel the bureaucracy going on in the background. Also, this depends on the team, but be prepared to have a lot of meetings, most if not all of them including having to deal with the joy that is conference calls.

Pros:
If you can get a job in an area of investment (e.g. cloud, research) and keep transferring into the shiny new areas that IBM Executives are all excited about then the likelihood that you will remain employed at IBM increases.

Ability to telecommute is a great benefit of IBM.
Cons:
Benefits are average but not thrilling.  Health care insurance is expensive at IBM.  Severance pay is sub-par.

IBM overworks its employees.  Following 2008 productive increased 10-fold but IBM didn't increase pay or benefits and hasn't staffed up to reduce work load on employees.

IBM loves to lay off people and doesn't like employees to stay past 25 or 26 years.

IBM Executives are short sighted and distracted by the stock price and earnings per share at the expense of their employees and customers.

Pros: Strong support for internal and external education. Flexible scheduling. Improved review processes. Support for volunteerism. Great benefits both medical and financial. Positive reinforcement from colleagues is encouraged through BlueThx program. Mentorship encouraged.
Cons: The only downside that I can think of is that change has been slow because of the massive size of the organization. But as the company is turning to an Agile methodology it appears that changes are happening a little more quickly. Also, while IBM encourages employees to learn about new IBM applications, it could do a better job of ensuring that all departments have the means of incorporating appropriate software into their department processes.

Pros: 401(k), High quality co-workers, working with Fortune 500 and Fortune 100 accounts.  Short Term disability plan is excellent (but no one wants to have to use that, right?).
Cons: Sales plans are aimed at not rewarding highly skilled, high performing employees.  Commissioned positions may not receive commission for 3 to 6 months.  Employee rating system limits top rating to a bell curve type distribution, regardless of department member's performance.  If you achieve your quota, during the year, it may be raised to a higher quota before the end of the year.

Pros:
For consulting and IT specialists, fair salary, but don't expect bonus.  Take the job, get some experience, then move on.

For Sales, base salary adequate with high earning potential; but you can make more on commission selling real estate.

Attempting to change; just going about it the wrong way.
Cons:
Poor morale.

No corporate loyalty - you need to watch out for #1...IBM will not have your back.

Lack of balance between Accountability, Authority, and Responsibility.

HR is not your friend; they exist primarily to limit corporate liability.

Clients are not first priority - first priority is earnings and revenue.  Hence lack of real leadership, failure to leverage experienced work force, resulting in poor financials.  Vicious circle.

Pros:
Mobile employee with lots of freedom
Great training
Still a good name on the resume and a place to get paid to learn
Still bright spots of pure talent if you can find it
Cons:
Constantly changing territory and product bag; reps have been spinning their wheels for years
Constant, pointless change in strategy and organization hierarchy
Top Heavy: lower and middle management have no authority to run the business
Rolling layoffs have destroyed morale
Company is run entirely focused on short term net income which is destroying it
Massive, government-like bureaucracy

Pros: The people, the variety, the customers are all awesome!
Cons: Too many reorganizations, ineffective management(!), unrealistic understanding from management of what is really going on in the field and unwillingness to listen to the people who are interacting with customers on a daily basis; hiring of too many inexperienced Client Executives who are supposed to be the key contact with many high level customer executive managers, and as a result, are ineffective - period; this has hurt many account relationships and resulted in lost business; so frustrating for the account team selling specialist solutions to these customers

Pros: I just recently on-boarded with IBM in Columbia, MO and I couldn't be happier with my experience thus far. The opportunities are endless, the energy is vibrant, and everyone is incredibly welcoming and helpful. IBM seems very "fluid" in their approach to different areas of business, and I find that refreshing because it allows for employee's to share their thoughts/suggestions. I  am very excited to see where things lead with IBM.
Cons: I'd say the one drawback I have come across is the multiple apps/programs that are used. Not the end of the world -- just an improvement opportunity I have noticed.

Pros: Competitive Benefits package but a bit average now.   Vacation time is not Vacation and Sick time (Sick time is as needed).    retooling to be more attractive to recent graduates
Cons: It is trying to find its way in an increasingly competitive landscape.   have trouble finding its next big thing.  Watson may be it but Google, MS, Apple and Amazon are also competing in that space.   IBM does well when it can command a premium and not so well with commodity products.

Pros: Amazing company  with a culture of innovation, in continuous transformation, leader in AI, Blockchain, and strong position in the battle for the cloud. Salaries are competitive for the industry, there are endless opportunities to grow within the company, nice people, hands off leadership, many more benefits, overall great company to work for.
Cons: continuous change can be challenging for many people to embrace and adapt and then change again (change of clients, territories, products on the portfolios, managers, leadership, go to market strategy, new products, new teams ETC) = change, change, change, be ready for it. If you can deal with it (I personally find it engaging), then you are in good hands

Pros: There is only ONE “pro” and that is working from home.  That’s it!
Cons:
This company cares NOTHING about the employee. They care about one thing.  Dollars!  

Clients hate us. The processes are insane and quash all ability to work with any creativity. 

IBM does not care about its customers. If they only knew what goes on behind the scenes. 

No bonuses, or when they come they are a complete and utter joke.  Less than 1% of salary. 

Raises non existent for anyone other than management. 

In short, unless you are a complete F-up, I’d run for the hills as this company will put you in the dirt. 

They expect you to give them your heart and soul, but when the bean counters or analysts decide they need to cut, you could be Mother Teresa and you’ll still get kicked to the curb with an immoral 1 mo severance.  No matter your tenure.

Pros:
1. Meet research gurus and many famous geniuses
2. Steady, stable work environment; not terribly high pressure
3. Have lots of time to learn new things and experiment
4. Excellent support and incentives for patent development
5. Many tech talks, outside visitor talks of great interest
Cons:
1. Can sometimes feel cloistered, esp. since said geniuses are usually not social wizards
2. Salary / Title growth very slow
3. Very miserly, essentially nonexistent bonus program
4. Highly bureaucratic -- almost like government

Pros:
Good benefits
Great career opportunities if you want to put in the work
Cons:
Zero job security
DO NOT RECOMMEND FOR COLLEGE GRADS
Some new hires are assigned SAP practice and it's very hard to get out of (SAP incredibly dry and pays less than other roles) New hires have no choice over their starting assignment.... at least when I joined

Pros: I enjoy working with really smart people and IBM is filled with them.  People typically have a very well-meaning, "how can I help" attitude.  The benefits are great with annual rebates for participating in a healthy living program.
Cons: The cash portion of compensation is lacking.  For instance, I've been at the company for four years and have always received "top performer" or "above average contributer" ratings and have received a single 3.5% raise.  Another complaint is the beaurocracy and paperwork required to do anything.  We are significantly less nimble than our competitors because of this.  It can also be difficult for some to work in a matrixed organization where you have to please multiple people, both your direct management and others.

Pros: Tremendous work flexibilty in terms of when and where to work.  Depending on job may work with some of the best minds in the industry.  Salary and benefits are competitive, however the cost of living in the Poughkeepsie, NY location has gotten dramaticly more expensive over the past few years but salaries haven't nearly kept up to make it worthwhile to live/work here instead of for example a place like Austin, TX.
Cons: Stagnant salary and career growth.  New hires fleeing due to uninpired leadership and work.  Very low morale.  High cost of living and not other opportunities in the area outside of IBM keeps salaries down.

Pros: Very interesting work, particularly in the more technical areas. Lots of smart people to work with. Lots of opportunity to move, and if you are lucky you can gradually move into a job that is a good fit for you. This might be harder is a smaller company.
Cons: Very big company - not all parts of the company are equally well run. Some parts don't seem to be as good as others (in terms of being a good place to work).

Pros: The IBM name is impressive on a resume.  Some of the folks working there are very talented.  Some of the managers are very good and understanding of the pressures in the work place.
Cons: Overall a cut-throat, finger-pointing environment.  Managers have no problem yelling at individuals in front of their peers.  When work load is heavy, management expects employees to work round the clock to meet THEIR ridiculous schedules.  Too many releases leaving exhausted employees with no time to regroup.

Pros: Great place to learn from others
Cons: Focus is given to those who only exist to contribute to IBM, without regards for any personal life. In other words while IBM touts "work/life balance" as being important, it actually encourages an "all work / no personal llfe" atmosphere. The moment a person realizes that they need to slow down and re-claim their personal life, IBM loses interest in that person and labels them as "making too much money...", hoping that the person will eventually get frustrated from a lack of forward financial progress, and simply quit. Alternatively, if the person doesn't quit, they get laid off.

Pros: Stable, well funded, solid company.  Can change careers within the company and maintain benefits.  Although that may have changed in recent years.  IBM is a survivor and is a market leader in many areas.  Working for IBM can open doors.  The IT infrastructure that supports internal operations is well managed and reliable.
Cons: The perks that used to make working for IBM valuable are going away.  No pension, no job security, and no sense of community.  Frequest downsizings.  The executives say one thing and do another.  Misleading information and half truths are communicated to employees regarding future objectives.  The soul of the company is gone.

Pros: Great people. Lots of opportunities inside IBM. Good compensation.
Cons: Performance review is done in a meaningless way. Everybody except one or two has the same performance review. Some managers are incompetent compared to others. Generally, performance reviews must be done strictly to managers as well as employees. Whatever standard will be like publication, patent, and product impact, it needs to be completely reviewed. Senior management is only running the company to maximize their own personal compensation. Work coordination between teams is not done well. Decision is made very slowly. Good work often is not recognized if you are under incompetent manager. If you want to work at IBM, try to find competent manager.

Pros: company with solid financials, established footprint in emerging markets, breadth of portfolio, well established and respected brand, as saying goes 'no one is fired for hiring IBM'
Cons: large and disconnected organization, insular groups with no incentive to work with other groups or divisions, new hires left to their own devices to acclimate to firm and figure out how to be successful, career path unclear, nepotism rampant and trumps competence in career advancement, 20yr veterans has top slots so newcomers have a while to wait to reach senior level, matrix management of at least two managers for each employee is a waste of money and cons outweigh the pros

Pros: The people at IBM are second to none in intelligence and problem solving ability.  You learn more working here for 5 years than you will at any other company.  Lots of ability to know the whole computing industry and define what you want to work on
Cons: Upper management is only concerned about EPS.  Thus squeezing most of the innovation out of the company.  Most innovation is now accomplished by working extra hours and struggling versus being encouraged and part of the job descriptions.  Lots of work as well making charts with pretty colors that executives and management can understand versus doing product cutting edge work.

Pros:
Flexibility to work at home for many people.
Great benefits.
Company name recognition.
Cons:
Push by IBM to move many jobs from the US to other countries. IBM has made it clear that as a global company, they want a global workforce. While this makes sense in some ways, IBM is letting really good people, with experience and knowledge go, simply because they are based in the US. This move of resources to other countries means there are many people new to the company and job. 
Excessive workload leads to excessive work hours. It is expected that you will work nights/weekends to complete all the work that needs to be done.
Focus on negatives instead of positives.

Pros:
Great and reliable research sources, very intelligent workforce.
Excellent IT resources - no end to what you can have to enable a data deluge
A place to make a few great friends outside of the corp culture
Diverse enough so you're not always talking to "the man"
Cons:
in an effort to bring operation costs down, down, down  (and show profits)- employment in the US is almost non-existent.
too much management  (un-actionable) 
too much cross functional decision-making, makes projects and success long and protracted
still too siloed , GBS vs, S&D, vs, SWG - no single face to the customer
groups work against each other, and there is no hesitance to throw folks under the bus with lots of blame-gaming.

Pros: Even in the economy of today, IBM has continued to provide pretty favorable benefit plan options. Comprehensive medical, dental and vision plans are all still offered which in today's economy is very much needed and welcomed.
Cons: IBM continues to layoff employees practically monthly under the guise of the phrase Resource Action and the directive or reason most often given is "  re-engineer and move your work to an offshore location". If work were to remain in the US would not that help with the issue of unemployment in the United States?

Pros: IBM still has some of the world's best engineers, and we have access to cutting-edge technology.  Work-life balance is excellent.  Compensation is decent.
Cons: Our new CEO, Virginia Rometty, seems to have no vision for the future of the company.  She's a manager, not a leader.  The semiconductor business, where I work, is increasingly being pushed aside in favor of IBM's higher-margin services business, which is itself increasingly moving to India.  Working in semiconductors has become mostly an exercise in cost-control rather than innovation.

Pros: Good product offering and customers usually want to hear from you.  Working from home is becoming pretty standard for most jobs.
Cons: This is a huge company and the disconnect between upper management and everyone else is impressive at times.  I think I'd have a better chance of seeing the Pope in person than our CEO.  Big changes (base pay reductions, org changes) can be pushed down in an arbitrary fashion with sometimes little rationale.  Even managers 3 or 4 levels up don't seem to know what is going on at times.   Politics is just as important as the quality of your work, so know that going in.

Pros: We'll established systems that work really well.  Expense reimbursements are pretty much clockwork.  Travel agency does a good job.
Cons: Second straight year with 10,000+ layoffs or resource actions as they call it.  Layoffs seemed to be random since some people had 75%+utilization and already booked on projects for most of current year but they were still laid off.  They also had good performance ratings the past few years. Too much self service and hard to get a hold of competent people to help with questions.  Must rely on your own network to get some things done.

Pros: Smart, dedicated co-workers; Some vestiges of the old collegiality at the working level.
Cons:
IBM's business model is totally out of date.  They are now being marginalized by new players like Google, Amazon, etc., and old competitors like HP-Compaq.   As sales are falling drastically, they can't fire people fast enough.  The executives are running the place like a third-world banana republic:  Massive bonuses for themselves, the working stiffs in the US are all being fired for low-cost third-world labor offshore.  

The only engineering innovation that matters any more is financial engineering of the Earnings per share.  However, EPS targets can only be achieved by layoffs and share buybacks, due to falling sales, and Wall Street isn't fooled.  Businesses and employees are being jettisoned at a rapid pace, a much smaller and weaker company will be the result.

Pros: Good benefits and time off, if you can get it.
Cons: No matter what your level of experience is, if you do not brown nose, you will be stuck in the same position until you quit or they fire you. They promote inexperienced managers who are hated because they don't know enough to get out of a locked room. You will be worked to death, and you don't ever expect a thank you. When they decide they want you out, they concoct ridiculous reasons to push you out the door. They lie to clients, don't meet deadlines because their management staff is incompetent and knows zero about the industry. They are behind the times in their thought process, think 1968. Seriously, what other company remotely thinks mainframes are a technological advancement?

Pros:
Good benefits
Pay is OK but a little below local market average
Ability to move around in the company -- I've had 3 jobs in 8 years (by choice)
The company has a deep technical stack that is not matched by its competitors
Cons:
The market is changing, so is IBM and those changes are painful (including lots of job cuts)
Management changes major focus every few years and abandons thing that were key before they have a chance to produce results
Growth by acquisition, not by native development
Many customers see the company as having old, outdated technology.

Pros: Liberal vacation, time off (ie. sick, funeral, etc) Great work from home policy if you work for the right manager/division. No ceiling on your growth potential. Training and learning opportunities abound if you look for them and have the right manger that supports doing that. IBM wants you always learning always growing and always contributing. If you don't like change this is not the place for you. You have to reinvent yourself every 5-7 years.
Cons: Constant layoffs, horrible middle management. Huge disconnect of local management with corporate Armonk. Pay is different for each region. Find out about the pay for your region first.

Pros: There's only one benefit when working with IBM - work from home.  And that makes it all worthwhile for many.  Unfortunately, they know this, and hold you and your family hostage with low salary, no pay raises, intimidation, long hours, no perks (like no internet reimbursement, no cell phone, small cheap workstation etc)
Cons:
Everything else.  Management has no idea what to do.  There's always a general business direction crises of some sort in play.  Many goal oriented buzzwords appear and disappear without cause, usually daily.  Bluemix, Cloud, Mobile, Analytics etc.  But they all lose support in short time.  

You'll be harassed by all levels of management, as it flows from the top down.  You'll be assigned to work some new strategic objective such as Watson, but pulled away when bad numbers are publicized.  You'll be forcibly placed into another in-vogue area such as Cloud, but that will fail also within a few years where you'll be moved to yet another hot-item such as Agile development.  

Sometimes you'll be sent to an entirely different department, perhaps over to customer-facing duties where the customer contract is chaotic and usually in legal contention.  There you'll sit for months doing nothing, except filling out billing forms to keep your utilization numbers up.  

From there you'll be pulled from that "account" to another (different) customer, where the cycle starts again.  Then you'll likely end up back in Mobile or something, where one will languish for a few years until you're finally RA'd – that’s FIRED – not laid off.  Along with 20k others in the US, and 110K world wide.  But wait – Ginny said there’s 20k job openings.  Whew.  Thought it was gonna be a disaster for a second there.  A quick check of the job openings shows a strange removal of jobs after a one week posting.  You’ll print one out and call the hiring manager.  

Hiring manager asks where you got the requisition as they are pulled every week.  After you explain, he indicates that there’s a global hiring freeze throughout the company, and his department is no exception.  Feeling compassionate, he explains why he has to post them in the first place, then remove them 7 days later.  And he was never going to be allowed to hire for it in any event.  He’s busy and hangs up.

You'll miss the usual severance, and receive a month's pay before you're escorted to the doors.  You'll also forego your usual 401k match, because they sneakily changed the year's contribution to once/year on December 15th only - and only if you're still with the company on that date.  

Then you'll find yourself 57 yrs old trying to find a job with the IBM albatross hanging around your neck.  You'll think back to when you were 30 yrs old, where you were confident and cocky, knowing that nothing like this could EVER happen to you.  You snickered at the old folks, the 55+ crowd, and wondered why in heck IBM didn’t get rid of them so you could get a raise for yourself.  But now at 57, your family and kids will look at you in distain for being unemployed.  You've let them down.

Then you'll come to the realization of why IBM's legal dept is more than 8% of the company when you try to argue age discrimination.  Or why the latest RA took all of your friends over the age of 53, but mysteriously none of the hot shot kids or young management types.

You'll wonder why there's a list of con's of this company that goes on for 20 paragraphs, compared to just 1 for the Pros.  You'll wonder why investors don't see the execs wrecking the place in a hysteria, each taking home $15mil/yr salaries, with $7mil/yr bonuses, and another $45mil/yr in stock options.  You’ll imagine the execs stretched out and sleeping on one of the company’s fleet of 20 large luxury private biz jets on their way to the monthly financial meetings in Europe.  You’ll imagine.

In the meantime, the IRS is after you for some silly 401k malefaction and has put a lien on your house, IBM has sent your name to the credit bureau for a $920.00 trumped up travel voucher you supposedly never paid.  You'll wonder what has happened, or were you just run over by a bus?

Coming home someday you stop by the mailbox and notice a letter from IBM.  It's from Ginny.  She's congratulating you on your "retirement", and offers you a choice of 1) Jelly of the month 2) a jumpstart cable box or 3) a magazine subscription.  I’ll wonder if I should just toss it, or if she’s serious.  She is, and it gets tossed.

As winter sets in, you'll wonder

Pros:
Good overall benefits especially the 401k contribution.
Methodical and structured approach to business and planning gives some indication of order.
The work level can be manageable and overall the work environment is pretty flexible.
Cons:
History of moving many high tech positions offshore reduces long term job security in US
Frugal to the point of being absurd at times. Pay was decent at first but pay raises were very small.
Very bureaucratic. Many levels of approvals and management required to make things happen.

Pros: I have 25 years at IBM and have loved the journey. The culture is based on a core set of IBM values, but each area has it's own personality. I have had the opportunity to challenge myself to grow my career and responsibilities with each new assignment. I had the opportunity to work from home for the last 15 years  - and that gave me the chance to have a bit of work/life balance while contributing at a very high level.
Cons: Constant 'rebalancing' these days which is an ibm term for 'lay off'. It used to be an annual thing but it has turned to monthly. Morale is down in the areas where this is happening more frequently, as expected. And it very difficult to see talented folks let go.

Pros: The best reason to work at IBM is... I honestly can't come up with the best reason to work at IBM. I'm sure that there are plenty of wonderful reasons to work for IBM, but for me, it has easily been the worst professional experience of my career.
Cons: IBM Marketing consistently demonstrates a complete lack of strategic thinking coupled with constantly changing and competing priorities which lead to every day being a fire drill. Add management's recent decision to co-locate all marketing activities in six cities, and you have a toxic stew of negativity, a lack of accountability and morale that's so low that most people are working on an exit strategy.  For these reasons and many others, I would not recommend working in marketing at IBM.

Pros:
- Take chances on hiring "new collar" workers with no formal education
- Big teams making real world products with huge user bases
- IBM Design is young, creative, and blood-thirsty. They're IBM's killer feature right now and most of the company doesn't even know they exist.
Cons: It's an old guard brand and an old guard company trying to find it's place in the modern world. Some of it's biggest competitors are ruthlessly innovative start ups. At also over 300,000 employees it's very easy to just coast by and do just enough skipping from team to team, but it's hard to thrive if you're an ambitious and career minded coder.

Pros: "Some" very good people to work with.   The products used to be good, but now it feels like they should be in hospice.
Cons:
Much of the upper-middle and upper management are only trying to get their next promotion.    

The result is that very shortsighted decisions get made and often hurt the products, integrations and the people building/selling them.

MVP is a common phrase now with Product Dev/Mgmt --- this is not referring to Most Valuable Process.   MVP refers to Minimal Viable Product and they rarely meet this MVP requirement.

The amount of middle-management headcount through most of IBM is surprising.    There were 4 mid-tier managers that had no direct reports in our reasonably small territory.  IBM also chose to cut people that were genuinely doing work and adding value instead of repurposing spreadsheets.

Pros: Ability to work from home
Cons: I worked in IBM Global Services whose only focus was on cost reduction that was done at the expense of their employees and their customers.  Experienced, knowledgeable, highly competent employees were laid-off and replaced with inexperienced resources from other countries.  As a result, productivity and the quality of work produced suffered.  In Global Services, the only thing that mattered was utilization, and it was not unusual to have quarterly utilization targets of 120%-130%.  Obviously, in order to meet those targets, especially if you had taken vacation or training time, significant, unpaid, overtime was required on a consistent weekly basis.  Employee raises were very infrequent and small.  Unsurprisingly, morale was very low.

Pros: Fellow IBM employees are usually great to work with and add to the spirit of teamwork.
Cons: Left IBM in latest round of layoffs announced in March, 2018.  IBM sales management creates a hostile work environment.  Constant pressure to sell software with little regard for customers needs.  IBM Cloud Private is not ready to sell nor does it have required certifications.  IBM Sales Management micro manages employees with weekly and individual daily sales reviews at the end of the month and quarter.  IBM delays commission payments to employees as they see fit.  Recent sales closed in June were only paid at the end of September, almost 90 days.  Even new hires have little chance to be hired into full time positions when they complete training.  Obvious effort to get rid of longer term employees in favor of younger new hires.  Don't plan on moving ahead at IBM US Federal let alone getting paid on time.

Pros: Recent college grads treated like golden children. Learning opportunities and wild advancement beyond their skill sets. Young people with minimal skills were trained and promoted
Cons: Experienced people are treated very poorly and have zero job security. A culture of idolized youth over knowledge and skills. If you are beautiful and dress well, you will do well here. If you are middle aged and look over 40, go elsewhere. Worst and most extreme age discrimination practices imaginable. I have never seen or heard of a worse place for people over 40. If even 10% of the staff was over 40. Thus was in what should be a technical and product area.

Pros: Quick path to promotions/raises if hard working, Pretty lax work environment including work hours, and easy to talk to higher ups.
Cons: In my particular office we are usually understaffed because the pay is lower due to the area we are located. This causes them to hire people who aren't necessarily cut out for the job and keep them because they're better than losing the contract. This can be good and bad because if you're hard working you will excel like I said in the pros but it is bad because you tend to get on projects with people who are there to just pickup a paycheck and you end up having to take on more work.

Pros:
Fast paced work that is challenging.
Amazing people and culture to work in.
Career opportunities are seemingly endless.
Visibility to leadership.
Promotions are given quickly to top performers.
Hybrid work (in-person & remote) as of 4Q22. 
Opportunity to work in different countries. 
Collaboration of employees across the globe.
Top tier education for employees - dedicated time to learn and grow your skills. 
Mentorship / shadow opportunity are abundant and encouraged.
Extremely inclusive culture in finance. Diverse workforce up until senior management.
Cons:
Outdated internal financial systems/tools.
Average pay (has been better in recent years).
Some population that does not adapt easily to change.
Uncertain direction for some parts of the business. Kyndryl spin off has helped tremendously.
Senior management is not diverse in ethnicity and backgrounds.

Pros: Many of IBM's employee's are remote workers. This comes with both pro and con qualities. The pro's are obvious, less gas used, less time spent in travel, flexible work hours, etc. The only real con is isolation. The division I work in has been extremely generous with flex time, allowing me to work when I want.
Cons: IBM is such a huge organization that sometimes getting through the red tape to accomplish something is horrible. Most everything in my division is driven by customer dollars, leaving little room for R&D type activities.

Pros: Dedicated employees. Competitive pay and benefits. Large company with opportunity for skills and career advancement. Ability to work from home, job permitting.
Cons: Tasked to meet billable hours, which most times greatly exceed 40 hours.  Whether or not you agree, a GBS employee is committed to 100% travel if s/he is a part of the GBS organization.  Persons on external (green dollar) accounts are oftentimes treated better than those on internal (blue dollar) accounts come promotions, variable pay and raises.  Management is great at not giving employees all the facts when presenting sensitive issues, such as the salary plan (raises).  Continued initiatives to offshore labor.  Execs like to limit their vision to the dollar sign.

Pros: Many different technologies used, many industry engagments, world wide opportunity to consult if you find that interesting.
Cons: Zero investment in new skills.  If you learn something it is only because you took the initiative.  IBM is constantly releasing new and revised product solutons and yet their own core employee base does not know how to utilize them making internal and external employment more difficult over time.

Pros: You are treated fairly and most managers acknowledge your contribution.  IBM has inroads with hardware, software or consulting; you will see more large scale end-to-end projects with IBM than anyone else.  International travel is a easy to come by with a year or two of experience.
Cons: They pay you as much as they need to keep you there.  You pick up slack for older less computer savvy workers.  Utilization is king, if you are a business resource on the bench, don't be surprised if they ask you to learn SQl, SAP or take a testing role.

Pros: Great Research Environment.  Great people to work with, and great managers.  The research teams all have top-rate researchers, and the managers all seem to know how to run their groups efficiently.  I've never worked anywhere where people meet their software development deadlines like clockwork.  The work-life balance is pretty good there too - I was in to work on a few weekends and I don't think I saw anyone else in the office.
Cons: It may be slightly bureaucratic for silicon valley types used to a start-up culture.  Moving up in the company (as well as the financial rewards that come with it) seems to take time.

Pros: The positives outweigh the negatives in the work life balance, working from home.  However the  needs of the individuals in remote settings are often difficult to harmonize for the benefit of a team and the individuals involved.  IBM is addressing this issue in a number of ways and stimulating good ideas to bring the challenges into focus so that there is inspiration and greater productivity.  I find that heartening as I personally enjoy working from home but miss some of the values derived from face-to-face stimuli with colleagues.
Cons: It is a HUGE company that requires strong navigational skills to work into all of the values and be the most productive employee one can be.

Pros:
Ability to work from home most days
Somewhat flexible at hours, start / stop time
Good Technology and resources for job
Cons:
Poor poor pay vs other companies
Terrible "rating" system
No pay for performance
No job growth or ability to move to other jobs within IBM

Pros: There are a lot of projects and products to work on and you get exposure to working on enterprise software for global markets.
Cons: The company is short sighted and is basically a giant people mill. A few bubble to the top and are rewarded well, the rest are supposed to be satisfied with the glory of working for IBM. As a good performer you are treated in an average to poor way. It is highly political because of this mechanic. Work-life balance isn't a reality even though it is discussed all the time.

Pros: The pros are hard to come by these days. The people you work with are hard working and professional.
Cons: No vision and because of this the company is struggling. Revenue is flat lined. Salary increases are abysmal, profit sharing shrinks year after year and benefits cost more. People are clearly "resources" and "assets". Upper and senior management have no concept of respect for the individual. Work/life balance has magically morphed to work/life integration meaning your life is your work. Internal processes are extremely bureaucratic and it is a grind it out environment - day in and day out.

Pros: I spent 12+ years at IBM and the first 10+ were fantastic - great people, challenging problems, and lots of growth opportunities.  The people are still fantastic, the problems are still challenging.
Cons: Over the past 2 years, there has been a lack of direction and consistent support.  The leadership team says one thing, and then does another.  The lack of trust is horrible and the morale is as bad as I've ever seen.  When I left, I felt like I was one of the lucky ones... and since I landed on my feet, I know that is true.

Pros: Great opportunity to learn in a global company.  Good opportunities for global assignments.  A lot of M&A activity so if you are interested in getting involved in that area it could be a great fit.
Cons: A lot of cut backs in the labor force based in the US.  Fewer entry level positions so harder to get in and if you do not move up quickly it can lead to a dead end.  Cutting back on employee benefits so again important to move up to keep your compensation in line with market/personal demands.  Minimal bonuses at the lower levels.

Pros: There are many positions at the company. You can usually work from home.
Cons: If your salary is deemed too large, you will be let go as a result of the bi-annual "resource allocation." Just be prepared that your skills don't matter as much as what IBM is paying you. The business plan for IBM for new business is to bid low on the support contract, support the account with enough skilled staff for a while and then let people go or shift support to cheaper off-shore resources. If the account is not making money for IBM, your salary will determine if you stay or are let go.

Pros: The best reason to work for IBM is flexibility. Ample vacation time allotted, and the culture is performance driven; as long as the deliverables are met, you can do all the other things you do in life. Also working at IBM you're surrounded by awesome people. Education and skill development is encouraged and required.
Cons:
When there's an important or time sensitive deadline you end up working a lot of hours. Also, its difficult to meet the deliverables of clients when "costs" are too high and heads are getting cut. 
Its an unending cycle of knee jerk reactions.

Pros:
GBS was pretty hard to handle with all the traveling, utilization, etc, but working as a consultant for different companies gave me a great deal of experience and exposure to pretty much all the experiences you want to have during your lifetime - from sad to funny, from beautiful to ugly.
Exceeded pretty fast by working hard, and giving it my all. But that was when the economy was better.
Cons: Depending on which group you're working in, there are not too much personal relationship that you develop in GBS. The manager that supposed to rate you, doesn't work with you on a daily basis, and in most cases have never met you before. Reviews strickly rely on the people you work with that will report to this stranger who'll give you a rating your bonus, salary, and future depend on.

Pros: Still unbelievable resources, breadth of scope and fantastic people on the lower levels that not many companies can match, no matter how much they talk about it.
Cons: Need to change the name to ISS, International Support and Services, because it is barely a Business Machines business any longer.  And I don't know any other company that would see the kind of results they have seen for the past 12-13 quarters and continue with the "leadership" that is basically destroying one of the great success stories of the past 100 years.

Pros: Opportunity to learn many business areas, industries and develop positive relationships with many customers.  Also had opportunities to travel domestically and globally in support of various accounts.  Benefits and vacation time were very good.
Cons: Constant learning requirements and extended work hours left little time for any true work life balance.  The company also initiated numerous layoff's which significantly affected the overall morale of personnel still working with the company.  Layoff's also negatively affected overall productivity in many organizations.  The layoff process was quite impersonal and harsh.  Raises were non existant for the 4 of the last 5 years.

Pros: Good work life balance, great insurance coverage and benefits (not including bonuses, which are notoriously terrible). They care about their employees in a lot of ways (but not others - see cons)
Cons: Horrible culture - working remotely (as 60% of IBM does) is nice but you can go years, if not your whole tenure at IBM without ever meeting your boss or peers face to face. In addition to the faceless factor, for a company that trades on "innovation" the culture and environment are anything but that. Antiquated, old school, conservative and top down to the fullest. People are often lifers at IBM and that has some drawbacks - old perspectives, outdated management styles, leadership that is out of touch with the bleeding edge.

Pros: I love this job, my manager is great and always looking out for his employees.  If he sees an opportunity for advancement, even in another department, that he feels one of his employees is suitable for, he will bring it to their attention and go the extra mile to help them get it.
Cons: Things don't happen fast.  HR is in India so job changes tend to take a long time to complete.  There is also a bit of a Big Brother feel here with all of the security requirements but I guess that's understandable.

Pros: Hired as a college grad and promoted within year and half. Great place to learn about marketing platforms, systems and tools all in one place within IBM. Great work like balance, and you get credit for your achievements. I work in the design studio in NY. Agile and lead methods are prized.
Cons:
Pay isn't good for the work that we do. 

Working for corporate marketing also comes with the baggage of enabling 4000 marketers around the world for the innovation created at headquarters. Innovation is great but deployment is slow. Even innovation within corporate can't keep up with the smaller firms in the space in marketing technology. However, I accept IBM is doing a great job in trying to keep up. I do say our leadership is putting a lot of pride in becoming a world class marketing analytics organization.

Pros: With many any IBM's employees being in the mid 50 year old range, there is going to be many opportunities available for management positions in the upcoming years.  Many people that I work with have worked at IBM their entire career, so there's a TON of knowledge and company history everywhere.
Cons:
Too much management; big blue moves slowly because of it.
Lot of resistance to change to newer technology, so many of the software tools being used are dated.
Not many recent college grads around -- lots of older folks.
No free lunch or coffee offerings, or any perks for that matter.

Pros: Very professional environment. Flexible hours and very flexible on the type of work people do. Is very easy to move from one project to another and learn new things. They encourage and give time to study and learn.
Cons: Full of processes. Processes are getting on the way. Also full of managers which, I presume, is the reason for the focus on the processes. Managers like processes, most of them are extremely focus on all the stuff that the developers have to keep up to date about what they do instead of focusing on what is done and how is done. They also like meetings....O  M   G, the meetings!!! Sometimes is impossible to get anything done because of the meetings. Sometimes all that comes out of the meeting is the time and place of the next meeting

Pros:
- Work with some of the smartest, most motivated people in the world
- Exciting work designing, stress testing and implementing world class, enterprise data platform
- Learning opportunities are endless,  Great place to learn/grow. 
- Truly global company - no better place to learn International business
Cons:
- Need to be comfortable with very fast pace of change needed to drive IBM transformation.
- Transformation also requires a lot of "dot connecting" - need to be able to connect disparate information and see unique patterns/issues to deliver best results - not everyone comfortable with being able to do this.

Pros: It has been much better recently with development and management trying to become more agile and using design thinking for the way we work and plan.  No more groups of project managers bugging you for status all the time.
Cons:
Although they have gotten better, HR and bureaucracy is a nightmare. I don't want to deal with paperwork and just get back to doing my job.  For a tech company they should be better at automating all our processes.

Also not sure of the current company strategy. It seems all over the place trying to pick out whatever will work.  Going in too many directions at once.

There are way too many VPs that I can't even name.

Pros:
A paycheck
Medical benefits which are on par with most other places quite frankly.
401k match - although only at the end of the year. You leave before, you get nothing.
Cons: Awful company to work for. I was in one of the supposed strategic imperative areas. Watson IOT but its all a sham. Smoke and mirrors. People work hard but its over shadowed by terrible management that don't have a clue what they are doing. Constant fire drills reacting to the competition. Each quarter there is constant layoffs. Lately they told everyone that was working at home to return or relocate to a bunch of bland offices scattered around the USA in areas you wouldn't want to live. I got out and found another job. I suggest you do the same if you are still there. With declining revenue each quarter the only way ibm can maintain any EPS is share buy backs and resource actions. Don't even think about ibm as a place to work even if you are desperate.

Pros:
IBM is constantly reviewing and updating our benefits.  Just this week, a new parental benefit was announced, now:  new mothers can now take up to 20 weeks leave, up from 14 weeks; and the IBM dads, partners, and adoptive parents to 12 weeks. Plus, IBM will reimburse as much as $20,000 for eligible adoption or surrogacy expenses.
This is a great way to attract and retain employees, because it is clear that IBM thinks and supports the IBMers in the most important moments of our lives.
Cons: Need more advertisement internally and externally

Pros: Well-known company name, good analytics/Excel skills learned, good connections from working here
Cons:
Cyclical work, can be boring, not any clear path to promotions - they are chosen at random and could depend on whether or not someone above you retires or goes on maternity leave. Compensation is well under the market. Employees often sit "on the bench" for several months without an assignment before getting a role. 
There is a program in place in the Rochester MN site where analysts get a higher band if they come from an East Coast school -- this is totally bogus because they are not any more qualified than the Midwest students, and they are all living in the same area so it is not cost of living adjustment. This program was started after I began, so I am simply speculating on how ridiculous it is - beware of this before starting! Overall very shady company.

Pros: IBM Pros at Eugenics, White Supremacy, Nazism, Racism (Think Black - Book), Mass Murder, Genocide, Holocaust (IBM and the Holocaust - Book), 9/11 invlovement & coverup, Multi-Trillion Dollar Theft of Leader Technologies Intellectual Property (All Social Network Technology) via IBM Eclipse Foundation setup especially for the theft. IBM World Holocaust 2.0 - The Genocide of the Human Race !!!
Cons:
I'm a Vice President at IBM. I have discovered Top Secret Confidential IBM documents that confirms the Coronavirus Pandemic is a cover story for the IBM World Holocaust 2.0 (2020) - The Genocide of the Human Race via Vaccines headed by IBM Eugenics frontman Bill Gates.

IBM Attack Against The World Population !!!

Vaccines are Bioweapons - IBM World Holocaust 2.0 (2020) - The Genocide of the Human Race !!!

Job Title: Senior consultant, executive search & leadership hiring
Pros: Great culture and teaming; IBMers are very down to earth and pragmatic in approach. Very smart, driven individuals work at IBM, and are willing to help with solving problems and overcoming obstacles.
Cons: IBM is a large organization and learning "who to go to for what" takes time. Not many formal protocols appear to be in place as to how to get work done, so it's often a matter of who you know and connect with to understand the processes. As a plus, this provides an opportunity to work in an ambiguous environment and learn to be nimble and solution-oriented.

Pros: People don’t take anything too seriously. Too big to fail (fully). Great work life balance. Fun people. Occasional travel to a massive conference. Name recognition. Good design culture. Always someone to learn from (either to aspire to be or vow NOT to be). They’ll pay you to learn. Individual teams have a lot of variety/variability and easy to switch. Decent efforts toward diversity and inclusion.
Cons: Badly run business (product managers never produced a clear list of priorities in 9 years), old technology or architecture on all products and not enough engineers to fix it, low commitment to UX quality by business, overemphasis on time in band and not merit, managers barely have budget for raises or any team events, slight “boys club” but getting better, lots of politics, hard to hire and retain talent.

Pros: - Great if you love the feeling of your brain decaying because we are in the 21st century and somehow this cutting edge Data Scientist job is a glorified excel data entry role - Great if you love feeling useless and helpless in your role due to circular management - Great if you love being screamed by superiors for not magically solving problems you asked for support on months ago but support was not offered - Great if you love facing micro-aggressions from your whole team because everyone hates each other because no one has any idea what's going on because no one takes accountability for anything; especially when you jump for a new opportunity and everyone starts spreading very true stories that definitely have factual backing behind them about you :) - Great if you love HR hounding you after you've left, claiming overpayment (pennies, btw, to this billion dollar corp)
Cons: None! See above; I clearly only had pros :)

Pros: 40% of IBM employees are work from home employees.  They do believe in a work/life balance for the most part.
Cons: The will work you to the bone if you'll let them.  Recently, while the company is making LOTS of money it is not being channelled back in the form of increased salaries or training of their employees.

Pros: It is a relatively solid company that has a good history and longevity in the marketplace. There is a lot of opportunity for growth within the company, and it seems like there are some managers that really want to help you flourish in the company. They have a great work-life-balance perspective, but unless you're in a personal crisis - you are expected to perform above and beyond (as the norm)
Cons: Corporate bureaucracy, lack of employee appreciation, poor planning on many internal projects that lead to disastrous or clunky tools for the internal population. We're a top technology company who makes it's employees use antiquated hardware and tools.

Pros: For a large company with over 330,000 employees, IBM does many things right as an employer. They pay competitively and have a solid benefits package. They have a great internal training program for things like management and project management. They delegate much of the human resources (HR) responsibilities to the first-line managers, so that key HR decisions are being made by those with the most knowledge about the employee instead of by HR representatives who couldn't pick the employee out of a line-up. They have a strong mentoring program (people who say they don't have a strong mentoring program probably weren't willing to put in the effort and time necessary to make those mentoring relationships fruitful). IBM is large enough that employees can have multiple careers without ever changing companies or having to rollover their 401k.
Cons: Anytime there is a large number of people, communications become harder. Project managers or engineers might think about the number of communication channels, which is n(n-1)/2 where n = number of stakeholders (Ref: PMBOK, 3rd ed.). For 330,000 employees, that means IBM has 54.4 billion communication channels. Obviously that is difficult to manage and work within. Recognizing that there is an inherent challenge in the liquidity of knowledge and information can help employees find ways to solve those problems, such as developing wikis for small teams. The other downside to having that many employees means that every time the company spends $3 on each employee, you just spent $1 million. Many employees don't understand this problem, and instead complain about only receiving free ice cream in the cafeteria after project milestone is reached when their cousin at the unprofitable, but well funded, start-up is getting free coffee and soda every day.

Pros: Job stability is good and there are lots of opportunities for changing jobs within the company. If you can take advantage of all the benefits you can get a lot of value in addition to your pay.
Cons: Upper management is in denial on a lot of issues that the client-facing employees are dealing with

Pros: To simply get those 3 letters on your resume.  Also, most of the grunts are good people who deserve more.
Cons: You will get lied to by management.  Constant fear and low morale run the hallways since management won't tell you anything.  If you are one who contributes to the rumor mill or constantly question what's going on rather than remaining positive that things will be alright, you end up as one of the people who get layed off.  The stress isn't worth it.  You can be a top performer, work more than anyone else, solve problems no one else could and still be chosen during lay offs.  Offshoring US jobs is the strongest point.

Pros: IBM has a great deal of bright, talented, dedicated, hard-working people -- and there's a lot to learn at a company of this size.  I used to be able to also say there are many opportunities in a company of this size, since if you didn't like your first job, you could always apply for a position in another area / division.  Today, however, with nearly quarterly downsizings / job outsourcings going on, when you do look for a new job within IBM you're often competing with hundreds to thousands of others who were just advised they're on the way out the door and have only 30 days to find a new job in IBM.  As a result, over the past 8 years or so, mobility within the company has been very limited. -- as has upward mobility due to IBM's laser focus on reducing SG&A (sales, general and administrative = headcount) expenses quarter to quarter.
Cons: Employee morale is poor, and workloads are unreasonable (with many working 60+ hours per week in salaried positions) due to IBM's laying off so many American workers in 2009 (in spite of reporting record earnings for 2008).  IBM's performance appraisal and rating system, called the Personal Business Commitments (PBCs) system, is a flawed system which forces managers (I know, I was a manager myself for 10 years) to "skew" the ratings to match a normal, "bell shaped" curve distribution.  For all but the few fortunate workers who are able to secure a top rating, the system is demoralizing, and is seen as an unfair way of keeping pay increases and bonuses low.

Pros: Good work/life balance, wide variety of resources for employees to take advantage of, global opportunities, friendly colleagues, growing new college hire programs
Cons: The compensation system at IBM works to the advantage of executives at the expense of regular full-time employees. Raises and bonuses are based on an annual review, but even top 1 PBC performers are left with 2% raises and 5% bonuses. New college hires are being paid significantly more than employees with 1-2 years of experience, and management just makes excuses and blames Human Resources. Significant increases in pay can only be expected when one threatens to leave the company, and even still, IBM almost never will match competitors.

Pros: Employee benefits (healthcare and 401k), competitive salary, work/life balance, promotional ladder, opportunities outside of initial career position, executive management grown internally
Cons: Lower annual bonuses than major consulting companies like McKinsey, Accenture, BCG, etc, rely on "hour glass" resource model so college hires are sometimes isolated from other young professionals in the company if you're stuck on mid-long term client site projects.

Pros: Still relatively secure place to work with lots of opportunities especially if you want to live in a growth country.  Opportunity to work with some of the industries brightest people and some leading edge technology.
Cons: Continued downsizing of North American workforce.  Constant threat of layoffs. Unfair treatment of older employees.  Benefits eroding.   Corporate strategy forcing huge changes inside the company in order to stay competitive.  Remote workforce... hardly anyone works face to face anymore.  Doesn't feel like a company that values the people who are doing most of the work but continues to reward and promote executives across the board.

Pros: Variety of technologies and career path within a company.  Still has a bit of prestige left.
Cons: Declining morale, due to continuing and excessive offshoring.  Low pay relative to competitors.

Pros: Smart people, good compensation (at least for information developers--aka, technical writers), great benefits.
Cons: All the pros I've written up make it sound good, huh? But I should have listened to my first instinct about the workplace there: I'd never felt like the people around me at work were so unhappy. But instead I stuck it out for more years than I care to share here. There were a few fantastic colleagues along the way, but unfortunately IBM promotes the people who will do anything to be top dogs. There are a few who are so smart they don't have to bend over for management. If you think you can end up being among the "top contributors" every year, then you might not need to fight for your job to escape the annual layoffs at IBM.

Pros: Decent salary, flexible work schedule
Cons: No focus on people management, too many managers or leaders interfering with actual work, bonuses not good, stock options very rare, atmosphere depressing, very limited career advancement opportunities

Pros: You're working for an industry leader in their field. There is something to be said about that. I love telling people I used to work for companies they've heard of. It also gives you some credibility in the industry as well.
Cons: So many layers of management that decisions are made by people who seriously don't understand anything they are managing. They also do not value the individual, everything is team or group based. While teams are important, everyone knows there is usually a "QB" or "Captain", and IBM does not really acknowledge this at an institutional level.

Pros: Good benefits, good work life balance. Except to get what you would get at any large american corporation. The benefits are good, the network is large, there are opportunities to work remotely.
Cons: No training, not great work environment, no mentorship. IBM is a factory for entry level work. Tons of people leave after a year or two in the organization. The people that stayed for longer in the consulting world were not very happy at the company and they showed it. It was hard to find people who had been there for an extended time and were happy with their jobs. I didn't know any.

Pros: They encourage telecommuting; they keep the focus on up and coming technologies; the people, in general, are cordial and professional. If you enjoy the global enterprise, high tech B-to-B environment--and you have technical skills--you'll probably like it. They company values integrity and high quality. CEO Ginni Rometty is sharp.
Cons: The company is very, very, big. It can take quite a while to understand how things are organized and who is who. You may feel like a cog in a wheel. The stakes are high and as in any organization, you need to watch out for a few sharks.

Pros: Very little actual work to do so the hours are great. People are generally nice. Since so little analysis or thought is required for the job it's very easy and simple.
Cons: Extremely boring and repetitive work. You won't gain any tangible skills from this job. Furthermore, your manager may be completely unaware of what your job actually entails since all different corporate finance functions are put together at the CoE. Instead of learning what the day to day work is for the analysts under him or her, your manager may be content to expect everyone to read their mind on a daily basis. Managers at the CoE in Rochester seem to think they are god's greatest gift to management when in fact they are simply supervisors for glorified clerks. Your manager will require of you to never approach work in an intelligent manner since they themselves are incapable of thought.

Pros: Good, professional colleagues with excellent work tools provided.  Comprehensive benefits package.  Travel can be heavy at times, but you may also get some work from home assignments.
Cons: Understand going in that being billable is the most important metric you will be judged by.  IBM ranks consultants into tight tiers of five percenters, fifteen percenters, seventy-five percent, and bottom five.  Bottom five are gone (as they probably should be.)  Seventy-five percent may feel employment is 'safe', but don't count on it, as I learned the hard way.

Pros:
Shifting to more entrepreneurial culture and investments in innovation  e.g. Spark
Flexible hours and work from  home when or if needed
At same time, creating workplaces / hubs for greater synergy
Diversified workforce worldwide
More townhall / community meetings helping build synergy and awareness
Cons:
Still too many layers of management, siloed functions, and barriers between teams to working better/faster
Too many legacy products and processes; simplification needed faster (see above)
Not changing fast enough
Coin operated sellers who have only quarter to quarter focus
Horrible sw desktop tools; spending too many hours during the day dealing with Notes issues

Pros: There are still advantages, IBM has fully bought into working from home, the groupware and productivity tools are plentiful and useful including mobile and the ability to use Mac products, dogfooding is prevalent so there's ample opportunity to try new products, there's a lot of focus on education.
Cons: IBM stock price continues to decline, and it appears management's solution is to continue aggressive layoffs.  I have worked on 5 different projects in the past two years, each was profitable, but aggressive global resourcing and resource actions led to insufficient and inexperienced support staff, which led to missed SLA's and caused the projects loose profitability.  20% overtime is expected.  IBM appears to be killing off areas of it's business that don't align with the overall vision, even if those areas are profitable.

Pros: I get to work with cutting edge technology on a daily basis. I get to be creative and agile to determine new use cases for artificial intelligence in the real world. Sometimes this is with clients and sometimes this is with internal IBM teams collaborating in order to create the next best use for cognitive.
Cons: Watson can be applied to various industries in many different ways. Goals and metrics are constantly changing so you have to be flexible and motivated to learn new skills to keep up with the fast paced market.

Pros: There are opportunities to do nearly anything within IBM. I have personally be the beneficiary of many good managers and programs. Although my experience has been exceptional, I have seen other not be so fortunate.
Cons: Many managers are removed from their reports and are only focused on utilization. It is a big company and is easy to get lost / challenging to find the right place. Bonuses are a joke; pay bumps are fair, but you won't be getting rich.

Pros:
This is in regards to the IBM business center in Lansing, MI only-
The work experience is very fast paced and with multiple teams and projects.
High profile clients.
The benefits are good.
Cons:
Lower than the average hiring salary.
Very low bonus amounts given annually after a rigorous application process for them. The bonus is so low it only comes out to $20-$50 more on your monthly paycheck. No option for title promotion or any bonus given. If you work with all remote clients (which the majority of us do) the manager of the building still requires you to come in and work. So you waste time in the morning to go to a building where you work with no one and sit in an open office environment to work remotely. Highly distracting and not productive.

Pros: Big Company with lots of smart people, many places to move around to and a solid benefit package.
Cons: Some organizations have sadly grown allowing a combative culture where cussing and yelling is accepted, or where managers that say things like  "do it or you are fired" because they are not capable of finding a more productive way to motivate people.  They lay off all the time and have reduced the layoff package to 1 month pay regardless of your time there.

Pros: IBM builds education and training into your daily job. This means they not only encourage you to stay current, but they back it up by giving you real work hours to complete training. Education is provided via numerous weekly webinars given by Subject Matter Experts across an expansive list of subjects (e.g., Quantum computing to Growing Your Career). Education also is available an endless catalog of up-to-date online curriculum, classes, and funded attendance at IBM and non-IBM Conferences, as well funded classes/curriculum from outside IBM. These classes lead to certifications (also funded) and badges. I've even attended classes at Harvard. IBM is truly the place to grow your skills and your career.
Cons: IBM is pivoting its solutions to support a hybrid multi-cloud strategy. This is good, but at times the transition brings frustrations.

Pros: IBM is a great company to work- benefits and culture wise. But things can be very different for you personally depending on the manager and the department. Some people are never meant to be managers. And some departments are pure toxic and filled with bias. Especially the case with acquired companies. IBM has a tough time blending acquired company culture into theirs and often times end up abandoning the whole team after a few years of trial.
Cons:
This is the mother of all corporates. Everything you have heard about corporate world is true about IBM. Too much of hierarchy. Its all about people you know. IBM has alot of cool projects but to get into one of those is either luck or knowing someone who is already working on it.
Good benefits but pay is borderline.

Pros: Flexible work from home options. If you are interested in technology and innovation, this is the right place for you. You're asked to constantly change and adapt.
Cons: Constant change sometimes comes without the full solution in place. EPM rollout but missing data to actually use the tools fully in daily work. Bonuses are laughable and employees received such little year end "bonuses" due to IBM lack of performance. Something that most finance employees have very little to do with. Also, such a had drive in finance to pull things forward that we end up playing catchup every quarter to make unrealistic targets...

Pros: Benefits are excellent. Job flexibility in where you work, when you work, how you work are very positive reasons to be at IBM. Also, there are very smart and engaging people to work with who have high standards and moral integrity.
Cons: You can feel just like another number. Constant threat of outsourcing has hurt morale and job security is a thing of the past. Teamwork is also lacking because at the end of the day, most employees feel like its they have to look out for themselves. Thus, atmosphere has become more cut-throat and ultimately, a lot of employees have lost any sense of loyalty.

Pros: There are not many, if any good reasons to work for STG.  The only good reason I can think of to work for STG is a steady pay check for the short term.
Cons: There is no appreciation or respect for employees, management is incompetent and decisions/promotions/raises are completely political in nature.  It is not what you know or what you do, its who you know.  Upper management is too greedy with the distribution of wealth, leaving employees with only crumbs.

Pros: The opportunity to work for such a global company. IBM sets the pace in many technology sectors.  Skills learned here are in high demand outside of IBM. As a software engineer got to work on latest and greatest web technologies and got a job really quickly after leaving IBM. I was able to rotate around to different software brands building a good portfolio of knowledge of software offerings. From development to application software.
Cons: the BIG in Big Blue. Sometimes feel kind of distant. Most of HR is taken care in a central place, e.g Raleigh, NC.  Also most people are very good at what they do making promotions kind of hard to attain.

Pros:
Management supports working from home.
Good group of people to work with.
Cons:
Frequent layoffs.  Gradual shift of workers from US to India.
Understaffed for amount of work.  Poor communication from project managers.
Unreasonable project schedules that have just become a joke.
No sense of big picture, everything is week to week survival.
Upper management seems to be only concerned with profit and their stock options.
Difficult to see where you fit in such a large corporation.
Can easily have first line manager be in some other geography hundreds of miles away.
Working remotely from the main group can leave workers feeling isolated and lost.

Pros: There are a wide variety of projects available to Consultants within GBS and the brand name of IBM still goes a long way.  Additionally, opportunities for professional advancement/training are abundant.
Cons:
Opportunities to be staffed on projects outside of your service area are rare, so if you wanted to move from say Supply Chain Management to Finance, don't count on it.
Additionally, movement between the Public and Private Sector practice areas is equally rare.
If you are staffed on the client site on a small project team, your exposure to Managers and other IBMers can be very limited.

Pros: Very talented and technical work force.  Its a great place to learn a lot.
Cons: Advancement within the company is very slow.  Changes take forever to be put in place.  Upper management only cares about stock holders and not about the employees.  Treatment of employees is very poor.  Company is very against advanced degrees... fear of loosing people and its quite difficult to move around within the company because everyone is so division/department centric and managers are not willing to loose their good employees to other departments.

Pros:
- Great technology
- Ability to switch and do something new every couple of years
- Extensive training opportunities
Cons:
- Salaries are not competitive
- Lack of motivation and employees recognition from management

Pros: Top technology name, great resources for technology smarts.  Large consulting and software business.  Well known name.  Largest global outsourcer.  Recognized worldwide.  Have moved globally quickly with people and sales.  Smarter planet seems to be working well as a marketing campaign.
Cons: Short term focus on people.  Moving jobs overseas at a rapid pace.  Frequent downsizing.  Changes in direction on the consulting side are frequent.   Changes in middle level management frequently.   They have never gotten all the parts of the business working effectively together; often work across purposes.  Losing ground to MSFT and Oracle in enterprise software.

Pros: Consistently excellent colleagues and teamwork mentality. Robust infrastructure, extremely huge  intranet, and generally great management. Great work environment. I feel safe and able to do my work. Everyone is busy and productive here--and some people are truly remarkable.
Cons: Career development can be challenging, especially because there is too much to do and sometimes not enough interest in how to best utilize talent. Opportunities for career exploration and side projects are well-advertised within the company, but difficult to execute on a general engineer/technical staff level. Especially if you want to grow skills in a slightly different technical area. However, this is perhaps inherent for all large companies.

Pros:
Decent health insurance (if you pay for the step-up plan)
Well known company
Access to all documentation
Access to self-paced training on a variety of topics
Cons:
Low salaries in comparison to the market
Employees are micromanaged
Experienced professionals are treated like children
Attendance is taken 
Employees (might) have one square yard of work space in the office
Employees are discouraged from working from home, even when their clients request it
Long term supplemental employees are not allowed to post for "regular" jobs for 18 months from when they were hired.

Pros:
Flexible work/life balance, easy to work remotely.
Pay is satisfactory.
Company policies can be short sighted and frustrating.
Cons:
Difficult to get promoted. Especially if you're not a typical role like a developer.
Employee evaluations are subjective, it all depends on your management.
Each team works differently. Overall the IBM culture is friendly and fair, but if you join a recent aquisition, for example, you may not be treated "fairly" by the non-IBM environment.
Work environment has become depressing over the years, with most people working from home. Not a lively place to work anymore.

Pros: Good training ground for new graduates.  Especially in consulting, a chance to learn a lot by working with many clients.
Cons:
You get locked in into one area of specialization and industry - difficult to then work with clients in other industries if you want to 
Opaque career level ("band") structure and salary levels associated with them - no manager ever showed what is the salary range for a band; you have to guess or figure out from colleagues what is possible. 
Very slow and opaque promotion process
Low salaries compared to similar companies; good benefits though.
Grueling schedule for consultants, driven by utilization requirements that sometimes were 100%
A lot of things sound good on paper (benefits, mentorship programs) but they are not realized after that

Pros: A great company if you have family and need the flexibility to work from home or take care of the kids. Still at the same time working. Decent health benefits as well.  If you don't like to do any work but like to talk as though you are doing work, this is the company for you.
Cons: No 401k match. No pay raises unless you're an executive. No job growth unless you're best friends with upper management or legacy into the IBM family. The only employees that get ahead are those that throw their work over the fence and take credit for others work and accomplishments.

Pros: Tons of good smart people.  Lots of different possibilities for work, if you can get approval to transfer there.
Cons: Due to the size, often hard to effectively execute on change (not very nimble).  It takes a ton of effort consensus building, getting buy-in, securing resources and finally (if you ever get there)  ability to execute on the idea or change.  Also often have got mediocre evals with no warning of what I need to change or improve.

Pros: Very smart people, with deep personal and professional commitment, who remain blissfully unaware that they will have no future.
Cons: One of the most depressing, alarmingly arrogant and confused IT companies in the world. Acting like wolves, hunting in small packs, they eventually run out of food and are then forced to eat their own kind.
