Greed remains the key motivation for leadership, who will seemingly stop at nothing to best a colleague, weaken a partner or flip a customer. Reckless outsourcing of American jobs for low paid, often unqualified personnel in so called “growth markets”. Stay away from this work environment.

Pros: IBM is a 100 yr old company that knows how to adjust to the changes in the industry and reinvent itself when required.  The company has lots of products and services and therefor provides opportunities for its employees to move around to various roles within the company and it's various software and services brands.
Cons:
- Employee's do not feel values, moral is at a all time low
- Employee Performance  program is broken, doesn't lend itself well to teaming 
- Compensation is low compared to competitors
- Too much bureaucracy, hinders the organizations level of flexibility and  ability to move quickly

Pros: Learning new skills that you can take to another company. Co workers for the most part are great to work with.
Cons: If you are of a certain age you are treated like garbage. In Dubuque there is no way to grow your career. No raises, no bonuses, first line managers play favorites. You never know from one day to the next if you are going to have a job. The managers do not have managing experience. If you screw up you move up. No sense of following business conduct guidelines even though we are required to read them each January.

Pros: They have been in business for a very long time, have re-invented themselves repeatedly in order to stay relevant, and they are relevant still. They are also very DEEP and forward thinking in terms of technology, still have one of the cutting edge semiconductor research capabilities along with software as well. No they aren't always as sexy as the latest valley social media knockoff startup but are still, in my mind, as an engineer, pretty solid
Cons: They are a LARGE company, and you do have to spend some time figuring out how to navigate within the organization. Due to their size they can sometimes be. I worry a bit because like many other tech companies, they undervalue doing development domestically at times and are under pressure to streamline in areas where I think in the long term could be leaders

Pros:
1) People are great, willing to help
2) IBM is great name to have on resume 
3) Good way to start career
Cons:
1) Lack of formal training, disorganized management strategy
2) Lack of opportunity to advance due to bad performance in the division, promotions and raise are hard to come by
3) Managers expect you to work weekends and after hours - although the hours can be flexible
4) Managers disconnected with what employees actual do - inability to make business decisions, decisions and works progresses very slowly
5) Culture lacks energy and employees lack work ethnics - most people are ready to retire no incentive to work hard

Pros: Provides great breadth of services, many smart people, and an offering catalog that is second to none. Has a name and reputation that almost everyone around the world can instantly recognize.
Cons: Global Business Services is slow to adapt to the market and is often held back by its size and overhead. There is a lack of focus on talent retention and often senior leaders are powerless to help keep top employees.

Pros: Benefits as per with IBM employees. Support for benefit is great.  Other than that , I have got nothing.
Cons:
Corruption.
 When I got selected by client , the recruitment coordinator for IBM contacted me through common friend ( small Indian community in CLT) to lure me to join to his bro-in-law's company- which is a vendor to IBM. 
When I complained to someone in the  the Partner level , he sent the  recruitment coordinator to India for couple of months - and now , after 2 and half , he is back with the same position same place . 
The partner must have got real mad at me for complaining , since after that he never spoke to me and generally everyone in IBM ( employees) ignores me.

Pros:
Flexible work schedule. Every day and every engagement is a way to learn new things. At IBM, you never stop learning and gaining knowledge. You can never get bored. You are always challenged with new products, new solutions and new business problems.
No Micro-management. Good Pay. 
I just LOVE IBM!
Cons:
Nothing major. With so many people working there and so much knowledge generated it is sometimes difficult to get quickly to the person or information you need. 

No coffee machines, snacks at IBM Offices.

Pros:
* Supportive management
* Very little micromanagement
* Competitive Salary
* Excellent Benefits
Cons:
* Not too many extra perks such as outings or  meals or gym memberships or extra vacation days 
* If things go wrong, it can take some time to get them fixed.
* Work culture is okay. Split into various micro groups.
* 401K match contribution only happens at the end of the year. If you leave before year end, you forfeit the company's contribution.
* Not much support for personal growth except for what is offered by company itself.
* Monthly employee recognition process makes no sense.
* Finally, the company has implemented a new way to evaluate performance based on input from employees. Have to wait till the end of the year to see how it works out.

Pros: Has a sales person you can walk into some of the biggest accounts with very little resistance. There's smart people and tons of resources for you
Cons: Poor culture. Employees always complain (they have legit complaints too), a seller of X will be told they now sell Y (with no experience in Y), constant reorgs, quarterly lay offs, no sales momentum is built, even if you work hard and get positive reviews - you can be laid off.

Pros: Great coworkers and you learn a lot from constantly changing focus areas.  Good benefits and pay.
Cons: IBM no longer lets employees work from home.   In marketing the expectations are unreasonable so all employees work at least 10 hours a day and are expected to be available at anytime to assist management.  Teams are very siloed in both function and product focus so you don't have as much control over your marketing plans as would be ideal and you end up competing as much with other IBM marketing teams as external competitors.  Matched with the fact that you rarely get to focus on the same thing more than a year it is very challenging to meet targets.

Pros: Some really talented and great people to work with.
Cons: uncertainty with cost cutting-resource actions and changes with several newer leaders, new CDO, new CMO. New co-location work strategy will be great for people who live in the  right cities but many locations are geared up to handle the volume of people who will be coming in to those sites.. so it may be interesting to find a place conducive to work in the new open floor plans!

Pros: Nice co-workers who worked hard to bring in new business.
Cons: Black cloud over everyone there due to constant Resource Allocations (lay offs). Never know when the next one is going to happen. Crazy multi-level policies where you are having to jump through hoops to do your job. Literally 20 emails a day (internal emails) from the company- post this, read this blog, etc leaving little time to actually do the job you were hired to do. Territory changes every 6 months. Company going down hill fast.

Pros: I joined the Strategic Enterprise Transformation (SET) team of the Transformation & Operations (T&O) Organization on April 25, 2017. The SET organizational culture, ways of working, and mission and objectives are the key reasons why I love working at IBM. My current role has given me an opportunity to drive transformation in multiple, creative ways from a stakeholder management and communications perspective. If you're looking for a new and different challenge to redesign the way one of our  most storied global organizations work, please join our team!
Cons: IBM is a very large and complex organization, so it can take some time, patience, and resilience to fully understand how each Business Unit and Function operate to support IBM's performance in the market. Please keep this in mind as you consider opportunities for any role at IBM.

Pros:
• Excellent Benefits

• Good Education 

• Great Clients and Business Partners

• Great Place to start a career in technology
Cons:
• Layoffs quarterly. Experienced, top performing salespeople are being affected. 

• Several Sales Managers are not staying educated. They are not leading and/or preparing members of the team to go to the next level. They are not familiar the team’s job tasks. Focused on playing politics with other managers.

• The “Bonus Plan” is too subjective. Sales reps on this plan are paid from a pool of money. Managers determine how much each sales rep makes.

• Limited career growth

Pros: Failing projects take a while to find their way to the chopping block; ideal if your team has a plan to turn things around or if you need extra time looking for a new job.
Cons: Inconsistent priorities and a false sense of entitlement - "we invented X, Y, and Z 100 years ago so we can rely on that to carry our brand forward". Forcing teams to use your own tools, your own cloud, your own everything is a outdated model.

Pros:
I've been in IBM for many years with the opportunity to move into various technical and leadership roles as my skills and personal interests matured and changed.
And IBM provides access to and highly encourages continuous education and skills development through both self-paced learning and on-the-job experiences allowing me to continuously explore and grow my personal skills and interests.
Cons: While IBM is a big company, the size can be daunting. I suggest focusing on an area of expertise and a single unit within IBM to learn and mature that skill and expertise. Gradually look for opportunities to collaborate with other skills / units and gradually grow your skill and networks in this way. This approach worked very well for me!

Pros:
A wide range of technologies that are available to serve markets
Expertise in some areas backed by extensive research and experience
Respect for one another
Cons:
Missing Synergy between various practices
Too many levels of Management 
Too slow a growth. Promotions are not based on capability, but based on power groups
No accountability for Partners to perform. 
Success is rewarded to Top Level Management - Failures are blamed on lower levels. 
No Career path planning. You have to figure it out for yourself.

Pros: Agile culture, empowered employees and a culture of continuous learning and opportunities to grow in different roles to name a few
Cons: Hierarchical, too many layers, heavy on senior leadership, leadership selection process inconsistent without a focus on the right leadership fit and style to enable the growth behaviors we need to sustain change.

Pros: During my first year I have been allowed to grow into the role I was hired on for, which has been invaluable to me and the growth I want to achieve in this field of IT. Hopefully I can continue to reach my ideal goals here, and continue to grow my knowledge base which IBM feels like their views on employee growth and development are on the same page as what I had hoped for in this new journey.
Cons: My particular specialty needs more resources I think to learn from the ground up. We have a lot resources for those in this field who are beyond mid level. We can still figure everything out eventually if you are not above mid level, but I feel it would be much easier/quicker to excel if there were more beginner/entry level resources to use.

Pros: I have been with IBM about 6 years now, and during this time i have had the opportunity to learn quite a bit. It is a big organization so you can try different roles, and management does encourage that. They have internal educational tools that help you get exposure to a wide variety of fields and continuously learn new things at absolutely no cost. The benefits are pretty good too.
Cons: A pro and a con, it is a big company so you can easily get lost, and sometimes it can feel like what you are doing is not that relevant. There are changes happening all the time as company strategy shifts, and management can change quite frequently too. In the 6 years there i have had 4 managers, and i am still working for the same org.

Pros: large company with (theoretically) lots of opportunities to do different things.
Cons: Lots of layoffs (RA's). Very bureaucratic. A very "let them eat cake" attitude from executives. Despite almost no raises, no bonuses, and poor revenue performance, executives continue to make bonuses and get raises. IBM spends money on the executives, on the backs of the employees, who they continue to take away from. Definitely cannot recommend.

Pros: IBM Research has some really smart people working on very interesting problems.  There is a lot of freedom to work on our own ideas, which leaves us responsible for our own success and failure.  There is also a lot of freedom in work/life balance -- I don't know anyone who has the same freedoms that I have (working from home when I want, travel, etc).
Cons: Politics often define which research projects ultimately fail and succeed, and you have to learn to play the game.  It can be quite difficult to get a good project into product.  Salary and benefits used to be very good, though they have been tightening in the last few years.

Pros: Large community of people and resources to work with.  It's usually easy to find expertise.  There are always opportunities to learn more and work with some of the best minds in the industry.  Help customers see value in the payback they'll achieve by deploying solutions end-to-end across their enterprise to achieve a Service Oriented Architecture. Whether your in software, hardware or services -- whether you do sales, development, marketing, or product advocacy, IBM will challenge you to give your best and provide the best to companies across many geographies and industries.  At IBM, you can build specialized or broad-based knowledge and experience.
Cons: Cuts in commission, especially for technical sales.

Pros: You get to work with intelligent people who are also nice.  Brand-name recognition.  Generous compensation package.  Being able to telecommute saves time wasted sitting in traffic, helps the environments, and boosts employee productivity.  I'm not a morning person, but happily works late into night sometimes if needed.  Management in general are competent and understanding.  It doesn't hurt that employees get all sorts of little perks, too, from discount show/movie tickets to free museum admission, from travel priviledges (cheaper car rental, hotel stays) to employee pricing at some of the customer websites -- Apple, Sony, Panasonic, GE, Sharp, Philips, to name a few.
Cons: Politics, politics, politics.  A lot of decisions are made from top down.  Bureaucracy.

Pros: work from home mobility is nice.  IBM has nice logo items.
Cons: Senior management is only interested in keeping stock price high.  IBM is always offshoring jobs.  2/3 of IBM employees are outside the US now.  Vacation blackout dates for a total of 2 months each year.  Management has not mentioned a word to it's US employees, and over 5,000 have lost their jobs in the last two weeks.  They rule by fear and intimidation.  When you manage good business results, you don't get a raise, and instead are fed the line "at least you have a job" all while IBM records record revenue.

Pros: Place for discovering innovation. Plenty of opportunities to move within STG for good-fit. Many opportunities to learn new technologies and contribute to the same.
Cons:
STG's primary business model is to make and sell hardware products - high end servers/data storage/mid range server/storage. This makes it hard to change course midway. 
STG is not a good fit for computer science professionals (e.g. BS or MS in CS).

Pros:
The 401k benefits are outstanding.
The opportunity to do many projects in various areas are excellent.
The opportunity to work in many different locations are excellent as well.
Cons: You are the only person responsible for your career.  Employees are just another number.  The way promotions are handled are completely unfair.  Do not expect to get raises.  They do not develop their employees.  They will lay people off if they do not have projects to work on.

Pros:
For Sales folks - you can leverage the client team matrix (I have heard - so far it hasn't worked for me)
If you can reach them, there are some really SOLID tech folks (when customers complain about bugs)
Cons:
Sales plan is dismal at best - if you work the same amount at another company, you probably would make twice as much.. 
many gotchas in the sales comp plan - not the best way to retain hard working sales folks
Competitive products within IBM itself - and you probably would be selling only one of those products
no work/life balance - you are expected to work over the weekends
Takes 3-4 days for folks to respond to your emails if it is not urgent
Not a place to make money

Pros: Reasonably good people work at IBM
Cons:
Everybody's hands are tied.  Nobody can help you.  You will be paid as little as possible while your benefits are chipped away.  

There is a strong sinking ship feeling.  Early this year there was a significant layoff.  Just a few weeks ago, furlough.  This is scary.

Pros: The people and the innovative culture of behind the products.
Cons: work-life balance has gotten out of balance and is more like work-work balance.

Pros: The people I worked with were great.  If you can get into one of the hot projects like Watson is at the time I'm writing this, you might be successful.  Hot projects don't stay hot for long though.
Cons: The company is focused on the "2015 Roadmap".  Nothing matters but getting EPS to $20.00/share.  They'll fire as many people as the can and cut budgets to the bone to get there.  In 2013 the 401k was changed to a once per year match.  If you aren't employed on December 15th of the year you don't get the match.  I ended up leaving for a new job in October 2013, so I get nothing.

Pros: So many areas you can work in and it is not just limited to IT or sales. Benefits are decent but not as good as they used to be.
Cons: IT is not the place for people who do not want to travel or who wish to have a steady life-long job with one company. IBM hires and lays off people without much long term thought. Many IBMers have been laid off and rehired 2 or 3 times. Many have left IBM for business partners only to have IBM buy the partner.

Pros: Working for IBM is like working for many different companies, so potentially you can move about and build your career without changing companies.
Cons: Employees taken the burden of what I like to call "IBM Blue Overhead". There are processes, tools, databases by the 1000s. Getting help or support often requires contacting someone in another country. Raises and bonuses are abysmal. They have off-shored so many internal support positions that basically you need to be your own IT help desk, HR partner, and BA. Your first line manager has virtually no control over your salary, raises, bonuses.

Pros: In the fifteen years I was there, I worked with many very talented people across the globe.  In the late '90's, talent and technical depth were developed, nurtured and expected to excel, and work/life balance and the internal culture was built to retain the best of the best.  The people within IBM from that period, in the first two management tiers, are outstanding.
Cons: With the Service Delivery Center concept, people became commodities, and the brain trust in services was drained.  Work life balance eroded along with benefits, training and retention.  Executive direction became obsessed with quarterly reporting to Wall Street and the bonuses at the expense of long term performance planning and responsible expense planning, resulting in whimsical and contradictory leadership.

Pros: All co-workers had a great work ethic. Incredible opportunities in learning within the company with various executive calls to interns where they can learn and ask questions.
Cons: Huge company, and the culture to go with it. I asked someone in an intern call what should attract people to IBM as opposed to the hot, smaller startups with a more relaxed and fun culture and the answer ended up being along the lines of "IBM will buy them in the end anyway." This reflects horribly on the company culture and vision, at least for me.

Pros:
401K matching 
Pays Travel For Work
Job-related Paid Training/Per Diems
Schedule work from home/office
Depending on miles driven, possible company car/transit 
24 hr support team & dispatch
IPhone 5s or higher work phone.
Job related certification opportunities
Overtime opportunities
Cons:
Management doesn't always have to understand your job to manage you. 
Buggy work related software/tools on Iphones, can delay your jobs.
No progressive salary, raises, bonuses.
Overtime may be demanded at anytime rather than requested/asked of you depending on client needs and priority.
Hierchy system of management has poor communication at times in regards to employee needs.
Resource Actions
Expectations/schedules might change without much notice.

Pros: IBM is a globally respected company and one of the few companies capable of handling the IT requirements of the world's largest and most complex enterprises.  IBM is also a leader in the latest technology advances related to cloud, analytics, data, mobile, and AI.   Many IBMers work remotely, and the company rates highly as an equal opportunity employer
Cons: IBM jobs in the US are drying up.  Cost pressures and are driving job opportunities overseas.  IBM is forced to treat US employees as costs they would get rid of if they could.  This is especially true in Technology Services and Strategic Outsourcing.

Pros:
IBM Research is the best place to work in IBM:
 - Interesting and difficult problems to solve
 - Highly intelligent coworkers, expert in a wide range of fields
 - Chance to influence the future of the company
 - Connected to industry and academia
 - Offices! (Researchers need places to hunker down and concentrate)
Cons: IBM is very bureaucratic and seems set on saving money by cutting everywhere they can, often to the detriment of employees and their morale. IBM Research is only partially exempted from these problems.

Pros: Relatively competitive pay. 60% of the time your teammates on the project are very smart and fun individuals.
Cons: The management on the consulting side at least expect everyone to put in long hours, overnight travels, weekend travels. The practitioners at IBM are expected to find their own projects which add a lot of unnecessary stress. Just because the partners can't sell their projects, the practitioners get punished for low utilization when there are really no projects available to be staffed on.

Pros: The salary is great, and IBM has a fantastic reputation. The career path set out for consultants is pretty straight forward, as long as you're in a prominent field that you enjoy. There are also a lot of opportunities to work on your current skill set, provided that it's related to your current field and you find them yourself.
Cons: IBM is a very large company, which unfortunately means it tends to be very political and inflexible. The culture is terrible, in terms of there not being much support or guidance in comparison to other firms, and the offices tend to be notably empty. Also, you don't have any say in the projects you're placed in unless you find them yourself, which makes it harder to control your career path.

Pros: Knowledgeable and smart colleagues.  Good work balance.
Cons: The company has mass lay offs frequently. Almost half of their employees are on contract, most of whom have been let go from their full time roles,  only to be brought back on contract three months later.  All this while the CEO draws 32 million dollars a year in salary and writes herself a check of around 3 millions dollars as "bonus". How can she get a bonus when the company is performing badly and the other employees don't get any?!

Pros: Work life balance is great. More than average flexibility to work from home whenever needed. Several teams only work in office twice a week.
Cons: Management is still operating under the former company, good Ole boy system. If you're not white and or a male, you don't stand a chance of promotion, unless your manag(er/ement) is from the traditional IBM. Otherwise, all of HIS people will get the promotions and or pay increases.

Pros:
- Good Training for new employees
- Good place to start for college grads
- Name looks good on a resume (although it's waning a bit nowadays)
- Lots of knowledgeable people
- Opportunity to learn more
Cons:
- "Legacy" IT
- experience heavily depends on your team/product
- lots of people are deadweight and aren't given the chance to pull the cart

Pros:
IBM is learning from past mistakes. They are continuing to improve in areas that matter to employees.
If you are a top contributor your pay scale and rewards are fantastic.
Unlimited opportunity to learn in all areas of any IT business
Brand recognition opens opportunities for future career changes however IBM is so large you have potential to do anything you like and they actually offer the checkpoint to get there.
Cons:
IBM is a very large company so processes and change take time. 
Even though there is an improvement in transparency from executives it still seems like there is a lot to improve.
IBM is changing business in the right direction however previous mistakes still haunt and the "front line" is still paying for those mistakes via retention or lack of ability to replace skilled workers.

Pros:
- Opportunity to work with and learn from leaders in your field.
 - Access to high-end computing resources (leaders in quantum computing)
 - Company has high visibility. Opportunity to make a large impact
 - Opportunity for remote work, flexible with work hours and days off.
 - High Morale
Cons:
- Pay may be a notch lower than other big-tech rivals; however, the pay is very competitive in tech overall.
 - IBM is an older company, more geared toward long-term growth. Stock options and short term gain potential may be less than at other companies
 - Interview process can be slow, and there can be a lack of communication during that process

Pros: IBM has the best programs for career advancement and mobility of anywhere I've worked. I've been promoted twice in three years. They also have paid learning time, and a massive library of courses, as well as free access to other libraries like O'Reilly and Red Hat. There is a serious effort put into diversity and inclusion, not just lip service and ads. The company is socially conscious and takes a stand on important issues affecting the world today. They also take work/life balance seriously, and have benefits to back that up.
Cons: I can't think of any. I used to change employers regularly because I couldn't advance my career any other way. I no longer have to do that. I plan to stay at IBM long term.

Pros: Strong practices in business and technology consulting as well as technology capabilities that can make a significant business and technology impact. Broad portfolio and lots of experience across several verticals. Execution post sales has been awesome so far.
Cons: Lots of process red tape. Reporting revenue numbers is not really beneficial or fun. Too much emphasis on the transaction vs. building a strong foundation for a long term partnership. Recent feedback from shareholders on gross profit have lead to burdensome controls being put in place on pricing approvals.

Pros: Good training for early professionals. Team with others to grow your skills. Get out after 2 or so years. Be aware IBM is not seen as a plus to prospective hiring managers.
Cons: Not a sales oriented company, Finance runs IBM. Accounts move around to the point that you loose customer relationships and the commission. The finance folks will find ways to not pay commission. if you blow out your number, they will exercise their right to not pay you, you have to sign a doc agreeing that they have the right to pay what they want.

Pros: IBM Research has a good reputation. As a result it can open doors. There is flexibility with respect to balancing work/life/family issues.
Cons:
Although there are some projects in which RSM's do real research, overall IBM Research is not what it used to be. It's mostly a development lab rather than a research lab. This is why many promising young researchers who start at IBM become invisible in their fields several years after they start.

This problem is an old one. Management claims to want to address it, but there has been no progress in addressing the underlying culture and issues.

Pros: Good amount of vacation time, and sick time policy was very flexible.  I got really sick and took a week off, no problem.  Lots of opportunities if you are able to stay there for a long time, and you are noticed.
Cons: The managers interperet coroporate policies so differenttly, this makes some people very lucky and others very unlucky.  Compensation starts very low for entry level positions, and people treat each other like crap, that was my experience at least

Pros:
- Flexible work arrangements, can work from home depending on project or job
- Name recongnition for resume
- Exposure into how a corporate entity operates
Cons:
- Salary and Bonus is downright poor now.  IBM sr mgt believes staff are commodities.  They pay/reward below market.
- Since salary has become poor, a new medicore class of employees are being hired.  I gues these are the ones that couldn't get a higher offer somewhere else and it shows!
- Seasoned partners are leaving...lots of middle managers with no skills left.
- No more education reimbursement (MBA)

Pros: Solid, well-recognized company with decent benefits. Definitely a large variety of positions and experiences available and most employees (US-based) work from home, so there is reasonable flexibility.
Cons: Working from home makes it very tricky to have any kind of personal relationship with colleagues. IBM continues to layoff US-based workers without any notice, whatsoever...Morale is just terrible. Amazing to see people who have 30+ years in with the company still work 16+ hour days when they are fearful (daily) that they won't have a job tomorrow.

Pros:
i) People, people people. My co-workers were mostly young and fun people. Very helpful and knowledgeable.
ii)Growth opportunity. IBM is a big company, you can switch between very different fields and still work for IBM - which is good for salary, further opportunities and meeting new people.
iii) The Research Triangle Park is a great place to live. The ocean is near, smokey mountains are near. A lot of nice clubs and a college life and city feel in the Raleigh area.
Cons: i) The cubicles were grey and rather boring. Some more collaboration on specific problem solving would have been better. Do not get me wrong, there are a lot of meeting and talk between developers and managers, but it was a tiny bit more general.

Pros: If you don't care about job security, and can get a job, it may pay well.  However, IBM is shifting American workers into centers in low wage states and locations.  Existing employees can relocate themselves or simply lost the moved job.  Many job types were "debanded" (demoted).  Today it is all about cheap labor.
Cons: Enormous job insecurity.  Many Americans lost jobs this year but some get to return as contractors (without benefits).  Number of American workers declined to 105,000 in 2009 and is believed now to be about 95,000.  This is a company with about 400,000 employees.  There is job growth, but not in the USA.

Pros: was able to survive 30 yrs. and when I went there I knew I had been blessed to work for the best company in these United States.
Cons: greedy upper management, no longer can they cling on to respect for the individual.  nothing is good enough, and you can work 24 / 7 and sometimes need to to survive.  pay bonues on company performance are now a joke or don't exist and you can go years without a salary increase but you will get new and more job resposibilties.  they continue to raise the bar and top mgmt. gets all the money and perks.

Pros: IBM is a good place to make contacts and to network. Many people are quite knowledgeable, and if you stick with them, you can learn a lot.
Cons: IBM tends to layoff hundreds or thousands of people every quarter or two if they need to boost profit (by decreasing payroll). If you're ok with the knowledge that you could be fired at anytime – even if you have decent performance reviews – then IBM is great for you. Also – it is IBM’s stated policy to pay 80% of the mean salary for a job in it's geography. In other words, it is the stated policy to pay less than you could get at many other places.

Pros:
Being an IBMer.
Flexible hours.
Good benefits.
Cons:
Unfortunately, at the Kenexa office, we are always running and going nowhere. Goals are not clear or change all the time.
First level managers are all juniors, they think that they are awesome though. The truth is that they have no clue of how to motivate or lead a team.
Many people are leaving the company not only for the stress but for the inefficiency to get the work done. Many people are just waiting to get their Green Cards and then they will leave.
The former CEO (Rudy Karsan) has a great speech, he even wrote a book about motivation and how important is to have the employees engaged. Unfortunately those are only words when it comes to Kenexa.

Pros: Excellent telework opportunities, great technology exposure, if you're willing to move around within the organization alot.  Unlimited access to RedBooks, the IBM Systems Journal, etc. so whatever you want to learn, you can learn if you're motivated.
Cons: Leadership is (and has been) woefully lacking.  Middle management got there simply because they weren't technical enough in most cases and spend a lot of time managing up.  Any time I had concerns about working relationships in the highly matrixed organization, I was told to just find someone else to work with.  No team spirit - more of a team competition as there is always the need to justify your position to upper management.  Bad energy.

Pros: People are talented and gifted; a lot of projects to roll onto to try different roles/responsibilities.  Work with a variety of people where you can learn from; people who've been with the company for 10+ years and those at least a year. Benefits are great - covers dental, medical, etc.
Cons: Depending on who you have as your manager and who he/she reports to, you may or may not get training dollars - you need to talk to the right people (mainly those higher in the chain) to get the training you need to get ahead for your own career development

Pros: As the name implies, IBM is an international/global company and the right roles provide the opportunity to work with colleagues and clients all over the world.  Given the monolithically huge size of the corporation, one can have a lifetime of jobs within the same company.
Cons: The biggest con of IBM is the current culture of  distrust, fear, and bitterness engendered by on-going layoffs and substantially reduced severance packages that dramatically affect longtime employees.

Pros: Great place to work, fun & challenging.  Supports working from home (depending on your position).
Cons: VERY stressful the past 4-5 years wondering when (not IF) the call would come that jobs were be transitioned to India.  This happened to our group earlier this year.  The rumor mill is saying that they are cutting to the bone for US-based folks, trying to have US population to be only 20% of the total...   A LOT of great talent has left...  Also they changed the exit package from one week paid time for every year worked (max of 26 or so) to everyone gets one month as of January this year...   ;-(

Pros: Some good benefits as expected from a big company
Cons: Even though the upper management has a lot of female presence, at the ground level for example projects like CAMMIS (State of California Medi-Care and Medi-Caid account) there is a lack of female presence in the management. It is predominantly Indian male dominated in with very less presence of women or non-Indians on the management side. And as with any other big companies, there is lot of politics with discrimination in salary standards from male to female for the same job role. Also being predominantly Indian male dominated, there is an expectation to socialize outside of work, as the men do, in order to get benefits and promotions.

Pros: Good position for early career opportunities.
Cons: Not very well structured. Pay is low. Travel 100% even though it says 50%.  Different mentality between CIC centers and regular IBM. IBM treats the CIC as "Near Shore" workers with the concept of bringing offshore work to the US.  No defined career path for early professionals after a certain point. Managers make it hard to promote to band 7 while CBDers in the company automatically get promoted between the 1.5-2 year mark. Managers change every 6-10 months because they don't even live in Baton Rouge.

Pros: Global business, household name, corporate discounts, and competitive compensation.
Cons:
Worked in the consulting by degrees program for two years out of undergrad.  They grossly over-hired entry-level consultants and eventually people were fighting to get on projects. 

Managers are not invested in your career development. They just check in with you to check off another box on their to-do list. You have to network within the practice to even find work and you have very little choice in what you get staffed on. When you do get work, it's usually tedious and you don't learn a lot from the experience. 

The opportunity for bonuses and 401K matches are promised when you sign on and then you don't get anything.  The company is struggling and you can feel it when you work there. Just look at IBM's revenue from the last few years: revenue has consistently declined over 22 quarters.

Pros: The  benefits were good.
Cons:
In 2017 and 2018, IBM decided to co-located their entire US Marketing department. This is where they asked their entire Marketing team to move to one of the 6 key cities that they had selected. If you didn't up and move your entire family, then you were without a job. 

This was completely unfair as there were so many GREAT marketers who had been loyal to the company 20 or 30 years, and were now without jobs! The only ones who could truly co-locate were younger people with no families or roots established.

So, if you were in your mid-30s and up, and not currently located in 1 of the key cities, you were basically going to lose your job.

This was a cheap way to layoff a lot of great older workers, and IBM should be ashamed of themselves!!! STAY away from IBM unless you're under 30 years old!

Pros: IBM finance and operations have some incredibly smart and driven individuals that, if you work hard for them, will in turn ensure that they do what they can to work for you.
Cons: Around the organization, there are massive pockets of complacency that drives subpar performance. Strategy needs to become more aligned, or the organization will continue to pull in directions that disable true "agile" movement into new and emerging markets; this will consequently continue to keep IBM from being an innovative competitor.

Pros: IBM was once a great company to work for. Pensions, good benefits, education reimbursement, training, great management, etc. Unfortunately, now this company is a shell of it's former self.
Cons:
Pensions gone. Benefits slashed. Good luck on getting anything reimbursed (even internet access and phones for remote employees was cut). Horrible, toxic management so infested with workforce politics that even Queen Cersi from Game of Thrones would blush.

Employees are in constant fear of resource actions (RAs) and management is in a perpetual cycle of evaluating who the next person(s) to include on future RAs. (Forced rankings/PBC where employees have to compete against each other never went away).

IBM was late to cloud computing and never made any in roads to market share. Their technology is outdated and (offshore) customer support is horrible. There are many other fantastic Cloud companies to work for these days. Stay away. 

IBM has become irrelevant.

Pros:
IBM is a good place to work. 
They are very flexible with your work schedule which is nice.
In the decades I've been here I've never been bored, always lots to do.
People I work with are great for the most part.
Cons:
Most of the time we're understaffed, way too much to do.
Salary is sub-par, and the longer you are here the lower your pay vs the rest of the industry.
Tons of hierarchy and bureaucracy, can be frustrating at times.

They advertise that since they are so big they have lots of opportunities for you to move around and do different things, but if you are good at what you do then forget about being able to shift positions, they want to keep you right where you are. This can be a pro or con, depends on your desired career path.

Pros: Corporate culture has evolved into one that embraces diversity and inclusion. Employees' input is sought-out because each person's unique talents are valued. First and Second line managers hold tremendous power to define the culture in their organizations. Many work tirelessly to ensure their employees know how much they are appreciated.
Cons: Employee experience of corporate culture can vary greatly depending on the team and leadership they are under. Some managers find their organization's culture of no importance and only value the bottom line. Employees on these teams tend to be less satisfied.

Pros: Work/Life balance options are mostly pretty good.  If you're non-exempt and in a position that can get some overtime hours or carries a pager, the pay isn't horrible.
Cons: Very poor senior management treatment of lower rung employees.  Nearly all technical workers are now non-exempt (hourly).  The big push is to globalize resources to areas with cheaper labor rates.  American technical employees are second class citizens and liabilities.  Due to these issues, morale in the company is dreadful and getting anything done is pretty much impossible.  The other large issue in Services is that Sales is under the gun to sell as much software as possible and we are always stuck trying to deliver the promises.

Pros: Lots of different things to work on.  Good ability to switch jobs if you don't like what you are doing.  Many jobs have the ability to telecommute if management approves.  More of a results oriented management style than one focused on face time.  Most first line managers are competent and seem to care about their people.
Cons: Long hours and the usual corporate stuff:  bad senior management decisions, "cost cutting" that ends up costing the company more money, mass decisions that don't make individual sense, etc.  Issued laptops are often very unreliable and it takes forever to get a new one.

Pros:
1) Global
2) You could work a lifetime and not know all of IBM
3) IBM Name Hype
4) Diverse experience opportunities
Cons:
1) Global means you 
2) You can work 1 year and know all the management "BS".
3) Underpaid
4) Benefits suck this includes cafeteria facility too
5) Need to subscribe to Blue Culture
6) Its like running a 4 x 4 relay, you do your bit and hand it over to your manager who passes it on and so on......

Pros: Prestigious company, decent pay, free health insurance for employee, varied work available, very flexible with regards to work location (if your client doesn't need you at site, you can work from home or any IBM office)
Cons: Your career has a ceiling unless you bring sales to the company - big con for technical people, 45 hour work week required if you want any salary increase, large amounts of time to find your way through the bureaucracy - especially when it comes to evaluations and tracking skills

Pros: As a research assistant, I was frequently given free reign to try new technologies and see how they might be applied to real world application.  It can be exciting to take something new from the lab and actually oversee implementation as a pilot in a customer setting and be able to take the feedback directly back to the lab in a continuous improvement cycle.
Cons: It was a temporary assignment and had to come to an end.

Pros: Colleagues are awesome, work content is challenging and interesting, ability to work at home, great interaction with clients, lots of potential to move around business units at the company
Cons: 20 hour work days and weekends are the norm for managers due to global team structure, expectations are total work overload, lack of work life balance, positions are not back-filled as promised, annual raises are pathetic or non-existent, requirements for advancement are ambiguous or poorly communicated, bottom line thinking prevails such that only sales related efforts are rewarded monetarily

Pros: IBM USED to be a wonderful company to work for, but that was many, many years ago
Cons: Employees are increasingly treated like they are dirt.  Constant chronic cuts and stack ranking have made IBM a cut throat, miserable environment to work in.  I am so tired of seeing my fellow workers get canned - and what a coincidence - they are all in their 50's when it happens. For those of us left, we work insane hours because we are doing the job that 3 or 4 people used to do and this only gets worse with every year. Nothing is done to quality anymore. Customers are no longer a priority either - not sure what is a priority with this company.  If you are looking for a job, look elsewhere - you will fare much better at another company, especially if you are just starting your career.

Pros: Collaborative atmosphere, smart people, investment in basic science and research, proactive opportunity creation and advancement for women, phenomenal technologies.  highest integrity and ethics. lots of opportunities to move within the company. Watson strategy will propel the company to next level. Top executives (VP level and above) are smart and excellent at what they do.
Cons: processes designed for the last decade prevent company from moving fast enough to compete with new threats. Not-invented-here syndrome. Poor middle management.

Pros: Flexible work schedule and telecommuting. Developing products can be interesting.
Cons: You are forced to work using IBMs platforms and infrastructure which is usually behind the industry. Also with so many different pieces of the architecture of the software solution being developed at the same time, it raises the risk significantly as many pieces are interdependent of each other and when one fails, it breaks all others. Many different departments with different goals and agenda's lead to the nothing getting accomplished.

Pros: Pay, lifestyle, people. IBM is great if you are looking for a conservative environment with minimal change year in and year out. Most of the people are fantastic, but middle management can be very political.
Cons: Pay is OK, but not top tier in the industry. Very process oriented...so much so that it impacts sales and customer relationships. Lost the ability to react which is hurting market share. Current company strategy is built on M&A because innovation is not taking off.

Pros:
Flexibility to work from home
Opportunity to work on extremely advanced systems technologies, but see cons section.
Good 401K match % but only applicable if employed on Dec 15th
Cons: Revenue is in a tailspin and profits are up at the expense of employee compensation.  Quarterly layoffs are the norm, and specifically target the 40+ population in the US.  If you're very good, you have Job security but don't expect bonuses or career growth, that's reserved for the low cost geographies.  If you're not good, you'll be laid off swiftly, unless you're in a low cost geography.  In short, all stick, no carrot.  In short, the culture the made IBM great no longer exists.

Pros: The only pros i have seen the company has got flexible work culture.
Cons:
IBM is such a Huge Company but implementing a change or getting an approval takes for ever. If you need a single thing to get signed off Non of the Management folks would take responsibility to make it happen. Every one feels it's not their job to get it done. 
Additionally  Management tries to preach a particular Culture and they never follow. When it comes to Promotion they recommend doing Career Framework and all  Crap and Finally they provide peanuts for their employee who works 18 hours a day. 
In my center please have experienced Managers. Do not bring in in experienced rookies as Managers for Senior Employees.

Pros: Flexible work schedule but expect to work much more than 40 hours a week. If a new hire they will treat you better for awhile until the favorites are chosen and the next batch come in.
Cons: Below average pay for above average work load. No pay raises for several years in a row. Raise have been below CPI since Gerstner left. Lower level management is very political and petty. Upper level management completely clueless. They think being a "me too" company will lead to profits.

Pros: You have the full spectrum of solutions for clients so that you can tailor a custom approach to meet their needs.  Bright and motivated colleagues for the most part.  Incredible brand recognition.  Endless resources.  R&D second to none.
Cons: Specific to my experience from early 2014 and prior to that, IBM could be slow to recognize critical new technology directions such as cloud.  There are so many offerings across the software, services and hardware landscapes that it became challenging to get a clients focused attention to act and buy and implement resulting in some dilution of client focus.

Pros: Nice coworkers, not all that technically capable.  Limited by their training and separation of duties on the Div16
Cons:
DIV16 - Government division is full of don't rock-the-boaters and show up and collect a paycheck people.  If you are hired into DIV16 you can not leave that division, you may be loaned out to the commercial side, but will not truly ever be able to leave without quitting and applying from the outside.  IBM Boomerangers (leave to come back) are high because of this and similar policies.  Company culture of redefining yourself is not adhered to by complacent and lazy managers.

Benefits for a family are EXPENSIVE and not particularly good.  If your single they seem to be mediocre.

Pros: Great opportunity for someone getting started right out of school.  The salaries are better than average and the Learning and Development is unsurpassed.
Cons: Most everyone knows IBM unless you are under 25 years of age.  The company is suffering from brand recognition, but trying to make a comeback.  The recent reduction in employees should help the bottom line, but what does it do for the reputation?  The future of this once glorious technology leader is in jeopardy.  Let's all hope it can come back and soon.

Pros: My organization was acquired by IBM, so the only pros that came with the organizational transition were a direct result of my prior employer.
Cons:
-Decrease in remote work
-no sense of placement within the organization
-not enough placed on building culture and group dynamics within regions
-no professional development opportunities beyond your service role. as a world class leader in business, it is unthinkable that professional and personal growth are not  top priorities for employees.

Pros:
- Flexibility to work on multiple cutting-edge technologies
- Ability to shape and define markets and be truly competitive for enterprise software
- Gain experience working with the world's largest major companies as clients
- Work in any industry or technology you want to get into
- You're able to take control of your own career and have multiple careers within one company, if you choose
Cons:
- Your experience will 100% be based on the team you work for, you can have a range of experiences based on your team and manager
- Can be a process and bureaucracy-heavy company to navigate internally

Pros: It is a good place for young people to start a career and get good training as long as there is a plan to leave the business within 5 or 6 years.   Employees in the sales and marketing professions can gain significant good contacts to move into other businesses as they grow their skills.
Cons: IBM discriminates against white males, and in particular, those over 40 years old.   It is clearly a supporter of reverse discrimination.   All diversity groups are protected and nurtured except white males over 40.  It's a disgrace and causes many roles to be filled with people of lesser skills in order to minimize the role of white males in the workplace.

Pros: Very flexible with work at home options.  Opportunities to work with the best in the industry.    Excellent on line/virtual classroom professional courses available for all employees.  I've had excellent growth experiences working on smaller start up projects which have provided invaluable experience.
Cons: Too much red tape hinders decision making.    Too many middle managers who do not understand software development or developers.     It is very difficult for non-technical employees to get good raises or promotions.   There is no identifiable corporate culture in the software group and people are given assignments rather than  put into growth or career positions for the larger projects.   Senior management determines schedules and scope and does not understand appropriate project management methodology which leads to lots of weekend work to accommodate already compressed schedules.

Pros:
Home office. Varied projects.  Pizza gift card one Christmas.  Boss says "go home early" at end of day before holiday.  Boss buys drinks and dinner for team 2 to 4 times a year.  Flexible hours. Usually no one looking over your shoulder.
Once a month team meetings.
Cons: Spread out across the globe.   Each person for themselves.  Technically incompetant leaders.   Can't understand heavy accent fast talking Indians.  Lacking networked architecture before software solutions are expected.  Holiday party consisted of a meeting on the phone.  No preliminary meetings to prepare and unite as a team for in house customer service visits.

Pros: The pay is good, and you get to work with people around the world as well as a bunch of hillbillies in North Carolina.  IBM is customer focused.
Cons: The review system does NOT promote teamwork.  It is cut-throat.  Also, IBM never does anything new or creative.  You use old tools to work on last years technology.  IBM buys new companies, it doesn't invent or create anything.  Its heyday is long behind us.  This is sad.   Also, the stress level is unbelievable.  I've seen people crying at their desks far too many times.

Pros:
-Great benefits when compared to other companies. 
-Big company = lots of opportunities
-The risk of failure vs. the risk of reward in inside sales is pretty good
Cons:
-It's a big machine, you might inadvertently get chewed up by it.
-Moving around within the company is a crap-shoot, you might end up in a spot that's terrible, but you have little way of knowing ahead of time.-\
-Lots of people slacking off, hiding within the protective confines of the big machine.
-The right hand doesn't know what the left is doing

Pros: When first started they took care of there workers, gave great raises and bonuses. They gave you the tools to be the best at what you do. Gave you opportunities to grow in your Career.
Cons: Now they don't give you the tools to be better they try to keep you limited to what you do there knowing if you got more skills you may leave. Your pay wasn't up to standards and some years you didn't even get a raise or a bonus. There was very little opportunities to grow later on in my career from when i started twenty years ago.

Pros:
1)  Competent management has a clear plan to shift its product mix to highly profitable segments on an ongoing basis.  
2)  There are more career development resources available to you than you'd likely find at any other private corporation. 
3)  There is always a group of people somewhere that has similar interest / skills in your area of interest.
Cons: 1)  Experiences will vary widely depending on where your position is within the business.

Pros:
Let you work remote
trust you to get your work done, no micromanaging
great coworkers
interesting work
Cons:
ridiculous policies for performance reviews(pbcs). Perfectly good people get low reviews and great people get passed over for top ratings because they follow an algorithm instead of honestly rating work
Top execs do not value their employees
very little training/investment in employees
changed the 401K match to yearly matching so they can freely lay off people and save $$
Do not allow much transfer between departments

Pros: Company has a great history. The opportunities are good if you have a responsive Band 10 or above to employees needs and concerns. Benefits are fair to on par with industry.
Cons: Where do I begin?  No one in this company can communicate for beans. Leadership calls employees resources and gives us all serial numbers...most organizations call their people, well, people or talent. This trickles down to everything...poor treatment of employees, ever shrinking benefits, terrible pay and no increases, company expects the world out of its employees but gives us NOTHING in returns. IBM has sold out to EPS and absurd promises to the street

Pros:
Lots of opportunities to try different technology sectors, but this also depends on the type of employee, the more challenges an employee wants the faster their career path can move. The opposite is also true, the less challenges an employee wants the more their job can become stagnant
Most of the company is family oriented
Cons:
First line management most of the time is good about protecting their developers but upper level management doesn't always seem like their vision is aligned with their lower level management.
Morale is not so great right now, poof performance has caused the company to make some decisions that are not always the best ones

Pros:
Talented smart people
Loyal peers in face of a company that has not reciprocated
Cons:
Few opportunities for advancement in North America
Executives are tone deaf
Limited staff to support clients
Morale horrible
Using outmoded stacked ranking

Pros: Excellent thought leadership & vision in the market, Good work life balance, good flexibility like working from home (teams are distributed all across the country), Good benefits, industry average salary. If you're getting a job at IBM, I highly suggest you work here for one year at least and figure out if this culture is a good fit for you or not. You will learn a lot here.
Cons: As usual with big companies, too many processes, takes too many approvals to get things done. You have to work hard to stand out, But that is true for any other company. Don't expect big bonuses or stock options.

Pros:
- Good reputation
- Some bright coworkers (not all, but there are some brilliant people here)
Cons:
- Frequently poor managers (common in technical jobs)
- Poor review cycles and promotions: complex and infrequent
- You are a cog in a wheel, no chance to make an impact until at least at the partner level
- Constant focus on cost-cutting, there is a general lack of organic growth focus

Pros: Great entry level training. Solid reputation in the technology industry.  Over 100 year old company so it has some stability based on longevity.  You have the opportunity to work with some smart, innovative people.  Compensation is ok and when you add benefits, they are competitive with the market.  They do not pay at the top or bottom.
Cons: Has lost some of it's focus on the people and not as invested in training management on strong people skills as well as good functional skills.  If you get a manager with both functional and people skills, you will enjoy your job.  If not, they seem slow to move poor managers out which affects the whole team.

Pros: Great, Good  and very smart people especially at the field and 1st level management.. Excellent Benefits( Although Changing).
Cons:
Poor - work life balance. Inefficient management regimen, despite all their tools, Salesforce, Notes, still rely on MS Xcel spreadsheets to mange their business. " Chinese Fire-drill" cadence calls. Trickle down communication is very ineffective. Many 3rd and 2nd levels confused about roll and create "panicked" environment for rest of organization. Very Stressful.
Because of size of organization, Internal IBM'ers become gatekeepers making contact with customers and prospects the most difficult experience ever.Difficult to run a team effectively with current management structure

Pros: Good pay (as a band 10). Work from home. Largely get to define my own priorities and tasks in support of the overall mission. My manager isn't focused on time in the office as much as on accomplishing objectives, so work schedule varies and is flexible.
Cons: Most of my projects (staff role in global for GTS) seem to go nowhere and don't make a difference to anything important, which isn't what I was hoping to do with my career. It's painful to get things done with so many competing interests and priorities in the company. Problems with employee technology and tools (e.g. cleaning up mail due to ridiculously low email quota, instant messaging and intranet sites not working, etc.) have to be dealt with on personal time (since I'm measured on objectives accomplished, not time in the office).

Pros: When I started at IBM it was an amazing place to work. Great group of extremely dedicated talented and driven people. Superb, world-class education available to all employees, great culture, IBM had the world by the tail. That all changed when Sam Palmissano took over as CEO in 2001.
Cons: Sam destroyed the company via lack of vision, extremely poor leadership, and excessive cost cutting. IBM internally is now a terrible place to work, with constant layoffs and a culture of fear and intimidation. They are so tied up in their own bureaucracy that they can't get anything done quickly. Many of the superb employees have left and those that are left are afraid to do anything for fear of losing their jobs.

Pros: Co-workers are extremely talented and professional ...  work is challenging and  gets accomplished with great teamwork. A great deal of flexibility in terms of work hours, work from home, etc.
Cons:
Very long hours for very extended periods of time. Significant overtime is expected on a regular basis along with 24x7 availability.  Many people go for years without a raise.  When raises are received they are typically small (1-2%).
The rating system discourages many talented people from pursuing advancement in terms of promotions.  Once yo're promoted, your performance rating will drop making you a more likely candidate for the next  resource action which is IBM's term for layoff.
Very average benefits.

Pros: IBM really has what they are doing "down pat".  For a big company I was always impressed by how smoothly their internal systems worked and that they really tried to help employees when they needed it.
Cons: In order to advance in the company managers have to work in all different parts of the business so they can understand them.  This means you will get short-term managers popping in on a regular basis who don't understand the part of the business YOU are in so they can learn.  Some of these are good, some not so good.

Pros: Great pay and good benefits. Depending on the project you may have flexibility to work from home some days.
Cons: Many managers were disrespectful and unprofessional. No boundaries (calls from managers all day/evening and work almost every weekend). Must record your time, for every 15 minutes, every day. Must work a minimum of 45 hours a week. Must meet annual billable hour rates which can be unreasonable if you are in between projects and cannot bill hours. Part of annual review is how much "give back" (e.g, community service) you did outside of work hours. Must have at least 40 hours of education credits each year (again, time spent outside of regular workday on new learning which takes away from your billable rate/calculation). Many

Pros: Great group of professionals to work with and for
Cons:
- Forget about your life - your utilization targets are 110% ... not sure if that is even legal 
- When your executives are not closing deals, you get bad ratings which means no salary increases and no bonus ... even though you could be working around the clock 
- When you executives are closing deals, you barely get any meaningful bonus because you are delivery guy (or what they started calling it past couple of weeks client service professional)

Pros: Massive presence and brand, top notch telecommuting environment for individuals who qualify. Touch many areas and industries.
Cons: I think they invented bureaucracy, or at least perfected it. HR is a an offshore call center, I once hung up after being told the average wait time was 2 hours. At IBM you are literally a number. Most of of the company seems obsessed with "growing" through squeezing customers and tightening margins, not much technological innovation for such a powerful company with a proud history.

Pros: Good benefits sucha s 401k, vacation, insurance, and flexibility to work from home to a certain extent.
Cons: As an engineer, unless you are brilliant it is pretty tough to move up the ladder. Raises were not given very easily and you really had to suck up to management and brown nose tons of people to climb up. Also, depending on your team, your work can either be very invigorating or very dull.

Pros: IBM is undergoing a radical transformation to remain relevant in the new cloud and big data economy. This offers a lot of opportunities to shape the future and evolution of the company. The job of product manager is challenging and allows for a lot of creativity.
Cons: Big company, big politics. The current climate is difficult with constant efforts to reduce cost while at the same time having the challenge to re-invent the way it brings products to the market. I've seen for quite a while a parade of executives that are only interested in promoting themselves rather than delivering value for the company.

Pros:
- Depending on team, can be low stress with good work life balance. Flex time and work from home are nice benefits.
- Generally pretty good culture. People try to help each other and there isn't much backstabbing.
Cons:
- Depending on area, things are in flux and management will constantly being changing priorities.
- Quality of engineers is questionable in general. No technical questions are asked during interviews, so you can get hired without really knowing how to code.
- Flat or pathetic increases in salary.
- Not much room for advancement since everyone has 20 and 30 years of seniority.

Pros: If you have your eye on a role or are passionate about something, you are the only thing standing between success or failure.  People who create their own opportunities will thrive here.  If you are not ready for that entrepreneurial atmosphere, this may not be your best option.
Cons: There are many layers of redundant process supported by a back office function that needs its own transformation, but you can be a part of that change if you bring solutions to the problem into the process.

Pros:
1) IBM is a (the?) top, global brand in the IT products and services space
2) IBM Watson has been a huge differentiator in the past 2-3 years
3) IBMers are highly competent individuals who are full of integrity
Cons: Financial performance over the last five years has not met Wall Street's expectations. Resource actions have been necessary to align headcount with declining revenues. Employee morale has declined accordingly

Pros: Some great technical minds and groups to work in. The occasional good manager (I had at least 10 managers in 15 years). Large company means choices for affordable benefits. Opportunities for college grads.
Cons: You are a number, plain and simple. Ageism is rampant. Terrible management at every level. Morale is horrible as everyone waits for the next layoff. Great people get let go every quarter. Your yearly review score can be excellent yet you're not valued as an employee.

Pros: Some flexibility around work hours. Expected to work beyond what you're compensated for, though work/life balance is good - better than many companies. They're also trying with snacks, catered lunches, happy hours, etc - but that doesn't really appeal to the masses who are just trying to get the job done and not engage in a million activities that detract from work.
Cons: Management turnover is atrocious. Don't expect anyone to advocate for you, you're just a cog in the corporate machine. Anyone director level & up will likely jump (sinking?) ship within the next fiscal year, unless there's a huge turnaround.

Pros:
Lots of opportunities for starter in the Technology industry. One is able to learn so much from people who are highly qualified.
The work environment is very laid back. You do not have a situation where a manager is constantly on your shoulder.
Talk about work/life balance, this is where you find it.
The pay is very good
Cons:
Young people may find it a bit hard because there are very many old people in this company. Many of the old people have been there for several years. The company`s old creed of giving people a career for life is responsible for this.
The company also embarked on rebalancing to refocus its business model which led to some people losing their jobs lately

Pros: In IBM Research you will in general find smart above average PhDs. Flexible schedule most of the time, and the possibility of extra vacation at partial pay. IBM Research is usually open to academic collaborations and encourages publications.
Cons: Bureaucracy and lack of resources to achieve your goals are the biggest problems. IBM Research model is on the one hand individual-oriented, but it is hard to get resources other than your salary. On the other hand, when teams are formed, they are usually big and scattered around the globe, so more often than not, credit for success goes to a very small number of high-rank managers.

Pros: Money.  If you are out to do nothing but make money this is the job for you, otherwise go somewhere else.  If you are looking to make a difference or do something epic, this is not for you.
Cons: Long Hours.  Unfair review process.  Poor career growth.  Short on staff.  Horrible business practice.  Employees are required to work a 44 hour work week, coincidentally works out so that you only wind up with 1 day off a year IF you are able to take vacation.

Pros: Many paths for advancing your career and skill set.  Great people to work with (though if most of your team is on another site, move there or change to a local project).  The environment really is set up to communicate well with your team and provide you the required assistance in getting a project done.
Cons: Constant threat of layoffs even in the quarters with good market performance.  Upper management really gives no warning about employment prospects.  It is probably best to be in a city where there are other employment options, should your job go away.

Pros: Strong technical talent. You can find a person in IBM that is an expert on anything. This makes it a wonderful place to learn and grow.
Cons: Very large and bureaucratic. Not very nimble. Lots of people in middle management just looking for a way not to be blamed if things go wrong. The appraisals are more based on quotas and financials than on performance.

Pros:
1. Good number of hard working, intelligent practitioners still at in the firm that care about the development of fellow co-workers.  
2. Dollar-for-dollar 401K matching up to 6%. 
3. Strong health care benefits
Cons:
1. Number of hard working practitioners attribute is overshadowed by the larger number or employees and majority of leadership who do not care.
2. 401K match only applied to employee's account once each year, not per paycheck.
3. Raises for top performers limited to 2% max annually, if any.
4. Rarely any annual bonuses for top performers.
5. No corporate funds for local office social gatherings

Pros: The working people or the ones that do all the heavy lifting at IBM are fantastic and very intelligent. Once you get on a project the team of resources pull together to pull off miracles.
Cons:
Pay is not to averages in industry
Heavily in cost cutting mode, this affects everyone
Behind the curve in the industry trends; Mobile and Smarter commerce has some promise
If you expect a raise, re think coming
If you like 1-3% bonus, then this is not a CON
Expect to work 60-80 per week if you want a chance to move up

Pros: Company values are well established and the company size allows a lot of latitude especially in the areas of research and development around new technology.  Depending on your work location salaries can be 10% - 20% above the average rates for that location except in some of the biggest metropolitan areas.  Almost everyone knows IBM..
Cons: No longer "your father's IBM"...many of the perks and benefits associated with IBM have eroded over the years.  Sometimes the bureaucracy can become overwhelming -- the company is not everyone's "cup of tea".

Pros: One of the best place all over the world to do R&D in Microelectronic! Lot of very talented people, so you can learn a lot from them. Since it is R&D it is still a very interesting job where you could learn everyday
Cons: Not easy to work in a company when you do not know what's going on. Not clear vision of what will happen in less than a year. Due to that lot of people are just not motivated anymore. Forget about see you salary increase, even if you are in the top performers!

Pros: Provides an opportunity to work with some extremely bright people.  Forces you to look at issues from every angle (sometimes to a fault), but is invaluable experience for career growth.  A great place to learn and then move on so you can advance in your career both level wise and $$$ wise.
Cons: No life balance at all.  Work, work, work at all hours, since the organization has most of its employees outside of the US you need to be available at all hours.  Employee morale is horrible (at least in the US) and the focus is always on costs...ALWAYS.  Those at the top are very well paid, with lots of incentive; however, the workhorses are not as well rewarded with pay and other types of remuneration.  Obviously, I'm not a long term fan.

Pros: Typically a very solid company to work for.  Seeing increases in positions for support and development in the software side, specifically cloud based and aaS (as a Service) offerings.
Cons: Sometimes, managers higher in the structure value only the bottom line over the actual effort it takes to get the job done.  This is most evident in the Hardware support arena.  US based support is being still outsourced to other countries, and those that are left in the US are facing an increasingly difficult time getting the training and equipment needed to continue to provide the world class support we had been known for.

Pros: Huge company lots of people you can meet and connect with. Looks good on resume.
Cons: Company used to be more stable. Over the past 3-5 years it's starting to get rocky. I wouldn't be surprised if there were massive changes in the next 6-12 months. IBM has always been a set of revolving doors and they seem to be revoling a lot faster as of late. Pay is awful compared to others.

Pros:
* The people I work with immediately are great people and honest workers.
* The pay is good
Cons:
* The company itself does not care about its employees. They are quick to lay off and let go and it's causing their company to become a stepping stone rather than a career builder. 
* There is no accountability in upper management. They all look after each other to keep their bonuses.
* I feel like I signed on to a job rather than a career. It's pretty much expected that you'll leave within a year or 2 for another position. They provide absolutely no incentive for employees to stay.

Pros: I met some wonderfully talented people. I did learn a few new programs. Symphony is a terrible program compared to Microsoft.
Cons:
The performance reviews were rigged. You were judged not on your personal achievements but on your "band" (level) on your floor on a bell curve. Just like in college. A couple would get 1s, a few would get 2+s, a lot would get 2s, a few would get 3s, and a couple would get 4s. 

Only the 1s & 2+s would get raises and if you got a 3 you were stuck in your position for 18 months. If you got a 4 you were walked out. 

Many times your work was not even comparable to the other band members' work but you were judged the same.

Pros: I thought the work life balance was good.  You were able to go home at the end of the day and were not called after hours or on weekends very often.  Most of the time the job seemed balanced, enough to do but not too over whelmed.  I thought management help keep you balanced if you got too much on your plate. Enjoyable people.
Cons: You will find cons any where you work.  If I had to pick one sometimes you had to find root cause on things that almost felt impossible, but you can do your best and if you came prepared I thought management was pretty understanding.  I can also remember people being unsure if they would have a job from lay offs but this may be over with now.

Pros:
Good pay.
Flexible work location and hours - sort of - new move towards co- location may change this.
Employee discounts
In theory, job mobility within the company... but not job security
Brand recognition - you never have to explain to anyone who IBM is.
Cons:
Continuous silent layoffs - feels very sneaky.
Job performance system is a joke - it's all pre destined.
Beware if you are an older worker in lower to middle management - not safe to work there.
Bureaucracy can be frustrating if you are not used to it.

Pros: There aren't any pros to working here.
Cons: 100% lack of qualified management; decisions made on a short-termsurvival basis only with no consideration given to the stability of the business in question, the employees, or customers. Agents swapped from account to account depending on call volume or account need without regard for the state of the account they're taken from.  Boulder building is colossal, mostly empty, cold, poorly lit from room to room. Training is generally completely insufficient, pay is below average with starting salaries just over minimum wage. People approaching official retirement will be let go, forfeiting all benefits owed to them and there are occasions where, instead of firing people to improve the bottom line, they will mandate miserable schedules in the hope that the employees will quit of their own accord. There is no overtime for night shifts or holidays. There are no advancement opportunities available from the call center agent position despite the generous description found in job postings.

Pros: Flexible hours, great technical toys, able to work with people throughout the world. Some great groups of super smart people in there.
