Cons: Hiring lower technical skills means slower, lower quality products because the experience isn't there. Surprising lack of good software discipline in pockets. Also, definitely not a support of diverse personnel here despite the good press. Finding the right group is key - and harder to do now. Don't take a job here expecting long term safety, there isn't any. Find a position in a good, growing group.

Pros: Encouraged to give your best self everyday. It’s very rewarding. Leadership is top notch. Great mentor culture. Senior leadership is breeding best in class marketeers, watch out world!!
Cons: Co-location created a glass ceiling for professional growth. Unless you’re willing to pick up your family and have your spouse quite their job to move to an approved “hub” location. And the hubs are not in easily accessible or affordable cities. Clearly I was bummed about this strategy!

Pros: Large company with opportunities to explore interesting projects. Decent benefits.
Cons:
In spite of what they claim, hard work is not recognized. Management is too frequently ineffective or bullying. There are some exceptions, but the rule is too strong to ignore.

Note of bias: I was let go due to a round of layoffs. Unfortunately, this is common - there were at least 3 other "resource actions" before I was included in one. The claim by IBM is that layoffs were necessary to balance the books. I could have accepted that had the CEO not taken a huge bonus that year.

Pros: IBM encourages development of innovation technologies and products.  There is opportunity if you really seek it out. and because they are so big there are lots of directions in which you can steer your career.    There are a lot of really talented people who work for IBM and a strong network of women.  The pay and benefits are competative.
Cons: It's BIG.  There can be a fair amount of beaurocacy and sometimes getting the right thing done takes enourmous effort.  There are still some pockets of old-school philosophy (comand and control instead of empower and trust.)

Pros:
Ability to explore new and unique ideas. Opportunities for ideas and concepts that can be patented.
Great work / life balance for all employees. Excellent health and 401k plan.
Cons: Poor communication tools. Outdated software available for design. Clear divisions between design and development teams spread across regions, US and Globally. Many decisions take too long with too many people involved.

Pros:
- Strong leadership and good management development programs
- Great benefits ($0 premium healthcare option, good 401k match)
- People are generally nice, down to earth, intelligent and hard working
- Lots of opportunity if you have a diverse technical / business background
Cons:
- Promotional opportunities are not transparent; there seem to be people behind the curtains plotting your career for you and exec level positions are sometimes bestowed on those who put in the most face time and make the right connections while there are some very very hard working people who go nowhere
- Company is super stingy -- we don't have kitchens or water coolers (basic necessities!), printers always seem to be broken and company outings are none existent
- Development opportunities may be limited if you do not have a technical background

Pros:
They have a strong work from home culture. 
As a global company there is a lot of opportunity to work employees from other countries.
Cons:
In the group I am in there is zero budget for training, I haven't had training for over seven years.
The company is very top heavy with more managers than "doers".
The utilization rate is outrageously high, if you take your vacation you have to make it up with overtime otherwise you can not meet your utilization target.

Pros: Your colleagues will challenge you professionally, your goals will be set for your ability to achieve them, and there are endless possibilities for the motivated to advance their careers. This is a company that cares deeply for the world it operates in, and seeks to make a profound difference in the lives of it's employees and the world we live in.
Cons: We work really really hard. If you appreciate the challenge and opportunity to build and own something, this is for you. If you prefer to coast, you'll slide right off the cliff here.

Pros: Flexible work hours.  I've never had an issue with regards to having to plan something around family events or emergencies.  My 1st line managers have always been good at their jobs, managing people.
Cons:
Everyone and their mother is a manager.  There are too many people in the upper levels of management who have their MBAs.  All of them are trying to build their own little castles and they don't care who they have to step on in order to do it.

The company lacks direction and suffers from a lack of technical professionals.  Likely due to the low wages and terrible benefits.  They are not competitive in the job market and make no efforts to retain their worker base.

Pros: I've worked at IBM for the past 15 years in both smaller groups and larger groups, and there are many things to appreciate about IBM.  First, you have the luxury of changing jobs often to gain experience in different software and hardware product groups, which is a huge benefit. The processes are very well established and refined often, which many smaller companies find helpful when they hire IBMers.
Cons: The downside is that all the processes tend to take a lot of time away from doing the job they hire you for. IBM knows this and spends a lot of time simplifying the internal processes, but sometimes that's not always doable.  Overall, I have high respect for this company, and it's a great place to learn all about IT.

Pros: The only positive element working at IBM at this time is the people you work with who are all in the same boat you're in.
Cons: Executive Management is too focused on their own measurements and not looking at growing the business.  The more discerning Wall Street Analysts are starting to figure out that these people are chasing a target rather than focusing on growing the business.  The work environment is so awful that the people who are getting laid off actually feel better than the people who are left.  Once they hit their coveted $20 EPS and these bunch of Yo-Yo's leaves, IBM will again return to being a great place to work.

Pros:
People recognize IBM as a leader in the world of high tech
Co-workers are overall great to work with - quality employees
Expenses are paid promptly and the online expense tool is easy to use
"LOVE MY JOB but HATE THE COMPANY"
Cons:
CHEAPSKATES on 401k reimbursement and matching contributions.
Health care benefits are extremely poor compared to similar companies like Dell and Brocade.
IBM recognizes same-sex domestic partnerships but NOT opposite-sex domestic partnerships.
IBM has the WORST INTERNAL WEB SITE of any company I've ever worked for.  Need multiple browsers to get work done.
On-boarding of new employees is EXTREMELY POOR
Lotus Notes is MISERABLE TO LEARN AND WORK WITH
The company comes off as not caring about their employees in a million tiny and large ways over time.
The company is penny-wise and pound foolish.

Pros: Technical competence is high, lots of skilled people that understand and perform their job very well.  And, for the most part, everyone works hard and is willing to help each other.
Cons: There are far more planners, project managers,  sales-people and managers than actual 'doers' - that implement the technical plans created by others, an 'inverted pyramid' organization where the majority of the effort is on requirements that cascade downward from on-high to a small number of over-worked, stressed out implementers.

Pros: The technical writing community is an amazing group of people who are willing to help each other. Plus, there are a lot of innovative documentation strategies being worked on.
Cons: It's no secret that IBM hasn't been doing well. As such, more and more people are leaving to take better paying jobs at other companies. As they leave, replacements aren't hired so the workload keeps growing. The stacked ranking system is absolutely ridiculous. After years of losing employees, everyone left is amazing, and to have some people fall to the bottom sure doesn't make people want to do more. Morale is at an all-time low.

Pros: Great people (non-management)! You may get to work with emerging technologies if you are providing support to external customers. Work life balance can be great depending on business unit. Access to some emerging enterprise level technologies.
Cons: Constant staff reductions to drive shareholder value overrides sound business management/operations. Employee morale continues to degrade with each quarterly/monthly staff reduction. Internal tools and technology are rarely updated as most of the support staff have been let go and no capital investment internally due to cost controls. Overall the business is run via spreadsheets despite the availability of industry leading solutions. Salary growth and bonuses are non-existent.

Pros: People, work ethic, solution's promise, end-results value to client's customers.
Cons: Management cares about executive vision and profitability with little regard for workers over-all. To many middle managers seek promotions rather than understanding excellence and talent within their teams. Managers might want to support their employee's productivity desires rather than managing expectations upward...which my colleagues and I are all too aware of.

Pros: Most of the people I work with are wonderful.  Ability to work from home is nice.
Cons: As a contractor you are treated as a second-class employee.  We receive very few benefits - my agency does not provide vacation or paid holidays. We have little to no input on where or for whom you will work, will be moved from one group to another without consult or warning, and can be let go after years of employ with no explanation.  You have absolutely no say in the direction of your career, and attempts to move upward or into a new position are thwarted.

Pros: Great Salary, benefits, *initial training. Work with a lot of very smart and talented people. Lots of flexibility to move to different parts of the company. Very progressive in letting employees work from home.
Cons: Not much of a standardized sales process. If you struggle with ambiguity of lack of direction then it most likely not the place for you. Once your out of training, its sink or swim and as an outside rep you do not get a lot of additional support. Keep in mind IBM is a big company with a sales force of 7,000 strong with 5/6 different business units, so this is not true of the every part of the company just my experience within the business unit I worked in.

Pros: Huge choice of jobs & locations, easy to hide in mid-performance zombieland if you're so inclined.  You'll see their marketing on the TV at the Masters.
Cons: Getting promotions and raises is all about who you know.  All senior management positions go to long-term IBMers with micro-management styles honed in the 1970s.  Newly acquired companies are forced to use existing IBM systems that 100% of the time don't work for the newly acquired businesses.  You really are a number - layoffs are regular and dehumanizing.  Senior management do not care about people at all.

Pros: IBM has plenty of great, talented people with lots of interesting projects.  They have a number of initiatives to push innovation and lots of ways to get involved and stretch yourself.
Cons: IBM is huge.  It's easy to get lost and feel that your work and your product doesn't matter.  Most of the company works on a self serve mode, so to get things done from HR queries to getting access to VMs you need to be able to search and network with other employees.  Keep a resume handy.  IBM is constantly re-inventing itself and layoffs happen every 2-3 years.

Pros: Salary was competitive with the market. I was compensated well and the travel policy was at par with the industry.
Cons:
Old thinking.  I arrived and realized that most of the MEN on the team were in their second or third careers.  There was not a lot of fresh thinking and it was very stale.  I also realized that 85% of the project team had been outsourced to contractors.  Of the 100+ people on the project there were ~15 people who were actual IBM employees.  The rest were 3rd party contractors who had nothing at stake for the organization.

Career Development was none existent.  Coming in from the "outside" meant that I had to try and learn the "IBM way" through trial and error.  There was no one there to guide or mentor me through.

Pros:
-Great 1st line managers
-A few nice staff members (in rare cases)
-Cognitive Computing is somewhat exciting
Cons:
-Bottom feeder team leads
-Personally witnessed sexism, rascism, and favoritism
-Old business practices
-"Agile"focus that ends up being more like a poorly-executed version of Waterfall
-Little room for advancement
-Sales teams affect your team (even if there is a lack of communication between production and sales)

Pros: The ability to work on some cool projects and interact with handful of really smart people who are looking to change the world.
Cons: No support at all! Archaic management systems. Dozens upon dozens of weekly meetings. Constant requests for deal updates (4-5 people per day despite having 5-10 weekly status meetings on one deal). Reports and new strategies to deliver (in GBS) more than one per month for last 18 months. Almost no respect for hours. Expect to work over 80 hours/week and never take a full vacation or sick day. You're lucky if you don't get calls on the 6 major holidays.

Pros:
Competitive salaries.
Plenty of new technologies to learn.
Cons:
If you play their games (blue dollars used on internal tools that don't work but offered by IBM), you'll do great.
Management taught to never make waves for fear of career being hurt.
Too many policies in place now that only help IBM.  401k matching will only be given in December, if you leave earlier, you forfeit any matching contributions.
No matter how long you've worked with IBM, if laid off, you will only be given one month of severance.  Used to be based on years of service.
These are all smart moves for IBM but eventually the employees understand how little they really matter.
If you've worked there over ten years, be careful, you could be laid off only to be replaced by college grads making 40% less.

Pros: If you live in the USA, getting hired on will be tough, since IBM offshores jobs like crazy.   If you live in a strategic location, find a way to get hired, and join a good team, you might enjoy being at IBM.
Cons: IBM has suffered 18 or so quarters of revenue decline, so the company is always "restructuring".  In other words, you will always wonder when you will get laid off (or RAed in IBM terms).  I advise anyone thinking of joining IBM to go elsewhere.  I left IBM voluntarily and it was the best decision of my career.

Pros: I consider myself to be a "graybeard" having been around IBM for 20+ years. Over the course of my career I've learned, delivered and succeeded multiple times for multiple clients. Most importantly, I got to decide exactly what I wanted to do each step of the way. During 2016, I participated with the IBM Corporate Service Corps, deployed to Dakar, Senegal with 14 other practitioners to work on several "pro bono" projects that will pay dividends to the Senegalese people and to IBM. I must say this project stands alone as being a highlight of my IBM career.
Cons: Like any other organization you must deal with a bureaucracy; however, IBM continues to re-make itself and to remain relevant all practitioner's are challenged to do the same, continuously.

Pros: Good middle management, new technical directions are promising, big company can have opportunities if we're willing to relocate. Benefits are good but not great.
Cons: Upper management treats people like interchangeable parts. Highly political environment as you get into senior technical and management areas. Experienced employees regularly laid off in favor of new college hires. Annual layoffs. New policy of no working from home. Poor technical vision from upper management.

Pros: Smart, motivated people up to the mid management level. Work from home makes it nice especially since must of the day is spent on conference calls.
Cons: Six month sales plans and shifting comp strategies with unachievable quotas  make it difficult to make steady commissions worth the intense pressure the company applies. Constant layoffs with ever changing criteria has every employee concerned that they have a target on their back.  Budget cuts have gone so deep that customers are paying the price with reduced support resources and churn.

Pros:
- Flexibility of work hours.
- IBMers are great people to work with.
- It's trying to transform the way we work.
- Career opportunities, you can different roles within the company.
Cons:
- Bureaucratic, too many politics. Too many executives and managers.
- Too many employees with "old" mentality.
- IBM has a big gap in the employees age, and sometimes is hard to push back from a young employee with new ideas to old employees with "this is how we've been doing it..."

Pros: All of my managers have cared about whether I enjoy my job.  They also seek to find out what makes me tick so that they can help me work on projects that mean something to me.
Cons: A lot of redundancies/overlaps in jobs.  The company is so large that there are portions of the company that has no idea that other areas exist.

Pros: The people with who you get to work. Smart, motivated, caring, and passionate about doing the job right.   The term "Respect for the Individual" exists between employees. (see con)
Cons: The motto "Respect for the Employee" WAS a tried and true belief at all levels of the company.  Unfortunately, the company no longer treats its employees with respect.  Resoure Action after Resoure Action killed morale.

Pros: Still some good jobs and opportunities outside of USA.
Cons: High-stress jobs and long hours.  Subject to constant layoffs in USA.  Often drives people into early retirement.  Very few pay increases.  Keeps cutting benefits.  Poor senior management and lack of training of new managers who are often placed over departments in which they have no experience. Best talent often leaves.  Work/life balance can be difficult.  Lack of respect for the individual employee.

Pros: Github, Slack, security and complacency if you're into that kind of thing.
Cons:
Internal tools like email and calendar are impossible to use. Modern companies use Gmail or Exchange.  "Success" is defined by sales revenue, not usability or quality.  VPs are very boring, grandparent-like, and submissive people who don't think outside the box and probably haven't seen much of the world.  Culture is about fitting in and not standing out.

Instead of using good tools like AWS (that most IBM employees want to use), IBM tries to take it on with the IBM Cloud.  Ask a good systems or dev ops engineer what they really think about IBM Cloud.  Don't take on a giant, use them and pivot your business to improve your quality.

Pros:
[1] You get to work with diverse teams and enjoy a great work environment in which everyone feels welcomed.
[2] You will be appreciated for your contributions and your hard work will always be recognized
[3] In addition to offering training for your current role, the company invests in you to set you up for success in your future roles by imparting you transferable skills.
[4] You will be challenged to learn and grow at a pace that is conducive to natural career progression.
[5] You can change your job/role multiple times in your career and stay within the same company you love to work for.
Cons: None that I can think of for now.

Pros: high salary, employee stock purchase plan
Cons: Recently got hired at IBM. I had asked the recruiter to give me details on the medical insurance, but he said he could only provide the premium costs which were very low. I accept the offer and finally get to review the medical insurance... wow, the worst i have seen. Their most comprehensive option has a max out of pocket of $7500 for a single employee. After deductible, you have to pay 20% of any proceedure or ER visit.  I have worked at lots of companies and I can tell you this is not competitive. Not close.

Pros: Telling people that you work for IBM gave me immediate respect for my abilities - regardless of what I said I did.  The benefits were greats
Cons: The division I was worked for had very poor communication.  The change in the operations from inhouse to the global delivery system was done with seemingly little regard for the inhouse personel.  Compensation changes had rules changes every year - regionalizing pay scales, market adjustments for specific job classes and not others - unfortunately, there are people that were not receiving even a cost of living type adjustment thus effectively getting a negative raise.  That doesn't do much for morale.

Pros: Flexibility, work-life balance, strong technical community, ability for an individual to make a difference (for a large organization!) Good salary and benefits (grass isn't greener when you check out other companies). Also, you can have a long, interesting career at IBM by moving around to different divisions, specializing in industries, etc. if you want change (I've been here 10+ years and never thought I would last that long).
Cons: A VERY large organization that can be overwhelming when you are new. Some of the senior management seems clueless and you have to wonder how they got to where they are (must be related to someone at the top!)  I think IBM does a good job of recognizing top performers.  Average performers are usually the ones that make the most noise, at least in my division.

Pros: Variety of job possibilities; positions available worldwide; fairly stable; low expectations; average compensation
Cons: Lack of "cool" products; loads of bureaucracy; impersonal; pay is not concomitant with effort; you work for a law firm, not a software company (#1 in patents for years has led to a very litigious corporation); carebear corporate culture that promotes based on externally-recognizable characteristics instead of merits

Pros: Decent and comprehensive set of benefits. Ability to interact and network with bright people.  A robust infrastructure for access to employee benefit and technical information.
Cons: Annual resource actions by stealth that lop off 10% - even solid and above average performers - is demoralizing.  Minuscule or no salary increases. Far too much political correctness required for advancement.  I have over 20 years with IBM and moral is the lowest I have ever seen it.  People are in fear of keeping their job and therefore reluctant to stretch into a new assignments for fear of being the low person on the totem pole when the next RA hits.

Pros: In most instances, IBM allows employees to work at home which has been a blessing.  The other benefits (health, dental, and vision) are among the best I have seen.
Cons: They will work you to the bone for months on end with no real recognition for it.  For being the largest computer company on the planet, they have internal systems that can frustrate the hell out of you.  IBM's first principle used to be Respect for the Individual, no more.  You won't find that statement anywhere within IBM.

Pros: none that I can think of. IBM has an attitude of wanting more for less. The ONLY people who matter are the shareholders, employees are treated badly and expected to give their total commitment to a company that will suck you dry and then throw you aweay when you cannot keep up with the pressures of the work. The ONLY good thing abuot the company is that the insurance package is good compared to some other companies, but even that is being whilttled away year by year. Equipment for actually doing the job is limited and of incinsistent quality, I even had to buy my own monitor as the company refused to allow one as thehy did not feel it was required for me to actually do productive work!!!
Cons: long hours, bad conditions, more work for less attitude from management

Pros: Name recognition, access to a ton of free Computer Based Training to improve skills (for your next job), good medical benefits for employee (expensive for family)
Cons: Utilization targets to meet minimum review ratings require all PTO, holidays, and all other non-billable time to be made up with overtime.  Endless layoffs of Americans to ship jobs overseas.  Heavy time demand as you work full time at customer site plus any OT they will allow, plus 5 hours a week to follow IBM documentation processes.  You may never physically meet the manger responsible for you reviews, only your project manager.  High turnover in recent years.

Pros:
Work at home is great.
Benefits are good
I thought I would have more Pros, but there aren't any left.
Cons:
Very long hours - easily work 11-12 hour days and still far behind in work
Most work in my area moved to Brazil
No time for education
Constant threat of layoffs...every quarter.  I'm just hoping I get it next and get it out of the way.  I've probably skirted 8-10 of them already.
Used to perform real analytical work, now we just comply to business controls, perform the minimal work necessary and that's it.  No innovation or ...no time for it

Pros:
Working from home.

The System x Technical sales group is by far the best technical sales team out there. Sadly, I don't think that's going to be true much longer. I have heard that IBM SE's aren't that great, but I think that's true for the other brands, not x86. The x86 SE's at IBM are top-notch.
Cons: Just about everything at this point. IBM was getting to be a terrible place to work about 3 years ago. Now it's unbearable. Almost everyone I know wants to leave.

Pros:
The opportunities to learn are endless. 
Many wonderful people. 
IBM has terrific brand recognition. 
Great benefits. 
Work from anywhere helps work / life balance.
Cons:
Sales teams chasing an arbitrary quota where you may only have control over certain aspects of compensation (i.e. ability to influence revenue but not profit). 
Increasingly more internal meetings & inspection...very inwardly focused. 
Extremely conservative from a contracting and legal standpoint.
Complexity in navigating the internal process. 
Competing against your own company in some cases.

Pros:
Good starting salary (don't expect much if any increases once you start)
Good opportunity to grow skills
People are friendly and great to work with but are depressed and want to leave
Cons: Many of us joke that working for IBM in the US is like living in a third world country.  No free water, coffee, not even utensils!  We have to buy our own whiteboard markers and batteries due to the extreme penny pinching. The long hour demands are insane, deadlines are unrealistic, morale is terrible and it just keeps getting worse and worse.  They even took away work from home flexibility.  Average breakroom conversation is wanting to leave IBM and how run down and crappy it is.  I started as a new college grad not that long ago and the whole group that started as new grads is already gone.

Pros:
Stable company
Good medical benefits
Depending on projects - excellent work-life balance
Work from home
Nice coworkers
Cons:
Not so exciting projects 80% of the time
Some people can just coast by without putting in any effort and goes unnoticed 
Non-existent raises (if you're a high performer you can get 1%, that's lower than inflation adjustment, if you're a mediocre performer you get nada)
Limited room to learn and grow skill-set
Out-dated software - some people still use windows XP and MS Office 2002, really!?
You get good amount of vacation days but you can never use them because taking one week off will take 2% off your total utilization

Pros: The people are nice, and its a world wide company with a good reputation.
Cons: Pay was below average for what I did.  The HW engineering side was obviously never growing and therefore full of the same people doing the same position for a very long time.  AKA if you expect to move up you had to wait for someone to retire (or get laid off).  The business strategy is good but at a determent (shrinking) to HW engineering.  You had to compete with people who should have been advising you for any attention with your upper management.

Pros: IBM is a huge bureaucracy.  There are a few excellent, highly skilled and motivated employees, but also a huge overhang of non-productive, incapable middle management types.  IBM goes through constant layoffs, but instead of cutting the deadwood in middle management, they workers.  2/3rds of middle managers could be removed with no noticeable impact, other than an improvement in the bottom line.
Cons: The sales process is chaotic with no coordination across business areas.  Layers upon layers of middle management making presentations to each other.  Middle management has no understanding of what the products that are being sold actually do and no contact at all with customers.  Ridiculously difficult to get anything done.  IBM is notorious for "stacking", ie. having multiple parallel organizations selling the same solution to a single customer.

Pros: IBM is great for people with families. There is a lot of flexibility in your hours and when/where you work. You'll find some very smart people here, and I do have to say, most of my closest friends are from IBM, because they are just that nice. There's some flexibility in moving around the company and trying different roles.
Cons: Everything here, salary/bonus, promotions are generally just a numbers game, whatever is available in the pool. Employees feel under appreciated. No more real perks like free coffee. Salary is more likely on the low end.

Pros:
Excellent pool of employees. I worked with a great set of colleagues with strong skills who were always willing to assist
Good cooperative development teams and product portfolio.
Good sales resources (competitive analysises etc)
Cons: Very weak management team, particularly at the executive levels. Sales quota appear to random and can not be explained. If you are given certain territories you will make your quota without doing any work (literally). If you are not so blessed, you will have a very difficult time. Management does not differentiate between sales people who walk into large deals vs ones who fight tooth and nail to win small ones. Expect to have your territory changed every year.

Pros: If you like large companies with lot of processes IBM is for you.  Depending on the department you'll get to work with some of the coolest and newest technologies. If you work for one of their cash flow businesses that support all the new research it's a good Job.
Cons: Down turn in hardware sales across the company impacted all employee's compensation.  Even though on the the software side there was great growth. Lots of processes that require lots of people to complete.  buying a box of pencils takes way too much energy and time.

Pros: The work-life balance is great. The focus is on the work being done and not the arbitrary amount of hours that you need to spend in the office, so if you get all of your work done then you can go home. Keep in mind that I am doing a full-time internship and can only speak form that perspective.
Cons: The cubicles aren't necessary. There is not really a collaborative atmosphere at least for my project. People seem to be segregates. There needs to be more introduction across the teams to make the work atmosphere social and friendly.

Pros: IBM has allowed me to have many unique roles in my 20+ years here.  I've been able to gain skills and work with some of the most amazing people in the industry.  IBM is a wonderfully broad and flexible company. I have more flexibility in working from home and flex hours than all of my friends at other companies.
Cons: Sometimes IBM can be it's own worst enemy.  Lots of reorgs and realignments. Can be unsettling at times.

Pros: You can make good money if you work 14 hrs a day and meet your objectives
Cons: After 15 years at IBM, just before my 60th birthday and eligible for full retirement benefits, I was part of a 50,000 u.s. employee layoff. I actually had grounds to sue, but who has the means to sue big blue.

Pros: I worked with the Windows Services Support Team, Specifically the group administering Microsoft SCCM for multiple clients of IBM.  My team manager was excellent. Communicated expectations and goals clearly and was always very supportive.  The clients site leads I worked with the exception of one individual were always professional, highly skilled, easy to discuss client challenges with, and always willing to provide focused and pertinent advice.
Cons: The primary negative was the one most large organizations face.  The creation of a morass of mechanisms to execute the simplest tasks

Pros: IBM is a wonderful company, they have generous salaries, good self-directed training, and a good corporate culture. Their Summit Program is quite nice and I graduated from it with a good sense of sales.
Cons: Company is too big to get out of it's own way sometimes. I was disappointed in the lack of support I got in sales from senior members of my team when I asked for help, even though I offered to assist them with their grunt work.  They move their sales force around too frequently for them to get traction with their accounts. After the initial training reps need to self-direct their training and it can be monotonous.

Pros: Good Health Care Benefits package options. Generous 401K contributions from the Company.  Stock Purchase plan available. Leading edge Technology company that is making a difference in the world, which you can actually see and read about.
Cons: Global workforce, which means you might not ever meet your manager or other members on your team, which means you would need to set up a scheduled call just to talk.   Not enough focus on educating the employees for the job they need to perform.

Pros: In this position there is  an opportunity to work with a cross section of dynamic technical, management and executive resources.  The ability to work remotely is a benefit and most effectively  when permitted,  especially since most managed resources are also remote.
Cons: The constant 24x7 on-call matrix  is often draining with little to no regard to  salaried personnel work hours, work/life balance or well-being. Poorly assessed business continuity requirements, transition analysis and contract over commitment  on out-sourced contracts result in crit sit accounts, dissatisfied customers, over extended budgets, eventual  reduction of needed resources  and personnel burn out.

Pros: A very diverse environment to work in, in terms of technical backgrounds. You can learn from senior researchers with decades of experience in the physical sciences, computing systems, computer science, quantum computing.
Cons: Over the last 3 years there have been constant changes to the upper management. Research requires a longer term view, commitment, and institutional memory. Much of this is falling away I am afraid, which will affect the ability of IBM Research to have an impact upon the 5-10 year and beyond horizon of IBM’s business.

Pros:
Lots of jobs across all the projects
MacBook Pro laptops
Cons:
Hyper focus on stock price
No raises even for cost of living unless you're rating is a "1" yet money spent on stock buy-backs
Band promotions come with escalating "give back" review requirements outstripping pay increases
Facility conditions are poor and outdated.  I'm usually embarrased to bring people on campus.
Facility "renovations" strip you to a 4' work table in an open area. with no privacy and no work areas. And overnight only lockers.
Poor work life balance unless a baseline review and no raise is acceptable to you
Health insurance is costly and restrictive on medications

Pros:
-Opportunity - So much opportunity to do more than just your job, passion projects, giveback to community, working with schools, internal groups, external groups.  My development job at IBM is a very small amount of the work I do, I do more for IBM outside of my lab/office just in the external giveback and working with outside organizations and groups.
-Work Life Balance - I think it's termed "integration" now, which i prefer, I've raised three kids here, it's never a perfect balance but that's ideal, because I get time to work when I need it but also time to drop kids off at school, go to kids sports/games, and help with homework.  I do work a lot, but it's driven by me.  There's tons of projects and things I do when the kids go to sleep or on a quiet evening because I love to do this stuff, and that's just me. 
-Community outreach- there's a huge sense of giveback at IBM.  IBM has a portal for registering volunteering and giveback and gives grants to organizations you work with.  IBM encourages and gives us a lot of autonomy on this so there's no real limit to how much you can work outside of IBM giving back to community as long as it doesn't interfere with your business commitments, and they will provide computing/tech resources/educational kits to help support it.
-Mentoring/networking-the most underated feature of IBM is mentoring, as a senior engineer  we're encouraged to be mentors to junior engineers, and while it's not required, it's extremely helpful to have a mentor, it's allowed me to navigate and plan my career progression based on their advice and experience.  Because you're in charge of your career the mentoring is the perfect amount of coaching and self-accountability that I need to stay motivated and on track in my career goals.
-People- People are awesome, I've worked with many people who work tirelessly with time they don't have to help me, or other people, to work with high school groups, to help people they don't even know within IBM who need help.  The part that makes IBM culture and values amazing is every single person you meet who is a living embodiment to them.
-Overall - The thing I love about IBM is that there's so much to do, I'm never bored, and always feel like I have an impact, but most importantly I feel like my impact is greater outside the company, and helping make the world better by being me and defining how I can give back to my community and help others. Is the pay comparable to the other big companies trying to recruit me?  No, but like Kingpin said "It's not always about the money Spider-Man"
Cons:
-Big-, IBM is B-I-G, so there's no list of steps for things like career progression, establishing internal support groups (like a gaming group for example), how to establish a community outreach event, etc. and that's mostly because no one defines what/how you do any of that, and really the way it's done is different for everyone so it's really up to you to figure out how to do all that. 
-Money - They pay well, is it great?  Not compared to the giants like Facebook, netflix, or Google, I've talked to those companies just to know what a move would look like and the money difference can be quite big if that's your motivation.
-Getting things done- I'm not sure I would do anything different for this given IBM's size, but IBM has a much more organic approach to starting things, getting things done, innovating side projects and community outreach etc, where you can start groups and projects you're passionate about, but you have to gather the support for it, you can get support and funding, but you have to originate the idea and figure out how to make it work and do the leg work for it, which is great if you're a type A personality and passionate about something.  But also means you become the project manager, recruiter, and communications person for your particular cause so its easy to take on too much at times.

Pros: Very talented and smart people , amazing  collection of technologies , ocean of opportunity to learn technology  , great culture and work is more of fun if you live technical challenges
Cons:
New York Armonk oldies and CFO killing the company , Imagine they were able to frustrate Warren Buffet who dumped IBM stocks ...IBM execs are more focused on stock buyback and financial engineering to manipulate quarterly results  then actually giving control to new generation of smart folks .  
  Ginni and her gang would drown this company soon ...they need to leave with all millionaire execs sitting in New York and some smart young executive from outside IBM need to come in to change the top management layer .

Pros: Lots of smart people to work with, top notch in their technical skills.  Working on latest technologies makes getting up in the morning to go to work a worthwhile endeavor.
Cons: Overall treatment of employees needs to be improved.  We are certainly not "interchangeable parts."  Lack of pay raises because one has reached "50%" of market penetration is a joke - one wonders who they survey to reach that conclusion.

Pros: There is room to grow and many resources to learn from and take advantage of. There are opportunities to work from home or remotely; however, those opportunities can sometimes be difficult to find and acquire. Benefits, job security, and resources are the biggest reasons to work for IBM.
Cons: Typical "big company" politics and game playing regarding promotions, ratings, salaries, etc. Multiple managers and numerous "admin" tasks and policies are sometimes cumbersome. Depending on the employee's specific organization, there can be a high travel requirement for those workers who may not want to travel.

Pros: They'll hire just about anyone who has the word "Java" on their resume. Fairly laid back atmosphere. Great for a first job out of college. Chance to get real industry experience with fortune 500 companies. Great benefits on day 1.
Cons: Lowest salaries in the field. Overtime exempt. Clients can be downright abusive (in terms of work/life balance) and give impossible deadlines. I know people who have been flown to a client site and worked 10+ hour days every day for a month, and only got to fly back for a day and a half to see their families.

Pros: Despite attrition in recent years, still has very deep technical staff.  One of the greatest assets the company has is its people.  Its amazing the work that can be done if you know how to navigate the organization....once you master this skill, the sky is the limit.
Cons: On the hardware side, its not clear what the vision is for the company.  As software and services are the financial engines for the company, I think we've lost sight of how hardware fits into the equation.  Also, when the chips are down, there are some really bright people that have come up with unbelievable tactical ideas that have helped us....lets leverage those people more on an everyday basis.

Pros: Decent salaries, decent benefits, great co-workers and everyone takes care of business.
Cons: Executive management seems to have no clue.  Blindly cutting folks that are needed just to make their numbers look good.

Pros: The employees are all smart and dependable. The company is efficiently run (at least in my department) and I learn a lot about efficiently managing and working in large software projects.
Cons: The workplace is very competitive and not very rewarding. You complete against your peers for paltry raises. The amount of cost cutting is very concerning and many people are worried about layoffs. Everyone I work with has been been working on the same pieces of the same software project for over a decade.

Pros: Some really smart and talented people who go way above and beyond under difficult circumstances to meet stated objectives.
Cons: Knows they have some great people so uses them until they are driven off or ground to dust.  Relies too much on the name brand and past glories.  Shadow of the company it used to be.

Pros: Great people, very bright and lots of R&D.  Health and 401K are very good, except that they moved to giving the company match only at the end of the year - so either you stay and get it or you loose it. You also loose the benefit of investing through the year instead of one day. Flexibility is great and IBM knows how to get work done, irrespective of where you are (home, beach, office).
Cons: Employees are not given good incentives and growth opportunities are not even. Too much work for very little monetary rewards. Some have been lucky to be in positions that have great rewards.

Pros:
I am a part of the Summit program, which is consistently ranked as one of the top training programs in the country. IBM invests a significant amount of time and money into developing young professionals, which is not very common these days. 
Work-life balance is very good. Employees are able to work from home. I go into the office 3 days a week and work from home the rest. 
Women hold a large portion of senior leadership positions, and support for women is standard practice.
Cons:
Bureaucracy of a large company and the time it takes to include all the right people. 
Some silos that make communication between business units uncommon.

Pros: IBM has a rich array of software offerings addressing many industries and their associated business pains.  The rich technologies come from the organic and acquired genius of technologists from around the world.
Cons: The organization of the business is a mess.  Very talented individual contributors are being sacrificed while tens of thousands of VPs and GMs hold onto their jobs and lofty salaries but aren't adding value in solving current day partnership concerns in the age of Cloud and SaaS for the digital marketplace.

Pros: Excellent support for personal issues like appointments, childcare related time off, etc.  Reall good leadership development, incredible smart and talented peers, Latest technology innovation like AI, fantastic benefits package.
Cons: Not specifically a con, but more a data point, being a large company, the work culture depends on the division you are in.

Pros: There are a lot of really smart people you can work with and a lot of opportunity to travel and learn. You can be well compensated if you have the right accounts and compensation plan.
Cons: They are constantly trying to adapt which means new managers, new accounts, and quotas made from thin air. Many IBMers feel like there is a target on their back with all the layoffs and job security is almost non-existent.

Pros: For someone like me - extremely dedicated to my job, hard-working, always going the extra mile - IBM has been a great place to work. IBM is a high performing company and expects its employees to be high-performing as well. I have had very little issues acclimating myself into the IBM culture. The salary is competitive and the benefits are excellent. And with such a large and diverse company, the opportunities for growth and for branching out into different technologies/markets are great.
Cons: If you are someone who wants to do the minimum... who watches the clock for that eight-hour mark so you can sprint out the door... who does not want to be in a competitive and high performing environment... IBM is probably not the place for you.

Pros: The company has good values and managed by policies. Looks for the next game changing or technology for the future. Lots of patents and RnD.
Cons: IBM uses GBS and GBS-GD centers across the world to bring in the technology services for the low cost, and use these resources at client locations. The salaries of the on-site consultants placed by IBM India Pvt Ltd are very low, and with no bonus nor increments, 401K.  The company has a stringent policies with respect to resignation and has 3 month notice periods.  Also, they hold up the experience and relieving letters, if you do not pay the 90 day notice period obligation which is $10,000. No value for loyal employees

Pros: Simply put, I work at IBM because of the great people and the broad career opportunities -- along with additional opportunities to make a difference.  One that stands out to me is Pathways in Technology (P-Tech), a wonderful mentorship program that I've been involved with for 3 years.    I enjoy making a positive impact on public education, and IBM has offered me a great way to contribute.  New collar jobs are critical to our future success, and I'm confident that my P-Tech mentee will one day be a star!
Cons: Long hours at times, given global working relationship and dependencies in our business

Pros: Without a doubt the best part of the job is the people. Brilliant, collaborative, and open to new ideas, they spur lots of opportunities for employees that aggressively seek advancement. And I'm particularly impressed and proud to call myself an IBMer because of their leadership in diversity, inclusion and patent leadership. I'm bullish about IBM's future and the powerful ways we can help our clients and their clients build smarter businesses.
Cons: At 380k people, this business is not for those who can't operate in a matrixed environment. It's best suited for networkers who thrive on the size instead of getting lost in it.

Pros: Global Sales School was incredible. I learned so much and developed my communication skills in a way that has helped me in every aspect of life. IBM really does put a lot of effort into eduction and providing resources.
Cons: The whole company is a massive mess. No one knows who reports to who and who owns what account. No one wants to take responsibility to anything so everything, including yourself and your career, gets passed around like its a hot potato. Definitely a company that looks at you as just a number and the politics is ridiculous.

Pros: Big company where it’s easy to hide / be lost if that is your desire (not mine).  Interesting projects for some, resources are available on priority projects
Cons:
Management spreads resources too thin with too many projects approved and not enough resources per project

Despite name no amazing AI brought to market 

No bonus for years

Poor morale

Layoffs

Pros: Large company with many business units means you can expand your skills and grow your career without leaving the company. Strong emphasis on learning and many internal resources to build skills. Positive stances on important issues facing the country (e.g., diversity)
Cons: Large company with many business units can sometimes mean too much bureaucracy, too much reporting, and groups working within their own silos instead of collaborating. There are some amazing, smart people... but there are also many who have risen up the ranks but don't add value. It's frustrating to encounter those people. Despite the positive stances on important social issues, I'm not always convinced they practice what they preach. Layoffs every year are inevitable and no one is immune.

Pros:
Good Vacation/Holiday per year
Decent Medical
Excellent Paternity/Maternity
Cons:
Interdepartmental Communication lacking
Salary is lower than same positions at other companies (in some cases by a significant amount)
Retention of skills employees is lacking due to culture of "we can just get someone else"
Large amounts of funds wasted on pet projects of executives and midline managers, cost cuts to compensate coming from inadequate hiring to maintain staffing levels (and staffing quality)
Recurring yearly layoffs make long term job security questionable.

Pros: Excellent training and education programs, opportunities for advancement, diversity, a culture of volunteerism. Some great products to contribute to and work on.
Cons: Big Company Problems. The organization is so large that it is easy to get lost in the shuffle. Similarly, it's difficult for top leadership to recognize the rot within as long as revenue keeps rolling in. Inept and toxic leaders can thrive if they have an effective line of b.s. and a good sales team bringing in new accounts.

Pros: Very few. I was a 31 year employee and have watched as the current management has taken  what was one of the best companies in the world and reduced to an "also ran". Senior management has been in "react mode" for so long that they think long range planning is what's for lunch tomorrow. The work force has been so reduced that we were all forced to work 15-25% uncompensated overtime and still the layoffs continued. They company no longer cares about it's customers or employees, just how much upper management can steal from the company. Most of us long term employees lost over 50% of our retirement in 1999 when "Three-Fingered Lou" needed some more money.
Cons: Long hours, low pay, no job security, no respect for workers.

Pros: Resources are limited so you get to wear many hats.  You have the ability to move to different organizations if you have the required skillsets.
Cons: Gradual replacement of on-shore with off-shore resources.  Cost and and number of billable hours appears to be their number concern.  Your job can be eliminated at any time if they no longer need you or you become an expense to the company.  There are a few unfair practices that I've seen while I was working at IBM, such as deferral of vacation to boost their productivity ratio, reduction of base salaries by 15%,  reclassification to lower band.  Management is not always supportive.  On the average, you have the find another position every 2 years.

Pros:
Whilst promotion is often terrible if you stay in the same job group, IBM is such a large company that there is always an opportunity to move elsewhere if you're prepared to step out of the 'comfort zone'
The support from your colleagues and team members is usually excellent and wherever possible there is a great deal of flexibility in hours and locations worked.
Cons: Its a large company... The same thing that makes for a wide range of job options has also meant that the company is suffering from excessive red tape and is frequently far too process led.

Pros: The rang of opportunities is very high. A lot of very talented people work here. While not always easy to find, there are projects that are on the bleeding edge of technology.
Cons: High barrier to ship projects; a lot of non-functional requirements to keep in mind (globalization, accessibility, etc.) that detract from interesting work. Hard to be promoted if in a top-heavy organization with a lot of senior engineers.

Pros: There's ample opportunity to work on cutting edge stuff.   Anyone who enjoys systems programming and is good at it will have a job at IBM.
Cons:
- The belts in the company are extremely tight right now.  Despite record profits, IBM is not investing the money in their employees.
- Getting your job outsourced is a constant fear.
- attempting to complete any task is a constant battle.  The bureaucracy at IBM is worse than its reputation.

Pros:
Good Pay, some flexibility... really depends if you work in Hardware or Software. 
Payscale is good compared to other companies at least in Austin
Cons:
off shoring, complex management system. Likes to make everything single thing way too complicated. 
Management does not value employee loyalty and experience... if they don't need you, then you are out. 
management keeps changing often. Its hard to focus when you management keeps on re organizing every 4  - 6 months. 
By the time you get comfortable working with one manager, you have another manager and his style to adapt to. 
Employee morale is also low because of this.

Pros: Working at IBM there were many opportunities to learn new technologies and a wide range of jobs available if interested in moving about the company.  HR and corporate IT were competent and professional.  Managers were typically well trained in their roles (e.g. strong focus on communication and coaching).  Coworkers were usually sane, intelligent and amiable.
Cons:
The business focus was driven entirely quarterly.  Very bad vibe coming from middle-management (who didn't care about their professional employees).  The atmosphere felt cold and chronically stressed-out.  Upper management was aggressive about rolling back employee compensation (e.g., shifting focus toward younger, shorter-term employees that can work insane amounts and burn out).  Easy to become pigeonholed in a bad role/division (managers can block you from seeking different jobs within the company... and do exercise the right during horrible projects or in bad teams -- most of which are).

Feedback/ratings were based more on gaming the system than actual employee contribution (i.e. to limit bonuses/raises there can be only one, maybe two, excellently rated employees in your team; the rest have to be average).

Most importantly, moving up in terms of leadership is only a doorway into some weird political arena where you are more responsible for gaming the arbitrary metrics defining success than in actual accomplishment -- i.e., you do whatever it takes to affect some meaningless improvement in a spreadsheet.

It's an OK place, but don't stay too long or it will rob you of the skills needed to survive outside the company.  Lots of people in their late 20's talk about their big ideas outside the company, but get comfortable and never go anywhere.  But the company is ruthless now so realize from the day you join your days are numbers (so always keep exit doors open so when the time comes it's for the betterment of your career rather than for the sake of whether your division exceeds or underperforms its quarterly target by one percent).

Pros: IBM had a good name years ago, one of the top innovators.  If one focuses on learning there is a lot of potential to learn many aspects of the business.  There is potential to excel in one's job if you keep your focus.
Cons: Too big so that some managers are apparently either not competent and not trained to bring out the best in themselves and others.  It appears innovation is not rewarded enough.   Not just technological innovation, but innovation in how to run a business in order to make the truly company indespensible because customers will always expect the best, next great thing.

Pros: There are opportunities to work on exciting projects and learn how a large company works.  The benefits are good (not great).  With the right manager, you can have a good work-life balance.
Cons: Executive management does not communicate truthfully about layoffs or pretty much anything dealing with employees.  They have basically been lying about the current layoffs.  Of course, they layoff staff but very few managers.  They purport to hire only the best, but then they have no problem giving ranking based on an arbitrary distribution.  Which in turn does not make employees feel very valued.  Benefits have slowly been reduced over the years; waiting for that to happen again.

Pros: Wide array of projects. Experts on almost any subject are available and helpful. IBM has a reputation for excellent which lends automatic respect to any outside contacts.
Cons: Constant reorganizations and layoffs.  Organization is intended to protect senior managers turf, not promote efficiency.  Respect for IBM is largely based on IBM's past behavior when product excellence was encouraged and employees were encouraged to develop deep expertise in subjects.  Current IBM strategy is to minimize cost and produce mediocre products that are "good enough."  Technical expertise is not valued by management. Successful IBMers learn to ride the wave of popular technology while doing little concrete work.

Pros: Great benefits for all.  The pay is also quite good.  The name will really open a lot of doors for you down the line.  They also offer great training opportunities for all employees to join in on.
Cons: No such thing as a 40 hour week. they expect much more of a time commitment from their employees though which is a bit unfair in my opinion.  Also there is no real office.  So many people work from home so it is tough to meet coworkers.  Theres no real office christmas party and things like that, youre kind of on your own.

Pros: Good people to work with and the work can be interesting.
Cons: There is never enough time or people to do the work we're given.  There is very high pressure to get any problem resolved immediately.  Nights and weekend work is common, without compensation.  There is little recognition for doing a job well the first time.  But if you make a mistake and then correct it, then people notice that you fixed something, even though you were to the one to break it to begin with.  As in many places, those that talk the loudest are those that advance, even if what they are so loudly talking about is nonsense.

Pros: Solid company with a good reputation.  Good benefits including 401k with company match, medical, vision, dental, etc..  Training is generally available but needs to be completed on line.  On site training opportunities are rare and limited due to funding issues.
Cons: Work life balance is challenging.  Resource actions are becoming more numerous.  Too much focus on the cutting costs at the expense of jobs in the US.  Global resourcing can result in significant positive impact to the companies bottom line, but for the most part the quality of services provided suffers and results in poor customer satisfaction and a loss of revenue.

Pros:
wealth of knowledge and decent products
Many different jobs to gain experience and build a resume
Cons: Only a selected very political few will ever rise to the upper echelons of IBM where you can make decent money.  IBM executives are not sole selected based off of skill and talent.  How well you play the game will determine you potential as an executive.

Pros: Its part of a historic company who's values have been treasured by employees for years. Working for such a diverse company with the benefits it provides makes you recognize the historic support of its employee value proposition.
Cons: IBM has lost its way, with IGS leading its demise, by ignoring customer value and destroying employee morale. IBM believe that billing is more important that the clients needs, and has become a factory of poor skills that clients end up replacing weekly.

Pros:
Available opportunities to contribute and lead on your individual project, if you seek them

Very bright and competent colleagues who really roll up their sleeves to get the job done
Cons:
If you are too good, you may end up stuck on the same project for years.  While your specialization in a subject matter area may deepen, your opportunities to go to other projects becomes severely limited.

Your salary may trickle.

Pros: Good brand to keep you afloat in bad economy. Not sure IBMer meanes anything with 400K emplyees.
Cons:
Its a Jungle inside. everything is virtual. Like a website.
Partners are Gods. very unapproachable.
100% of GBS is travel based. travel/expense policy sucks. IBMers have lost thier class. Sole aim make wealthy share holder happy. 
With 95% utilization requirement, only thing you can take is 3 days and federal/state holidays.
extremely limited salary increase. Promotion means nothing with limited salary increase.

Pros:
The stability of my particular job and some of the people I have been able to work with are the best parts of working for IBM.  It's also relatively easy to look for other job opportunities within IBM before they go to external hiring.

The benefits (salary, health, retirement) are basic but actually quite good, IMO.  I'm not sure about the salary part, but my health and retirement benefits are good, including retirement matching (up to 5% of my salary) plus an additional 1%.
Cons: I'm not sure the salary is as competitive as it could be.  It seems other newer companies pay more for their engineers.

Pros: smart people, many of whom do care about relationships and doing the right thing for the client
Cons: It's a financially driven organization and we are absolutely feeling the pain of not growing the top line;  They compensate by squeezing more costs out (our salaries) to grow the bottom line;  many of my peers have had salary roll backs in the last many years as sales objectives are nearly impossible to make......

Pros: it offers you a challenge environment; if you are self motivate and love the challenge to figure things out yourselves, this is a good fit for you.
Cons: The morale is at all time low with the delay 401k contribution to 12/15 every year. It is a increasing competitive at the top so they find way to ask you work more and more hours ON THE WEEK END under different initiative like Innotivative Summit, Talk40. I guess this is find if you don't already put in 50 or even 60 hours a week like I do.

Pros:
Great health care  benefits
Many committed employees
Opportunity to work in many facets of IT industry
Pension check for those who were fortunate enough to be in the plan
Cons:
Requirement to work 60+ hours weekly 
Target employees for resource action ( firing)  once they turn 50  reardless of performance, and contribution to the business..
Too many layers of executive management and the executive perks are bordering on criminal 
Latest 401K modification (paid only once a year so if they RA you 1 day prior to the annual payment day you get no IBM matching)   
HR focused 
In the future I expect IBM will default on the pension plan

Pros: I enjoyed/respected the amount of trust placed in me.  I felt very empowered to do whatever was necessary to get the job done.  The people I worked with were the some the best, most knowledgeable folks I have worked with in my life.
Cons: I specific group I worked in handled Lenovo service.  Like any other company working in service in the USA, it felt the pinch of the global economy and the VERY thin margins in that business.  My job was one of 5000 that were eliminated in a round of down-sizing.

Pros:
There are many people with very good technical skills in the company, and a strong work ethic.  Having been with the company for a long time, in my opinion there is no longer "dead weight" in contrast to 20 years ago when there were still employees with mentality that IBM was a place of lifetime employment regardless of contribution level.  

The career opportunities are especially good for new entrants into the company (college hires).
Cons:
The company is trying to execute on new strategies which is both exciting and stressful - the legacy businesses are still critical to maintain which stretches resources thin.  

There are a lot of experienced and hardworking employees with limited opportunities.

Pros:
amazing work life balance
people are kind, smart, and generally very collaborative
marketing jobs allow for creativity & autonomy - you define your own role
work when i want, where i want - and the Austin office is one of the best IBM sites
it's exciting to be a part of a huge corporation's transformation
opportunities to learn & travel
Cons:
one word: hi- er-arch-ic-al
executives and directors aren't questioned or challenged enough
as a new employee, remote working can become isolating & impersonal
budget is incredibly tight
unclear path to advancement + promotion for new University hires

Pros: Some of the industry's greatest talents and professional managers work here, solving some of the world's most interesting challenges. Client success and integrity are paramount. Brand carries incredible industry respect, allowing you to work on amazing projects. Talented people can have 5-10 different rewarding roles during their time here.
Cons: Strategy makes sense though transition from where IBM was to where IBM is going is not easy. Brand is viewed as tired by many. Bringing on more outside senior talent is a welcome change to sometimes insular Somers/Armonk centricity. Company's investment in developing employees also makes them good candidates to be poached.

Pros: The pros are that you receive a lot of training and there are a lot of advancement opportunities.   I had wonderful teams and managers in my time there.  Although my experience at IBM was mostly great, it has changed tremendously in the last 5 years.  It's a very different company.
Cons: The majority of the people there are wonderful to work with and for but mid level management doesn't have a lot of control over what happens with their employees.  A lot of people work in fear of being laid off.  Employees are expected to work long, stressful hours and they do so because no one is safe from me let go. IBM'ers are very loyal and should be treated better.

Pros: IBM has great, smart people and very meaningful work.  IBM as a corporation wants to change the world, and because of that takes on bold challenges.  There is an amazing depth of skills across the company, and for self-starters, you can constantly learn about the new technologies and capabilities that IBM has to offer.
Cons: Because the size is big, and it is hard to turn a big ship, it can be a difficult place to Transform quickly.  The workload can be significant, so a person needs to manage his or her work/life balance effectively.

Pros:
Cutting-edge technology alongside products that still support software from the 1960s.
Competitive levels of pay and good choice of benefits programs (in USA at least).
High expectations from customers and coworkers.
Opportunities for challenging work, supporting largest customers in world.
Strong focus on building out cloud, cognitive (AI) and devops focused products and capabilities.
Cons:
Waves of lay-offs across the company regular occurrences.
Past job performance no predictor of being targeted by a lay-off.
Moving away from supporting remote teams, home/remote working.
Off-shoring work is a reality.
Can manage own career but much depends on skill/quality of your immediate manager.

Pros: IBM brings together an amazing array of technology as the basis of real, practical solutions  that power Earth's commerce.  Some people still think of IBM as "that mainframe company", but today's IBM has been transformed into an agile, leading edge technology creator.  As an IBMer, it is amazing to be able to pick up the phone and chat with the very people who are creating and shaping tomorrow.  Blockchain, quantum computing, cognitive computing, and countless other technologies are real-world here.  Yes, we still sell some big iron; but (surprise!) it runs Linux!
Cons: No way to hide it -- IBM is a big enterprise, with nearly a half million employees around the world.  It isn't a startup!

Pros: Large company who is trying to provide services it hadn't before and strives to innovate.
Cons: In my experience IBM turned out to be worse than all of the worst things you've ever read about the company,  and that is pretty bad considering the volume of terrible things that are written. The work they acquired from PepsiCo was managed incredibly sloppy, they did not seem to care about their people at all and over time proved to be bold faced liars. The executive team and company had no interest in trying to learn the work before making assurances they could not, and did not deliver. I would be shocked if Pepsi continued to do business with them and renewed the contract here in a couple of years.  Overall my experience after 3 years was that the company was sloppy, careless, and remarkably arrogant.

Pros: If you have very little experience and want to get a job where they will train you. This is the perfect fit.  Lots of training options/certifications available.
Cons: Salary is well below industry average. But if you go in just to get the experience it's worth it.  Did not like the "contract-like" setup. Where each employee is responsible for finding their own projects.  If you don't find a project they will fire you.  But if you search really hard, you usually can find one.

Pros: You can tackle anything at IBM if you find your nitch.
Cons: No one has your back.  Cutthroat is the current model.  No one cares about the client or delivery.  It is all about selling and not about the people.

Pros: Big name, lots of room to hide if you do not really want to work and drive results.
Cons: Lots of room to hide.  Plenty of "empty boxes".  The GM  and her club of ex-Philips people inherited a mess but did nothing to improve Watson Health.  In fact, the culture is toxic.  The technology does not work.  Watson Health has been the kiss of death for many people including former PwC folks who came over from GBS, the old "bleed blue" boys clubs, and a few rounds of hi-po talent recruited right out of school.

Pros: You have a job...that is
Cons:
Tons of issues. I have been with IBM Watson for more than 4 years. Joining IBM is the worst decision I made in my career. I thought Watson might not be the same as the other parts of IBM. But I am wrong... Most of new people I lead or work with left within 2 years. I have trying all the effort I can to deliver solid foundation for Watson...but I failed...not because of me or my team. We are hard working people...because of the IBM leaders. They are the worst leaders I ever work with for my 20 years career. 

Working in IBM, you have two choice. One is to leave the company and the other is to become the people playing political against your colleagues.

Pros: Remote work options and autonomy
Cons: Too many execs, and none of them want to roll up their sleeves and do work. Very top down management structure and with the new Indian CEO, a LOT of U.S. jobs are moving to India under the guise of "cost savings" because of COVID slow downs.

Pros: You have a ton of hands on experience with coding in the company. In my case I got to work with many full time employees and projects. I was able to learn a ton of new stuff like how Gradle build tools work and Git work. They also have a lot of activities to keep interns engaged and networking. This was nice because you do not see people around the office like you would if the internship was in person.
Cons: There were very few downsides in my opinion. I would have to say that the thing I didn't like the most is that it took me a while to find out what I would be working on.

Pros: Innovation. Smart colleagues. Opportunity for advancement.  Great brand name.  Ability to work with many clients to solve real world problems which for better or worse, if often less glamorous than the recruiting brochure.
Cons: Heavy red tape.  Cut throat.  Must manage your own career.  Need to find your tribe otherwise the machine will chew you up.  Very short term / quarterly focus.  Aggressive sales culture, at the cost of developing long term client relationships.  Senior management rotates regularly , reinforcing short term results versus building sustainable businesses.

Pros:
Everyone I have met is top notch and on their game.
Exceptional training.
Exceptional tools.
Exceptional Support
The best thing about IBM is the Depth and Breadth of skills
Cons:
NONE

The worst thing about IBM is the Depth and Breadth of skills. You can get yourself lost in expertise sometimes but having all this knowledge to draw from is absolutely awesome and EVERYONE is ready to jump in and help, just waiting to be asked or to find a place to contribute.

Pros: IBM offers many opportunities to explore different disciplines from Technical Development to Strategy -- and everything in-between. The people are continuously working to help clients evolve their business by taking a perspective entrenched in a rich history of experiences. Whereas other consultancies have life time consultants -- IBM brings together consultants with Industry Experts. Some of the leadership has 20+ years of industry experience which is invaluable.
Cons: The shear size of the Company can become daunting for anyone to wrap their head around. It's the old adage of "the land of opportunity", but when there's too much to chose from sometimes people lose focus and burn out. Similarly if you can work 24 hours a day if that's your goal, but for many it leads to challenges.

Pros:
Solid, stable place to start a career.  You can grow as fast as you drive yourself... but motivation must be internally driven.  

Experience will widely vary by which division that you land in.  Services businesses typically place a large emphasis on number of billable hours worked.  Systems division is always trying to run a more lean business and do more with less.  Software is not uniform as a number of current employees were brought on through numerous acquisitions over the last 5-10 years.
Cons: Salary is not competitive with market rates if you stay more than a few years.  Constant revamping of employee benefit programs makes you wonder if HR has anything better to do.

Pros: It's a large company so you can change jobs without missing a paycheck or losing your seniority.  We produce innovative technology that is exciting to work on and gets used around the world.  And there are a number of really outstanding people to work with.  Most parts of IBM area also very supportive of having a life outside of work, and are friendly to those of us with families.
Cons: Red Tape.  IBM is slow to change directions and slow to take up new initiatives.  It also gets political because of it's size.

Pros: There are good discounts with business partners.  It looks good on a resume when you look for a new job (and most of us inevitably will).
Cons: Layoffs even when the company's profits are in the billions.  The CEO describes layoffs as 'business as usual'.  We're expected to create world-class products using worthless, freebie tools that don't work properly.  Managers change jobs regularly every two years, leading to instability in every group.  Quotas in performance reviews stop careers from progressing.  The internal financial results our bonuses are based on are always somehow lower than the public results, so our bonuses are always lower than projected.

Pros: Engineers can get to work with the highest level of semiconductor technology the world has to offer.  The 300mm fab is a magnet for partner companies around the world to come and develop the most advanced computer chips.  We have the newest and best processing equipment that money can buy and the most talented engineers who are able to get the best out of the semiconductor manufacturing process.
Cons: Layoffs have been happening frequently for the last eight years.

Pros: Awesome colleagues.  The software engineers I worked with were absolute professionals, hardworking, helpful and most were wonderful to work with.
Cons: You never know from one quarter to the next whether you'll still be employed.  Your performance doesn't matter if you're in the wrong place at the wrong time.  You may be given time to find other jobs within the company, but even if you find an opening within your division, the manager may not be allowed to hire you if the overall goal of the "resource action" was to reduce headcount:  They have to wait until the latest batch of "surplus" employees are out the door before filling the position.

Pros: It got me into a client that proved to be a good working environment, a solid project, in an industry I knew nothing about.
Cons: I was a contractor to IBM, which then farmed me out to their client.  The role was more a project planner than a PM, at a very premature time in the cycle (platform was not approved, no project sponsor ID'ed, no scope done, no feasibility done, no on-boarding done - to IBM or the client...

Pros: Large company with many areas to move around in.  Hiring salaries are somewhat competitive.  Working from home really allows people to focus on families.
Cons: It is simply impossible to move your salary yearly at IBM.  Even when your a top 10 percent contributor each year, you often max at at 3 percent raises.
