I have moved 4 levels in 10 years and am an enterprise level manager, and make less then new professional hires.  Life at IBM is always travel freezes, and Resource actions.  IBM is just not a place you can be a top performer and care about your career long term anymore.

Pros: Great people, solid middle managers.  Good benefits.  Worked with a team that genuinely tried to get the best work completed.  Our worst enemy was the internal system i.e. input of same data had to be entered into three different databases, all with their own separate nomenclature.
Cons: Procedures are "good" for the company, but bad for individuals.  And the procedures are infinitely more important than an individual.  Salaries are below market rate.  Such a large organization has massive bureaucracy.  Working within my team was great, but to get anything done was an exercise in frustration, it was like the company punished us for trying to do our job.

Pros: Great benefits, flexible schedule if you can carve out the time and are meeting all your deadlines/meetings. Pay does not reflect the time commitment. Depending on how many accounts you manage you can be expected to work some pretty absurd hours (evenings/weekends in addition to the Mon-Fri). Great support team in place to assist in day to day. Lots of room to grow and learn. Most days bring new challenges.
Cons: Staff/customers can be demanding, strong people skills are required to build buy-in and maintain customer relationships. Can be very high stress, not recommended for people that do not handle anxiety well.

Pros: Good benefits, lots of opportunity to learn new skills, matched 401K up to a certain percentage, looks good on a resume.
Cons: Huge company, you feel like a number. Poor decisions have been made at employees' expense in the past five years in the quest for share price targets. Resources are a bit of a mess....while they exist, they are somewhat unorganized, and you either have to work within your network to find out how to go about certain things, or follow breadcrumb trails through intranet. Highly matrixed organization---people managers often have little to no interaction with you and gain insight as to your performance from others...highly subjective.

Pros:
Technology oriented company, specially if you are working on an IBM product which has good market share like Tivoli, WAS and others, you will be best in the market. IBM is known as career maker and when you move out of IBM you will actually feel that you know lot more than others in the market.
HR policies are one of the best, unlimited leaves, medical cover.
Cons: Poor salary, no hike, you have to slog at work.

Pros: IBM is a highly professional company, and is usually the first to implement the newest HR policies generally advantageous to the employee. Their management practices are generally fair, and education is a top priority. While IBM is not usually on the cutting edge in the market, their research certainly is, and the wait and see mentality allows them to enter the market from a position of strength, and at less cost. IBM advocates working from home, which is a great help to people who have to balance work/life.
Cons: As in most big companies, there are too many checkers checking checkers. Decisions need to be made faster and at lower levels.

Pros:
The Best know global brand, therefore ease (in most cases) of door opening and doing business..
Technology investment
Largest number of patents
Cons:
top down management, not focused only on operational efficiencies to achieve results for Wall Street.
Old management style from the last decade.. this also carries through to the people they hire today.. The place is run by Finance and Operational efficiency people with the heavy hand of HR..
There is no constancy or investment in their people ensure job satisfaction and desire to stay and do the best for IBM's clients.

Pros: IBM is one of the most honorable companies I know of - focused on honesty and integrity throughout everything it does.  The company is so large and diverse that someone like myself can  have dozens of different experiences without ever having to deal with switching companies.
Cons: As good as the career opportunities are in IBM, mobility has gotten worse as the company strives to find its place in the changing landscape of commercial software.   Talent is held tightly on projects because the projects have such potential to be important for the future.

Pros: You can move around in the company and get new experiences.  The pay is good.  Opportunities are good.  Can often times get training or certification through the company.  Can stay technical and continue to progress career or jump into mgmt
Cons: Its not uncommon to work a 60 hour week.  The benefits keep eroding.  Layoffs are ongoing in my part of the business and it happens to really great skilled hardworking employees.

Pros: Work life balance, open door policy
Cons: No merit pay increases and little to no bonus.  I have worked for this company over 3 years and from the first day of employment there have been mass layoffs every 3 months.  The performance review process is shewed and is subjective and not objective.  When an employee is placed on the RA (Resource Action) list these employees are not moved to another account and there must be a special request submitted with an 1 PBC rating.  This process is unfair when you are a solid contributor.

Pros: The technology your introduced to and work on is amazing.  Projects are typically never the same, always changing, and your constantly learning.
Cons: Staffing continues to decline with no backfills.  Workloads get larger and larger.  If you enjoy juggling your workload and learning new things while doing your old job, this is the place to be.  Very hard to spend any time picking up knowledge in other areas with the limited time you have to do your work.

Pros: One of the best things about IBM is all of the flexibility.  If you're a strong contributor, and are forward about what you want from the company, most managers will work with you to make your goals happen, but you have to spearhead this effort.  Additionally, there are many teams to switch to or between if you find yourself not liking your current role.
Cons: You have to look out for yourself.  If you are not careful, many managers will work you WAY more than 40 hours a week, and the job can be very stressful.  Set clear limits about your hours, accessibility from home, etc.

Pros: See cons. Currently no pros.
Cons: IBM used to be a wonderful company to work for, where hired were top shelf from best school and the culture of high respect for career advancement and the individual promoted growth, efficiency, and effectiveness, with a high morale and a deep pride of being an IBMer. Now, working in the company means to continuously work with less people doing more, fighting against the low morale of individuals who don't know what day, month or year, they will get the axe, but they are sure they will. A disgrace!

Pros: I joined IBM three months ago and have had an exceptional experience coming in-board.   I've changed companies in Silicon Valley every few years so I have a good baseline for comparison.    I've found the people I'm working with to be eager for and open to new ideas on products and process.   It doesn't seem like the market appreciates the transformation taking hold at IBM and the opportunity with Cognitive technologies which makes it a great time to join the company
Cons: There's still a lot of work to do to breakdown boundaries and drive speed but Ginni and her team really are out in front driving change.

Pros: IBM has a heritage of being a technology leader and developing many amazing products.  In addition, IBM has traditionally been very supportive of its employees.
Cons:
Too much middle management - top leadership has no concept of reality due to being insulated by a middle management team that only answers to "Yes".  The result is unrealistic goals for the Sales Teams as well as dated products.

This once great company is in the midst of another transition -- only time will tell whether or not it will return to its once former self (in terms of ethics and dedication to its employees).

Pros: The benefits and pay are great.
Cons: Layoffs are CONSTANT!  They cycle people in and out at astonishing quantities.

Pros: Strong humanist values for a large corporate entity. No ceiling on ability to impact or effect change at any level. Great patent culture. Diverse teams/global collaboration. Vast library of  development and learning programs/certifications.
Cons: Largeness (300k+) means it's really like working at a company made of many smaller companies - so your experience can vary a lot depending on where you are. Like everywhere else- your experience is hugely influenced by the style and skill of your manager.  Also like everywhere else, there are a mix of of skilled and unskilled managers.

Pros:
- Flexible remote policy
- Kind people
Cons:
- They sell this role as mgmt consulting.. it's not
- Very volatile working environment (people get fired all the time)
- Consistent talent loss to better companies
- Hierarchical / no one listens to younger folk who genuinely want to improve the company
- Disinvestment from many interesting innovation programs
- They make it hard to be a self-starter
- Lack of transparency around changes and issues with GBS. The culture of secrecy is getting out of hand.
- Can only get a role if you network for it. Meritocracy, I hardly knew her..

Pros: I joined IBM as a intern, within 6 month internship, I learned more than I did in college 3 years. It is definitely a great place to start your career as a college graduate. People are nice, helpful and smart.  The work hours are very flexible, alot good opportunity to advance your career inside the company.
Cons: Big organization, its hard to get your voice heard. The company had some of the most advanced ideas and opportunities in many high tech field in early years: cloud, Big Data, AI, LOT. However, with all the other big competitor,  IBM is falling behind in all of those fields. Many of my fellow co-workers went to Google, Amazon, Facebook, not only because of the pay check, but the career opportunities.

Pros: Gets you the entry-level experience you need before moving to another company.
Cons: Office politics are out of control. Company is driving itself into the ground and cutting away its top talent. 401K match is horrible! There's no longevity in any role anymore. Insurance is costing more and more each year. Unless you're in executive management, you're just a number and don't matter. The company consistently cuts mid-to-high wage earners, who've worked hard for their experience and for the company, rather than cutting the actual dead weight and slackers.

Pros:
One of the great things about IBM is there are so many different opportunities to deliver value and help our clients realize their business goals. Wide range of industries and areas of focus that IBM clients leverage across the company.

IBM does a great job of onboarding new employees to help you become productive as quickly as possible. The tools and training provided are easy to use, most onboarding training is self-paced. As part of the onboarding experience, mentors are assigned to help answer questions.
Cons: IBM is a large global company, it is intimidating at first, it takes some time to understand the organizational structure and how to operate within it.

Pros:
I've never had a team and organization as truly dedicated to helping me become the best contributor that I can. I have never been left to flounder or struggle needlessly to get onboarded into a new project, everyone shares knowledge freely, and the organization has a STRONG push for supporting individuals in ways I've never had before.
Part of your weekly schedule is intended to include individually directed continued learning, you're encouraged to explore job or project opportunities in other divisions or teams for projects that interest you, agile is actually followed, and my manager and teammates all work together to protect our time from last-minute or overbearing requests.
Cons: Marketing? I had no idea IBM was this amazing and I could have missed out on this opportunity.

Pros: A very supportive organization that struggles with the challenges of being at the leading-edge of a still 'immature' industry (i.e. outsourcing). IBM works hard to keep up with both the constant change of technology that its clients are using and the technology needed to provide 'superior' outsourcing services. Management works hard to stay ahead of both its customers and its customers. Great opportunities are available for those working to be flexible and ready to turn their hand to anything. Those who don't are left behind and soon become 'dead-weight' in the organization structure.
Cons: Some dead weight in middle-management and the constant challenge of integrating the operations of new clients into the IBM Delivery Model.

Pros:
Brand recognition.  People recognize the brand and it does carry value as a technology provider. In regards to services, it is still trying to build a reputation in other service offerings.

If you are looking for stability, IBM is a great company.
Cons:
Very large company. It is hard to network. You have to take the initiative to met people and find growth opportunities. The company focuses on the bottom line too much and sometimes ignores it's people. 

Projects can be mundane and boring. Billing hours is a top priority, but this is typical at most consulting firms. Bonuses are small compared to competitors.

Pros: A large company with many opportunities to grow both horizontally and vertically. The sheer amount of resources within the company is astounding and can greatly improve your abilities and knowledge.
Cons: IBM is such a large corporation that it is easy to get lost in it. It is often times very difficult to balance getting your work done with creating a large enough network of co-workers to get the information that you need. Having a manager only a few levels above you that you will never see and most likely never speak to is not especially endearing for making a career at IBM.

Pros: The pay at IBM is good.  Also, one of the real positives is that there are many different products worked on in IBM.  This means that one has the ability to move around and work on these different projects while taking the opportunity to learn many different things, including newer technologies that one might not have the opportunity to work with at a smaller company.  I always felt that I could find better job stability at a smaller company, but I could never find the vast assortment of technologies to work with that I find at IBM.  That's the main reason I like it.
Cons: Mentioned in the previous section.

Pros: IBM still has a pretty good name so it is not a bad place to work for initial IT experience.  The benefits (Vacation, 401k, Health Care, etc) are still good but seem to get worse every year.
Cons: Raises are few and far between at IBM even if you receive a satisfactory PBC rating.  If you are lucky enough to get a raise it is only 2-3%.   Very few people can make a career out of IBM now.  I've seen  many quality employees leave or be laid off to be replaced by lower paid employees with less experience.

Pros: Overall the salary is good, but not spectacular.  They are a strong company, with many different divisions to move between and gain experience.  Most managers are good at helping with your work/life balance.
Cons: Executive management is taking more control from staff and line managers.  The company has had very good years and the executives are not sharing so that the stock price can be driven higher.  The are the main ones who get stock options, so it only rewards them.  The expense cuts are not likely sustainable without serious negative effects.

Pros:
- Name recognition
- Ability to command more far money at another firm
- Plenty of Learning and knowledge opportunities
-
Cons:
- NO work/life balance (we are expected to be the lasts ones in the office, despite the fact that the client staff leaves at least 3 hours before us)
- Management is the worst, no communication and lots of sugar coating bs
- salary below industry average; bonuses are the WORST and pay raises are non-existent unless you're already making $250K
- morale low
- resource actions are arbitrary
- promotion process is a major joke, not at all merit based; based on how much @ss you kissed 
- WAY TOO MANY POLITICS

Pros:
demanding / challenging work
smart co-workers
access to cutting edge technologies and huge accounts
Cons: work is constantly being off-shored.  The current business model is to simplify job roles and then off-shore them to low cost labor countries.  Means getting promoted is difficult, and a probability of a good salary increase is low.

Pros:
1.  Benefits - pretty decent, health and dental insurance you can get for free if you sign up for the basic plan.  401k match is up to 6% after you've been there 1 year.

2.  Flexibility -  Depending on how lenient your manager is (mine was) you can work from home if you're sick or out of town without taking any PTO.

3.  Co-workers -  Basically all of the FA's are 20-somethings, so you'll be able to work alongside some good people.  Then you can all go to lunch and talk about how stupid your job is.  True story.  Happened a lot.

4.  Good resume builder

5.  Ping-pong.
Cons:
1.  Compensation - Starting salary is 40k with a sign-on bonus of $1,500..  Not bad for a recent college grad just starting out, I'll admit.  But don't expect to see a raise any time soon.  Or a bonus.  You'll likely see that same paycheck twice a month for years to come.

2.  On-the-Job Training - This was how I figured out IBM was a joke within the first couple weeks.  My previous manager told me on the first day, "you'll think we've never trained somebody in before."  He was right.  Although they offer training classes, these are basically a formality for all new hires.  These sad excuses for classes won't actually help you do your job.  The person I shared an office with basically taught me everything.

3.  Job Satisfaction - I worked some not-so-fun jobs through college.  I sold shoes, did janitorial work, cleaned horse stalls.  Even at $8-10 an hour, these jobs were still more enjoyable than being a Financial Analyst at IBM. 

4.  Cost-Cutting - This is my biggest problem with IBM as a company.  IBM actually just laid off about 1,200 employees from their US workforce in the week I wrote this review.  Some from the Rochester plant were included in this.  If you're thinking about starting a career at IBM by taking a financial analyst job, consider this:  From 2007 to 2011, the US IBM workforce has shrunk from 135,000 down to 98,000 employees.  They have been shipping these jobs overseas and will continue to do so because the labor is simply cheaper over there.  IBM could care less about their employees.  It's all about making the shareholders money, even if it means canning people that have been with the company for almost 30 years.

5.  Work-Loads - Although some of the work is being shipped overseas, a lot of this work is just being piled on to current employees' workloads.  Now I understand that the longer you stay with a company the more work you'll have to do, that's a given.  But along with that usually comes a pay increase.  As a Financial Analyst I guarantee you will be given more, and more, and more mind-numbing work to do.  And to thank you for your efforts, IBM will let you use their bathrooms.  Sweet deal, right?

This job does provide good finance experience for a recent college grad, but that's about it..  This isn't the place to build a career.  In my opinion, the entire COE will be shipped overseas in the next 5-10 years.

Pros:
Bright and intelligent people that do a lot of great things
Resources available to learn about new products and services
IBM technologies are used globally and are transferable to any industry if you know your stuff
Flexible Work at Home environment and tools to do the job.
Cons:
2015 Roadmap will produce only more and more layoffs in US
Business Model is unsustainable for long term US employees
IT support Model is all off shore replacements
Below market/industry pay for more senior level jobs

Pros: I had the opportunity to work on international projects, traveling to multiple locations around the world.  My level of responsibility grew as I proved my ability to successfully deliver results.  I gained experience managing teams and being responsible for project profitability.  Co-workers generally intelligent and friendly.
Cons: Travel is constant for GBS, so it can be difficult, especially with a family.  Sometimes you have to take projects that are not ideal/interesting because of the need for very high utilization (time billable to client).

Pros: Telecommuting is available, its a paycheck
Cons:
-Employee morale is very low
-Very small raises, none in recent years
-No training whatsoever
-Threat of layoffs, almost all jobs in my division have been offshored
-Constant changes in policy to cut every last penny. Im sure soon we will have to buy our own laptops.
-Everyone has a "Not my problem" attitude, very adversarial environment
-Too much red tape and endless unnecessary conference calls
-Review process is completely broken and ratings are usually based on whether or not you are in your managers inner circle
-Top performers are either leaving or giving up and just collecting a paycheck waiting to be laid off.
-Gloomy depressing atmosphere. 
-Finally, you will never get even a hint that anything you do is appreciated.

Pros: Many really intelligent people work at IBM. High innovation and strong teamwork come naturally to anyone who focuses on their work and cares about the product(s) being developed. IBM is very serious about work/life balance.
Cons: IBM claims to "pay for performance" and they do. However, the differentiation on pay is not as strong as I would logically expect.

Pros: Work from home, good base pay and bonuses
Cons: Management not in touch with staff.

Pros: Huge network, ability to move around within the company. Mostly great people. Predictable culture. Rewarded with promotions for exercising my passion, following my interests. Have to admire a company that knows how to sustain itself for decades.
Cons: Exasperating organizational infighting and agendas are to be expected within this vast company, despite a facade of collaboration. I wish it seemed genuine. Workload increasing too steadily to work on career advancement. Seeing I will have to sell my work-life balance to reach the next level. Fear I'll be politely shuffled out the door in 10 years anyway, for costing too much.

Pros: None worth mentioning at this time
Cons: They flew me to Austin had an interview and a few days later offered me a job and stated that they are going to call me in a few days for details..... 2 weeks passed i called them they said the person that was to give the actual offer letter was out and i should give them a week. A week passed and i called them they said that they were sorry that they will not be able to get me on the team. They referred me to another person for a different position that really never existed...

Pros: Brand recognition; flexible work options;
Cons: Compensation not up to par with competition, especially for top performers; VERY limited career options / opportunities for WFH employees; lack of employee visibility to other areas of the business (employees are often pigeon-holed, especially top performers); typical bureaucracy inherent to large(r) companies.

Pros: Some of great things about working for IBM are the ability to work from home. I think this allows you to get online and check on projects or email anytime of the day or night. I liked working on a global team of great people.
Cons: Some of the cons are working on internal accounts, they will do anything to save money including running outdated software on very old hardware and having you fix or make excuses for why this is okay. no recognition of band aiding the old apps and hardware.

Pros: If you are a Ph.D. and want to work in the industry but still be in touch with the academic work, IBM Research is one of the few places that can provide that opportunity. As a research staff member (typically only Ph.D.s are hired), you will be measured based on three things: 1. your project work and how much it contributed to the company in terms of cost savings, revenue impact, or other qualitative impact, or technological advances if you are lucky enough to be working on such things 2. patents you file, 3. papers you publish. Since IBM is a global company, the projects can come from many different industries and many different locations in the world. The Research division enjoys high respect within the company but much more so outside the company.
Cons: IBM's obsession with pleasing the Wall Street brings about a short sighted view to its research policy and hence impacts its Research negatively. All parts of IBM unfortunately scramble to meet short term financial objectives and Research is very often called for help, which takes researchers away from their primary roles of inventing and innovating game changing technologies and methods. By definition, research means investing time and money in high risk high reward problems. For instance, Watson was developed over quite a few years with dozens of people involved. That is what it takes to create serious technologies. Watson team had the few lucky researchers. Unfortunately, many researchers find themselves in a situation where they are asked to help the other parts of IBM improve their bottom line. Since other parts of IBM provide research its funding, they have a lot of influence on defining research projects and therefore how researchers spend their time. Since they are hard pressed to meet their financial objectives, they tend to define projects that help their short term financial goals. Such projects are almost always less innovative and tend to have marginal value for the company. IBM researchers are very capable people. IBM hires the very best to its Research. However, under so much pressure to help IBM's bottom line and do it fast, it is hard for researchers to come up with earth shaking innovations, though they would be perfectly capable to do so if they were given some breathing room. There are still quite a few researchers who still get to work on really promising things but their numbers are quite small.

Pros: Smart, interesting people; training; flexible work options (work from home, etc); benefits. People managers who CARE about people are effective.
Cons: Need executive sponsor to advance, even if top performer. Performance management fosters competition. Salary program is broken. Bureaucracy.

Pros:
* Work-life balance usually better than my previous jobs.
* Some interesting projects using advanced tools/technology.
* Met some very intelligent and good people.
Cons:
* Overselling and then not able to meet timelines adds pressure on the consultants who actually do the work.
* Does not seem to have a strategic direction. Upper mgmt. just wants to make their quota.
* Getting to attend training/conferences is virtually impossible.

Pros:
Working behind a well known company.  
Lots of training available. All jib related certifications are paid for.  
Many employees have been with the company for a long time. They have lots of experience to share.
Cons: Having survived the last round of layoffs, I've come to find out that no job at IBM is safe. The company is not employee focused anymore. It's more about cuting costs (i.e. employees) if shares are down. Being a newer guy with the company has felt like I have a target on my back because older guys think I was hired to replace them.

Pros:
Huge variety of projects, with opportunities in pretty much every field.
Access to internal experts in each field.
Access to experts in the whole chain of operations right from Industry SMEs to technology experts to technology support people, everyone within the same company.
Cons:
Less control over the kind of projects one wants to work on.
Excess emphasis on billing and utilization during yearly ratings.
Work life balance not maintained but varies from project to project.

Pros: Interesting job assignments with challenging tasks. The fellow employee are also super friendly and helpful.
Cons: Being so new in this area there is lack in the access to  equipment and personnel resource that you expect to find at a company of this size.  There is no one to talk to about health and benefits locally and they lack a IT department to handle Ofiice materials. You have to provide your own equipment beyond the provided think pad laptop.

Pros: IBM sits in front of massive revenue streams. They pay on time although their ethics (especially on sales commissions) are deplorable.
Cons: Intellectual capital is the only true asset a technology company owns. They are running talent out the door as quickly as possible. There is value in the gigantic revenue they control and huge inertia for their customers to drop them, and if (God help you) you work here, you will see first hand how the leadership team is shoveling that cash into their pockets as quickly as they can.

Pros: Excellent benefits, pay, and there are enough opportunities for many people.  The talent of the people at IBM is amazing.
Cons: The company is struggling with its Cloud, Watson, and Analytics strategy.  It is continually reducing costs to protect the bottom line, but it seems to be doing this more indiscriminately rather than strategically.  It is forcing its enterprise customers to move to the Cloud, but they are resisting this massive change in strategy.  The cuts to the software development teams are having a negative effect on code quality, DevOps is not working for every team.

Pros: Working for IBM means you get to work with some of the brightest tech minds anywhere. It means travel, many times internationally, and working with a wide diverse group of people. Its means something special to be an IBMer and to know your work helps change the world to be a better place.
Cons: IBM is a big, complex machine and its a very easy place to get lost in. IBM will consume you and your personal time. Its not a place for passengers, only drivers will see success.

Pros: Work life balance is alright.
Cons: Managers promise promotions to employees in return for the employees to exceed their quota but promotions are then put on hold because budgets are supposedly not figured out. Extremely high lack of transparency.

Pros: IBM recognizes that in order to compete in the 21st century IT market, it has to change. It's changing everything from its strategy - moving toward Cognitive, Data, Analytics, among others - to how it interacts and engages with clients and employees. As a millennial, I'm relieved to see that IBM is taking advice from my peers through an initiative called the Millennial Corps. In all, I have had been so lucky to work with great, smart people.
Cons: Large company with a lot of bureaucracy... It's often difficult to track down information - your network is so important at IBM.

Pros:
Work/Life Balance is literally amazing.
The environment and teams you work with are wonderful
Managers have always been extremely helpful to me as a junior engineer. 
You won't find a nicer group of people to work with. 
Team leads and subject matter experts always seem willing to help when you get stuck
Cons: Certain projects feel stagnant, as potential for growth seems entirely dependent on whether upper management feels the product/project is worth investing "resources" in.

Pros:
- PEOPLE: you get to work with some of the greatest and brightest people if you're lucky. You'll get close to your start class and it'll feel like an extension of college. 
- PAY: if you went to a target school, then your pay is probably pretty good compared to your peers' starting salaries at PwC, EY, etc. (hey, that's how they trapped me here)
- TRAVEL PERKS: if you enjoy traveling, then you're in the right place to rack up miles and hotel points. You can also do alternate travel and fly somewhere else for the weekend, which is pretty nice.
Cons:
Despite what the recruiters/interviewers tell you, IBM is NOT a management consulting company. Yes, we do talk to C-Suite, but only the CIO, and when we do, it's because we're either selling or implementing IBM products/solutions, not because we're trying to help you figure out why your company's profits are declining. 

Given the sales-driven and margin-driven nature of the company, here are some cons if you don't do your research thoroughly...

- MENIAL, MINDLESS WORK: as a CbDer, you're hired in to do PMO, testing, and note taking. People have this misconception that CbDers are their assistants, and will treat you as such, making you schedule meetings, book conference rooms, upload a document onto Box. There's no analytical or critical thinking required whatsoever, and definitely don't expect to be challenged. 
- LONG DURATION OF PROJECTS: IBM projects run longer than typical consulting firms, usually ranging from 6-9 months. Again, because they are mostly implementation-type work, you'll be doing the same thing (e.g. testing) the whole time. Don't expect that much exposure to different industries or types of projects. Your first project pretty much pigeon-holes you to do the same thing for the rest of your career, unless you really fight HARD to get onto something you want.
- LACK OF PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT: in the CbD program, you have 3 mandatory trainings. They're a lot of fun, because you get to hang out with people in your start class. However, the stuff you learn is absolutely useless for your job. They hire a third party vendor to conduct these sessions. They teach you things like how to present better, but it's useless because you'll never be given an opportunity to present to anyone.
- CONSTANT REORG: there's been I think 3 (?) reorgs during the 2 years that I've worked here, both GBS-wide and CbD-specific. Despite IBM being an established corporation, the consulting arm is still relatively young (acquired from PwC a few years ago), so it almost feels as if we're going through the growing pains of a young company... just a general lack of clear direction and constantly shifting corporate strategy.
- LAYOFFS: during my time here, I've seen maybe 3 rounds of layoffs, which has affected people that were on my team, as well as people in my start class (yeah, THAT young). If you think you're immune from layoffs because you're a fresh college grad, think again. No one's safe here, and everyone's always on edge.
- OUTDATED INTERNAL TECHNOLOGIES: it's embarrassing how bad IBM internal technologies are being that we boast we're at the forefront of technology. Most tools employees use (expense system, travel booking system, lotus notes) SUCK. They haven't been refreshed since the 1990's and are extremely cumbersome to use.

Pros: potential for company, some interesting projects
Cons:
poor benefits, no bonuses (literally as little as less than <1k for band 9s) , poor morale
trying to reinvent but not making the turn quickly enough
older lifers stop change

Pros: IBM has a number of projects and initiatives that you can take advantage of outside of your "day job."  They reward based on performance and that has always been a selling point.  I had a recent opportunity to participate in the Corporate Services Corp (CSC) program and travel to Senegal for a month to provide free consulting services.  I also had an opportunity several years ago to do a three month assignment in Hursley, England and work with my product's development team.  There are non-travel assignments as well that you participate in and the culture for innovation is very much encouraged.
Cons: The down side of working for IBM is changing jobs.  It is sometimes very difficult to change jobs within IBM.

Pros: Great and very fair company. Legacy of hundreds of years of innovation and market leadership. Highest patent filed year over years in last thirty plus years
Cons: Top heavy. Slave of process.... always late to react. Missed opportunities to capture the marked in cloud, analytic. Hope cognitive pays rich dividend. Current culture in IBM is more you are away from client more authority you have and more money you make. Most business leaders in IBM spent more time in convincing internal CFO and COO than serving clients.

Pros: Benefits plan is in line or better than industry standards.
Cons:
- No direction in "strategic imperatives" (Software) that are suppose to drive growth.
- Continued playing of the shell game with alignment creates a poor environment for customers and for the sales force.  
- Aging internal systems and processes are a setback when compared to other smaller more agile companies.
- Management does not join you in the field and therefore is of little value.  Their job is solely to drive an accurate forecast.

Pros: Fortune 500 company on your resume, 6 months of travel and training
Cons:
-No organization whatsoever in the digital rotation program, will stick you anywhere just because of headcount
-Out of the blue PAY CUTS. They are giving out significant pay cuts along with reducing benefits
-Management doesn't care. The premise of the rotation program was to find people job opportunities moving out but 80% of the people graduating from the program do not have placements and are essentially unemployed.

Pros: Endless learning opportunities, great people in my particular business unit. IBM is a big company, you can move around and learn new roles and responsibilities and still keep growing as an employee.
Cons: Processes can do more harm than good. Can feel like you are the only one that cares about your particular project, but with the right direction things can get accomplished. The threat of being a victim of a resource action (RA) is somewhat stressful, but that's most large organizations.

Pros: Lots of smart colleagues. Attracts talent due to name recognition, commercials...?
Cons: Sizable gap between the sunshine spread by C level execs versus the reality of first/second line managers. In my last position, C level said one thing and then first line manager completely disregarded the overall strategy including skills needed for team. The layoff cycle is constant. It's tiresome. No one feels valued. No job security.

Pros:
Top Benefits
Alot of smart caring people in field and middle management 
Pretty good pay for the market
Plenty of responsibility
Cons:
Bureaucracy Bureaucracy Bureaucracy
Difficult to navigate the myriad of "Federal Government" like policies
A lot of groupthink inertia in the IBM cocoon so change is glacially slow to effect
A lot of overlapping job responsibilities among employees causing conflict

Pros: Fair Benefits; Good Mgmt Team; Able to work from home during pandemic. Supportive of family issues. Good place for folks who are getting started in the business. I've staying over 3 years because of work/life flexibility, but am considering moving on due to low salery (<$55k after 3 years!!).
Cons: Client Innovation Center, CIC is a sub-department of Global Business Services, GBS: takes two full years for 401k matching and that does not happen on a bi-weekly basis but only occurs in a lump sum at end of year if you complete the full year.

Pros: IBM is a top Consulting brand that will look good on your resume. The training opportunities are plenty more than most other Consulting Firms. IBM and Accenture are two of the best Firms to build up your Core Consulting skills. IBM unlike Accenture has more over 40 year old Consultants, so it is a more mature Work-Life balanced culture than Accenture's Long hour Work-days and Spring-Break Weekends.
Cons: IBM is too big to notice you as a person. I hate the Partner worshiping. The Coaching and Performance Reviewers just suck. The retirement and benefits package used to be good but they are being cut significantly.

Pros: A lot of various kind of opportunities within the company. Can do well if you network well. They reward the best employees quite well. Good benefits.
Cons: How well you play politics is more important for promotion than your performance. Management doesn't seem to care about employees. There is no sense of a strong company culture. I don't think employees have any pride in working for IBM anymore. Even as a full time employee you feel like a contractor. You know management has virtually no interest in trying to save your job

Pros: Many opportunities if you want to travel.  Working directly for a client can be rewarding.
Cons: Many opportunities, BUT you have to travel.  There is really no work-life balance.  If you are supporting commercial clients, the clients come first above everything else.  If you are in the I/T side of the business, you have no work-life balance.  The 100% expectation is to be "on the road".  Nothing else matters and there is no sympathy from exec management.  IBM has spun the media on this and it is beyond me why the covers do not get blown off on this issue.

Pros: Work/life balance is great simply because many of us work from home.
Cons: Salary and band promotions are rare regardless of your performance. There is no budget for outside training (classroom). Entire teams are being laid off and replaced with workers from a lower cost region. That is hardly necessary in order to remain competitive, especially for a company with huge profits. It's interesting that the executives making all the decisions still have their raises, bonuses and jobs.

Pros: None that I can think of, management does not care about staff no matter what they say. Talk is chaep and so is IBM. No career coaching no performance reviews excpet once a year with is basically sign it or leave! Absolutely disgutsing everything is a fire drill and must be done right away at management discretion. Projects are mismanaged and the stuff always rolls down hill, partners never do anythign wrong and simply perform a fly by and expect everything to run smoothly. Comp plans are heavily weighted to partners and staff get the crumbs if anythign at all.
Cons: Work you to the bone, pay you little and demand demand and demand

Pros: Work Life Balance, Career Opportunities, Flexible Hours
Cons: Getting to the right source for an answer. It is so large that at times it is impossible to get an answer!  It is important to get to know people that can help your career along within IBM.  Since it is such a large company you could get lost in the masses.

Pros: The benefits packages were well above average, corporate discounts available to me as an employee were great, industry recognition of the IBM name.  Company match of the 401k
Cons: The most senior managers only care about their stock options and their million dollar pay checks.  They couldn't care less about people and the impact of their decisions and policies on people.  The company is too large to have a feeling of belonging or camaraderie outside a few specific work groups.

Pros: The "workers" still have faith in IBM even though management is trying to break that faith.  IBM has very flexible work policy.  Can pretty much work your own hours as long as you get your job done.  That's one of the things that 1st line managers still have control over.
Cons: The erosion of benefits, retirement, salary, and off-shoring of jobs has taken a terrible toll on employee morale.  Having been around to see the days of management that cared about employees really breaks my heart to see what IBM has turned into.

Pros:
Autonomy
Brand Recognition
Competency of Peers
Technical Leadership
Cons:
Overwhelming Processes
Sales Model/Sales Support is Challenging
Delivery Support of Sales is variable

Pros: Name recognition on the resume, ability to use the "methods" and have hands on experience in a variety of activities, diverse client base, interesting projects
Cons: Culture accepting of poor behavior if it means more revenue; cookbook type of consulting - have the rookie read the cookbook and he is now a subject matter expert; work-life balance is not there - the organization runs on billable hours and volunteers to manage it; utilization target and calculations are insane (eg, you can take vacation and training - but make up the hours...kind of like advanced comp time rather than real vacation)

Pros:
8% employee match 401k
True flex time
Work from home
Cons:
Constantly worrying if you will be part of the next set of layoffs.  (I escaped it twice, but unable to the third time).
Poor bonus (2-4% on avg and was a consistent 2+ on reviews)
Expectation of every single employee to either patent, publish, or create a new innovation, every year.  Just not possible.

Pros: Very competative pay. Remote/WFH capabilities a definite plus. Great Intern bonus oppurtunities like lunches, tours, and dinners.
Cons: You are treated like a piece of hardware. Using your ID# you are even refered to as hardware. Very impersonal. All meetings were teleconferences so I never met 95% of the people that I worked with on a day to day basis. Outsourced employees are integrated into every level of the business process, even if the language capabilites are not 100% on par for efficint work streams.

Pros: like being in any team contest, the colleagues that you work with daily on sales efforts, you come to admire and like being with, as you have a common goal: closing the sale, so you can make money and keep your job.
Cons: some would say the total lack of an effective strategy from senior mgt to handle the onslaught of new sw acquisitions and integrate them into an effective sales plan.  However, I would say that the layer of sw sales mgt at a regional level is all about themselves, not about the field, all about how they can use you to make themselves look better.

Pros: The company is dedicated to solving big problems and giving their employees the resources, time, and motivation to be creative and innovative. There is a lot of incentive to work on tough problems that nobody has worked on before.
Cons: Projects can often get shelved without getting off the ground. It's easy to work on projects that don't go anywhere. There is a big focus on developing patent-able software, but there can be a lack of guidance in terms of what to work on.

Pros: IBM does so many things you could potentially stay in the company your whole career and have 10 different job roles in 10 different areas of the business.
Cons: IBM has aligned itself with a 2015 roadmap that's great for shareholders, but horrible for employees. Costs are continually being cut, resource actions are annual when they are not quarterly, and decisions are becoming less and less strategic and more and more tactical.

Pros: Access to leading technology, world class talent, many people have decades of experience. Great place to build a resume, write patents and learn. Great work life balance, lots of responsibility given to engineers. Huge company with many opportunities if you can find them.
Cons: Change in business strategy to software and services has severely impacted the hardware group and it's ability to execute with questionable financial results. Challenging growth environment given hardware sales decline. Ancient buildings and offices.

Pros: You will be hard-pressed to find a more dedicated and smart group of peers to work with.  You'll work alongside some of the best and brightest.
Cons: The leadership can be disappointing at times... more interested in their own careers than doing what's right by the business or our clients.  The benefits are not nearly as good as they used to be, and the compensation for quota employees is "managed" to make sure that no one is bringing home piles of money.  If you're on track to blow out your number, don't be surprised by a quota increase.

Pros: There are a million things you can do in IBM, and they'll help you learn new skills or give you the opportunity to do something really cool. You really have to make something of it yourself, no one's going to give you anything.
Cons: Politics. So much bureaucracy that you spend 85% of your life dealing with that instead of what's actually important. Management manages to numbers instead of asking, "does this actually matter?". Only business goal is a stock price. They've lost track of what made them great, the people. The culture isn't fun for 95% of IBM, it's all about the dollar.

Pros: vacation and paid holidays are still a premium if you can find a backup to cover for you; overall benefits are still decent
Cons: Corporate greed has taken over, customers and employees are no longer top priority for this company unless your a top executive.  Executive pay and bonuses continue to rise, pay and bonuses for non-executive employees Band 9 and lower have been frozen.

Pros: Large pool of employees, so you can find some very intelligent people
Cons: Most of the creative and intelligent folks left years ago when job insecurity became the norm.  Company is no longer a leader in innovation, benefits nor work-life balance.  Expect to work weekends, holidays, and sometimes 24+ hr shifts without additional compensation.  Promotions and raises are mostly a thing of the past.  Best description of the work environment is "toxic"

Pros: Benefits are average, able to work from home. lots of time on my hands because we are losing new business and contracts
Cons: Executives/management do not care about you, it's all political, if you aren't a sheeple you won't survive. Compensation sucks, no raises or bonus's for years. It's a toxic cutthroat environment and takes a very tough skin to work at IBM. They truly have their heads in the sand. As an IBM employee, we all saw this tanking of IBM coming for years and knew their vision wasn't sustainable. They constantly fire employees to make their gross profit look higher as they can't grow their revenue. How does a company survive with the lowest of employee morale?  Future employees, please be aware you will not be happy at IBM, avoid at all costs.

Pros: Work/Life Balance:  depending on job, great flexibility in hours and location (ie remote or onsite) as long as you put in your time and get the job done.  Excellent co-workers who are very dedicated and intelligent.  Ability to really learn from some of the top people in the industry.
Cons: Too much focus on bottom line business/stock performance.  Stagnation of salary growth.  Workload has increased significantly without relief of business commitments due to numerous resource actions.

Pros: Having done software sales close to 10 years, I believe it's a great company to build a career in - you're surrounded by a lot of intelligent, experienced professionals so you never stop learning.  Management for the most part is reasonable so long as you're a hard worker. Working remotely has its perks/conveniences.  Work/life balance is good for the most part.
Cons: The selling culture has been significantly changing over the years in which sellers are pressured and tasked with specific activities that may undermine their relationships with their clients.  Attaining quota has become less and less achievable.  While working remotely has its perks, it could get mundane.

Pros: Everything you are required to do is reasonable (they hired you because you can do it!) and everyone is willing to help you along the way. Being an intern, they try to expose you to more than where you work, pushing you to network and experience other places around IBM that you otherwise wouldn't with just your internship. Overall, wonderful place to be an intern even if its not something you learn you don't want to do.
Cons: Currently the company is going through some reshaping, so the idea of opportunities is very vague. If you enjoy your job, being an intern makes you sad that this can't be your real position.

Pros: Lots of learning ops if you like few classroom opportunities
Cons:
Company spends billions on stock buybacks, but currently views employees ONLY as expense. The immediate response to bad news is always to cut employees or employee benefits.
Measurements all focus on revenue growth YTY, but we keep selling off huge units of the company - quickly doing what Lou Gerstner saved the company from in the 90s.   
If you're in a major market country, you're in constant risk of layoff.

Pros: I worked at IBM for many years, with very intelligent, forward-thinking leaders. Pros include: Strong leadership; clear direction; career growth / opportunities, and work-life flexibility options (work at home; part-time schedule, leave of absence, etc).
Cons: Depending on the position at IBM, it can be challenging to truly find work-life balance, due to the size and global nature of the business. Also, as a mobile employee there were not many networking events in my area (that I was aware of) that could bring mobile employees in similar functions together.

Pros: The benefits package is overall pretty good. The healthcare package is especially great. The teams that I work with are also extremely helpful. Management has appeared to be open to new ideas and technologies.
Cons: During this time of transition to IBM we have heard mixed things. Some of the promises initially made are not being upheld and as time goes on the actual information we are getting isn't quite as rosy as initially put to us.

Pros: Salary and Benifits. Being able to work from home is nice.
Cons: The company lacks leadership, guidance under the current CEO. It's a fend for yourself type environment instead of a team building, help the last man standing type place. Managers only look out for themselves and don't create a cohesive team environment..

Pros:
Like with any big company there are a lot of different opportunities to do different things, which is great.  Global company which is great as you get to work with people in different geographies. The health benefits and other healthy perks are superior to other companies.
great people to work with.
Cons: Being such a large company the process holds you up and even though trying to be agile, the process doesn't allow for being truly agile.  Hindered by certain tools, although we are improving, but that comes with growing pains.

Pros:
- Excellent bonus structure
-  There are some very good people to work with
-  Executive MGMT was very accessible
-  I worked with a great product that their customers loved
Cons:
- My particular manager was very closed off meaning that it was his way or the highway
- To many mandatory scheduled company meetings - 4 per week
-  They force you to travel 4 out of 5 days EVERY week - if you don't, you get chewed out 
-  Here is the breakdown - 
-   East VP - Great guy easy to work with/ no issues, 
-  West VP - will micromanage you to death and question everything you do

Pros: There are many pros to working for IBM as a graduate entry consultant: Group training every 6 months for the first two years, great benefits (medical, dental, 401k matching), large company so many opportunities
Cons: The cons are really things you will find at any large corporation. You are in charge of your own career, if you don't take the self initiative to find projects and know where you want to go, then you may not get placed in roles that you desired to have.

Pros:
- Flexibility to work from home on Fridays 
- Ability to travel to "cool" cities sometimes depending on projects
Cons:
- Org change 3 times already in my less than 2 years of time at IBM; very confusing
- Doesn't care about its people as much as it advertises; at the end of the day, you'll be guided into wherever there's needs, rather than your own desires 
- A huge gap between entry-level employees and middle management, which lead to misunderstandings and conflicts at times
- Middle management is basically comprised of white men with age of 40+

Pros: If you find the right position, you may be able to work from home, with little travel. This is a plus.  This does allow for a work/life balance. You may also get the opportunity to work with a global team.  If you are flexible with your working hours, this may be a good fit, as there isn't a tendency for senior management to not be micro managing.
Cons: The bureaucracy and top-down management  of corporate America is a big part of the culture for approvals, even though they are pushing for Agile.  You will find huge discrepancies between pay, for the same job across the different business units. They are (nothing new) moving more and more jobs to India.

Pros: You have an opportunity to do many different things.....you can work just as hard and as much as you would like...over and above your daily job.
Cons: Most career decisions were based on diversity.  It didn't matter how good you were, how much you contributed, how much you worked........the award, promotion, recognition, and decision to keep you on board when the rest of the team was being off-shored was purely based on diversity.

Pros: This company has reinvented itself multiple times in its more than 100 year history.  There is a realization that the company needs to reinvent itself and they are working  towards it.
Cons: Very large company, very distributed company and therefore very difficult to steer the ship. Trying to reinvent itself as a Cognitive and Cloud Company but has not, yet, found the angle to make either of that happen and therefore struggling.

Pros: Company has an amazing portfolio and talented engineers. The company is rapidly simplifying its internal processes, roadmap and leadership. They definitely have the lead in AI, Hybrid & Blockchain. Co-location was a good thing for culture and speed. Work life balance is good, and people are very respectful compared to most tech companies in the Bay Area.  I think they're on the right path to turning the company around quickly!
Cons: None that I've noticed so far.

Pros: Challenging work. Great benefits.  Very good opportunities to continually learn and grow. Exposure to global markets and new technology.
Cons: Leadership was very weak in the area I was in. Conflicting goals, lack of vision and  a poor approach.  Horrible execution and a general lack of accountability from cross functional teams. An almost maniacal emphasis on social media and marketing but outdated and overly complex systems and processes bog down work efforts.

Pros: Great people, products, and line managers.  Flexible work environment and facilities.
Cons:
Little to no investment in legacy product line that still generated good revenue. 
Travel policies that did not take the into account the strain on the employee(Flying coach for 20 hours to  a customer engagement is bruta especially true if one is over 6 ft tall).
Bonus plan for employees in a non sales role almost non existent.  
To much customer interaction done via conference call instead of face to face.  
Preach agile but still takes to much time to get new product releases out the door.

Pros:
Lots of opportunities for learning.
Travel.
You have the freedom to do your job how you like. I've never been micromanaged, even in training.
All the managers and execs I've met have been great and very "on-the-ball". Even the ones who are considered "tougher" are still nice and fair, they just have high expectations for themselves and others, which is good.
Good to Great Pay.
Cons:
If you don't like travel or flying, don't go into tech sales or sales here.
Some of the other new hires aren't "on-the-ball", use a lot of buzz words etc...... please don't be one of them.

Pros: no good reasons, this is really the worst company ive ever worked for in 20 years, stay away from this company, there's a reason their stock price has been flat for 7 years
Cons: double standards, too much micromanagement, low salary, high task load, expected to work over time and not get paid, unable to take bathroom breaks or have chance to eat food during the day, the only thing worse than a government job is a gig @ IBM, flex time is given to those who have spouses or children; extreme discrimination against singles, terrible telecommute options, client device has hardware & software issues daily, no helpdesk support

Pros:
Salary and that's about it. IBM seems to focus heavily on frontloading salary and signing bonuses to get people in the door.

The company still looks good on a resume for now.
Cons:
For GBS it's a 44-hour workweek minimum to make utilization targets. The 44 hours thing is set up to dilute our hourly rate on bids. You will not promote if you only put in 44 hours though.

Management is full of fake leaders and buzzwords. There is a great deal of lip-service leadership going around and little actual leadership. Promotion seems based on loyalty and brown-nosing, so many managers in leadership positions don't actually know what they are doing.

Pros: Flexible with work from home, relatively high pay (but low for big tech), some in demand skills and experiences.
Cons: Limited exposure to work with clients, dysfunctional sales methodology. Product roadmaps were very unstable and often rebranded and shifted products in a way that left clients unsure of what they were buying. Many of the software products are created and not maintained, either from FAQs all the way to functionality issues. Also the company really isn't ready to sell in a cloud based world, there are still a lot of perpetual licenses and the company really struggles with selling usage based products like AWS.

Pros: IBM has provided provided abundant training and resources for managers, to change mentality from 'managing' people to Coaching. The concept of coaching makes sense-- its about guiding and helping resources to succeed, bring their best to IBM and show/ contribute to make IBM successful. Times have changed, mindsets have to change and adapt.
Cons: Culture has not changed enough. Coaches who do not seem to get it and leadership that continues to support old thinking.

Pros:
The Benefits are the most impressive in terms of non-monetary support with 401(k), Medical and Work-Life Balance.  Work Life Balance is the best reason at the moment for my high satisfaction.  I work from Home and at this point in my life and current job is a great match for high productivity and satisfaction.

As a matter of recognition and feedback, IBM allows more communication back to the employee and empowers the employee to provide input to how his job will benefit the company and support results to match that commitments.
Cons: Large company and sometime its difficult to move between divisions.  However opportunities are available and its up to the employees to support this growth.

Pros: It's a great place if your in your mid-life or later-life career. The environment is easy going. Fortunately my management is very much on the order of "give the employee goals and let them at it". This lack of micromanagement style is refreshing considering this is almost a 100 year old company.
Cons: Everything is process and procedure. No authority to act in the best interest of the organization even though your judgement is trusted. You need to take the initiative and be assertive on issues. Covering your "ass" is very much in the culture, so beware. As an individual, it takes time to get used to this kind of place and the people who work here.

Pros: Maybe a good place start if you get on a good project, but never a good place to stay. Management does not care about career growth or achievements, only what are you doing for me now and what I can get out of you in the future ... great work in the past is never remembered.
Cons: Management is only concerned about one thing .. utilization. What the utilization is right now and what the 3 month forcast is. There is no long term planning or thoughts. They will have professionals sweeping floors if it helps their utilization. If you do not make your utilization target, you are out the door pretty quick.

Pros:
Lot's of room to move around if you have to but with the lack of communication at times, it's hard to tell if you "need" to move.

Issues that directly affect your position are kept really close to the vest until after the fact. This makes deciding what to do prior to the "event" very hard to prepare for.
Cons: You get lost in the shuffle and support for needed equipment is often denied or forgotten. It often takes several attempts to even get an up or down verdict. This is a VERY large ship and does not turn quickly. If you have a lot of patience, then this might work for you.

Pros: Huge company with a lot of opportunities to try different career options; technical persons get a lot of respect; probably one of the few places left to do research; people respect people; managers spend a lot of time to promote employees and really care about your career development
Cons: very limited business growth opportunities, frequent resource actions in technology division, and as a result compensation is not great, no stock option at all, very little bonus; managers are paid the same or less than engineers; office buildings are in poor condition; almost unusable fitness center for a site with ~5000 employees; health insurance cost is high compared with other high tech employers

Pros: Solid products and services you can believe in.  Wide variety of business units means lots of opportunity to learn.  Worldwide presence also provides many opportunities to experience other cultures and learn.
Cons: The executives (and I was one so I know!) tend to spend most of their time infighting with each other.  They view their peers as competition, because they are so focused on their next job.  Sucking up pays off, giving an executive the honest news but perhaps not what they want to hear can kill your career.

Pros:
No.1 Global Business Consulting
Large Clients with lot of opportunities to grow with learning
Knowledge sharing is easy and great
Consulting Team at clients have good skill mix with experienced professionals and some new hires.
Cons:
Large, huge, Not easy to get Noticed or Promoted
More paperwork to complete with PA and PBC rather than the work at client site
Promotions and compensation are based on the reporting manager who doesnt know what a consultant is doing - where it should be fro the client project manager or team lead.
Growth from one position to another will take atleast 10 yrs unless we kiss a**
To get a training - Is next to impossible when on a project

Pros:
Lots of good people working for the company
Lots of flexibility to work from home and to change jobs.
Good benefits.
Cons:
Many employees were overworked.  
Many U.S. employees were being laidoff and their jobs given to IBM India employees, also to Brazil and Argentina.  
In the past few years I was considered the lucky one if I received a 2% raise. Some depts were given pay cuts.  
The PBC appraisal rating system needs to be scrapped.  I hated receiving a large list of PBC objectives from management that were outside of my control.

Pros: IBM treats you well, both in compensation and professional / technical education, while you are there. You will be offered continual challenges and are expected to make your own way.
Cons: Surprisingly, IBM offers no job security, or stability, even for outstanding achievement. You are expected to make IBM successful, and your reward is in your paychack. There is no guarantee that your achievements will be considered during the continuous "musical chair" strategy IBM uses. Best advice - Get in, excel, and be prepared with an exit strategy.

Pros: Extremely flexible company, as long as you get your work done.  Opportunity to work in wide variety of areas to build professional experience.
Cons: Pay is OK for entry level position, however as you progress in your career and take on additional responsibilities you might be lucky to get one promotion (8% raise). To put it another way you could work 20 hrs / week doing the bare minimum and get paid the same as a top performer who is working 60+ / week. There's no motivation to perform.

Pros: Incredibly dynamic and engaging organization given it's size (we're not talking startup here). Opportunities for career development are abound and there is a lot of flexibility if you are willing to step up and drive your career.
Cons: IBM has been a bit too focused on cost cutting which is hurting employees - salary raises, 401k contributions, IT equipment, etc. Most of those can be overcome with the right attitude and if you're a high performer you will still get the recognition (financially) that you deserve.

Pros: Flexibility in schedule.  401k match is better than most.
Cons: 401k match recently changed so that we get the company match at the end of the year and ONLY get it if we are employed then.  We are challenged to drive and manage technical staff in a fragmented support structure in which accountability is low.  Sometimes you get the impression support teams are doing you a favor in resolving a complex issue.  Much time is spent teaching processes to technical teams with high turn over.

Pros:
When I first started working at IBM I worked with amazingly smart people who mentored and helped me grow professionally and academically.  I was allowed a flexible schedule to be able to continue going to school and finish my MSEE and start on my PhD.  

However, IBM began to pigeon hole me and would not allow me to do new work and I was stuck on a project that I wasn't able to get out of or attempt to correct some problems since it could slow down the rate at which new features were being added.
Cons:
-Messing with benefits constantly
-Salaries are low
-Raises are non-existent
-Ability to move jobs within IBM is meager at best despite what they tell you

Pros: 4 consecutive years of record earnings, record profits, and record cash on hand.  Ability to work remotely can be very helpful.
Cons: Recent management actions show a lack of concern for employees.  In spite of 4 years of record profits, layoffs continue, 50% of employees get no raise at all, health care benefits continue to decrease, retirement plan in place at time of hire was completely taken away, with 61% profit in our business sector in 2012 no bonus was paid because "we didn't meet the target".  Employee morale is the lowest I've seen in my 31 years with the company.  I literally have to buy my own pens and paper.

Pros: Brilliant minds. Dedicated employees. Several positions allow home based offices.
Cons: No raise for 10 years. No chance for advancement. Direct management and second level management had little power.  Zero budget for training or even work related expenses.

Pros: There are pretty good benefits.  Many folks can work from home which is nice. And there are quite a few good people that work there.
Cons: But, the pay is below average.  Yet, they insist they want the best employees and expect that type of performance.  So, there is a disconnect between how they pay their people and what they expect from them.  It is also very bureaucratic.  It is really not worth bringing up new ideas for improvement.  Also, very political, meaning the best person isn't getting promoted, but the one with the correct connections.  Too often, A-holes seem to get promoted.

Pros: Lots of opportunities to learn new technologies. Education is pushed heavily, so if you want to learn the IBM product stack, you'll have the opportunity.
Cons:
Where to start? The 2015 business plan is sucking the life out of employees. Raises are almost non-existant (even for top performers), as is any type of bonus payout. Resources consistently leave, and there is almost no headcount to replace (at least in most areas). The emphasis is driving EPS for stockholders, with little to no regard for the employee. 
IBM has been in business a long time, and I'm sure they will weather this storm, and at some point change strategy. But I don't see that happening in the next few years, which gives me no confidence in them as a current employer.

Pros: There are some pretty aspirational things happening at the company - like using Watson to help cure cancer.  Also opportunities like the Service Corps (a "corporate" Peace Corps) are fantastic if you can get them.
Cons: It's a huge company and it can be difficult to navigate.  If you have a good manager you will be in a much better position to succeed.

Pros: There is a global work force and you get to meet people from other countries.   Working from home is possible.   Lots of custom tools and local support.  You get to share an office with another employee in your team.  You are not micro-managed and you might meet with your manager once a month.
Cons: No real support for Hardware development from the CEO.    Open source of the Power Architecture to anyone shows that IBM is looking for someone else to build the hardware and IBM can just be a software company.

Pros: Mostly excellent people, and great traditions of high product quality and high standards. Good work/life balance policies, strong diversity programs
Cons: Current management is running the company totally to please Wall Street. The core principals of the company - especially the dedication to customers - is being sacrificed.  Employee morale is AWFUL; almost everyone is angry, depressed, or has just given up.  NOT a pleasant place to work at the moment.

Pros: Very rewarding and a great team of coworkers, great international exposure, broad business exposure and challenges with multiple lines of business, and multiple country legal requirements. Management recognition of high performance contributors.
Cons: Working in a global deployment with teams in time zones that contribute to long hours in order to support the development and test teams. Weekend work, reduced personal growth as a result of cost cutting and job eliminations.

Pros: Some of the people with whom I worked were pros for this organization - some of my peers, the technical line staff, and occasionally an executive who understands the balance of delivering well with ensuring overdelivery is avoided.  Executives take the manager's side on most manager-employee disputes.
Cons: They offer very poor compensation vs. the market, and offer no consideration of work-life balance.  People at sub-executive levels literally live in fear of "resource actions" that are executed annually to move more resources offshore for a (currently) favorable price model.  Repositioning the truth to the customer to reflect internal changes in policy or strategy is commonplace.

Pros: Flexible work schedules, ability to work from home for many positions, good pay, and interesting work
Cons: IBM is in decline, management decisions are short-sighted and just focused on the next quarter.  Cost cutting and layoffs are common, and moral and motivation is very low.  The cost cutting and layoffs are damaging IBM's ability to remain competitive.  Raises and bonuses have been almost non-existent the last few years.

Pros:
Instant brand recognition with customers - easy to get in the door
A wealth of support, development, and management resources available
Clearly defined career paths - management encouraged to help with this
Cons:
It is easy to get lost in such a massive organization
Yearly review process is setup so that somebody on the team must get a low mark, regardless of work output
Very difficult to get raises - negotiate a salary you'll be happy with for a while

Pros: If you end up on the right projects, you get interesting challenges and the chance to learn a lot about dealing with large cross-disciplinary teams and messy problems, and even as a recent graduate you can have a really big influence on major products—if you end up on the right projects. You work with some great people, and everyone is really friendly. The design studio (and by extension designers) currently have relatively strong political backing and a lot of pull within the company, so in some cases at least, you get to drive strategic discussions and sit at the table with product managers, dev leads, etc. A lot of big companies are trying to make design work for them right now, and IBM has one of the most serious efforts in this area, so you can learn a great deal about how it might work and how to go about helping an organization become more user focused. A lot of what determines your experience also depends on your attitude and expectations—if you look at challenges as something to learn from, you will learn—if you want an easy job where someone has already figured everything out... You will be disappointed.
Cons: A lot of teams are quite dysfunctional, sometimes for reasons internal to the studio, but usually because of the widespread bureaucracy and politics within the broader company. Also, lot of people choose to work at IBM because they can hide in the vastness and get away with doing next to nothing, so mediocrity and lack of motivation are the norm outside of the design studio. A lot of people are completely out of touch with current trends in technology and design, at least as far as user interface stuff goes. Another downside is the fact that even within the studio, the real goal is just getting to a place where design best practices can be applied, not pushing the field of design forward. There is no need for real innovation or flair, just for applying techniques that were worked out ten years ago to problems defined years before that. While what IBM Design is doing can be quite exciting, there are a lot of exciting things happening at the intersection of design and technology right now, and a lot of them are much more exciting than IBM. Also, expect to be around a lot of people just out of college with little to no perspective.

Pros: The pros are having a job to go to every day. There are so many nice people working there and they help whenever they can. Employees are encouraged to participate in a lot of community involvement and diversity is respected.
Cons: No pay raises ever and they tend to pay under the national and local averages. Promotions are promised but never come to pass no matter how hard you work or how much of your life you devote to your job. You have to be in the right clique at the right time. Managers are not given head count to meet the growing demands of the business.

Pros: Large company with many good people.
Cons:
Direction is faltering. A series of short sighted bad decisions have put IBM behind in most categories. These short sighted decisions still persist today. 
Inter-company rivalry puts one IBMer against another in an increasing escalating cycle. Lack of care/respect for employees is growing as IBMer at all levels fear for their jobs. Lack of communication by management only increase fear uncertainty and doubt about job security.  Salaries lag behind industry

Pros: I have reinvented my career 3 times without ever leaving the company.  I am around highly skilled, highly motivated people that have the abilities to drive the future of technology.  IBM is involved in every aspect of technology.
Cons: The size and bureaucracy can kill productivity at times.  Any organization this large tends to be loaded with A types that have conflicting personalities and power politics can be a problem at times.

Pros: We were initially thrilled to be acquired by IBM. However, the "Blue Washing" started immediately and destroyed everything good and unique about our company and product. While there are some good people (mostly waiting for retirement under the old pension plan), the work at home "benefit" and travel restrictions make it hard to meet them except on conference calls.
