Cons: Terrible technology tools (Lotus Notes / Connections, W3 Intranet broken links, Expense Reporting) and a company run by Financial Engineering have destroyed everything good about IBM. Employee morale is awful with layoff after layoff, decreasing benefits and a culture of fear and mistrust. PBC rankings are used to deny raises and manage employees out yearly.

Pros:
IBM is a dynamic company that promotes  personal and professional growth of the employee. Likewise, it is an organisation that focuses on the innovation and uniqueness inside the market. 

On the other hand, this role will give me the opportunity to develop new skills in a work environment and it allow me to perform my expertise in different roles. Finally, I know that IBM recognises its employees as a person and as an important individual within the organisation. I also like how IBM works together with their employees to motivate and help them achieve their personal goals whilst continuing to improve the growth of IBM.
Cons: In some countries HR recruiting are not willing to help students who want to start or continue working at IBM.

Pros: It looks good on a resume and people immediately respond to the name recognition of IBM. So it has that going for it, which is good I guess.
Cons:
Like most people at IBM, we were acquired. We had high hopes, but they ended when we realized IBM had no interest in our business and certainly no intentions of investing in it to make it work. So we languished on an island for two years -- losing good people the whole time -- all the while being treated with disinterest. Unless they wanted to complain about decreasing revenue. Then they'd take interest.

All in all just a horrible place to work with confusing chains of management and little to no value.

Pros: I love working with IBM.  It mostly works on contacts. If you have a good network within IBM, you can easily move across competencies.
Cons: But the only drawback is Pay., people trying to grow within IBM may get the required role but salary increments do not happen that easily.  Hence career-wise growth  is assured based on your performance but do not expect Hikes equally.

Pros: Global scope the business, sense of real influence over the software industry, excellent peer to peer culture in most places.
Cons: No money for anything, even the business initiatives they claim to prioritize. Labyrinthine bureaucracy around everything, terrible work life balance, salary did not keep up with job market or cost of living.

Pros:
(1) Very strong technical expertise among fellow developers; I have great respect for my friends and colleagues
(2) Salary seems to be competitive in my area
(3) Throughout my career, I've been exposed to lots of useful and modern technologies
Cons:
(1) As a developer, I do not have clear visibility to what's going on with senior leadership. That's good because I care most about developing and testing code on a daily basis, but it's also scary because I don't know where our company is going (and I'm not sure if I like the direction).
(2) There aren't many perks to the job outside of salary: no free food, transportation, etc

Pros: You will meet some of the smartest people addressing very significant problems that have never been solved. Some of the scale of projects that come to IBM are beyond the scope of most competitors. Great place to get training on sales, consulting and specific software or hardware offerings.
Cons: Very bad mid-level management who provide poor information to senior management.  Employees are "resources" that are frequently "rebalanced" to make the balance sheet look good.  Salaries for non-sales are set at the median of the industry. Sales people can do well if properly managed, but eventually the incentives will become punitive.

Pros: Was once a great company with a historic past, I really wanted to like IBM but in the end they really are the monster that I had guessed they would be.
Cons:
Company is now a shell of what it once was, having only been with them for five years in that time they acquired the startup I worked for and they systematically upset our clients and forced out any innovation in the products.  Items that they fail at
HR - there is none it is self serve - good luck finding anything you would think the company that created the hard drive could at least create a usable search engine for company data.
Management - all check the box no real solutions for clients

Pros: I can hardly find a reason to work with them right now except that it pays my bills until I find a new one
Cons:
No work from what so ever.
Micro managing managers/Team leads.
Having worked at both schaumburg and Oakbrook, both are dead, no team lunches, no team building, lunch hour restrictions, not even proper coffee or cutlery on place to have lunch.
If you have an Asian Manager, good luck with dealing with the micromanagement.
If you are moving to Downtown Chicago, good luck with the work life balance

Pros:
-Unlimited Sick Leave
-Some really cool and smart engineers that are willing to work long hours.
-Some snacks
-Decent benefits I guess
Cons:
-Lots of dumb people who need to get purged from IBM.
-Lots of good people who don't get compensated well enough and end up leaving.
-Pay is way below market value.
-Crappy raises/bonuses
-On Call 24/7 is not compensated because of salaried employee.
-Senior management blaming young millennials for product pitfalls.
-Employees are treated like McDonalds fast food employees.
-Cloud Infrastructure looks like crap.
-Internal Employees are the worst to deal with since they escalate everything to Sev 1.
-Lack of motivation and enthusiasm for products.

Pros: IBM is constantly encouraging its employees to learn and grow.  There are so many opportunities available to improve our work, processes and people.  Yes, there are periods when we are swamped with work and cannot take full advantage, but we are always encouraged to make time for growth.
Cons: IBM is currently at a point where market share is an important focus and perhaps employees wish to see higher paychecks and bonuses.  However, IBM is known for its longevity and its ability to rise up from difficult times.  While some employees may not trust that IBM will be able to reward enough, the high performers end up returning because this company will always represent growth and determination to succeed.

Pros: I was in the professional services organization and a fast growing division. The technical aspect of the job was very interesting. Working in a big company has a lots of advantages to expose one to several technologies, professional peers and understand broader industry knowledge. Working from home most of the time is a huge plus.
Cons: Working with global teams is very challenging and counters most of the advantages the position has to offer. The fast growing division succumbed to the shorts falls of being part of a big company. In short great idea with growth potential with less promising future in reality because of the strong competition

Pros:
Flexible work hours, ability to work from home, supportive, caring, 1st and 2nd line management that provide great guidance and regular feedback and constructive criticism, amazing teamwork among peers.  Clearly defined goals and objectives and a willingness as a team to go above and beyond to achieve them.

Good benefits.
Cons: Senior executives don't care about employees or understand the value of institutional memory.  Rampant age discrimination and a policy of secrecy, deflection, resistance to confronting the business and personnel issues in the company

Pros: IBM is a great place to start a career in consulting, but most people leave after a year.
Cons:
The center has a very high employee attrition rate and struggles with retaining top talent. Center employees are put under the same client pressures as their core counterparts, but make a fraction of their salary. Despite being a high performer and delivering value, you'll still feel micromanaged. You're only allowed 2 work from home days a month which is quite frustrating if you travel.

If you probe enough, you'll discover new hires are making more than seasoned employees at the center.

Pros: Got 3% raises and bonuses up to $200
Cons: Management and above are clueless on what their employees do for the business and think they know best when they layoff critical personnel. They should really listen to the people doing the work, it would benefit all parties involved. They should rethink the 12 hour work day and go back to 8 work days, to support personnel redundancy when vacations or time off is used. wages should be better. Most people live paycheck to paycheck. They need to pay people a fair wage to keep up with the changing economy, not pay them just enough to cover basic living.

Pros: IBM is still a good company to work for, often focus are focus on projects and not anything else, lots of tools available for self-learning, team members are very open to share what they know and team members are willing to help each others to get the project done, management is very caring and appreciative
Cons: IBM is splinting into 2 companies in 2021, one will focus more on Cloud Service(IBM) and the other company(NewCo) will focus on IT Service and there are a lot of unknown as to who is going to be which company and which contracts will stay with IBM and which companies are willing to go with NewCo, future isn't that bright for both IBM and NewCo.

Pros: Limitless opportunities, abundance of learning resources to take advantage of, competitive benefits.
Cons:
Your manager can make or break you. If you don't' have an advocate, you will find yourself floating aimlessly in the sea of IBM bureaucracy and leadership negligence. 

Because the company is so large, its difficult to make changes quickly, and adapt to changing needs of both employees and clients. The organization is also very segmented, making collaboration across units a real challenge. Leadership also tends to be incredible secretive and there is no insight into how decisions are made.

Pros: You work with well educated, hard working and ethical people who are also personable, warm, polite and friendly. You work with latest and greatest products and tools in technology. Do not forget - it's IBM and not Apple nor Microsoft that made computers accessible and reliable in every workplace.
Cons: This job is addictive. You might put your personal life on a back seat if you are not careful.

Pros: IBM has some great mentorship programs for individuals seeking to move up in the organization. They also have great benefits if you want to take advantage of all the programs they offer to their employees.
Cons: IBM gets in their own way. They make licensing hard for clients to understand. They are not flexible in their deployment models and they cultivate a disfunctional work environment with in the organization. They can seem like a bully to clients based on how their business units operate.

Pros: Work from home and pay is decent. Depending what division you have a chance for advancement and a possible career here.
Cons: No real advancement. As a contractor to IBM after my Manager who was an IBMer for many years with IBM tried to get me hired directly he finally gave up as he tried for the first few years but it seems once IBM hired you as a contractor they do not want to spend the extra money for benefits if they can you to do that job without paying for them. Since I was stuck with no chance for advancement or a possible career with them that was the straw that broke the camel back for me.

Pros:
Worked there for 5 years as a full time staff engineer.

- Interesting technical projects.
- Some very experienced technical people.
- Will meet good people and friends here.
- You can learn a lot working there.
- Opportunity to work directly with clients in a technical capacity.
- Travel, even international, might be an option depending on your job role.
Cons:
- Pay is OK, but there are other more competitive companies out there.
- Very political, as other big corporate firms are.
- Have to pull lots of strings to get any sort of upward mobility.
- Management can throw you under the bus in an instant and not think twice.

Pros: Flexible schedule, fair amount of time off (3 weeks plus 9 holidays, ample sick time).
Cons: IBM is falling behind the current market. They are not keeping up with salary increases and they are making little effort to retain people.

Pros: Excellent for resume based on well established brand and large enterprise clientele. Good base pay and benefits.
Cons: IBM sales is highly complex, heavily process-driven, and subject to micro-management and over-tooling. The constant change in CRM and other poorly integrated tools as well as annual changes in territories and constant educational experiences and meetings makes it difficult to focus on clients. Work-life balance is almost non-existent. The culture has changed and become politically driven. Quotas are consistently unreasonable and often obviously unachievable, making it hard for sales reps to feel set up for success.

Pros: IBM offers excellent opportunites for career growth.
Cons: IBM touts a "Work/Life Balance" policy, yet expects its employees to work an average of 5 hours of overtime per week.  IBM also recently reclassified over 7000 IT Specialists from salary to hourly, reduced their pay by 15%, and told them they could make it up with overtime.  However, that overtime is not available on all contracts.

Pros:
- Work from home is available and encouraged
- micro-management is a minimum
- good with work/life balance
- respectable place to work
- on the job training for technical jobs is helpful and useful for your career
Cons:
- salary is low and raises are very low even with great year-end ratings
- expectations to always work over 40 hours per week
- always cutting jobs, worry all the time about lay-offs
- awards are far and few between
- employee morale is terrible
- education is cut every year
- too many approvals are needed for everything (education, expenses, OT)

Pros: Company longevity, name recognition; global reach; cold calls are rarely unreturned except in cases where there is a negative predisposition; many exceptionally bright people with the highest standards and best intentions
Cons: Complete lunacy wrt sales quotas - unachieveable at all but focus accounts; as a result, attainment extremely difficult even when you have a fabulous year; popular myth that opportunities are legion - they only exist if first assignment is highly successful; if not a fit, there are few optys to recover; high level of arrogance at even low levels within org; organizational structure highly complex requiring much 'feeding the machine'

Pros: Reputation, branding, diversity, wide variety of experts in many areas.  Company is universally known so hopefully it will help former employees get their next jobs.  Some opportunities exist to work from home although in the consulting group, too much time is spent at client sites and traveling.
Cons: Poor compensation, compensation is not tied to performance, bonuses are poor, unclear promotion and compensation criteria.  In consulting, one of the advantages is supposed to the ability to be vendor neutral when recommending new systems for implementation.  However IBM tries to force IBM hardware and software to its consulting services clients rather than going with the best vendor for a particular situation.

Pros:
* Large company, lots of room to join different groups
* Bound to have very competent, intelligent people working alongside you
* No myth about bureaucratic processes dragging down development
* Most manager very fliexible about work, life balance
* Many career development opportunities, perks that only a large company could offer 
* Jobs being outsourced
Cons:
* Lots of lifers, particularly management who have no clue about life outside of IBM
* Lots of layoffs, even while company is doing okay.  IBM hides layoffs as resource actions to avoid having to report.  5000 people can apply for 5 open jobs.

Pros:
- Bright, nice colleagues; not a cut-throat environment
- Generally, a strong (and real) emphasis on work/life balance compared to other firms
- Large company with opportunities to transfer to non-consulting roles 
- Reasonably good job security
Cons:
- Lack of an up and out policy limits upward mobility; executives find comfortable roles where all that is required of them is showing up to a few meetings each week
- Management has never trusted current staff - almost all "Partners" are hired from the outside  
- Consulting services were hit hard by the down economy; some practices have dissolved from RIFs and departing staff and will take a few years to recover

Pros:
* Good people to work with, with some really stellar folks
* Nearly any important company or government in the world is a customer
* Good benefits
* If you're on a good project that's doing well financially, it can be fun (and a lot of work)
* Well known, well-respected company
Cons:
* Expense tightening is getting a little too much 
* Committees for everything as a way to avoid personal decision making
* Compartmentalization of roles can be extreme
* Antiquated systems and processes (green screens, and Lotus Notes needs a serious overhaul)
* Interruptions and crisis mode are a way of life 
* Politics can be soul crushing
* It's a Big Machine

Pros:
Free schedule: as long as you get the work done, it doesn't matter as much as other companies where or when you do it.
Entry level graduates can accelerate quickly in the first 3 years before stalling out.
Good Benefits
Fully vested in 401k from the start.
Cons:
Pay less than competitors
Too big of a company
Mandatory 44 hour work week
Expectation to do Human Resource rolls and other 'give back' to compete with your peers for year end ratings

Pros: Professional to the core. No arrogance about the great work that is done. Client is king. Work hard to maintain strong partnerships. Great technology that can change the world.
Cons: Professionalism can read as too stuffy or boring. While there are some fun events such as a quarterly afternoon with beer and music, it isn't Google/Apple/Facebook-type fun. No awesome bands coming to play, etc.

Pros: IBM has a culture of honesty. It is common to find people that are very committed to the success of their projects. The benefits are top-notch. The company communicates in advance what it intends to do and follows those plans.
Cons: New growth is outside the US, where skills have been much weaker. Managers are given very little opportunity to reward employees or help them with advancement. Bureaucracy sucks the lifeblood out of eager employees. Departmental targets are set in such a way that even high revenue departments can miss targets and thereby not be allocated funds to reward staff.

Pros: Company has good benefits and allows you to easily change job roles if another role interests you. Terrific access to above region experts, SMEs, solution evangelists
Cons: Cost cutting measures over the years have almost eliminated sales support staff, increasing non-revenue producing activity.  Also, severe cuts to technical and services roles delays sellers ability to act quickly in a sales process.  Extreme pressure to meet 2015 plan to reach double digit profits has driven down morale across the board. Management layer still too heavy and non-revenue producing. Company needs to keep boots on the street who generate revenue for the company

Pros:
-Salary was good.
-You pretty much work entirely from home or a clients site.
Cons:
- Turn over is a very big problem, at least in the business unit I worked in.
- In 2 years went through 6 direct managers and really only talked to them once a month, maybe.  You are really left on your own to manage most aspects of your job.
- As an employee, getting support for IBMs own products is very difficult.  I found it easier to have the clients ask IBM support for help on issues than trying to go through the IBM channels.
- No training, you are expected to learn everything on the job.
- As a consultant, there is no real career growth.

Pros: Variety in job opportunity, possible to reinvent yourself and access to the best research department in the world.
Cons: Difficult to navigate, achievement is available to those who spend their time self-promoting and networking.  The commitment to IBM is 24x7, difficult to have work-life balance.  IBM and their clients demand real-time anytime access and response making it almost impossible to vacation or have time away with family with out taking conference calls and doing follow ups.

Pros: Strong support and training available, smart colleagues, (relatively) stable company, always a challenge around the corner. IBM treats it's entry level employees fairly well, and the health care offered is fantastic.
Cons: Like others have said, as a consultant prepare to work long hours with clients that may not hold IBM in the highest regard. Also, in the near 2 years I've worked here, the companies financial performance has been declining. That has definitely reduced morale around the office, and the feeling by those around me is "why try hard this year, there are no bonuses anyway"

Pros: Working for IBM so you can say you worked for IBM, remembering it's past.
Cons: Working for IBM is not the IBM that you envision.  You're overworked so much that you can't learn anything new or retain any new training.  Their trainers are all foreign and difficult to understand, their benefits packages are one of the worst in the industry.  Their recruiters try to sell you on an IBM that's state of the art, the only thing state of the art with IBM is Watson, everything else is sub par with other offerings in the industry.  You'l get used and abused and then thrown away.  Ask anyone that's been there for over 10 years.

Pros: Great work experiences in my 25 year career! Performed many different job functions over the course of my career there!
Cons: Since the shift towards CAMSS, seems like they are purposely shedding employees. They refuse to train unless employees are out of college. I have only positive feelings though towards the company, I just hope they come to their senses soon!

Pros: Great technology, intelligent people and seem to no where they need to go to be considered a market leader in the flash business.
Cons: No collaboration between business units because of IBM's concern of over compensations

Pros: IBM is filled with wonderful people who have created and work in a consensus-based environment that encourages teamwork and collaboration.   Although weaker than in the past, the company retains a large number of highly skilled, innovative technical leaders capable of competing succesfully in the market.
Cons: Although some improvements were made in 2015, the company has been laser focused on short term profits and EPS targets for the past 10 years, resulting in a long slow decrease in core innovation and level of technical talent.

Pros: Multitude of opportunities, eclectic interest groups, broad geographical dispersion of jobs (where do you want to work?), work from home possibilities
Cons: Company was more interested in diversity than shareholder value, being politically correct than increasing sales and profitability, cutting US workforce and outsourcing jobs than maximizing employee potential.  More than once I heard "this is not your father's IBM," and sadly, it was true.  Pay increases were nonexistent, even for top performers.  Advancement?  Forget it, especially if you were over 40.  Month-end focus?  Check.  Long-term focus?  Nope! Everything was built around Wall Street expectations, which were never met.  IBM is yesterday's company, not tomorrow's.

Pros: Great breadth of products to sell, including cutting edge technologies such as Watson. Name recognition in all areas of information technology, with a 100+ year history of helping companies solve business problems with technology. Best of breed software products built through development and key acquisitions.
Cons: Due to its size, IBM has challenges in changing to meet volatile market dynamics. At the individual client level, sales strategies are often driven by constantly changing compensation plans.

Pros: Competitive salary, flexibility, good work-life balance. If you have a good Manager (I did), you have a lot of autonomy.
Cons:
Benefits while very good are also very pricy. You’d expect much lower premiums than you actually pay. 

If you work from home, there’s a reason it’s called “I’m By Myself”. Desktop support is a last resort when you have an issue. And you literally have a serial number. 

They fill your head with “so many opportunities!”, but the reality is that it’s just as difficult to move around in IBM as it is to get your foot in the door - you have to know someone.

Pros: Stability reputation experience global reach, IBM as a research firm with strong analitics and over 100 years of existence will mean when appropriate, we can bring more capability to the table than our nearest next 5 competitors
Cons: Lack of experience of first line management means they are sometimes more idealistic than they are knowledgeable about industries and client situations

Pros: Very good research .  Powerful company that can leverage its size to make deals happen.  Very good place to get initial experience.
Cons: Different parts of the company are in competition with each other.  Management  is lacking a compelling vision and very dumb decisions are often made.  Reorgs happen about every 6 months, and take a while to execute. During that time, workers are paralyzed and very little gets done.

Pros: People, flexibility, work/life balance is pretty good in Austin (might be different in other markets), culture in Austin is really good, lots of opportunities to move around the company if you want to, salaries are pretty competitive, incredible paid family leave policies and good benefits and 401K match
Cons: Heavily matrixed, highly bureaucratic and political. The "escalation" culture is a problem in many parts of the business leading to poor decision making and sub-par work because someone more senior demanded.  It is very challenging to get into senior leadership unless you're willing to participate in the politics. Success often means taking on 2-3 different jobs at a time. Bonuses are non-existent inside of marketing.

Pros: I love IBM. I was in college intern in the summer of 2019 and now I am a full time employee. The culture is kind, hardworking, innovative, and encouraging. We know IBM is not the coolest kid on the block (of tech companies) but we are passionate to help IBM grow because of all the neat work and technologies we have here. What I appreciate most about working at IBM is how understanding the people are. The company really treats us well.
Cons: It is quite oversized and some parts are siloed because it is big. Makes it hard to disrupt the industry.

Pros:
- Good pay
- Solid job security 
- Brand name
- History of the company
- Good room for growth
Cons:
- The oldest systems and technology, IBM talk's about innovation when all they use is the oldest email systems, databases that are outdated, and non-functional reporting platforms
- No transparency or communication, if you ask for help people either direct you to the wrong places or don't care to help you at all 
- Takes 4 - 6 weeks to get onboarded and you don't have access to the systems until you finish the training
- Even when you are fully ramped up, it's a circus every day for how things operate

Pros: 1.Great and convenient workplace and work model. 2.Big learning opportunity. 3.Ethical and inclusive workplace.
Cons: 1.Weak employee retention policy. 2.Managers are not real career advocates. They don't really care for employees career growth. 3.Bad employee evaluation. 4.Hiring employees with non-technical background in technical roles, and vice versa. 5.Average salaries compared to the market standard.

Pros: I work with a great team. My 1st line Manager is awesome, he is very sensitive to my religious beliefs and practices. I left IBM for a personal issue for a few months, but came back because of my Second Line Manager. He is always looking out for his reports and very fun to work with. Great Work Life balance.
Cons: I love working with people around me but after covid and when we went remote I got more work done but newer ideas, and the social nearness is missing. Rest of the folks do not want to comeback to office to work. I wish they do.

Pros: Smart people, challenging projects, name recognition of your company. It can be a fun place to be, and you see a lot of useful information that comes across the transom almost accidentally. If you hunt, you can find some info that just isn't available anyplace else.
Cons: The smart people aren't always where you are, the challenging projects aren't, either.  There's a lot of grunt labor that has nothing to do with the stuff that generates the name recognition. Pay isn't very good unless you're a star. The sense is that senior management is running scared, and their paternal style doesn't allow them to frankly ask for help.  They do try, but only intermittantly.

Pros: You have very good job security and flexible work hours at IBM. My current manager permits me to work from home, which is terrific. Not all managers at IBM are like that, though.  I really like that there's a credit union on site. The fitness and recreation center is nice too.
Cons: Red tape and bureaucracy are burdensome. The "climate" varies dramatically between departments and projects. It's really hard to stomach the fact that Sam "earned" a $40M bonus, and many of us have not had a raise in several years. There are internal hiring rules that prevent an employee in one division (SWG) to obtain a new position in another division (STG).

Pros: IBM fully supports diversity in the workplace.  It has strong programs in place to promote women and minorities.  People managers are given wide latitude to deal with personnel problems and to work with their direct reports in resolving issues.
Cons: It's very big.  Because of the number of people and the 'layers' required to manage an organization as big as IBM, it's sometimes difficult to find the right person to talk to.  It can be difficult to navigate through the processes to get assistance with issues related to work being performed for a client.

Pros: Cutting edge innovative company that values its employees. Be ready to work very hard but be paid fairly for the work that you do. Great learning opportunities are available for all employees. Company values its position in the market and is constantly innovating in order to meet customer needs.
Cons: Big company so implementing new ideas can be a tedious process. Work life balance is not great if you really want to get ahead. If you are not looking for speedy advancement, then good work life balance is possible. Some employees have been around for a many years and believe they are entitled to things because of their seniority. This can create problems for younger employees like myself.

Pros: Great opportunity to move around during your career. Excellent education opportunities.  Great innovation with large dollars spent on R&D (#1 in patents for 15 years).  Decent benefits. Very flexible work hours. Working from home with budget for home office.
Cons:
Off shoring, downsizing, forced moves, too much work per technical worker, bureaucracy abounds, fat upper management.  

Respect for the individual has declined, but all companies now days treat employees as an asset instead of a person, until you are not longer considered an asset , thus terminated.

Pros: Excellent learning opportunities and very supportive culture.  This company does a very good job of capturing knowledge and promoting continuous education.  Time and learning materials are provided to employees and you are given the freedom to direct your learning activities as you desire to reach your personal career goals.  If you like travel, learning and people then you will like this job
Cons: bureaucratic advancement scheme and occasionally a lack of challenging work.  It can be difficult when you come off of a high paced project and don't immediately have a new project to begin.  This, however provides a good opportunity to support knowledge sharing and take some courses.

Pros: The work and working conditions are very reasonable for the wages paid. Work at home is a great incentive that actually improves productivity while increasing flexibility.  Managers generally allow for a great deal of autonomy and trust in their employees. The means and accommodations when traveling are comfortable (no Motel 6).  The opportunity for promotion and variety of profession is very good.
Cons: Constant threat of "resource actions" that could cost you your job (annual occurrence). As with any large companies, the processes are so cumbersome as to cause business losses to competitors. IBM remains the most expensive provider or products and services, but they are likely to survive downturns when their customers need them.

Pros: Great Global  Connections.  Leader in the forefront on green technology.  Professional coworkers.  Great for working from home or in mobile offices.
Cons: The culture at IBM is to work all day everyday.  If you were to close your laptop and leave around 5ish you would  feel guilty.  Project Managers from other departments create additional work for the understaffed finance departments.    Professional movement up the ladder is bureaucratic at best and very tough to do deal with.

Pros:
+ smart colleagues
+ LOVED the working from home
+ good starting salary (but see below - they gave COL increases but raises weren't great)
+ tons of autonomy and challenges
+ lots of opportunities to transfer internally
+ Research group is great
+ client focus
Cons:
- work being moved offshore -- constant threat of lay-off -- very unnerving
- managers are useless politicians
- employees below exec level (so, band 10 and under) treated like muppets
- senior mgmt detached & largely clueless
- mandatory rah-rah conferences in vegas 
- stay out of GBS!  they work consultants to death
- small salary increases

Pros: Lots of smart people.  A pretty good reputation across many industries and job roles.
Cons: The 2015 Roadmap as published to Wall Street is driving stupid decision, after stupid decision, after stupid decision.  The top doesn't seem to notice or care that things are breaking everyday, with more and more consequences for those who remain.  It's like plugging holes in the dike when the rain is pouring down and every minute there is a new leak.  Eventually the dike breaks.

Pros: Pretty flexible work times, except if you have to work with ibmers overseas you have to use your personal hours, dinner/breakfast time to be on calls with different time zones. No personal time available anymore.  Work comes in waves.  When it's busy it's really stressful.  We are finally starting to hire some new hires and new blood into the company.  Still pretty top heavy and hard to move up.
Cons: It seems like our budget for anything is smaller and smaller every year when we are reporting record profits. Healthcare benefits aren't great. A lot of out of pocket costs.  They are outsourcing a lot.

Pros: The company is determined to increase shareholder value by reaching their 2015 goal.
Cons:
They will do whatever it takes to get there. So much for respect for the individual as a basic belief.

I joined IBM 29 years ago as an engineer. At that time engineers were recognized as the core of the company. Now engineers are a seen as necessary, but are largely ignored by upper management. Management is now focused on  vague marketing slogans like cloud computing and smarter planet. Engineers are cut when the aggressive division goals are not met.

Pros: There are many opportunities to change positions/specialties/focus areas without having to go find a job at a different company.
Cons: As a sales person, I started out in a local office with frequent face-to-face contact with management. Ultimately I was laid off by a manager I had never met in person.  I have heard that there are plans to rebuild an office/collaborative/supportive environment, which is needed in order to help employees feel connected to resources and learn how to navigate the complex structure of a large corporation from more experienced IBMers.

Pros: IBM is a great company, that provides top corporate benefits.  Very flexible with work/life balance, vacation, etc.  Working here will give you exposure to top solutions and innovations in industry
Cons: Typically the pay scale/earning potential is lower here compared to smaller technology companies.  In addition, this environment creates complacency with the employee.  If they don't believe they will be rewarded then why go the extra mile.  In addition, large company that is changing direction in changing industry means regular resource actions resulting in many lay-offs.  Lay-offs happen that are not always based on Job Performance

Pros:
- Flexible work schedules and locations, work from home options, offices everywhere
- A big name company
- So big and poorly managed that you can coast while you look for a new job
Cons:
Everything about IBM's software group is so backwards, behind the times, and inefficient - the leaders, the technology, how they work, etc. 

They only people who speak well about IBM are those who have been with the company since they were 22 and have pension plans waiting for them.  The positive reviews here on Glassdoor are all fake and from their HR department.

Pros: Got a chance to work with a company who is transitioning to a better future
Cons:
Overworked, underpaid, and managment/leadership does not care about the contractors not the other IBMers that work underneath then

There is a glass ceiling for all races, genders, sexes, etc for EVERYONE to break through as far as advancing your career

No time given to take the IBM endorsed course that could give you the skills you need to advance

Many people hear your ideas, concerns, or suggestions but do not do anything to improve how the team functions as a whole (and when they do listen, they pass your ideas off as their own)

Pros: There are a lot of great reasons to like my team and position: I work 100% remotely and get to partner with people all over the world; my schedule is usually pretty flexible; I get to work on a variety of interesting projects; and I work with really smart and creative people and have learned a lot from them.
Cons: Working 100% remotely can be a bit isolating, but the pros far outweigh the cons of this. Many positions are contract so if you're not comfortable with that, might be hard to get on with the company.

Pros: Proud to say you work for "Big Blue." Feels like a sense of career accomplishment. Well established company with a long history.
Cons: Too many Chiefs & Indians. Expect to have a 1:1 conversation with a customer you can forget it. So many different departments all wanting to get their fingers in your account or opportunity. Legacy IBMrs have a sense of entitlement when in actuality they should be made to retire. Their "old school" way of thinking is what has them following AWS. Lotus Notes (IBM owned) for email, give me a break. Doesn't integrate with Salesforce but then, IBM uses its own CRM, SalesConnect which is terrible. Let's just say I was proud to work there but the name doesn't live up to the hype.

Pros: Great innovative company with great stability, if you are in a high growth area.
Cons:
The company is ultra conservative and when times are average or bad for the company everyone pays the price.   In consulting even if your practice is preforming extremely well and destroying revenue and gross profit goals (at record levels) you are ignored and cut backs hurt everyone, which costs us good people.    
Another major negative is pay is much below average for many high growth consulting areas, and sr mgt doesn't care.  Very much treated as if it is a privileged for us to be allowed to work there and we should be thankful for just that.

Pros:
-Brilliant people. 
-Diverse teams.
-Great happy hours.
-Job security (in Public Sector in DC).
-Best benefits in industry.
-Awesome work/life balance
Cons:
-Government clients are morons, though I guess that why they need us.
-Management is doing its own thing, meaning not thinking about you.
-Bureaucratic assessment and promotion system is tedious and useless.
-Separate day-to-day manager and career manager (who you may meet once if you're lucky). 
--Guess which one is responsible for your promotions?
-Worst salary in industry.
-Working in government office because they are old and dreary (in Public Sector in DC).
-Working with out-dated technology  (in Public Sector in DC).

Pros: You are allowed to work independently or as the member of a team with minimal supervision.
Cons: Management is following the direction from above to reduce costs wherever possible.  Unfortunately, this does not align with the company publicly stated goals.  While the company states that customer satisfaction is top priority, key resources are stripped from account support teams and moved over to lower cost labor pools overseas. Service quality is reduced, overall morale is low, and many customers are supported by teams that have little or no understanding of the systems that they support.

Pros: Its a big company, you can shuffle around if you want. There is always stuff to do, or places to hide if you don't want to do anything...
Cons: It is a dinosaur stuck in its old bureaucratic ways. Upper level management continually forces down irrelevant new rules designed to cut headcount without calling it as such. Given the current lack of raises and bad policies has created an incredibly negative work environment.

Pros: Great place for early career learning, both on the job and company sponsored education. Lots of opportunity to grow responsibilities and your career. Somewhat flexible work arrangements have been ratcheted back recently, but lots of options still exist.
Cons: Personnel management is terrible at middle and executive levels. All the focus is on business drivers / metrics, Too much pressure on short-term financial goals for personnel managers to spend time with employees.

Pros:
- There are many exciting paths your career can take...there is no excuse to be bored!
- Leadership recognizes and values diversity.
- IBM is willing to invest in your skill development as long as you are too.
- While a lot is demanded of you as an employee, IBM is an empathetic company that recognizes the importance of work-life integration and balance.
Cons:
- Because there is never a dull moment, you can wake up and 20 years have passed
- Transformation never stops at IBM, so catching your breath can be hard

Pros: Working from home, good teammates, good work-family mix.
Cons: In her quest to turn IBM into a purely Cloud and Cognitive company, Ginni has trampled across the lives and careers of some her most loyal employees. If you're not part of this group, you will be forever looking over your shoulder and asking, "Am I next?" This recent RA, in which all the affected people I know, were all sprouting gray hairs, iis a 100% RA of older IBM'ers; no question. This, along with her naked firings in 1st world to hire in 3rd world, shows that IBM is on the ropes both in technology and finances.

Pros: Great place to learn and be able to do whatever you like to do, you aquite on your own.
Cons: You can give your heart out and company will not appreciate you, no holiday parties, no bonuses, people are all over the place, you totaly on your own.

Pros:
Opportunities to grow a career in many different directions
Access to great people and a variety of work experiences. 
Taking initiative is encouraged.
Good corporate value structure, very inclusive.
Cons: Change and transformation is constant leading to lots of turnover especially in sales jobs. Client-facing roles in newer solution areas have to grapple with prejudice against possible IBM innovations. Difficult to get across the middle management line to become an executive. Lots of overhead of administration, company mandated programs that don't add value to clients. Inconsistent management quality.

Pros: IBM has a large amount of opportunities. The more you take advantage of them, the more you get back. I’ve found a large majority of the people to be extremely friendly. You also have the ability to build your career by the projects you work on and the people you network with.
Cons: The company is so big and can be confusing at times. It’s currently going through a huge transformation and I don’t think the C-Level’s have a clear end goal in site. There’s a lot of bureaucracy. It leaves a lot of talent untapped.

Pros: IBM is a great place to start a career.  Good benefits as well as work-life balance.
Cons: Don't stay too long.  I didn't see much of an opportunity for professional development or upward mobility.  In 18 years I saw very few people who were able to move up in the organization beyond a band level. .  Training budgets were always minimal.  There was also an ever-present threat of being laid off .

Pros:
IBM is a great company and another face of innovations which make impact on world. It is having great work culture, tremendous opportunities to learn on job as well as through digital offerings. You can choose the technology of your interest and excel into it. IBM provides great opportunities to work in all domains when you are ready to take the challenge. 
Provides great work life balance and you can reach out to great fellows in IBM who authored books which you used in your engineering education.
Cons:
Compensation growth is slow, not at par with market.
Large organization so difficult to navigate through different business units.

Pros: Big name in business, lots of contacts, lots of different jobs, competitive salary at hiring time.
Cons: Lays large numbers of people off regularly regardless of job performance.  Very poor compensation adjustment over time, outdated and time consuming yearly review cycle that reaps little to no benefit for employee or management, lack of billable projects puts you on the bench a lot which is negative.  Report directly to someone in a different state you will never meet.

Pros: Flexibility and very challenging work assignments in CIO organization.  Company has improved in many areas in the last few years making it more inviting to "junior" level workers.
Cons: Bitterness from IBMers that have been through the difficult times and worked under poor leadership are at the surface.  Conflicting internal processes and lack of willingness to accept certain facts as roadblocks makes certain roles extremely frustrating when attempting to enable processes through IT delivery.  Company will have skilled employees train and coach less skilled employees and then lay them off, using their complex band and role matrix to avoid the appearance of certain lay off practices.

Pros: As a new employee IBM recurits hard. They are looking for the best in class ,so if you get a call from a posting know that you are a standout . Once you get setllted into your new role you will notice that everyone is there to make you a better professional .
Cons: As with any large legacy org. There is a lot to grasp cultre ,policy etc. Being in tech. Change is not on the horizon but is an everyday occurance . Once you are a part of the IBM team personally you have to commit to being the change .

Pros: The C-Suite of IBM is fully committed to its transformation. In my 10-year career at IBM, this is the first time where I have seen the entire corporation aligned around a single strategy with a clear path of execution. I am observing an emerging belief across the sales organization in our new leadership and their ability to get the company onto a strong path of growth.
Cons: Change is hard. It's tough for teams to go through this transformation but the rewards are coming quickly as clock speed is a priority.

Pros: It's software technology and patent portfolio are impressive. At IBM you can work on software projects ranging from mainframes to PCs and the disciplines vary from firmware, operating system and compiler development. Development labs are scattered but multi site software development has been something that IBM has always embraced and known how to do. Being close to IBM Almaden was good as we could cross polinate with research and bring some of the research ideas into products, sometimes very successfully but other times not so. IBM seems to have its fingers in every pie and this was one of the reasons why it appealed to me to work there.
Cons: Outsourcing threats. Building up teams outside of the United States in China and India.

Pros: Flexible work schedule and the ability to work at home.  Communication and technology surpasses most other companies.
Cons: Sr Mgmt cares little about workers.  They are seen as dispensible.  IBM states they are fair in evaluations but then they put limits on the ratings employees can receive.  IBM is claiming they are leading the way in salaries but their marketing tool is that they are now bringing salaries up to the midpoint of industry standards.  In the end, it is shareholders that IBM cares about - not the workers.  Its a tough environment to excel compared to your peers while still balancing work life issues.

Pros: resume builder, experience, ability to learn from others.  The benefits are very good, hands down.  The 401k match is the best in the consulting industry.  You will be able to learn a great deal in a very short time frame
Cons: very large, too bureaucratic, managers with poor people skills.  There are a good number of managers who are out to benefit themselves and no one else.  They get bonuses based on their staff utilization and meeting numbers.  Many IBM employees are just numbers to the staff.  Its all about who your manager is at IBM.  Bad manager = bad experience.  Good manager = good experience.

Pros: Flexibility and the work environment is very professional.  Everyone is willing to help one another and there are abundance or resource when needed from either peer or co-worker.  It has a large supporting network.
Cons: The pay is not as competitive and advancement within the company is very minimal.  More over, there are many layers of redundancy in the company that can be eliminated.  Sometime it feels like too many management personnel running around asking for the same status.  It's like going in circle asking each other for the same status.  Bottom line, too many people asking for status and not enough people working on the actual problem.

Pros: Large company with a lot of opportunities to move around if they aren't downsizing. They also have a lot of opporutnities for continued education if you take advantage of it.
Cons: Too big, they don't seem to notice who does what, when. Managers don't spend enough time managing down to their team, which is their best asset. It is hard to get noticed for doing anything significant and you can be moved around a lot without being asked for input. Once you learned where you where, they reorganized and moved you.

Pros: IBM honestly cares about my personal and professional growth.  Granted not all will feel that way, but top talent IS given top treatment.  You can reinvent yourself in many ways at IBM -- which I've been able to do.  Because it is such a big place you have the ability to move around functions, business units and geographies.  This takes self-initiative.  In other words, don't just expect it to happen.  I feel a great sense of job security here, even now.  I'm proud to be an IBMer and won't be leaving anytime soon!
Cons: IBM is a big place.  There are many of us, we're globally integrated, and quite often meetings are virtual.  If you aren't comfortable with that, don't come here -- but welcome to 2009!

Pros: One good thing about IBM is that you can move between jobs in different areas and get a lot of different experiences. With the poor economy this is harder than it used to be, but still is possible.
Cons: Sales jobs are just terrible. The quotas are not reasonable and intense micromanagement. The sales management tools are just archaic and are not integrated so you have to enter the same data multiple times on a weekly basis.

Pros: Name recognition. IBM still has the name brand recognition and cachet cachet that goes with a technology company which certainly helps with resumes. The majority of the people working at the company are intelligent, trustworthy and competent.
Cons: There is too much focus on expenses, awards are nonexistent, salary increases are a joke, and even performance pay is taking a hit to where you are slowly being trained to not expect any at all no matter how good of a job to do.

Pros:
Wide breadth and reach of the company.
Better than average salary and excellent benefits.
Amazing networking opportunities
It's THE IT outsourcing firm
Cons:
No investment in tools
Annual layoffs of 2 - 4 % of the U.S. workforce, so either you will be hit or your co-worker will, in which case you will have to do their work as well as your own.
No investment in training.

Pros: IBM is a company struggling to find its identity.  It has purchased many companies over the past few years but it doesn't seem to know if it is a software or consulting company.  If you are a rep and get a good commercial territory you can make money.
Cons: Very political.  If you are part of the insiders club, and are willing to be a yes man, then this is a good place to work.  Fly above the radar and have original thoughts and you will get your wings clipped, regardless of how smart or successful you are.

Pros: Large Clients; good place to learn fast; strong peer group
Cons: slow decisions making; cumbersome internal processes; lots of politics and turf wars; inconsistent compensation policy

Pros:
They have an official work from home policy
Flexible work hours
Cons: Constant cutting of benefits.  First, they took 15% of our pay.  Then they took overtime.  Then they took away reimbursement for needed items.  Then they changed the work week to start on Saturday to prevent overtime.  Lastly, they changed 401k matching to end of year lump sum.  So if you leave early, you forgo all matching for the year.

Pros: - many different job opportunities because of the size of the company (if your manager lets you leave the team)
Cons:
- shameless self-promoters who take credit for others work make it the farthest
- hard, quality work is not rewarded
- pay is awful unless you come in from an acquisition. Getting the highest rating every review period even results in very small raises and bonuses (~5%)
- executives are driven by their own success instead of what is best for the company
- executives are out of touch with the market do not listen to employees who actually talk to customers
- product development and delivery processes slow down and stifle innovation 
- because of the above, no one is motivated to work hard or fast

Pros: IBM has flexible work schedule for consultants. You can work from any location. That is very productive.
Cons: No incentive for the employees to work hard for the company. The yearly employee performance review/rating is based on your contributions to the company relative to other employees in your team. That does not make sense to me. My team had very strong results last year and all members in the team have  similar contributions, but under the current rating system, there is only a fixed percentage of members who can receive the exceptional rating, which is not fair in my opinion.

Pros: I really wish I had some... I have been around IT for decades and used to really respect IBM... they have lost their way and I dont think they can recover.
Cons:
Horrible leadership
Micromanagement
Horrible hiring practices
Unskilled and untrainable personnel
Little to no promotion or raise potential
Dubuque site is just an slave labor sweat shop
High burnout and stress with no help or care from management
Good talent is constantly pushed away while the horrible people are promoted and allowed to keep doing a horrible job.

Pros: History of this company is exceptional. Training was excellent at the time of my transition in. Professional employees who are dedicated, competent  and personable. Workload fluctuates and expectations are relatively clear and communicated well in certain divisions.
Cons: Values used to be strong and clear, but these have disintegrated and moral has diminished greatly. Individual employee value seems almost non-existent.

Pros: Many employees are allowed, if not encouraged, to work from home.  There is also a long list of discounts that IBMers can access, offered by hotels, retailers, car rental companies, and more.
Cons: There is a narrative at IBM: we have challenges, but they have been identified and we're meeting them effectively.  We are on the cusp of being dominant again.  Any news, event or opinion that does not conform to or support this narrative is either ignored or contradicted.  Executive management spends more time cheerleading than actually leading.

Pros: Working in a big company such as IBM can provide lot of opportunities and diverse roles to don. Your work can take you to different places and get you to meet diverse set of people. If you have joined the company with a good salary it can work out in your favor. The brand name can help you if you intend to switch in the future.
Cons: As any big company it is extremely bureaucratic, so its absolutely necessary to build a strong impactful network if you want to get things done or even to grow. Bonuses are a joke. Growth can be painfully slow if you can't find your godfathers or godmothers in the company.

Pros: The company pays for an excessive amount of training. The experience provided from working with the company is priceless.
Cons: The company has issues keeping the employees on project due to many new hires having little to no experience. As well there is no room for growth and pay is below market average. Most stay for a year at the longest to get the experience and training. Managers have a hard time keeping qualified employees. Another issue is regardless if you work 40 hours a week or 500 hours a week you get paid the same. Some spend much of their time working getting paid little.

Pros: This is a great place to work, there are many different things that you can get involved within and it has such potential for students who are looking for experience.
Cons: You can very quickly be overcome with the amount of work that you take on, you must be careful and manage your time correctly. As there are so many options choose the primary ones you would find most helpful for your future career.

Pros: Work life balance is nice.  I travel alot in my free time and the hours are flexible to accomadate that.  Great teammates.  The job is fun.
Cons: Upper management doesn't have a clue.  Keep laying off older experienced employees but don't hire anyone to replace them.  They also slashed bonuses this year while rewarding the CEO/board

Pros: flexibility, life/work balance, recognized name
Cons: lack of loyalty, short sighted, unethical

Pros:
-Flexible work schedule
-Great benefits (health, 401k, adoption, maternity/paternity leave, health wellness incentive)
Cons:
-The products are released and marketed as if it's ready to be used but that is rarely the case
-Too many similar tools are used and so it takes up a lot of time to figure out where to go for what 
-Management does not help provide actual career development. HR is reached through an employee service line; no real human contact

Pros:
Your success at IBM is wholly dependent on your manager.  I was lucky, I had a great manager. 

Remote work - though they are trying to take this away
Benefits - decent enough, not earth shattering but they didn't break my bank
401K match - good, but it was paid out only in December
Cons:
work/life - balance is non existent, you will be expected to travel at a drop of a hat
Identify crisis - IBM has no idea who it wants to be as a result there are are constant re-orgs, shifts in management, and focus

Pros:
1. Some smart people at the lower levels. 
2. Work from home option.
Cons:
1. Yearly layoffs for the last 15+ years. 
2. 1000's of US jobs moved to other countries for cost savings. 
3. No useful training. 
4. Upper management out of touch with day to day activities at lower levels. 
5. No value and respect for the employee. 
6. No respect for their customers. 
7. No innovation. 
8. If you think IBM is good place to work you have been fooled by them.

Pros: Innovation, good work/life balance, good benefits, great, wonderful teammates. Watson has the potential to change the world.
Cons:
IBM hasn't met their market targets for 20 quarters. Unfortunately, this results in IBM's continued need to lay off workers. 

Career opportunities used to be endless with IBM's remote work policy. However, IBM is moving to a collocation philosophy, which makes career moves within the company much more difficult.

Pros: 3 months training on Design Thinking is a great experience! You learned a lot about how to work with customers and teams to figure out the optimal buyer journey which is the greatest starting point of building a software solution. A lot of learning opportunities offered in the company.
Cons: Be careful about the team you are joining. It varies a lot from team to team. Be careful about bureaucracy and old-management style of your manager. It might destroy your career there.

Pros: You meet a lot of nice people and build are large network around the world. You get to travel to cool places and sell cool technology that helps companies be successful. I hope they are paying me enough :)
Cons: It's a big company so it can take longer than usual to get things accomplished. The business changes it's organizational structure a lot so be prepared to change territories frequently.

Pros: Good learning experiences offered if you can network your way into a sector that you are interested in. IF you can find associate partners/partners to care about you then there are a lot of opportunities for growth.
Cons: Bonuses are based on the company performance, not individual performance so you almost never get one (if you do its like 1K). Also, do not get as many benefits or perks as other consulting firms and pay is better at other consulting firms. I'm a female and sometimes I felt like others had bigger salaries than me just because they were male or bc of who they know.

Pros: Work with state-of-the-art technology in an environment that encourages experimentation and overcoming roadblocks. We hold the honor of being the leading generating patent company for 28 years in a row. IBM puts a lot of emphasis on trust, respect, inclusiveness, and ethical behavior in all relationships. To top it all off, our professionals foster one of the best working environments in the industry.
Cons: The constant seeking for excellence and the attraction of cutting edge technology can lead to long hours of dedication at times.

Pros:
Good work/life balance
Good pay and benefits
Innovative
Interesting work
Flexible work hours
Not very bureaucratic for a large company
Work with dedicated professionals
Easy to work for company
Great variety of opportunity
Cons: I've worked for a lot of different companies over the last 35 years and I have to say this is one of the best companies I've worked for . There are pros and cons no matter where you work . I only have one thing worthy of mentioning as a 'con' and that is the worry about being laid off, which happens at all big companies. I do feel that the company has done much better at trying to move people around recently.

Pros: Very nice people who are eager to help. The starting compensation was fair, not outstanding. Beautiful campus in Armonk with shuttle service.
Cons: Quarter close is terrible! Systems rarely tied. We had mandatory meetings on Saturdays and Sundays after already working 12+ hours Monday through Friday. No bonus until you reach Executive band. Annual raise was 3% - not nearly enough for the amount of work and re-work during quarter close periods. Quick turnarounds for last minute changes during quarter close. Honestly, quarter close is just awful on all fronts! Super stressful and most of it could've been avoided.

Pros: Do you know what is doing research in academia as a PhD or post-doc student? Imagine the same with a six figure salary and plenty of resources. That is what you'll get as researcher at IBM. Freedom of action.
Cons: It is not a place to be told what to do. You should drive your own research agenda and innovation. Takes time to convince other people and management, but after all, this is research, and research is plenty of risk and unknowns and you should be ready for failure and changing topics.

Pros: Flexible hours are good.  Working from home allows this flexibility.  The people that are left are good, but overworked due to outsourcing.
Cons: All technical jobs are headed to India.  First they "leaned" 50% out, then outsourced the rest to other countries, that cannot complete the job satisfactorily, which leads to more work for the competent here.  There no longer are company parties, where families are invited, limiting the "family" feeling you get when you are able to meet and learn others outside of work.

Pros: IBM is an innovation driven firm, focused on sustainable growth and the continuous evaluation and development at the enterprise, brand and employee levels.  IBM provides extremely competitive health care and 401(k) benefits, a mentoring program and substantial training and development opportunities.  There are ample career paths to choose from at IBM.  At IBM you are provided the tools to make your career your own.
Cons: As a member of a extremely large company it is easy to feel as only a number.  While there are ample career paths, it can be challenging to navigate to a significantly different career path.  The salary compensation appears to be average.

Pros:
Looks good on the resume
Some very talented people work at this company
Tremendous resources that can be brought to bear - financial, talenetd people, geographic reach, technology
Cons:
Old boy network - very hard to break into
Consulting business model is broken - billable utilization target is 95%!!
In GBS people are commodities to be hired out on ANY project irrespecive of whether or not it fits your skills and interests
In GBS salaries are usually lower than the market
Most leaders are rewarded based solely on business generated - no incentive to look after their people or invest in innovation

Pros: There are smart, technical, helpful, and hard-working engineers working on cool, challenging assignments.  An open environment to try out new ideas and methods all in the name of getting the latest products out on time.  Good team atmosphere.  Good pcs and technology.  Flexible with working from home.
Cons: At IBM, as in hardware companies in general, we are being asked to make more and more complex products with less and less resources/people (due to computers (vs. cars, milk, and most other products) becoming cheaper with each passing year).  Technical leaders are not promoted as often or as high as managers, in most areas.

Pros: I still work for IBM because I like the project and the client that I am working for. The location is perfect and I have been working with this client for the past couple of years. I have considered looking for another job but the timing is not right.
Cons:
Employee manger is located some where else and there is no direct communication.
Manager is the one who decide on promotion and bonus even though he does not work directly with the employee. Reimbursement for tuition is very hard.

Pros: To be clear, this is about IBM/Rational in Lexington - I have little knowledge about other corners of this vast company. The pluses of working there are: They produce some technically interesting and successful products in the software-development-tools space, so you know you're working on software that is actually used. There are some good senior developers there, who you can learn from, which is a plus. And finally, you will be working for a large stable company with a good pay and benefits package, which is not something to be sneezed at in these tough economic times. That's it for the good stuff. Next...
Cons:
The downsides of IBM/Rational are unfortunately numerous. The place is big, and with bigness comes bureaucracy and politics. There are about 600 employees at the site. The ClearCase project alone has over 100 developers working on it (that's not even counting things like QA). There's no way a SCM system inherently needs that many people - there are competitors who build very functional systems with 10% as much people (and 10% as much code). With too many people comes some very undesirable phenomena, like people competing to "get to" do scraps of new work that are needed, competing internal projects doing the same thing, numerous meetings and processes to decide *what* to do, etc. The software itself has a long history, so parts of it are old, with newer parts grafted on as new layers, so the software as a whole starts looking like an archaeological dig. Nobody seems to understand it top-to-bottom, so it's hard to do anything significant. 

For a new person coming in, all this can be frustrating. You feel like a sheep that is part of a big herd of animals. It's hard to get noticed, hard to get onto interesting sub-projects doing new things, and hard to get your ideas put into practice. Also there's a bit of an "old boys club" mentality, where a new person in the group (no matter how smart and experienced) has a hard time breaking into the "in group" where the important technical discussions happen and the real decisions get made.

I haven't even gotten to the subject of management yet. With a lot of developers comes a lot of managers. Many of them, while being nice people and competent administrators, are pretty non-technical (there are a few exceptions where good developers moved up to manager level, but most choose not to because it means spending most of your day in meetings). So you get a number of people in management who basically don't understand the technology, making and communicating the decisions about that technology, which just leads to... well, nothing good.

I think for a junior person just starting out this might be OK. Or for a more senior person who is content to not do too much while waiting for retirement. But if you're an experienced software developer with energy and ideas who wants to build interesting things, this probably isn't the environment for you.

A couple final points. For me these are not the high-order bits, but they are additional minor irritants. The place has a ton of useless "security" rules, like clearing/locking your desks and wiping clean your whiteboards, etc, along with random inspections (really!) to catch violators. It's like kindergarten at times. Also the company has become cheap in petty ways - like not even giving out free coffee (even though they pay people good salaries). Oh, and one last (no so minor) thing: Even though the company overall and the Rational group are successful and making money, they seem to be in the habit of doing regular (almost annual) "layoffs". I put this in quotes because it's more like a mass firing of the bottom 10% of performers than a traditional layoff - I mean there's no financial reason for it, and they go right back to hiring (sometimes even on the same day). I think they've decided this is a methodology for increasing the average quality of their remaining workers over time. (Unfortunately many other companies are doing the same thing these days, which means all that's really happening is everyone is replacing their laid off bottom 10% by hiring someone elses laid off bottom 10%, so it's completely useless even in its intended purpose.). For me all this wasn't a huge issue since I was never in the bottom 10% and never laid off, but nonetheless regular layoffs produce an atmosphere of general unpleasantness - I mean nobody likes to see bad things happen to colleagues.

Well, that's about it, hope this was helpful.

Pros:
Lots of opportunities for doing completely different work
Great flexibility -- in where and when work is done, allows easy work/life balance
Supportive direct management
Great tools to get work done remotely
Decent salary, benefits and bonuses
Good recognition for high achievers in the right part of the business.
Cons:
Clueless senior management
Too much deadwood in employees and management
No clear direction for the future
Big raises are no longer available
Can get stuck in poor performing businesses and be at risk for losing job through no fault of your own

Pros: Stable company. Excellent product lines. People who care for the customers.
Cons: There is still too many layers of management in sales for all brands.

Pros: If you can find time between the very long hours in sales, you can try to stay current with technology. The people you work with are all top notch, A team.
Cons: Very long hours. When you get home, you log right back on to do hours of email, conference calls, and adminstrivia. The level of inspection on each deal is absurd. The quotas are not attainable, just set high to control your earnings. Extreme pressure to make monthly goals. Administrative systems to track your attainment has been grossly inaccurate for years. This is handled out of Brazil, making it nearly impossible to rectify errors.

Pros: There are some great benefits (health, vision, dental) at IBM.  People come from all sorts of backgrounds and it lends to a nice experience in diversity.
Cons: Opportunity for growth seems very limited, as the company is so large.  This leads to certain managers playing favorites.  It is easy to get lost in the shuffle.

Pros:
Work with some of the most talented people in the scientific research community.
Great place for research -- good balance between academic and industrial research.
Opportunities to work on some cutting-edge research projects.
Encourage publishing in conferences/journals and development as a scientist.
Pay well compared with other companies for a similar position.
Cons:
Too much bureaucracy, and too much paperwork for everything.
Despite the high stock value for IBM, none of that seems to make it to the employees.
Hiring freezes and restrictions on travel spending every so often -- higher ups don't seem to be managing the budget very well.

Pros:
Salary and benefits are competitive
People I worked with were some of the best
Lots of interesting and challenging work
Cons:
Company always trying to streamline work and become more efficient, this always resulted in more work with less people and longer hours.
A lot of hard work put into standardizing processes which results into easy migration of the work overseas.

Pros: Exposure to large commercial accounts. Employee stock purchase plan. Access to education classes, materials and certifications. Work from home. Partnerships with other large companies provide for good networking.
Cons: Opportunities for advancement are limited in some positions due to a tendency to pigeonhole employees in current role from lack of availability of trained resources to assume responsibilities. Extreme cost cutting measures especially in Q4 limiting education, travel and hiring. Many layers of management to navigate. Distribution of work across global regions slows down delivery of projects. Salaries below market value. Recent 401k changes are viewed as unfavorable to employees. Overall low morale.

Pros:
Super co-workers (and many of the leaders)
Good salary & benefits
A chance to get involved in leading-edge work
Cons:
"Same size fits all" view of performance goals - irrational and harmful
Disorganized & disjointed - TOO much material to study, too little idea of which parts MATTER
You have to find your own way through the bureaucracy - which can be VERY daunting

Pros: - Left Brain: 'Performance-based culture': you can rise quickly and gain access to top people and a great many resources when you have success...
Cons: - Right Brain: 'Performance-based culture': perform within the confines of a near-soulless formal organization, working with, but also to best your valued co-workers who are similarly numb - so that you can continue to do what you do...

Pros: There's a brilliant group of strategy folks from the PWC era that have tried to cultivate the same culture that led them to success but the firm does little to cultivate internal talent below the associate partner level, particularly millennials to retain the next generation of strategic talent.
Cons: Poor incentives, poor usage of resources, very little reward is given to going above and beyond on proposals or client engagements,

Pros:
* Exciting opportunity to collaborate with world-class researchers covering a broad array of disciplines, focused on
solving real-world problems.
* Expectations include publishing papers in high-quality venues, allowing one to maintain good contact (and possibly even collaborations) with academic community
Cons:
* Employee evaluations based on a quota system that other companies like Microsoft have now abandoned because it has been proven to hurt employee morale; employees can receive low evaluations for excellent work, and incentives can thwart collaboration among employees
* High-level corporate strategy of cutting way to growth seems wrong-headed and unsustainable, and has negative impact on Research including tight budgets and shortened time horizons for Research
* High-level corporate budget-tightening has in some cases translated to less freedom in Research, with some managers treating their teams like military command-and-control organizations

Pros: Higher level philosophical purpose (to be essential), excellent marketing campaigns (Smarter Planet), smart people and great talent, diverse set of capabilities and offerings to solve practically any problem, great brand name
Cons: Too self-serving as opposed to client-focused at times, bureaucratic and process focused in managing business, leadership detached from employees and their needs, any person is one quarter away of loosing their jobs based on stock performance

Pros:
Great Work culture
Great colleagues
Great projects
Cons:
Little room for promotions for the 8+ yrs that I was there; management is trying to change it.
Company dumped folks when it came time to help transition people; some of the folks had already worked out a move to other groups but that was blocked and people dumped in the recent "RA" exercise
Poor bonuses.
Poor rating process
You get stuck at the salary you joined.
Leadership works with 1 or 2 of it's favorite individuals and then no opportunities for the rest.

Pros:
Over 20 vacation days starting out
Resume builder
Offers some training
Talented coworkers
Good networking opportunity
Cons: Upper management is very disconnected from the hands on techs.  For the majority of my time here, my team was not allowed to hire anyone, regardless of how many people left.  Contracts were signed for millions of dollars to determine what my team supports, without any consultation of us whatsoever.  This led to unreasonable demands from the customers that we could not meet.  Management would always side with the customer.
