Pros: Innovative people and excellent ability to scale up successful endeavors to global proportions. Reasonable pay, and good benefits.
Cons: Executive Leadership has lost its way.  The folks selected to serve at the most senior levels behave like tyrants, are not likeable and in some cases aren't trustworthy. That means the people they lead don't give their all  and the company is suffering as a result. It's a big difference from where the company was 10 years ago.

Pros: I have been working with IBM for 22 years now. IBM has given me the opportunity to work with so many different technologies as well as interact with amazing people. Of course there are difficult times, but the strength of being a IBMer pulls us all together to solve a client's challenge. There is not a day which goes by, we as a team look for a better way to solve a problem. I love that. I am a #ProudIBMer.
Cons: Keeping up with so many new advancements in Cloud, Analytic, Mobile, Social & Security (CAMSS).

Pros:
You probably think having a great job is an unattainable fantasy, but I know through my work with countless clients up and down the corporate ladder that it's not. If the mere act of fulfillment and joy aren't enough of a reason to make the shift, how about the potential of living longer?

1. Happy equals healthy.
2. A good job fuels community ties.
3. Good work brings fulfillment. 
4. Liking your job brings less stress and anxiety. 
5. Being challenged is better than being bored.
Cons: While being challenged is better than being bored; a overloaded email In-box is at times a hindrance to allocating time to learning new skills.

Pros: IBM is a great technology company with a number of products that are the best in the industry.  The working environment is relaxed yet professional.  There are many great people throughout the company.
Cons: The company is so large that management doesn't always make decisions that are based on reality in the market.  Many exceptional employees have been "resourced" as IBM changes the product mix and how they go to market.  Although a great technology company, IBM is a not so great marketing company.

Pros:
Training effectiveness: IBM commits 6-9 months of devoted training time to new hires for their sales roles if you are an coming out of school, and 3 months for experienced hires. It is a wealth of knowledge and their is a lot of development that you receive through this program.

Mentorship: This really boils down to personal experience, but not for a lack of availability. The people here are definitely open to be mentors during your time at IBM, and they will continue to work with you if you show initiative during your time.

How Summits are treated: It is really nice to come to work and have a big group of other summit hires that you work alongside (this may be different depending on where you work). They provide you with enough resources to succeed, and continually try to improve the experience. 

Shadowing experiences: This is up to you. It is highly encouraged for you to reach out to other IBMers. IBMers will be open to this, for the most part. They are very valuable because IBM is such a large company. There are tons of shadowing opportunities that can lead to opportunities or a deeper level of understanding.

Sales training & curriculum: This is very extensive. They have 6-9 months of training about sales methodology, IBM products, IBM processes, and building a strong foundation of knowledge. You will get what you put into the experience. 

Hands-on (in-field) experience: The training gives you experience in around 20 client conversations with sales advisors (IBM employees who were very successful salers). They believe that you learn by doing, and this environment is conducive to a less-pressured approach to just learn, and succeed when you do go on quota.

Quality of peer group: There are tons of smart, hard-working, and very nice employees. For me, the people that I work with are great. They challenge me and do so positively.

Interview: I spoke with an IBM representative at a college networking event, completed a phone interview, and attended a hiring event that gave more information about IBM, included 4 interviews, and a team presentation. I was given an offer a month later.

Community culture: IBM is changing a lot. Before really understanding IBM, I had a skewed view of the culture. It is a great culture for me: collaborative, hard-working, and generally trying to improve as people.
Cons:
Training effectiveness: This program is really tailored to client-facing sellers. There is a gap in training for digital sellers. There is training that is supplemental for digital sellers, but it can be improved to greater address learning gaps.

Mentorship: None.

How Summits are treated: Some sellers will be hired directly onto teams. Others will need to get the job at IBM, and then they will need to connect with a team to work for after training. It is a little frustrating to think about and act on, but is definitely good practice to connect with a lot of other people at IBM.

Shadowing experiences: If you ask, you can find good experiences, but you have to provide value if you can. 

Sales training & curriculum: N/A.

Hands-on (in-field) experience: It would be nice to have set in-field experience, but this really depends on the teams which is why it isn't scheduled as part of the official training.

Quality of peer group: Some may not enjoy or click with their group. There are a lot of people that work at IBM.

Teaching team: N/A

Management style and effectiveness: There may be some micro-managing, but it depends on your team and manager.

Interview: It was frustrating in terms of timeline. They would not be very good at communicating what was happening. I received duplicate messages from different people, and some logistical conflicts. I suggest being proactive about reaching out to your contacts to confirm next steps, follow up, and stay top-of-mind for the recruiters. I wouldn't just bother them, but show them that you are committed and able to provide value by reiterating your fit at IBM. It was also a very rigorous process during the hiring process.

Community culture: A lot of working here is learning how to find and work with people internally. Some sellers may not want to share information because they will be worried about you taking over the client relationship or it is not worth their time to help you with a deal. I say this because working here has another layer of learning how to be effective internally.

Pros: Newest technology, industry leader -- IBM was always "THE" company to go to work for.  Best education, the brightest minds, and an admirable corporate culture.
Cons: Unfortunately, many of the "Pros" listed above are a statement of their past.  No longer in the leadership position that defined the industry, IBM is now a company in search of their own identity.  Corporate management has traveled down the path of greed and ineptitude followed by so many great companies in America, causing the slow but inevitable demise of this 100-year-old+ behemoth.

Pros:
You are surrounded and part of a community of some of the smartest people on the planet and the scale of what you work on is global.
You can feel like you are part of something bigger than yourself.
Lots of opportunities for global travel and team building across multiple cultures.
Name brand cachet for mom and dad (and grandma and grandpa).
Your work might be around for an eternity (in software years).
Your coworkers will stimulate you and you will be inspired by what they create.
If you like big complicated problems that require systems level thinking, this could be for you.
If you want and are able to travel a lot (and have experience schmoozing with clients) this can be a really great place.
If you want to learn (by doing) about how to persuade and lead people without authority, this could be a place for you. 
If you are a power networker, this could be the place for you.
If you think winning means everyone else has to lose, this could be for you. 
If you enjoy an always on environment, this could be for you.
If you manage to stick around, you will probably advance through attrition.
Cons:
One of the Senior Vice President's children summed it up succinctly after interning at IBM for a summer: "What a soul sucking place, Dad."

Politics reigns supreme here and you must constantly flatter people whom you don't respect (if you want to advance). You will also be the pawn in multiple Director's, VP's, and GM's power games to further their own agenda and sphere of influence. Favoritism and Cliques abound and you must devote time to making sure you do not become the next target of their attention (or worse, start a witch-hunt against someone else to provide cover). 

At times you will feel like you have been assimilated by the Borg.

This is a stack ranked environment (despite the new system) where managers are forced to pick losers, even in stellar teams. And yet, Leadership isn't held accountable for failures, because goals change so quickly, or are never decided, that it is impossible for them to fail (on paper). 
Leadership constantly makes the sure bet, and follows the leader (over radical and risky innovation), yet excoriates the ground level employees for the results of such decisions. All innovation happens through acquisition.

The ratio of time spent coordinating and selling yourself and the work you did is almost one to one to actually doing work. You could even do no 'work', if you are good at fabricating stories and narratives that management, or analysts want to hear.

The list goes on and on with every Dilbert scenario you can imagine to some degree.

Pros:
Smart people. Great technology. Great Customers.
Great if you are a Millennial now as they are purging Baby Boomers.
Cons: With a broad portfolio, Executive Management and Marketing misses the connection between the high-level message and execution at the field level. This and the resultant org & comp structure creates silos that impact product & sales.  They do not see this as they continuously present big deals that cross all of it while pushing for more small deals, yet burdening sales management with administrative overhead and without providing real sales training.

Pros: The people are what make IBM special. I've met so many brilliant, kind, helpful people in the past few years. Conferences in Vegas are really fun, especially thanks to great coworkers.
Cons: My portfolio/team has changed names, divisions, product lines, management and analytics tools more times than I can count in 3 years. As soon as you figure out your job, it changes again. Now they're moving away from remote working so you'll have to be in specific US cities. My role is moving and I would never move for a job I barely tolerate.

Pros: A lot of the people are great. You learn a lot very quickly because there isn't too much training. Very flexible schedule which is fantastic.
Cons: Not as much structure as I was used to. Felt like my job was unnecessary at times and had to find/make my own work and carve out my own role. Not a lot of room for growth. Morale is pretty low right now in marketing because of executive decision to co-locate. We're losing a lot of good talent to competitors. It's extremely difficult to get things done or be innovative at a company this size. Bonuses have been terrible.

Pros:
- Work with some of the smartest, most forward thinking leaders
- Access to cutting edge technology (Watson cognitive / AI computing; Blockchain; Quantum computing)
- Commitment to fundamentally transform processes, offerings, and culture to lead for the next 100 years
- Work / Life balance
- Global, vocal leader in support of diversity and equality
- Offerings in Healthcare (oncology, diabetes, etc.) impact the WORLD, at a personal level
Cons:
- Change is continuous... can be difficult to keep up
- Complicated matrix structure due to diverse businesses and global nature
- No free lunch, snacks, etc

Pros: IBM is very flexible. Working from home is great.
Cons: The CbD program flaunts itself as some kind of recent graduate mutually beneficial training program to groom you to be a consultant, but don't let that fool you. I remember when I first started, I came here to glassdoor to check the reviews and I found one where the reviewer was talking about being laid off. He said "Dont be fooled, you can be laid off just like everyone else!" I talked to one of my peers about it and they said that does not happen to CbD'ers as long as your trying really hard to get staffed, which I was trying my absolute hardest. The problem is IBM hired way to many resources. There were hundreds of recent grads like me trying to find projects. Sure enough, a year later it happened to me too. They tell you that they will find you projects to work on and that you only need to put in a little effort to find them, but the truth is you are competing with everyone around you for projects, and they (Management) dont do much of anything to help you. If you go to long without a project, they will fire you. Yes, I said fire you, because they make it seem like your getting "laid off" but from a HR standpoint, you are being fired, which means your next employer will know about it. They not only not "launched my career", but they actually significantly damaged my reputation in the working world.  Many IBM Managers still have this manage by fear mentality also and a very serious fraternal style attitude where the newer consultants are treated like were worthless.

Pros: They are hiring a lot of younger folks, which is good news for new grads. They have a number of decent long term projects and as long as you're getting your work done you have good job security.
Cons: They underpay, hard. They are not competitive especially at the entry level. Older, long time employees have benefits that new employees can't even get anymore (smaller PTO ceiling, etc). Generally the government contracts are working with outdated technology or in house stuff that nobody outside would have even heard of because nobody else uses it since there are popular, well functioning alternatives is basically everything. Raises are done on a schedule and are incredibly difficult to negotiate.

Pros: IBM generally pays fairly well and there are other perks to working for a large, bluechip company - such as travel opportunities, good health insurance coverage, etc.
Cons: Very little trust or transparency within the company. There is a, "whats in it for me?" culture that can be toxic at times (people are unwilling to help each other unless helping could directly benefit them by way of retiring their quota). When you work in sales, you will experience a reorganization every 6 months (at a minimum). There are not many people at IBM who feel they have a high level of job security - any one could be let go at any time by one of IBM's infamous reorg's or notorious workforce reduction actions.

Job Title: Entry level software development testing specialist
Pros:
Upward mobility into management due to high retention
Employees are relatable and understanding
Location is near good areas to retire
Outdoor trails and parks in driving distance
Cons:
Very low pay
Either unrewarding and dull work or dumpster fires
Transferring is difficult and discouraged
Location is uninteresting for younger adults
Culture of avoiding work

Pros:
- Company offers a lot of benefits to its employees.
- Salary structure works well if you can position yourself in the appropriate band.
Cons:
- Small companies absorbed suffer tremendously from merging with IBM and their strict regulations, policies, and required training/learning while still expected to maintain and deliver at the velocity of a start-up. Managers forced to lose their leadership positions because they don't have the required number of direct reports to warrant it in IBM's eyes.
- Poor leadership is put in position to lead absorbed companies with little understanding of the products / teams being worked. This leads to baseless layoffs of high quality talent and destroys morale of employees that remain.

Pros:
I enjoying Learning. 

IBM offers (and helps you track) your perpetual technical self-development. 
There are literally hundreds of online courses and a broad range of education opportunities . 
As I look back on 2020, I see I have completed some excellent certification courses in Python, AI, Quantum computing, BlockChain , Agile and OpenStack just to name a few. 

I start my day with 10 minutes on the Nordic track and 60 minutes of online self-development content. The hours are tracked automatically, so I see measurable progress. 

Interestingly, many of my co-workers engage in a similar daily schedule. 

If this is your kinda thing, you will enjoy it here.
Cons: You have to stay current with new technologies.

Pros: Really great people that are technically strong. Team knows what they're doing, are diligent and deeply skilled. Breadth of capabilities with depth that goes beyond services that brings software, systems, and cloud into the mix. Movement towards operating more like an integrated AI and cloud company - not just another consulting/systems integrator house.
Cons: We're a challenger brand that has to build a new identity that is distinctive from others. We need more people and a SIGNIFICANT amount of my time is focused on hiring more talent. We're strong on inclusion, weak on diversity. Need to continue cultivating and growing our diversity.

Pros:
- Great experience
- Salary
- Benefits
- Big tech industry experience
Cons:
- No one has cameras on, feels very impersonal
- Not a lot of care for early employees, no coaches or mentors
- Siloed within current business unit / org. No visibility into other businesses at IBM. Hard to feel connected to larger strategy.
- Very easy to feel unhappy or lonely in this role
- Much older crowd. Most people here already have kids or grandkids, so they don't take an effort to talk to other people or learn about new hires.

Pros: Exposure to a variety of top level clients, working with dedicated, intelligent people, company opportunities for variety of work.  Ability to join communities of interest in topics such as Agile, SOA, etc.  Opportunity to work with teams, both co-located and virtual.  Ability to take on leadership roles if you want to. Online education at a basic level on a large variety of topics.  Benefit benefits package including medical plans, 401K, etc.
Cons: keeping up the billable hours, administrative policies are sometimes too clerically focused and could be simpler, some jobs require 100% travel.

Pros: Colleagues are excellent.  Very bright people,  Good support structure so you don't have to wear every hat and can focus on your areas of expertise.  Example, great legal support.  People are anxious to help you out - so you can reach out to pretty much anyone.  It also has just about any type of job so it is possible to experience many different disciplines.  Also, if you feel you have an entrepreneurial spirit, there are places you can work that allow you to create and grow a business.
Cons: Very large, difficult to have your hands around everything.  Having to worry about legacy solutions - hardware and software is a challenge, but a reality when you have a history of success.

Pros: You can be part of something much bigger. Very few companies have the history and breadth and market impact of IBM. Working for IBM means you can be part of a company that sets an agenda in business and society. Plus, you can be attached to some of the great societal work IBM is working on.
Cons: IBM's great strength, it's size and market impact, can also be challenging. It's very hard to navigate within the company to find where one site, where the real work is getting done on a particular project, etc. Plus, it's so big it can sometimes trip on itself. Multiple people are often working on virtually the same projects, so redundant work is common. Finally, processes can be overwhelming.

Pros: IBM has vast number of areas that one can work and develop skills.  It is somewhat strong in the mist of the economic turmoil.  It has a recognizable and good reputation amongst society as a whole.
Cons: IBM tends to augment staff excessively and just place employees in projects without providing a defined role.  You will end up doing random meaningless tasks, in which will amount to nothing and will barely assist you in growth.  It really hurts you if you decide to leave apply for another position; you have nothing to really add.  In addition, you will find youself in undefined roles, feeling like a lost fish in a pond.

Pros:
Great knowledge sharing via internal tools and search engines.
Staff like to share and help each other.
Salary is competitive, but in the middle of the range.
Relatively easy to move from one practice to another.
Cons:
Work/Life balance is more of a dream than a reality.
Outward appearance of caring, but not all managers really care when there are revenue and profit impact s.
Reward goes to those who are cooperative, not those who think outside the box, although they pretend that innovation is their goal.

Pros: IBM has good benefits and the people in general are a pleasure to work with and very supportive.  Within IBM there is a wide breadth of opportunity and IBM does promote networking with colleagues throughout the company.
Cons: Politics and personal aspirations can affect decision making in the best interest of the smaller business units.  It is expected that an executives will put their career first.

Pros: Working with very smart people. Very good benefits. Most jobs offer flexibility. Variety of things you can do throughout your career. Diversity. Ethical place to work.
Cons: Extreme expense controls limit salary increases and other compensation. Starting salaries are not competitive. Very little opportunity for promotion. Long work hours. It often can be very stressful. Constantly expected to do more with less. Relentless focus on moving jobs to growth markets.

Pros: Flexibility to work remotely is a big plus for work life balance.  If a new college grad, probably a good opportunity for you.
Cons: You actually end up working more due to time saved commuting and working early and late evening hours as is generally needed with the workloads.  Loyalty, work ethic and performance don't come into play anymore when it comes to job retention... Employees get cut first to make financials look good.

Pros: Access to methodologies and frameworks early in my career, able to form several mentor relationships during my time at the company,  visibility and exposure to different industries and opportunities, emphasis on solutions and strategic focus from lower-level managers, great team environment
Cons: Huge discrepencies between sales force and delivery team causing the company to over-sell and under-deliver, which results in diminished client relationships, compensation is average if not below, traveling lifestyle wasn't for me, questionable ethics with client billing requirements/mandates that came from senior management

Pros:
Enormous reach, rich talent pool and strong brand
Focus is slowly turning back to Innovation and being essential to clients
Competitive sales environment with generous benefits
Strong culture of ethics and strict controls
Cons:
Too much attention to shareholders at the expense of employees and maybe even clients
Work-life-balance can be very challenging, specially for consultants in GBS
Employee morale issues is GBS and STG
Matrix organization is very hard to work with
New employees get lost in the maze .. enablement needs to be better

Pros: IBM is a big company.  I have worked in a few different areas, and each is like a different company, with its own culture, and people.  If you don't like where you are, and you're capable, there are lots of opportunities, lots of products, lots of places to try.
Cons: Top management has a focus on shareholders first, then clients, then employees.  Once you recognize and accept that the word "customers" usually refers to shareholders, much of what upper management says makes more sense.

Pros: Smart people and products.  I'd say overall there is very good atmosphere of trust and fairness. There is a strong focus on education, and they reimburse for outside classes taken (Up to 5k/year I think). Benefits are good, and I'd say quite competitive in the market. Good 401K matching (they'll contribute a max of 3% of your 6% or greater). Free drinks in the breakroom. Flexibility to work from home at times. (If you live 50+ miles away from an office you can work full-time from home...policy).
Cons: Very corporate. Corporate structure makes it hard to advance, while salary can be decent, the sales roles can be a grind. Management is usually slow to accept proposed changes, and the team espouses top down management

Pros: A large company provides greater opportunities for advancement or to become a specialist.  The projects and accounts I was exposed to were always rewarding and challenging.
Cons: Ibm was so worried about what would happen if the employees formed unions.  Additionally they had no loyalty at all towards employees who joined from an acquisition or outsourcing.  In most cases they would find ways to speed up the attrition of these people.

Pros: Ability to learn alot about different software, your way around a server, and change management process.
Cons: Antiquated processes created because the small number that did mess things up. If one personal makes a mistake, everybody essentially pays for it by being inundated with more bloated process so the mistake doesn't happen again. Haven't seen a solid vision for the Delivery center part of the IBM business, therefore motivation to do better and succeed has been sucked pretty well dry.

Pros: Lots of freedom to choose what you want to work on and become an expert in.  Great work/life balance.  Working remotely is common and the environment is very supportive of people with families.
Cons: Can be a little slow to react to things.  There's lots of politics and bureaucracy.  Some folks don't get research anymore, they've been at IBM for too long.  The culture is quite insular and we're constantly fighting for funding.  Bonuses are small and pay increases are slow as well -- they come for past work.

Pros:
Flexible hours, where you control when and how your work gets done. 
My department is doing fairly well and is still hiring. 
The amount of vacation days is pretty decent.
Was able to get promoted relatively quickly.
Cons:
The office space is depressing, feels like I'm stuck in the 80s...no open space to interact with other employees...complete opposite of a "start-up" type environment. 
Bonuses and compensation are non-existent.
Pretty sure lower management is there to just listen to the employees and nod without actually taking action.
The yearly employee rating system is horrendous.
Money is tight and doesn't look like anything will change in the near future.

Pros: Good: There are many IBM divisions and groups that there are many different career opportunities to keep resources interested.  IBM culture embraces employees who have good ideas and are willing to take ownership to implement their ideas.
Cons:
Bad:  Over the last few years changes have been made that make it appear that the company doesn't care about their employees, little or no bonus after requiring massive amounts of over time, 401K company match changed from being paid with each pay period to being paid 12/31 IF you have not left the company or they did not lay you off before that date. 
Ugly: Currently alot of the US staff fears for their jobs and the moral is not good

Pros: Had the opportunity to work on some leading edge technically, such as Apache Spark and the new LinuxOne servers. Also, had the opportunity to work with a Master Inventor on multiple patent applications.
Cons: You are very much expected to be independent (which isn't necessarily a bad thing), but at times when working on something you have never seen before, it can be quite difficult.

Pros: Great people, extremely experienced and dedicated.  Global opportunities and excellent on line training and education.  My experience with direct management has been wonderful.
Cons: It's not the company it used to be.  Benefits have been slashed to almost nothing.  Employee health care contributions have risen steadily, pension has been eliminated, 401K matching contributions cut from 6% to 2% and only paid at end of year, severance pay has been virtually eliminated.  Constant lay-offs that create a culture of fear and result in the remaining employees taking on the work or it's outsourced to global resources that do not have the experience or skills necessary.  Workers are being cut to give the executive and the board millions in bonuses.

Pros: Flexible work hours to start, but working at home , you have tendency to overwork with long hours , evenings and weekends.
Cons: Cloud, Watson, and new Logo's not making quota. Layoffs every quarter, losing experienced talent, and morale very low.  Behind the curve of competitors and losing traction competing with winning new business. End of working long hours in evening and over weekend. Not able to take vacation yearly due layoffs every quarter and loss of many skilled peers, and end up working until very end of year. Have to get management approval yearly to carry over vacation, if you don't use it , you lose it.

Pros:
Decent benefits package.
I met some good people
Cons:
I was laid off after 20+ years working at IBM.  The severance package was reduced from 6 months to 1 month just before being laid off.
On my previous team, it took a very long time (over 6 months in some cases) for delivered code to be put in production.
Delivering code updates and fixes was a torturous process requiring forms, more forms, and approval by multiple non-technical people, no matter how trivial the code change.

Pros:
There are a lot of nice people in the territory 
Work/Life Balance is great 
First Line Managers are great
Cons:
Too many reorganizations
Senior/Executive Management doesn't care about customer relationships, because they keep reorganizing. Customers want to buy from people they know and trust, they like consistency. 
Management doesnt seem to care about their employees, or their career growth
Lack of communication between sales teams
IBM doesn't let you move to new positions. If you are an over achiever and do well, they want to keep you in the same position.

Pros: Great benefits (Health Insurance, 401k, etc) and my department is all work from home, so it is far easier to accomplish the work / life balance that all HR departments are so fond of trotting out.
Cons: As you likely know, the company is huge. Truly vast. So it can be a challenge to find the right person or people that you need.

Pros: Flexible work environment and schedule.  Many interesting projects and challenging problems to solve.  Many great and talented people around you to work with.
Cons: With resource actions happened every year in last 5 or 6 years, work force has been cut to a bare minimum.  It used to be a fun place to work.  With remaining employees to pick up the work left by previously laid off coworkers and no new hiring in near future, morale is pretty low as we constantly switching hats for different problems at the same time.  This lowers productivity and qualify of work.

Pros: In 2017, there are few to none.
Cons: IBM no longer supports work at home employees. Long time skilled employees are being told to move thousands of miles to specific work sites (even those in close proximity to an IBM location. No salary increase is offered nor is any guarantee of employment once you make the move. Should they decline, a contractor is hired, often working remote. It's a veiled attempt to reduce FT headcount for contract employees. Strong founders and contributors are leaving (my entire Watson team) for other opportunities given the absolute break down of a talented work force. And last, a colleague who CHOSE to  commute three hours daily to keep her job, was just laid off after 2 months.

Pros: An amazing history of innovation and contributions to the world for over 100 years
Cons: Not your father's IBM. The company has changed, as it should, but there is a combination of lofty, worthy goals and financial targets that are often illogical and impossible to attain because there is inadequate, or incompetent, support. There is a slash and burn mentality with staff cuts or tactics to make staff leave.

Pros: IBM is a middle of the road company (decent salary, benefits, stability, mobility within the company, etc) but with great people. In nearly two years most everyone I've met is a good person, smart, and trying to do the right things to get their jobs done. The C-level team is working really hard to reinvent the company to bring it into the modern era of cloud computing and AI. Amazing work/life balance (for now, see advice to management).
Cons: Seriously outdated internal tooling, a huge company with layers upon layers of management, many different and competing objectives and brands that are all glued together.

Pros: IBM has incredible internal marketing.  When working within IBM, you actually start to believe that you are fortunate to work at IBM and that the company is on the brink of a brilliant transformation.   The town halls and internal events feel celebratory even when the earnings calls are anything but positive.  And even when you're working 16+ hours per day and under pressure to perform miracles.
Cons: The stress level at IBM creates a toxic and unhealthy environment.  So many colleagues endured stress related health issues and medical leaves that I lost count.  It wasn't until I left IBM that I realized that "work life balance" still means something outside of IBM.

Pros: Good benefits - nice health insurance, paid time off, decent vacation days and sometimes you're allowed to work remotely.  Culture in the design studio is young and fun, but outside of that it's very legacy.
Cons: The company is very wishy-washy in terms of who they give certain benefits to.  Some employees are allowed to work remotely but for the most part co-location has forced families to uproot their lives and move to an office, or lose their job.  My manager doesn't know anything about development so it's been hard to get a promotion.  Some of the projects can be a bit dull.

Pros: Lots of technology, a lot of it leading edge, and a bunch of it legacy systems that still need people knowledgeable in it because it is part of the backbone of all the new stuff.
Cons: Shifting focus of upper management, being a large corporation, folks get shifted around a lot, and a lot of folks seem to get left behind when the dust settles.

Pros: I spent 17 years at IBM and the company gave me great opportunities that I will always be grateful for. There were, and are, extremely bright people and challenging work. IBM has thousands of clients, many very long-standing and has deep relationships with many of its clients.
Cons: Pressures to turn around the revenue declines have turned the company into a meat grinder. The company is really now run by the finance org, not by operational execs who understand the markets and the customers

Pros: You get to work with some of the smartest people on the planet. There is no limit to how you can to grow within the company.
Cons: If it wasn't for the excitement of learning from the best and working with the best, there's not much the company itself does does, in order to keep the team morale high. You can't help but feel the 'can't wait to go home' energy on a daily basis.

Pros: Good pay. great coworkers.  snacks, can work from home most days.
Cons: Missing some perks I got elsewhere like on-prem gym and cell phone stipend.  It seems like most things never get done, don't work right or are late.  Everyone has a sense of irony.  Whenever I assume something will work out my coworkers say, "you must have never worked for IBM berfore" or "prepare to have your hopes and dreams crushed."  They are joking but only half-joking.

Pros: Great teams to work with, very skilled and knowledgeable team members - THINK - a basic belief / mantra as you approach the business. A company that is committed to the success of their clients, employees and the company. Loyal customers and a strong brand and heritage. Great place to launch a career and grow.
Cons: One of the basic principles/basic beliefs of IBM was - Respect for the individual - with the initiation of resource actions as a means of balancing the workforce, this respect for the individual for the employee has dropped off over the years.

Pros: Great campus vibe (pre-covid), Gym, snacks, a LOT of campus activities. Long term career opportunities exist--it's still on you to do the legwork! Easy to build a network and or obtain mentors--again, you still need to put in the work. IBM promotes and values diversity and inclusion.
Cons: Layoffs appear to happen almost every year.

Pros:
* great vision for the cognitive era of computing and its role in business, government, and society
* ample talent and resources to bring the vision to life
* limitless opportunities for anyone to contribute and be part of this journey into the future
Cons: IBM is big, complex, and ever changing. If you're looking for a regular 9-5 job in a static environment -- think again. IBM will support you in efforts to change the world -- but you have to lead the way and show you can do it.

Pros: Good Healthcare options and HSA plan is no cost to LTS Employees
Cons: Hire you as Long term supplemental with reduced PTO and benefits package, Company is all about volume and # of fills, reports, KPI's and metrics. You are expected to carry and effectively manage and huge req load and still do a good job in just 40 hours per week but you end up working way more. High pressure to meet KPI's that is all they focus on --- you are just a #

Pros:
The level of competence across all employee levels is very high, at least at ibm.com.
Great workplace environment in my division
Forward-thinking technology-wise, fully embracing social media
Good work/life balance
Good opportunities for advancement
Cons:
Lots of politics
Too many silos.  Company is so big, there may be thousands of people doing similar work as you, but if you're not in your department, you may never hear about them.
IBM is a global company; US employees are the most expensive, so many jobs are being outsourced, and management is under terrific pressure to downsize all the time
Too many contractors, not enough full-timers.  IBM gives a false impression of the number of employees there because probably 40-60% are contractors.

Pros: Fantastic breadth of opportunity to either expand depth of knowledge through research or scope of experience by working on a variety of projects.
Cons: Understanding that things take longer in a large organization and there are lots of processes that need to evolve quickly becomes a challenge/requires patience and urgency in large quantity and at the same time.

Pros: diversity of technology, ability to learn new skills
Cons: politics seem to out weight business objectives, as a result people don't always focus on what's best for IBM in lieu of their personal short term objectives.

Pros:
Work, life balance is realistic and very advantageous. Flexibility in work schedule and location is left to mobile employees giving you the opportunity to live anywhere in the world.

Company is committed to social responsibility and maintains very competitive and liberal employment policies. Great corporate values.
Cons: Glass ceiling for associate partners. Still old boys network. Company needs to walk the talk. Lip service given to many real, day-to-day policies that employees are supposed to live by. Company often alters annual policies mid year making it difficult to live up to personal business commitments. Employees often bogged down by internal paperwork and bureaucracy making it difficult to get work done.

Pros: IBM is a cornerstone in creating a very DIVERSE place to work and that is one of the reasons I was attracted to working here. It's the first place I was ever OUT from the beginning and have always been and will always be. I'm proud to work for such an inclusive and supportive company.
Cons: In working for such a large company with nearly 400,ooo people you feel like a number sometimes.

Pros: Good reputation in the market and benefits.  Company has the name to get you into any account easily.
Cons: The company has a 6 month quota system that they adjust to make sure that they keep your pay in check. They do this to place a cap on your income.  The company is a huge matrix to figure out and it involves a huge group for everything at times there is a lot of conflict as each person is driving for a different objective.

Pros: Good opportunities for personal development , opportunities for advancement if you have what it takes, the people are great - some of the smartest people around work here.
Cons:
Work-life balance not an option in some areas of the organization
Have to deal with internal barriers (aka business processes) to get things done
Employees often do not have the resources to get things done
No conference travel in eons
Average or below average salary and benefits

Pros: IBM offers great Benefits for their employees.
Cons: With this division of IBM employees are viewed as a resource.  The employee is not the most valued resource,  profit and revenue is the only driver with IBM. IBM is move a lot of jobs offshore, and/or replacing full time employees with temp or contractors staff.

Pros: IBM is a large company with lots of different areas so if there is not an immediate fit, there are generally opportunities to find other areas to work in.
Cons: IBM has over the last several years performed well financially but distributed very low bonus payouts to employees, at least in the US. Additionally, IBM has very aggressively moved as many jobs as possible out of the US to low cost centers, resulting in layoffs every year.

Pros:
Flexible work schedule. 
Low work load for the competent.
If you're a tech geek and play the politics, you can play with lots of new toys.
Still sells some hardware, software, and operating systems that are excellent tools for having stable business IT.
Cons:
A lack of backbone in lower management unless it's a factor in drive to rise in the ranks.
Those that rise in the ranks usually have a vision of having a fiefdom instead of looking at the company as a whole.
For a technology company that does consulting for banking and pharma, they can't seem to learn from processes they help implement for their customers and serve their customers well.

Pros: Brand recognition, access to resources to get information, global, sheer size, everyone has heard of IBM and the pay and benefits are really great
Cons: It is very difficult to get the management approval processes to move as fast as the clients require, therefore many opportunities are lost and you can miss targets as a result. It's also very difficult to work in the services or given the products driven culture

Pros:
Can work from home most of the time
 Lots and lots of OT (the only way to make 1/2 way decent salary)
 Free health insurance
 6% 401k match
 Profit sharing bonuses
 Paid technical training
Cons:
Not enough room for advancement
 People with no experience getting lead and manager positions
 Some managers will only give 2 for PBC score (hint, switch teams now, dont wait another sec.)
 Far below fair market value in pay (hence why so many demand OT over comp time)
 GDF is a failure, too much overhead and accounts are leaving, they need to dump it

Pros: Lot of opportunities inside the organization to grow and look for opportunities that might be of your interest. Diverse work culture and a lot of focus on patenting ideas.
Cons: You are a drop in an ocean. To get visibility from senior or middle management, you have to market yourselves. More than the work you do, you may be appreciated for the initiatives you take and how good you can communicate and convince others.

Pros: Good people.  Exciting technology.  Work-life balance for most of my time working there.
Cons: In the 80's and 90's, I think IBM still had a foundation based on respect for the individual.    That seems to have gone by the wayside over the last ten years.    The core of the company, the "IBMer" who signed on, and stayed loyally with the company for their entire career, is a thing of the past.

Pros: IBM seems very generous with the way it handles its employees. Between the benefits package, IBM events, community discounts, essentially unlimited sick leave, and flexible work schedule, it has made for a fantastic starting point for an IT career.
Cons: IBM is implementing a new system for technical support, and it is currently going through understandable growing pains. For the most part management still seems to be trying to figure out how to best handle the new system, and many odd decisions are made that often hinder efficiency in favor of process.

Pros:
- IBM Corporate culture is geared towards continual improvement and collaboration. 
- Many, many, growth opportunities exist withing the company.
- Evolutionary innovation exists at IBM
- Large corporate IP portfolio which to build from
Cons:
- East Fishkill culture is gravely flawed, lack of ownership and vision!!!
- Hardware division lacks revolutionary innovation

Pros: Telecommuting, which offers some flexibility in work schedule.
Cons: All about the next quarters bottom line. No raises in over 5 years. International outsourcing requires 7am phone calls to China as well as 2+ hours calls to China starting at 8pm. Sure makes your day feel like it never ends. Have to use Lotus Notes. Now being required to run RedHat (RHEL6) for email, and then Windows inside a VM for "security". This might not be so bad if things worked properly under RHEL or if the VM scaled properly but that's not the case.

Pros: Great place to work if your a software engineer, you will have a job for life. Work/life balance is great. Pay is fair.  Lots of vacation and paid time off. Good benefits.
Cons: If your a hardware engineer you will have to be in the right group or you will always have to worry about the next layoff, which happens every year like clockwork. Upper Management is lost and appear to have no clue what they are doing. Apparently the only way they can make money is to lay people off.

Pros: Best reasons to work here include opportunity to lead in many technology areas and great educational opportunity.
Cons: Some of the cons of working here are::while data as seen as a natural resource,  employees are not.  Benefits and opportunity are eroding - be it salary, health benefits, 401k (matching for the year only occurs if still on payroll as of year end, many jobs have moved outside of the US and to employees who have been with the company for less than 5 years.

Pros: Co-workers.  But nothing else.
Cons:
Management is so busy taking cash out of the company that they have lost control of the business.
After the last re-org theatre there are literally 1000s of people sitting around with nothing to do.  There is no mandate. No direction.
Employees are blamed and penalized for management's misdeeds.  No raises. No control over your career.  There are no careers left at IBM.  You are at the whim of the company. The rating system is entirely corrupt.  It awards brown-nosers.  Management forces business conduct guidelines and platitudes down your throat while breaking every rule.
The company is completely hierarchical.  Employees are serfs who are punished for speaking up.  Stock prices are manipulated.  Employees are lied to.  Employees lose their jobs for no rhyme nor reason. Employees are pitted against each other.

Pros: Incredible work flexibility, unlimited work at home and sick days, the opportunity to work on cool projects for big name customers.
Cons: Since our new CEO took over in 2013, morale has been decimated.  Good business units have been sold off, others are mismanaged into the ground.  It is very difficult to get a bonus, a pay raise, or a promotion.  To top it off, our software engineering salaries have stagnated below the national average.  Local management teams have almost no leeway to give an empoyee a raise or promotion to keep them on the team.

Pros:
* Flexibility at work. 
* Support from several other teams within IBM
* Travel is limited to small geographical regions
* Several educational resources
Cons:
* Market perception of IBM is not very positive, if covering small and medium businesses.
* Promotions and pay raises are not easy
* Be prepared to do an unofficial  TAM (Technical Account Manger) role for existing customers ensuring all their support requests are properly handled and they have deployed software. (It really may not be a Con. It may be a boring, but good practice)

Pros: Promoted fast and lots of experience gained in roles, good people you work with in somers. Work from home whenever possible.
Cons: High turnover, no experienced hires, minimal training, work until you break, low compensation,

Pros:
I applied online in early June and received initial contact from the hiring manager in early July.  The first phone interview was with the hiring manager.  He told me a bit about his particular department and the types of products his UX team is currently working on.  He then asked me to talk about a couple of projects in my online portfolio.  A few weeks later I had a second phone interview with two members of the UX team.  The conversation was the same as the first call.  

Throughout the process, the manager was kind enough to keep me in the loop instead of leaving me in the infamous black hole of uncertainty.  He was very accommodating when I expressed that I had received another offer while waiting for IBM to make their decision and tried to fast-track the process for me.  

I was then asked to fill out my residential and criminal histories for the last seven years.  After this, I took the IBM Information Processing Aptitude Test (IPAT) which consisted of three logic-based sections, two of which were numbers based.  I'm not a math person, so this was nerve-wracking for me, but I heard that it's an outdated test that they don't really pay attention to. 

A few days later, The manager asked to set up a short phone call.  I was expecting another interview or to talk about flying me out for an on-site interview, but to my surprise was offered the position.

It was a great base salary offer with great benefits for someone fresh out of college like myself. I'm still in the process of gathering information prior to starting, but I can tell that IBM wants us to succeed.  It still feels like I'm dreaming.
Cons:
In the beginning I was only communicating with the hiring manager. Once I received the offer letter, I was told to communicate with a recruiter from HQ in Armonk, NY. Having to deal with a completely new person in a completely different location kind of slowed the process down and it seemed somewhat unnecessary to involve a third party at this point.  Since then, the recruiter has been much slower in responding than the manager, but I don't want to distract the manager from his primary job.

Because of this, the on-boarding process could be made a bit smoother. Communications with a slow-to-respond recruiter is frustrating when you have less than two weeks to find an apartment and move across the East coast.

Pros: There are lots of things to like about IBM, first their legacy. They have existed for a long time and still vibrant and leading in major technologies. For instance, watson is a great product helping to save lives. Most of their software too are cutting edge.
Cons: I am aware that every company has one reason or the other for personal opinion, but I strongly believe that most of these opinions can be bias. So, it depends on how determined someone is ready to succeed.

Pros: Great on a resume. The benefits are decent, but you don't get full benefits until after 2 years. There is opportunity for growth, but it's really hard getting your current managers to help you transfer to where you need to go to grow.
Cons: Hard to transfer. Benefits don't fully kick in until after 2 years. The max number of vacation days you get after 20 years is 20 days off.

Pros: I learned a lot at IBM over many years and most of the people were great. There are more new things to do every day and there is nothing the company is not involved in.
Cons: The frustration level is extremely high, the care for people is very low, and the company does not realize it. You can do great things at IBM, but you really need to weather a tough environment and some pretty random cuts.

Pros: Overall great company with great benefits.  Managers are very focused on the needs of the individual employees. The compensation and benefits are not as generous as they were in the past and have move much closer to the industry average.   Great support for skill development
Cons: It is a very, very big company.  No single review can give it justice because the environment will vary greatly by business unit and sub-domains.   Someone who isn't comfortable with big orgs (large cities, large schools, etc) may feel lost.

Pros: IBM (and Watson, specifically) is a major player in the new AI economy that has established itself in the tech industry. A position at IBM means your work may eventually have some very impactful effects on individuals and larger entities who are customers. IBM takes care of its employees, as well, with comfortable salaries, adequate vacation allotments, and a very generous 401(k) matching program.
Cons: The company is just too big to move quickly. Politics and geographical separation make collaboration extremely difficult, and sometimes brings into question the scientific merit of what products get shipped. Specific cities are also not adequately classified for things like salary and cost of living considerations.

Pros: Great opportunity to learn new technical skills and keep your career at the cutting edge. If you peel off the layers of inefficiency there are some great people and great minds. Excellent opportunity in a good organization and work from home is a big plus.
Cons: The whole show is run by insecure and political leads who lack skills and vision. Harassment and bullying is very much alive. Chat monitoring is non-existent and that spawns a ripe environment for targeting, harassment and bullying.

Pros: Most peers are intelligent, hard-working, and respectful. Some of the best folks to work with.
Cons: Executives care only about lining their own pockets and very little about the folks doing the work. Bonuses are almost non-existent as are raises and promotions. Neither good work nor hard work ensure job safety. If profits don't meet expectations, EVERYONE is at risk of being cut.

Pros:
Diversity: company's respect to minorities is awesome.
Technology: it is great to feel like you are part of the next big thing.
Cons:
Oldfashioned Management: middle and higher management feel like they are stuck in 1980/1990. A lot of talking about "The New IBM", but no action to fundamentally change the structure. 
Prevalent Disorganization: everything is caotic and disorganized. None of the departments talk to eachother and the customer (and those representing the company before them) are penalized. It went as far as having someone elses bonus paycheck cashed into my account. 
Payment: under the market average... no matter the area or position.

Pros: Serving clients.  Removing their pain points.  Interesting projects.  Good mix of old and new puzzles.
Cons: Heightened & incrementally increasing year over year disregard for the individual.  No tangible evidence of Field Service Division leaders viewing the workers as their most valuable asset.  Encroachment on personal life in an effort to provide best of breed service with staff erosion.  I would highly recommend against my offspring following my path in my current job.

Pros:
You will meet talented engineers if you get to work with those outside of the CIC

If your skills are lacking, for whatever reason, this is a good place to learn on your own and get where you need to go.
Cons:
The salary is laughable compared to the national average.
Promotion is non existent
The CIC has a band cap so you won't get that far
The projects will set you up for failure because all of the technology is ancient
Management is basically lying to your face so you won't leave

You will have to have some serious connections to leave the CIC and get on IBM's real pay scale.

Pros: Flexibility, Education, Job Diversity, Teaming, Remote Work, Travel
Cons: Compensation Regulations (internally)  have a tendency to be a disadvantage to long time employees. Its easy for someone who has been with the company 5 years to be instantly out-paid (10-20k more) by a college grad, professional hire, new hire.  This is to be considered someone starting at a low pay band and works their way up...the compensation increase plateau fairly quick for that employee while give way to someone with unproven capabilities making hand-over-fist more.

Pros:
- Able to touch multiple levels of code
- Write code designed to scale for millions of users
- Hours are generally 40 per week
- Company really tries to make you succeed / have you learn
- Watson Health is trying to solve hard/interesting/good problems
- Office is in an amazing location (for Cambridge, MA)
Cons:
- No food (yet?)
-  A lot of audio conferencing (small push to video conferencing)
- A lot of young engineers, lacking senior engineers
- Slow moving (healthcare has a lot of red tape)

Pros: Trusted advisor to clients big and small, across different industries and geographies. I love the fact that innovation is at the heart of the work - not just patents but new techs like artificial intelligence (cognitive), quantum computing, blockchain.  And I really like the focus on values and diversity around the world. We recently expanded parental leave (regardless of Family unit/type), just another example of leading with values. The company also has a focus on work/life balance and has that infused in leadership education. Finally, lots of opportunity to change roles and grow new skills.
Cons: Constant change to create new markets, improve the portfolio, engage new markets. Not suited for people who prefer to stay in one area.

Pros:
- Great Benefits which includes, PTO, PCH, Sick Time Off, medical benefits, Matching 401K, Stock Options.
- learning Resources are so many  and free that you can pretty much utilize and learn anything that relates to your career and grow with them.
- Tools that IBM uses are very intuitive and technologically advanced in the IT market which makes job simple to understand and use.
Cons: - In the area where I am working is very competitive and data centers getting build consistently which creates lots Job opportunities with higher pay and Management is not able to match that which causes high turnover and losses of great talent and dissatisfied employees

Pros:
- So many great opportunities
- can work on cutting edge and high profile projects
- competitive salaries
- clear career paths
Cons:
- lacks mentorship (really have to look for a mentor)
- can be a dispersed environment (not always a bad thing)
- have to actively look for project so you don't get stuck on a bad one (which can last a long time)

Pros: Awesome benefits in the beginning that went to great benefits. Work from home options assisted with worklife balance
Cons: Last 7 years continual fear of resource actions(IBM for layoff) as the company continues to send work out of country.  Management heavy. Tons of managers. Annual review also sucked. You write your own review then management picks it apart to justify a per-determined rating

Pros: I have only worked with wonderful, smart, and hardworking people who support each other and don't play games. They respond to emails and Slack messages promptly and all realize we are a part of a greater team. The benefits are good and the pay is comparable to similar positions in the RTP area. Lots of opportunity for growth and professional development and the company is doubling down on it's commitment to the environment. People say IBM is an "old" tech company, but it is moving very fast and effectively towards a new outlook that will drive serious revenue for years.
Cons: Constant shifting of employees makes it hard for teams to gel and get into a high productivity cadence.

Pros: Socially responsible, learning and skills-based culture, strongly focused on diversity and inclusion, competitive pay for top performers, work with really smart people creating innovative cool technology. Access to a massive amount of free training. You can move between teams, to different sites (even globally), and through different professions. Great chance to have multiple careers all in one great company.
Cons: After years of transforming to Cloud and AI, business results are just showing signs of positivity, which means raises and bonuses will take a couple more years to improve. But potential is high.

Pros: There are a lot of opportunities to learn about interesting tech.
Cons: Management and senior leadership at IBM have their heads in the ground. Their compensation is not competitive, growth opportunities in Corporate Development are incredibly lacking after years of them saying they're working towards fixing it, and there's a culture of following the big machine's process instead of asking why or trying to change it for the better. Anyone with new ideas might feel empowered to change this, but will leave beaten down and uncared for.

Pros:
- Great opportunities to learn as much as you want
- Open door management policy
- Constant improvements to address internal feedbacks
- Excellent opportunities exist to move laterally and explore other job roles
- Supportive culture and Self empowered culture to steer and drive personal and career development
- Respectful company culture
Cons:
- Many internal tools and complicated processes, which are on the journey for consolidation and standardization for improvements
- Salary, Insurance and benefits can be more competitively benchmarked to the top Tech companies
- Complex organization, takes times to know the teams you will be working with

Pros: At IBM, my experince has been very rewarding and refreshing. Skilled teams, continuous learning and an electric environment with many different technologies being applied in every known sector. Emphasis is moving to AI based models for solutioning with a culture to deliver the very best to clients is inherent in every decision that is made. There is no better place to be than at IBM for work-life balance which is phenomenal relative to other consulting firms I have worked. Strong ethics, diversity and inclusion are key hallmarks that you can see in every team.
Cons: None that I can think of right now.

Pros:
Following are the best reasons I think anyone should like IBM.
-Research in particular helps you innovate and also absorb your creative inputs. 
-Lot of highlight on work life balance (honest effort from the company)
-Very flexible work hours
My liking for IBM are mainly because of these additional reasons:
-I work in research and not too many companies have industrial research labs like of IBMs. They are unique for carrying academia quality research in industry
Cons:
My points of dislikes
-not a good ladder in terms of professional growth. You are silo-ed in specific groups and very difficult to reach across. 
- you are evaluated on your bands and the process is too bureaucratic

Pros: IBM values their employees.  Employees are compensated well, both in their salary and medical and health benefits.  Employees are provided an opportunity for advancement all over the world.  If you are requested to transfer to a new location, they make the entire process as painless as possible. They help with the sale of your current residence, provide interim living expenses, help with the purchase of your new residence and even subsidize a lower interest rate on your new mortgage.  They provide all of the resources necessary in order for you to complete your work.
Cons: The only difficult period was during the troubling 1990’s.  At that time, IBM was forced to abandon their “Full Employment Principle” and initiate the Ranking System, whereby, periodically; the lower 5% of the workforce was dismissed.

Pros: IBM is a good place for a diverse experience across a wide range of areas. I
Cons: Stagnant advancement, poor communication with management, older workforce.  have been here for less than a year and have received very little feedback and very little contact with management. Opportunity to grow and move up seems to be very difficult because people tend to stay around for a long time. There was very little growth which also limited career advancement. The work force average age is rather high and people seem to be set in their ways of doing things rather being inovative. Instead of looking for new ways to approcah problems they stick to what they know.

Pros: You can work from home a lot of the time and while in different cities.  There are lots of training (classes) provided by IBM you can take.  Managers are flexible on you taking time off work to take care of person errands.  After IBM your resume will have lots of name recognition.
Cons: They have been gradually outsourcing lots of software development work to India and China. Its only a matter of time before they will no longer have software developers here in the US.  PBC ratings completely unfair.  Management basically rates your performance against the entire organization and not individual performance.

Pros: Minority and female advancement opportunity
Cons: Job insecurity.  IBM is committed to sharp reductions in US employee base

Pros: None...Used to be a great company to work for but not any longer.
Cons: Pay raises of 1% or 2% every few years drives newer employees away. Unfortunately the respect for the individual that was IBM's creed has vanished. Used to be the Flagship company to work for however now just another large multinational that most new hires stay on for 5 years and then move on.

Pros: Smart people, good experience overall provided you work hard and get yourself a good role on the project. There is a lot of scope for enhancing your technical skills especially in the Application Information Services practice area.
Cons: Some projects are large - do not necessarily have a great work culture. You might end up feeling lost or may not get a role of your choice in such situations. Raises are not good enough. An experienced person ends up making the same as a new hire after couple of years of working at IBM. This is one of the main causes why IBM would suffer from low retention rates especially in their experienced band 6-7 resources.

Pros: In a sales function, the name IBM certainly opens doors with prospective clients; they're more willing to listen.  There is more than enough training in all aspects: function, product, industry.  I enjoyed and miss working with smart and dedicated professionals.  Direct management that I experienced was fair and reasonable.  Lots of fun networking opportunities in major cities.
Cons: Things move relatively slow in a large organization and consequently enthusiasm can lose steam.  On the other hand, a recent reorganization in sales and marketing swiftly cut thousands of positions.  Once hired, if you want to stay with IBM, learn as much as possible, keep your eyes and ears open, and network like crazy to secure your next position.

Job Title: Program manager - software sales and marketing
Pros: Excellent environment to gain and expose skills in varied parts of the business. No one need feel as though they are placed in a niche work environment- never to entertain other viable options (including world wide assignments) within organizations.
Cons: Lack of focus by management to recognise employee skills levels  and assist placing them in appropriate roles within organization. Need to stop the 24x7x365  work day demands.

Pros:
1. The congeniality and the people willing to help. 
2. Being a very large company, IBM has jobs in almost every field in CS and many non CS fields.
3. You can develop niche skills that are tough to find elsewhere.
Cons:
1. Reading legacy code and supporting old technologies might seem uninteresting to fresh college graduates.
2. Being very huge has its own disadvantages - like - a few processes/rules that might not make a lot o sense, but have to be followed.

Pros: The caliber of the people I worked with, ability to network, collaborate, and communicate with others, and flexibility and freedom to do my work on my own schedule in my own way.
Cons: They have barely any FT job offers for their interns (at least in my area), and their persistent focus on cost-cutting and leanness has led to overworked, under-appreciated employees.

Pros: Quality people and a fast paced environment that will help you maximize your potential.  Great flexibility of work/life balance.  Even with all the changes in the world, and even some negative ones at IBM, IBM still manages to make the work experience a model for the rest of the world to look up to.
Cons: Small fish in a big pond for sure, but these are merely byproducts of the environment.  Your challenge is not to complain about them but to adapt and become successful in the framework that exists.

Pros: To develop great skills, works with some of the brightest minds, and support some of the biggest companies in the world.
Cons: The constant focus on layoffs impacts employee motivation and performance.  IBM was once the best of the best and has reduced intself to a commodity.

Pros: There are some good employee discounts with large partners.  Some good perks include public transportation passes, recreation areas (at least at my site), and flexible work-at-home schedules.
Cons: There are about 300,000 fewer American employees in IBM than there used to be, and you can expect that number to grow.  Compensation lags competitors and won't be improving.  Some of the cost-cutting measures over the last several years are ridiculous, such as reduced trash collection.

Pros: Decent compensation.  But watch-out for those who become employees in an acquisition!  They do not grand-father tenure from previous company in compensation calculations when they lay you off.  Also, they are committed to drawing down their US staff as much as possible.
Cons: Our small customer-focused software company was acquired by IBM SWG in 2009.  They laid-off 25% of us within first year.  They would not allow us to go to training for other software tools.  Their bureaucracy and "blue washing" is ridiculously cumbersome.  They were only interested in Sales numbers and only gave lip service to customers.

Pros:
Chance to work with world class technology.  
Vacation holiday and personal time flexibility.  
Health benefits seem to be pretty good.
Cons:
Erosion of support functions, leads to extra work just to keep your work environment going.  Workstation support is one, admin support is another. 
Recurring layoffs keeps you on edge.

Pros: Brand name.  Difficult & challenging assignments:  great "boot camp" for future opportunities
Cons: Workload increases constantly.  Most of my peers and coworkers are constantly putting in 60-70 hour weeks just to keep up as well as giving up vacation time.  We feel like we are being ground to bits at this pace.  What used to be a work-life balance benefit (work from home) has turned into you-are-on-call-20hrs/day.  I get the pressures of the current economy, but this is not sustainable.

Pros: Home-based employees, great benefits, top-notch ethics, easily accessible management, decent work-life balance, unlimited training and learning opportunities. Change is a constant - I put this as a "Pro" because IBM tends to anticipate and drive many market segments.
Cons: Complexity drives the downsides: too many account managers with different agendas; corporate processes and matrix structure can be overwhelming, especially for new employees. Rigidity, which is needed for such a large company, often ties hands of management when it needs to be more nimble, such as with employee retention or in highly competitive sales cycle situations. Self-service culture. Compensation is neither worse nor better than industry average.

Pros:
People - I have really enjoyed most of the people I worked with at IBM. That being said, most of the young ones who were great moved on to other companies. There were some really great employees who had been there longer and were just sticking around because their project was a good fit. 

Projects – There are a lot of projects that will give you exposure to all sorts of different clients and industries. However, if you aren’t staffed on a project you only have a certain amount of time (30-60 days) before you’ll be let go. There are a good number of projects but if you can’t find one in your location you’ll have to look across the country so be prepared to travel anywhere in the US if you aren’t staffed locally. Some practice areas are more particular than others that you work on a project in THAT practice area which can make finding a project even more difficult. 

Health/Vision/Dental – pretty standard, you have good options to choose from each year. 

401K – IBM does have a good 401K match percentage (up to 6%) but they don’t match until the very END of the year so if you leave anytime before 12/31 you won’t get your match. Something to consider before ever leaving IBM.
Cons:
The experience at IBM varies WIDELY depending on which department and practice of IBM you join, as well as the project you are assigned to. For IBM GBS, like the other major consulting companies, there talent model is to hire the best talent they can, overwork them so their profit margins are high, and only promote those that contribute the most; they expect the rest to leave voluntarily after they’ve had too much. 

For those that stick around, the responsibilities continue to pile up the further up the chain you go. Having a good work/life balance isn’t realistic if you plan to move up, unless you want to stay at the same level on the same project for as long as you can. I know several people who are doing this and will quit if they have to move to another project. On top of regular project work, employees are expected to help out with recruiting events, assist with bids and proposals (B&P), contribute to their practices areas in various ways, and have at least 40 hours of training every year. Consider that a full plate? I've also heard that most of the very high-ups don't even have time to take their own vacation. Sad.

Performance Reviews – everybody is given a rating (1, 2+, 2, 3). Mostly everyone is given a 2 if they meet their goals. People have to work a LOT more to get a 1, something in the 150% utilization range and lots of “giveback”. All that work and the bonuses aren’t even that much. Not worth it in my opinion. 

Managers – In three years I only spent 3 minutes face to face with my personal manager and we never worked on the same project. The quality of managers varies widely across GBS and each practice area. I knew another IBM manager on one project who was thankfully quite frank about things since he's near retirement age. He described the upper management of GBS with terms such as 'shady', 'selfish', 'backstabbing', and 'dishonest'.

Promotions – employees have to fill out a promotion application and submit it for review. The process can take 6 months or longer and the application itself is quite extensive, mine came out to 30 some pages in Microsoft Word. There is no visibility in to how they actually decide (other than that you have good utilization).

New Hires - I also found out that GBS was offering new hires $10K more than my current salary, and a $7K signing bonus. I was hired during the recession in 2010 when salaries were lower, but even still I was pretty angry there was such a large difference. After I got promoted I was still making ~$3/4K less than what they were offered. Unbelievable if you ask me.

Pros: If you are a hard worker you will do well at IBM. You are surrounded by talented people. Company has great values. You are told to never compromise your values and alway conduct business in a ethically. Even in sales!
Cons: You are definitely part of a machine, its hard to shine until you put in you time. Lots of process. I guess you can expect that from a 100 year old company.  But with that said the pros out way the cons for sure

Pros:
Good team atmosphere, everyone's nice. Work is OK, not overly demanding. Learned a lot. 

Good emphasize on a systematic approach to software development, most based Agile Methodologies. They also encourage you to establish patents and technical articles. 

You may be able to work with a lot of teams around the globe. And you have some opportunity to rotate to oversea offices
Cons: I met many low-key experts and I also met quite a few egoistic know-it-all. Really need to focus on concrete learning by yourself and make sure your skill set has a strong foundation. You need to search and discover who those real experts are, the ones who are willing spending time to help you to grow your own expertise.

Pros: big company, tons of resources, large client base. IBM has some of everything making them capable of competing with anyone in any space
Cons: The pay is lower than industry average and the amazing benefits are starting to be watered down. Management is under ridiculous targets which can't be met leading to negative feelings in the rank and file as we are very short sighted and cheap. Many managers and partners are not good consultants, they have just stayed for many years. Tons of politics.

Pros: Professional colleagues who are usually willing to help.  Easy to move around US while staying in the same position.  A sense of stability, depending which group you are in ( I am in SWG).  Salary seems to be competitive no matter of race or sex.
Cons: Management does not provide what is needed to be excellent only enough to get by.  Hard to be a top performer without sucking up to management.  Very hard to move up without being a consecutive top performer (1).

Pros: Emphasis on learning - excellent place to learn new skills, it's very encouraged to expand one's skill set and there are plenty of opportunities to do so: conferences, podcasts, in -person etc. Very good life/work balance with an option of working from home several times a week, no micro-management, as long as work gets done nobody seems to be checking how many hours were spent doing it (it has its pros and cons of course!). Had
Cons:
Outsourcing - at least in the finance community. Three of my jobs were outsourced and whole departments were moved out of the country. 
Salary - not very competitive for the industry average.

Pros: Ground floor of a big movement in design, inspiring company legacy, vacation and benefits, funding.
Cons: Management cares more about perception than substance; they want to promote themselves as good designers more than to be good designers. IBM is a tough company to get things done in. It is so big that projects are disorganized and extremely political. It is hard to do good design here.
