Cons: IBM is still focused on mainframe. From a sales perspective, most of what we do is work on projects to wrap around mainframe. Seems like that technology is the cornerstone of what we work on.

Pros:
Good work/life balance
Flexible schedules
Ability to work from home
Great people doing the real work
Cons:
Executive and management teams care only about offshoring and getting the work done for the lowest cost with no concern for quality.
Management doesn't understand the importance of the work done even by their top performers
In recent years, wages have either been stagnant or have even decreased
All bonus pay has been eliminated
All ability to work overtime has been eliminated for those unlucky IT folks who had been "reclassified" as non-exempt
Severance package has been cut from six months to ONE month regardless of time with company
Most IT jobs at this company are dead end jobs with no opportunities for advancement or promotion whatsoever

Pros: Benefits on par with other large Fortune 500's. Training opportunities. Lots of enthusiasm from the younger employees starting out. Now Apple gadgets galore.
Cons: No idea how to sell services appropriately. Constantly being challenged by competitors for the same work, resulting in lower margins, higher travel requirements and mismatched resources. Bench time is severely penalized. So forget about taking advantage of the training opportunities unless you are making all of your numbers. It feels like a ship in decline.

Pros: The Summit Program has offered me top of the line sales training, that I feel as though is unattainable from any other company. I have been able to enhance my sales skills, as well as my overall business knowledge. Each day I find myself challenged, consistently learning throughout. Being able to shadow with some of the top sales professionals in the industry has been unbeatable in terms of sales knowledge. IBM and the Summit Program have set me up for my sales career, wherever it may take me in the company!
Cons: Being that IBM is such a large company, it can feel overwhelming. Networking and making connections as much as possible is a must in the company.

Pros: Very large accounts which makes for some great team interaction,  and an opportunity to take advantage of tools that many of us haven't used in awhile.   These are company policy standards that must be used such as Lotus Notes, SameTIme, Mozilla Firefox, Box.
Cons: Challenging place being that it requires using tools as part of company policy such as Lotus Notes, SameTIme, Mozilla Firefox, Box. No Outlook, Skype or Skype for Business, SharePoint or Azure to be used. Offshore used in almost all accounts, and has to be part of RFP and proposal submissions.

Pros: Worked with very smart hard-working people, very few egos and everyone I worked with was committed to driving projects forward. Good benefits for road warriors. Depending upon the department, there were some strong leaders in the organization.
Cons: 401k didn't kick in until you completed your first year with the company. Consulting side of the business was cyclical and we didn't win a lot of the types of projects I was brought in to lead. But because everyone needed to be billable, I was staffed on projects that weren't challenging or aligned with my skillset. Would have been fine if it were short-term but there was no end in sight.

Pros: Ethical dealings with clients.  They really put the customer first.  Excellent opportunities to switch around in jobs and careers as well as geographies.
Cons: These days it is all about the numbers.  What have you done for me lately.  I've seen some great people ushered out because of a bad client spending year.  Or a year after exceptional client spending that cannot be matched the following year.  Loyalty to the employee is much more limited than it used to be.

Pros: Great professionals  who are willing to help their peers.  Strong technology roadmap.
Cons:
Constant upheaval and changes that make it difficult to build a sustainable business.  Upward mobility is difficult due to so much uncertainty.  No real feedback mechanism that is acted upon.  A very tone deaf top leadership team.
There is an atmosphere of discontent across the board.

Pros: Internal education is frequent & diverse. Coworkers are some of the brightest & hardest working people in the industry. Great 401k 100% match to 6%
Cons: Constant & massive resource actions. Very low morale, everybody is nervous, unattainable sales quotas. Legacy top performing employees with 20+ years of valuable knowledge & experience are being let go with a mere 30 day severance for their decades of loyalty in favor of less skilled & lower salaried young college grads. Too many  underwhelming middle & senior managers who should be let go instead. No accountability at the top line for 20 straight quarters of declining revenue.

Pros: IBM typically has very well trained, experienced, open and thorough first line management which are always available to help new and old employees and legitimately care about their people.
Cons: Processes are often in constant flux. Pay tends to be below average in many/most divisions. Offshore outsourcing continues unabated as a way to offset the continued lack of revenue generation. Persistent disconnect between sales and support, transition & build to steady-state leads to extreme levels of micromanagement which only causes more muddled processes and lack of solid process improvement.

Pros: not many pros to this company unless you are corporate mgmt.
Cons: They play favorites when it comes to promotions  they don't promote according to knowledge and experience they go by  who kisses their butt the most.    they dont give pay raises after a year there.  I worked there 3+ year and never got a raise  maybe because i didnt kiss butt.  something i dont believe in. there is no education reimbursement,  the only peple that got raises were the very upper mgmt .  that is why they never had enough money to give us raises cause upper mgmt got all of it.

Pros: Because of the fact that it's a large company that has been around a while, they have proven systems in place, offering exceptional training, with the opportunity to move within the company to learn and grow. I loved my time there and the people were absolutely amazing. They hire exceptional people, who were all nice, fun and supportive.
Cons: In an effort to stay competitive, they do sometimes stretch the teams too thin. There were times that they consolidated roles into one, where I ended up doing the work that was previously done by 3 people. Thank heavens I had a great group of people around me who helped me do the work expected and achieve my goals.

Pros: Great legacy and history.  Ability to move around and work in different areas and develop new skills.  Still some of the better benefits in industry
Cons: Has become company run by accountants who fire good people indiscriminately.  Management scrambles quarter to quarter.  Spend most of your time reporting internally instead of doing real work.   So focused on getting "younger" they ignore everything else.

Pros: My manager helped with the overwhelming issue of every large company by introducing me to the stakeholders. Love my team and the wonderful options to move within the company.  A lot of options to continue education and work with others on projects.
Cons: Decisions are made at a level that do not know the impact it will have. Some managers will hold good people back so they can keep good employees with them. Layoffs are many and sometimes they are not based off of performance, more political.

Pros:
- There are some new smart people  within marketing
- Exposure to some good opportunities
Cons: -I spend most of my time working, its never ending. Some managers dont have boundaries, and do not encourage any sort of work life balance. Time off isnt encouraged at all

Pros: You can change paths in your professional career without leaving the company. A great place to work and grow professionally and as a person. Excellent values and ethics.
Cons: Complex and sometimes bureaucratic, too many middle managers, Directors, VPs reporting to other VP, GMs to GMs. The organization matrix is confusing.

Pros: large organization, lots of opportunities to move around and grow your career and skills. Although the actual diverse representation is pretty horrible, they do have great diversity and inclusion training, business/employee resource groups etc
Cons: awful culture and many poor leaders - rather than making "rea" change, they just keep shuffling the same leaders to different roles (and expecting different outcomes). Very focused on short term sales/signings and not on building trusted relationships with clients. They allow very poor behavior if you are a good salesperson.

Pros: Flexibility is the key, I do what I want, when i want, I head in late, and I leave early. As long as I get my work done, no one says anything to me. It's almost like working for your own company that is barely struggling along. The people are great too, and if it weren't for them IBM would have a HUGE problem retaining people.
Cons: PAY SUCKS, don't come here to be rich, or even decently paid. Even when told you are doing well, you will not get rewarded. No stories of great raises/bonuses/stock options. Just keep your head down, and work,

Pros: Despite being big blue and all the connotations that come with that, it's still a great place to work with such a large organisation that does such varied products. the locations IBM has across the world is also a bonus in providing the ability to visit other cultures and countries. there are many opportunities for recognition both within the company and on a wider stage with the range of research IBM carries out. work life balance has been a struggle in the past but has improved through the use of our own technology and acquisition of technologies have also spurred the company on.
Cons: the size of the organisation can sometimes be overwhelming

Pros:
- Encouragement to be the best you can be.
- Learning opportunities are good.
- Management encourages creative thinking.
Cons:
- Management will work you to the bone. They are trying to do too much with too few resources, constantly making me feel overwhelmed, and in the end unappreciated.
- There are too many processes hindering productivity and causing frustration beyond belief.
- Internal organizations don't always work well together. Getting help or cooperation from other organizations is problematic and another point of frustration.

Pros: Many places to work within IBM.  Building a strong network helps getting promoted and understanding IBM capabilities.
Cons: Middle management cannot and does not take risks.  Managers do not position their employees for success.  The finance organization and business controls prohibits many operational desires.

Pros: IBM has a culture of collaboration, integrity, and performance.  Individuals are given contribution targets and are expected to achieve them, but working with others is a prerequisite for success.  The company often manages by matrix, meaning that you can have objectives from different managers with different objectives; e.g., manage costs and grow revenue.  This tension makes for better overall performance, in my opinion.  I have worked at firms that belittle their clients when they're off-site and IBM doesn't tend to be that way.
Cons: You can get lost in the matrix if your manager isn't covering for you.  It's a big company and you need to have some political savvy as well as the ability to "cold call" within the organization to find the help you require.

Pros:
Great resume builder, every company will bring you in for interview with IBM experience
work with very bright people
Cons:
salary very low compared with industry
low level management freezes up when discussing matters with upper level management, will not think twice about throwing own employees under the bus as long as they look good
long hours and management grumbles when you take time off
little to no guidance or feedback from sr. management until year review
bonus is non-existant
not even think about salary increase
no room for growth, opportunities very limited unless you know someone
too much delegation of work
analysts don't understand information that is in the systems
organization is very top heavy

Pros:
exposure to many new and innovative approaches, software and global opportunities
fantastic if you are a hot sales person
employee benefits are very strong
Cons:
not employee friendly - strong bottom line focus
do not provide face to face training or hard to get funding for external training
very virtual atmosphere - over the last 5 years, I've seen my manager 5 times in person 
unless you are on a project with people in your division, you never get to meet them personally

Pros: Career is stable compare to other consulting companies.
Cons: System is very bureaucratic. You will get frustrated and leave after a while and no one cares. Things are improving recently making managers accountable for helping and retaining high performers. This will hopefully differentiate IBM from body shoppers.

Pros: Strong company strategy and a real chance to succeed in the market. Lots of tools and IP available. Flexible benefits. Good company culture. Global reach.
Cons: Complex processes. Company is very good in squeezing the most out of its employees making work-life integration (I guess they gave up on the term "balance") a challenge. You need a strong sponsor to move up as the complex matrix structure provides potentially too many stakeholders to roles. Negotiate for the highest salary possible when you come in as good incremental increases and promotions will be difficult to come by. Many jobs being shipped overseas.

Pros: You don't need much experience.  Lack of certifications in any product /technology was never an issue.  Great company for recent grads with no experience.
Cons: Certain IBM positions entail working long exhausting hours.  Very little training if any.  In my opinion, after the company requested and received US bailout money, the number of US positions that were lost to India increased.

Pros: Working at home.  Challenging projects.
Cons: Constant worry about being laid off because they move so many jobs off shore.  Raises are far and few between and pretty lean.  Plan to work 12-14 hour days and weekends.  No work/life balance.

Pros: Can't really think of any pros.
Cons: Once you become an employee of IBM don't expect being treated as a human being, it is all about what the company wants. Fringe benefits are a thing of the past. Raises are nonexistent, unless you are in management. They get incentives for squeezing all they can out of workers. The "bean counters" are on their  jobs 24/7. Moral is at an all time low for employees who have helped place this company were it is today and when you think you have given all you can give, you find out that your job has been outsourced. So much for gratitude.

Pros: Work at home flexibility, autonomy depending on your manager, pays well, great benefits; some big-picture projects.
Cons: Work overload, ongoing fear of layoffs, some of the processes are very rigid, extreme cost cutting that made team meetings impossible.  I never met my manager in the two years I worked for him due to cost reasons and we hadn't had a team meeting in 8 years for cost reasons.  Also while great, the work at home made some of us call IBM "I'm By Myself"

Pros: Large company with some sense of security if you are among the top contributors.  Benefits aren't bad.  Lots of room to move around if  you are  young and mobile.  Ability to work at home.
Cons: Resource Actions instead of revenue growth.  Benefits degraded from what they used to be.  One of the values that attracted me to this company was "Respect for the Individual", that is LONG GONE and has been replaced by new values centered solely around business results.  Pensions are gone for new employees and been replaced by an adequate 401K.

Pros: A lot of opportunity within the company.  Allowing you to move around over the years.
Cons: Terrible communication and culture fueled my Sr. Management.  Weekly focus on numbers causes a crazy number of sales cadence calls.  A toxic attitude has become pervasive after years of lay offs with little to no communication.  EPS goals for wall street are hurting moral and customer satisfaction.

Pros: Working from home full-time, work is easy, not stressful. Paid well relative to work and how much experience I have. Very rarely had to work over 40 hours per week and when I did, was paid overtime.  Learn what you can and get out!
Cons: I was a contractor so no benefits.  Also no raises, training, promotions, etc.  Basically I was only there to do my job and fully disposable.  The company is like a huge cruise ship that is sinking. Employees rarely get raises and when they do it is peanuts.

Pros: .Pays well, benefits, vacation, 401K
Cons: Good pay but believe me you REALLY earn every dime. Highly competitive and large demands placed on every employee are extremely high. Therefore, you can't trust anyone you work with. Management isn't as well aware as they would have you think. Had 7 managers in 10 years. Some of them didn't have a clue about proper management. More concerned about meeting work objectives than managing people and helping them achieve their goals, opportunities or promotions..

Pros: There are a large number of software development teams in IBM including both proprietary and open source team. With the right skills, it is possible to transfer to new jobs within the company.
Cons: Corporate downsizing has affected all areas affecting moral, and pay growth.  There are lots of very talented people at IBM but their jobs may be at risk if corporate decides to downsize.  Instead of retraining, the company is quick to layoff employees.

Pros: IBM offered flexible work hours.  The hours were long and there were no boundaries (i.e. 6a or 11p meetings on the same day are the norm); however, generally I could carve out time in the day to be there for my family.   The work at home environment allowed me to have more flexibility if a chlid was home sick.
Cons: No growth potential in the US.   A strong focus on outsourcing minimized opportunity for growth within the US.

Pros:
- Core technical teams work well together
- Work/life balance
- Recent restructuring done to provide autonomy so different pillars within IBM can begin finding ways to operate with speed and simplify
Cons:
- Processes are still thick and difficult to navigate at time
- Still the same yearly employee rating process so even if the team has experienced attrition without backfill a solid employee could be RA'd out
- Executive management team is disconnected from management and teams doing the actual work

Pros: A lot of smart people and a lot of support from colleagues. Great benefits. Flexible hours and locations as long as you can deliver your work on time.
Cons: Your career growth highly depends on you manager. Your SAM(service area manager) plays a huge role for your promotions. Sometimes it's unreasonable and totally unfair. I saw people did not do any much works, just because he/she worked in the same project as his/her SAM and he /she got promoted rapidly. A lot of good and smart people have left the company for that reason.

Pros: Great benefits.  This is a blue chip company that uses benefits for employee buy in.  More than fair consideration.   Definitely a model for other aspiring and existing organizations.
Cons: Caliber of Co-workers in business consulting were dubious, particularly with client facing work.  It's clear making computers is there thrust and where the energy is most involved, only fair to them as that's how they made their reputation.  To expand into the consulting industry requires a more rigorous analytical team.

Pros: Work-life balance is great.  I work with some really talented people, a few are among the best in the industry.
Cons: Constant layoffs, constantly being asked to do more with less and less, poor raises (far less than cola), poor bonuses, shrinking benefits, human capital considered a liability instead of an asset.

Pros: Easy access to decision-makers, excellent training, good products with strong R&D back-up . . . in other words, everything that a salesperson needs to compete.
Cons: I have worked for several software companies over the years and my sense is that IBM pays less than the industry average.  As you might expect, big company = big bureaucracy and I never felt that I had the power to really deliver for my customers in the way that I would have liked.

Pros:
Relaxed environment without much pressure. 
Group training with people of your own age and caliber which provides you to learn more and a supportive environment.
Very organized management with separate people manager for your HR and career related support
Cons:
Assigned me to a project which required skills different from the skills or domain I was trained. So it was tough to grasp all the concepts in the initial stage of project
Lesser salary growth at least for my position in my country
Slower career growth 
Lot of policies

Pros: The people and relationships I built in the company were and still are amazing.  With such a large corporation there are countless possibilities and with the right maneuvering it's possible to have a diverse and long career.  The company is currently in process of redefining itself which could mean great things for the future.
Cons: The Core Values of the company are top notch, however, not often implemented or experienced by the everyday employee.  Raises, growth driven profit and numerous other perks have been dwindling for years.

Pros: Decent benefits that come from working at a large company.  Career growth and opportunity.
Cons: I've only been an IBM employee for a little while.  What I have seen is a bit scary so far.  For a technology company to run on systems from the mid-80s should be a concern to anyone walking in.  Beyond their antiquated tech, the leaders say one thing then do another.  Not sure how you can grow key pieces of the business and at the same time, invest zero into them.

Pros: Provides unique opportunities for employees, including advancing education, leadership training and the ability to move into new areas of the business without changing companies.
Cons: Quarterly pressure on results can lead to short term decision making, for example including short term cost controls, etc. Also, support for "mobile" employees seems to be changing in favor of locating groups of employees in specific locations, which apply constraints on specific roles and will lead to significant reduction in opportunities for employees.

Pros:
Global and diverse 
Dedicated & Talented People
Cons:
Middle Management is a nightmare: first line managers that follow the process (and listen to their exec) prevail above leadership and customer appreciation 
Artificial: people and real results do not count: when you contribute well but do not fit culturally or politically with your local mgmt your career will not progress

Pros: Flexible work and vacation schedules
Cons: Lack of leadership from the Top down.  Very low employee morale in multiple divisions within the company. There is no trust between the employee population and management at the 1st, 2nd and 3rd levels.

Pros: I had heard glowing statements from recent new hires at IBM when I starting to look for a new career role.  Now that I've had 80 days as an IBM employee, I can state that the current IBM is a revitalized, open, collaborative, and exiting place to work.  The new collaborative mindset has been exciting yet surprising based on my prior experience at IBM.
Cons: Some old systems still remain.  Most notably Lotus Notes.  Does any one outside of IBM use it any more?

Pros: Some powerful products to sell, huge global reach, smart people
Cons: Management is constantly changing directions, people policies that show how little the company cares about it's employees, policies dictated from corporate that make little sense in some business units, ridiculous amounts of paperwork and corporate bureaucracy that make getting deals done near impossible (e.g. 24 approvals to release a simple price quote).  Salespeople required to sell the hot product of the day which is constantly changing and more often than not is vapor - go sell it and then we'll figure out how to deliver it (which NEVER works).  Constantly changing sales targets and territories - continuous reorganizations make it impossible to get traction in any one area.

Pros: company treats it employees well
Cons: lots of employees and employees  are not visable

Pros: Good salary, lots of employee resources and training
Cons: You are overworked, overlooked, and expendable. It does not matter how hard you work, how great your performance reviews are, you can be released at any time. If not all teams pull their weight, targets aren't met, or someone in a different portion of your sector drops the ball, you are all at risk. IBM's fealty is to their shareholders at the expense of their employees. Despite their trying to "shake things up" and rebrand as "not the old big Blue", old habits win out. IBM is a top heavy organization with more management and process than output and innovation.

Pros: Very smart people that you can learn from. Innovation through collaboration is encouraged and rewarded. Results in general are rewarded. It has been a very challenging time for the company but the people and the quality of the solutions delivered makes it a great place to get experience on how to succeed just about anywhere. You can learn so much from incredibly talented co-workers and can in turn be a great resource for others.
Cons: Very tough environment and lots of org changes over the past 5 years. Can be very bureaucratic, adhering to standards can be limiting and time-consuming for products and solutions. Sometimes it is difficult to get things done quickly.

Pros: The fact that IBM is immersed into almost every industry and governments throughout the world affords many opportunities to work in a broad spectrum of roles and jobs. From banking, to digital video content post-processing and distribution to cloud, A.I., etc. I have had the pleasure of performing and thriving in all of those environments developing software solutions and systems. Plus every employee is within reach that you can call upon regarding their area of expertise and experiences. It is refreshing to see the level of effort that IBM'ers put into helping each other here.
Cons: I have yet to find any cons to working here at IBM.

Pros: Work-life ballance is good as you can " go at your pace to close renewals. Also , a large volume of Opportunities are Auto renewal and no touch.
Cons: countless non renewal requests come in on a daily basis from many areaa that have little to do with closing the renewal. hampering a rep from getting through their To do's for the day. Often felt like a billing specialist vs Renewal rep. I was also assigned 5 times the Number of accounts I anticipated.

Pros: A great place if you want to telecommute, their virtual services are second to none.
Cons: Management is just plain incompetent at all levels.  You'll never get a decent raise.  They expect you to work 80 hour weeks in most cases. You'll get no respect from any level of management and in many cases clients are so fed up with IBM that they are just waiting for their SLAs to expire and then they go with someone else.  I've seen it happen over 8 times in the last 5 years.  It is absolutely appalling.

Pros: Flexibility.  You can work from home and live anywhere.
Cons: A HUGE percentage of the jobs are being oursourced to other countries.  There is little funding for employee education.  This is not a people company anymore.  They just want you to work overtime all the time.  There is constantly this unspoken message that you better be happy that you have a job because we can outsource your job any day now.

Pros: big company, diversified, generally decent benefits and hr policies.
Cons: if you are a US citizen, it's unlikely you will have your job for long.  IBM is seemingly on the warpath to get rid of all American employees.  In some divisions, at least 65% of the employees are "global resource" .. apparently americans are not part of the 'global' community .. and that is only expected to go up.    Depending on your division, can be surprisingly cheap ... no money for education, travel etc., but other divisions can be quite generous, just luck of the draw where you end up.

Pros:
1> Stable organization, decent benefits, great work-from-home culture.
2> Lots of groups, departments... If you don't fit somewhere, you can try your luck at another dept.
3> People are respectful of other people's viewpoints
Cons:
1> No salary hike, no promotions
2> Not enough big projects in App Dev and Maintenance area... It's difficult to get large projects to lead/manage.
3> Lots of meaningless reviews, quality assurance activities, etc.

Pros: It is a large company with lots of opportunity.
Cons:
It is a large company with lots of processes and people to navigate. You can easily get stuck in a staffing pool and sitting unbillable - all as a result of business conditions and with no reflection on your individual skill. Nevertheless, they require a high billability - something in the mid-ninties - for you to even be considered for promotion. 

In addition, clients were not always the most educated buyers of consulting services so you had to justify your existance inside and outside the company. 

IBM also has substantial outsourcing capabilities but none of them relate to decks or writing.

Pros: - work-life balance -- work from home allowed
Cons:
-- Absolutely no meritocracy -- totally based on personal relationships
-- Raise and bonus are a joke, compared to industry
-- Career progression is bureaucratic and not merit based 

it is a heavily matrixed organization filled with ego-centric mediocre managers who have no competitiveness in them -- IBM is successful not because of skill but because of size. It needs some decent competition to spin the leaderships head.

Pros: There are so many different jobs within IBM, that you can literally do anything and have a career that travels the globe. Your job can have a global impact, even if you never leave your local area. Their policies supporting work at home, leave of absence, training and charitable giving are top notch .
Cons: Bottom line decisions made at the corporate level can feel heartless and callous. Being such a large company, if budgets and profits are on the line, sharp changes can occur with little or no notice.

Pros: Deep pockets and technology to properly fund and support interesting projects, great wealth of talented people to draw from, many whom go on to start other companies.  Good social and technical  interaction between employees all over the world = excellent teaming.  Acquisitions have been very well chosen.
Cons: Inconsistent management, too much politics and no long term measurement of management decisions.  Acquisitions not well integrated quickly enough, focus on process may unnecessarily scare away good talent - since most of it is trivial.

Pros: Global company with a tradition of technical excellence (read the con for context).
Cons: IBM is bent on meeting a 2015 stock increase commitment at all costs.  There is no avenue for skill development for current employees that wish to move into roles in emerging areas.  Why train someone in analytics or public cloud when you can buy a company and it's people.  If you join the company have a full handle of your careerpath and when you deviate from your goal, move on.  There is no loyalty and the golden years of caring about employees is gone for good.

Pros: If you like high structure and rules, this is the company for you.  Procedures are well written. Travel sites and reimbursement is easy and done quickly.  If you enjoy a specialized area such as consulting or sales, lots of opportunities.  Using Sametime instead of email is very nice.
Cons: If you need more flexibility and growth - IBM usually takes longer to do anything. Resources like software and hardware can take awhile to obtain.  Management normally is not proficient in technical skills but in manager skills.

Pros: Salary compensation was reasonable and similar to other area positions.  People are generally very helpful when working across the more global organization.  IBM has the technology and resources to pull-off major engagement opportunities and also to bring numerous products into an integrated solution.
Cons:
The bureaucracy is absolutely terrible along with the ridiculous expense controls.  If my project team needs a simple tool or immediate need replacement part, it should not take two months of procurement hell.  I should be able to go down to Frys and get the immediate need part.  Talk about lack of impowerment ....

Jpbs continue to get off-shored.

Pros: A wonderful company with employee friendly policies. Mother of computer , it has vast opportunities in different vertical and countries. It does the business pretty much in all fields related to IT, spanning over consultancy, infrastructure,software, services and research.
Cons: A great company with lot of bureaucracy , a lot of unnecessary process and documentation became cause of inefficiency. Poor business model encourage sales over software development.  They are becoming inefficient day by day due to burden of its own legacy and inertia against change

Pros: IBM is still respected as a name
Cons:
Constant cost cutting makes it hard to do your job
You are on your own - no money to support your efforts
Bare bones benefits - no raises for several years - travel allowances sub par
Management changes every 6 months

Pros: The people I worked with were knowledgeable, enthusiastic, and a pleasure to work with. As an intern, I was very pleased with the educational experience and challenges I received.
Cons: The company is in the midst of a long term transition out of the semiconductor business. It seemed like the ultimate goal of the company was always to keep the stock price high for the moment, even when it meant cutting positions.

Pros: The company has some of the best innovation and exceptional colleagues that are dedicated to the company and their co-workers.   Most are willing to help in any way to make you successful.
Cons: The company continuously transforms to satisfy Wall Street, impacting employee moral and results in continuous layoffs. Company puts profits over people far too often resulting in significant loss in intellectual capital.

Pros: I've worked for IBM for 13 years.  When I started it was a good place to work, good benefits, good training, but that's changed over the years.  I can't remember the last time I got any real training.  I guess the benefits are still reasonably good compared to what other companies have.
Cons: If you're in Strategic Outsourcing, good luck to you, but you have to see what's been happening, as more and more people are laid off.  Like I mentioned above, the training (which was one of the best things about this job) has totally dried up.  So now you have below average pay to go along with no training, and no opportunities to really move up in the company either.

Pros: Many potential paths for career development are highlighted,  Good high level PR and marketing.    Generally good folks in the trenches.
Cons: Zero to no support for any innovation from employees despite plenty of management rhetoric about vitality.  Companies purchased for this are bled dry.   Direction changes quarterly based on poor financial results, latest reorganization, and incessant rise of next "executive resource".  Once dominant sales culture has been replaced by finance and HR.

Pros: The company offers a competitive salary package and good opportunities to move up through the ranks, especially for their sales people.
Cons: The company culture is terrible, focused on short term financial gains rather than long term success of their clients and employees. If only senior management's smugness was matched by competence, IBM would be in much better shape. Work-life balance is not that great, but you know that is what you sign up for.

Pros: Depending on your position you have an opportunity to be self directed and the work hours and location can be very flexible. Benefits are decent although they have suffered some serious cutbacks in the past few years. The 401k and IBM match is very good
Cons: You are evaluated based on a bell curve. In a particular group there must be some % of low ratings. This can be very detrimental if you are part of a small high performing team. You are also responsible for finding work that aligns with your band.

Pros: The people, the people, the people. The engineers are the cream of the crop.  I cannot say enough about the quality of the workforce here. It's always been a pleasure to be a member of any of the teams I have been lucky to work with. Also, management seems to be listening to us, ratings systems are changing for the better.
Cons: It's a big company, of course you have to watch out for bureaucracy. Managers' hand have been tied on rewards, promotions, and raises and has led to employees looking elsewhere, but I do believe things are changing enough to curb exits and actually re-attract people.

Pros:
- Good benefits (health insurance, 401k, discounts on rental cars and electronics)
-This is a pro and a con, but honestly you can get by without doing much. Often people would "Work from home" but really not do anything and no one cares
- Interesting and complex problems for a designer to solve
- Good continuing education for a designer with the speakers and enrichment they have.
- More responsibility than the average entry level position due to the designers being spread thin.
- Great Peers! You fellow designers are smart, passionate, and driven. They are literally the only thing that keeps you from crying every day.
- Some of the higher up staff are great, inspiring, UX professionals. It was awesome to meet and work with them. Some less so.
- Do you want to improve as a designer or learn politics? I learned more politics than anything here and I was glad to learn, but it was tough.
Cons:
- If you work really hard, put in extra hours, and do your best work but no one notices or cares, did you really do well? It's hard to feel like you are valued and appreciated when the only way to get recognized or heard is to threaten to quit. As a designer right out of school I wanted to put in the work to make the best experience for our users, but despite almost 2 years worth of work I left each day feeling like a cog in a huge machine. What would it matter if I left? Nope.
-The development and product management organization aren't ready to work with designers. I had instances where the developer leadership flat out wouldn't build our designs. What a waste of time.
- You'll move up in the organization (if you are on the right project at the right time and have the right manager to fight for your promotion.) I was told before I took the job that I would be able to move up quickly. I couldn't wait any longer. My manager would forget to give me feedback to be able to improve and rise in the organization. If I wasn't doing well enough to be promoted, please tell me why and what I can do to get better!
-Picture this: You are at the entry level of a job and you are tasked with convincing your entire project team(including people who have been at IBM for 20-30 years) that they need to give you extra time to design so you can change things and make an awesome product. As you fight this fight you aren't recognized, promoted to a position of power within the group or anything. All you get is told that you need to do better and that it's your job to turn things around. If you bring up the problems to your superiors they can't or won't do anything so you are forced to continue working on a project that doesn't want to leverage your expertise, doesn't respect you or what you do, and can easily do whatever they want because they are in an office in another state or country. Even if you make headway you're not recognized for the work that is 2-3 levels above your pay grade.
- At least when I worked there, the recruitment setup had major problems. People watching portfolio reviews would all be chatting with each other and laughing about the candidate presenting or about something else entirely. Both are unacceptable. When I brought up the unprofessional nature of this I heard nothing but excuses and that it was my problem that I didn't like it. Every candidate deserves respect, but the talent staff didn't seem to agree.

Pros: My colleagues are terrific, working from home is a fantastic benefit especially if you have kids, benefits are very good, company is always changing so job stays fresh, lots of opportunities
Cons: Bonus structure is weak and not competitive with companies like Microsoft.  Same with stock. ESPP could be improved by going back to a bigger discount like what we had about 10 years ago (15% discount vs. the existing 5% discount).

Pros:
- Brilliant and hard-working people
- Opportunities for women 
- Mentoring program
- Company name opens doors
Cons:
- Frequent comment heard when joined, "IBM is like the federal government, only worse," as the bureaucracy and massive PowerPoints seem designed to stop things from happening vs empowering people to make a difference
- If you are entreprenuerial or creative, you won't be happy, nor valued
- Rigid hierarchy
- Fewer growth opportunities due to financial problems (i.e., revenue and profit losses)
- Too many meetings - from am to pm
- Terrible "productivity" tools
- Low employee morale - no work/life balance
- Layoffs needed to make financial targets for stockholders and executives

Pros: Flexible work environment and good opportunity for those that put forward effort.  Cognitive future embedded on cloud platform- CAMSS - cloud, analytics, mobile, security, social - focus around these core to strategy.
Cons: Long hours leads to nonexistent work life balance.  Not industry leading compensation any longer - very focused on cost take out/reduction of work force in North America.

Pros: Fair (and declining) benefits, good salary, flexibility of hours.  You are not micromanaged (other than staffing decision)
Cons: Benefits rapidly declining (paying more for less insurance, 401K matching diminished and must be there at end of year), multiple layoffs per year, company strategy to realign is purely words and only strategy is to shift work overseas.  No focus on customer satisfaction.  Forcing layoffs for even profitable employees.  Micromanaged staffing decisions.

Pros: Lots of resources around somewhere.  IBM can mobilize a lot of expertise on any individual problem or situation. It has good training programs, good benefits, and a solid expectation of ethical behavior.  It's involved in lots of interesting technical areas and you can move around a lot in terms of job areas during your career.
Cons: Hard to coordinate with all of the people who might have an interest in what you're doing.  Challenges with legacy systems. Very challenging transition ahead as customers move from on-prem to cloud.

Pros: Great access to a tremendous online training repository, challenging projects, work with very smart people and access to cutting edge technology.  I've worked for other big consultancies and they're all basically the same minus some extra time off at other places (that you never get to use).
Cons: Project work keeps you disconnected from the bigger company opportunities unless you luck out and find a partner wiling to offer you the chance to work on non-project work.

Pros: The company is world class, with thoughtful management, top notch health coverage, excellent employee savings program and recognition for a job well done.  Colleagues and management all operate at a highly functioning, professional level.  Travel booking, approval and reimbursement are way ahead of any other company in terms of timeliness and ease of use.
Cons: Bureaucracy is rampant.  Even though many processes are automated, be prepared to spend over an hour each week in front of a computer, complying with various information request requirements and reporting.

Pros: People you work with, tales of the past
Cons: Stress, Constant Worry, Low Pay Increase

Pros: The business appears to be headed in the right strategic direction. Watson is a key component. Telecommuting is still permitted in some areas but it appears that may be going away.
Cons: No work/life balance. High stress. Frantic pace. Insufficient staffing across all teams. Poor business decisions at the VP levels. Employees are not empowered to effect change. Benefits are not competitive.

Pros:
- Many different industries and jobs to get exposed to
- Many people to network with
- Growth potential
- Easy to get by with minimal effort
Cons:
- Its a large company and you won't feel appreciated, instead more like a number
- You might get on a long term project that you are not passionate about and can become stuck
- Its annoying that you have to quit and come back to make what you want.

Pros: There are many smart people that work here. The designers can really push themselves on challenging domains and products.
Cons:
Every business organization is inconsistent on everything. There are many that follow IBM design thinking and others that don’t. Teams struggle to releases any product or any type of software. Which leads to a lot of designers hopping to new teams to find something better. I have seen design teams cut and the project moved to development (great way for a company being “design focus”).
 
I will only speak to what team I was on. The management is all over the place. My team went through three design leads in less than a year and a half. Our Program Director didn’t know how to deal with any of the problems in our business platform/team so they would just move people around never addressing the problem.
 
You could see how overwhelmed and inexperienced some of the design leads were. One in general couldn’t lead the team and placed most of the responsibility on other team members. If you didn’t meet demands we were blamed for failure or even an ultimatum to stay or move teams. When asked what they did they would respond with “going to meetings.” With little to no directions, you scrounged for work. If you didn’t know what you should be doing or asked what you could do you got nothing more than “You should know.”
 
There were no check-ins and the design lead assumed you were taking advantage of them. There are goals and performance system but the lead didn’t effectively use or acknowledge it until it was too late for the designer. Most of the designers left the team for new teams and some tried to stick it out in hope it would get better. Program Director should have intervened but never solved the problem but switched old designers with industry designers (A few months later everyone was moved off and development are performing design).
 
The culture at IBM design can be summed up as everyone's out for themselves and less than teams. It is my observation employees work in secret not sharing their work. If you didn’t have a loud voice or opinions, you were cut down or see as weak. How do you grow at IBM? It’s hard with a culture where you are viewed as weak. Then you are pushed out.

Pros: Lots of options in sales as IBM is involved in most aspects of business to business technology. Remote work environment for salespeople. Good personal freedom as long as you are making your numbers.
Cons: Constant sales territory reorganization prevents you from really getting to know your customers and prospects and hinders sales success and commissions. Constant realignment of roles so what you sign up for may not be your role in 6 months.

Pros: Work from home.  The last true benefit that sets IBM apart (if you are lucky enough to have such a position).  All the rest is average.
Cons: The annual Growth Driven Profit Sharing is dismal, insulting, and ridiculous.

Pros: Have a good vision and strategy.
Cons:
Looks at data on papers and for short term. Not a comprehensive and strategic approach in maitaining clients or talent.
No job security. It does not matter how long you've served the company at the end you are just a number. I guess that applies to all big corporate America companies.

Pros: Lots of opportunities for recent graduates - if you can get through the front door.
Cons: Dysfunction reigns supreme.  IBM is a 100+ year old company pretending to be a startup.  It isn’t.  It’s slow, arrogant, and out of touch with client realities.  Management declared war on experienced employees in order to reduce the cost basis.  While that may improve the numbers for shareholders (and the CEO who should have been fired years ago) it is a temporary and unsustainable strategy.

Job Title: Chief technology officer - gbs global quality
Pros: I have come to IBM as an intern in Research, and have worked on long term client engagements and been on 3 international assignments.  I have enjoyed the opportunities to expand my skill and to work with IBMers from every Geo.  The latter has been one of my best experiences. Today I continue to work in a Global role and I'm still as excited meeting and collaborating wit IBMers from all parts of the Globe
Cons: There are some places I do not wish to go at certain times

Pros: Cutting edge work and access to top clients (Fortune 100). Great solutions and offerings.  Smart and talented people.
Cons: Very monthly and quarterly focused culture and that often leads to bad behavior. Too many processes and bean counters in the entire chain and very few people actually creating value and delivering to the clients.

Pros:
The main reason I have stayed at IBM is that I have always had new opportunities. I do a job for 2-4 years, then I go do another job - All while growing seniority and the benefits that come with it. 

If you have an interest in something you can find away to work on that something - you just have to be creative - as the path is not always a straight line.
Cons: Very Large company - if you are not outspoken it is easy to be overlooked. The size also makes it hard to find all of the benefits that we have access to.

Pros: Global opportunities to develop a life long career. If you want to be part of a company that can give the opportunity to work with the smarter people in the world, work and/or live in amazing places, do jobs that can transform clients' businesses to make them grow, and challenge yourself and learn something new every single day, this is the place to be!
Cons: Not cons, but a reality. As a technology company, change is a constant, so you need to be always willing to adapt to change and constantly learn.

Pros: Flex schedules, name recognition, and global opportunities.  IBM allows employees to work remotely if they so desire, which is hugely beneficial especially with gas closing in on $5/gallon.  It is one of the most recognizable brands in the world, and is a definite resume builder.  Finally, IBM has offices in just about every major market around the world, allowing employees a huge array of geographic work possibilities.
Cons: Massive corporation, with all the benefits and drawbacks that come with it.  It can be difficult to work in some situations with so many co-workers working remotely.

Pros: In my particular location, and it is definitely not the same throughout IBM, I am able to work on a great variance of projects.  And If I need time off its not even questioned however that is because of the work I produce
Cons: The hours are long, there are very high expectations that are sometimes unrealistic and bonus's and definitely not on the  high end and compensation is average.

Pros: IBM has a lot of neat products, exciting innovators, and fantastic teams. We get to be on the bleeding edge of innovation every day. Things evolve quickly, and the pace is exhiliarting. We have many wonderful benefits options, 401k, discounted stock, pension, lots of days off, and many team outings. It's very family friendly, and management encourages us to get personally involved in our communities.
Cons: Bureacracy, red-tape. Inability to change. Pay. Our commissions system is completely messed up. It's embarassing how wrong our data is. We spend as much time adhering to process as we do to actually selling to customers.

Pros: good benefits, relaxing work atmosphere, no one watching over you, and complete freedom with your time.(great if you have a family and kids)
Cons: little focus on career and talent development, low salary for entry level and mid level hires. brings you onboard without specific projects, long benches, meaning you are going to sit for a while when there aren't projects around, most of the times, you have no choice in the project you are staffed on.

Pros: Many options to advance or change careers.  It is great to work for a company that is well recognized in the marketplace.  I enjoy working at IBM because we are the benchmark by which many companies are measured.  It feels good to be working for one of the top companies in the world.
Cons: Very large company.  Sometimes you feel like just a number.  Although the size of IBM brings stability and job security, the size can also make you feel lost.  IBM has focused more on Wall Street expectations and less on employee moral in the past few years.

Pros: The overall product line is second to none - overall.  Easy to get an appointment and to have the customer to listen to you.  You have the ability to sell all products as a generalist or specific products as a specialists.  Specialization can be in hardware (Servers, storage, etc.) and in software (middleware, such as data management and business intelligence, web servers, application development, systems management and security) and services (IT services that are hardware or software centric; or business servcies, such as consulting, systems integration, application management, systems outsourcing, business process transformation or business process outsourcing).  There are other more detailed specializations.
Cons: Pay is not as good as it is with competing firms.

Pros: Flexible hours and work locations.  Lots of free classes available from the IBM Global Education website.  The benefits are excellent.  You get 18 days of vacation to start and that becomes 23 days on your tenth year.
Cons: Excessive overhead created by matrix organizational structure.  Pressure to outsource is constant and there is little job security.  46 hour work week is expected.  Employees have to fight for themselves to get recognition for work they do.

Pros: Alot of education opportunities. Working from home.
Cons: Most US jobs being offshored forcing those left behind to find less satisfying/interesting work or leave. Alot has changed in the past 5 years.  Work-Family life balance is no longer a priority for management - "Family First" used to be a mantra of IBM.  They have cut pay, cut work force, don't give raises and those left behind are working harder and longer hours for less pay.

Pros: Get to work on large projects that you would not get to work on anywhere else. I do enjoy working on very large projects. Where else would you get  to work on the majority of the fortune 500 IT environments. If you take the attitude of learning from what you are doing you will get to continually learn.
Cons: One of many.  You become lost in the crowd at times even when you shine. Often times management does not understand what you are doing. Progressing up the chain is limited because it seems people either have to die or retire.

Pros: Good learning, excellent options for advancement. There are a multitude of online and in-person training opportunities that build skill sbeyond immediate job requirements. IBM also has general philosophy of growth through experience, encouraging employees to advance through taking roles in other business units over the course of their career.
Cons: Can be very beaurocratic. Siloed business units challenge company's ability to work in unilateral direction. Many legacy employees overly reliant on conventional ways of doing business can retard real growth and internal innovation. Size of the company is an advantage from a personal benefits standpoint also interfere with capacity to employ new thinking.

Pros: IBM is great name, with a great reputation.  It has a lot of upside, in that they are able to give new college hires an opportunity to be on a client site and learn real world skills without having to be at the bottom of the barrel first.
Cons: It is very hard to get fair market value for your salary.  Once you are in the system at IBM, you are constantly fighting a losing battle against compensation problems.  It helps to ensure a good starting salary.  Also, your success sometimes depends on your internal management team (SAM, SAL, etc) rather than your ability.

Pros: Current postion offers a good deal of flexibility and independence.  Benefits, particulary 401K matching are solid relative to many other companies.  Particularly for some one in my age group.
Cons:
Raises have been paltry for past several years.  If we had a solid previous year, point to a bad current year as cause, if good current year, point to bad previous year as cause.  

Should be more upfront about the intended course for the company, even if that includes.  Dont think the way these recent rounds of job cuts has been handled properly and are hurting morale.  Claiming this is just BAU type resizing/shuffling is silly.

Pros: Being in alliance sales, IBM can provide momentum for large deals.   GBS can be help if managed correctly.   Many products and solutions for package sales.
Cons: Constant layoffs that happen every quarter.   The alliance and partner divisions seems to take the brunt of these resource actions.   Also targeted for layoffs â?¦ older employee (over 50).

Pros: IBM has some great technology and very solid rank and file employees.  Overall  benefits are good but are constantly being reduced.
Cons:
Below average salary and pay increases.   Excessive management oversight with very little value from them.   Very little actual control over success,  you can work like a beast and be fired without cause.   Very discouraging negative environment.  

Most strong sales and marketing persons leave to make more money and not deal with the lack of respect by management.

Pros:
You like the people you work with everyday. 
Your job will be challenging and interesting
It's a big company, so there is a reasonable chance of moving into another role
Cons: Morale is horrible. Work/life balance is nonexistent. Instances exist of senior management calling regular conference calls on Sundays, then challenging those who decline on their "commitment to the business."  Quotas are set irrationally, and people are laid off spontaneously and without notice. Also, IBM has become a master at skirting age-discrimination laws; employees over 55 (when the cost of your health care premiums the company pays starts to skew upwards) can expect poor reviews regardless of performance to give the company cover if they want to fire you. They can always hire two people in India to replace you for less.

Pros: Internationally recognized brand.  Looks great on a resume.  Due to the massive size of the company, an incredible amount of resources available to practitioners.
Cons: Better negotiate a salary that your happy with forever, because IBM does not give meaningful raises, even for top performers.

Pros: You have an IBM stamp on your resume.
Cons:
1. Very very poor planning on the facilities in the new & state-of-the-art (huh, really !!!) building.
2. Plan to stay at this location for 2 years before you can move on to another opportunity within IBM.
3. Forget abt promotion for 2 years at this location.
4. New 'process' and 'framework' model really sucks.
5. Work From Home - SORRY, You have to be at this location (for what ???) even though all of your team is located acrosss the world.

Pros: Still good image and it is good to have in your CV that you worked for this company
Cons:
Low salaries, respectless treatment of employees, even if company is overall seen as a LGBT friendly in fact there is a number of homophobic manegers across the world that know how to influence negativly career of gay people who are out... Fireing best employees on cost of quality of services. An administrative monstrum what means that each employee needs to spend 50% of time on the admin work...Internal tools are crap. What IBM is selling is not used internally.
Agenda 2015 which means that IBM want to achive 20US$ profit per share is causing that talented people are fired.

Pros: The people you work with, the customers are great, and they will make you feel as part of their team. There is a lot of great and talented people in IBM, and they keep the company going.
Cons: the company no longer cares about it's employee's.  The focus is making money, and they will do it at all cost. People are let go, retire or what ever, and all they do is give those left working more work, no additional compensation, and taking away your home and family life.

Pros: Great history, plenty of variety, truly embraces remote workers, decent pay (not for the sacrifice)
Cons: Oversells and under-delivers leaving teams too small to get the job done leading to over-worked and stressed teams. No ability to live in apartments while working in other cities. No ability to temporarily relocate.  Training and vacation time work against you as your billable time is what matters the most to IBM (not the people)

Pros: Global community of co-workers can be empowering. Focus on professional development can be really beneficial if you take it seriously: Many opportunities for learning new things and improving your skill set. Sometimes you have to organise this for yourself but you stand a good chance to get support from your manager.  You can still find many great, talented people at IBM.
Cons: Conservative and "big": complex communication, silos. Lots of internal tools and heavy processes. Services branch: sometimes messy, you have to work really hard to keep the quality at a level that is acceptable to you and your standards.

Pros:
1) Good smart colleagues
2) Flexible work hours
3) License to learn new things, and come up with completely new ideas
Cons:
1) The company seems to be run by bean-counters. These are MBA types that do not care about technology, and don't take into account any considerations which do not have quantifiable monetary value. For example, how much do free snacks contribute? Travel to talk to colleagues overseas? 
2) Slow decision making process
3) Difficult to transition ideas and code from research to development.

Pros: Although it's not a relevant technology company anymore, IBM still offers many opportunities to work across industries and functions.
Cons: Entrenched management class; elitist and self-serving. Plus, they are extremely cheap with salary, bonus and travel expenses. My advice to new employees is to get some experience and contacts and quickly move on to another company that appreciates talent.

Pros: The depth of experience, personal support, and learning opportunities you have available is substantial.  Your ability to influence where you take your career within IBM, is very real and enabling.  You have the insights of a well experienced team and through internal options you can collaborate around the globe on ideas and projects.
Cons: Large organizations often get more difficult for targeting rapid change, based on the culture.  This is no different at IBM, but it has changed momentum significantly over the last several years, picking up speed in each passing month.

Pros: The people are great, and you can (for now) work at home for the most part, depending on your job. Some of the products are good.
Cons: Company is lost.  The CEO is slowly tearing apart everything that was once good about this company.  Doesn't matter how hard you work, or how much you produce, you can be fired (RA'd in the internal parlance) any time, with no cause given.  Zero loyalty to employees.  Only care about stock price (see how well that's working out).  Allegedly trying to become more nimble (Agile), but too many entrenched executives protecting their turf to allow that to happen.

Pros: Working from home. Ten second commute. Allows for a very flexible schedule and contributes to more fulfilling life style. IBMers are still a very dedicated bunch.
Cons: Working from home. I never met in  person any of the people I worked with in my last stint at IBM. Required quite a bit of extra effort to maintain effective communication. I was very surprised at the dedication of IBMers regardless of somewhat tenuous business environments.

Pros: Great reputation and products in the enterprise space.  Somewhat late to cloud game but catching up VERY quickly through acquisition & building out a leading edge PaaS (Bluemix).  Good compensation & benefits.
Cons: As IBM transitions from hardware/legacy software to a cognitive computing cloud platform company, there a many many constant changes. Unfortunately these changes are necessary as IBM tries to get it right, and the changes are paying off.  Growth in strategic imperative areas is coming in strong. If you can handle constant change and corporate strategy implementation, you'll be happy. If not, stay away.

Pros:
A multitude of careers to choose from as well as a huge portfolio of product and solution focus areas.... in good times it is relatively easy to transfer to something different with manager's support.  Very strong solutions but too many things (see cons) get in way of delivering and gaining success.
A lot of new job openings due to their focus on replacing old skills with new perspectives.
Cons: Lately they have lost their way with too many restructurings impacting client relationships and satisfaction and losing too many outstanding employees .  Respect for the individual, which IBM has traditionally been known for, seems to have vanished.

Pros: Great, hardworking employees who made this company great at one time!
Cons: Three layoffs last year, another just announced and CEO is promoting hiring 25,000 in US.  Promotes internal education to enable employees to gain new skills to meet demands of new technological initiatives, but denies funding to employees for this education in order to retain them to move into new positions.  Extremely low but mainly NO raises at all.  Lowered 401k match and severance package in 2016.  Advice to current and new hires:  read your benefits package thoroughly - especially the fine print!

Pros: Strong culture with desire to change the world with technology
Cons:
Eroding confidence with years worth of continual revenue decline leads to desire to cut costs ("Get expenses in line with revenue").  Therefore death spiral - less revenue, cut people to reduce costs which leads to fewer sales and less revenue therefore cut people.....
Getting rid of many experience people to reduce costs leads to a feeling of many looking over their shoulder on who will be next to get laid off

Pros: None anymore, now that they have taken away working from home.
Cons:
f you are living in the US you will be fired in less than 3 years.  And for those 3 years you'll wonder if you are on the list every quarter.  You will be fired.  They want only offshore cheap employees.  And yes you will be training your replacement.  Severance pay was 1 month and now I hear it's nothing.
Morale is terrible.
Management is out for themselves, don't expect any support or backing.
Sell deals they cannot deliver.

Pros: large company involved with many aspects of the IT industry.  Can find something that interests you.  401k match and medical benefits.
Cons: No interest in the well being of employees nor in providing basic support to ensure their success and efficiency.  Layoffs every year and recently more often with seemingly no management planning beyond the current quarter.  Purchases innovative new products and companies instead of investing internally.  Strategy constantly shifting and a moving target.

Pros:
-Get exposed to a lot of different elements of business right away
-Lots of different people to learn from
-Opportunities to get into new fields with little experience
Cons:
-No Career path clarity
-Poor managers giving little guidance
-Undervalue their employees
-Consistently misuse talent for shortsighted goals without considering the long run
-The company is still trying to reinvent themselves

Pros:
- Great people and company reputation.  
- Great marketing.
- Resources are available for the important priorities
Cons:
- Bonus program (as small as it is) distinguishes very little between the very top performers and other good performers - mainly because the company results are repeatedly mediocre.  So the very best people are leaving for greener pastures.
- Very slow salary growth, if at all.  Despite being a consistent "1" top performer, economically, I am behind inflation as compared to when I started in the 80's.
- Thousands of jobs posted internally, but requirements are so extremely specific, it's hard to fully qualify for other positions.

Pros: None that I can think of
Cons: Fake glitz and glamor.  Products are no longer what they should be, nor do they meet many of the marketing stated capabilities.  Minimal employee investment, with the exception of on line courses.  As long as it doesn't cost them $, its fine.  Employee rating system is bogus, and don't expect a raise ever again.   People try and do well at the expense of others.  Customers now come last - which bodes ill for getting future work.

Pros: - Put IBM in your resume, may be impressive to some recruiters.
Cons:
- compensation is under the average in bay area.
- no room to grow.
- The higher level managers are, the less Software knowledge they know.
- healthcare insurance is one of the worst package across US. I had to pay triple price  to get 1/3 benefits comparing with my current employer offers.
- Manager calls you anytime they want, even 5AM on Saturday/Sunday Morning.
- Lay off at least fourth times per year.  Ginni increase IBM's income by laying off people with something she calls to hire more new talents. 
- If you're good engineer, do not ever apply for a job at IBM. IBM isn't worth for even 1 cent in your career.
- Free coffee only from 2pm - 4pm in SVL site? One of the worst coffee service in Bay Area.

Pros: Not really many good things left about working for this company.  Until recently, their work from home policy was strong, but the current senior leadership destroyed that one last positive benefit.
Cons: IBM  is by far the most toxic company I have ever been part of.  My company was purchased by IBM a few years ago, and quickly ran it into the ground.  IBM senior leadership acts to serve their own over-inflated egos, and rarely ever use common sense in making decisions.  The entrenched long-term marketing and sales employees are dedicated to blocking any kind of useful progress.  Overall, the company treats their employees horribly.  IBM is obviously in a decline that its current leadership team can't reverse, and it deserves the crash that is coming

Pros:
Good opportunity to create your own career paths.
Great, smart employees to work with and for.
Lots of exciting travel to work on customer problems, both domestic and international level.
Cons:
If a manager and their employee DO NOT get along for whatever reason, your IBM career will most likely be over unless you can move out of the division you're in to something with a new manager.
Too many employees who have been working there for 25+ years and are pulling down the competitive quotient to move the company forward.

Pros: Managers are professional, and IBM has processes to handle every situation. When I contracted with a different company, my manager went on vacation and the person delegated to sign my timecard didn't. No pay that week! That doesn't happen at IBM.
Cons: IBM has embraced the bottom line to the point that it overrides everything, including customer service. And it's no longer about excellence, it's about doing more with less and fewer, and not in the good way. Claiming it would take X employees to do handle an account, when it really required more employees, and then making those employees work mandatory overtime got them in trouble. I don't think that's changed.

Pros:
- Get to play with some really cool technology
- Work life balance better than anywhere I've ever worked
- Management is pretty hands off which gives you a lot of head room to do crazy innovative stuff
- IBM as the first name on your resume opens a lot of doors
- Some travel opportunities
Cons:
- compensation is not competitive
- offices are kind of old
- hard to move teams or locations

Pros: Good benefits,  offices all over the world, wide range of options with regards to the type of work you do for IBM.
Cons:
Stagnant wages, poor workplace culture, limited opportunities for advancement. 

IBM is a huge company and these problems may not apply to all of the various branches, but it speaks to the types of issues facing a big corporation like IBM and the negative impact they have on employees (as well as the company).

Pros: There are a lot of smart people and the pay is good.  Many very large companies absolutely need IBM in order for the those companies to continue operations.
Cons: Despite years of trying to re-invent IBM the company has not been reinvented.  Too many people know how to "play the game" - avoid making measurable commitments,  always have an excuse for missed delivery or quality problems, fly under the radar and keep collecting paychecks.

Pros: Some positions are remote work at home, so that keeps you from completely loosing your mind when working all the OT hours.
Cons: All they care about is "utilization" or billable hours.  You work tons of hours of OT and give up so much of your personal life for years and get top performance ratings for year & are told when the contract ends they will help you find another position within IBM and then they abruptly lay you off like garbage.

Pros: My team is fantastic and so is my manager I love the environment and the flexibility that my manager has. He doesn't lord over anyone and as long as you do your work and strive to learn and grow then there is any issues.
Cons: IBM itself as a company is a bit of a problem, things are slow and I guess it's still in a transitional phase but it's been in that way for a while even before I got there. IBM has a lot of catching up it needs to do if it wants to still remain competitive within the tech industry.

Pros:
Lots of learning resources.
Great culture for constant self improvement.
IBMers really help other IBMers succeed.
Cons:
Layoffs are more frequent than you would like them to be. Valuable peers will be let go, then you will see a new team get created and you wonder why they could not just reassign your peers to the new team.
In many sites, promotions can take forever. To get promoted, you better be ready to look at a different company.
If you stay there long enough, you may end up with a mindset that everything is better at IBM, limiting your chances to move out quickly if you get laid off.

Pros:
- Flexibility 
- Good Benefits, especially mental Health and Fertility 
- Paid Leave for Children
- High Base Salary 
- Selling Gartner and IDC recognized products
Cons: IBM's lack of transparency around layoffs, especially for employees who have overachieved. Also, IBM chose to freeze salaries and prevent promotions during 2020, while managing to pay shareholders dividends. Who really matters? Finally, IBM failing to announce a 2020 100% club and payout bonuses is just cheap. Sad!

Pros: The upside from both career development and compensation is very good. Fantastic support for continuing education and moving into new roles. You will learn a ton - both on technology and business.
Cons:
It's a big, complex company, with lots of bloat in middle management. This is not unique to IBM and while the company is in the midst of major transformations, there are still tons of people "hiding" in the complexity.
You will work, a lot. Hours can be over 80+ per week under certain circumstances.

Pros: Resume builder to say you’ve worked at IBM.
Cons: The worst company I have ever worked for. Processes were rolled out without consulting any front end users/subject experts. Last minute 911 meetings, which would often be cancelled after you’ve rearranged your calendar to attend (virtually). Super high cost, low coverage health benefits. For being a Fortune 500 company, they certainly aren’t passing that on to their employees in their benefits. Froze our annual increases, expected to work 50-60 hours a week on frozen pay (I received a 30% increase in my pay when I left to work for a local healthcare company.) Didn’t pay bonuses we had already earned from the previous quarter. Over the course of 14 months, the Senior Project Manager changed THREE TIMES. In 3 years I’ve watched my entire time, minus 2-ish people, leave for other orgs.

Pros: I feel valued as part of my team and my manager always finds new opportunities for me to grow based on my goals. I never feel stuck or bored - I continue to learn even as my role has become more senior. Work/life balance is great.
Cons: Often feel pressured to produce results in a small amount of time with last minute changes - can increase stress on the job.

Job Title: Full time entry level developer position
Pros: Plenty of freedom, no one ever really bothers you. If you can make your closest boss happy and can sustain your work/life balance while entirely on your own then it's for you.
Cons: Some people can't balance the freedom, and you go back on the job market when looking for new projects. It can be aggravating for a new developer in the industry when you're constantly being asked to work on Salesforce when it's not what you wanna do.

Pros: Great for someone that wants to get their foot in the door at a young age and possibly embark on a career path.  Being one of the largest technologies company in the world means good benefits, ample vacation time, and if you choose to ever leave, IBM looks great on a resume.
Cons: It's not really a downside of working at IBM in particular, but corporate America in general.  All large corporations tend to micromanage and plan for future contracts poorly, letting the lower rungs of support staff deal with the problems created due to poor planning and incompetent project managers, etc.

Pros: It's a large company with a lot of different opportunities.  If you choose you won't get bored. They also are pretty good with work/life balance.
Cons: The bureaucracy is painful.  Way too many project managers collecting status and bothering others doing real work.  Not very agile in projects. It is hard to change positions within the company.  Easier to leave.

Pros:
Well diversified company with many opportunities for advancement and leadership. Management does a good job articulating your place in the company and how you can personally help achieve the organization's goals.

IBM also has a flexible work/life balance and work from home program, but be careful as with some managers, "out of sight; out of mind".
