Cons: Many times you will find yourself spending unnecessary time working through "red tape" in order to get things done, which can mean many late nights in the office or working multiple weekends.

Pros: Work life balance is respected at IBM!  There are unlimited opportunities for gaining valuable work experience.  IBM is such a big company that you can change your career and still work at IBM!  IBM supports teamwork and collaboration across within and across business units.  Overall it is a gret place to work!
Cons: If you don't negotiate a high salary when you get hired you will struggle for the rest of your carreer.  There are constant budget constraints that limit salary increases  and bonuses even when you get a high performance rating.

Pros: The Name is huge, and there are lots of smart people who are also decent human beings.
Cons:
The brand name is the only reason that I selected some areas of satisfaction in this poll, because IBM will help my career growth when I decide to use the brand name to land something much better outside the company. It's pathetic how they bring in talented people, train them, and then stupidly lose them because compensation is sub-par for the level or work and workload, and management is out of touch and arrogant. Great strategy - spend money to hire and train and then let other companies reap the benefits. It seems like the really good people leave unless they become someone's pet and find a political loophole to career advancement. The good ones who stay probably do it for family reasons due to workplace flexibility, or don't want to take a risk... IBM should be one of the most sought after companies to work for, but it's just a place to build a great resume for 2-5 years and move on for anyone with career ambitions. 

I haven't worked outside of Market Insights, but from what I hear, this is supposed to be one of the best places to work. Maybe it is by IBM standards, but not by what you would expect. There are way too many politics. Management doesn't even take the time to get to know employees or take an active part in developing them. It's all passive. The employee has to initiate everything (career talk, mentorship, and even just basic learning about how to do the job). You only interact with the first line managers even though the executives make the decisions. If you get a few minutes with them, they act like God. It's an outdated style in today's world. It sounds nice to say that employees should manage their own careers, but there's way too much workload and secrecy to cut through. Most of my senior colleagues tell me that if you want to advance, it's more about wasting working time to put on shows and kiss executive ass than about the quality of the work. Doesn't sound like a lot of fun when you can just leverage the name for 50-100% higher salary and a better title... The thing is that management could avoid that by just respecting and fairly compensating employees when they have the chance, but that makes too much sense.

Pros:
flexible - work from home or anywhere
good online resources to education you can take in your own time
large company with alot of job opportunity in services, hw, sw etc
some of the smartest people on the planet work here
Cons:
too much work not enough employees
sr leadership in somers/armonk out of touch with whats happening at customer's real world
rampant employee burnout from overwork
no investment in $$$ education
micromanagement to wall street/stock results

Pros:
Very flexible in working remotely from home for many positions - just be aware that that sooner or later your job / position will be off-shored to a cheaper 3rd world country, no matter how great of performer you are or how dedicated you might be.

This is a good company for any fresh-out-of-school job hunter that wants to gain some standard 21st corporate world experience.  The pay is not bad for the fresh-out-of-school job hunter. For more experienced workers however, IBM is very limited. Executive management's not-so-secret agenda is to layoff as many "high priced" USA-based employees (and in other developed countries) and off-shore everything possible to the 3rd world. Any gaps are theoretically back-filled with the "layoffees" as contractors, assuming they can't find work elsewhere.
Cons:
IBM is not a place where job hunters should apply if they are seeking long term employment.or stabilitry.  One day an IBM employee may come into work as he/she has done for the past 20+ years and be taken into the manager's office to be told their position is being Resource Actioned (IBM does  not like to use the words "Laid Off").  The soon to be EX Employee will then be required to stick around for the next 30 days.  This 30 dats period is so the soon to be EX Employee will have tyhe privilage to train their  India Replacement staff member.  Once the 30 days is past and the training is complete the EX Employee will no longer be needed and will be thrown out like yesterday's garbage.

You'll have lots of exposure to different technologies at IBM. Unfortunately, a lot of what's forced on you is either proprietary, obscure, or rapidly vanishing outside the world of IBM (think Lotus Word Pro, Lotus Notes, Domino, etc). Many US-based jobs at IBM are "tenuous", so the workplace feels a lot like dining under the Sword of Damocles. Since your co-workers know that the end could come at any moment, and their survival depends upon how well they rank compared to you, the result is reduced information flow/share, cooperation, participation, and general workplace camaraderie among your co-workers. 

On the subject of "how you rank", the PBC system (performance reviews) at IBM is a TOTAL FARCE. It's basically a random system of ranking by the managers. Worse yet, you usually already have a performance number assigned before the evaluations ever begin -- based on who the manager's favorite employees are, how many people in the dept the execs said will need to be laid off in the next year, etc.

Pros: Looks good on a resume.  Often get to work on new technologies.  There are still many, many great folks there.
Cons:
Full disclosure:  I was laid off.  However, I am not a bitter and angry ex-IBMer - I was elated to get my layoff package (very reasonable) and  found a new, much better paying job before my severance ran out.  IBM was very good to me for many, many years (and my tenure started long after the golden years before the early 1990's) and I'm too young to have been personally affected by the pension shenanigans. My review comes from working in the Server group.

It is no secret that IBM's "strategy" has been to reduce it's US workforce.  They're achieving this by two methods:  small but continuous layoffs spread throughout the company and by making it more unpleasant to work there to encourage attrition. The unpleasantness ranges from big things (most people haven't had a raise in years) to the petty (no coffee, no soap in the kitchens, etc.).  Meanwhile, the senior executives are making millions upon millions  Consequently morale throughout the entire company is extremely poor.

Training?  Only if it's free and local (no travel expenses).
Raises?  Small and non-existent.  IBM redefined their salary ranges a few years ago.  We used to 
   hear you've got lots of growth left in your salary range.  Now you hear, "well, you're near the 
    mid-point of your range, so you're paid what you should be paid.  It's like jumping halfway to a 
    wall - you'll never reach it.
Salaries?  When I worked there, I thought it wasn't bad, but three of us have left my team in the 
   past two years and we've each received pay increases at our new companies in excess of 30% 
   and that's been in this terrible economy.
Working Conditions?  Varies widely throughout the company depending on your local mgmt and 
    location.  It was generally pretty good where I was in the Pacific NW.
Career?  At the big sites, there's plenty of places to transfer or try new jobs.  Smaller remote 
   sites are more limited.  And there's no way IBM's paying for anybody's relocation.  
Promotions?  Still possible if you're on the right projects or working with the right customers.  Pay 
   raises are minimal with a promotion, but at least the halfway point in your salary range is a little 
   further away after a promotion.

IBM's always been beauracratic, but local management always had flexibility to take care of their people.  That's gone now, First and Second line managers are now probably the worst jobs in IBM.  They're reduced to just implementing the new and often petty people policies dreamed up by the execs.

Pros:
-- IBM is committed to making alternative work situations available to employees: work at home, work in the nearest office, etc. When your company is worldwide, this makes sense.
-- I work with some very intelligent people who are genuinely interested in what they do.
-- Depending on your product/project, you get to work on what interests you (within reason, of course). I'm going to work on some new technology that I've been wanting to work on for a while now.
-- My pay is better than any other place I have worked.
-- They take the annual review process very seriously, from the writing of goals to regular review of your progress towards your goals. I haven't been here long enough to know what the annual review itself is like.
-- The people I have direct contact with are very helpful and a pleasure to be around every day. People have a lot of respect for their coworkers and immediate management, but there seems to be a general contempt for the bigger company and its processes and policies, however.
Cons:
-- This is an enormous company. There's a lot of stuff going on, and it's very easy to tune out the rest of your division. As a result, personal and career growth tools and advice are about as generic and non-specific as possible, and therefore not all that useful.
-- Size makes finding useful information on the company intranet almost impossible. Pages are frequently out of date, and you seem to be redirected to 2-3 other pages before you find anything of use.
-- No two groups seem to use the same technology for source control, access management, requirements management, or just about anything else.
-- For some, it's such a good place to work that it's impossible for anyone else to advance into a technical leadership role, so you end up leaving or creating something new and esoteric to make your mark, which makes it even harder for someone new to figure out what's going on.
-- Benefits (primarily health care) are not as good as other places I've worked.
-- Can be very hard to figure out who your customer really is, or who is using what you work on.

Bottom line:

It's almost impossible to describe the 'good and bad of IBM', because it's such a huge company. IBM has acquired so many other companies in the past few years that you can't really describe the culture of IBM anymore. There are a few unifying pieces, like benefits and the review process, but if you want to work at IBM you will want to talk to a lot of people during your interview to find out more about the specific site you want to work at.

Pros: Smart dedicated individuals.  Heft of IBM behind sales and delivery teams.  Global reach and solution set enable plenty of career opportunities.
Cons: Bifurcated sales and delivery create high levels of friction.  Metrics (revenue, profit, signings) create constant battles between groups vying for credit.  Solution approach frequently ignores customer pain points.  Working from home approach creates disconnected culture, managing by remote control, and importantly, hampers the development of customer relationships/intimacy.

Pros: Awesome, intelligent coworkers.  Family atmosphere.  People are honest.  Great to spend time together.  Generous travel budgets.  Best networking opportunities and respect from industry hands down.  Great tech.  Easy to sell.  Hot trends like Analytics and tablets.
Cons: Goals to hit stock prices are leading to low salaries and promotions.  Too focused on the business and not on identifying top performers.

Pros:
Wonderful people, breadth of opportunity to develop your skills and build a resume
Decent benefits
Wonderful 401k match
Cons:
Too many managers not really selling but reporting-up
Pay compared to competition is really low for enterprise sales
Lack of focus on client success
Comp plans don't really align well with what you do

Pros: They hire with litle to  no experience in many positions. Prior experience is no necessary. Always positions open.
Cons: Most have not had a raise in years. A lot of behind the scenses job band and title manipulation with no communication to the employee. No logical path to promotions.  No ergonomic concerns. Tools inhibit prodicutivity. Computers and software are dated. Management are not here for the long term so no local loyalty. What morale?  Management makes no attempt to remedy any issues - they have their own goals and it would not include employee retention.

Pros: A Well known company. A good place to learn and use new software. There is room for growth depending on your expertise and where you work.
Cons: The bulk of the work is being sent out of the united states. They used to use folks in the U.S. to do the work. Now like many other companies, they use India, Brazil etc. They are all about numbers, layoffs and cutting corners. Its not like the old IBM I knew and loved. They let folks go and double the work the current workers have without compensation.

Pros: The pre-sales team at the time was great as we sold SDLC solutions to medical device, pharma and telecommunications companies
Cons: Pressure, like most public companies, causes trade-offs between short-term sales and longer term positive change to the client. That's where continuity of revenue comes from, after you can really partner with the client. This advice comes from a Client Executive Unit Director.

Pros:
The ability to shift between various groups and positions was really great.
Learning new skills that could be applied to the current job or even the next one was encouraged. 
People were the best part.
Cons:
Compensation after you arrived did not keep pace with the industry. 
Personal Business Commitments (PBCs) were tied to annual increases and bonus, but used imaginary numbers to artificially down grade the payouts to employees even during great years for IBM as a company.  If you are having an excellent year expect the target to be moved, "to increase challenge".

Pros:
Good work life balance when in the right team. Local office or home based work if your mgmt. approves. 

You have the capability to perform like a real pro, you just need to keep reminding your manager about that.
Cons:
Too many layoffs, at least 2 each of the past few years, causes constant strain on work effort. 

Salary has become stagnant. No raised or any bonus this year except for the very select few.

Pros:
4 weeks vacation (3 weeks plus 6 personal days)
Depending upon the job, work-life balance can be good
Opportunities to work from home are higher than other businesses
Cons:
Compensation could be more competitive
Bonus structure makes it difficult to get a significant bonus unless you are a top producer in your band/group
Only get 6 holidays off each year (other 6 are given to you as personal days)

Pros: The pros are, corporate America is seeing that this rudderless ship is not able to innovate or lead in the technology space. Companies see first hand that IBM is now an accounting company. They rely on revenue streams by playing with accounting plus auditing thousands of their valued customers. They will not grow without leveraging these two tricls
Cons: A reality show called "Lord of the Flies". Upper and Middle management are worthless and are paralyzed by their sheer inability to push back on upper management. Daily cadence calls, asking what time deals are closing is ludicrous but yet, this is a common practice by these crazy accountants (managers). I am interested in seeing what happens come January

Pros: There are a lot of nice people at the individual contributor level, and if you are lucky you will get the rare "professional and fair manager" to work for. The IBM logo is good to have on your resume.
Cons: In sales, IBM is capping many commissions and, in some instances, creatively avoiding them altogether. Technical positions are seeing salary reductions.

Pros: I believe salaries here are good relative to other employers in the Raleigh / Durham, NC area.  There is a lot of opportunity for technical challenge.  Flexible working hours (but definitely expect to work over 40 hours / week).
Cons: Maniacal focus on cost cutting to compensate for current lack of revenue growth.  This translates into regular "resource actions" and continuously trying to do more with less.

Pros: Great training, resources, and a solid foundation.  You are surrounded by very intelligent individuals and resources that leverage your work.  Benefits are good.  You will learn so much by the expertise within the company.  Opportunities are in abundance.  You have the flexibility to work from home or at the office.  You manage your travel as you see fit.  Plenty of opportunities to cross train.
Cons: Too many layers to cut through to get things done.  Innovation is getting better but still not where it needs to be.  I am optimistic that they will get there.  They have reinvented themselves before and can do it again.

Pros:
Good pay if you're an executive
may flexible work location jobs
Cons:
Pay for non executives 
retirement is now below poverty line for even senior level people
retirement doesn't include health benefits
Customers hate IBM and are no longer interested in buying from us...

Pros: Great place to work if you have the right team.  Having a motivated FLM is key to success here.  Plenty of tools to succeed
Cons: Lost the ability to work from home when they moved everyone into call centers.  Need to stick with a model and work on it for long term.  Too much change and shuffling at the executive levels, leaving employees wondering what their role will be quarter to quarter.

Pros:
You will meet a lot of intelligent, talented, skilled people.  Some name brand recognition for those who would not  
know any better.
Cons: You will be a number, a resource to be used up. Very little career development will be available to give you flexibility to leverage your industry outside the ibm eco-system. Poor morale.

Pros: I work with some of the brightest, most creative and fun people I've ever met. They work together to bring new things to clients despite corporate.
Cons: Corporate tends to make severe course corrections with little to no warning. No longer a sales culture, but managed by spreadsheet and financial engineering. The result is that you never know if you've won the lottery or about to be laid off.

Pros: The employees who are genuinely dedicated to achieving business objectives make IBM a generally fulfilling place to work.  The potential business opportunity of deep insights through IBM's Watson technology and APIs.
Cons: IBM's focus on its 2015 roadmap was a colossal failure.  It should have given up sooner and directed its massive stock repurchases into earlier investments in analytics, cloud, SaaS solutions, etc.  There is no loyalty to employees as IBM discards anyone possible in its relentless drive to yield a bit more short term profit.

Pros: Good culture and environment. Workers are smart and hardworking and provide good coding review. Leaders are really fine and work is not that stressful. I love it in the total and for other reason I have to go. That's it.
Cons: lower salary and not a city I like actually. It is not the most edge cutting company in the whole country so I want to move to some companies like google that can really make a difference in the future and I don't quite like hardware.

Pros: I have over 18 years at IBM and have been given tremendous opportunities to work remotely with global teams.  The experience I have earned is invaluable.
Cons: Through the years, IBM has taken away benefits....pension, reward incentive programs, holiday parties, etc...  And now, the ability to work remotely.  Not just go back into the office, but move across country in order to keep your job.  Working remotely was a culture IBM employees have been accustomed to for years, a culture that IBM claimed made them more productive, even capitalizing on the technology.  All in all, it is not the same IBM I have known and loved.

Pros:
Love the people I work with, passionate and hard working
Some teams, individuals are over-worked and other under-worked, seems like its up to the team management and how they position their yearly objectives
Lots of opportunities to move around the company, in 5 years I've finally found my home after two other spots
Cons:
Big company issues like disconnected HR, company wide regulations that may not make sense for your team, your location
Advancement is difficult, lots of people join and stay their whole careers, some adjust with the times and other do not making innovating harder than necessary

Pros: I have the opportunity to work with some of the smartest people on the planet. Everybody is extremely helpful and the first line managers are fantastic.
Cons:
Where to begin... Our department (MSS) Is literally falling apart. It is one terrible change after another from upper management. What was once a well oiled machine has now crumbled into a completely dysfunctional mess thanks to recent changes brought in by upper management in an effort to save money. 

These changes completely break processes, and cause interdepartmental turmoil. The general mood has shifted from a thriving fun environment to somber. Everyone works as if the next career move is right around the corner.

Pros:
Was a great place to work with challenging projects when the technical and management start align.  
Smart colleagues you can learn from. 
Work location flexibility (can work from home)
Cons:
Company going through major restructuring of business. New sales pipeline is completely broken currently. 
The management layer is disconnected with the technical layer currently (2017-2018). 
Project delivery and technical resource management communication is broken. There is no objective way to forecast work and  ensure that the right person is doing the right job.

Pros: Good salary, benefits, work-life balance. Overall, great people to work with: professional, very technical, and intelligent. People are mostly open to helping one another to get things done. IBM has been around for 100 years, so it is stable.
Cons: Although the company is stable, the workforce is not.  IBM goes through frequent purges in which experienced employees are laid off. This churn means gaps and holes start showing in knowledge and procedures.

Pros: I worked on new projects every 2 years, exploring and learning next generation technologies.
Cons: In the last 18 months of my employment, I had 5 different managers. I was purely a resource number in the IBM system. Additionally, my hours worked  per week in the last two years of my employment were consistently between 50-70 hours a week. My pay was well below market value, 10s of thousands to low.

Pros: I thoroughly enjoyed my time working out of the IBM's design studio in Austin, TX. I was there for 3 years and overall it was a positive experience. The studio itself is beautiful and well designed for an open-floor layout. The working environment was rather relaxed. The design organization was a bit separate from the rest of the organization so I was thankfully shielded from too much politics.
Cons:
- Lots of time spent creating designs that very often go nowhere 
- Although you're shielded from heavy corporate politics, the office drama that can occur between 100+ early 20's graduates all in the same open office can be a distraction.

Pros: In the Cloud division I work in, lots of people work from home full-time, which is very convenient.
Cons: Lots of layoffs and poor decisions made by senior management with no regard for the impact on customers and people's ability to get their work done.  Strategy seems to be "keep cutting until customers start running for the exit."  With fewer and fewer people to do the work, work/life balance continues to deteriorate and morale is very low.

Pros:
* Amazing benefits: literally saving me hundreds of dollars per month compared to other hiring mechanisms
* People-centric support: whether from headquarters or work in the field or in the Ronald Regan building, there is an emphasis on people first in all the work we do. 
* Smart and Creative Team: Willingness to learn and work hard from top to bottom and processes and policies are created only if it efficient and helpful.
Cons:
* Growing quickly and there can be growing pains
* Institutional Contracting can be hard as so much of opportunity is not based on ZemiTek but on technical office and their willingness to provide those opportunities

Pros: IBM is reforming itself from a value to a growth stock under Arvind's leadership. Consider IBM like a brick and mortar in IT of yesteryears but leaping into the future by staying ahead on very key areas of growth and performance required for our large on-premises customers. It will be visible in the next few years by the growth in the revenue where hyper scalers will struggle as they can not match the experience of IBM for enterprise customers.
Cons: Covid-19 put a damp on the growth but since we are getting out of it, growth will be visible.

Pros: The work and ongoing projects can be interesting. Could be a good starter job.
Cons: The overall culture is mediocre and career progress is slow regardless of performance. Management will burnout high performers w/o any really compensation. Pay is so so, raises and bonuses outside of salary is lacking. Management leaves much to be desired which is often disorganized and disconnected. Leads to employees to prioritize attending meetings to talk rather than making real contribute to projects

Pros: There is a lot of work to be done, because we have so many people we need to communicate with and keep up to speed.
Cons: You are a resource, not a person to the executive team. Your manager is asked if s/he has the absolute best people on board, if not, work the less than perfect people out of the business - tell them the bar is rising and they no longer meet the requirements.

Pros: Fairly good pay & medical benefits.
Cons: The vast majority of technical jobs in the United States are going overseas to India, China, Brazil & a little bit to Russia.  Opportunities to excel at IBM in the U.S. are diminishing every week & every month.  Pay raises are non-existent or minimal.  You can quickly get the feeling that IBM does not present a level playing field to everyone for promotions & career advancement.

Pros: Big company with many different opportunities to expand your skill set.  Still a lot of high quality people in the organization, especially our technical resources.  Benefits are decent, not great.  IBM will spend time educating new comers to the business, while so many others don't.
Cons: Big company with lots of internal paperwork, we are slow moving (still).  The selling skils of our client teams has diminshed greatly over the past twenty years as we have failed to keep our salaries competitive with the industry.  You won't make a great income, and you will be ground into the ground

Pros:
diversified business - global client base, opportunities, 
IBM brand still commands a lot of value
Cons: Big company - 350K+ employees - you will be just one among the crowd...very difficult to stand out

Pros: If you take ownership of your responsibilities, and prove yourself, you can largely direct your own work.  Management listens to your suggestions, and if they make sense, often say 'make it happen'.  Very flexible schedules, and good work-life balance.
Cons: Training and personal development aren't an emphasis.  You can make it happen, assuming you find free online training in the Global Campus, but it will be on your own time.  This is different in different areas - some get a ton of training.  Others are left to wither.

Pros:
Work with Fortune 500 Companies
Working relationships with high level management
Get experience with large and small teams
When not on the client site, not required to work from office
Build extensive network and contact list
Deal with a wide range of business issues
Cons:
Excess Travel and low work/life balance
Little to no comradery with other consultants in practice
Tend to get treated as a number in the vast employment pool
Quick turnover and burnout
Can get pigeon-holed into particular tasks if "too good" of job is done
Other typical complaints regarding large companies

Pros: You have access to lots of up to date technology. There are a lot of competent people that work at IBM. You can gain a lot of valuable experience in the industry. The benefits are decent, and the work hours are very flexible.
Cons: Management is very stingy with salary increases and promotions. The performance review process (PBCs) is very opaque and and seemingly random. You are given very vague feedback from management on the type of work expected from you and your performance relative to your peers.

Pros:
Opportunity to work with some of the best and brightest
The opportunity to gain knowledge/experience and learn to question every step is outstanding
Cons:
EVERYTHING is a priority
It's all about the cost ($$$$)
The never ending EPS roadmap is killing morale with all the cuts, cuts, cuts
Some members of senior management are absolutely off their rockers and thrive on power
Do more with less is the mantra
There is NO work/life balance, rather, IBM supports work/life integration.  So while you can work from any remote location with an available internet connection, there is an expectation to integrate your life into your work.

Pros: Consistently in some category of "Top XYZ of companies to work for," wide range of services and project opportunities, reputation and brand recognition as a global leader.
Cons: Moving towards a virtual firm with little office interaction;  VERY stingy with extras (providing cell phones or even reimbursement for consultants, few training dollars, no coffee or water provided in those offices that are left, etc.)

Pros: This is a large company with a well-known brand.  Although many developers know of the toxic environment, other employers are still unaware of the situation.  As such, having IBM on my resume has helped create opportunities.
Cons:
Stack ratings guarantee politics as opposed to good performance.  Employees who are good at networking and promoting themselves (or taking credit for work) will excel.  Actual performance on the job is not rewarded (or punished).
In addition, outsourcing at IBM is extremely pervasive.  Get used to late night/early morning meetings with India.  This also means that there is very little job security.

Pros:
Looks good on a resume while you are looking for a job.
Cute downtown location - shops, small restaurants, salons/spas
Daily huddles
Cons:
Don't expect to make any better wage than anywhere else in Dubuque or small surrounding communities
Unclear path to moving up
People go years with not a penny raise
Highest turnover rate any GDF Center in North America

Pros: Flexible work at home and work life balance.  Respectful of individuals and overall good team environment. Attracts some of the brightest and best.  Good overall Management and Leadership for the most part. Good open sharing of ideas and information.  True global focus.  Good corporate culture on the whole
Cons: Limited career options, especially for US workers. Constant concern over potential layoffs and cutbacks, or offshoring of US jobs. Slow career advancement and limited promotion opportunities. Salaries increasingly are not keeping up with the marketplace.  Very low to nonexistent bonus opportunities.

Pros: Great management and co-workers, come and go whenever for short breaks, no punch out time cards, hard work and long hours do pay off with recognition, free coffee all day, nice office with great views of Mississippi River, privacy rooms available for small meetings, nice conference rooms for team meetings, great desk set-up, intense but well-worth classes which offer free vouchers to obtain licenses upon completion.
Cons: Managers do change often but not really a con-  this is a way to experience a 'fresh' outlook on team building which I suspect is why management does frequently change.  If you are not one for adjustments or  changes, this type of work force is not for you.

Pros: The company has a long history, reputation (the name speaks for itself), great product, global, benefits, skies the limit for above/beyond contributors, resources and a great talent pool!
Cons: It's a big company therefore you'll have to contribute above and beyond to be recognized or to survive. Employees are just employees.  Concentrate at what matters to the company not what you think matters.  However, these are prevelant in most companies today.

Pros: Successful multi-national information technology company with multiple career opportunities across a broad spectrum of jobs and geographic locations.  Successful systems, services and software middleware businesses.  Client base includes some of the largest companies in the world.  Does business in 170 countries.
Cons: Large, impersonal, slow to innovate with a finance-driven culture.  Does not invest in employee training, education and skills development as it did in past years.  Does not value sales and sales leaders as it did in the past.  Weak product management teams in many segments of its business.

Pros: IBM has talented people, a good reputation in the market, advances the business by investing in technology or creating alliances with strategic partners, and has a strong client base. From an employee perspective, the benefits are good.
Cons: There is bureaucracy throughout the company that makes it difficult to advance. I realized pretty quickly that some people were basically waiting their time for retirement, and just keep their head down and collect a paycheck every month. There is little incentive for them to innovate or contribute more than what is asked or expected.

Pros: Great experience all over the country with excellent career progression and upward mobility if you're willing to play the game and make personal sacrifices.  Ability to work from home office.
Cons: No separation between work and life...and work usually wins out.  Worked with the company for almost 2 decades with top level performance ratings for the bulk of my career and was then 'sold' to another company without any protection on long term employment or even current salary as part of a transaction involving over 30k worldwide employees.  Company clearly sees its employees as numbers and not humans.

Pros: flexible working environment for some of us
Cons: I work with some rather unethical and untalented people. It didn't used to be that way.

Pros: You will work with smart, nice, family-oriented people. Managers are understanding and supportive.
Cons: Almost everybody I work with is remote. There is no real reason to show up at the office most days, which is great if you enjoy working remotely, but not so great if if you enjoy collaborating and working with people in person. Also, Most of the teams I work with are short-staffed, which causes stress and lowers the quality of IBM products. IBM isn't necessarily replacing the people that leave the company or retire.

Pros: Opportunity abound to be exposed to a lot about new technologies, learn about and share information with colleagues. Very flexible work / life balance.
Cons: The needs of the business can far out weigh your own needs, hence your career can suffer in lost opportunities to attend classes, speeches or seminars that would otherwise promote or further your intellect and career. The continuous resource actions that take place causes one to be distracted and lose focus of their work and thus lose interest and seek employment elsewhere.

Pros: Prior to acquisition by IBM, I was  with an 70 person company that you were expected to and able to wear many hats, make strategic decisions and make things happen with out the politics and bureaucracy of larger technology organization.
Cons: When IBM acquired our company we became challenged with the politics and bureaucracy of the multi Billion dollar company.  Great, highly experienced, super smart people at IBM, but there was little room for the leadership personnel being acquired to fit into the greater IBM organization

Pros:
PTO - 3 weeks
Holidays - 12 (7 mandated 5 floating)
Sick Leave
Maternity/Paternity
Comparable health care options
Job Security
Plenty of online self paced training
Cons:
Big focus on Chargeable utilization
Big company so a lot of spreadsheet management
No raises for 85% of employees for a couple years now
No raises for 40% of employees for last 6 years
Bonus/Profit sharing not available for last 2 years
Training is done on personal time with minimal budget allocated 
401k match paid out at end of year
Expensive health care
Attrition of talented individuals

Pros: You are surrounded by the smartest people in the world.  This is the first job I had where I didn't feel like I was working with a bunch of idiots.  It was fun to work on developing the latest and greatest technology.
Cons:
Everyone is always worried about the next RA.
1st line managers hands are tied.
Executive leadership is very short sighted.

Pros: Always working with smart, motivated people. The size of the company means there is a wide range of projects in different technologies and there is flexibility to move between projects. Flexible work environment that is understanding of times you may need to work from home. Opportunity to work with people across the globe. Management embraces diversity.
Cons: Raises are small so salaries fall way behind the current job market. Excessive number of meetings that can consume entire days, so the only time to get actual work done is off hours. Senior management is too far removed from the actually development. Too many levels of management.

Pros: Great Co-workers, very talented. Work from home is encourages, most of the time.
Cons: Benefits and pay sucks, constant layoffs. I started in 1984, and it was the best place to work, now one of the worst. Morale is horrible, and management does not care. no chance of upward mobility, Clueless management, except for a 1st level once in a while. Right now you have entry level kids, and grey beards with 20++++ years. When they leave there will be no skills or expertise left. IBM can't fulfill commitments now with lack of talent.

Pros: IBM is a great place to work:  Challenging work, smart people, good compensation packages.  Also, management requires constant coursework and training.
Cons: IBM is a bit hampered by its size.  Because it is so large, IBM operates in a bureaucratic manner to maintain operational effectiveness.  Ironically, this operational efficacy of IBM's makes it tougher to make quick decisions.  Decisions are always slow in coming but extremely sound once made.

Pros: Competitive Salary, Good Benefits, Flex Hours, Work from home, Very Good on line training resources, there is a collaborative spirit in that peers tend to be willing to help each other.
Cons: IBM doesn't delegate authority well.  They have a few people making decisions and a lot of people trying to implement them.  There is little incentive to use initiative or to take risk. Internal IBM experience is valued to the point that promotions of those with less IBM experience is very difficult.

Pros: Great opportunities to travel while on projects. Meeting awesome co-workers. Able to get vacation time even if you started with the company in the middle of the year
Cons: They are not completely honest about the job description while in the interview or with the posting online. You have to be on a project. If not you are at risk of being fired within a few months. Even if there are no project in your service line.

Pros: If you are coming out of college, don't know what you want to do, and are looking to learn about a number of different businesses and industries, IBM is a fantastic place to work.
Cons: If you don't want to travel, stay away.  You'll be on the road almost every week.  But for some, that might be great!  Can't beat the miles!

Pros:
Lots of smart people that are willing to help you learn. 
Everyone is very helpful. 
Ability to work on big important projects that can have a huge impact on the World.
The people around you want to see you succeed and want to help.
Cons:
You can get lost in such a big company. It's hard to not feel like a small person in a large machine.
Not much leadership from management, but there are others around that can help teach you the in's and out's on the company.

Pros: Great place to begin a career; learn business and technical skills and gain experience working directly with clients; everybody knows IBM so great name recognition for those looking to move on
Cons: Size of the organization and the fact that junior consultants spend most of their time onsite with clients makes it difficult to get noticed within IBM; where unproven junior consultants end up is largely luck of the draw

Pros: Employees have opportunity to network well internally, but are somewhat inbred from onset of employment and lose touch with the outside  business world.
Cons: A lot of dead weight shifted around from one dying account to another.  IBM is very afraid of law suits, so employees know they won't be removed for lack of performance, hence the system breeds mediocrity.  Middle and Upper management are focused on bonuses over account success, and contractors are heavily penalized with unscheduled, last-minute furloughs to help make quarterly returns to investors.   These are the same contractors that help make the accounts successful; they are treated quite badly.  Overall, a very dysfunctional organization.

Pros: Work from home, that is the only positive left.
Cons:
IBM has been on a downward spiral for almost the entire time I have been employed here (15 years). Constant shift of jobs to offshore, stock buybacks, financial engineering to keep share holders and execs well paid are all short sided. 

If you have any talent, vision, or want to make a difference in the tech world I would recommend looking elsewhere. Find a company that values your talent regardless of pay/location. 

The corruption goes all the way to the top, with the latest dagger being management has cut severance from 26 weeks to 4 (no matter how long you have worked there). I have effectively lost 6 months severance pay, while all the executives continue to pilfer the coffers.

Pros: Most of my time was a good experience (even without having been there in the "good old days" of high bonuses and respect for the employee as part of their values).  Many positions offered flexibility to work from home.
Cons: The "threat" of layoff always loomed which didn't help morale for those that made the skew each year.  News about the company was often received on the local news (which turned out to be true), only later to be briefly communicated by management. Focus at EOQ set unrealistic precedent for employees to perform miracles with little work/life balance.

Pros: The EDA department was an interesting place to work.  Almost everyone is extremely bright and competent.  Being in a single company with a fab means no lawyers stop you from seeing how your software is used.
Cons:
The chip fabrication business is not growing, so periodic layoffs are par for the course.

IBM has its own proprietary solution to most problems in chip design.  The knowledge yo gain will not transfer to other companies.

Pros:
- Good starting base pay
- Consulting by degrees program training
- Fast promotion to senior consultant
Cons:
- Can get pigeonholed easily
- Public sector projects are year long commitments and therefore you do not have a true consulting experience
- Lack of project diversity
- Easier to quit IBM and get rehired than to move to another department 
- Hard to differentiate or shine when you're on a government contract

Pros: In the Software area, IBM Has a multitude of resources and a broad portfolio of capabilities, many market-leading and having resulted from acquisition.  The wealth of technology and talent means that IBM can win large scale deals that niche providers cannot.
Cons: As a very large organization, change and overall execution pace is slow.   The resources and investment put into improving offerings and synergy across the various software acquisitions is moderate to low, focus is much more on just posting sales in the next two quarters.  It results in a largely tactical operating model for many in the sales and delivery organizations.

Pros: Good people to work with.  Most of the people at IBM really do try to do the right thing for their customers.  The amount of talent is ofter amazing.
Cons: Too large, hard to get the right things done.  Reluctant to change.  Although there is a lot of talent to work with the internal processes make it hard to get things done.

Pros:
Wide breadth of resources means you can almost always find an answer to a question from someone
Large technical community and opportunities to learn on the job
A lot of opportunity to move within the company and be exposed to wide range of technology
Cons:
Command and control management style
Who you know matters more than what you know
Aggressively move jobs overseas
Quarter to quarter pivoting in direction and deciding what's important

Pros: Brand permission, a few star inspirational folks not yet worn down by the machine.
Cons: Significant bureaucracy. Lethargy amongst senior leadership. 'Lifer-status' of many senior leaders carried as if it is a strength, when it is in fact a major weakness - since they have lost sight of what 'good looks like' outside of the blue walls.

Pros: Can work from home (although that is ending for most people).
Cons: Corporate management cares only with enriching themselves.  Revenue shrinking continually for the past 5 years.  Massive layoffs are a regular thing now.  Experienced, talented employees are no longer valued and are being replaced with younger, cheaper (and less talented) people at an alarming rate.  CEO talks about hiring 25,000 people in the US, but MANY more than that are being laid off.  Corporate management is dishonest about the overall state of the company.  Morale is terrible.  No pay raises for the past 5+ years.  No promotion opportunities.

Pros: A very large portfolio of software products and the potential to provide an end to end platform to help companies know and sell to their customers.
Cons: A culture that sells speeds and feeds/features and benefits as opposed to providing solutions. A company focusing on short-term gains to the exclusion of ensuring its future.

Pros: Verizon sold their cloud/hosting business to IBM in Sep/2017 and I was among those who transitioned to IBM. From the beginning, I noticed how IBM offers a more organized environment, with excellent opportunities to improve and expand our careers, with clear learning paths and multiple resources.
Cons: Health insurance options seem to be designed for singles, who get free health insurance. Married individuals with kids pay expensive insurance to have spouses and kids covered. Compared to what I used to have at Verizon, IBM health care plans offer less and charge way more.

Pros: Good ethics. Provide employees the freedom to take  new initiatives. Lot of lateral move options to gain a wide range of experience.
Cons: Disconnected and at times dysfunctional communication across the layers and layers of hierarchy. Extremely difficult to move the needle on outcomes due to the complexity of the organization and processes. Letting people go is a continuous process in IBM  which creates a permanent state of flux resulting in lackluster performance.

Pros: Workplace flexibility, opportunity to work in several capacities
Cons: Lack of communication about policy changes affecting employees, pay below market, constant restructuring to try to catch up to competitors or show change for change's sake, annual layoffs not due to performance but to make short-term cost/profit targets

Pros: Much of the work is performed remotely.
Cons: IBM tries to do just enough in terms of employee support to say they are not below average, i.e. they are only average.  Not a leader in any benefit category, nor do they care to be.  Mgmt position is "I am smarter than you, so you just listen.  We don't need your ideas or input".  Once they are through with you, employees are cast to the side of the proverbial road like yesterday's trash.

Pros: If you identify an executive who is really willing to mentor you, it can be hugely beneficial to have that person guide you through the many layers of matrix that exists at IBM.
Cons: You have to find your "village" and your sponsorship to move around, either sideways or up, otherwise, even if you're an expert in your field, you're not recognized on your own merit.

Pros:
Learning, Learning, Learning
Good Pay
Great Benefits -- Able to get life insurance at my age (70) 
Access to Mega Free Leaning
Good Coaching
Remote Work
Good People
Really Emphasize Diversity Inclusion -- Whatever your sex, sexual orientation, color, race, ethnicity, political persuasion--as long as you are willing to help the companies bottom line and abide by ethical standards.
Cons:
Some of the Massive Personnel Systems are hard to navigate
(One particularly annoying feature is called MyScore--It keeps dinging me about something no one can answer about utilization--Watson is no help.)
Hard to get answers about some of th Personnel Software

Pros: There are some interesting projects and nice managers
Cons: Promotion process is not equitable or transparent. If you are POC or a woman, you will be held to a different standard and be expected work harder and prove yourself more. Managers will gaslight you and even manipulate you by dangling the promotion carrot to work longer hours and deliver with little or no resources. And if you are a genuinely hard-working and capable person, you will be expected to clean up after people's mess instead of participating and leading career-building or self-development initiatives. Leave this place before it destroys your soul!

Pros: Great place to start out in an effort towards growing and promoting through various divisions and job roles.
Cons: More opportunity for mentorship and developmental programs for dedicated employees

Pros: There is a lot of momentum at the NEW IBM. We are focusing on improving our agility while delivering value to our clients. We have a good balance of work and life. We are shedding businesses that don't make sense for a growth company and acquiring ones that do.
Cons: There is still some baggage with clients that expect the old IBM that is hard to work with and really a "legal company that happens to do services". There are still some old school leaders that need to be upscaled or outed but this is not the majority anymore.

Pros: Nothing, Since joining till date didn't observe a single positive sign. Management always try to protect their seat and will throw you out of IBM irrespective of how you perform. Lot of communication gap with management and HR. PTO's are a joke, if you lick your boss shoe, you will be able to utilize your PTO to the fullest.
Cons: need to lick manager's shoes always to get promotions. Otherwise it's hard to survive. There is no HR system in place to raise concerns on working hours and office premises. Bonus is Joke and HR is invisible. Unrealistic goals to achieve. Management without technical knowledge will decide your future in IBM. All these managers can't survive outside and I see most of the managers working in IBM for 20-30 years. If these is any Zero star, I will give it.

Pros: Great work life balance. Decent pay and good opportunities for growth and career advancement. Tons of resources to leverage, if you know where to look and connect with the right people. Overall, IBM is a great place to work.
Cons: Suffers from the classic challenges of a huge corporation. Things can advance pretty slowly. Sometimes you may end up on projects that are not great. Pay could be a little bit better. Benefits are not great either. Also experiences vary quite a bit depending on role, position, sector, project, etc. But all in all, IBM is a good company to work for.

Pros: The name of IBM speaks for itself.
Cons: You are lost in such a big company. Will be confused as to how to get help. The Partners and Senior Managers looks for themselves not for others. Least bothered to find what is actually going on with the lower-level staff.

Pros: In my department, we have a really strong positive culture and are challenged to grow, explore, and be our authentic selves. I have a decent work-life balance, one of the reasons I love IBM. Company has a clear vision of where it's headed. My mentors and managers have full faith that I can do a great job and are constantly building me up and giving me that room to grow.
Cons: No stock benefits outside of executive level. In general pay is worse than other tech companies, but no massive layoffs over here (knock on wood).

Pros: There are none left. All of the good people have left IBM and are abandoning ship.
Cons:
Extremely top heavy with managers and executives. They are completely out of touch with their workers.
Raises/bonuses and the ability to advance your career or further your education have all been eliminated for the past 4 years.

Pros: The opportunity to work on Linux and get paid to do it. Biggest company so I felt that I would have the most opportunity to move up.
Cons: Senior management is incompetent and lower level workers suffer from it on a constant basis. Also the politics at IBM are unbelievable,  people are placed in places for pure political reasons. Promotions are totally uneven, if fair at all. There is a system in IBM that after awhile you begin to realize is completely rigged.

Pros: Brand recognition, and instant credibility on engagements.  Also, the company has a world-wide presence.  Thus, you could be tapped to go on an international engagement; or, you could lead a data recovery team in the Gulf states.  The place has a lot of opportunties.
Cons: Huge technology services firm, and so you are rated with EVERYONE at your level.  Plus, the pay slowly matriculates upward.  The bonuses are fair, but I'd like to have more pay and not worry about looking elsewhere.

Pros: Large customer accounts offer enterprise-level systems experience and a variety of problems to work on. Other teams nearby offer the potential for information sharing. Good food in the cafeteria. Parking lots are well lit at night.
Cons: IBM Global Services is motivated to take on as many large, outsourced support contracts but provide the cheapest support possible. Constant staff cuts and uncertainty of future work, despite outsourced accounts justifying the need for staff and elevated levels of support. Managers sometimes change frequently with little notice. Supported customers don't realize the diminutive staffs that are supporting their accounts and demand high levels of service.

Pros: Decent bennies at ok salary for regular employees (for others, it's a completely different story).  Flexibility of working from home was good.  Some of the technologies being used are up-to-date; others are clearly legacy.
Cons: The hardware market is shrinking for a company like IBM, and also the company is moving technical work offshore as quickly as possible.  Don't get trapped in a dead end position, or think that this place will offer a career.

Pros: IBM is a good place to work.   There is good deal of respect for employees except when it comes to the resource actions.   In many parts of the company you get the opportunity to change jobs every 2-3 years and that helped maintain my interest and keep me challenged.   Also, if you get a manager that you don't like very well you can be pretty sure that you or they will move before too long.
Cons: The lack of promotions.   You need to want to work a lot of hours - this isn't a 9-5 place.

Pros: IBM can do anything a client wants, and as a Client Rep, I had the opportunity to build a solution for almost every business initiative my customers had.  Many very smart people.  Excellent ongoing product and sales training.
Cons: Too big.  Too many sellers looking for that grand slam and not interested in working the smaller deals in SMB.  Hard to move out of the call center and into the field sales environment.  1st line and 2nd line mgt had trouble setting quotas

Pros: Teamwork is strong, so you can usually craft a solution to beat the competition.
Cons: You'll make decent money, but it's difficult to "blow it out" because they will at random raise your quota to ensure you do not reach "excellerators" (multipliers) in commission pay formula.

Pros:
* Leading edge technologies.
* Good place to get a start.
* Good support if you need time off work.
Cons:
* No longer a good long term employer. Older employees are targets for layoffs. Check out how many people make it to retirement from this company today -- very few. This was very different in the past.
* You can no longer trust managers to watch out for you. Your career is now entirely your responsibility. If you get assigned to a "bad" project, you could get let go through no fault of your own. Watch your back - once again, very different from the old IBM.

Pros: Working from home, 401K match, medical
Cons: Lots of rules and restrictions.   Silo mentality for job roles and responsibilities.  Can be frustrating for someone who is used to and enjoys wearing many hats in their job function.   It takes forever to get a decisions made.  Feels like 70's managment style.

Pros:
Benefits are some of the best in the industry, IBM brand still looks good on a resume. Great place to gain experience.

If you are a high performer and show it you can possibly be recognized for it with financial incentives but this also depends on how well you play into the politics more than anyone likes to admit.

Lots of opportunities to build your skill-set, if you prove that you can get things done early on you will get the interesting high skill work as it comes in.
Cons:
In these new "delivery centers" micromanagement is the encouraged norm not the exception. Be prepared to be forced to sit though lots of useless "GDF education" seminars which rehash the same information over and over about how you should be working (and then management will want you to do it a different way anyway after the seminars.) Also once a year all employees have to use a time tracking tool for about a month, where everything that is done has to be logged and analyzed to decide if the work can be done efficiently by less people or not.

This is an extreme cost cutting environment, instead of having a real catering service they contract that to a local gas station. Things in the building that break will not be fixed for months in the future, if they even are at all. Overtime hours getting revoked is the norm, some teams inside the building have lost entire clients due to the overtime crunches but management doesn't care.

With this new "GDF methodology" the hiring of inexperienced people is also the norm. Plenty of people in low level system administration positions have never even logged into a server before.

Salaries are also below market rate.

The focus on team metrics is also a little extreme, too often it gets to the point where more time is spent trying to game the metrics system rather then trying to improve the real processes.

People see the writing on the wall and know that in a few years most of the jobs will be done from India.

Pros: IBM has excellent processes, solid management and excellent work-life balance for employees.  IBM has good focus on employees development and offers great training opportunities for employees, if they choose to take them up.  As always, career development is up to you, so more work you put in, better results you will get at IBM.
Cons: Processes can mean slower response time sometimes, especially working across international boundaries. It's hard to avoid this for a large corporation, especially since each geography has its own operating company (due to legal and regulatory requirements).

Pros: Great company to work for.  Excellent benefits and great co-workers.  Strong belief in work/life balance and was able to work from home as needed.
Cons: Poor integration of people from acquired companies.  Difficult to move within the company from one position to another.  IBM is a very large company  so it takes a long time to learn and fit into its internal system, if you do at all.  The PBC s not working as it is designed to be. The evaluation of performance and promotion process is not  clear.

Pros: A lot of opportunity to try new things, learn new skills and take on new projects. In marketing you can always find a way to work on a project (or 5) that interest you. And in the right department travel is easy to come by.
Cons: You are expected to work on multiple projects at one time and not just the original job you were hired for. 40 hours is a joke, but to get the ratings for promotions and salary bumps 55+ is very realistic.

Pros:
It's extremely easy to be an outperformer. All the technology is at least a decade old and development (due to bureaucracy and process) proceeds at a crawl. Show the tiniest bit of talent and you'll be a rock star. 
Low level managers are pretty flexible. It's pretty easy to get approval to work from home, which is advisable because the buildings are falling apart.
Cons: The management is clueless, nobody has the will to change anything, the internal tools are horrid (ask an IBMer about any Lotus or Rational product, if they've ever used an alternative, they'll have plenty to tell you about).

Pros:
Incredibly broad solution portfolio
Company capable to do any project, any size, anywhere
There is a suitable job for everybody
International job opportunities
Staff empowered to be creative and innovative
Cons:
Too many executives and far too many "program management" roles
Management out of touch with client needs and only managing on metrics
Education hard to get because of expense controls
It is more about who you are than about what you know and what your capabilities are; almost like a TV show

Pros:
Many different projects and opportunities to move around.
Many experts in different area, from whom help is often given freely.
Flexible work hours.
Cons:
Ratings/reviews seem to make it necessary to compete with co-workers, with emphasis on visibility to management.
Trend seems to be moving jobs overseas, reducing US workforce. Cuts are often across the board, so many very good employees being let go.
Most projects end up being teams in multiple locations around the world, making collaboration difficult to match up work schedules.

Pros: You can definitely learn a lot at IBM either by going very deep on a topic or moving around to different jobs.  Benefits are above average (but get trimmed every year).  Lots of international opportunities.  You get to work with people who know what it means to be a professional.
Cons: Resource actions (layoffs) happen at least once a year.  Lack of organic investment in products.  Internal incentives and silos get in the way of success.  Getting harder to move from one group to another.

Pros:
People are knowledgeable and kind, lots of good things to learn if you are in the right team. Funding generally is not a problem. Working on a right project can help you publish a lot of work. 
Work life balance is good. Generally no need to travel or work over the weekend. Things go along with a steady pace.
Reporting structure is generally stable. You report to one boss and don't have to change manager all the time, which happens in some other companies
Cons: People are lay back. Hardworking may not necessary bring you promotion or salary increse. Besides work, politics also impacts your performance.

Pros: Good work moral and environments for ones who want to retire from IBM.
Cons: No special considerations and incentives for talented technical employees if the one is not "Really Outstanding" techie in IT.

Pros:
- Looks good on resume for now (people will find out the truth someday)
- They hire straight out of college
- Pretty decent benefits package on day one
- Work from home 2 days/week if you have to commute over 45 minutes to the office
- Good place to gain experience IF you get placed on projects that actually require your skills
- I like the people I work side by side with most of the time.
Cons:
- The nature of this place is to "Reshore" the offshore jobs that clients don't seem to be satisfied with. In the long term strategy, IBM has built service centers in India and conducted mass layoffs in the US. Then after some client dissatisfaction with their contractors being on the other side of the globe and hard to communicate with, IBM opened a service center in economically depressed Michigan, knowing that competition for jobs was stiff, and that people would work cheap just to have a job.
- Raises, which are rarely given, are abysmal (I think a dollar an hour raise every 3 years is all one can expect)
- Overtime was taken away when we were converted from Supplemental to Regular employees, which for me worked out to be a 20% pay cut. This was a deal-breaker for pretty much everyone and has permanently scarred morale to the point of disfigurement. 
- Clients can be as demanding as they want, and if your project manager is a "yes man", you could end up working every night and weekend, and traveling to the clients site every week.
- Forced to work 45+ hours per week minimum, which pretty much sucks the life out of you.
- HR managers are also on projects of their own, so they really don't have time to be managers.

Pros: They used to care about their employees. Used to be a company ran by "techies" and cared about their customers too. See cons.
Cons: They laid off to many of their greatest techie employees. Company is now run by bean counters. Their idea of letting one bright mind go is to replace them with 3 or more contractors that cost them a whole lot less, can be fired at any time, and don't have to pay them benefits.

Pros: Compensation and benefits are solid, lots of vacation, good insurance, and I'm working with an extremely talented team.
Cons: The org structure prevents real work for getting done and there's constant pressure to help the company as it struggles. Despite promises and going above and beyond for my group, I've been blocked from promotion.

Pros: Ability to work as a mobile employee. Benefits are average, however compensation is not competitive. Opportunity to change jobs without leaving the company.
Cons: Employees are not viewed as assets but rather as resources. There is an "I" in team where the objective is to survive the next round of layoffs. IBM is bleeding business and customers every quarter.  It's a revolving door where there is a constant stream of talent leaving. Essentially it is a lumbering elephant that is without leadership, vision, strategy or direction.

Pros: Remote work.  Customers continue (blindly) to purchase whatever IBM will sell them without question.  If these $bil dollar customers only knew what they were throwing their money at.
Cons:
As most have already stated, the management chain at IBM is deplorable.  From execs to senior to middle to junior management, without fail they have ALL been placed there as a level of their incompetency.  

Execs are not technical and have no idea what IT does.  Most are psychologists, HR types, or from Social systems.  Problem employees that can't be dealt with legally are often promoted to some level of management, and given new subordinates to manage.  Problem junior/middle managers typically find a director or a VP to cling to, and spend the rest of their lives kissing their butts to keep their jobs.  They provide no leadership, no forward thinking, and certainly no one that can be approached for some meaningful insight.  These are truly incompetent people, and the company is full of them - upwards of 45% of the world employee pool is management.  Management is does not and is not supposed to produce ANYTHING.  Except that phone call that you've been laid off or a bad PBC review.

The mood/tone at IBM is just awful, and every day we look for the proberbial email of a 2 week notice.  Approaching your first line manager is pointless and often backfires into an RA or a poor PBC rating.   Poor PBCs have tripled in the last 2 years, using this tool to eradicate older and other "miscreant" work staff.

Most are fired within 12 months in advance of retirement.  IBM only retired several employees last year, all of them were from the management ranks.  And yes, everything you hear on the news RE execs robbing the place blind in the $millions is true.

It's an IT company that's BSing it's way through new technologies - and most know it

Pros: IBM has the culture and the people that allowed SIGNIFICANT advanced to semiconductor IC technology over the years to the point we are now (2015) manufacturing the most sophisticated high performance ICs ever made by mankind.
Cons: IBM's ICs are so high end and so expensive that IBM priced itself out of the OEM market.  IBM Microelectronics' main customer, IBM server group (mid and high end servers) sells only thousands of units, not  the millions of units of game consoles, for example, that are sold.  The resultant money pit that IBM Microelectronic became led to persistent layoffs or threats of layoffs that has decimated the populated of IBM's 300mm fab.

Pros: For those interested in trying different things, lateral movement is still possible, though not as much as it used to be.  As a large company, IBM has lots of resources.
Cons: You are worked hard without much credit/compensation.  If you're not in sales or marketing, you are treated merely as a fungible resource.  It's a somewhat stodgy company.  They try to do modern things, like agile development, but that philosophy doesn't go very high up the management chain.

Pros: My area is flexible and works for my family.  I am a work at home employee and this is a huge help. Benefits are average at best. There are career opportunities if you are able and willing to travel/work at client site.
Cons: Untilization targets are high as you give back all earned time off. Resource actions seem to happen every quarter so I am always on pins and needles. Rating system is unfair. Variable pay, and raises are anemic at best and reward only the top few.

Pros: Super People , strong industry recognition, work from home, some great managers, good benefits, work/ life balance, excellent place for older workers, talented CEO who inherited a difficult situation, in many accounts strong long-term relationships with IBM & client senior management, mainframe customers are demanding, but extremely loyal
Cons: Company manages incomes, can be late to market with solutions, feeling of being isolated , some poor managers only interested in impressing their superiors with no regard to direct reports, stock price performance has been weak, inter company communications can be a challenge...

Pros: Great people to work with.  New technologies available to learn.
Cons: Consulting services is loosing ground, IBM is not actively funding work in these areas. Customized software and its support is loosing ground in the US not only to offshoring but also to newer technologies where customization is becoming more configuration management.  Employees in consulting services are made responsible for their utilization and forecasting and targets are well over 100% ..vacation is not considered and must be recovered in the percentage targeted!!!

Pros: Excellent benefits, worked remotely from home.
Cons: Global company means calls at any time of day in the US - sometimes 9-10pm at night. Current state of company is you are always worried about losing your job to a layoff. No one is safe even if you received excellent job performance reviews. Company is using more and more global resources from low cost countries.

Pros: IBM pros include its brand and strength in key market areas such as security, analytics, cognitive computing.  IBM continues to strengthen its software portfolio by aggressively acquiring new companies to expand into new areas or build out gaps in current portfolios.
Cons: IBM is struggling to get its footing as it reinvents itself into a SW company.  The company is managed by the finance dept.  Expectations from Senior Mgt are often misaligned with reality of local geographies.

Pros: They do a great job of taking care of you. Mostly a laid back workplace. Not super stressful. Not usually working long hours. Super flexible about remote work and hours when needed.
Cons: Too big for their own good. Separation of decision makers and do'ers makes any practical decisions next to impossible. IBM doesn't invent things anymore. They just react and buy other people's work. No one has guts to be truly innovative because executives only care about the numbers on their yearly report.

Pros: The pay is good for those that put the time in, and the benefits are comparable to same jobs in other companies of like positions.
Cons: IBM is going through company direction changes and has had multiple Resource Actions (layoffs) over the last several years.  Hard to stay focused and engaged when you are constantly concerned you are going to be part of the workforce to be let-go.  These layoffs include high performers, and all levels of the workforce.

Pros: If you are starting your career, carrying the IBM name in your resume may still be a positive,  but the company has changed so much...
Cons: Uncertainty, driven by Wallstreet,  no respect for employees, no investment in growing skills of its workforce, disposable employees,  disatisfied clients, confusing product line, managed by fear.

Pros: Wonderful, talented coworkers. I found my coworkers to be intensely focused on customer and IBM success rather than petty internal politics.
Cons: Expected to work large amount of overtime. Annual reviews and raises largely based on your organization's results. Deck stacked against individuals. IBM's constant attempts to cut costs continually introduced chaos into the business.  Very hard to make forward progress as the company always was undercutting success via changes for cost cutting. Management always trying to positively spin things.  Was Orwellian at times.

Pros: Wonderful co-workers, Ability to work from home.Flexibility.   Travel to conferences which enables learning.  A few good managers and mentors.
Cons: Long hours, extra work every year due to repeated resource actions, which has become demoralizing.   An overly political environment where most management is afraid to take a stand on ANY issue.   Poor marketing framework with "New Work of Marketing Model' not working or capturing leads.  IBM website that doesn't work to capture responses. Inability to be nimble.  IBM moves on turtle time. More important to build consensus than do good work.  New CMO has NO tech experience.  Most new hires have no experience in tech or the markets IBM plays in.  Outsourcing to India and Brazil on the rise. American works are laid off every year.

Pros:
Prestige of being an "IBMer"  (other people think it's cool)
Fantastic product
Historically a leader in equal employment
Great Pay
Fantastic benefits
Cons:
Cut throat internal politics driven by consistent mass layoffs
Eligible for RA without explanation, even if you overachieve quota and get excellent reviews
Disconnected management that fear for their jobs just as much as you do
Frequent reorgs and product name changes are confusing for sales and customers
Channel conflict is REAL - channel is in direct competition with direct sales
Working from home means the day never ends - and weekends are fair game for managers expecting a same day response

Pros: When I started more than 10 years ago at IBM, it was a thriving company that gave me a competitive salary, ability to work from home, and opportunities for career advancement. Unfortunately, that is no longer true.
Cons: Reorgs are constant, so you have no chance to get any traction for career advancement before you are working for someone new. The constant churn in the management and organization leaves employees with a state of confusion and lack of motivation. Innovation is non-existent in many areas. Most areas of the business are declining. Employees live with a constant threat of losing their jobs.

Pros: IBM is one the best companies where it comes to people's culture. Comprehensive offerings and services enabling skills growth.
Cons: Poor top level leadership teams who seem to be out of touch with the reality; Huge morale issues due to constant resource actions and change of business direction on half year if not quarterly basis. The bureaucracy is at highest level in some parts of the organization. It has gone from leading to following in the market (i.e. me too mentality);

Pros:
In a company consisting of 500k+ employees, I was always surprised by how many incredibly nice and thoughtful people worked at IBM.  
They will offer a great starting salary, but do NOT expect a steady pay increase with promotions.
Cons:
Lack of transparency between upper management and their teams
Poor mentorship
For a company that promotes employee advocacy, it does a terrible job keeping up employee morale and giving the power to the employee. All the power stays in the hands of senior management.

Pros: Excellent team, highly skilled professionals. The team I was on had some very good people. I think they were struggling a little bit with getting the right direction from their management
Cons: there seem to be a little bit of confusion about the market direction and approach. Sometimes we are going One Direction, sometimes were going another. It was tough to keep the software base in place with all the different changes.

Pros: So many incredibly smart people. Culture of mutual support at all levels.
Cons: Lack of leadership that starts at the top but continues all the way down. Poor product focus comes from a myopic view of client needs and a culture of emperors new clothes. IBM fundamentally has no cloud, but rather than addressing this, they turn to new ever more convoluted sales quotas and ubiquitous product name changes as a substitute for functionality.  Every quarter, they let go over key people: The technical and with increasing obviousness older (expensive) staff.

Pros:
big name, lots of opportunities, good platform to learn things
co-workers are very nice and ready to help each others
cross country work experiences
agile environment 
easy internal job transfer
Cons:
company is going down, resource action everyday
too many meetings- fully booked with meetings everyday
many processes,  the company does not have a clear picture of its next move

Pros: Technology is great. They spend a lot on research and development.
Cons:
In spite of the treat technology, they rarely capitalize on it themselves. This has gone on for decades and is still happening.
