They have also started reducing spending on acquisitions and the software they currently have is starting to show signs of age.
Also, they are continuously reconfiguring the company to try to keep Wall Street happy.
Not viewed by customers as a partner anymore - just a vendor who keeps asking them for more and more money.
Pay scale for sales is not keeping up with market.

Pros: Some great colleagues, not much else.
Cons:
I'd like to point out that I can only speak for the client support center in Johannesburg I worked at, not the company culture as a whole. 
There are quite a few cons to mention. Upper management cares too little for its employees and makes sure to avoid ever entering into any kind of open discussion. Morale is chronically low with employees openly and publicly criticizing management, employee turnover is absurdly high resulting in the department constantly being understaffed and its employees overworked, while no action is taken to improve conditions or retain those employees who actually care about keeping the department afloat through hard work and initiative.

Pros:
IBM is a fantastic place to start a career.
They are flexible as they can be with vacation.
They provide a ton of resources to learn new skills or career paths.
Cons:
Your experience at IBM really depends on what project that you are on, they can be great or can be very menial work.
Opportunities for promotion are sometimes hard to get depending on what internal opportunities are available.
Pay can be average, they do better at providing other benefits.

Pros: Pretty good wages, working from home if position allows it, and IBM as a household name. A good stepping stone.
Cons: Red tape and corporate bureaucratic nonsense took over the company that I worked for after being acquired by IBM. Useless training, meetings, and IBM "family" indoctrination. The more they stuck their fingers in the pie, the worse it got.

Pros: I love the culture at IBM. Despite being a giant organization, colleagues are always eager to help each other. Of course, there are always a couple of odd ones, but very rare compared to the other companies I previously worked for. I'm also impressed by the knowledge and skills of my colleagues. I'm proud to be an IBMer. Throughout 2020, the company really tried to make everything to make us feel comfortable in our new reality, often checked on us and extended some of our benefits specifically designated to these challenging circumstances.
Cons: Can't think of any at this point. Best company I ever worked for.

Job Title: Data science and ai technical solutions specialist
Pros: Continuous learning and unbridled exposure to every thing going on in information technology, get to work with customers of all sizes across the globe, be able to find your sweet spot, locate an division or org within that would cherish that and grow your career (advantage of working for a large company)
Cons: Large behemoth - no comparison or parallel exists in IT industry. Sometimes this might be intimidating if you are not used to that!

Pros: Great management, a lot of room for growth, and tons of resources to develop new skills. I came in as an Application developer but told them I like working with DevOps, they slowly put me on more projects where I can build DevOps skills. Because it's such a huge company with so many positions, you can practically pick a job role you want and slowly move towards it.
Cons: Pay is not as competitive as application developers for other companies. Benefits are so-so. You need to work for IBM for a minimum of 3 years for them to contribute to 401k.

Pros: People are genuine and supportive of those around them. Managers are rewarded for the strength and capability of their team not just what they do. New management working hard on the change management aspect of re-inventing IBM for the future. Company is moving in the right direction
Cons: Still a sales driven but with good support. Sadly there continues to be a lot of finance interference. Finance's only contributes with "no" never any constructive advise.

Pros: 1. Vacation Time 2. Worldwide Company 3. Sick Leave
Cons:
- Nepotism
- Management does not back you
- Disorganized 
- Policy changes are normal, but changing a policy and Not telling your staff is the norm in this department. 
- You do the work of multiple departments, but don’t get paid for it.
- This department was about who you know and not what you know. So sad!

Pros:
Great colleagues to work with!
Good flexible work hours....No more pros I can list...
Cons:
Extremely less salary for the work we do!
Can not climb the ladder - no promotions
No good increments
Who works hard, they work hard always, and who leisure, management don't bother them at all!
So if you are hard worker - IBM is not a place for you, look elsewhere!!

Pros: Company name, great health insurance options
Cons: Management leaves a lot to be desired. Whoever leads your practice area will greatly influence your experience and opinion of the company. In my practice area, leadership is thoroughly disconnected from practitioners and doesn't care much about people individually (in fact he has no idea who most of the practitioners are). IBM Consulting hires really great people who do amazing work for clients, but the poor treatment/lack of respect within the company is the reason why people leave to work at other consulting firms.

Pros:
IBM works to retain employees with marketable skills and provide continuing education to maintain and add to those skills. 
We have a team focus with mutual respect and accountability that stimulates us all to be better and seek to do whatever it takes to get the job done.
IBM insists on personal integrity in all our relationships -- both business and personal.
Cons: A change in the market can cause people to quickly lose their jobs. It would be better to retain these talented people by retraining them in new technologies.

Pros:
Good base pay and benefits.
Well recognized brand with high expectations.
A strong, diversified technology and services portfolio.
Cons:
IBM is a machine ... you're assigned a serial no. and largely treated like an asset to be managed.
The firm's culture is limited to your client experience which is largely cut throat, bottom line, big blue business.
Partners manage margin and client satisfaction, everything else is secondary.
Expect 50 - 60 hour work weeks, aggressive targets, and always-on accessibility.
Professed methodologies are largely set aside when it comes down to delivering work, its a do-whatever-it-takes model to achieve deliverable milestones.

Pros: Great benefits in my opinion. Not offered now, but I have 5 weeks vacation, plus 6 additional personal days and 6 official US holidays. Coworkers are really great.
Cons: Work is long and stressful with pressing deadlines and expectations to work weekends or nights to meet these.  Endless layoffs leave you having to "read the tea leaves" to stay ahead of the next one. Morale is very low as a result.

Pros: At IBM there are lots of opportunities to grow your career. If you are an independent worker and do not need constant direction, you will love the autonomy most jobs provide. Great experience working with a variety of enterprise clients across different industries trying to solve various challenges. Co-workers and managers are great to work with.
Cons: Work life balance can be challenging, but mostly controllable by yourself. It is very easy to overcommit yourself and work more than needed. Awareness of the solutions IBM offers seems to be low, so sometimes challenging to get "the foot in the door." Some bureaucracy, so definitely helps to be able to navigate it

Pros: Good benefits and great opportunities. The company is really big so if you dont like a work location or a specific job. You can always search for new jobs around the company and move on. They are very into working remotely and that will work for some people. Also, IBM has really good health benefits, diversity resources and a really good 0% tolerance rule.  That could be good depending on the situation
Cons: Working at IBM is really good maybe the only downside is that is a really big company and you can get lost if you are trying to search for something in particular

Pros: IBM has a large global presence and can whether a downtown in the economy better than smaller companies.  Also, IBM does reward it's top contributors well.  And finally, IBM does try to be sensitive to the "work life balance".
Cons: As a big company, it's sometime hard to "stay in the loop", i.e. communication becomes more difficult as IBM has a large number of sites spread out geographically with even small teams tending to be geographically separated.

Pros: Smart colleagues, challenging and interesting work. Opportunity to travel and earn points on hotels and  airlines. Great experience, looks great on your resume. You get to work with Fortune 500 companies and learn all about the industry you are consulting in. Exposure to many different industries and business problems throughout your career. You become knowledgeable in many different areas, not just one or two. High-quality training and education opportunities.
Cons: Weekly travel can be taxing. Heavy workload and high expectations are common. Most people are worrying about the large numbers of jobs that are being shifted out of the United States.

Pros: A lot of technical opportunities. You can do software development for storage systems, servers, database, mobile devices, and etc. Not too many companies can offer this kind of variety. You can work with many talented engineers and learn from them. Big and exciting projects that you won't see in small companies.
Cons: NO work life balance. Poor senior management and unrealistic scheduling. Too many layers of senior management. I could never keep track of which VP is in charge of which VP since there are just too many VPs.

Pros: If you can keep your work-at-home job, it is great for convenience.  But be prepared for little to no financial compensation for home office expenses.  $40 a month for a phone line is it and no compensation for high-speed internet access.
Cons: Compensation - 1% increase to top performers, less down to zero for anyone else.  No Job Security.  Upper level management is dishonest in communication to employee population.  Women typically lag behind men in compensation by 10-30%.

Pros: IBM may be a good place for someone to gain some initial experience, but don't plan on staying very long.  Because no matter how good a job you do - someone, somewhere can do it for a lower cost.  Not necessarily better, but cheaper - and quarterly results are all that matter.
Cons: There's no loyalty; no job security.  There is so much emphasis on cost-cutting practices that management has been effectively "throwing the baby out with the bath water" for several years now.  It's frustrating to try to do a good job in a declining business environment surrounded by low morale.

Pros: Good salary, great brand recognition, innovation is praised and desired.  IBM has some of the best benefits I have had as a working adult but their old style retirement package has gone the way of the dodo.
Cons:
1. With many outsourcing deals, acquired human resources are thinned out to make projects profitable.  So if you did not come from IBM but were acquired, you stand a chance of loosing your job.
2. Too many layers of management.
3. Too many software tools to interface with

Pros:
Flexibility in work-life balance
Telecommuting culture
New parent time off (for both moms and dads)
Projects are generally stable and longer-running
Cons:
Very limited resources for supplies, education
No interest from management on your professional development or support
Employees are numbers - good ratings (2/2+) do not mean you are safe from layoffs

Pros: Size of the organization and breadth allows a wide range of options for meeting you customer's needs, resources available to each employee are vast,  peers are usually very knowledgeable in their disciplines.  Senior managment very capable and delivering consistent results.  Good salary and excellent benefits.
Cons: Size of the organization makes it often challenging to figure out where to get the answers you need.  IBM is very mid management heavy with many layers that often frustrate workers in the trenches.  Mid management policies are often in conflict with each other requiring one to work around things - get it done folks that cannot adapt to policy enforcement might struggle.

Pros: IBM sells most solutions. If the client needs it, good chance you can sell it. The badge and the reputation get you in to many engagements that otherwise would be out of reach. Work at home, travel policies, diversity and corporate culture are all very good.
Cons: Layers of approvals and thin staffing make actual delivery a nightmare. Just because you can sell it, doesn't not mean you may actually close the deal. If you care and are aggressive, you will feel like you have weights on your ankles.
